entry.title: Parsha Pekudei
entry.content:
Thu, Mar 7, 2019 | 31 Adar I 5779 |

Parsha Pekudei /
Sefer Shemos 38:21 - 40:38
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, Vayakhel-Pekudei 5777, Pekudei 5776, Vayakhel-Pekudei 5775, Pekudei 5774, and Vayakhel-Pekudei 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Pekudei, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the twenty-third Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.
As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Shemos, we say, "Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !)" which means, "Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!"

Shemos 39:2, Out of gold, turquoise wool, purple wool, scarlet wool and twined linen
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe expounded this verse thus, The Torah normally prohibits the mixture of wool and linen (shatnez) in clothing: one important exception is the priestly garments. There are two classic explanation of why the Torah normally prohibits the mixture of wool and linen: one is that linen represents harmful influences while wool represents positive influences; the other is that while neither wool nor linen are intrinsically harmful, their mixture is.
The first reason affirms the normal way we lead our lives: avoiding evil and doing good. From a deeper perspective, however, evil can in many cases been seen as the expression of some very high level of holiness that for some reason has suffered some tragic fall. From this perspective, linen (flax) embodies and expresses a very high level of holiness. Even from this perspective, linen should not normally be mixed with wool, since what matters is how an entity is expressed in this world, regardless of it source. But in the Tabernacle, where Divinity was revealed and everything indeed manifested its spiritual source, the mixture of wool and flax was permitted.
From here we see that the ideal is to reveal Divinity so intensely that evil ceases to exist as evil; it manifests its source in holiness and becomes our ally rather than our opponent.
Wool comes from sheep, the animal kingdom, while linen comes from plants, the plant kingdom. HaShem created a division between the two kingdoms in the mundane world, and it is the height of foolishness to think we know better. But the Holy Temple and the Tabernacle while in the mundane world, were also within the spiritual world, uniting the two. There, spiritual and mundane meet, and all the kingdoms were united. In the Tabernacle and the Holy Temple, the kingdoms of material, plants, and animal were combined by the kingdom of humanity, under the direction of HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
Wed, Feb 6, 2019 | 2 Adar I 5779 |

Parsha Terumah /
Sefer Shemos 25:1 - 27:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Terumah 5778, Terumah 5777, Terumah 5776, Terumah 5775, Terumah 5774, and Terumah 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Terumah, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the nineteenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Shemos 25:8, They must make Me a sanctuary, so that I may dwell in their midst.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe taught: Not in its midst but in their midst: G-d told us to make a sanctuary so He may dwell within us. There are three types of sanctuaries included in this commandment: the physical Tabernacle that the Jews build in the desert; the personal, inner sanctuary that each of us most construct out of our lives and our sphere of influence in the world; and finally, the world at large, which we must transform into G-d's home.
In all three cases, the task is possible only because we are simply revealing the hidden, true nature of reality. The world at large and everything in it exist only because of the Divine energy pulsing within them, so making the world into a place where Divinity is revealed is simply a matter of removing the obstructions that hide this reality. Similarly, the essence of every one of us is our Divine soul, so making our lives into a Tabernacle for G-d is nothing more than allowing our inner essence to shine through the excess material baggage we have accumulated during our journey through life.

We forget at times that the world and all within it, was and is created by HaShem in a continuous action that is beyond our understanding that began over five thousand seven hundred eighty years ago. Everything within the world was created for a reason, and that reason is to create a home for HaShem within the lowest, most mundane world. HaShem, of course, could have done this Himself, but as instructed in the Torah, gave us this task. The Tabernacle in the Torah is the model/prototype and guidelines for us to do so. And as the Rebbe pointed out above, the structure, itself, is not the goal, but a means for our task. Just as the Tabernacle had many physical parts and manual duties involved in it, so too, does our Divine mission. As the Rebbe also points out, while the Torah talks of the community act of the Tabernacle, there is also a personal mission of the Tabernacle for each of us. This may seem overwhelming, but Rebbe explains that we are not building from the down-up, but merely polishing up what already exists.

Shemos 25:31, You must make a Candelabrum
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe expounds this verse thus: We are taught that Moses did not understand all of G-d's instructions how to make the Candelabrum, so G-d showed him an image of a fiery Candelabrum. But even so, the Candelabrum was still too complicated for Moses to envision, so G-d told him to simply throw the gold into a fire and the Candelabrum would miraculously take form.
Besides the Candelabrum physical construction, what Moses found most difficult to grasp was how such a physical object spread the light of Divine consciousness to the outside world. By showing Moses the fiery Candelabrum, G-d affirmed his hesitations. He informed him that indeed, using physical objects to spread Divine awareness in the world is impossible for us do on our own. He therefore told Moses to cast the gold into the fire and that the Candelabrum would take form by itself.
Similarly, G-d requires us to transform all our material pursuits and possessions into sources of Divine light, but He also knows that we cannot do this on our own. All He asks is that we cast it all into the fire of our hearts i.e., to let our love for Him permeate all we do and He will miraculously do the rest.


As the Rebbe stated, we can apply this lesson of the Candelabrum to other parts of our lives, which seem to be too complicated and seemingly beyond us and yet, if it is for our true benefit and keeping with our Divine mission, we merely need to start the process and HaShem, Himself, will see the rest done. Of course, HaShem could have done everything, but He wishes for us to participate, even if it is as simple as taking the basic material and throwing it into the fire, the very first and most basic step for gold-smithing.

entry.content:
Thu, Jan 31, 2019 | 25 Shevat 5779 |

Parsha Mishpatim /
Sefer Shemos 21:1 - 24:18
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Adar I /
Molad for Adar I will be on Monday, February 4 at 11:57 pm and 15 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Adar I is on Tuesday and Wednesday / '
Past Posts: Mishpatim 5778, Mishpatim 5777, Mishpatim 5776, Mishpatim 5775, Mishpatim 5774, and Mishpatim 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Mishpatim, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the eighteenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Shemos 22:24, When you lend money...
It is written the Lubavitcher Rebbe remarks about this verse: The commandment to lend money applies even if the borrower owns possessions that he can theoretically sell. Thus, the commandment to lend money, unlike the commandment to give charity, is intended to benefit not only the poor but also the rich.
If, at times, we are reluctant to lend money to someone who is not poor, we should consider the possibility that in a previous lifetime, the present roles may have been reversed: we may have been the beneficiary of a loan or some other form of help from the person presently requesting a loan from us. This is our opportunity to repay his good deed.

We need to remember that there is more going on than what we, finite, beings know. Human thinking is limited. And yet, HaShem is not. HaShem ensures that we are given opportunities to grow as human beings, to better ourselves. Sometimes, unfortunately, we can miss a chance. HaShem in His mercy, can give us another, whether we recognize the event for what it is or not.

Shemos 23:19, You must not eat a young animal cooked in its mother's milk.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe comments on this verse, Cooking a young animal in its mother's milk is an act of consummate cruelty. The Torah therefore forbids us not only to cook a young animal in its mother's milk, but to cook any animal in any other animal's milk, to each such a mixture, or even to derive any other benefit from it.
We see here what extremes the Torah goes to in forbidding cruelty towards animals. The precautions the Torah takes to distance us from causing suffering to an animal demonstrates how much care we must take to avoid causing suffering to a fellow human being.


In other words, from the lesser (animals), we learn a lesson for the greater (humans). We also need to keep in mind that while HaShem places this world into our hands, we are but the guardians, and that includes the animals. We cannot ignore that the animals are creatures of HaShem and have a role to play as well.

entry.title: Parsha Yisro
entry.content:
Tue, Jan 22, 2019 | 17 Shevat 5779 |

Parsha Yisro /
Sefer Shemos 18:1 - 20:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Yisro 5778, Yisro 5777, Yisro 5775, Yisro 5774, and Yisro 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Yisro, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the seventeenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Shemos 18:22, Moses appointed leaders of thousand, of hundreds, of fifties, and of tens.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe expounds this verse: In Jethro's plan, the people would be under the authority of judges who were beneath Moses' stature. Nonetheless, G-d approved of this system, because this way even the simplest among the people would be able to solve their problems according to the Torah's legal system, thereby submitting their lives to its authority. If Moses had remained the people's sole judge, some of the people would have been too intimidated by his awe-inspiring presence and spiritual stature to approach him with their problems. This might have led these people to feel alienated, or beyond the Torah's concern.
This would have been most unfortunate, for the Torah was given to everyone, including unsophisticated, average people.
It is to the Torah's credit, and a demonstration of its truth, that its laws govern not only our most sublime moments but also to the seemingly trivial concerns that crop up in our daily affairs.

We need to recall that the Torah is the blueprint of the world and all within it. From the majestic mountains to the snowflakes. The Torah covers it all. We see this as the large, thousands or mountains, to the small, tens or snowflakes. All these appointed judges were from among the people, so that one did not have to go to strangers for their problems. The tens were like your neighbors, and the hundreds were like those of your city, and the thousands were like those of your county. These judges would also serve as examples of how one was to live.

Shemos 20:23, You must not ascend My altar on steps, so that your nakedness not be exposed over it.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe commented on this verses thus: The priests wore trousers under their tunics, so their bodies would not have been exposed to the altar even on a staircase. Nonetheless, since walking up a staircase givens the impression of exposing one's uncovered body, it is more modest to use a ramp.
If G-d requires us to respect the feelings of unfeeling stones, all the more so does He require us to respect the feelings of our fellow human beings.
The requirement to show respect to the stones of the altar teaches us to safeguard the honor of other people even when they are not aware that they are being disrespected, even when we do not mean to offend them.
Thus, this last verse of this section of the Torah sums up the message of G-d's revelation at Mount Sinai. G-d is found in even the most mundane things. Our relationship with other people are part and parcel of our relationship with G-d. And in a positive sense, loving other people is in truth loving our Creator.


Each of us is created in the image of our Creator, and have a piece of Him within us. We are His children, and He is our Father and King. The Torah is the user's manual for humanity. As the Rebbe points out, just as we should be careful when dealing with mere appearance, so how much more so when dealing with actuality?

entry.title: Parsha Beshalach
entry.content:
Tue, Jan 15, 2019 | 10 Shevat 5779 |

Parsha Beshalach /
Sefer Shemos 13:17 - 17:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Beshalach 5778, Beshalach 5777, Beshalach 5776, Beshalach 5774, and Beshalach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Beshalach, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the sixteenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Shemos 13:19, Moses took the bones of Joseph with him.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe taught on this verse, The Hebrew word for bone (etzem) also means essence. The Jewish people were about to embark on a journey through a desert whose barrenness and perils were a reflection of its spiritual desolation. In order to be able to survive this journey, Moses ensured that the Jewish people were accompanied by the essence and spirit of Joseph.
Joseph's essence is expressed in his name, which means May He add, for when he was born, his mother Rachel prayed, May G-d add for me another son. This wish includes the desire to welcome the estranged Jew back into the fold. In a more general sense, it includes the desire to transform all mundane reality into the vehicle for holiness it was originally intended to be.
The odyssey of exile is likened to a journey through a barren, perilous desert. In order for us to preserve through periods of spiritual desolation, we must take our cue from Joseph's essence. We must strive to bring even the most distant and rebellious individuals back to the fold, showing them that they are G-d's beloved children. When we remain true to this objective, we are assured that in the end, no Jew will be left behind.
The Egyptian exile and redemption that we read and study in Shemos, are the prototype of all other exiles. Just as Jewish people did not ignore the past, but built upon it, so too, do we. We need to mindful of our elders and the essence of our ancestors to help us in our personal journeys and ultimately the final redemption, may it be speedily in our days. Joseph was the first Jew placed in exile, while there, he remained steadfast to the ideals of his father and family. As he was with HaShem, so HaShem was equally with him, allowing him to rise to the position of vice-royal. Despite his success in Egypt, he always recalled that his home and heritage was within Israel.

Shemos 14:16, [G-d told Moses,] Take up your staff and raise your arm over the sea.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe points out, The splitting of the Sea of Reeds was a miraculous and supernatural event. Yet there had to be a natural action to ignite the miracle: G-d instructed the people to journey forward and Moses to lift his staff over the water. G-d always demands some human act first and only then does He perform miracles.
This is because events that occur without our involvement do not truly affect us. Only when we expend some effort do we appreciate G-d's miracle. The same applies in all areas of life. Asking for G-d's blessings is not sufficient; we must make some effort that can serve as a conduit for the blessing.

The purpose of Creation is for us to create a home for HaShem within the mundane world. HaShem could have easily does this by Himself, but choice for His own reason, to create us and set us up to partner with Him in this process. Thus, while HaShem can do everything Himself, He wishes for us to be involved. If we know, first hand, how much work goes into making a dish, we enjoy that dish more because we know the components of the dish versus the dish as a whole.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eira
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 2, 2019 | 26 Tevet 5779 |

Parsha Va'eira /
Sefer Shemos 6:2 - 9:35
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Shevat /
Molad for Shevat will be on Sunday, January 6, 2019, 11:13 AM and 14 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Shevat on Monday /
Past Posts: Va'eira 5778, Va'eira 5777, Va'eira 5776, Va'eira 5774, and Va'eira 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Va'eira, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the fourteenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Shemos 6:2-3, G-d spoke to Moses, saying to him, I am G-d, I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe expounded this verse thus, When it appears to us that something is wrong in the way G-d runs the world, G-d wants us to question Him. But at the same time, we must continue to believe absolutely in G-d's reality and goodness.
From where can we draw the power to believe in G-d so thoroughly that we virtually see Him even in the darkest moments of exile? G-d answers this question by saying, I appear to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. The patriarchs and matriarchs possessed this unshakable faith, and we inherit it from them. If we nurture it properly, we, too, will see G-d even when His goodness is not readily apparent.
This faith enables us to live out the final moments of our exile yearning for its end and demanding it! while maximizing our use of its remaining moments. In this merit, we will hasten the Messianic Redemption.
Three times in a row makes a precedent, which is why HaShem said that He appeared to all three patriarchs. It would be one thing if HaShem only appeared to Abraham, and not to Isaac and Jacob, who would have been raised with Abraham's tradition, but HaShem to appeared to Isaac and Jacob as well, saying the same thing. We believe in HaShem, because there is a history, how Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses and the entire Jewish people at Mount Sinai, saw HaShem. HaShem did not appear (directly) to Joseph and the other offsprings of Jacob, but they say HaShem's Hand first hand, and heard from their father of HaShem. When HaShem spoke to Moses, He introduced Himself expressing the existing tradition and understanding of HaShem. And Moses asked questions to expand that knowledge, as we all have.

Shemos 8:12, G-d instructed Moses to say to Aaron, Raise your staff and strike the dust of the earth, and it will turn into lice.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe explained this verse thus: The louse is a parasite; it lives off animals and people without contributing anything to their lives. It is there a metaphor for evil, since evil thrives by sucking the life force out of holiness rather than by its own merits.
Just as a louse can attach itself to a person only if his hygiene is lax, evil can only thrive when we allow our Divine consciousness to lapse, falling either into misdeeds or the apathy towards holiness that leaves us vulnerable to the enticements of materialism.
By infesting the Egyptians with lice, G-d was showing them what their indifference to Divinity made them into: parasites.

All their achievements in literature, art, architecture, science, and so on, served only to inflate their egos and enhance their material lives. As such, they were draining vitality from the forces of holiness in the world rather than aiding holiness.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 26, 2018 | 19 Tevet 5779 |

Parsha Shemos /
Sefer Shemos 1:1 - 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shemos 5778, Shemos 5777, Shemos 5776, Shemos 5775, Shemos 5774, and Shemos 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shemos, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the thirteenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Shemos 1:22, Pharaoh gave orders to all his people, You must cast every boy who is born into the Nile, but you must let every girl live.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe expounded this verse thus: By instructing his people to let every girl live, Pharaoh meant that the Jewish girls should be raised as Egyptians. He thus decreed that the boys be killed physically and the girls be killed spiritually. The decree to throw the boys into the Nile also alludes to immersing the Jews in Egyptian culture, for the Egyptians worshipped the Nile as the source of their livelihood and culture.
Egypt is the prototype of all exiles. In all exiles, the ruling culture urges us to raise our children in its ways, promising that this is the path of attain material and social success. As in Egypt, resisting these promises and ensuring that our children grow up cherishing the Torah's values is what will guarantee their material, social, and spiritual happiness, as well as their freedom from the bonds of exile.
Thus, we see the very importance of Jewish education, not to instruct on what needs to be done, but to teach the why, where, and when. We understand, we can appreciate the Torah's values and how the Torah have withstood time and many challenges.
As Mark Twain (1897) said, [...] The Egyptians, the Babylonians and the Persians rose, filled the planet with sound and splendor, then faded to dream-stuff and passed away; the Greeks and Romans followed and made a vast noise, and they were gone; other people have sprung up and held their torch high for a time but it burned out, and they sit in twilight now, and have vanished.
The Jew saw them all, survived them all, and is now what he always was, exhibiting no decadence, no infirmaties, of age, no weakening of his parts, no slowing of his energies, no dulling of his alert but aggressive mind. All things are mortal but the Jews; all other forces pass, but he remains. What is the secret of his immortality? Answer to Mark Twain's question, What is the secret of Jewish immortality is the Torah. The Torah that we have in Synagogues, homes and schools, is the very same one that Moses wrote, literally several thousands of years ago.

Shemos 5:22, Moses returned to G-d and said, G-d, why have You mistreated this people?
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe commented on this verse thus: Deep down, Moses was not questioning G-d's justice, but was just seeking to understand it. Moses and the Jewish people had inherited their faith in G-d from the patriarchs and matriarchs.
This faith was indeed very strong, but in order to be redeemed from Egypt and receive the Torah, it was not enough for their relationship with G-d to be an inheritance from their ancestors; they had to make it their own. Only when a person internalizes his faith and makes it his own can it permeate his whole being.
Ironically, the way we transform our inherited faith into our own possession is by questioning it not out of doubt or for the mere sake of questioning, but in order to truly understand it.
Thus, in response to Moses' desire to understand G-d's ways, G-d told him that the purpose of the exile was to enable the people to reach an even higher level of Divine consciousness than they could by relying on their inheritance from the patriarchs.

Jewish education is passing on what came before and transforming it into something new and personal. Education is learning why we keep the Shabbat, and seeing how the Shabbat has kept us. We explore how the Shabbat helps us in our daily lives, both as a person and as a community, and in doing so, we understand G-d better, move closer to Him and understand ourselves more.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
Thu, Dec 13, 2018 | 5 Tevet 5779 |

Parsha Vayigash /
Sefer Bereishet 44:18 - 47:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayigash 5778, Vayigash 5777, Vayigash 5776, Vayigash 5775, Vayigash 5774, and Vayigash 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayigash, which is the eleventh Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the eleventh Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Bereishet 44:18, Judah then approached [Joseph]
The Lubavitcher Rebbe tells us: Judah did not shy away from speaking hardly with Joseph; moreover, he began his appeal harshly. He knew that when someone's life is at stake, we must not be diplomatic; our listeners must sense that we are not involved because of ulterior motives, such as political or financial interests. When it is clear that the cause for which we are fighting cuts to the core of our being, it will evoke honorable and compassionate response.
Today's Benjamins, our Jewish children, are threatened by a different sort of Egypt that of assimilation. To save these Benjamins, we cannot wait for someone to appoint committees that will conduct lengthy research and then deliberate over what should be done and how much it will cost, etc. When lives are at stake, we must do whatever we can to save them, immediately.
Judah's efforts proved unexpectedly fruitful: is presumed enemy proved to be his greatest ally; and even Pharaoh himself provided the greatest possible means for securing the uncompromised continuity of Jewish tradition. So it will be when we follow Judah's example, selflessly and vigorously exerting ourselves on behalf of our children.

Our children are blessing from HaShem and our future. Like Judah, we need to be prepared to take on the Vice Royal of Egypt to defend and protect them from outside forces. But we must also teach them to protect themselves, through Jewish education and example of living a Jewish life that we set for them.

entry.title: Parsha Mikeitz
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 5, 2018 | 27 Kislev 5779 |

Parsha Mikeitz /
Sefer Bereishet 41:1 44:17
Shabbat Rosh Chodesh Tevet /
Seventh Aliya (Shabbat Chanukah/Rosh Chodesh) - Bamidbar 28:9 28:15
Maftir (Sixth Day of Chanukah) Bamidbar 7:42 7:47
Haftarah (First Shabbat of Chanukah) Zechariah 2:14 4:7
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Mikeitz 5778, Mikeitz 5777, Mikeitz 5776, Mikeitz 5775, Mikeitz 5774, and Mikeitz 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Mikeitz, which is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the tenth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Bereishet 41:51-52, Joseph named his firstborn Manasseh he named his second son Ephraim.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe teaches on this verse, Living in exile requires us to use two apparently contradictory approaches towards the world at large. One the one hand, we must be constantly on guard against harmful influences; on the other hand, we must engage the outside world in order to influence it positively.
Clearly, influencing our environment is a greater accomplishment than merely maintaining our values. Nonetheless, maintaining our values must be taken care of first, for if we forget our roots we will no longer have anything to contribute to the world.
The two sons of Joseph, born and raised in Egypt, personified these two aspects of life in exile. Joseph named his firstborn Manasseh (meaning [Exile] causes one to forget) in order not to forget his family and heritage. Joseph named his second son Ephraim (he will be fruitful) in order to emphasize that our purpose in this world is to influence it positively.
We are placed in this world to interact with it and create a home for HaShem among us. We are not meant to be hermits, to live alone in some distant place, nor are we to get lost in the crowd. How do we do this, as the Rebbe said: first, we remember we are the offsprings of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, we have the Torah, and are HaShem's children; and secondly, we share the seven Noahide laws with the world, we follow the Torah, HaShem's wisdom, and live our lives as example of what moral and conscious living is.

Bereishet 34:2, [Joseph said,] Put my goblet the silver goblet at the top of the pack of [Benjamin], the youngest one.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe tells us about this verse, Joseph knew that the Jewish people would be in exile for a long time, and that not all of them would posses the same level of Divine consciousness that enabled him to thrive in Egypt. Joseph therefore sought a way of protecting them from Egyptian depravity, ensuring that they would eventually leave Egypt and receive the Torah. Joseph realized that what they needed was a love for G-d powerful enough to overcome the materialism of Egypt.
Joseph's silver goblet alludes to this love, for the world for silver (kesef) is related to the word for yearning (kisuf). Joseph further knew that not-yet-fully-righteous people cannot spark such a love by themselves, so he implanted this love in them by implanting it within Benjamin.

The question of why the youngest, aside from Benjamin sharing the same mother as him, is that the youngest tends to be the weakest simple because of time, itself, and learning the experience that comes with age.

entry.content:
Wed, Nov 28, 2018 | 21 Kislev 5779 |

Parsha Vayeishev /
Sefer Bereishet 37:1 - 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayeishev, which is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the ninth Parshot within the entire Torah, which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Bereishet 37:18, Before [Joseph] reached [his brothers,] they conspired against him.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe teaching of this verse, Although they neither intended it nor foresaw it, the brothers' actions led to Joseph's eventual rise to power and the survival of Jacob's entire family. Jospeh's experience vividly demonstrates that whether we realize it or not, everything that happens to us is orchestrated by G-d for our benefit.
It is therefore foolish and unproductive to be angry with those who appear to be harming us. Although they may indeed be guilty for their actions, they cannot do anything to us that G-d does not will. Rather, we should learn from Joseph, who repaid his brother's evil with kindness, continuing to love them despite their hatred towards him.
As we saw with Joseph, HaShem has a plan for us, and while during the events they might see "bad," in the end everything works out. As Joseph, himself, said, it was all HaShem's plan. There might a lot of downs and a few ups, but ultimately it is for our benefit and the survival of the Jewish people. While we are not all like the Sage Nachum Ish Gamzu, who always said "Gam Zu Letovah (This too is for the best)" Nothing evil comes from Heaven. We do not why something happens, only that HaShem is Merciful, Just, and Loving-Kind in all that He does.


Bereishet 37:24, The pit was empty of water.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe informs us of this verse, saying, Allegorically, the pit represents the human mind and water represents the Torah. This incident thus tells us that the surest way to keep our mind free of snakes and scorpions negative and destructive motions is to ensure that it is always full of Torah-related content, for G-d's Torah is wholesome, restoring the soul.
Our sage say that positive thought brings positive results, and there is nothing more positive than Divine wisdom of the Torah.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 21, 2018 | 13 Kislev 5779 |

Parsha Vayishlach /
Sefer Bereishet 32:4 - 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayishlach 5778, Vayishlach 5777, Vayishlach 5776, Vayishlach 5775, Vayishlach 5774, Vayishlach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayishlach, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the eighth Parshot within the entire Torah , which is divided into fifty-four Parshot in total.

Bereishet 32:29, [The angel said to Jacob,] No longer will it be said that your name is Jacob, but Israel.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe explains this verse thus, The name Israel did not replace Jacob's original name but complemented it. It expressed a new, loftier status that he was now granted. Whereas Jacob had to struggle with Esau to secure Isaac's blessing, these blessings were not granted to Israel openly by Esau's guardian angel.
Jacob's two names represent the two ways in which we interact with the world. Sometimes the material world or our own materialistic tendencies can get in the way of our Divine consciousness or mission in life; we must then, like Jacob, struggle to reveal the Divinity that underlies the material world. At other times, the world can be used as a means to enhance Divine consciousness or fulfill our Divine mission; at such times, our challenge, like Israel, is to use these opportunities both to bring the world to a higher level of Divine consciousness and to promote our own spiritual growth.
We view Jacob as down to earth, dealing with the mundane, everyday activities within the world, and view Israel as highly spiritual, dealing with lofty spiritual meditations and prayers. Comes the Torah and reminds us that Jacob and Israel, where the same person. We can look at the world from the bottom upward, or we can view it from the top downward. Both are valid views, and but each has its place and time to be used. It was Jacob that struggled with HaShem, and it was Israel that had to live in Egypt. Such it is the existence of a Jew, we live in the mundane world and follow the spiritual path that HaShem has set for us.

Bereishet 34:1, Dinah went out to observe the girls of the region.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe teaches us that, Dinah's intention was to convince the women of Shechem to adopt the righteous ways of Jacob's family. Although it appears that she was hardly successful, her efforts were not entirely in vain. Although having the residents of Shechem circumcise themselves was partly a ruse to weaken them, their assent indicates that they agreed to be spiritually refined to a certain degree. Their circumcision refined their society somewhat, including the women. And indeed, the women and children were taken captive, most of them becoming servants in Jacob's household and thereby absorbing Jacob's values and morals.
Dinah's behavior teaches us that women who are blessed with unique talents that enable them to influence others should utilize those talents not just to build their homes and family; they should also use them to draw the hearts of their fellow women to the Torah and its ways of goodness and kindness.

As the Rebbe states, Dinah's intention were honorable, and what happened to her, tragic, and yet, in the end as the Rebbe points out, she did have an impact upon Shechem. Sometimes it can seem that we are faced with an impossible task, and even seem to fail at it. Or suffer greatly because of it. And yet, all that effort and determination is not in vain. So with that in mind, we should not be scared off an impossible task. HaShem will see that the books are balanced in the end and are good intentions bare fruit.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
Tue, Nov 13, 2018 | 6 Kislev 5779 |

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Sefer Bereishet 28:10 - 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeitzei 5778, Vayeitzei 5777, Vayeitzei 5776, Vayeitzei 5775, Vayeitzei 5774, and Vayeitzei 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayeitzei, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the seventh Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 28:20-28:21, Jacob vowed, If G-d will be with me and protect me on this journey that I am undertaking, and will provide me with bread to eat and clothing to wear, returning me to my father's house untainted.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe explains these verses thus, Bread and clothing refer allegorically to the study of Torah and to the performance of G-d's commandments, respectively. When we study the Torah, G-d's wisdom become parts of us, just as the food we eat becomes part of us. When we perform a commandment, we are enveloped by an external, transcendent feeling of inspiration, much as a garment surrounds and warms us.
In this context, returning to my father's house untainted alludes to our return to the domain of holiness after venturing out temporarily into the mundane world in order to refine and elevate it to holiness.
As I read this, I had a thought, Ya'akov Avinu vowed HaShem with me, is like bread to eat. Without food/bread, we cannot exist, nor without HaShem can we exist. Protect me is like clothing to wear, for what is clothing for, but for protection. HaShem is with us and protects us as we journey from Heaven to earth when we are born, and the journey we are undertaking is life, and we are returning to my father's house, which is HaShem's home, or heaven/presence.

Bereishet 29:1, Light of foot, Jacob set out for the land of the people who lived in the east.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe explains this verse thus, Even though Jacob was on his way to enter a spiritually dangerous environment, his joy in fulfilling his Divine mission and trust in G-d's protection permeated his entire being, down to his feet.
Following Jacob's example, we can adopt the same joyful and confident attitude when we set out to tackle life's numerous daily, mundane activities, even though they may not seem as spiritual.
The key is to make sure beforehand that, like Jacob, we are properly nourished (by studying the Torah), properly clothed (by observing G-d's commandments), and properly focused on our goal (of making the world into G-d's home).
Why does the Torah mention foot at all? Why not mention easy of mind or heart of joy?

I have thought of this a bit, and came up with this. The Sages speak of three realms; the realm of thought, the realm of speech, and the realm of action. The realm of thought exists within our minds, while the realm of speech exists within our mouths, and so, the realm of action would be hands and feet. So we know that Ya'akov Avinu studied Torah and prayed, which are of the realms of thought and speech, what of the realm of action? Ya'akov set out light of foot, or he put words to deeds. While it is important to know something in one's head, it is more important to put that knowledge/wisdom into action.

entry.title: Parsha Toldos
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 7, 2018 | 30 Cheshvan 5779 |

Parsha Toldos /
Sefer Bereishet 25:19 - 28:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Toldos 5778, Toldos 5777, Toldos 5776, Toldos 5775, Toldos 5774, and Toldos 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Toldos, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 26:12, Isaac sowed grain in that region that year. He reaped a hundredfold, for G-d had blessed him.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe having said about this verse, It is clear from a close reading of the Torah's narrative that the patriarchs were astute businessmen. Nonetheless, it is also clear that they engaged in material pursuits solely with the objective of fulfilling G-d's will. In this case, Isaac's true goal in sowing grain was to be able to give charity to the poor, which the Torah stipulates can only be performed with one's own produce. Like our patriarchs, when our involvement in the pursuit of a livelihood and wealth is similarly motivated, we are blessed with overwhelming success.
We see, here, that the patriarchs were able to take something as mundane and necessary as growing food to eat, and using it for a holy purpose. We need to remember that we work to provide for ourselves, not for the sake of work itself. And any mundane/necessary task can be elevated with a holy intention.

Bereishet 26:19, Isaac's servants dug in the valley and found a well of fresh spring water there.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe having said about this verse, Although digging wells certainly served to further the advance of civilization wherever they were dug, they more importantly exemplified Isaac's message to the world. As opposed to filling a pit with water brought from elsewhere, digging a well reveals an already-existing source of water concealed beneath layers of earth. Thus, whereas Abraham's message to the world was: Let me revive you with the refreshing water of Divine consciousness, Isaac's message was: Now that you have been revived, look for your inner source of water. Dig away all the dirt encumbering your life, and you will reveal within yourself a wellspring of Divine awareness. This awareness will quench your spiritual thirst throughout your whole life.
Isaac's well-digging teaches us that our flashes of insight or inspiration must be followed up with self-improvement and self-refinement in order for them to make lasting changes.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
Wed, Oct 17, 2018 | 9 Cheshvan 5779 |

Parsha Lech Lecha /
Sefer Bereishet 12:1 - 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Lech Lecha 5778, Lech Lecha 5777, Lech Lecha 5776, Lech Lecha 5775, and Lech Lecha 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Lech Lecha, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 12:14, When Abraham came to Egypt...
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe teaching about this verse, Instead of being allowed to pursue his monotheistic revival in G-d's Promised Land, Abraham was trust into the world's most prominent bastion of paganism. How ironic it must have seemed to witness the ambitious monotheist suddenly reduced to seeking the mercy of a cultural environment that mocked his every ideal.
Yet, in a miraculous reversal of fortune, Abraham soon had the Egyptians begging him for mercy, and shortly thereafter returned to the Land of Israel with greater wealth, with a greater reputation, and accompanied by Hagar, the Egyptian princess who would in time, become the mother of Ishmael, his first child. It thus became retroactively clear that this apparent regression was actually a further stage in Abraham's progression towards his goals.
Similarly, we must never be intimidated by the world neither by the world outside us nor by the world of personal desires, feats, or preconceived notions within us. Once we answer G-d's call to go, to yourself, we are no longer bound by the limits of our own capabilities, even apparent regressions will ultimately prove to be an integral part of the process leading to ever-higher realizations of our Divine purpose in life.

We need to remind ourselves that the world was created by HaShem, as such, it was created to allow us to fulfill His will. Society, on the other hand, is created by people, as such, it is imperfect and various from time to time, place to place. One can be like (ancient) Egyptians, or one can be like Abraham. The Egyptians only saw stone, sand and water, while Abraham realized that what is stone, sand and water is but manifestation of HaShem. Jews need not be bound by the world, rather, the world is bound to us through Torah and HaShem's mercy.

Bereishet 16:5, [G-d told Abraham,] Look toward heaven and count the stars if you can count them! That is how your descendants will be.

It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe teaching about this verse, Although the plain meaning of this statement is that the Jewish people will eventually be as numerous as the stars, its metaphorical meaning is that they will sparkle like that stars; their light is so bright that even those walking in the thick of night will not stumble. We are all Abraham's shining stars, possessing sufficient moral and spiritual fortitude to prevent those around us from stumbling and to exert a positive influence on them.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
Thu, Oct 11, 2018 | 3 Cheshvan 5779 |

Parsha Noach /
Sefer Bereishet 6:9 - 11:32
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Noach 5778, Noach 5777, Noach 5776, Noach 5775, Noach 5774, and Noach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Noach, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the second Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 6:13, G-d said to Noah, I have decided to put an end to all flesh.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe has said of this verse, G-d did not bring on the Flood because He suddenly realized that He had made a mistake by creating the world. Rather, the pre-Flood and post-Flood realities were necessary stages in the world's development, stages that are reflected to every individual's life.
Before the Flood, reality was locked into the irresistible forces of cause and effect. Every good choice reinforced goodness permanently; every bad choice reinforced evil permanently.
The Flood softened reality by introducing the opportunity of repentance. Thus, when Noah emerged from the ark, what he beheld was not a ruined, post-apocalyptic devastation, but a new, fresh world, full of promise and free from the shackles of the past.
In our own lives, too, we can mistakenly think that we are inescapably locked into a destiny dictated to us by our heredity, our upbringing, or our own prior errors. Because of the Flood, the exact opposite is true; it is never too late. G-d is always waiting to welcome us back with open arms to begin anew. Repentance, like the Flood, enables us to transform any challenging situation or turbulent phase of our lives into a means to cleanse us, refine us, and prepare us to carry on with greater faith and strength.

There are many ways HaShem could have dealt with the generation of Flood, but He chose His method with wisdom, to teach us a lesson for then and now. As the Rebbe points out, HaShem does not wish the death of even one deserving death, but rather, their return to Him. HaShem gave the generation of the Flood several warnings which they did not heed. HaShem could have easy raised a mountain above the flood levels for Noach and his family to survive, but rather, He decreed that Noach should build a boat, an ark, for him and his family to survive. Such as the ark protected Noach upon HaShem's command, so too, His Torah and His commandment's protect us, spiritually.

Bereishet 7:1, G-d said to Noah, Come into the ark.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe had this to say about the verse, Metaphorically, our personal arks are our periods of Torah study and prayer. Just as Noah and his family were protected by the ark from the flood that raged outside it, we can enter the world of Torah study and prayer in order to be protected from the flood of worldly concerns that threaten to inundate us.
It is particularly helpful to immerse ourselves in prayer first thing in the morning. When we confront the world anew each morning, it and everything in it can seem to exist self-sufficiently; as if in no need of G-d. The morning prayers help us recognize that the world could not exist on its own, and that its purpose is to be made into G-d's natural home.
Beginning our day this way helps us to consciously avoid activities that do not further this goal, taking care instead to use every moment as an opportunity to fulfill it. Thus prepared, we can engage in worldly pursuits without fear that they will turn into raging waters that overwhelm us with anxiety, stress, and distractions.

entry.title: Parsha Bereishet
entry.content:
Wed, Oct 3, 2018 | 25 Tishrei 5779 |

Parsha Bereishet /
Sefer Bereishet 1:1 - 6:8
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Cheshvan /
Molad for Cheshvan will be on Tuesday, October 9, 2018 at 9:01 PM and 11 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Cheshvan on Tuesday and Wednesday /
Past Posts: Bereishet 5778, Bereishet 5777, and Bereishet 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Bereishet, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the first Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 2:7: G-d formed the human out of the dust of the ground and blew into his nostrils a soul of life.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying about this verse, By blowing the soul into the body, G-d indicated that our soul originates deeper within Him than does the rest of creation. This emphasizes the fact that we are the primary purpose of Creation, whereas everything else is secondary.
Our Divine Soul is a spark of G-d. Therefore, the soul can never lose its intrinsic connection with G-d. Our challenge is to ensure that this connection remain manifested within our physical being.
Just as when one blows, the air can reach its destination only if there are no physical obstructions, so too, the more we free our lives from spiritual sludge harmful or negative thoughts, words, or deeds the more our G-dly souls can shine freely.
We see here the uniqueness of humanity, for we are formed via bodies of dust of the ground and animated by soul of life. The dust of the ground is literally earth, materialism, while soul is something Divine and heavenly, obviously, spiritualism. Thus, humanity has a dual origin in both earth and heaven, and a mission in both. The mission in heaven, I do not know. The mission on earth, however, is to create a dwelling place for G-d among us. That was the mission of Adam and Eve, and it is our mission. We connect the earth to heaven through our spiritual actions.

Bereishet 4:7, [G-d told Cain,] If you improve, you will be forgiven.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying of this verse, Cain's true failure was that he did not learn from G-d's positive response to Abel, who had offered up the choicest of his animals. Had Cain presented a second offering, this time from the choicest of his crop, G-d would have forgiven him and accepted it. G-d here tried to teach him that if an individual learns from his errors, his slate can be wiped clean. However, Cain refused to admit his error. Convinced of the rightness of his action, he felt that if Abel were eliminated, his own view would necessarily prevail.

Our challenge, as well, is to learn from our failures, rather than to stubbornly refuse to admit them and even rationalize them. By learning from our failures, we can transform every one of them into an impetus for further spiritual growth.

entry.title: Parsha Vayelech
entry.content:
Wed, Sep 12, 2018 | 4 Tishrei 5779 |

Parsha Vayelech /
Sefer Devarim 31:1 31:30
Shabbat Shuvah /
Haftarah: Hosea 14:2 14:10; Joel 2:11 2:27; Micah 7:18 7:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayelech 5777, Vayelech 5776, and Vayelech 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayelech, which is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the fifty-second Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shabbat Shuvah is the Shabbat During Ten Days of Repentance.

Devarim 31:6, [Moses told the people,] Neither fear nor be discouraged...for G-d, your G-d, is the one who goes with you; He will neither fail you nor forsake you.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about his verse, In both Moses' time and our own, the Jewish people witnessed how they have survived miraculously in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds. We have been how G-d is the one who goes with you; He will neither fail you nor forsake you. We must, of course, employ every natural means at our disposal to outsmart and outfight our enemies, but in the final analysis we must not deny G-d's openly miraculous assistance and protection.
This holds true on the personal level, as well, as we each fight our own battles against our inner and outer enemies. No matter how formidable our demons may seem to us, we should recall that these challenges were put in place by G-d in order to test our faith in Him. Consciously or not, they are waiting for us to resist them, and once we do, they will be transformed into our allies.
All of this will lead to the ultimate victory of good over evil, of right over wrong, and of holiness over materialism, hastening the advent of the final Redemption of all reality.
As we said in our prayers, Avinu Malkeinu (Our Father, Our King). HaShem is our Father, and looks out for His children. As the Torah says, Israel is His firstborn, whom He loves dearly. So He watches out for us and is with us in trouble and joy. We need only look at history to see how miraculous the Jewish survive is, and know that HaShem is there for us as a nation. HaShem is also there for us as individuals, doing what HaShem can for us. HaShem is the only helper we need, and we should not depend upon mortal help.

Devarim 31:17, [G-d instructed Moss to tell the Jewish people.] I will hide My face on that day.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about his verse, In this verse, the Hebrew verb for hide is intensified by a grammatical repetition. According to the Ba'al Sham Tov, this teaches us that toward the end of the exile, G-d's hiddenness will itself be hidden from us. In other words, having become accustomed to spiritual darkness, we will view it as natural.
However, we have also been taught that all of the Torah's threats are really blessings that are too intense or too sublime to be revealed to us as blessings. In this case, the double darkness of our present exile is the external manifestation of a double light that we are indeed bathed in but cannot perceive. This double light is the awareness that G-d is not only beyond anything that we can conceive, but beyond anything that we can conceive of conceiving.
This double inconceivability of G-d allows us to believe that He can extricate us from the double darkness of exile, inconceivable as it may seem to us. This awareness can inspire us to redouble our dedication to G-d and to our Divine mission.
We know that HaShem had hidden His face, as there are several that doubt the existence of HaShem, despite how impossible and inconceivable the world and universe is. That there are laws of nature/science and life is evidence of a Higher power, whom created the universe with wisdom.
That some deny this, is because of our verse, that HaShem hides His face. For in the face of HaShem, there are no falsehoods. It will be the final Redemption, when HaShem will reveal His face as He had done at Mount Sinai, and we will say, this is our G-d, the G-d of our fathers.


May we be inscribed for life, health, peace, blessings and sweet year.

entry.title: Parsha Nitzavim
entry.content:
Wed, Sep 5, 2018 | 26 Elul 5778 |

Parsha Nitzavim /
Sefer Devarim 29:9 - 30:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Tishrei /
Molad for Tishrei will be on Monday, September 10, 2018 at 8:17 AM and 10 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Tishrei on Monday and Tuesday /
Rosh HaShanah 5779 / ''
Past Posts: Nitzavim 5776, Nitzavim 5775, and Nitzavim 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Nitzavim, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the fifty-first Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 29:9-11, [Moses said to the Jewish people,] You are all standing today before G-d, your G-d, your leaders...elders...young children... in order that you enter into a covenant with G-d.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe had said about this verse, Inasmuch as the chief instrument of this covenant is the Torah, this means that every word of the Torah is relevant to every Jew, containing a lesson for even the youngest and uninitiated. Of course, every word of the Torah also contains infinitely more insights, of infinite sophistication and depth, which can only be understood by those with the requisite background. But these deeper levels of meaning are additional to the Torah's basic, simple meaning and lessons.
Thus, regardless of our background, the entire Torah is relevant to each of us in a way that we can immediately understand and appreciate. The deeper meaning of the Torah's words indeed beckon us, but we must always first and foremost seek to understand the Torah's message for us implicit in its simplest, most accessible meaning.
The words of Torah have multiple layers, like an onion. And like an onion, regardless of which layer the piece of onion came from, the taste is still the same. First and foremost, the simple and obvious meaning of the words of Torah are true, and deeper layers are also true, but are still connected to the original meaning.
The simple meaning, one of many, here, is that we are all the same before HaShem, whether we are a leader or a child. Before HaShem, even Moshe Rabbeinu was but like a child. While we each has a role among the community, family and individually; we all have equal parts in the Torah and HaShem.

Devarim 30:3, [Moses told the Jewish people,] G-d, your G-d, will bring back your exiles.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe said of this verse, This phrase may also be read, G-d, your G-d, will return together with your exiles, implying that G-d, so to speak, accompanies us into exile.
This notion may be likened to the law that stipulates that when a student commits an act of unintentional murder, requiring him to be exiled to a city of refuge, his teacher must accompany him. G-d is our teacher and we are His students, thus, when we go into exile, G-d must go into exile along with us.
This means that G-d is just as accessible to us in exile as He was before we were exiled and as He will be after the Redemption. This includes all our states of personal exile i.e., situations in which we feel estranged from holiness or apathetic to it. Even at such times, G-d is nearby; opening the lines of communication is entirely up to us.
HaShem promised to dwell among us, and so, wherever we are, HaShem is there with us. Like a Divine Father that looks at for and over His children with love and affection, checking upon them when He can. It is never HaShem that distances Himself from us, but us that distances ourselves from Him, for various reasons. HaShem does His part in trying to draw us nearer, and we just need to met Him halfway, He will do the rest. And just as the children learn from their father, so too, we learn from HaShem, for it is the ways of HaShem that we strive to emulate.

-----


May this new coming year be a year of blessing, year of health, year of good, year of life, year of joy, year of happiness, year of family, and a year where we all be in Jerusalem with the Holy Temple and HaShem revealed.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Savo
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 29, 2018 | 19 Elul 5778 |

Parsha Ki Savo /
Sefer Devarim 26:1 - 29:8
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Savo 5776, Ki Savo 5775, Ki Savo 5774, Ki Savo 5773, and Ki Savo 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Ki Savo, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the fiftieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 26:13, [Moses told the Jewish people, When you bring your first fruits to the Temple, you must declare,] 'I have also given the Levite [his due].'
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about this verse, As opposed to most offerings brought in the Temple, the first fruits were not burned on the Altar, but given to a priest to eat. Although portions of those sacrifices that were burned on the Altar were also eaten or used by the priests, the first fruits were unique in that no part of them whatsoever was burned on the Altar. The priest only placed them in front of the Altar for a short time, and they were thus considered to have been given to G-d. After this, they were enjoyed entirely by human beings.
The reason for this is that while all sacrifices expressed how we strive to become closer to G-d in some way (this being the meaning of the Hebrew word for sacrifice, korban), the first fruits chiefly expressed the attitude we are intended to have towards our involvement in the physical world. We are not meant to destroy physicality but to elevate it, so that its inherent holiness is revealed even while it retains its physical state.
The physical world exists for us to use on behalf of HaShem. HaShem gave us the instructions and building blocks to create a home for Him and us, here in the mundane world, while we are both mundane and spiritual beings. The First Fruits remind us that we are here for a reason. Fruits grow on their own, their water comes from Heaven, their food the ground and the Sun, and the farmer needs to only avoid pests, pick the fruit, and clean up. Like the fruit, HaShem does a lot for us, and asks so little. And yet, what we give, we receive so much more.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Seitzei
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 22, 2018 | 11 Elul 5778 |

Parsha Ki Seitzei /
Sefer Devarim 21:10 - 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Seitzei 5777, Ki Seitzei 5776, Ki Seitzei 5775, Ki Seitzei 5774, Ki Seitzei 5773, and Ki Seitzei 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Ki Seitzei, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-ninth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Each of these writings, I have counted as part of their file names; and this one is three hundred one.

Devarim 22:1 22:2, [Moses told the Jewish people,] You must not see your fellow's ox or sheep straying and ignore them; you must return them to your brother. If your fellow is not near you, or you do know him, you must bring [the animal] into your house, where it must remain with you until your fellow seeks it out, whereupon you must return it to him.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying about these verses, Allegorically, the missing ox or sheep alludes to elements that are lacking from our fellow's observance of G-d's commandments and/or spiritual life in general. The Torah tells us here that we must not ignore such shortcomings in our fellows: we must help them reclaim their spiritual wealth.
This is true even if your fellow is not near you, or you do know him. Even in such cases, we must help our fellows retrieve whatever spiritual wealth they have lost due to their inadvertent over-involvement in the mundane affairs of the material world.

Furthermore, if, for some reason, our fellows do not consciously value their missing spirituality enough to seek it out, we must educate them to appreciate it until your fellow seeks it out willingly.

entry.title: Parsha Shoftim
entry.content:
Thu, Aug 16, 2018 | 5 Elul 5778 |

Parsha Shoftim /
Sefer Devarim 16:18 - 21:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shoftim 5777, Shoftim 5776, Shoftim 5775, Shoftim 5774, Shoftim 5773, and Shoftim 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shoftim, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-eighth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 16:19, [Moses instructed the Jewish people to tell their judges,] You must not accept a bribe, for bribery blinds the eyes of the sage....
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about this verse, The problem with bribery is that aside from making us act immorally or irrationally, it distorts our sense of judgment, making us sincerely behave that our warped perception is indeed objective and just. The Torah therefore tells us that bribery blinds the eyes of the sage implying that even after accepting the bribe, the individual remains a sage fully capable of logical reasoning but that he has become blind to objective truth.
It follows that besides that usual form of bribery a monetary or other type of gift there also exists a subtler form of bribery: our simple awareness of ourselves. If we seek to ascertain the truth about anything, we must approach it without any sense of selfhood, for even the slightest degree of self-awareness can cause our perception to be subjective and therefore incorrect, even if only subtly.
In contrast, by cultivating true selflessness, we can be truly objective and see the unobstructed truth in all situations.

Devarim 18:13, [Moses told the Jewish people,] Be wholehearted with G-d.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about this verse, In the course of fulfilling our Divine mission in life, we can sometimes wonder if we have properly ascertained what G-d wants of us in a specific situation. After all, we are only human and we all know only too well how possible it is to be misinterpret the meaning of messages.
The answer to this concern is to be wholehearted with G-d, meaning to trust that G-d does not place us in situations that we are insufficiently equipped to handle. If from our part, we make sure to enlist G-d's help and rely on it ignoring whatever internal or external voices there may be that attempt to dissuade us Divine providence will ensure that we possess all the knowledge and other qualities necessary to navigate life's challenges.

entry.title: Parsha Re'eh
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 8, 2018 | 28 Av 5778 |

Parsha Re'eh /
Sefer Devarim 11:26 16:17
Rosh Chodesh Elul /
Maftir: Bamidbar 28:9 -- 28:15
Haftarah: Shabbat Rosh Chodesh / Isaiah 66:1 - 66:24
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Re'eh 5777, Re'eh 5776, Re'eh 5774, Re'eh 5773, and Re'eh 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Re'eh, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-seventh Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 11:26, [Moses told the Jewish people in G-d's Name,] See, I set before you today a blessing and a curse.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about this verse, G-d provides all His creatures with whatever they need to accomplish their purpose in this world. This includes both physical gifts (such as good health, prosperity, and talent) and mental gifts (such as courage, optimism, and sensitivity). However, even if G-d has designated the proper gifts for us, obstacles (such as various types of misbehavior) can sometimes prevent these Divine gifts from materializing in our lives, preventing them from descending from the realm of the potential into the realm of the actual.
In such cases, we need a blessing. A blessing does not create new Divine beneficence, it simply allows us to receive what G-d has already intended for us. Thus, when G-d tells us that He has set before us a blessing and a curse, He means that through the choices we make, we can determine then extent to which the beneficence He has stored away for us will become manifest in our lives.
Furthermore, the more we dedicate ourselves to fulfilling out Divine mission, the more means G-d provides us with in order to fulfill our goals. Thus, besides accessing what G-d has set aside for us, we can increase the Divine beneficence available to us, as well.

Would not the Architect of All know what is needed for each part of His design? As such, HaShem knows what we need and provides for us. Whether we realize it or not, actualize it or not, that help is still there. If we follow HaShem's ways, we move closer to Him and thus able to realize what is available easier.

Devarim 14:7, [Moses told the Jewish people,] But you must not eat [the following animals].
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying about this verse, G-d created everything for a purpose, and it is our task to help each component of creation fulfill its purpose. In many cases, we accomplish this by making active use of the item in question for example, by using it to fulfill some commandment. In other cases, however, we accomplish this goal passively for example, by avoiding the item in question or not using it. In those cases, we elevate the object by avoiding it.
G-d commands us not to consume non-kosher animals since they originate in the realm of spirituality tha tis beyond our ability to elevate through eating. In their case, we elevate them by fulfilling G-d's commandment to abstain from eating them.
On the other hand, these animals can be elevated directly and actively by using them for purposes other than eating. For example, when a donkey or horse transports a person to perform a commandment, it, too, is infused with holiness.
By utilizing everything in our lives for fulfilling our Divine mission, we sanctify all aspects of reality with which Divine providence has put us in contact.


There are several methods for which anything can be infused with holiness: either by eating it, thus it becomes a part of our very being; or, by using it as a part of doing something holy, thus it becomes holy by association. Both ways are valid and help us in our Divine mission.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 1, 2018 | 21 Av 5778 |

Parsha Eikev /
Sefer Devarim 7:12 - 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Elul /
Molad for Elul will be on Shabbat, August 11, 2018 at 7:33 PM and 9 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Elul on Shabbat and Sunday /
Past Posts: Eikev 5777, Eikev 5776, Eikev 5775, Eikev 5774, Eikev 5773, and Eikev 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Eikev, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 8:3, [Moses told the Jewish people, G-d has given you] a land of wheat, barley, grapevines, figs, and pomegranates; a land of oil-producing olive and [date-]honey.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying about this verse, Wheat is primarily human food, barley primarily animal food. Wheat and barley therefore represents our work with the our Divine and animal souls. Wine the product of the grape represents the joy with which we should approach this work. Since Adam and Eve's first clothes were made of fig leaves, figs represents our efforts to refine the garments of our souls, i.e., thought, speech, and action. The seed-laden pomegranate symbolizes the multitude of Divine commandments through which we refine the world around us.
Olives and dates signify the extra exertion required for our work during the exiles. Olives produce their oil only when pressed hard; date palm trees take a long time to grow. But both olives and dates produce added benefits: light from oil and honey from dates. These allude to the revelations of the inner dimensions of the Torah that will accompany the Messianic redemption.

Similarly, as each of us journeys towards our personal promised land, the great efforts we make in attaining, and spreading Divine consciousness will enlighten and sweeten our relationship with G-d and His Torah.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eschanan
entry.content:
Wed, Jul 25, 2018 | 13 Av 5778 |

Parsha Va'eschanan /
Sefer Devarim 3:23 - 7:11
Shabbat Nachamu /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Va'eschanan 5776, Va'eschanan 5775, Va'eschanan 5774, Va'eschanan 5773, and Va'eschanan 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Va'eschanan, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-fifth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

This Shabbat is Shabbat Nachamu, Shabbat of Comfort, which starts the Seven Weeks of Comfort that occur before Rosh HaShanah. Although, in truth, all Shabbats are comforting. This one reminds us that HaShem loves us and cares for us, because of what we have done, the good and the not-so-good. As it is recorded, Isaiah 40:1, Comfort, comfort My people, says your G-d[, addressing the prophets.] Isaiah 40:2, Speak to the heart, which our Sages say of, from the heart to the heart. That which is spoken from the heart travels to other's hearts (directly).

Devarim 4:41, Moses then designated three cities....

It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe has said of this version as, Allegorically, the study of the Torah is our city of refuge. This is alluded to by the fact that in order for a city to be considered a city with regard to certain aspects of Jewish law, there must be at least ten people living in it who study the Torah all day long.
The required number ten alludes to the ten powers of the soul (three intellectual, three emotional, three behavioral, and one of expression), indicating that in order for the Torah to function as a city of refuge for us, we must immerse ourselves in it fully, with all ten powers of our soul. Furthermore, the word for refuge (miklat) literally means absorption. Thus, we must not only immerse ourselves in the Torah, we must fully absorb and internalize its message.
This is how we protect ourselves from the negative spiritual influence of our materialistic environment, thereby remaining spiritually strong enough to influence the world positively.

Throughout the long millennia, HaShem has been with us, and His wisdom, which is the Torah. The Torah has sheltered us and provided guidance and insight throughout our history. We have seen the cultural changes throughout the world, and just as the Torah has not changed in three thousand years, the Jews have survived through the changes.

Devarim 6:4, [Moses thold the Jewish people,] Hear, Israel, G-d is our G-d; G-d is one.

It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe said of this verse, When we say G-d is one, we mean that the creation of the world did not change G-d in any way. He is the same after creation as He was before creation filling very moment of time and every iota of space. When we look at the world from this perspective, we no longer see trees and tables; we see only G-d.
The implication of such a worldview are sweeping. If G-d is everything, then there is no longer any possibility of self-centeredness or even self-awareness. The importance and significance we normally grant the world and the attention and devotion we normally let it command dissolve into nothingness. We can no longer be fazed by any seeming obstacle that the world seems to pose to the observation of the Torah, because we know that when we look at trees and tables, we may be seeing trees and tables, but we are really looking at G-d in the guise of trees and tables.
This awareness enables us to truly know G-d in all our ways, to transform every aspect of our lives whether sublime or mundane into an encounter with G-d.

The verse in Hebrew is ' ' . The Rebbe speaks of G-d's oneness, the last part, but helps explain the the second part, ' , as it can be explained: HaShem, His aspect of Transcendence and Mercy, is our G-d, His aspect of Nature and Justice. As HaShem is one, His aspects are One. He is both transcendent and finite, both merciful and just. Which in others can be opposite and opposing forces. But because of human limitation, we can only see one aspect of HaShem at a time. Sometimes we see nature as separate from HaShem, or some aspect removed from Him, be it a destructive force such as a hurricane or an earthquake or a gentle rain. It is all HaShem, in His infinite mercy and loving-kindness, even when we do not understand how that can be.


May the time come soonest when HaShem will be fully revealed and we will see the truth in all things.

entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
Wed, Jul 18, 2018 | 6 Av 5778 |

Parsha Devarim /
Sefer Devarim 1:1 3:22
Shabbat Chazon /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Devarim 5777, Devarim 5776, Devarim 5775, Devarim 5774, Devarim 5773, and Devarim 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Devarim, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shabbat Chazon is the Shabbat of Vision, which falls on the Shabbat that is prior to Tisha B'Av.

Devarim 1:16, [Moses told the Jewish people,] I commanded your judges at that time, saying, Hear [disputes] between your brothers...

It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying about this verse, The Hebrew word for between (bein) is related to the word for understanding (binah). Based on this, the Ba'al Shem Tov interpreted this phrase allegorically:
If you have refined your spiritual senses, then you can hear G-d articulate His great love for every Jew. You will then be between your brothers, i.e., you will understand the true, great worth of every Jew.
Thus, if you can hear, you will delight in the company of any Jew, and you will make it a point to be between your brothers to associate with them and socialized with them.
The reverse is also true.
If you want to hear, i.e., to develop your spiritual sensitivity so that you can hear G-d articulating His love for every Jew, then be between your brothers, i.e., make it a point to associate with them and socialize with them, even the simplest among them.

It is a Mitzvah in the Torah to love your fellow as yourself; how can you do this? By knowing that HaShem loves every Jew, and we should share that in that love with our brothers and sisters. How can we show this love? By socializing with them. We should never ignore a fellow Jew, regardless of their social standing or understanding.


Devarim 1:35, [G-d told Moses,] None of these men... will see the good land that I swore to give your forefathers.

It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying about this verse, Punishments are administered in order to correct the wrong committed. So why did G-d give the generation of the desert what they wanted to stay in the Divine atmosphere of the desert, protected by the clouds of glory and provided for the manna and the well of Miriam?
The answer is that their request was not really evil. It was merely based on a mistaken premise. By expressing their preference for the spiritual life of the desert, they demonstrated that they were not yet ready to deal with the physical world. Only the next generation, who would benefit from growing up in an environment of spiritual sustenance and nurturing, would be able to safely settle in the real world.
We see from this that we can gather the strength necessary to elevate and refine the world in two ways: First, by periodically devoting time to re-charging our spiritual batteries in the spiritually conductive environments of the houses of prayer and study, and secondly, by renewing our faith in G-d's supernatural assistance, which enables us to succeed even if our natural strengths are insufficient.


It is the goal of creation to create a home for HaShem here in the mundane world. We do this through: Mitzvot, Torah study and acts of loving-kindness. There are times, when it feels like the world is getting us down. Thus, HaShem created the Shabbat and the Yom Tovim, to help us re-charge. By davening with others and socializing with our fellow Jews, we can re-charge our spiritual batteries to carry us through the mundane week and the bumps on the road of life.

entry.title: Parsha Matos-Masei
entry.content:
Wed, Jul 11, 2018 | 29 Tammuz 5778 |

Parsha Matos-Masei / -
Sefer Bamidbar 30:2 - 36:13
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
