Past Posts: Matos-Masei 5777, Matos-Masei 5776, Matos 5774, Masei 5774, and Matos-Masei 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Matos-Masei, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the forty-third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.
As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, we say, "Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !)" which means, "Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!"

Bamidbar 31:3, [Moses told the Jewish people,] Carry out G-d's revenge against Midian.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, G-d sought vengeance against the Midianites because they had caused the death of thousands of Jews. But these Jews died because the Midianite women enticed them into idol worship and immoral transgression. In other words, these Jews died because they had sinned.
We see here how much G-d loves His people. He cherishes even those among us who lack the moral fortitude to resist temptation, holding accountable those who take advantage of these people. This intense love can only inspire us to love Him with a reciprocal intensity, devoting ourselves to accomplishing His purpose in the world.
Our Sages tell us that we are to hate the sin, but not the sinner, and the Torah tells that HaShem desires the return of a sinner over their justified death. So because of HaShem's love and infinite loving-kindness, HaShem is patient with us, The path of return/Tisuvan is always open for those that seek it.

Bamidbar 35:25, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people, The murderer] must remain there until the high priest dies.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, In linking the inadvertent killer specifically to the high priest, the Torah has effectively adopted the attitude of the Jewish people's very first high priest, Aaron. Aaron loved all Jews and drew them to the Torah; the Torah institutionalized this love integral aspect of the high priesthood.
This teaches us a great lesson in brotherly love and Jewish unity. No matter what heights we have reached on the ladder of spiritual or social status, we must remain concerned with all elements of society, even criminals. And even if we think that we, like the inadvertent killer, are on the lower rungs of humanity, we must remember that we are still connected with those on the highest levels, for we are all one people.
We are all our brother and sister's keepers. We are all a family, the biological and spiritual descendants of Abraham and Sarah, Yitzchak and Rivka, and Ya'akov and Rachel and Leah. We are bound in the infinite of HaShem and family.

entry.title: Parsha Pinchas
entry.content:
Wed, Jul 4, 2018 | 22 Tammuz 5778 |

Parsha Pinchas /
Sefer Bamidbar 25:10 - 30:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Menachem Av /
Molad for Menachem Av will be on Friday, July 13, 2018 at 6:49 am and 8 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Menachem Av is on Friday /
Past Posts: Pinchas 5777, Pinchas 5776, Pinchas 5774, and Pinchas 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Pinchas, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the forty-first Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 26:9, The sons of Eli'av were Nemu'eil, Dathan, and Aviram.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe said concerning this verse as saying, It would seem unnecessary for the Torah to mention Dathan and Aviram in a census whose purpose was to number those living at the time, since these individuals were already long dead. The same is true of Eir and Onan, who are also mentioned despite having died long before.
The reason the Torah does count these individuals in this census, taken in preparation for the Jewish people's entry into the Land of Israel, is to teach us that negating the faults that these people personified was necessary in order for us to enter the Promised Land and remains necessary even today.
Eir and Onan did not honor the holiness of their procreative power. We are taught that this lack of respect delays the Redemption. Dathan and Aviram rebelled against Moses's leadership. Since contesting Moses' leadership was tantamount to contesting G-d's leadership, they were not worthy of entering the Land of Israel.
From this we learn that by honoring the sanctity of our procreative energies and submitting ourselves both to G-d's will and to the leadership of His representatives on earth, we can hasten both our personal redemption and the collective Redemption of the world in general.

We are told in Bereishet 46:12, And the sons of Judah were Eir, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah. Now Eir and Onan had died in the land of Canaan; and the sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul. And here, in Bamidbar, they are mentioned again in the census of those about to enter the Promised Land. Eir and Onan's sin involved not having children (procreation), and yet, they are counted among their brethren; Shelah, Perez and Zerah. Both here in Bamidbar and Bereishet.
What is procreation/children? Our future. We, literally, have the power and responsibility to be mindful and respectful of our future, literally, in the form of our children, and figuratively, in our redemption. How can we achieve redemption? By listening to the Sages and what HaShem wants of us.

Bamidbar 27:1, The daughters of Tzelofchad came forward (to present their case to Moses.]
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe said concerning this verse as saying, Tzelofchad's daughters' desire for a portion of the Land of Israel was characteristic of all Jewish women of their generation. Due to their love of the land, none of these women sympathized with the spies' counsel against entering it.
The purpose of creation is to reveal G-d's presence in the world, which the Jewish people were meant to accomplish by entering the Land of Israel and engaging in mundane life in a holy way. This is why the Jewish women cherished the Land of Israel. They knew that the eyes of G-d are always upon it, meaning that it is uniquely suited to revealing the Divine dimension within all mundane acts.
By cherishing this ideal, Jewish women in all places can positively influence not only their own conduct bu that of their husbands, both within and outside the home. This, in turn, ensures Divine blessing in all aspects of their physical lives, as well as those of their families.

It is Heaven on Earth that is the goal of Creation. To show that HaShem is everywhere, from the highest to the lowest, from the spiritual to the mundane. How can we do this? By living a holy mundane life. By doing Mitzvot and studying Torah here in this world, a physical world, we show that HaShem is One, that there is but one G-d, both in Heaven and on Earth.

Bamidbar 27:16, [Moses said to G-d.] Let G-d... appoint a man over the congregation.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe said concerning this verse as saying, Moses knew full well that G-d would provide a leader for the Jewish people after his death. However, he was concerned that on account of the incident of the Golden Calf, G-d would decide that the people did not deserve a leader similar to him, that is, one uniquely blessed with the same qualities that he himself possessed.
Moses had also learned from the incident of the Golden Calf that G-d allows Himself to be influenced by our prayers, and even altering His plans on their account. He therefore now, as then, asked G-d to deal with the Jewish people beyond the strict measure of the law. Now, as then, G-d assented to Moses' pleas.
From this, we see both how necessary our prayers are and how powerful they are. G-d wants us to ask Him to alter His plans for our better interests.

It is said that our patriarchs and matriarchs' occupation was prayer. What is prayer, simply communicating with our Father and King, Who is both in heaven and on earth. As our Father, we, the children, need to communicate with our Father to ensure that we are well and get to know HaShem. As our King, our King wishes to know what His subjects are doing. Communication strengthens and illuminates the relationship between us. We may not be spiritually sensitive enough to understand HaShem's part of the communication of our prayers, but we should know it is there.


May all our prayers be answered directly from HaShem, Himself, in the final Redemption.

entry.title: Parsha Balak
entry.content:
Wed, Jun 27, 2018 | 14 Tammuz 5778 |

Parsha Balak /
Sefer Bamidbar 22:2 - 25:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Balak 5777, Balak 5776, Balak 5775, Balak 5774, and Balak 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Balak, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the fortieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 22:5, [Balak] sent messengers to Balaam.
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe has said on this verse: Two enemies opposed us on our journey from Egypt to the Land of Israel: Amalek and Balaam.
The ancient nations knew that G-d had delivered the Jewish people from Egypt and had promised them the Land of Israel. What emboldened these two personalities to oppose G-d's plan was their common ancestry with the Jewish people. Amalek was a grandson of Jacob's brother Esau, and Balaam was another name for Jacob's father-in-law Laban. This common ancestry made them think that they had a say in the Jewish people's destiny.
Similarly, the evils represents by Amalek and Balaam oppose our journey from spiritual slavery to spiritual freedom. Their common denominator is their haughty claim that they should have a say regarding what should be the proper Jewish attitude towards life.
We can resist their claims by asserting that the sole arbiter of Jewish life is the Torah. By cultivating humility the opposite of the haughtiness demonstrated by Amalek and Balaam we can summon the Divine strength to ensure that our attitudes remain holy and positive, free from unholy, negative influences.
All too common, anyone with the slight reason with jump in and tell us how to live our lives. Some do this because they think they are right, implying we are wrong, or that they somehow know better than the Creator of All. History has shown us what happens when life-choices are decided purely by human methods. By following the Divine wisdom that has lasted for over five thousand years, we can be assured that our attitudes will be the correct one. History has also shown the troubles that occur when we veer from that path.

Bamidbar 23:21, [Balaam said, [G-d] does not look at the evil in [the descendant of] Jacob and sees no perversity in Israel. G-d, their G-d, is with them!
It is written that the Lubavitcher Rebbe having said, Our patriarch Jacob faced many struggles during his life. G-d gave him his additional name, Israel, in acknowledgment of how he overcame these struggles.
Accordingly, the name Jacob applies to us as we struggle with mundane reality during the workweek, whereas Israel refers to us as we rise above mundane reality on the Sabbath.
When we attempt to pray during the week, we must strive to overcome the many confusing and distracting thoughts that intrude from our involvement in worldly affairs. We are only able to succeed in this struggle because G-d, their G-d is with them.
On the Sabbath, however, we do not have to expend any effort to rise above the distractions of the mundane world; all we need to do is be sensitive to the special illumination of our soul that accompanies the Sabbath. Thus, on the Sabbath, the same phrase, G-d , their G-d is with them takes on a new meaning that we attain a higher consciousness of G-d than we posses during the workweek.

HaShem is with us, day and night, workweek and Shabbat. As Jews, we are both Jacob, with our struggles with the mundane, and Israel, with our faith in HaShem and His infinite mercy. We operate in both the mundane and spirituality worlds, connected through Torah.

entry.title: Parsha Chukas
entry.content:
Wed, Jun 20, 2018 | 7 Tammuz 5778 |

Parsha Chukas /
Sefer Bamidbar 19:1 - 22:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Chukas 5777, Chukas 5776, Chukas 5774, and Chukas 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Chukas, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-ninth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 19:21, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] Anyone who [carries enough of] the sprinkling water [to] sprinkle [with becomes defiled.

It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe having said, Although the rite purifies the defiled, it also defiles the pure. Thus, the priests who administered the rite had to be prepared to become temporarily ritually defiled and thus excluded from all things holy in order to purify their fellow Jews. It was the priests' willingness to overlook their personal interest that inspired G-d to overlook the bounds of nature and logic in order to wipe away the negativity and depression that threatened the person in need of ritual purification.
To be sure, the priests knew that G-d would reward them for putting aside their own purity and troubling themselves to purify their ritually defiled brethren. But in order for the ritual to work, they could not have this in mind; their motives had to be pure and selfless.
From this example, we can learn first of all how willing we should be to help another person reenter the dominion of purity and holiness, even if doing so requires us to become temporarily sullied ourselves. Secondly, we can learn how much care we must take to ensure that our motives are pure.


We need to help those we see, for they are our family, our brothers and sisters, all descendants of our Patriarchs and Matriarchs. We need to help with positive things, such as holiness and purity, while avoiding the negative, such as sin. Family looks out for one another.

entry.title: Parsha Korach
entry.content:
Fri, Jun 15, 2018 | 2 Tammuz 5778 |

Parsha Korach /
Sefer Bamidbar 16:1 - 18:32
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Korach 5777, Korach 5776, Korach 5775, Korach 5774, and Korach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Korach, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-eighth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 16:1, Korach took... and On son of Pele.

It is written as having been said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, Korach was a member of the one of the Jewish people's most distinguished families, and also learned, wise, wealthy, and among the inner cycle of Moses' and Aaron's closest confidants. In contrast, his fellow conspirator On son of Pelet, was quite ordinary, both in terms of his intellectual capabilities and his lineage. Yet Korach came to a tragic end, dragging hundreds of other people down with him, whereas On was the only one of Korach's entire assembly who emerged completely unscathed.
The difference in the fates of these two conspirators was due to the behavior of their wives. Whereas Korach's wife encouraged him to rebel, On's wife prevented him from participating in Korach's mutiny.
This demonstrates the great responsibility of women particularly those who are wives, and especially those who are also mothers. Women should never underestimated their ability to influence their own destinies as well as those of their community, their husbands, and their families.

As Bereishet stated, woman was created to be a helpmate against man. While the Torah does speak a lot of men, there are messages to and of women as well.
This is one of them.
Here we see the power of a wife can help or hinder her husband, as which ever case is needed. Woman was created neither has a servant or a mistress, but as a helpmate, to work side by side with her husband.
The Jewish Matriarchs, Sarah, Rivka, Rachel and Leah, were as responsible as Abraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov, for the founding of the Jewish people. The Matriarchs were pillars and comforts on our nations. Without them, the Jewish people might not exist.
Whether one is Jewish or not, an important distinguishing characteristic, is dependent upon one's mother. When speaking of health and recovery, we invoke our mothers.
While the women of the Torah did not have much to say, their actions spoke much louder and carried on for generations.

Bamidbar 18:23, [G-d told Moses,] The Levites must perform the service of the Tent of Meeting.

It is written as having been said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, Korach had argued that isasmuch as all Jews are holy, there is no need to recognize any differences between them. This outlook leads to the mistaken notion that there is no need to encourage others to enhance their spiritual wellbeing or their connection to G-d, and that doing so is an insult to their intrinsic holiness.
The truth, of course, is the exact opposite: Our love for others leads us to devote ourselves to bettering their spiritual life and lot.

Out inner Korach is the temptation to ignore Moses' call to care for the spiritual needs of others in order to focus on our own spiritual self-fulfillment. Rather than listen to our inner Korach, let us respond to our inner Moses wholeheartedly. As for our own spiritual well-being, G-d assures us that if we champion His cause, devoting ourselves to our fellow human beings, He will treat us like spiritual Levites, drawing us close to Him and providing for all our needs, spiritual and material.

entry.title: Parsha Shelach
entry.content:
Wed, Jun 6, 2018 | 23 Sivan 5778 |

Parsha Shelach /
Sefer Bamidbar 13:1 - 15:41
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Tammuz /
Molad for Tammuz will be on Wednesday, June 13 at 6:05 pm and 7 Chalakim
Rosh Chodesh Tammuz is on Wednesday and Thursday /
Past Posts: Shelach 5777, Shelach 5775, Shelach 5774, and Shelach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shelach, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-seventh Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shabbat Mevarchim is the Shabbat before Rosh Chodesh. Rosh Chodesh Tammuz falls this year on Wednesday and Thursday of the coming week.

Bamidbar 13:2, [G-d told Moses,] Send one man from each tribe.

It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The intrinsic unity of the Jewish people derives from the common Divine mission we all share: to make the world into G-d's home. The Jewish people is divided into twelve tribes because there are different ways in which this one goal must be accomplished. G-d gives each of us, as individuals, specific powers and characteristics that suit the part of reality that Divine providence has charged us to transform. At the same time, however, we should pursue our individual goals in the context of our general goal as a nation.
It was in order to express our common Divine mission that G-d instructed all twelve tribal representatives to walk the length and breadth of the entire land, rather than having each representative only scout out his tribe's specific territory. At the same time, the fact that all twelve tribes were represented signified that this overall unit of purpose should permeate daily reality, in which we must emphasize our individual identities and their accompanying differences in purpose and approach.

While the Promised Land was divided into twelve parts, it still had a common name, the Land of Israel. All twelve sons, the founders of the tribes, were all the sons of a single man. Each one of the sons took on the mission of their father, as their own and went about completing that mission in their own way. Each of those twelve ways are just as valid as the other, and suited to each of sons, their children.
In Judaism, the individual, tribal affiliation and nation identity all play equal parts. No individual is greater than the whole, nor the whole over the individual.

Bamidbar 14:9, [Joshua and Caleb said to the people,] Do not fear.

It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, Since time immemorial, those who aspire to do what is right have faced opposition and even ridicule. Yet, the Code of Jewish Law begins with the instruction: Do not be embarrassed by the mockers. When G-d is with us, there is no reason for fear.
The same response applies not only to fear of others, but to fear for our spiritual well-being. Other than Joshua and Caleb, the spies were afraid that engaging in material life in the Promised Land would undermine the people's ability to lead holy lives. Since G-d is with us, aiding us in our mission to transform the physical world into His home, there is no reason to fear. We can indeed infuse Divine consciousness into all aspects of life, down to the most mundane.

Fear is a challenge that we all have to deal with, from time to time, and it can paralyze us. Fear can prevent us from growing in our spirituality and understanding.
It can feel as it the very world is against us, entire civilizations trying to destroy us; as in the past and very modern day.
So how can we overcome this fear?
By knowing that HaShem is there, protecting us and guiding us. HaShem is with us every step of the way, from before we are born, to after we have passed on from this mundane world. If we understand that everything that happens, happens in accordance with the Divine providence, we can remain calm and see the miracles that are happening before us.
Fear can blind us, but Faith can shed light and allow us to see.

entry.title: Parsha Baha'aloshecha
entry.content:
Wed, May 30, 2018 | 17 Sivan 5778 |

Parsha Baha'aloshecha /
Sefer Bamidbar 8:1 - 12:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Baha'aloshecha 5777, Baha'aloshecha 5776, and Baha'aloshecha 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Baha'aloshecha, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 8:2, [G-d told Moses,] Speak to Aaron, telling him, 'When you kindle the lamps...'

It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying, As King Solomon says, The lamp of G-d is the human soul. The flame of a candle constantly flickers upward, as if yearning to leave the wick behind and ascend heavenward. The soul shares this nature, constantly striving to reconnect with its spiritual source by breaking out of the boundaries of time and space imposed on it by the body and physical world.
At times, however, this nature becomes dormant. The soul is so blinded by its surroundings that it forgets its natural thirst for Divinity. This is why every morning after every period of spiritual darkness our soul-lamps must be re-kindled. They must be reminded of their innate desire to ascend. Whether it is our own soul or that of someone with whom we come in contact or even the soul of someone we have never met but have only heard about if we see that it is not aflame, it is our privilege and challenge to re-kindle it.

Just as it is important to ensure our own lamps are light, so too, we have the challenge to ensure that other Jews' souls are aflame as well. We should not say it is something that is beyond us, rather, a lightening a soul is its natural state that we have to nudge once in a while. We need to bring light of Torah into this world.

Bamidbar 10:29, Moses said to Chovav son of Re'u'eil...

It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe has saying, These alternate names for Jethro mean that he was the cherisher (chovav) of the Torah whose love of the Torah was derived from (the son of) his love of G-d (re'u'eil).
In searching for truth, Jethro had amassed expert knowledge of all the philosophical, spiritual, and scientific lore of his age. He eventually declared that all this knowledge must lead ultimately to the acceptance of G-d's Torah.
Because of the Giving of the Torah, G-d is not relegated to the religious facets of our existence, but can be sought and found in all life's aspects, even the most mundane. Jethro revealed this essential power of the Torah by declaring that all the world's wisdom even what we normally consider secular must be seen as part of G-d's wisdom.
We too, by studying the Torah, can reveal how G-d's essence encompasses all reality, even secular or mundane reality. This brings G-d into all aspect of life, making the world into His true home.


Just as HaShem is One, meaning HaShem is the same in both Heavenly and Earthly realms. Just as HaShem is in Heaven, so too, He is on Earth as well. Just as we do not understand Heaven, so too we do not understand HaShem on Earth. But, HaShem is everywhere, and is everything. Everything begins and ends with HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Bamidbar
entry.content:
Wed, May 16, 2018 | 3 Sivan 5778 |

Parsha Bamidbar /
Sefer Bamidbar 1:1 - 4:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bamidbar 5777, Bamidbar 5776, Bamidbar 5774, and Bamidbar 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Bamidbar, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 1:1, G-d spoke to Moses in the desert....
It is written the following was said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, The silent desolation is a metaphor for the lack of Divine revelation in creation.
The fact that the Jewish people were organized into an army while still in the desert alludes to the notion that despite the world's spiritual silence, it can indeed be taught to express the Divinity hidden within it. In this context, the enemies opposing the Jewish people's trek through the desert are the forces of negativity that we must battle in order to enable the world to reveal its inherent Divinity. The weapons we use to fight this battle are the study of Torah and the observance of G-d's commandments.
When we cultivate the barren desert, we help the world recognize its Divine source and the purpose of its creation. This, in turn, prepares it for the Messianic Redemption, when the world's innate Divinity will be clearly and fully revealed.
Any desert is not a welcoming place or a desired place, and yet, HaShem chose the desert to give the Torah and to transform the children of Israel into the nation of Israel. Here, we see the Chassidic understanding of how a negative, such as a desert, can be made into a positive, a life lesson.

Bamidbar 3:8, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people, The Levites] must keep the charge of the Israelites.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, There are two types of righteous people: One type is those who study the Torah and fulfill G-d's commandments perfectly, but do not share their spiritual wealth with others. A second type is those who devote some of the time and energy that they could have spent on striving for self-perfection to helping others.
Both paths are legitimate ways of serving G-d. However, as the Ba'al Shem Tov taught, G-d prefers that we fellow the second example, sparing neither time nor energy to ensure that we bring benefit to others.
This was the path of the tribe of Levi. They did not serve G-d on their own behalf, but as representatives of the entire Jewish people. In this way, they showed us how we can illuminate the entire world.

HaShem created the world to dwell among us, not to be by ourselves. We need to interact and learn from each other. As we treat others, so we are treated in turn.

entry.title: Parsha Behar-Bechukotai
entry.content:
Wed, May 9, 2018 | 24 Iyyar 5778 |

Parsha Behar-Bechukotai / -
Sefer Vayikra 25:1 - 27:34
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Sivan /
Molad for Sivan will be on Tuesday, May 15, 2018 at 5:21 AM and 6 Chalakim
Past Posts: Behar 5776, Bechukotai 5776, Behar 5774, Bechukotai 5774, and Behar-Bechukotai 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Behar-Bechukotai, which makes it the last Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.
As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, we say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !) which means, Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!

Vayikra 25:36, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] You must not charge interest.
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The crucial difference between interest-bearing loans (which are forbidden) and investments (which are permitted) is that interest is a reward for a past deed: the one-time act of giving a loan. In contrast, a return on an investment is a reward for the ongoing involvement that continues throughout the life of the investment.
In this sense, charging interest is fundamentally opposed to how G-d is involved in our lives. G-d does not loan us the powers that He grants us, as a one-time act; He invests them in us, remaining constantly and intimately involved in helping us reap the rewards of our efforts.
G-d behaves towards us in the same way that we behave towards our fellows. Thus, when one charges interest, G-d responds in kind: He grants him the initial potential but refrains from extending him ongoing supernatural assistance. When we forego interest on our loans, G-d also responds in kind: He not only grants us the initial potential to be successful both materially and spiritually but continues to assist us throughout our labors.
This is interesting/important as to show that HaShem wishes to have an active relationship with us. HaShem is our Creator, and could have left it at that, but HaShem desires to be a partner in our lives. HaShem is actively invested in our lives, year to year, day to day, and minute to minute. HaShem is our constant companion, there to guide and assist us as we go through life. HaShem could have been a hands-off type of deity, but that is not what Judaism is about. From birth to death, and beyond, HaShem is there with us.

Vayikra 26:14-43, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] If you do not obey Me...
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, In the Talmud, we are told that Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai sent his son, Rabbi Eleazar, to be blessed by some of the sages. They bestowed upon him what sounded like a string of curses. Only when he returned to his father did his father explain to him how these curses were really blessings in disguise.
We, too, can learn how to decipher what we experience in our own lives as G-d's curses, seeing them for what they truly are sublime but hidden blessings. Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai, who deciphered his colleagues' curses, is the author of the Zohar, the basic text of the inner dimension of the Torah. This teaches us that the study of the Torah's inner dimension trains us to perceive the inner dimension of reality in general, including the inner dimension of G-d's apparent curses.
Once we are aware that G-d's curses are really blessings, we can instinctively fulfill the sages' counsel to rejoice in suffering. By framing these curses positively, removing them from the negative light in which we originally saw them, we allow their inner goodness to be fully revealed. This, in turn, will transform them from apparent evil into revealed goodness.
The point here is that, only good comes from Heaven. If what is happening is not so obvious of the good, then there is more going on than we know or understand.
An optimist sees a glass as half-full, having more than nothing. While a pessimist sees a glass as half-empty, having lost what was before. And yet, both are looking at the same glass, it is all about attitude.

Vayikra 27:2, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] When a person articulates a vow of endowment of lives...
It is written as the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The laws of endowments (arachim) is one of those areas in which the Torah emphasizes the class equality of the Jewish people. There are indeed many times when tribal affiliation, inborn talents, or hard-earned achievements serve to differentiate us and qualify or disqualify us for certain roles. But at the same time, our differences must not be allowed to overshadow our basic equality, which is ultimately based on the fact that we all possess a Divine soul, which endows us all with infinite worth.

It is a concept from the very beginning. There was but one couple, from whom, all of humanity was born from. We all have a divine soul, a literal piece of HaShem, Himself, within us and a part of us. As Jews, we all are children of Jacob/Israel, and continue his cause, to create a dwelling place for HaShem. His twelve children continued together that mission, while having different tasks for each of the twelve tribes.

entry.title: Parsha Emor
entry.content:
Mon, Apr 30, 2018 | 16 Iyyar 5778 |

Parsha Emor /
Sefer Vayikra 21:1 - 24:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Emor 5777, Emor 5776, Emor 5775, Emor 5774, and Emor 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Emor, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-first Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 21:1, G-d told Moses, Say to the priests... say to them...
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The sages teach us that the verb to say is repeated in this verse in order to indicate that it is the priests' duty to caution their children regarding their priestly duties. The Hebrew word for to caution () also means to make shine, implying that we should not be content with training our youth to obverse G-d's commandments minimally and perfunctorily. Rather, we should teach them to perform the commandments in the best way possible, even going beyond the letter of the law. By imparting this enthusiasm to our children, we will enable them and the commandments they perform to sparkle and shine.
This lesson is emphasized by the fact that the Torah conveys it in the context of its instruction to the priests. The priests' task is to help others rise spiritually and become close to G-d. So too, we should strive to educate our youth not merely to be well-versed in the Torah and punctilious in observing its commandments, but to see their study and observance as ways to draw close to G-d.

Vayikra 21:16-17, G-d spoke to Moses, saying, Speak to Aaron, saying...
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, This section of the Torah discusses our responsibility to educate others. Since we are all responsible to educate those who need our edification or correction, the lessons in this section are relevant to all of us not only to professional educators.
Throughout this section, the Torah uses the idiom of soft speech () more than that of hard speech (). Educating through soft speech means praising the student. Praising the good in others draws out their infinite, latent positive qualities, allowing them to actualize their potential to a far extent than they could have on their own.
Of course, we must also assess other people's feelings honestly. But G-d only places people in difficult situations if He has given them the strength necessary to overcome such situations. If they fail to do so, it is because their strengths have not been allowed to become manifest and that is because we, who are responsible for educating them, have not praised them enough! Had we used our soft speech as much as we should have, we would have elicited our charges' latent potential and inner strengths.

Thus, we should all assume personal responsibility for the moral success of all those over whom we have influence.

entry.title: Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim
entry.content:
Wed, Apr 25, 2018 | 10 Iyyar 5778 |

Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim / -
Sefer Vayikra 16:1 - 20:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Acharei Mot-Kedoshim 5777, Acharei Mot 5776, Acharei Mot 5774, Kedoshim 5774, and Acharei Mot-Kedoshim 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the thirtieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 17:3, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] Anyone who slaughters an ox, lamb, or goat inside the camp or outside the camp ...
It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as, The blood and fat of animal sacrifices are burn on the Altar. Since the word for sacrifice in Hebrew (korban) means a means to draw close, this signifies that in order to come close to G-d, we must orient our delight (signified by the fat) and enthusiasm (signified by the blood) toward Him.
Practically, this means focusing our delight and enthusiasm on studying the Torah and fulfilling G-d's commandments. The natural consequences of this is that we will engage the material world without delight and enthusiasm.
This is the allegorical meaning of the Torah's insistence that we not offer up sacrifices outside the camp or even inside the camp but only at the Altar. Focusing our delight and enthusiasm outside the camp i.e., on unholy pursuits is obviously forbidden. But focusing them inside the camp i.e., on permitted pursuits but not on the Altar, i.e., on holy endeavors is likewise forbidden. We may engage in permitted pursuits as much as necessary, but our true excitement and enjoyment should be in furthering G-d's purpose in creation, making the world into His true home.
How do we know if we are inspired correctly? We check if it is kosher for it to be placed upon the Altar. HaShem created the world so that He may dwell among us. As we are in this world, so too, we need to elevate this world to meet HaShem's standards.

Vayikra 18:6, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] No one may approach any of his close relatives to 'uncover [their] nakedness.' I am G-d.
It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as, G-d forbids us to have relations both with those that are too similar to us (e.g., incest, homosexuality) and with those who are too dissimilar to us (e.g., intermarriage, bestiality).
Although G-d has forbidden such relationships, He nevertheless created us with the ability to become attracted to them. He therefore prefaced these rules with the statement I am G-d. This means two things:
Firstly, should we consider following such attractions, we should recall that G-d created the world to function in accordance with His will. Therefore, our ultimate personal and collective happiness can only be assured by following His rules.
Secondly, should we wonder why G-d implanted in us the potential to become so strongly attracted to others that it might compel us to defy Him, we should recall that He can be relied upon to reward us amply when we overcome this challenge.
Our Sages tell us that the Torah is the blueprint of the world. Thus, it is logical, if we wish to succeed in the world, we need to follow the rules of the game by which the world was created.

Vayikra 19:23, [G-d instructed Moses to tell the Jewish people,] When you enter the land and plant there any food-tree...
It is written as being said by the Lubavitcher Rebbe as, The Midrash notes that G-d's first act after creating the world was to plant the Garden of Eden, and that this verse implies that the same is expected of the Jewish people. Upon arriving in the Land of Israel, agricultural planting was to be their first endeavor.
The importance given to planting stresses the centrality position of agriculture both in civilization in general and in our personal, spiritual life. Just as trees and plants constantly bear fruit, so too, we must fulfill our Divine mission in a manner that bears fruit i.e., that affects ourselves and others in a lasting and meaningful way.

Fruit grow by through water, sun and time.

entry.title: Parsha Shemini
entry.content:
Thu, Apr 12, 2018 | 27 Nissan 5778 |

Parsha Shemini /
Sefer Vayikra 9:1 - 11:47
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Iyyar /
Molad for Iyyar will be on Sunday, April 15, 2018, 4:37 PM (5 Chalakim)
Past Posts: Shemini 5777, Shemini 5776, Shemini 5775, Shemini 5774, and Shemini 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shemini, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 9:7, [Moses told Aaron,] approach the altar.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, We are taught that there are three inherent traits of the Jewish people: bashfulness, mercifulness, and kindness. Therefore, Aaron knew that G-d chose him for his role as high priest -- and, indeed, had been preparing for it for a full week before this -- he was naturally bashful about assuming a position of greatness.
Moses therefore reminded Aaron that as praiseworthy as bashfulness is, we must overcome it when it is at odds with performing our Divine mission.
We, too, while cherishing our innate bashfulness, must not let misplaced bashfulness interfere with fulfilling our Divine mission. Our innate mercifulness and kindness towards those that need us to help them should in such cases override our innate bashfulness.

In Chapter 2 of Ethics of Our Fathers, verse 5 states, [Hillel] would also say: A boor cannot be sin-fearing, an ignoramus cannot be pious, a bashful one cannot learn, a short-tempered person cannot teach, nor does anyone who does much business grow wise. In a place where there are no men, strive to be a man. And yet, the Rebbe states it is taught that bashfulness is one of the inherent traits of the Jewish people. Rebbe also points out that we need to overcome our inherited bashfulness for our Divine mission. This includes learning Torah. We need to speak-up to ask questions when we do not understand. HaShem has goals for us to fulfill, and we need to trust that HaShem knows what He is doing, thus allowing ourselves to overcome our bashfulness with our faith and trust in HaShem.

Vayikra 10:1, [Nadav and Avihu] brought before G-d a fire that was foreign -- inasmuch as He had not commanded them (to offer it up.]
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, In his mystical vision, the prophet Ezekiel saw the living [angels] running and returning, which allegorically means that being alive entails alternately running and returning. Physically, this oscillation is manifest in our breathing and our heartbeat. Spiritually, it is manifest as our periodic alternation between world-forsaking flights of inspiration (runs) and world-affirming involvement in our Divine mission (return).
Inasmuch as the purpose of creation is to make the physical world into G-ds home, all our runs should be for the purpose of enhancing our returns. In the context, Nadav and Avihus mistake was pursuing the run for its own sake rather than as a prelude to the subsequent return
Learning from their error enables us to run for the sake of improving our returns, thereby fulfilling the purpose of creation and hastening the advent of the Redemption.
While Heaven is closer to HaShem, it is the Earth that Mitzvot and kindness happen. It the purpose of Creation to create a home for HaShem here, just as there is in the Heaven. Which means workins with what's here and elevating it. We can bring Heaven to Earth.

Vayikra 10:14, [Moses told Aaron and his sons, You must eat] the breast used as the wave-offering and the thigh used as the raised-offering.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The installation offerings were a type of peace-offering. All peace-offerings require raising and waving: the priest and the offerer must together hold specific parts of the animal and lift them, lower them, and then move them back and forth.
The vertical movements allude to our relationship with G-d: sometimes we ascend to great heights, and sometimes we suffer temporary descents or setbacks. The horizontal movements allude to our relationship with our fellow human beings: sometimes we need to draw them close to us, and sometimes we need to push them away, encouraging them to assert their independence.
The fact that both the raising and lowering movements are part of the sacrifice indicates that we can remain conscious of G-ds presence in our lives both when we are on the spiritual ascent and when we are suffering a setback.
The fact that both the back and forth movements are part of the sacrifice indicates that we must both reach this lesson to others and encourage them to develop their appreciation of it on their own.

entry.title: Parsha Tzav
entry.content:
Wed, Mar 21, 2018 | 5 Nissan 5778 |

Parsha Tzav /
Sefer Vayikra 6:1 - 8:36
Shabbat HaGadol /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tzav 5777, Tzav 5776, and Tzav 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Tzav, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-fifth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

This Shabbat is also Shabbat HaGadol, [the] Great Shabbat, which is the Shabbat just before or on first day of Pesach.

Vayikra 7:1, [G-d told Moses,] The following is the regulation of the guilty-offering.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The Torah describes the situations requiring a guilt-offering as acting unfaithfully to G-d.
Certainly committing any sin can be considered acting unfaithfully to G-d, yet the Torah makes this point specifically in the case of someone who sins against this fellow human being.
This is because it is easy to understand that transgressing a religious commandment is committing a sin against G-d. In contrast, it is easy to think that transgressing a social commandment is between us and the other person, and does not reflect upon our relationship with G-d even if we acknowledge that it was G-d who gave us these laws. The Torah therefore specifies clearly that wronging out fellow human being is equally an affront to G-d.
Therefore, when we wish to make amends for such a misdeed, it is not adequate to make restitution to the other person; we must also seek forgiveness from G-d. The ritual of the guilt-offering assures us that G-d holds open the door for repentance, allowing all our sins to be completely forgiven.
The awareness that our good standing with our fellow human beings is essential to our good standing with G-d helps us to acquire to the highest standards of social behavior.
Our Sages tells us that the love of a fellow Jew and the love of G-d are one and the same. For, if you love someone, your love includes the loves of that person as well. What those whom we care, we care what they care as well. HaShem loves us and we were made in His image, a reflection of Him.

entry.title: Parsha Vayikra
entry.content:
Wed, Mar 14, 2018 | 28 Adar 5778 |

Parsha Vayikra /
Sefer Vayikra 1:1 5:26
Shabbat HaChodesh /
Shabbat Rosh Chodesh Nissan /
Maftir: Shemos 12:1 12:20
Haftarah Shabbat HaChodesh: Ezekiel 45:18 46:15
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayikra 5777, Vayikra 5776, Vayikra 5775, Vayikra 5774, and Vayikra 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayikra, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shabbat HaChodesh is the Shabbat on or before Rosh Chodesh Nissan. As we read in the Maftir reading/portion, HaShem chose Nissan as the first of the months and the month of the Redemption from the first exile, ancient Egypt.

Vayikra 1:1. [G-d] called to Moses
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe saying, The first word of the Book of Chronicles is the name of the first human being, Adam. The alef in Adam's name is written larger than usual (), alluding to Adam's exaggerated sense of self-esteem over being the pinnacle of G-d's creation. Adam allowed what should have been healthy self-esteem to degenerate into conceit, and this caused his downfall.
Moses rectified Adam's mistake. Despite being aware of his own greatness and of the fact that G-d Himself selected him for his exalted role in human history Moses remained humble. Thus, the alef of the first word in the Book of Leviticus, [G-d] called [to Moses], is written smaller than usual (), alluding to Moses' humility.
Moses remained humble by reasoning as follows: I cannot take credit for any of my gifts or accomplishments, since they are all G-d-given. Indeed, were another person to have been given my potential, he would have accomplished much more.
We are all the spiritual heirs of both Adam and Moses. When we feel inadequate, we must remember that we are Adam, formed by G-d's own hands and fully capable of caring for His garden. But if we start to feel vain, we must recall that we are also Moses, thereby ensuring that our self-assurance does not develop into conceit.
Chassidus talks about how we should have two pieces of papers; one, should have that the world was created for me, and the other, I am but dust and ash. The trick is knowing when to use which piece of paper when.
Adam came first and oversaw the entire world. That was his merit, but he had issues. Therefore, we should recall that Moses came later, and gave the Law, to maintain and correct our world.

If Moses came first, he would be Adam, and if Adam came second, he would be Moses. The first has none to learn from, while the second has the first.

entry.title: Parsha Vayakhel-Pekudei
entry.content:
Thu, Mar 8, 2018 | 21 Adar 5778 |

Parsha Vayakhel-Pekudei / -
Sefer Shemos 38:21 - 40:38
Shabbat Parah /
Maftir: Bamidbar 19:1 19:22
Haftarah: Ezekiel 36:16 - 36:38
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Nissan /
Molad for Nissan will be on Shabbat, March 17, 2018 at 3:53 AM (4 Chalakim)
Past Posts: Vayakhel-Pekudei 5777, Pekudei 5776, Vayakhel-Pekudei 5775, Vayak'hel 5774, and Vayakhel-Pekudei 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Vayak'hel-Pekudei, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the twenty-third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot. As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Shemos, we say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !) which means, Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!

Shabbat Parah is the Shabbat [of the] Red Heifer, which we read about the mystical purification ritual as Pesach is coming. One had to be pure to participate in the Pesach offering, as we cannot perform the ritual today, we read about it in Maftir.

Shemos 36:14, [The artisan made] sheets of goat hair.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, These women understood that G-d had endowed them with a unique skill in order that they utilize this skill for holy purposes, and this is exactly what they did.
Similarly, those among us who have been blessed with special talents or skills, or who have received some unexpected Divine gift (for example, a disproportionately high return on an investment or transaction) should understand that the purpose of this gift is not that we use it for selfish purposes. Rather, we should use it to construct the Tabernacle, the home that we all construct for G-d out of our personal lives through the study of Torah, prayer, and the observance of G-d's commandments.
As our Sages say, everything belongs to HaShem. HaShem loans us the various talents and skills that we mistakenly refer to as our own. It is only proper that we should return that was given to us, and should be a benefit to our Creator.
In truth, HaShem could have done everything Himself, but He rather included our involvement. In other to do so, HaShem has provided us the means to accomplish the task at hand.

Shemos 38:25, The tally of silver from those of the community who had been counted was...
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, The material that the people donated for the construction and operation of the Tabernacle atoned for their involvement in the incident of the Golden Calf. Moses was perplexed by the notion that the soul can be redeemed from such a severe sin by a mere donation of silver. After all, the soul is spiritual, but moreover, its focus and drives are spiritually oriented. Silver, in contrast, besides being itself material, represents our lust for materiality. Since the reason the soul needs to be redeemed is because it has succumbed to materiality, how can too much materially (i.e., sin) be cured by even more materiality (i.e., donated coins)?
G-d answered Moses by showing him a coin of fire. Indeed, a cold coin, given without feeling, cannot redeem the soul. But a fiery coin, given with the Divine soul's warmth and enthusiasm for Divinity, can atone for even the greatest sin.
This lesson applies to all the commandments we perform. If we perform them with spiritual vitality and enthusiasm, they become coins of fire, atoning for our past misdeeds and binding us to G-d Himself.
It is the nature of fire/passion to reach towards the Heavens, while snow/disinterest fall from Heaven to the earth. It is the upward direction that we reach and desire, to uplift us closer to Heaven.

Shemos 40:33, [Moses] set up the Courtyard.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe as saying, Although the people fashioned the components of the Tabernacle, it was Moses who actually erected it.

Similarly, with regard to the spiritual Tabernacle that we each build for G-d out of our own lives, it is our inner Moses that actually erects it. Our inner Moses is our innate capacity to know G-d directly, despite the limitations of our human intellect. It is only by tapping this aspect of our souls and coming to know G-d in this way that we can construct a sanctuary for Him a realm within our consciousness that we can enter whenever we need to renew our awareness of Him and our oneness with Him.
