entry.title: Parsha Tetzaveh
entry.content:
Wed, Feb 21, 2018 | 6 Adar 5778 |

Parsha Tetzaveh / 
Sefer Shemos 27:20 30:10
Shabbat Zachor /
Maftir: Devarim 25:17 25:19
Haftarah: Samuel I 15:2 15:34
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tetzaveh 5777, Tetzaveh 5776, Tetzaveh 5774, and Tetzaveh 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Tetzaveh, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the twentieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shabbat Zachor is the Shabbat before Purim, during which we recall Amalek's attack on our way to Mount Sinai. Our Sages tells us that Haman (from Megillah Ester) was a descendant of Amalek.

Shemos 28:30, [G-d told Moses,] You must have them place the Urim and Tumim into the Breastplate of Judgment.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, The double name of the single parchment inserted into the Breastplate indicates the dual nature of our relationship with G-d. The word Urim (fiery lights) denotes our soul's ardent yearning to return to its Divine source and dissolve in it. The word Ttumim (sincere devotions) denotes our soul's humble submission to G-d's will and its commitment to fulfill His commandments. This devotion counterbalances the Urim-aspect of the soul, pulling it down from its ecstatic rapture in order to engage the mundane aspects of life and elevate them to Divinity.
Balancing these two complementary drives is both the challenge and the exhilaration of our spiritual life.

As there is Heaven and Earth, and only Man, alone, lives in both. Our bodies are of Earth, and our souls are of Heaven. This duality is what drives and praises Man. We are not merely souls, enclothed in a body, but a combination of soul and body, working together, for the purpose of transforming Earth into a dwelling place for the Divine.
As spiritual as we can be, our place is here on Earth, to do the Divine will. We were given bodies for a purpose. It seems that Heaven and Earth are separate, but HaShem is everywhere and the double name, mentioned above, was placed within a single compartment within the Breastplate of Judgment.

Shemos 29:14, [G-d told Moses,] You must burn the flesh of the bull.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, Normally, the meat of the sin-offering was eaten by the priests. In the case of the installation sin-offering, however, the priests were commanded to burn the meat.
The reason for this is that it is human nature to take ongoing, regular practices more seriously. In contrast, we tend to take new or temporary practices that are instituted by the rabbinic authorities of our generation less seriously. After all we tell ourselves previous generations got along fine without these practices.
It is therefore necessary to turn the matter on its head by being extra careful regarding the new or temporary additions to Jewish practice. This is why the one-time-only installation sin-offering had to be treated exceptionally.

Nowadays, in the final moments of our exile, the call of the hour is to prepare ourselves and the world at large for the coming of the Messiah. Inasmuch as this directive was not emphasized in previous generations, it is easy to undervalue it. Therefore, we must be sure to take extra care to fulfill it, dedicating to it all our enthusiasm and all our latent potentials.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
Thu, Feb 15, 2018 | 30 Shevat 5778 |

Parsha Terumah /
Sefer Shemos 25:1 - 27:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Terumah 5777, Terumah 5776, Terumah 5775, Terumah 5774, and Terumah 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Terumah, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the nineteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 25:3, [G-d told Moses,] This is the contribution that you must take from them: gold, silver, and copper.
It is written in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, Although gold surpasses silver in value, silver was the metal of choice for use as currency. The very fact that silver is not as rare as gold makes it more suited for daily purpose, and in this respect it is more important than gold. Copper, on the other hand, is even more common than silver, but it is so common that it lacks the distinction possessed by silver. (In the Torah, copper is not used as currency at all, and in societies where it is used or currency, it is typically used for coins of smaller denominations.)
Spiritually, the rarity of gold alludes to the otherworldly, transcendent element of our personalities -- our desire to rise above the natural and experience what is beyond the common. Conversely, the currency of silver alludes to our drive to draw otherworldly holiness into our common and mundane lives. The advantage of silver over gold reflects the fact that it is the silver aspect of our lives that achieves the Divine plan.

The Giving of the Torah, which only happened once in the entire history of humanity. Although the Torah attempts to describe it to us, even Divine words fail to express to truly unique impact it had. But then the point the Torah wishes to make is that the Torah is not something onto itself, but requires to be studied and practiced. We need to take the Giving of the Torah and make it a part of our everyday life. Just as the mundane days out number the holy days, so too, need to take the holy into the mundane. HaShem and His Torah could have stayed in Heaven, but that was not the Divine plan to build a dwelling place among the lowest.
It is relatively easy to be holy and spiritual when you are alone or among like-minded individually. But the trick, as it were, is to be holy and spiritual when among the masses. How can we do this? By taking the Torah with us. We take the inspiration of the holy days to carry us through the mundane days.

Shemos 25:17, [G-d told Moses,] You must have them make a Cover [for the Ark].
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The tablets housed within the Ark signify the union with G-d that we achieve by studying the Torah. The Cover of the Ark signifies G-ds grace from above, which we require in order to maintain Divine consciousness at all times -- even while uniting with Him through studying the Torah. G-d grants us this assistance in virtue of our intrinsic connection to Him, which exists independently of the connection that we forge with Him through studying the Torah and observing the commandments.
This intrinsic bond is alluded to by the fact that the word for Cover (kaporet) is related to the word for atonement (kaparah). Atonement for sin is possible only when we invoke and evoke G-ds essential love for us, which overrides the deficiencies in our relationship to Him that we cause when we disobey the Torahs instructions.
Our constant opportunity to repair and renew our relationship with G-d (represented by the Cover of the Ark) transforms our study of Torah (represented by the tablets within the Ark) from a purely intellectual pursuit to a springboard for spiritual growth.


As we are human, we are prone to making mistakes. These follies cause us to try to separate ourselves from HaShem, and only through transcendent love-kindness of HaShem for us, allows us to repair our relationship with Him. Through this repair, we use our previous follies to springboard us into higher understand and love for HaShem, reaching further than we could before, as we experience the divide between us and allow us to reach beyond it.

entry.title: Parsha Mishpatim
entry.content:
Tue, Feb 6, 2018 | 22 Shevat 5778 |

Parsha Mishpatim /
Sefer Shemos 21:1 24:18
Shabbat Shekalim /
Maftir: Shemos 30:11 30:16
Haftarah: Kings II 11:17 12:17
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Adar /
Molad for Adar will be on Thursday, February 15, 2018 at 3:09 PM (3 Chalakim)
Past Posts: Mishpatim 5777, Mishpatim 5776, Mishpatim 5775, Mishpatim 5774, and Mishpatim 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Mishpatim, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the eighteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shabbat Shekalim is the Shabbat Before Rosh Chodesh Adar. We read in the Maftir potion of the annual donation of a half a Shekel that was for a national census and the maintenance of the Holy Temple.

Shemos 21:2, If you acquire a Jewish bondman....
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, This case is quite rare, and moreover, it reflects negatively on the Jewish people, focusing our attention on the sinners among them. It is nevertheless chosen to open the Torah's presentation of civil law.
We might consider the criminal discussed in this case to be unworthy of our respect. After all, by stealing, he has clearly placed the materialistic desires of his body above the higher calling of his soul. Therefore, the Torah begins its laws specifically with this person's case, immediately informing us that even this blatant sinner must be treated with respect and compassion.
This compassionate approach to justice is the very heart of the system of Jewish civil law, whose goal is the refinement and elevation of our physical and material day-to-day lives.

Our Sages say that one who sins, the spirit of folly enters them. While it is not our true character, sin can happen when we listen too much to our animal-spirit, and not enough to our Divine-spirit. Although we may act like animal being concern with materialistic items, we do not lose our Divine-spirit. Even when we lower ourselves to sin, we are entitled to respect and compassion as we are still HaShem's children. The Torah creates a system of justice to allow for refinement and elevation of the seemingly lowly, with everyone treated the same under the Law.

Shemos 21:33, If a person opens a pit or digs a pit....
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The laws of damages are among the most comprehensible laws in the Torah, since they are seemingly based on human logic. However, G-d provides us with several reminders that this part of the Torah, too, reflects G-d's often unfathomable will. This law is one such reminder. Logically, there would seem to be no reason to differentiate between different type of damage caused by the same pit. Nevertheless, the person who dug or uncovered the pit is only liable for certain damages and not for others.
This demonstrates that even the Torah's civil laws are not just another man-made legal system that suffers from imperfections of all such systems, even the most advanced. They are G-d's will, which is by definition beyond our ability to fully comprehend.
This awareness helps us see these laws in their true light as the means G-d provides us with to refine and elevate our physical and material lives and serves to inspire us to pursue these goals enthusiastically.

Damage happens, a lot, whether by direct or indirect means. A careless word can damage friendships, a word in anger a relationship, or misunderstanding can lead to heartache. From a pure logical perspective, these damages seem inevitable and irrepairable. Comes the Torah and tells us how we can repair and even how to avoid such damage from happening.

We, humans, cannot directly see the spiritual but we affect it just the same as the material world. The Torah is our guide to the spiritual world and how to live a proper life in this world. We do not know the spiritual components of uncovering a pit or digging a pit are, for which we have the Torah.

entry.title: Parsha Yisro
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 31, 2018 | 16 Shevat 5778 |

Parsha Yisro /
Sefer Shemos 18:1 - 20:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Yisro 5777, Yisro 5775, Yisro 5774, and Yisro 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Yisro, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the seventeenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 18:12, Aaron and all the elders of Israel came to eat bread with Moses' father-in-law.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Moses himself, however, did not eat at this meal; he was busy hosting and serving his guests.
The lesson here is that regardless of our social status (and who can claim a higher social status than Moses?) we should consider it more important to take care of others' needs than to see to our own.
This applies both to other people's physical needs and to their spiritual advancement.

From whom did Moses learn this from? From Abraham Avihu, whom was staying before HaShem, Himself, and the Torah tells us, Bereishet 18:2, As soon as he saw them, he ran from the entrance of the tent to greet them Abraham Avihu left HaShem to carry out the Mitzvah of hospitality.
Our forefather and the Lawgiver shows the importance of hosting and hospitality.
We should also keep in mind, ultimately, we are all guests of HaShem, for it was He that made this world, invited us and taken care of our needs. We cannot do less than HaShem, when we can emulate Him.

Shemos 18:26, [Moses appointed judges] who would judge the people at all times.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The new insights that we constantly glean as we study the Torah constitute the on-going revelation of G-d that began at Mount Sinai. Often, the depth of our insights is so powerful that we sense that they come from someplace far beyond us which indeed they do. Because of this, we can easily fall into the trap of thinking that it is pointless to try to elicit these Divine revelations with our own effort.
To demonstrate that this not the case, G-d prefaced the account of the Giving of the Torah with the account of the judiciary system, which functions largely on human logic and reasoning. This teaches us that Divine revelation is granted to us only after we have fully exercised our human intelligence to comprehend G-d's will as it is expressed in the Torah.
HaShem does not wish us to do nothing, but rather be partners with Him in creation. In Parsha Bereishet, Rashi comments on Bereishet 2:5, with Because there was no man to work the soil, and no one recognized the benefit of rain, but when man came and understood that they were essential to the world, he prayed for them, and they fell, and the trees and the herbs sprouted Our Creator knows what we can do and not do, and sets us tasks accordingly. When our best is not enough, HaShem in His infinite mercy, is there to carry us.

Shemos 19:1, On this day they came to the Sinai desert.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, In order to receive the Torah, the Jewish people had to venture into the desolate desert, trusting that G-d would provide for them. To their credit, they did this without hesitation.
Just as our ancestors could easily have balked at the notion of following Moses into the desert, we too can easily find reasons to postpone, minimize, or even excuse ourselves altogether from studying (receiving) the Torah. Sometimes we may feel that we are discharging our obligations to G-d in other ways; at other times we may feel that we are too distracted, hungry, tired, or so on to concentrate. In such cases, we can learn from our ancestors' example that the proper approach to studying the Torah is total immersion in it, abandoning all other consideration and worries.
When we rely on G-d, studying the Torah devotedly, He will provide for all our material and spiritual needs, just as He provided for our ancestors when they relied on Him by following Him out of Egypt and into the desert.


It is HaShem that sustains and protects every being on the land, in the sea and in the air. But as said, HaShem allows us to partner with him, so we work for our food. But as HaShem provided for our ancestors in the Sinai desert, so too, He ensures that we are cared for.

entry.title: Parsha Beshalach
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 24, 2018 | 9 Shevat 5778 |

Parsha Beshalach /
Sefer Shemos 13:17 - 17:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Beshalach 5777, Beshalach 5776, Beshalach 5774, and Beshalach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Beshalach, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the sixteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 13:18, the Israelites left Egypt armed.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Although the Jews were leaving Egypt unchallenged, they took weapons with them, for their redemption was not yet complete. They would have to face other enemies in their journey to the Promised Land and conquest of it. In contrast, after the Messianic Redemption, no nations will oppose goodness and justice. Therefore, the whole world will beat their swords into ploughshares for there will be no more need for weaponry.
The same difference applies to the spiritual dynamics of the Egyptian and Messianic redemptions, respectively. At the Exodus from Egypt, evil was temporarily subjugated, but it continued to exist. It was therefore necessary for the Jewish people to be armed spiritually as well as physically -- to be on guard against evil and wary of it. This will continue to be the case until the Final Redemption. Goodness does sometimes gain the upper hand, but caution evil is always necessary. Only in the Messianic Era will G-d wipe the spirit of evil off the face of the earth, fully refining the world and transforming it into good. There will then no longer be any need for spiritual weaponry either.
In the meantime, as we continue to contend with evil, our awareness that the battle will soon be won keeps us inspired and properly directed.
As the Final Redemption has not happened yet, we still require the needs of physical and spiritual weapons; physical weapons like swords and guns, and spiritual weapons like Mitzvot and Torah study. We see this, in our days as the State of Israel requires an Army and Torah-studies to survive. There are wars we fight with HaShem's help and those that HaShem fights for us, as it has been since the Exodus and so to today.

Shemos 14:31, Israel saw and they believed in G-d.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Generally, after seeing something, we no longer need to accept it on blind faith. Why, then, after seeing G-ds deliverance, did the Jewish people still need to believe in G-d? The answer is that once they had seen the aspect of G-d that they had previously only believed in -- His ability to rescue them -- they could then upgrade their belief to believing in newer, higher aspects of G-d, which remained beyond what they had seen.
The potential upgrade our faith is infinite. Through the process of spiritual growth, we eventually come to know what we currently only believe about G-d. We then realize that there is still more to believe about G-d. In this way, we perpetually broaden the horizons of our faith and our capacity to relate to G-d on ever-higher levels.

As HaShem is infinite, there are layers upon layers of belief and faith. Each day is there is a belief in the present and the past, and a faith for tomorrow. What was tomorrow' faith is today's belief. Just as there is always a tomorrow, so too, there is more to learn and understand about HaShem. Just as yesterday's science fiction is today's science fact, so too, we have seen the unthinkable happen again and again, and yet, HaShem had been always there to ensure our survive, especially when we ourselves could not guarantee it. In many ways, the Egyptian Exile, was merely the hand of nature, it is only through the lens of Torah that we know there was more involved. That the Exodus occurred in the fashion it did, shows us that HaShem is not bound by nature or logic.

entry.title: Parsha Bo
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 17, 2018 | 2 Shevat 5778 |

Parsha Bo / 
Sefer Shemos 10:1 - 13:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bo 5777, Bo 5776, Bo 5774, and Bo 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Bo, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the fifteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 10:23, There was light for all the Israelites in their dwelling.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The Egyptians, like many ancient peoples, assumed that the opposing forces of day and night -- light and darkness -- were the manifestations of two opposing deities. G-d therefore caused darkness and light to occur simultaneously, so the Egyptians could see that nature is ruled by one, supreme power.
We, too, should realize that both the darkness and the light in our lives originate in the one and only G-d. We can then realize that the darkness is really an opportunity for us to bring more Divine light into our lives. This hastens the advent of both our own personal redemption and the Redemption of the world at large.

As we say, "Shema Israel, HaShem Elokeinu, HaShem 'ehad (Harken O' Isreal, the L-rd is our G-d, and our G-d is One." In every sense of the word 'one,' so is HaShem. There is only HaShem, and no other.
Thus, during the Egyptian Exile, HaShem demonstrated to the world that He is One, and no other.
But also in our day-to-day lives, HaShem is the Source of Everything, whether we understand it or not. Once we realize this, there is only the "good" and "what-we-do-not-currently-understand" as can be expressed by the Talmudic tales of Nahum Ish Gamzu and Rabbi Akiva.
When we trust in HaShem, there is light even in the most darken places in the world.

Shemos 12:33, The Egyptians urged the people on.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Despite the horrors of slavery, some Jews had second thoughts about leaving Egypt. G-d had to force these reluctant Jews out of Egypt by having the Egyptians urge them to depart.
Nowadays, as well, some might prefer to remain in exile rather than face what they incorrectly imagine to be the oppression of living constantly in G-ds presence -- as we all will after the Messianic Redemption. Nonetheless, G-d will redeem these people, too -- even against their will. Since G-ds mercy extends to all His creatures, He always does what is best for us on all levels, even if we do not presently realize or appreciate it.
On the other hand, if we study the Torahs teaching about the Redemption, we will truly yearn for it. Our increased, collective yearning for the Redemption will, in turn, hasten its arrival.

Those that might be tempted to remain when the Final Redemption comes will come from a sense of Stockholm Syndrome and misunderstanding of Judaism (usually because of a lack of education). It was true in ancient Egypt and it will be true with the Final Redemption. Unlike the Egyptian Redemption, the Final Redemption will be a complete redemption of both the mundane and spiritual. Where falsehoods such as Stockholm Syndrome or lack of education will not be possible, simply because of HaShem's revelation.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eira
entry.content:
Thu, Jan 11, 2018 | 25 Tevet 5778 |

Parsha Va'eira /
Sefer Shemos 6:2 - 9:35
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Shevat /
Molad for Shevat will be on Wednesday, January 17, 2018 at 2:25 am (2 Chalakim)
Past Posts: Va'eira 5777, Va'eira 5776, Va'eira 5774, and Va'eira 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Va'eira, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the fourteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 6:2, G-d spoke to Moses, saying to him, I am G-d.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, In order to impress upon Moses that He is indeed trustworthy, G-d deliberately referred to Himself in this verse by His Name Havayah. This Name indicates that G-d is beyond time and space that He is not subject to any of the limitations that operate in the physical world He created. Therefore, there is nothing that can prevent Him from keeping His word.
In fact, the reason why G-d exiled the Jewish people to Egypt although was in order to elevate our consciousness to the level signified by the Name Havayah. In Hebrew, the word Egypt (Mitzrayim) means limitations. G-d placed us within a world of seemingly inescapable limitations and then elevated us beyond it.
The exile and redemption from Egypt are thus a lesson that the Jewish people had to learn in order to become G-d's chosen nation, and they are a lesson that enables us all to rise above the empty routine of mundane life. Our personal redemption is not complete until we realize that G-d is unlimited and we learn to rely on His promise to free us from the bondage of materiality.

HaShem is infinite, and when we connect with HaShem, we touch and encounter that infinity.

By the laws of nature, the Jewish people should have disappeared being such a small nation and having been targets of super-power nations of their days. But because HaShem has chosen us, we remain, solely by HaShem's mercy and promise to our forefathers.

entry.title: Parsha Vayechi
entry.content:
Thu, Dec 28, 2017 | 11 Tevet 5778 |

Parsha Vayechi /
Sefer Bereishet 47:28 - 50:26
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayechi 5777, Vayechi 5776, Vayechi 5775, Vayechi 5774, and Vayechi 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayechi, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the twelfth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.
As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, we say, "Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !)" which means, "Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!"

Bereishet 47:28, Jacob lived 17 years in Egypt.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, When Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Lubavitch (the Tzemach Tzedek) was a young boy, he asked the following of his grandfather, Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Liadi: Granted, Jacob was happy to see how Joseph had remained faithful to Jewish values even in Egypt, the embodiment of decadence. But even so, how could the best years of Jacob's life be those that he lived in such a place?
Rabbi Shneur Zalman's answer was that Jacob had sent Judah to set up a house of learning so the family could study the Torah in Egypt. When we study the Torah, we become closer to G-d. Studying the Torah in an environment of spiritual darkness changes the darkness into light. In this way, it is indeed possible to live good years even in a decadent society like Egypt.
This answer is relevant even today. Although we are on the threshold of the final Redemption, our personal and collective world is still limited and imperfect; we still live in Egypt. But since G-d is beyond the limitations of our imperfect world, when we study the Torah and thereby connect with Him, we are immune to the negative effects of Egypt. Moreover, we can even transform the darkness of exile into light.
The Torah is HaShem's wisdom is a form that we can understand and work with. By studying the Torah, we can glimpse into HaShem, Himself, and His way. This is how Torah draws us nearer to HaShem. As HaShem is limitless, wherever we are, studying Torah, HaShem is there with us. Thus, allowing us to go beyond the physical into the spiritual.

Bereishet 49:1, Jacob summoned his sons, saying, Gather together and I will tell you what will befall you at the Ends of Days
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Jacob, like all the patriarchs and matriarchs, had surrendered his own will to G-ds. His desires therefore always reflected G-ds desires. Thus, even though G-d did not allow Jacob to reveal the date of the Redemption, Jacobs desire to do so reflected a similar desire to do so on G-ds part.
Likewise, although G-d did not reveal to us when Messiah will come, on some level He deeply wants to. And since He deeply wants to, He did in fact reveal this to us on a subconscious level. This subconscious knowledge of the date of the Redemption enables us to not take exile seriously, that is, to already live to some extent in the reality of Redemption -- free from the physical and spiritual constraints of exile, free from servitude to foreign masters, and free from our own yet unrectified selves.
By living this way, we hasten the advent of the true Redemption itself.
It is easier to fast when you have a choice, as you have food but choose for various reasons not to eat, than when you have nothing and have no choice.
Thus, it is somewhat easier to bear our exile, knowing that the Redemption is coming and a date set for it, as it we have a choice of exile, instead of being forced blindly into it.
Just as Joseph reminded his brothers (and their children) that HaShem will redeem them from the Egyptian exile, so too, our Sages and Tzedekim have reminded us

Bereishet 50:23, Joseph lived to see [his son] Ephraims great-grandchildren. Even the children of Machir son of (Josephs son) Manasseh were born between Josephs knees.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, the Biblical idiom of being born between someones knees means to be educated and mentored by that person.
According to Jewish law, a father and a grandfather are obligated to educate their children and grandchildren in the ways of the Torah. But the sages differ regarding whether a great-grandfather is obligated to educate his great-grandchild.
Nevertheless, we see from Josephs behavior that if we merit living long enough to see our great-grandchildren, we should, as Joseph did, study the Torah with them. If we are incapable of doing so, we can follow Josephs example by financially supporting their Torah education. We will thereby be contributing to their future and ensuring their greatest spiritual happiness.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 3, 2018 | 17 Tevet 5778 |

Parsha Shemos /
Sefer Shemos 1:1 - 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shemos 5777, Shemos 5776, Shemos 5775, Shemos 5774, and Shemos 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shemos, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the thirteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 1:1 1:5, There are the names of the descendants of Israel [] They numbered seventy.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The Torah first lists Jacob's descendants by name and then tell us how many there were. A name reflects an entity's unique identity in contrast to other entities in the same group. In contrast, when we count the entities in a group, we focus on their common denominator the fact that they are all members of the same group. Their individual identities disappear.
Thus, by both listing the Jewish people by name and counting them, G-d indicates that He loves them both on account of each individual's unique personality and on account of their common Jewish identity their shared, basic Jewish consciousness.
By stating this fact just before the Jews descended into the bitter exile of spiritual and physical servitude, the Torah indicates that when G-d sends the Jewish people into exile He does not love us any less; although hidden, His love for us endures.
In Bereishet, we are introduced to individuals, Adam, Noach, the Patriarchs/Matriarchs, and only then to the Tribes. In other words, from individuals to groups... And we see here, the Torah starts with names, individuals, and then count, group. There are two aspects, both important. As our Sages say, each individual has a Divine mission that only he or she can fulfill, and the Jewish people as a whole has a mission, to establish a home for HaShem in the low(est) world(s).
We are part of the whole and loved as an individual, all our mistakes, and successes.

Shemos 2:12, [Moses] struck down the Egyptian
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, At the time when he killed the taskmaster, Moses was being groomed for greatness in Pharaoh's household. He nonetheless risked his life and his comfortable and privileged royal lifestyle in order to help his kinsmen.
Similarly, we should not hesitate to risk our spiritual, social, or material comfort in order to help rescue our fellows who are suffering under spiritual or material bondage.

Our Sages point out that if you see something, Heaven is pointing it out to you to do something about it, otherwise, you would have not seen it at all.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 20, 2017 | 3 Tevet 5778 |

Parsha Vayigash /
Sefer Bereishet 44:18 - 47:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayigash 5777, Vayigash 5776, Vayigash 5775, Vayigash 5774, and Vayigash 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayigash, which is the eleventh Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the eleventh Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 44:18, Judah then approached [Joseph]
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Although he was begging Joseph for mercy, Judah was at the same time intimating to Joseph that he and his brothers were prepared, if necessary, to kill him -- as well as Pharaoh and the rest of the Egyptians -- in order to free their brother Benjamin.
Judah and his brothers were extraordinarily strong, but obviously no match for all of Egypt. In fact, the Midrash relates that at one point during this face-off, Joseph demonstrated his own might to Judah, prompting Judah to remark to his brothers, This one is stronger than me. Furthermore, Benjamins physical life was not in danger; Joseph was only threatening to separate him from Jacobs household. Yet, Judah realized that leaving Benjamin in Egypt would endanger him spiritually. Because Judah had assured Jacob that he would take personal responsibility for Benjamins safe return, he was prepared to risk his life for him, notwithstanding any rational considerations.
We learn from Judah that we must be willing to set aside rational considerations when it comes to the education and the spiritual safety of our children, for whom G-d has made us responsible.

The education of a Jewish child is vital. A child needs to know why we do what we do, and why it is important to be Jewish, especially in such a non-Jewish world most of us live in. Ignorance tends to lead to confusion and doubts, which others take advantage of.
If one does not education their children, others will be more than happy to fill that children up with their viewpoints.

Bereishet 45:7, But G-d has sent me ahead of you
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, When G-d arranged for Joseph to rule over Egypt, this included the mandate to positively influence it spiritually, as well. Therefore, in alluding to his position and ability, Joseph made it clear to his brothers that he was not acting as their emissaries, but as Gods: It was not you who sent me here, but G-d. He has made me ruler over all Egypt. (45:8)
Inasmuch as Egypt is the archetype of all exiles, Joseph was also granted the ability to positively influence reality in general, even during exile. Nowadays, this ability is vested in Josephs heirs, the spiritual leaders of each generation. When we act as their emissaries -- inspired, empowered, and guided by them -- we too possess the ability to affect the entire world positively. We do this by encouraging all humanity to embrace the seven Noahide laws as G-ds will for them conveyed in His Torah.

Those in charge are responsible for those they lead, and we lead by example.
We think we only affect our immediate surroundings, but in truth we affect our friends, family and those we meet. They in turn affect others, and they others more. A ripple effect from you to the world.
When we do positive things, Heaven helps us reach greater and greater.

Bereishet 47:23, [Joseph said to the Egyptians,] Here is seed grain for you so you can sow the ground.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Joseph gave the people seed, but they know that it was not enough to simply eat the seed; they needed to plant it, tend it, and harvest it.
The Josephs of our generation are our spiritual guides and teachers. When we receive spiritual sustenance from them -- that is, inspiration and knowledge -- we must not be satisfied simply to receive it and use it for our spiritual survival. Rather, we must plant these spiritual seeds and actualize their potential, both for our own spiritual growth and in order to inspire others.


We need to take our inspiration, use it positively and turn that seed into a tree. Our Sages tells us that the reward of a Mitzvah is other, good upon good. We build up from a single Mitzvah to many. We cannot merely stay still on our journey through life. If we do, it becomes harder to get ahead.

entry.title: Parsha Mikeitz
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 13, 2017 | 26 Kislev 5778 |

Parsha Mikeitz /
Sefer Bereishet 41:1 44:17
Maftir: Bamidbar 7:30 7:35 (4th Day of Chanukah)
Haftarah of Shabbat Chanukah: Zechariah 2:14 4:7
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Mikeitz 5777, Mikeitz 5776, Mikeitz 5775, Mikeitz 5774, and Mikeitz 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Mikeitz, which is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the tenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 41:1, After two years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Jacob was the central spiritual figure of his generation, and Joseph was the one who was able to channel Jacob's spiritual energy into the world. Therefore, the spiritual dimension of everyone's life took its cue from Joseph's. Since Joseph learned of his future through dreams, Pharaoh also learned about the future of his land through dreams.
The same is true in every generation. The spiritual dimension of the world at large takes its cue from the world's collective Joseph the Jewish people. Even forces that oppose G-dliness derive power from us, either by capitalizing on the negative energy produced by our misdeeds or by challenging us to tap potentials that would otherwise remain dormant.
When we encounter evil, we are apt to assume that it possesses its own power, and therefore be intimidated by it, or even seduced by it. Instead, we should recognize that evil is nothing more than a reflection of our own shortcomings or simple a challenge designed to elicit our dormant spiritual powers. It will then neither intimidate nor tantalize us. By rectifying our own shortcomings and rising to life's challenges, we cut off evil's supply of power, thereby bringing spiritual sustenance to the entire world.

As we say every day with the Shema, HaShem is One. There is nothing but HaShem. As HaShem is good, the truth of the matter there is only good and the lack of it. Thus, what we can see of evil, is in truth something that exists only because of a shortcoming or challenge, that requires action on our part. We also see from here that HaShem recognizes leaders, as HaShem tells Pharaoh what's going to happen to the land and it is up to Pharaoh to do something about it.

Bereishet 41:55, Pharaoh said to all Egypt, Go to Joseph; do whatever he tells you.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Although Joseph succeeded in refining Egypt somewhat by having the Egyptians circumcised, he was acting on his own initiative. Therefore, despite his good intentions, his plan backfired. By becoming more refined, Egypt was made worthier of receiving Divine beneficence, and receiving this beneficence strengthened it. Unfortunately, Egypt was not refined enough to use this power properly, eventually using it instead to persecute the Jewish people.
Similarly, we too must be careful not to overreach or compromise the Torah's rules in our efforts to do good, because no lasting good can come out of compromising the Torah's laws. The same G-d who created the world fave us the Torah. His Divine instructions for how to live in it. Only by following the Torah's rules will our efforts to help others be crowned with ultimate success.

The Torah are the words of HaShem. Just as He is eternal, so too, His words are eternal. We are mistaken to think the words of Torah are outdated or superstition, rather they are the instruction manual the Creator has provided us to understand and guide us through life, His creation.

We praise those that go beyond the letter of the law, but those that do, need to be cautious to remain within the law's spirit. Sometimes, people try too hard and miss the point. When they miss the point, things backfire upon them. The thing is, we don't know, how far off they missed, but only through hindsight and eternal wisdom, do we know they missed.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeishev
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 6, 2017 | 19 Kislev 5778 |

Parsha Vayeishev /
Sefer Bereishet 37:1 - 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeishev 5777, Vayeishev 5776, Vayeishev 5775, Vayeishev 5774, and Vayeishev 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayeishev, which is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the ninth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 37:28, [The brothers] sold Joseph for 20 pieces of silver.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The Torah considers our firstborn sons to belong to G-d, requiring us to redeem them from Him by paying 20 silver pieces (five Biblical shekels) to a descendant of Aaron, the first priest. This rule, which is still practiced today, is meant to remind us that everything we possess really belongs to G-d, and that therefore we should use all our possessions for holy ends.
In addition, the redemption price of 20 silver pieces is meant to remind us how Joseph -- Rachels firstborn -- was sold as a slave for that price. Yet despite the sale, Joseph was never truly enslaved -- for, as G-d tells us, The Israelites are My servants. On account of our inviolable bond with G-d, we can never be truly enslaved to anyone else.
The redemption price of the firstborn is thus fixed as the price for which Joseph was sold into slavery. This teaches us that both we and all we possess belong irrevocably to G-d, and can never be enslaved to any other master.
Psalms 24, 1, Of David, a song. The land and the fullness thereof are the Lord's; the world and those who dwell therein. The Earth and all within it are His, first and forever. HaShem has claimed Israel as His, and exercises that right before any other. Many have tried to claim or destroy Israel, but their plans come of naught. Every generation, there arises a foe, time and time again, and none prevail, because HaShem's claim precedes all others.
The bond among the Jews and HaShem are Mitzvot and Torah. Just as Joseph took the Torah with him into his exile, so too, have we, and as it helped him, so it has helped us.



Bereishet 38:29-30, [Judah] named him Peretz he named him Zerach.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes The name Zerach (shining alludes to the sun, which shines constantly, while the name Peretz (breaking through) alludes to the moon, whose light periodically breaks through its diminishment and disappearance.
Metaphorically, the sun represents consistently righteous people, whose Divine light shines without fluctuation. The moon represents people who have strayed from the proper path but mend their former ways and return to G-d, transforming their diminished light into increased light.
Because of their challenges, returnees reach a higher spiritual level than the consistently righteous. Thus, Peretz, who is associated with the moon and is therefore the archetype of repentance, preceded Zerach and was the firstborn.
For the same reason, Peretz is the ancestor of King David, whose inspiring Psalms express the great yearning and poetry of repentance. Through King David, Peretz is the ancestor of the Messiah, who will break through the walls of exile, ushering in the Redemption by inspiring and teaching the whole world to repent.
The Moon waxes and wanes through the month, seemingly disappearing and reappearing as times go. This is an illusion we see, as the Moon is unchanged, only the light from the Sun and the positions of the Earth and Moon make it seemed that way. So too with sin, which seems to darken our souls, but that too is illusions, as our souls are a part of HaShem. A repentant strays and returns, only because of the foolishness of the body, while the Soul remains.
It is said that we learn more from failure than success, and so the repentant learns from their mistake and grows beyond what they were before.



Bereishet 39:7, [Josephs] masters wife cast her eyes on Joseph
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Josephs masters wife had noble intentions in trying to seduce him. This incident demonstrates that beneath the surface even of circumstances that seem antagonistic to holiness there is a holy place.
Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Liadi offers the example of someone deliberately trying to disrupt us when we are immersed in prayer. In such a case, we should not allow the person to disrupt our prayers. On the contrary, we should recognize that G-d has sent this person as His messenger to stimulate us to pray with even greater concentration. The disruption person himself, like all of existence, is rooted ultimately in holiness, and is therefore motivated by a subconscious desire to serve G-d. It is only his conscious self that distorts this desire and expresses it in a form that outwardly opposes holiness.
The same principle is true with regard to all obstacles that we encounter. Rather than being discouraged by their antagonistic veneer, we should perceive their essence, i.e., that they are not obstacles to holiness but its servants.
As we say, Listen, O Israel, the Lord is our G-d, and He is One. As He is One, thus, all of Creation has but one source. Everything, the good and the seemingly bad, all come from HaShem. What may seem, at first, to be bad, if it comes from Heaven, is not truly bad, but something we cannot fully understand. Everything that comes from Heaven is good and has a reason, whether we understand that reason or not.

Just because something on the surface does not seem right, doesn't mean it is, but if we look deeper we can see the reality for what it is, a reflection of HaShem. Yes, Joseph's master's wife wished add to the Jewish people, but did not know if it was through her or her daughter, so she tried to seduce Joseph to see which way it was to be. Not the best way of going about it, but somewhat understandable.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 29, 2017 | 12 Kislev 5778 |

Parsha Vayishlach / 
Sefer Bereishet 32:4 - 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayishlach 5777, Vayishlach 5776, Vayishlach 5775, Vayishlach 5774, and Vayishlach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayishlach, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the eighth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 32:29, [The angel said,] For you have striven with [angels of] G-d and with men, and you have prevailed.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The channels through which G-d funnels his energy into the world in order to continuously create it and sustain it the spiritual forces that guide what we commonly refer to as the forces of nature -- are His entourage of angels.
Nature hides G-d's presence in the world, seeing beyond nature's facade acknowledging G-d's existence and His involvement in our lives is already a great challenge. But a still greater challenge is the toxic cynicism of those who mock our spiritual path.
Esau's guardian angel told Jacob that he had prevailed over angels and men, meaning over the angels of nature as well as the negativity of cynics. By giving us the name Israel, G-d thus assured us that both the forces of nature and human scoffers will ultimately join our efforts to lead a spiritually moral life and reveal G-d's presence in the world and bless us with success, as well.
These channels that the Rebbe writes are what we call Mazal, there is an association between the twelve channels and the zodiac/astrology. We also, as the Rebbe points out, think of these forces of nature as something besides HaShem, but they are not. The forces of nature are in fact, merely, entourage of angels, carrying out their Creator's will.
Once we understand that there is nothing but HaShem, everything falls into place and assists us in our Divine mission.
There are those that wish to be blind to the reality that everything but Fear of Heaven is in the hands of HaShem, that Nature is somehow separate from both Man and G-d. The Tower of Babel and Global Warming are but a couple of many examples of people's unwillingness to understand the bonds between Humanity and HaShem, and believe that HaShem has nothing to do with nature.
Humanity through Torah have been given the tools and knowledge how to positively affect both the mundane and spiritual world, and when we work with the Divine, we are blessed.



Bereishet 33:17, [Jacob] build himself a house and made huts for his livestock.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Allegorically, this means that Jacob made a home for his true, inner self his Divine soul and its spiritual needs but only temporary huts for his possessions and physical needs (this livestock). In other words, he made sure that his Divine soul felt at home in his daily life, but kept his material concerns outside of his focus, lest they feel too much at home and start to take over his life.
Similarly, a visitor once asked Rabbi Dovber of Mezeritch why his home was so poorly furnished. Rabbi Dovber answered by asking his visitor, Well, why don't I see any of your furniture with you? Because I am now in transit, replied the visitor, but my home is properly furnished! Rabbi Dovber then told his visitor, I, too, am just in transit through this world, and like you, I do take care to furnish my real home the next world properly.
The furnishing of the next world is our Mitzvot and Torah learning that we practice and learn here in this world. We also need to remember the words of Abraham, we are both travelers and natives of this world, and while we journey towards the next world, we need not go without. Even when we travel, we take stuff we need with us. We take the Torah with us and live in a just righteous manner.



Bereishet 36:3, [Esau married] Basemat.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Esaus wife Basemat was nicknamed Machalat (The Forgiving One) when they were married as an expression of the fact that G-d forgives a couples sins when they marry. At marriage, we commence a new phase of life and, in that sense, are born anew and are granted a clean slate.
One of the purposes of marriage is to bring new life into the world. Spiritually, positively influencing others imbues them with new spiritual life. Thus, just as G-d forgives our shortcomings when we get married, He forgives our shortcomings when we take upon ourselves to influence others positively.
The Torah specifically teaches us this lesson in the context of the wicked Esaus marriage in order to impress upon us that we should never consider ourselves unworthy of teaching the Torah to others. When we devote ourselves sincerely to this goal, we are elevated to a new spiritual level, revealing our true essence, which is indeed free of sin, and we are granted a clean slate.
From the lesser, we learn of the greater. If HaShem will do so for the wicked Esau, how much more so for the non-wicked?
Blessings upon blessings, spirituality upon spirituality, it builds. Freed from the past, we are unchained to grow, gaining new heights.

We follow the ways of our ancestors in holy marriage, we are blessed with children, whom we teach the Torah to, they grow with the Torah, and live spiritual lives as we do. Proverbs 3:18, [Torah] She is a tree of life for those who hold fast to her, and happy are those who support her. And Torah has kept us together and a people over the many millennia we have faced.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
Tue, Nov 21, 2017 | 4 Kislev 5778 |

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Sefer Bereishet 28:10 - 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeitzei 5777, Vayeitzei 5776, Vayeitzei 5775, Vayeitzei 5774, and Vayeitzei 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayeitzei, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the seventh Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 31:16, Only the wealth ( ). Rashi comments, This is used with the meaning but; in other words: of our father's [property] we have nothing, but only that which the Holy One, Source of Blessing, has taken away from our father belongs to us.
The Torah records that Rachel and Le'ah said this of their father, Lavan. They were referring to how their father had failed to support them.
There is a lesson there that a father needs to take care of his daughters as well as sons. There is also the lesson that ultimately everything belongs to HaShem, and it is He that gives us what we have.

Bereishet 31:19, and Rachel stole the teraphim. Rashi states, Her intention was to separate her father from idol-worship.
Although, Rachel's intention was good, she would still buy a price for her action, as she died on the way back to the Land of Israel.

Bereishet 31:24, neither good nor evil, Rashi tells us, [for even] all good that wicked people [do] is evil for righteous people.

For when a person does anything, they insert themselves into it, thus, the good that a sinner does, will have some elements of sin within it, which taints the action with their sin.

entry.title: Parsha Toldos
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 15, 2017 | 27 Cheshvan 5778 |

Parsha Toldos /
Sefer Bereishet 25:19 - 28:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Kislev /
Molad for Kislev will be on Sunday, November 19, 2017 at 12:57 AM
Past Posts: Toldos 5777, Toldos 5776, Toldos 5775, Toldos 5774, and Toldos 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Toldos, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 26:18, [Isaac redug the wells] that the Philistines had blocked up after Abraham's death.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Allegorically, the Philistines represent uncontrolled materialism, and the wells that Abraham and Isaac dug represent our inner wellspring of goodness. Abraham was not really a well digger: although he did inspire others, this inspiration was not enough to uncover their inner wellsprings of goodness, which would have improved their characters permanently. Therefore, the Philistines were able to block up Abraham's wells.
In contrast, Isaac's holy charisma forced people to confront their psychological obstacles to living a Divine life. He changed them by making them uncover their own hidden goodness. Therefore, the Philistines could not block up his wells.
Similarly, by praying and meditating, we clear away the mental dirt that has blocked up our wellsprings of inspiration. But if we revel in our inspiration rather than focusing on correcting a particular character flow, our wellsprings can become blocked again by our ingrained obsession for material satisfaction, once we re-enter the world of our mundane affairs.
In contrast, when we focus on improving a specific character trait while praying, we change ourselves, enabling us to retain our inspiration.

One digs a well, solely to find water. Water that had been there all long but requires effort to obtain it. There is goodness in everyone, we just need to take some effort to find it. Sometimes the water is close to the surface, while others, the water is very deep. So it is not a question of if there is goodness in a person, but rather, what does a person do with that goodness? Do they bury it under the dirt of materialism, or do they use that goodness to hydrate themselves? This world is a world of action, we cannot just stay in one spot forever. We move, but then stop, and forgot to move again. We need to know that that wellspring of goodness always exists within us and that we need to maintain it.

Bereishet 27:1, When Isaac was old, his eyesight went dim.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Instead of waiting for Isaac to become blind so Rebecca could maneuver him into blessing Jacob instead of Esau, G-d could have simply revealed Esau's wickedness and unworthiness to Isaac. G-d would not have been divulging anything to Isaac that he did not already suspect. Isaac already knew that Esau's wives were idolaters and that he paid G-d so little notice that he hardly ever mentioned him. Yet G-d was reluctant to speak ill of Esau.
Similarly, many years later, G-d refused to divulge to Joshua the identity of the person who had stolen some of the spoils that had been dedicated to G-d after the conquest of Jericho. This lone individual's embezzlement had caused G-d's protection to be removed from the entire Jewish army, exposing them to defeat. Yet when Joshua asked G-d to name the culprit, He responded, Am I to be a talebearer to you?
All this teaches us an important lesson: If G-d Himself avoided speaking negatively about these wicked people, how much more we take extreme care not to speak negatively of others, even if they are not of sterling character.


We know when HaShem tells Moshe about Kosher and impure creatures, the Torah, which is expressed in brevity, uses uncharacteristically long expressions to avoid calling them impure. Here we see a greater example of the further lengths about avoiding speaking ill of others. In the Prophets, HaShem says that He hates Esau and He loves Jacob, and yet, HaShem set up this situation to avoid singling out a person. We, too, need to be careful how we talk about others.

entry.title: Parsha Chayei Sarah
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 8, 2017 | 20 Cheshvan 5778 |

Parsha Chayei Sarah /
Sefer Bereishet 23:1 - 25:18
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Chayei Sarah 5777, Chayei Sarah 5775, Chayei Sarah 5774, and Chayei Sarah 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Chayei Sarah, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the fifth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 23:2, Sarah died in Kiryat Arba, which is Hebron.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Both Abraham and Sarah knew that sacrificing Isaac would threaten the success of their Divine mission. Even if they were to train a disciple to carry on their work after their death, such a disciple would not compare to their son Isaac, who carried their idealism and devotion in his very blood and bones. Yet, whereas Abraham was willing to sacrifice his son, Sarah could not bear to hear about such a possibility.
This is because Abraham was sufficiently detached from the physical world to image his and Sarah's Divine mission being fulfilled on a purely spiritual plane. Sarah, in contrast, was so focused on integrating Divine spirituality into the physical world that such a prospect was unimaginable.
The events immediately following Sarah's death vindicated her approach. First, Abraham purchased the Machpellah Cave in order to bury her. This began the process of transforming the physical Land of Israel into the setting where G-d's chosen people would become a light to all nations. After this, Abraham arranged Isaac's marriage to Rebecca, thereby ensuring the continuity of his and Sarah's mission through their physical progeny.
Thus, we can learn from Sarah the primacy of integrating Divinity into our physical world, rather than being satisfied with spiritual growth alone.
Our Sages tells us that Abraham and Sarah, both had the same Divine mission, as the Rebbe writes, and that Abraham represented the spiritual side, while Sarah, represented the mundane side. It is telling that we have Chayei Sarah and not Chayei Abraham in the Torah. Our mission here, in this world, is to integrate the Divine into the physical, the side of Sarah. And yet, Abraham outlived his wife, just as the soul continues when the body passes away. Even our souls require to be expressed and work within the physical world, as Abraham buried Sarah. This world expresses the union of Divinity and mundane, and how they are actually but one. We are all Sarah, and look to Abraham for support. Only working together can we be successful.

Bereishet 24:10, The servant took ten of his master's camels and set out, with all his master's wealth in his hand.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Although Isaac was already 40 years old at the time, Abraham nevertheless went unhesitatingly to all extremes for his son's benefit, for he knew that his role and responsibility as a parent never ends.
Indeed, there is no age-limit to the parent-child bond. The unique, spiritual connection between parents and children enables fathers and mothers to remain positive forces in their children's lives forever.
Of course, part of our job as parents is to teach our children to take responsibility for their own lives. But even then, as parents, we remain obligated to be involved, guiding and helping them in their journey through life.
This is said of mortal parents, how much more so, our Eternal parent, whom fashioned our very souls? HaShem is our parent, both mother and father, in both spiritual and mundane sense. Our very essence that which makes us us comes from HaShem. The design and ability to fashion bodies comes from HaShem as well. HaShem is looking out for us, as a parent watches over their children.

Bereishet 25:1, Abraham remarried [Hagar, the] woman who was [now also] named Keturah.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Hagar was renamed Keturah (which means incense) because, having permanently renounced idolatry, her deeds were now as pleasing to G-d as incense.
One of the ingredients of the incense that was offered up in the Holy Temple was musk, which was derived from the blood of a non-Kosher animal. This demonstrates the incense's unique capability to elevate even entities on the lowest rung of spirituality to the heights of holiness. Hagar/Keturah is therefore compared to the incense, because her return to Abraham and the path of truth after having lapsed into idolatry mirrors this unique characteristics of the Temple's incense.
From this we learn how great is the pleasure we can give G-d by returning to Him after any lapse in our own behavior.

As it is stated, Ezekiel 18:28, Do I desire the death of the wicked? says the Lord G-d. Is it not rather in his repenting of his ways that he may live? HaShem desires that we choose life, not death. Thus, all His Mitzvot lead to life, and sins leads to death, not as reward/punishment, but as the way the world was created.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
Thu, Oct 26, 2017 | 7 Cheshvan 5778 |

Parsha Lech Lecha /
Sefer Bereishet 12:1 - 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Lech Lecha 5776, Lech Lecha 5775, and Lech Lecha 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Lech Lecha, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 12:15, The woman [Sarai] was taken to Pharaoh's palace.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Sarai's resistance to the Egyptian king's overtures gave her descendants, the Jewish women enslaved in Egypt in Moses's time, the spiritual fortitude to resist the lure of illicit behavior even in the midst of the depraved Egyptian culture. The sages point out that the righteous behavior of the Jewish women in Egypt was one of the merits in which the Exodus occurred.
We too, can draw strength from the examples of our matriarch Sarai and the righteous Jewish women in Egypt, as well as the examples of all righteous Jewish women throughout history. When confronted with the depravity of the society we live in, we must recall that we possess the spiritual fortitude to resist its temptations. And just as our forefathers were redeemed from Egypt in the merit of the righteous women's dedication to Jewish morality and modesty, so will we witness the true and final Redemption in the merit of following their examples.

Bereishet 13:18, [Abram] came and settled in the plains of Mamrei, in Hebron. There, he built an altar to G-d.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The name Hebron (Chevron) is related to the word for connect (chaber). The city of Hebron, both allegorically and physically, expresses the unity of the Jewish people, as well as their unity with G-d.
This is why King David was crowned in Hebron. Of all Biblical figures, he personified our constant and absolute unity with G-d. His psalms, the source of many of our prayers, speak of his unwavering love and devotion to G-d, throughout both the successes and tribulations of his life. Furthermore, King David is the ancestor of the Messiah, who will usher in the Redemption, in which we will all live with the constant awareness of our unity with G-d.
This is the deeper reason why Abram build this third and final altar in Hebron. He built this altar unlike the first two neither to thank G-d for something nor to forestall some future calamity. He built it simply to express his oneness with G-d and his desire to spread Divine consciousness.

By internalizing these values, living in unity with one another and with G-d, we can hasten the Redemption, when both these unities will be fully actualized.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeira
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 1, 2017 | 13 Cheshvan 5778 |

Parsha Vayeira /
Sefer Bereishet 18:1 - 22:24
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeira 5777, Vayeira 5776, and Vayeira 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Vayeira, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 19:4, The men of the city, of Sodom, surrounded [Lot's] house, young and old, all the people from every quarter.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Despite the wickedness of the inhabitants of Sodom, Abraham tried to defend them before G-d. In fact, Abraham was the first person in history to speak up in defense of others. The Midrash relates that Abraham declared to G-d, If You want the world to exist, strict Judgment cannot also exist; if You want strict judgment to exist, the world cannot also exist.
G-d was very pleased when Abraham spoke up in defense of humanity, for in doing so, he was imitating G-d's own ways. As King David expressed it, G-d is good to all, and His mercy extends to all His created, For this reason, the Midrash teaches us that the world is sustained and was even created in the merit of Abraham.
Similarly, by defending other people's behavior, finding mitigating factors and reasons for their misdeeds as Abraham did, we become partners in sustaining the world. Moreover, we thereby sustain our own personal worlds the circles of family, friends, students, and co-workers among whom we live arousing G-d's mercy on them and on us.

Bereishet 20:11, Abraham said, Because there is simply no fear of G-d in this place, they will kill me on account of my wife.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, In this statement, Abraham voiced the two principles underlying his life's work: The first was that making the world into a home for G-d means, above all, encouraging virtue and the practice of justice. The second was that it is impossible to encourage virtue and the practice of justice unless they are based on the belief in G-d as the creator and master of the world. History has proven Abraham right: We have unfortunately seen all too many failed attempts to base morality on any other foundation.

Belief in G-d must therefore be the underlying foundation both of our own morals and ethics as well as of the education of our children. Only when we and our children know that G-d created the world and wants it to be made into His home through righteous and just behavior can we be assured that both we and our children will behave virtuously and justly.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
Wed, Oct 18, 2017 | 29 Tishrei 5778 |

Parsha Noach /
Sefer Bereishet 6:9 - 11:32
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Noach 5777, Noach 5776, Noach 5775, Noach 5774, and Noach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Noach, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the second Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bereishet 6:9, The following are the descendants of Noah. Noah was a righteous man; he was flawless. The Lubavitch Rebbe writes, By mentioning Noah's righteousness before discussing his children, the Torah teaches us that our truest offspring are first and foremost our own good deeds. Our children should thus sense that our greatest aspiration for them is that they excel in good deeds, which carry on our lineage in the spiritual sense.
In that we need to be examples to our children, just as we wish for them to live a good and joy spiritual life, we, too, must do so as an example for them to follow.
We cannot expect others to accept something that we, ourselves, do not. We need to ensure that the road we travel is paved with good deeds and spirituality that our children can follow as we followed our parents.

Bereishet 10:25, Peleg [Dispersed] Rashi tells us, The languages were mixed up, and [thus the people] were scattered from the plain and dispersed throughout the world. [From here] we learn that Ever was a prophet, since he named his son for what was to happen in the future, [for] we have learned in Seder Olam (ch. 1) that the Dispersion took place at the end of [Peleg's] life. Should you claim that in fact it took place at the beginning of his life [and he was named for the prevailing situation and not by prophecy, I reply that] Yoktan was his younger brother and he had fathered several families beforehand, as it says: Yoktan fathered.... (v.26), and [only] afterwards: The whole world... (11:1) [referring to the Dispersion]. And if you claim that [the Dispersion occurred] in the middle of his life, [my reply is that] the verse does not leave itself ambiguous when it can [be interpreted to] be expressing a specific [time, and] therefore you can deduce that they were dispersed in the year of Peleg's death.
Our Sages tells us that parents are granted a bit of prophecy to name their children to reflect their soul.
This is one of the first times we come across someone that was a prophet but does not get much attention within the Tenakh. Thus, we see there were more than the headlining Prophets and not all of them were Jewish.


Bereishet 11:5, the sons of man (Adam) Rashi asks, Who else's children, then, could they been? Perhaps the children of donkeys or camels?! [It refers,] however, to the children of [Adam] the first man who was ungrateful and said: The woman whom You gave [to be] with me... (3:12) These people, too, were ungrateful by rebelling against the One who had showered goodness upon them and had saved them from the Flood.
The world was created for the sake of man, to create a dwelling place for HaShem in the lowest of worlds. HaShem has provided for us from the womb to the grave, and yet, many of us, go so far to claim He does not exist. Some from the generation of Dispersion thought Noah's Flood was a natural occurrence and not a cause/effect of sinning. They ignored how our actions have spiritual consequences that affect our environment and those around us in ways we do not understand. The generation did not see HaShem's mercy for what it was, but taken for grant. How often have we done the same? How often do say it is just nature or just how it is, and yet, things could be better if we demanded it.

entry.title: Parsha Bereishet
entry.content:
Sun, Oct 8, 2017 | 19 Tishrei 5778 |

Parsha Bereishet /
Sefer Bereishet 1:1 - 6:8
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Cheshvan /
Molad for Cheshvan will be on Friday, October 20, 2017 12:12 (17 Chalakim) PM
Past Posts: Bereishet 5777, and Bereishet 5773

This week is Simcha Torah, which we finish the Torah and then began again with Parsha Bereishet, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which is the very first Parshot of the Torah. Sefer Bereishet has twelve Parshot, while the entire Torah has fifty-four Parshot.

Who is HaShem? How can we, mortals, know the Infinite? It is not possible for us to do so, but HaShem, Whom can do anything, has provided for us, His Torah. Through Torah, we learn of HaShem and what He desires of us.

Our introduction to HaShem is, Bereishet 1:1, In the beginning of G-d's creating [...]. We learn upfront that, HaShem predates creation, and that HaShem is the inventor of the very act of creation. This Infinite being created the spiritual (Heavens) and the mundane (Earth). Rashi points that the Torah, by its very name, is an instruction book and not a history book. Thus, there is a logical and spiritual reason why the Torah is laid out as it is. Rashi points out the very beginning of Torah is an instruction for we are to say, The entire earth belongs to the Holy One, Source of Blessing, He created it and gave it to whom He saw fit. When He wanted, He gave [this land] to them, and [subsequently] when He wanted, He took it away from them and gave it to us. For when the nations of the world would talk of the Land of Israel not belonging to the Jewish people.
Rashi also points out that our Sages explain the verse that the world was created for the sake of the Torah and for the sake of Israel. It is HaShem Whom engineered everything from the very beginning to be as He desired.

This also shows that there was a blueprint for Creation, itself, and a plan for its aftermath. Just as the Parsha on the creation of the world lacks details, and yet, it was Divinely planned, so too our lives have reasons, even if we do not understand why.

entry.title: Parsha Vzos HaBeracha
entry.content:
Sun, Oct 8, 2017 | 19 Tishrei 5778 |

Parsha Vzos HaBeracha /
Sefer Devarim 33:1 - 34:12
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vzos HaBeracha 5777, Vzos HaBeracha 5776, and Vzos HaBeracha 5773

This Parsha is special, as it is only read on Simcha Torah ( ), which can and does fall on days other that Shabbat. All the other Parshot are only read on Shabbat, but Vzos HaBeracha is read on Simcha Torah only, whether it is a Shabbat or not. Parsha Vzos HaBeracha is also the last Parshot of Sefer Devarim and the very last Parshot of the entire book of the Torah. So we will say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !) which means, Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen! And then immediately, we will start in on Parsha Bereishet, although on Simcha Torah will only one read the first aliyah or so. The rest will be read on Shabbat, itself.

Devarim 33:1, And this [] before he died, Rashi points out that Moshe was quite near to his death, For, he said, if not now, when? (Sifri)
Our Sages say that Moshe learned to rebuke and bless at the end of one's life from Ya'akov Avinu. The rebuke Moshe started with, at the beginning of Sefer Devarim, and at the end, there is only the blessings. Blessings for HaShem, for Israel as a whole, for each tribe, and lastly for Israel as a whole once more. Just as the end of the Torah is only blessings, so true, the entire Torah is blessing. Yes, as we have seen in our history, there are a lot of ups and downs, and yet, in the end there is blessing in our lives. We see, despite the efforts of others, we are still Jews and while we have suffered, HaShem is with us.

Devarim 33:4, The Torah [that] Moshe commanded us is a heritage [for] the Congregation of Ya'akov.
Rashi comments, we have taken it and will not abandon it.
Our Sages tell us that no Jew can claim exclusive rights to the Torah, for it belongs to all of us. It is our mission to tell the Torah to our children and never cease learning from the Torah ourselves. The Torah is a living instruction book on how to life a moral and just life. We only need to follow the numerous examples and lessons within it.


Devarim 34:12, in full view of all Israel, Rashi remarks, This refers to the fact that his heart inspired him to shatter the Tablets before their eyes, as it is said, (9:17) And I broke them before your eyes, and the opinion, as it stated that G-d said of the Tablets, (Shemos 34:1) , May your strengthen be well directed (; an expression of thanks and congratulations) because you have broken them (Yevamos 62; Shabbos 87a).
This is the mark of a true leader, one that acts the same in private and public, and does not allow the public to sway them.

entry.content:
Wed, Sep 13, 2017 | 23 Elul 5777 |

Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech / -
Sefer Devarim 29:9 - 31:30
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Tishrei /
Molad for Tishrei will be on Wednesday, September 20, 2017 11:28 (16 Chalakim) PM
Past Posts: Nitzavim 5776, Vayelech 5776, Nitzavim 5775, Vayelech 5775, Nitzavim-Vayelech 5774, Nitzavim-Vayelech 5773, Nitzavim 5772 and Vayelech 5772

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech, which is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the fifty-second Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.


Devarim 30:3 The Eternal your G-d will then come back with the captives ( ' ). Rashi points out, To express this idea it ought to have written , then He will bring back your captivities, but now it implies He will return with your captivity. But our Rabbis learned from this that, if one can so of G-d, His Divine presence dwells with Israel in all the misery of their exile, so that when they are redeemed, He makes redemption written for Himself that He will return with them (Sifri on Numbers 35:34; Meg. 29a). Furthermore the following may be said in explaining the strange form ... , that the day of the gathering of the exiles is so important and is attended with such difficulty that it is as though He (G-d) Himself must actually seize hold of each individual's hand dragging him from his place (so that G-d Himself returns with the exile), as it is said, (Yeshayah 27:12) And you shall be gathered one by one, O you children of Israel. And also regarding the exiles of other nations we have found this, as e.g. (Yechezkel 29:14): And I will return the captivity of Egypt ( ).
So one cannot say that HaShem has abandoned us, rather, He is as close to us as always. Whether the people are saints or sinners, HaShem is there with us. HaShem doesn't remain in Heaven, but is here on Earth with us. HaShem is around us, through us, and in us. Whether we are in the Holy Land of Israel or exile among the nations, HaShem is there with us.
