entry.title: Parsha Ki Seitzei
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 30, 2017 | 9 Elul 5777 |

Parsha Ki Seitzei /
Sefer Devarim 21:10 - 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Seitzei 5776, Ki Seitzei 5775, Ki Seitzei 5774, Ki Seitzei 5773, and Ki Seitzei 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Ki Seitzei, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-ninth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 22:3, you may not ignore [it]. Rashi states, i.e. to close your eyes tight, as it were, as though you would not see it.
The literally it here is a lost item and our Sages tells us that everything that happens, happens for a reason. A reason we may or may not be privy to. It was Divinely planned for us to find someone's lost item for some reason, and the Torah insists for us to ensure it is returned.
That is the literal interpretation, a spiritual one is that if we see someone that is spiritual lost, we need to go out of our way to help them return. Each Jew is very precious to HaShem, and if a Jew becomes lost, we need to ensure their return.

Devarim 25:12, you shall then chop off her hand. Rashi expounds this thus, i.e., she must pay money that is the equivalent of the shame to which he has been put, all according to /the social position of/ the person who put him to shame and of him who was shamed. But perhaps this not the meaning, but that you should cut off her hand, literally?! It states, however, here, Your eye shall not pity her and it states there (19:21) in the the laws concerning the plotting of witnesses You shall not pity them; now, what is the cast here? It is monetary compensation! So, too, here the intent is monetary compensation (Sifri; cf. B. Kam. 28a).
Here, Rashi points out that the Torah is actually speaking of a metaphor, instead of the literal. And yet, the Torah actually wrote the literal where someone not familiar with Torah could easily make a huge mistake. This is not the first time where the Torah talked of metaphor instead of literal, such as Bereishet 1:26, And the Lord said, "Let us make man in our image, The literal text would say that there are plural beings involved in the creation of man, and yet, only HaShem was involved. Then why the plural verbiage? To teach us a lesson, if HaShem, Himself, seeks counsel of others for important decisions, so too, should we. Here, too, we are to learn a lesson. What that lesson is, I can only guess, but I would say that strict justice might wish to remove that caused trouble in a permanent manner, but this world was created with Mercy, so it is transformed into money compensation.

entry.title: Parsha Shoftim
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 23, 2017 | 1 Elul 5777 |

Parsha Shoftim /
Sefer Devarim 16:18 - 21:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shoftim 5776, Shoftim 5775, Shoftim 5774, Shoftim 5773, and Shoftim 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shoftim, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-eighth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 20:3, listen, Yisrael, Rashi states, Even though you have no other merit than the fulfillment of the command of Reading the Shema you would deserve that He should help you (Sotah 42a).
How powerful and important the Shema is, which goes to show how fundamental the Shema is to Judaism. Listen, O Israel, our Lord is our G-d, and He is one. We cannot just stand there, but need to actively listen, as a nation, and as individuals, and know that the Aspect of Mercy and Transcendence is the same G-d of Nature and Judgment and that these two seemingly opposite concepts refer to the same being. HaShem is everything and there is nothing without Him. And just saying this line (and the three paragraphs), is enough to understand HaShem and our relationship with Him, that as a partner in our relationship there is a responsibility upon Him to act on our behalf.


Devarim 20:3, against your enemies, Rashi expounds this, By these apparently redundant words the priest says, as it were: Remember that these are not your brethren, and if you will fall into their hands they will have no pity on you. It is not like the war of Yehudah against Yisrael of which it states, (Divrei HaYamim II 28:14) And the men which were designated by name rose up, and took the captives, and with the spoil, clothed all that were naked among them, and put shoes on them, and fed them, and gave them to eat and to drink, and anointed them and carried all the feeble of them upon donkeys, and brought them to Jericho, the city of the palm trees, to their brethren: they returned to Samaria. It is your enemies against whom you march, therefore show yourselves strong for battle (Sifri; Sotah 42a).
In the speech that the Anointed (for War) Priest gives, the Torah emphasizes that we need to understand whom we are fighting are not the same as us, or believe as we do. We need to understand that those we face are our enemies, not someone to compromise with but to fight.

Devarim 12:30, They were destroyed from before you, Rashi explains this thus, The meaning is: after you see that I exterminated them from before you, you ought to pay attention to why these were exterminated because of the depraved doings which they practiced. Consequently you should not act likewise lest others come and exterminate you (cf. Sifri).
What the Torah is telling us that we need to take heed of those are around us and come before us, so that we may learn not to make the same mistakes as others did. We need to understand that HaShem acts Justify, Truthfully, and with Loving-Kindness, so if something happens, it happened for a reason. Of course, sometimes, HaShem just sits back and allows events to play out according to free will, but we know for sure, we should not second-guess HaShem, and take heed not to repeat the mistakes of others.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
Wed, Aug 9, 2017 | 18 Av 5777 |

Parsha Eikev /
Sefer Devarim 7:12 - 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Eikev 5776, Eikev 5775, Eikev 5774, Eikev 5773, and Eikev 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Eikev, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 10:12, only to fear, Rashi tells us, Our Rabbis derived from this (and now, what does G-d ask from you) that everything is in the hands of G-d except the fear of G-d (Berachos 33b).
There are two forms of relationship with HaShem, love and fear, as shown by Avraham and Yitzchak. As discussed in Parsha Chai Sarah, love leads to fear and fear leads to love. So what can be said is that, HaShem takes care of us and does everything for us, only for the sake of having a relationship with us. The fear that is being talked about is the fear of doing wrong because it hurts the other, and the fear of disappointing that other. It is for a relationship between us and HaShem that HaShem created the World.

Devarim 10:19, "for you were strangers", Rashi remarks, "Do not repoach your fellow man for a fault which is also your own (cf. Rashi on Shemos 22:20; Bava Metzia 59b)"
The Baal Sham Tov taught that what we see in others, there exist within ourselves. One can only see a fault that they have/know about, otherwise, they would not have seen it in the first place. If one did not know what that fish lived in water, one would not look below the surface to check for them.

entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
Wed, Jul 26, 2017 | 4 Av 5777 |

Parsha Devarim /
Sefer Devarim 1:1 3:22
Shabbat Chazon /
Haftarah: Isaiah 1:1 - 1:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Devarim 5776, Devarim 5775, Devarim 5774, Devarim 5773, and Devarim 5772

This week Parsha is a Parsha Devarim, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Devarim, which has eleven Parshot, and the forty-fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Devarim 1:27, Out of the Eternal's hatred of us, He took us out of the land of Mitzrayim Rashi writes, His bringing us forth was out of hatred. A parable! It may be compared to an earthly king who had two sons, and who had two fields, one well-watered, the other arid (dependent upon rain only). To the one he loved best of his sons he gave the well-watered field, and to him whom loved less he gave the arid one. The land of Egypt is a well-watered country, for the Nile rises and irrigates it, while the land of Cana'an is an arid country, and He brought us froth from well-watered Egypt to give us the arid land of Cana'an (Bamidbar Rabbah 17).
Moshe tells us (and the listeners) what those who listened to the Ten Spies said in private. Rashi explains what they meant, in that, in Egypt the fields were irrigated with little to no human intervention, while the land of Cana'an would and does require prayer and effort. What that generation did not understand was that spirituality and materialism are not mutually exclusive, but in fact, required mutually inclusive. We cannot do one without the other. What one does materialistically had a spiritual component to it, and the reverse is true. This is how HaShem created the world.
Rashi and our Sages tell us that what the people were saying in their tents was that all the bad stuff(tm) must be because HaShem was hating them, as they hating HaShem. And yet, the reality was that, despite all their faults, HaShem did and still does love the Jewish people.
This coming Monday night is Tisha B'Av, the 9th of Av, when we mourn the lost of the Holy Temple that stood upon the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. We might think that because we lost the Temple and were exiled from our land that HaShem hated us, and yet, we are still around. Despite the hardship and danger many Jews did not settle elsewhere, but made it a strong point to live in Israel, regardless of what was going on. HaShem could have just has easily destroyed Israel as He did the Temple, but He did not. Because, the Temple was a replacement for the people. Bricks and stone for flesh and blood. And we do mourn not the actual Temple, but what that Temple stood for. The Holy Temple was a physical place, one could see and feel spirituality in its fullest. It was a place that was obviously a complete and perfect fusion of spirituality and materialism. But alas, our baseless hatred caused HaShem to take it away, to teach us of our wrongful path and how to return to the rightful path.

entry.content:
Wed, Jul 19, 2017 | 25 Tammuz 5777 |

Parsha Matos-Masei / -
Sefer Bamidbar 30:2 - 36:13
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Menachem Av /
Molad for Menachem Av will be on Sunday, July 23, 2017 at 10:00 (14 Chalakim) PM
Past Posts: Matos-Masei 5776, Matos-Masei 5775, Matos 5774, Masei 5774, and Matos-Masei 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Matos-Masei, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the forty-third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.
As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, we say, "Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !)" which means, "Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!"

Bamidbar 31:49, and not [one man of ours is] missing ( ) Rashi states, Its translation in the Targum is which, too, in the Aramaic language means lacking, just as the words (Bereishet 31:39) "I will make good the shortage, are translated in the Targum by "that which was lacking of the number (Rashi on that verse), and so, too, is (Shmuel I 20:18) For your seat ", i.e., the place where you sat will lack the man who usually sat there. And similar (Shmuel I 20:15) the place of David his place lacked, and no man sat there.
What is Rashi trying to tell us here? In the first, Ya'akov Avihu telling Laban that if any sheep under his care was lacking, he would make up the difference himself so that Laban would not be short-changed. In the second/third example, Jonathan has suggested to David about being absent from Shaule HaMelech's table as a test to see how Shaule HaMelech will react, thus, Jonathan discovered for sure that Shaule HaMelech wished to kill David to prevent David from ascending to the throne. Both were preventative measures. But here, the verse speaks how the military commanders expected loses, and yet, miraculously, no soldier was missing because of death or captured by the enemy. We see here, HaShem's influence to protect those that protect us. HaShem protected Ya'akov's flock and allowed Jonathan to do as he did.

entry.title: Parsha Pinchas
entry.content:
Thu, Jul 13, 2017 | 19 Tammuz 5777 |

Parsha Pinchas /
Sefer Bamidbar 25:10 - 30:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Pinchas 5776, Pinchas 5774, and Pinchas 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Pinchas, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the forty-first Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 26:62, since a [portion of] heritable property was not given to them. Rashi comments, while those who were counted from twenty years were recipients of an inheritance, as it is said, (v. 54) each [tribe] shall be given its heritable property according to its [number of] counted ones, (consequently the Leviyim had to form a different group for the census).
While the Tribe of Levi did not receive a portion of the Land of Israel, they did receive cities and their surrounding area to live. Not only that, but, HaShem, Himself, is the inheritance of the Tribe of Levi. When the Tribes were exiles, they did not lose their inheritance, but have to wait for Mashiach to delineate where it is, nor so, the Tribe of Levi, for HaShem is with us forever.

Bamidbar 29:35, shall be a [day of] restriction for you ( ), Rashi add, you are restricted in the doing of work. Another explanation of : Restrict yourselves from leaving Jerusalem: this teaches that this (the eighth day) requires that they should remain in Jerusalem overnight (that the pilgrims should not immediately at the termination of the seventh day begin their homeward journey) (Sifrei). And an explanation of it in the Agada is: because on all the seven days of the Festival they offered sacrifices corresponding in number to seventy nations of the world, and they propose then to set forth on their way home, the Omnipresent says to them: I beg of you make a small banquet for Me, so that I may have some pleasure from you exclusively (Succah 55b).
Thus we can say that the Festival of Sukkot is one for the entire world, Israel and the nations, while Shemini Atzeret/Simcha Torah are for Israel alone.

Bamidbar 30:1, Moshe then said this to the Children of Israel, Rashi points out, This is stated to separate this subject (of sacrifices) from the following Sedrah of (vows). Such is the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael (Sifrei). What it means is: since up to now we have the words of the Omnipresent to Moshe (28:1-2: The Eternal spoke to Moshe etc.) and the chapter about vows that follows begins with an utterance of Moshe (And Moshe spoke), it is necessary firt to make a break by stating that Moshe in turn told this section to Israel (And Moshe then said etc.), for if this were not done it would imply that he did not tell them this section about the sacrifices, but began his address with the chapter of vows.

entry.title: Parsha Balak
entry.content:
Wed, Jul 5, 2017 | 11 Tammuz 5777 |

Parsha Balak /
Sefer Bamidbar 22:2 - 25:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Balak 5776, Balak 5775, Balak 5774, and Balak 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Balak, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the fortieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 23:9, and will not be reckoned among the nations Rashi expounds this thus, Understand this as the Targum does, They will not be exterminated with the other nations, as it is said, (Yirmiyah 30:11) For I will make a full end of all the nations [ but I will not make a full end of you]. The words therefore mean: They will not be numbered with the other nations. Another explanation is: When they rejoice, no other nation rejoices with them, as it is said, (Devarim 32:13) G-d will lead him alone to future bliss, and when the nations are in prosperity they (the Israelites) eat with each one of them and yet it is not taken into account for them thereby to diminish their reward in the future life; and this is the means of and when they enjoy with the nations is not taken into account.
What Rashi is telling us that this, not reckoned among the nations is a good thing and a blessing. The nations of the world will lose their identity as they are those that do not follow HaShem, but when Mashiach comes, everyone will be able to see and know HaShem, thus they will follow Him, giving up what they were before. But for the nation of Israel, we will have nothing to give up or change, but increase our following and understanding of HaShem then.

Bamidbar 23:24, they do not lie down, Rashi explains, at night on his until his consumes and destroys every noxious thing which comes to prey upon him. How so? He reads the Shema at his bedside and commends his spirit into the hands of the Omnipresent (Tanchuma). If a camp or troop comes to injure them, the Holy One, blessed be He, protects them and fights their battles and causes them (the enemies) to fall slain. Another explanation is as the Targum has it (Behold the people shall dwell as a lioness and as a lion shall he raise himself; he will not dwell in his land until he has slaughtered and he will inherit the wealth of the people).
The obvious question is, how is this, they do not lie down, a blessing? Rashi examples that because we say the Shema at night before sleeping and entrust our souls to HaShem, HaShem protects us. Two simple things, and yet, HaShem fights our battles and protects us, from forces that we do not know about.

entry.title: Parsha Korach
entry.content:
Tue, Jun 20, 2017 | 26 Sivan 5777 |

Parsha Korach /
Sefer Bamidbar 16:1 18:32
Shabbat Rosh Chodesh Tammuz /
Haftarah: Isaiah 66:1 66:24
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Korach 5776, Korach 5775, Korach 5774, and Korach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Korach, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-eighth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 18:1, shall bear the sins concerning the Temple, Rashi explains, upon you I impose the punishment for any strangers who may inadvertently sin in respect to the sacred objects which are entrusted to you, which are the tent, the Ark, the table and the holy vessels; you have to sit down (i.e. wait there and be in readiness) and give warning to any stranger who may be about to touch the holy articles.
Thus, the entire Tribe of Levi was charged with actively protecting the Holy Temple and what was inside of it. There were certain areas within the Temple that a non-Leviyim could not go. So it was encumbered upon the Leviyim to warn and non-Leviyim away. One could not say, they should know better or a mere sign was sufficient, rather, the entire tribe was charged and held accountable to ensure that others did not transgress.

Bamidbar 18:8, and I, have hereby given over to you Rashi states, with pleasure. This is suggested by the word Behold, for this is an expression used when something is done with pleasure, just as in, Shemos 4:14, Behold, he goes forth to meet You and when he will see You he will rejoice in his heart! A parable! This may be compared to a king who presents a field to his friend, but did not write or seal a deed of gift nor did he record it in the court. When a man came and laid claim to the field, the king said to him, It seems that anyone who wishes to do so may come and claim against you; behold, I will write and seal a deed of gift to you, and record it in the court! So here, too, because Korach came and made a claim against Aharon to the Priesthood, Scripture came and gave him the twenty-four gifts of the priesthood as an everlasting covenant of salt (i.e. an enduring covenant). For this reason is this section recording the fits of the priests placed here after that which narrates Korach's rebellion (Siphre).
What are the gifts that HaShem has given to the Cohenim? That which is given to HaShem, and from them, HaShem gives freely to the Cohenim. In truth, everything belongs to HaShem, but might think that those items that are sanctified could not be used by mortals, but HaShem comes here and tells us that, He, Personally, gifts them to the Cohenim to use in the manner prescribed, without losing their holiness.

entry.title: Parsha Shelach
entry.content:
Thu, Jun 15, 2017 | 21 Sivan 5777 |

Parsha Shelach /
Sefer Bamidbar 13:1 15:41
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Tammuz /
Molad for Tammuz will be on Shabbat, June 24, 2017 9:16 (13 Chalakim) AM
Past Posts: Shelach 5775, Shelach 5774, and Shelach 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Shelach, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-seventh Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 14:41, It will not succeed, Rashi expounds this thus, What you are about to do will not be successful.
Moshe was warning those that having just sinned in doubting HaShem, where now wishing to do so, but because HaShem was not with them, they will not succeed.
From the Negative, we can learn the Positive, in that, for us to be successful, we require the assistance and blessing of HaShem.
The Ten Spies did have a point, only in so much within the mundane world, the inhabitants would be too much for the Jews. But HaShem is the One, whom guides the world and Who speaks and it is so. As we see those that went up, were, in fact, defeated, since HaShem was not with them, which meant that their Teshuvah was not sincere. Had their Teshuvah been true, the decree could have been adjusted and a different outcome would have been possible, for such is the power of Teshuvah.

Bamidbar 15:38-39, Speak to the children of Yisrael, and you shall tell them [that] they shall make forth tassels on the corners of their garments, [] remember all The Eternal's commandments
How does the commandment of Tzitzis fit into the Parsha entitled, Shelach (send forth)?
The Tzitzis we wear is to remind us of the commandments of HaShem, and in remembers those commandments, we are reminded of He that gave them. And as messengers being sent forth, one need to remember who is the One that is sending us? Where ever we find ourselves, it is because we are meant to be there. Just as there was a proper time for the Jews to enter the Holy Land, so too, there is a proper time for us to be where we are and what we can do to be the Jews we are.

entry.title: Parsha Baha'aloshecha
entry.content:
Wed, Jun 7, 2017 | 13 Sivan 5777 |

Parsha Baha'aloshecha /
Sefer Bamidbar 8:1 - 12:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Baha'aloshecha 5776, and Baha'aloshecha 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Baha'aloshecha, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Bamidbar 9:1, [The Eternal spoke to Moshe in the Sinai desert] in the first month, Rashi points out, The portion at the beginning of the Book of Numbers was not said until Iyyar. From this, you learn that there is no chronological order in the Torah. But why did Scripture not begin with this chapter? For it is a disgrace to Yisrael that throughout the forty years the children of Yisrael were in the desert, they brought only this Passover sacrifice alone (Sifrei; Tosofos, Kidushin 38b)
Chronology is not the purpose of the Torah, Scripture is not a history text book. Torah is an instruction manual from HaShem to humanity, on what HaShem expect from us, and how best to meet that expectation. Yet, the Torah gives us a date here, to relate what is happening to us, to teach us about Pesach Sheni. It also reminds us that it is not the offerings or such that HaShem desires, but our desire to be closer to Him and fulfill His will.

Bamidbar 9:10, or is on a journey of some distance, Rashi expounds this thus, There is a dot on it (on the of the word which letter is therefore regarded as non-existent; cf. Rashi on Bereishit 18:9, in order to tell that what Scripture means by is that he does not really have to be far away, but that his sacrifice is postponed even though he was merely outside the threshold of the temple courtyard during the whole time that the ceremony of slaughtering the Passover sacrifice lasted. (Pes. 93B, cd. Sifrei) On the Second Passover one may have with him unleavened and leavened bread together in his house, and there is no festival in connection with it, and the eating of leaven is forbidden only together with it (the Passover Sacrifice) i.e. while it is being eaten (cf. Pesachim 95a).
Regardless of reason for missing the first Pesach sacrifice, one can still make it up with the offering of Pesach Sheni. This is true of most things, there is no sin that one cannot do Teshuvah for.

entry.title: Parsha Bamidbar
entry.content:
Wed, May 24, 2017 | 28 Iyyar 5777 |

Parsha Bamidbar /
Sefer Bamidbar 1:1 - 4:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bamidbar 5776, Bamidbar 5774, and Bamidbar 5773

This week Parsha is a Parsha Bamidbar, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 3:16, [Moshe counted them] through the Eternal's pronouncement, Rashi expounds this thus, Moshe said to the Holy One, blessed be He, How can I enter their tents to ascertain the number of their babies?! Thereupon the Holy One, blessed be He, replied to him, You do your share and I will do Mine! Moshe went and stood at the entrance of the tent, and the Divine Presence preceded him. A heavenly voice then emanated from the tent, saying, There are this many babies in this tent. That is why it says, - (lit., according to G-d's word).
HaShem, Himself, directly commanded Moshe to count the every Levite male-child from one month old and up, and yet, Rashi tells us that Moshe was troubled by this, so HaShem had to reassure him. This is the same Moshe that confronted Par'oh, the world leader of that time, with any direct trouble, he did wish that his older brother or Mashiach would have done it, but nothing about Par'oh directly. His desire for his older brother and Mashiach were about Jewish respect and honor. And I think that is the issue here. Rashi is telling us that Moshe is teaching us about respect for a Jewish home. That it is so important that he complained to HaShem about His decree to seemly break it. And HaShem seems to agree, as while the consensus was important, HaShem, Himself, counted the babies, protecting the Jewish home's honor.
We also learn from here, that when HaShem gives us our missions, we need to do our share, and HaShem will do His. HaShem knows and understands, better than we ourselves do, what we can and truly cannot do. As HaShem told Moshe, HaShem only expects us to do our part, and HaShem will do His.

entry.title: Parsha Behar-Bechukotai
entry.content:
Mon, May 15, 2017 | 20 Iyyar 5777 |

Parsha Behar-Bechukotai / -
Sefer Vayikra 25:1 - 27:34
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Behar 5776, Bechukotai 5776, Behar 5774, Bechukotai 5774, and Behar-Bechukotai 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parsha Behar-Bechukotai, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the thirty-third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.
As this is the last Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, we say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! !) which means, Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!

Vayikra 25:5, There shall be a sabbatical year for the land.
This is called Shemittah, where in the Land of Israel, we are commanded not to work the fields for an entire year, once every seven years. The question, of course, is why? Because, it is, Vayikra 25:4, a rest period [dedicated] to the Eternal.
By abstaining from working the land, for an entire year, we show that the Land and its produce is not the product of our hands, but the blessing of HaShem upon us. For those that follow the Shemittah HaShem promises that the Land on the sixth year will produce enough for the sixth and seventh years, and enough to resume working the fields on the eighth year (the first year of the next Shemittah cycle).
We are showing the natural and supernatural elements of our people through Shemittah. Torah commands us to work the fields for six years and allow it to rest on the seventh, just as we are commanded to work ourselves for six days and on the seventh day to rest. This seven day/year cycle has no barring on the natural world. Days represent the rotation of the planet Earth on its axis, while years represent the orbit of the Earth around the Sun. Months represent the orbits of the Moon around the Earth. Weeks are not represented by anything mundane, but by the spiritual. For HaShem decided that Creation would take seven days (time periods).
HaShem is tells us about organizing our lives and how to make the most of it.
Despite what the world thinks, nothing can truly operate twenty-four/seven, over time, issues occur, maintenance needs to be done, etc.,
Just as we apply the Shabbat to our daily lives, day in and day out, so too, we need to think about the Shemittah for the Land and our environment. By commanding us about the Land, HaShem is re-affirming His ownership of the world and explaining to us how best to use the gifts we are given. We cannot think purely in a mundane/materialistic manner, the world, Creation, was not designed and build that way. Everything we do, has a spiritual component to it, whether we acknowledge it or not.

entry.content:
Wed, May 3, 2017 | 8 Iyyar 5777 |

Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim / -
Sefer Vayikra 16:1 - 20:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Acharai Mot 5776, Acharei Mot 5774, Kedoshim 5774, and Acharei Mot-Kedoshim 5773

This week Parsha is a double Parshot, Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim, which is the seventh and eighth Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the thirtieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 17:5, who offers up a burnt-offering, Rashi tells us, This is intended to declare one who burns the limb of sacrifices outside the courtyard to be liable to the penalty of excision just the same as one who slaughtered a sacrifice outside the courtyard; so that if one person slaughtered a sacrifice outside the courtyard and another brought up on the altar to burn it both are liable to excision. (cf. Zevachim 106a).
The Torah is telling us that one that offerings a sacrifice outside of the Mishkan or the Holy Temple in Jerusalem is penalized most severely. Rashi is explaining that, it does not matter if the sacrifice is a whole animal or only a small part (a single limb), the penalty is the same.
HaShem does not wish to have sacrifices for the mundane sake, but for spiritual sake. Thus, the location, intentional and process matters greatly. Many believe that their sacrifice is to feed their benefactor, yet, HaShem tells us that He receives only a pleasant smell from knowing that His will has been done. The very act of sacrifices is not for HaShem, but for the offerer. But if the offerer decides that they do not wish to do as HaShem had commanded, but something of their own idea, it defeats the whole purpose of sacrifices.

entry.title: Parsha Tazria-Metzora
entry.content:
Thu, Apr 27, 2017 | 2 Iyyar 5777 |

Parsha Tazria-Metzora / -
Sefer Vayikra 12:1 - 15:33
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tazria 5776, Metzora 5776, Tazria-Metzora 5775, Tazria 5774, Metzora 5774, and Tazria-Metzora 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Tazria-Metzora, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-eighth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 12:2, When a woman conceives, to which Ibn Ezra writes, After completing the laws of ritually pure and ritually impure food, Scripture now discusses ritual impurity among people, beginning with the law of the new mother, because birth is a beginning. [...]
A rule of Torah is to talk about what is common and then after that what is exception, and what is more common that eating? You are only born once, after all. The beginning of a person is their birth.

Vayikra 12:3, On the eighth day [...]
Why the eighth day? Our Sages tells us that eight signifies one beyond the mundane (seven days in a week), so it is supernatural. And we perform the circumcision not for health reasons but for spiritual reasons.

Vayikra 13: 13, he shall ritually purify the affliction Ibn Ezra states, verbally, by declaring that he no longer renders others ritually impure. At this point the ailment has left him and has come out entirely to the surface.
Here we see that Tzara'as is not a mundane illness, for a mere verbal declaration clears it up.

Vayikra 14:3, the priest shall go outside the camp.
This tells us that the priest/Cohen should not be so non-humble that he should demand that the people come to him, but he must go to the person, who as being ritually impure, is outside of the camp. We can also learn from here that one should not hesitate to go out comfort zone in other to help a fellow Jew.

entry.title: Parsha Shemini
entry.content:
Wed, Apr 19, 2017 | 24 Nissan 5777 |

Parsha Shemini /
Sefer Vayikra 9:1 - 11:47
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarchim Iyar /
Molad for Iyar will be on Wednesday, April 26, 2017 7:48 (11 Chalakim) AM
Past Posts: Shemini 5776, Shemini 5775, Shemini 5774, and Shemini 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Shemini, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-sixth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 10:2, A fire then came out, Rashi states, Rabbi Eliezer said: the sons of Aharon died only because they gave decisions on religious matters in the presence of their teacher, Moshe (Siphra; Eruvin 63a). Rabbi Yishmael said: they died because they entered the Sanctuary intoxicated by wine. You may know that this is so, because after their death he admonished those who survived that they should not enter the sanctuary when intoxicated by wine (vv. 8-9). A parable! It may be compared to a king who had a bosom friend, etc., as is to be found in Vayikra Rabbah (ch. 12; cf. Biur).
We know that Vayikra 9:24, A fire then came out from before the Eternal, and here is the same terminology. So we know that this same fire also came out from before the Eternal, the question is why? How could the same fire consume the communal offering bringing praise, and here the same fire caused the death of two of Aharon's sons, whom HaShem, had selected to be the very first Cohenim. Rashi answers that this fire is HaShem's praise as He is gloried for punishing the righteous and sinner alike. So what was the crime that called for punishment? Rashi states it was as Rabbi Eliezer said or as Rabbi Yishmael said.

entry.title: Parsha Tzav
entry.content:
Wed, Apr 5, 2017 | 10 Nissan 5777 |

Parsha Tzav /
Sefer Vayikra 6:1 8:36
Haftarah: Parsha Tzav: Jeremiah 7:21 - 8:3, 9:22 - 9:23
Shabbat HaGadol /
Haftarah: Shabbat HaGadol: Malachi 3:4 - 3:24
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tzav 5776, Tzav 5775, Tzav 5774, Tzav 5773, and Tzav 5772

This week Parsha is Parsha Tzav, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-fifth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot. The Shabbat before Pesach is called Shabbat HaGadol ( ). Many of the custom of reading Malachi 3:4 through 3:24; Chabad has the custom of only reading that publicly when Shabbat HaGadol falls on the 14th of Nissan, as such, Jeremiah 7:21 thru 8:3 and 9:22 thru 9:23 will be read in Chabad shuls.

Vayikra 6:13, It is [also] a regular meal-offering half of it [to be brought] in the morning, and the half of it in the evening.
Meaning that the Cohen Gadol ( ) had to bring a meal-offering twice a day, ever day. Why did the Cohen Gadol have to do this? Our Sages give multiple reasons, the one I wish to mention is that a poor person should not feel shame for his meal-offering, for it is the same as the Cohen Gadol's. Another reason our Sages say, for sinner should not be shame, for each day the Cohen Gadol brings a meal-offering as a sin-offering.

Vayikra 7:1, And this is the law of the guilty-offering: It is holy of holies
Which is interesting to me, a guilty-offering is brought when one commits a sin, either intentionally or not, and HaShem tells us that it is holy of holies. Why is that? For through the offerings, we return closer to HaShem. For when the guilty-offering was brought, it was part of the repentance process. An individual has recognized that he or she has done something to distance themselves from HaShem, and wish to correct that. As it is said, paraphrasing, HaShem does not desire the death of even those that deserve it, but their Teshuvah (). HaShem desires a personal relationship with each one of us. That we place some distance between us, and then wish to return is most holy to HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Vayikra
entry.content:
Wed, Mar 29, 2017 | 3 Nissan 5777 |

Parsha Vayikra /
Sefer Vayikra 1:1 - 5:26
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayikra 5776, Vayikra 5775, Vayikra 5774, and Vayikra 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Vayikra, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, which has ten Parshot, and the twenty-fourth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Vayikra 3:11, [as] fuel for the first, for [the sake of] the Eternal ( ), Rashi explains, means: it is the food of the fire in hour of the Lord. (The translation is not: it is food, a fire offering to the Lord; is construct, and the words must be translated as Rashi does). Rashi also comments on (Fuel), is a general expression for food. Similar is, (Yirmiyah 11:19) let us destroy the three with the fruit thereof (); (Daniel 5:1) [Belshazzar] made a great banquet (); (Koheles 10:19) It is for laughter that a banquet () is made.
The Hebrew word means bread, food, banquet/meal and fuel. Which is interesting, a meal/banquet would have bread a common item. But fuel, how does that relate to food? Why do we eat? We eat to be able to do what we need to, just as fuel/gasoline enables a machine to operate. While there is a difference between bread and gasoline, but for their prospective systems, enable us to do what needs to be done. So the fats that are offered upon the fire, fuel/feed the fire that are used for the offerings.

Vayikra 5:23, when he sinned and [thus] incurred guilt Rashi points out, means when he comes to recognition of himself (recognizes his duty) to repent of his sin and makes up his mind to confess that he has sinned and has incurred guilt.
It is not enough that a person recognizes that he has sinned, but that he feels guilty about it. For the guilt will lead to remorse and corrective action to change, to prevent such conditions that lead to the sin the first place.

entry.title: Parsha Vayakhel-Pekudei
entry.content:
Tue, Mar 21, 2017 | 24 Adar 5777 |

Parsha Vayak'hel-Pekudei / -
Sefer Shemos 38:21 40:38
Shabbat HaChodesh /
Maftir: Shemos 12:1 12:20
Haftarah: Ezekiel 45:16 46:18
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayakhel-Pekudei 5775, and Vayakhel-Pekudei 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Vayak'hel-Pekudei, which is the last Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the twenty-third Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot. This Shabbat we also read Parsha HaChodesh, Shemos 12:1 through 12:20, which deals with that Nissan is the first of the month of the Jewish year and the Pesach offering.

Shemos 35:2, for six days Rashi states, [Moshe] preceded the warning [about keeping] Shabbat before the commandment of constructing the Dwelling, [thus] indicating that [the latter] does not supersede the Shabbat (Mechilta 1).
Because of the people's excitement for building the Mishkan, Moshe had to remind them that the Mishkan was a mere vessel. All the services of the Mishkan and the Holy Temple only had meaning in following the Words of HaShem. In other words, one should not lost sight of the big picture in your pursuit of a single task, even a task as important has building the Mishkan.

Shemos 35:5, (lit.) whose heart is generous, Rashi comments, Since it is [a person's] heart that prompts him to give a donation, he is [therefore] called: one who is generous of /heart/.
What was bothering Rashi? The verse speaks of the actual heart, as if that was the offering, in other words, human sacrifice, but that is not what was happening or even considered. Rather, Rashi is telling us that it is an express or metaphor, that one who is generous is as if giving their heart and follows that heart.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Sisa
entry.content:
Wed, Mar 15, 2017 | 18 Adar 5777 |

Parsha Ki Sisa /
Sefer Shemos 30:11 34:35
Shabbat Parah /
Maftir: Bamidbar 19:1-22
Haftarah: Ezekiel 36:16 - 36:36
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Sisa 5776, Ki Sisa 5775, Ki Sisa 5774, and Ki Sisa 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Ki Sisa, which is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the twenty-first Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot. We also include for preparing of Pesach, the additional verses for Parah, which speaks of the Red Heifer used to purify the people so they may bring the Pesach offering.

Shemos 30:13, The rich person must not give more, nor may the poor person give less.
What are we being taught here? That a rich person should not boost of his money, nor should a poor person feel dishearten for the lack of money. Before HaShem and within the nation of Israel, they give the same half-shekel. They are mentioned together because the rich and poor need the other, to fulfill the Mitzvah of Charity and love thy neighbor as yourself.

Shemos 30, 29: wash their hands and feet
We can know obviously why the Cohanim had to wash their hands for mundane and spiritual reasons, but why also wash their feet? After all, before even entering the Holy Temple, the Cohanim had used a Mikvah, so why again wash their hands and feet again? The hands if they touch something and to recall that their hands which perform the Service is holy, as well as, their feet that carry the Cohanim from place to place within the Holy Temple are holy too. The Cohanim in the Holy Temple were barefooted and thus, connected to the ground, to be humble and connected, literally, to the earth.

Shemos 32:10, let Me be, Rashi comments, We have not yet heard that Moshe prayed for them, yet [HaShem] says, let Me be! Rather, here He gave [Moshe] an opening and informed him that the matter was dependent on him, that if he would pray for them He would not destroy them.
Thus, we see that HaShem did not change his mind, but was teaching Moshe (and us) proper manners and the responsibility of Jewish leadership to defend the people, even from HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Tetzaveh
entry.content:
Wed, Mar 8, 2017 | 11 Adar 5777 |

Parsha Tetzaveh /
Sefer Shemos 27:20 30:10
Parsha Zachor /
Maftir: Devarim 25:17 25:19
Haftarah: I Samuel 15:2 - 15:34
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tetzaveh 5776, Tetzaveh 5774, and Tetzaveh 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Tetzaveh, which is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the twentieth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot. This week we also read Parsha Zachor for Maftir and the Haftarah.

Shemos 29:29, and to inaugurate them with them, to which Rashi states, [i.e.] by [wearing] these garments he becomes invested with the High Priesthood.
And that begs the question, how does that work? To be fair, the inauguration with the clothing is the last step in the selection process, but the question remains? And what is the Torah telling us here? That the clothes make the man, or the High Priest? Not exactly. Rather, the Torah is telling us the importance of visual clues and symbolism. As much as we are told not to judge a book by its cover, we still do, even if it is unconscious. We believe in certain expectations and follow them unconsciously, whether we realize it or not. But the garments of the High Priest (and the Priests themselves) do not belong to them, rather, they are the communal property of the entire nation, donated to the Temple Service. And the Temple Service requires the Priests to wear these garments. The garments which are the communal properties are symbols of the Temple Service and when see add to the Service itself. Thus, we can assume that the one wearing the unique garments of the High Priest, is in fact, the High Priest.

Shemos 29:43, with My glory, Rashi tells us, in that My Divine Presence will rest there. But the Aggadic explanation is: Do not read [this was as] with My glory, but with My honored ones. He [thus] alluded to him there [about] the death of Aharon's sons on the day of the erection of [the Dwelling]. And this is what Moshe said [then], This is what the Eternal spoke about, saying, 'I shall be sanctified through those who are close to Me (Vayikra 10:3) and where had He spoken [about this]? [When He said here] and it will be sanctified through My honor[ed ones] (Zevachim 125b)
Thus we see the foreshadowing of what will happen later. We also get a glimpse of the Divine Plan, as we know that Aharon's sons, Nadav and Avihu, where holy and righteous individuals, as here Rashi points out that HaShem is calling them My honored ones. And yet, for their sin, they were punished. In punishing the righteous, HaShem is sanctified as justice and truth are carried out. If those who stand close to HaShem are still punished, how much more so, than those that distant themselves from their Creator? And yet, HaShem is merciful, just and loving-kindness in all that He does.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
Wed, Mar 1, 2017 | 4 Adar 5777 |

Parsha Terumah /
Sefer Shemos 25:1 - 27:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Terumah 5776, Terumah 5775, Terumah 5774, Terumah 5773, and Terumah 5772

This week Parsha is Parsha Terumah, which is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the nineteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 25:9 And so you shall make [it], Rashi expounds, [also] in future generations; if one of the utensils is lost, or when you make for Me the utensils for the House of Eternity, such as the tables, candelabra, washing urns and stands that Shlomo made, you shall make them according to the same design as these. If this verse were not connected to the previous [verse], it should have not said and so you shall you make it, but rather so shall you make it, and it would be speaking about the making of the Tent of Meeting [itself] and its utensils.
For those that do not know, the term House of Eternity is another name for the Beis HaMikdash, the Holy Temple in Jerusalem. For it the place where HaShem's Name was rested upon, forevermore. But it is a telling name. Our Sages tells us that the Mishkan (and the Holy Temple) were micro-cosmos of Creation. Thus, we can learn from here, that just as HaShem was preparing instructions for Shlomo (and others) in the future, so too, HaShem is preparing for our future as well. When we contemplate eternity or just the future, we need to keep in mind that HaShem has us covered as well. Just as the Ark of Testimony was the heart/centerpiece of the Mishkan, so too, Torah and HaShem are our centerpiece for our lives and future. Just HaShem knew what materials and skills the Jews processed as they left Egypt, so too, He knows what he has done and what we can do with them. If we follow HaShem's ways, we too can build a Mishkan, so that HaShem may dwell with us.

Shemos 25:15: they must not be removed from them Rashi adds, ever.
What was troubling Rashi that made him add ever to the verse. Rashi was clarifying the verse so that no one should misinterpret it. One might think just as the other vessels have their carrying beams removed when not in motion, so too the Ark's should be. Rashi ensures that we don't think it, in fact, we are commanded never to remove the carrying beams from the Ark.
Our mystics tells us that the Ark represents our Torah scholars and the carrying beams represent those that support Torah scholars, by giving charity and volunteering. Thus, the Torah is telling us here that the two should never depart from the other. Just as the Ark carried those that carried it, so too, the Torah scholar carries those that support them. But just as the Ark did not move on its own, so too Torah scholar need their supports as well.

entry.title: Parsha Mishpatim
entry.content:
Thu, Feb 23, 2017 | 28 Shevat 5777 |

Parsha Mishpatim /
Sefer Shemos 21:1 24:18
Maftir: Parsha Shekalim /
Shemos 30:11 30:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Mishpatim 5776, Mishpatim 5775, Mishpatim 5774, and Mishpatim 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Mishpatim, which is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the eighteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Initial comments from L'Chaim Weekly, Mishpatim 5777.

Shemos 21:1, And these are the laws which you shall present before them
It is written, This section of the Torah comes immediately after the Revelation on Mount Sinai and the giving of the Ten Commandments. Yet what is enumerated here are not lofty principles pertaining to the relationship between G-d and man; they are very concrete laws governing man's relationship with his fellow man. We learn from this the lesson that good manners are a prerequisite to Torah. Rabbi Mendel of Kotsk used to say: The same way that a book's preface informs the reader of the book's contents, a person's courtesy and manners indicate just how much Torah learning he has acquired.
Just as the Ten Commandments came from HaShem, so too, Jewish civil law came from the same Source. We need to understand that there are spiritual components to our relationships between man and man, man and woman, and woman and woman that parallel our relationship between human and our Creator. Many make the claim that civil law is logical and one does not need Divine origin. And yet, history has shown that the removal of spirituality has lead to greater horrors of all time. Logic can be twisted and used to justify anything as history has shown.
But those that have spiritual leanings and upheld a standard from above, we see are able to be friendly and respectful of others.

Shemos 21:2, [...] he shall serve [you] for six years, and in the seventh [year] he shall go free without paying.
The Lubavitcher Rebbe tells us, Six years symbolizes the six thousand years of the world's existence; shall he serve refers to our mission to learn Torah and perform Mitzvot; in the seventh refers to the seventh millennium, when he shall go free, when the Messianic Era shall reign on earth and G-dliness will no longer be hidden but revealed.
Creation has seven days, and our Sages say that there are also seven ages or millennium that corresponds to those days. Just as the seventh day is Shabbat, so too, our Sages say the seventh millennium, which begins with the Year 6000, will be a Sabbatical millennium. Mashiach will come before then, Blessed Be HaShem, and the Sabbatical millennium will be a Shabbat to the previous six millennia. Just as the purpose of our week is for the Shabbat, so the purpose of the world is for the Messianic Era. Just as we work to ready ourselves for the Shabbat, so all our work of Mitzvot and Torah is towards then. We are blessed in the now, and do the now, which is also stored for us for the later.

For all manner of transgression...of which he can say, this is it
Rabbi Yisrael of Modzitz writes, Pride is the root of all transgression. The essence of sin is when a person says of himself - this is it - I am the most important thing in the whole world!
For in their pride they forget their Creator and the ways of the world. Par'oh of the Torah did so, and many others have not learned from him.

entry.title: Parsha Yisro
entry.content:
Wed, Feb 15, 2017 | 19 Shevat 5777 |

Parsha Yisro /
Sefer Shemos 18:1 - 20:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Yisro 5776, Yisro 5775, Yisro 5774, and Yisro 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Yisro, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the seventeenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 20:1, G-d then spoke ( ), Rashi points out, [The term] always signifies [G-d as] a judge (Mechilta) [and similarly it says verse 22:27, [where] Onkelos translates as: a judge]. [Now,] since there are certain sections in the Torah that if a person fulfills [the Mitzvos written there] he receives reward, but if not, he does not receive punishment for [not fulfilling] them. I might have thought that the Ten Commandments are also like this. [The Torah therefore] teaches [us] by saying: [signifying that G-d is] a judge who exacts punishment [for not fulfilling these Mitzvos].
If we recall the very beginning, the Torah has there too, HaShem uses His aspect of Justice. Here too, HaShem uses the same aspect. The seven laws of Noach can be found among the Ten Commandments. One can measure a society by the Ten Commandments. The basics of human life and creation are within the Ten Commandments and the enforcement of those. Just as Yisro sampled all the idols of the world and came to realize HaShem, so too, the world sampled different moral systems, and came to realize the Divinity of the Ten Commandments (Torah).

Shemos 20:1, all these words Rashi states, [This] teaches [us] that the Holy One, Source of Blessing, said the Ten Commandments in one utterance something that is impossible for a person to [do]. If so, what [is the Torah] teaching [us] by saying further: I am (20:2) and: You must not have [any gods...] (20:3-6)? [It is telling us] that [G-d] repeated and expressly uttered each commandment by itself (Mechilta)
The very concept of a single utterance of Verses 2 through 14, twelve verses, is hard to understand. Some Sages say that not only was the Ten Commandments said in a single utterance and was understandable. So then, why did HaShem repeat it? If He repeated because He was not understood, again why did HaShem repeat Himself? Just as HaShem created everything and set everything in its place, as our Sages said, setting a dinner date. So too, HaShem did the same with the Ten Commandments. By saying all twelve verses in a single utterance, It could also be said that the single utterance was addressed to the Children of Israel as a whole, and the repetition was addressed to each individual Jew personally. If HaShem could say the entire Ten Commandments as a single utterance, why could not HaShem say the entire Ten Commandments to three million plus individuals personally. Showing that HaShem cares for us as a nation and as individuals.

entry.title: Parsha Beshalach
entry.content:
Tue, Feb 7, 2017 / 11 Shevat 5777 /

Parsha Beshalach /
Sefer Shemos 13:17 17:16
Tu B'Shevat
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Beshalach 5776, Beshalach 5774, and Beshalach 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Beshalach, which is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the sixteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Base comments from L'Chaim Weekly

Shemos 14:31: And Israel saw the great might that the Eternal had exercised against the Mitzrim and believed in the Eternal
Chidushei HaRim writes, Even though the Jewish people had witnessed many wonders and miracles first hand they still needed to have faith in G-d.
For faith is on a higher level than sight; indeed, it enables a person to see more than the physical eye can ever observe.
Faith has carried us throughout the centuries. While it is something to see miracles, it takes more to believe something that we did not see ourselves. Our ancestors saw the Exodus from Egypt, and they told their children, their children told theirs, and they told us. Yet, we did not see it, but our faith has allowed us to connect with them and move forward even when it seems that the world is against us. What we see only lasts for a moment, but faith is eternal.



Shemos 14:31: And they believed in the Eternal
Sefer Hama'amarim 5680, The Hebrew word for faith, emuna, has a dual meaning. Etymologically, it is related to the word meaning to train or accustom oneself, and also to the word for power and strength.
However, these two meanings are interrelated. In the merit of emuna, i.e., by virtue of the strength and certitude of the G-dly soul, a Jew is able to overcome the downward pull of the animal soul and ascend from one spiritual level to the next, till he merits the very highest revelations of G-dliness. Indeed, the Jewish people merited to sing the Song of the Sea solely because of their emuna.
Faith is powerful, and allows us to carry on when logic has failed. HaShem transcends everything and through faith in HaShem, we too, can transcend above the world.

Shemos 15:26: all the illnesses that I brought against Mitzrayim I will not bring upon you, for I am the Eternal, your Physician
Torat Moshe, A house doctor who isn't paid according to how many visits he makes has a vested interest in keeping his patients well.
Rather than curing people once they're ill, his whole aim is to keep them healthy in the first place. Similarly, G-d is our in-house doctor Who has given us the Torah for our spiritual health. When we follow His prescription by observing the commandments, it prevents all kinds of spiritual maladies.
Who better to know what heals us then the One that created us? HaShem created the world and us, so He knows best what goes where and how things should be done.



Shemos 15:27, Twelve springs of water, Rashi adds, were found ready for them, corresponding to the twelve tribes.
Shemos 15:27, and seventy date palms Rashi adds, corresponding to the seventy elder
So HaShem prepared ahead of time twelve springs and seventy data palms for the twelve tribes and the seventy elders. Food (dates) and water (springs) were awaiting the Jews as they left Egypt. We see the care and love that HaShem has for us. Although we followed HaShem into a desert, HaShem provided for us in ways both miraculous and mundane. Although we may not know it when we first stepped out of Egypt, HaShem had a plan and prepared for His people from the very beginning.

entry.title: Parsha Bo
entry.content:
Thu, Feb 2, 2017 / 6 Shevat 5777 /

Parsha Bo /
Sefer Shemos 10:1 - 13:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bo 5776, Bo 5774, and Bo 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Bo, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the fifteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 10:1, The Eternal then said to Moshe, Go to Par'oh. Rashi adds, and warn him [about the forthcoming plagues]. Our Sages teaches us that there was a pattern to the plagues, in that, before each plague, three weeks of warning were given and then the plague would last for a week. The next plague would follow that pattern, and the third plague would follow without such a length warning. Seven Plagues had already ben visited upon Egypt, to show the world that HaShem controls all six directions and transcends even that. And yet, we have the Ten Plagues, not seven, as HaShem prevented Par'oh from being overwhelmed.
Moshe must have wondered what was going on, as HaShem states, Shemos 10:1, for I have made him and his servants stubborn, so that I may display these signs of Mine among [them]
Par'oh had been the leader of the known world at that time, and yet, HaShem tells Moshe, Go to Par'oh. Why Par'oh? As a leader, he set the example that others followed, and was the ruling symbol of his day. Par'oh existed in the mundane, material world. Logic and mathematics would state that the Jewish exodus from Egypt would be impossible. As the saying goes, the odds were against them.
But neither logic nor mathematics can account for HaShem, who is beyond any human comprehension, and that was the point of the Exodus. HaShem is not limited by anything and does as He wishes. He, alone, is, as He wishes. What we think of logic and mathematics are but glimpses into the works of HaShem, but not the totality of HaShem.
There are many Par'oh of the logic and mathematics out there, but a Jew must remember that just as Moshe did, we must go to Par'oh and tell them the truth. This world is not created by logic and mathematics but by HaShem. The World is as HaShem wills, and for us, His creation, to attend to, to be the gardener in the garden that is the world. Sometimes we have failed in our task as gardeners, or forget that the garden is not ours to do as we wish, but to mold and care for it by HaShem's will.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eira
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 25, 2017 / 28 Tevet 5777 /

Parsha Va'eira /
Sefer Shemos 6:2 9:35
Rosh Chodesh Shevat /
Maftir Bamidbar 28:9 28:15
Haftarah: Ezekiel 28:25 - 29:21
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Va'eira 5776, Va'eira 5774, and Va'eira 5773

This week Parsha is Parsha Va'eira, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the fourteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 6:13, The Eternal [...] commanded them regarding the Children of Israel
It is written in Sefat Emet, Despite the fact that the Jewish people hadn't listened because of their anguished spirit and the cruel slavery, G-d commanded Moses and Aaron to keep on talking. For the word of G-d always makes an impression and has an effect: if not immediately, then sometime later. Holy words are never wasted, and are always ultimately heard.
The words of HaShem are eternal as He is, they exist as He does, in the past, the present and future. What HaShem has to say, especially that which is transmitted to His prophets, has several meanings and lessons for us to learn. Even though the Children of Israel seemed to have rejected Moshe and his mission, HaShem still tells him as Rashi states, to lead them in a gentle manner and to be forbearing with them. Despite the seemingly negative start, HaShem tells Moshe to patient and gentle with the people. As with Moshe, all leaders of the Jewish people need to be patient and gentle, remember that they are on a mission from HaShem and to act accordingly.

Shemos 7:7, And Moshe was in his eightieth years, and Aharon, in his eighty-third year, when they spoke to Par'oh
Sha'arei Yerushalayim: Why does the Torah need to tell us the ages of Moses and Aaron? To refute the common misconception that only young people can carry the banner of liberation and redemption. Older people, too, can be revolutionaries, if G-d determines it is necessary and the proper time.
Many believe that only the young have passion, but comes the Torah and tells us not so. Passion is something that anyone, regardless of age, can have. Not only that, but combined with wisdom from age, passion can be very powerful and affect. Also, it shows that HaShem acts accordingly His plan. HaShem could have sent Moshe earlier (or later), but this was the moment that He chose. And although, Moshe was an imposing person, when he went to Par'oh, he was an old man. Not a typical warrior or such, which showed that Moshe was a prophet of HaShem, and not some naive youth.

Shemos 8:9, And the frogs died in the houses, in the villages, and in the fields
Kehilat Yitzchak writes, When the plague of frogs was over, the frogs died. By contrast, after the plague of various wild beasts the animals did not die, but went back to wherever they had come from. The reason is that no new animals were created for the plague of various wild beasts; at G-d's command they left their natural habitat and converged on Egypt. When the plague ended, they were still necessary for the world's ecosystem. The frogs, however, were created especially for the plague; when it was over, there was no need for so many.
Frogs were also native to Egypt, whereas the wild beast were not. In other words, the wild beasts went out of their way to fulfill HaShem's will, while the frogs did not. From here, we learn, when a persons goes the extra mile for HaShem, HaShem returns the effort in kind. The frogs were not inconvenienced, they did as their nature would have them, save for the shear number and allowance to enter places they would not normally go. The wild beasts changed their nature and environment for the sake of HaShem. HaShem cared for both, in accordance with their effort.

Shemos 8:22, It is not proper to do so...shall we sacrifice what is an abomination to the Egyptians before their eyes, and will they not stone us
Imrei Chein writes, The Egyptians were extremely careful to avoid hurting animals; according to the Ibn Ezra, they did not eat meat and would not even use any animal products. It is therefore not proper when such humanitarians, who are so filled with pity for four-legged creatures, think nothing about enslaving Jews and throwing their babies into the river.
Which we see in modern society, there are more laws protecting animals and pets, than there are protecting children. There are so many groups for causes, and yet, how many of them do anything for children and people? Those that society depends upon, teachers, are paid so much less than an entertainer. Yet without teachers, there wouldn't be any other professions. Many of the greatest crimes against Humanity have been undertaken by those who are highly educated and believe themselves to be highly civilized, and yet, their crimes are horrifying.
When Mashiach comes, the world will see what true civilization and humanitarian ideals are. May the world wake up from its corruption and peace reign throughout.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 18, 2017 / 21 Tevet 5777 /

Parsha Shemos /
Sefer Shemos 1:1 - 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shemos 5776, Shemos 5775, Shemos 5774, and Shemos 5773

This week is Parsha Shemos, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Shemos, which has eleven Parshot, and the thirteenth Parshot within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot.

Shemos 1:1, And these are the names of Israel's sons, Rashi expounds this thus, Even though [the Torah already] enumerated them by name during their lifetime [when they went down to Mitzrayim (Bereishet 46:9-27)], it enumerated them again [here] upon their deaths, to show [us] how loved they are [by G-d, which is manifest by] that they are compared to stars which [G-d also] takes out and brings in by number and by name (Tanchuma Yashan 2a), as it says, He takes out their multitude by number, He calls each one by name (Yeshayah 40.26).
Why Rashi, who deals with the literal interpretation, felt that he needed to expound this verse?
Because Sefer Shemos begins with and these (), which in Tradition when a Parsha begins with And, it's a continuation from the previous Parsha, but as the first Parshot of Sefer Shemos, there is no previous Parsha. So there is a continuation from Sefer Bereishet, which ended with the Yosef and the sons of Israel/Ya'akov passing away. So if it is a connection, why is it repeated? As Rashi said just as HaShem loved the children of Ya'akov while they were in the Land of Israel, so too, HaShem loved them in the land of Egypt. And to hint, just as we can not kill the stars, so too, the Children of Israel are immortal like the stars.
Also, this teaches us that the children of Ya'akov did not take Egyptian names or take the Egyptian language.

Shemos 1:8, There then arose a new king Rashi tells us, Rav and Shemuel [differed in their interpretation of these words]: One said that he was really a new [king]; and the other said [that he was actually the same king, but] that he made new edicts (Sotah 11a).
The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out that Rav is an expert on Mitzvos, while Shemuel is an expert on Civil Law. So their debate was whether Pharaoh's sin was against HaShem directly or not.
Our Sages tells us that we should not depend upon on Governments, for its leaders can arise a new at anytime. Egypt was saved and shaped by Yosef, and yet, a new king arose that (Bereishet 1:8) did not know Yosef or the contributions and merits of the Jews that had helped them.

Bereishet 3:15, This is My name forever, Rashi points out, [The word is written] without a [between the and ], implying: Conceal it that [My name] should not be pronounced as it is written (Pesachim 50a). Our Sages tells us that the concealed name is the Y-H-V-H name of HaShem, which is HaShem's aspect of transcendence and mercy.
I would say, this implies to me, that it would seem that HaShem's mercy can be subtle (concealed) at times, but it is always there forever.

Bereishet 5:3, So that He not have us encounter ( ) Rashi comments, They should have said [to Par'oh], so that He not have you encounter, but they [spoke] respectively to the king [and therefore expressed themselves as if the calamity would befall them and not Par'oh] (Shemos Rabbah 5:15). This [word] meetings is an expression of encountering death.
So while this king, Pharaoh, was a sinner, against HaShem and against Israel, and yet, Moshe and Aharon were respective to him. In other words, if you cannot respect the person, respect the office/position.

entry.title: Parsha Vayechi
entry.content:
Wed, Jan 11, 2017 / 14 Tevet 5777 /

Parsha Vayechi /
Sefer Bereishet 47:28 50:26
Shabbat Chazak /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayechi 5776, Vayechi 5775, Vayechi 5774, and Vayechi 5773

This week's Parsha Vayechi is the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, which has twelve Parshot, and the twelfth within the entire Torah of fifty-four Parshot. As it is the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, this Shabbat is Shabbat Chazak, where we say, Be strong! Be strong! Be strengthen! ( ).

And how does the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet start, Bereishet 47:28 And Ya'akov lived. Rashi asks, Why is this Parsha closed up? Because when our father Ya'akov passed away, the eyes and the hearts of [the Children of] Yisrael became closed up from the misery of the bondage that [the Mitzrim] began to impose on them. Another explanation: [Ya'akov] wished to reveal to his sons [when would be] the end [of all exiles], but it was concealed from him.

What does Rashi mean when he says this Parsha is closed? Our Tradition states that the separation between Parshot is the space of nine letters, and that is missing here. But we know from Tradition that this is the beginning of our Parsha. This that occurs here, Rashi comments on it. But there is an issue, the bondage of slavery was not imposed until after all the sons of Ya'akov had passed away. Which is why Rashi brings the second explanation, which is also dealing with Ya'akov's blessing of his children, which also happens later in the Parsha. But here is only spot, where the closing would be noted.

But there is still the matter that the Torah starts the Parsha with Ya'akov lived and sums up his life to the point of his death. It is easy for us to forget but we are live until we die, and there are those that live on through their children, such as our Matriarch Sarah and our Patriarch Ya'akov. From Matriarch Sarah, we learned that our mothers live on through our children, and from Patriarch Ya'akov, our fathers live on through our children. Just has Matriarch Sarah lived on through Yitzchak, her single child, so too, Patriarch Ya'akov lived on through all his children, even when his children had different mothers. There is a single unbroken line drawn from our Patriarchs and Matriarchs to us. So even in death, Ya'akov lives on, for we are named, the nation of Israel, for Israel, who is Ya'akov.

And how does the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet end?
Bereishet 50:26, Yosef died at the age of one hundred and ten, and [the Mitzrim] embalmed him and placed him in [his] coffin in Mitzrayim.
Here again, we see the Torah talking of death, when the Parsha's name means and he lived (). The Vav in means and, telling us that this Parsha is a continuation of the previous Parsha, which in turn was a continuation of the other Parshot.
From here, we know that Yosef never left his father's household. Just as Yosef's entire life was dedicated to following the ways of HaShem, his leadership set an example that later leaders followed.
Both Yosef and Ya'akov reminded the Children of Israel that they were separate from Egypt, and had a destiny that is in the Land of Israel and HaShem is always with us.

Just as HaShem was with the children of Ya'akov in Egypt, so too, HaShem is with us in our current lives. Just as HaShem took us out of Egypt, so too, HaShem will take us out of current exile and return us to our home in Israel, with Mashiach to guide us.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
Tue, Jan 3, 2017 / 6 Tevet 5777 /


Parsha Vayigash /

Sefer Bereishet 44:18 - 47:27

Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

Past Posts: Vayigash 5776, Vayigash 5775, Vayigash 5774, and Vayigash 5773


This week's Parsha Vayigash is the eleventh Parshot of Sefer Bereishet and the eleventh within the fifty-fourth Parshot of the entire Torah.



Parsha Vayigash begins with the confrontation between Yehudah and the Vice-Royal of Egypt, who was secretly Yosef. Yehudah did not know this, but did not allow the fact that the person was the second-most powerful person in all of Egypt stop him. It was a clash of ideals, Yehudah, the chosen of the brothers, and Yosef, the chosen of their father. Yehudah and the brothers believed in remaining a part from other, living among themselves and nature to follow the ways of HaShem. Yosef, in contrast, freely interacted with society and others, while following the ways of HaShem. Our Sages tell us that in exile, Yosef's way takes precedent, when Mashiach comes (speedily), Yehudah's way will have precedent.

entry.title: Parsha Mikeitz
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 28, 2016 / 29 Kislev 5777 /

Parsha Mikeitz /
Sefer Bereishet 41:1 - 44:17
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Mikeitz 5776, Mikeitz 5775, Mikeitz 5774, and Mikeitz 5773

This week's Parsha Mikeitz is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet and the tenth within the fifty-fourth Parshot of the entire Torah.

Bereishet 41:1, It happened at the end of two years
Rabbi Meir of Premishlan writes, Sometimes a person comes to the end of his years, the conclusion of his life, and, from the proper perspective, he finds that he only lived two years he was asleep the rest of the time.
In other words, are you just going through the motions of life, or are you actually active and passionate about what is going on around you? Are you a player in the game of life or spectator? It is so easy to just go with the flow, and yet, for a duck to be kosher, the duck must be healthy enough to swim against the currents. Are you being carried by the water or swimming against it? The Maccabees swim against the currents of their time, and we celebrate their faith and dedication to the Holy Temple, while their military victory was miraculous that is not what we celebrate.
There is a Divine plan that started before Creation and continues through the coming of Mashiach, and everything will happen in accordance with that plan. While Yosef could have been released at any time, the Divine plan was that he was to be released to explain Pharaoh's dream. It happened because Yosef tried to get his own release through ordinary means instead of merely relying upon HaShem to do so. Which is a bit hard for us to understand as our Sages teach us that we should not depend upon a miracle, but need to create a vessel for HaShem's blessings. But then we are not one of the Tribes, whose name rested upon the Cohen HaGadol's breastplate.

Bereishet 41:45, Pharaoh called Joseph, Tzafnat Paneiach
Yalkut David writes, Pharaoh changed Joseph's name because he didn't want his viceroy to have a Jewish sounding name. However, he continued to be called by the name Josef, as it is written in the next verse: And Josef went out from Pharaoh's presence..
Our names are our identities, and we see here that although Yosef was the viceroy of Egypt, he remained Yosef, the Hebrew/Jew, and did not become an Egyptian. Yosef did not allow his glory and honor to blind him to his heritage.
Pharaoh, the height of the secular world at that time, wished for Yosef to join him, just as Antiochus, the height of the secular world in that time, wished the same of the Jews. But just as Yosef stayed true to his father, so the Maccabees (and others) stayed true to their Father in Heaven.


Bereishet 42:1, And Jacob saw that there was food () in Egypt
The Magid of Mezeritch writes, According to Kabbalistic teachings, the world is filled with holy sparks that must be redeemed by the Jewish people through Torah and Mitzvot. These sparks are the result of (literally breaking of the vessels - the Midrashic account of the building and destruction of primordial worlds prior to this one; is similar to ). Jacob, with his prophetic vision, recognized the unusually high number of sparks that had fallen to Egypt, which was the reason for the Egyptian exile.
Our Sages tells us that exile is not a punishment, but an opportunity for us to redeem these sparks of holiness from spaces that we might not reach otherwise.
We only recognize the highs in our lives from having experienced the lows in comparison.

Bereishet 42:9, And he said to them: You are spies
Rabbi Avraham of Pshischa writes, Of all the possible accusations he could level against them, why did Joseph accuse his brothers of espionage? Joseph was afraid his brothers would utilize their visit to Egypt to investigate his whereabouts. By accusing them of being spies, he prevented them from asking too many questions. For no one who is accused of espionage is likely to make too many inquiries about a head of state...
Thus, Yosef could limit his exposure while justifying his inquiry into his brothers and their family. For Yosef knew that he had to control the situation to allow his prophecy-dream to come true. He did not do so for revenge or personal gain, but to follow the Will of HaShem, as he saw it.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeishev
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 21, 2016 / 22 Kislev 5777 /

Parsha Vayeishev /
Sefer Bereishet 37:1 - 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeishev 5776, Vayeishev 5775, Vayeishev 5774, and Vayeishev 5773

This week's Parsha Vayeishev is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet and the ninth within the fifty-fourth Parshot of the entire Torah.

Bereishet 38:1, At that time, Rashi asks, Why is this section placed here and [the Torah thus] interrupted the narrative about Yosef?
