[It is] to teach [us] that [Yehudah's] brothers demoted him from his prominent status when they saw their father's grief. They said [to him], You told [us] so sell [Yosef]. If you would have told [us] to bring him back [home] we would have listened to you.
The narrative of Yosef that is being interrupted is the first stage of the exile, although the brothers did not know that, but they did know what grief they had brought upon Ya'akov, their father.
But why does the Torah interrupt the beginning of the actual exile, as it is Yosef that brings the family down to Egypt? To tell us of Yehudah's first marriage and later marriage to Tamar, whom gave birth to the line that Mashiach descends from.
In other, as the light dims for the House of Israel as the beginning of the first exile is set in motion, HaShem, starts the line that leads to final redemption.

Bereishet 39:2, The Eternal was with Yosef and he was a successful man. Rabbi Simcha Bunim writes, Yosef was close to G-d when things were good for him, even when he was a successful man.
How was Yosef successful in Egypt? For Yosef knew that all that had happened to him was part of the Divine Plan and Yosef walked in the ways of HaShem. Since Yosef was with HaShem, HaShem was with him.

Bereishet 40:1-2, king of Mitzrayim's wine butler and baker [] his two ministers, the chief wine butler and the chief baker.
We see that to the king, these two were mere butler and baker, but to others, they were chief wine butler and chief baker. We can be self-important or humble, it should recalled that before the King of All, we are all the same, but among ourselves, we each have a task to perform and different level of responsibilities that goes along.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 14, 2016 / 15 Kislev 5777 /

Parsha Vayishlach /
Sefer Bereishet 32:4 - 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayishlach 5776, Vayishlach 5775, Vayishlach 5774, and Vayishlach 5773

This week's Parsha Vayishlach is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet an
d the eighth within the fifty-fourth Parshot of the entire Torah.

Bereishet 32:9, then the remaining camp will escape, Rashi adds, against [Esav's] will, for I will fight against him. [Ya'akov] prepared himself for three things: to [give] a present, for prayer and for war to [give] a present, [as it says]: the gift went on ahead of him (v. 22); for prayer, [as it says]: G-d of my [grand]father, Abraham,... (v. 10); for war, [as it says]: then the remaining camp will escape.
Why this three actions? And why this order?
The Sages have discussed this, as we are told that the Sages of Israel would study this Parsha before dealing with Rome (Edom). So this is important.
There are many ways to deal with any issue, and we see that Ya'akov Avinu chose these manners.

What was the gift that Ya'akov sent Esau? It simple terms, it was a bribe. On the surface, this would seem to be very materialistic of Ya'akov, but he was playing on Esau's materialism not his own. We are told by the Sages that HaShem's blessing needs a vessel to carry it, so Ya'akov chose a bribe as a vessel that HaShem should bless him with favor in Esau's eye. It was not merely something to appease Esau's greed but something to carry HaShem's blessing.

Ya'akov understood that while HaShem's blessing is infinite, his gift to Esau was not. Thus, he prayers, directly, to HaShem, thus the vessel is this case was Ya'akov's words themselves, which can hold far more than any materialistic item. In other words, would the material gift not work or be enough, Ya'akov went with a spiritual method to deal with Esau.

And then, Ya'akov prepared for war, for sometimes the answer to our Prayers are not for HaShem to act, but for us to act and be involved. In the first two, the gift left Ya'akov's hand and his prayer left his lips, they were out of Ya'akov's control. But with war, Ya'akov was in control, as they say, in the thick of it.

As all three were needed, we learn that we cannot just send others and just take a pure spiritual approach, and we must immerse ourselves in our challenges. We need to take all three approaches to be successful.

Bereishet 33:18, intact Rashi expounds this, thus, Intact in body, for he was cured of his lameness; intact in his wealth, for he was not lacking anything from [giving] that entire gift [to Esau, for G-d had replaced everything]; [and] intact in his Torah[-learning], for he had not forgotten his learning while in Laban's house.
After everything that HaShem had put Ya'akov through, Ya'akov was not diminished, on the contrary, Ya'akov prospered. I can see this three as symbols of: his lameness as the past, his wealth as the present and his Torah-learning as the future.
Ya'akov followed the path that HaShem had set before him, and was successful. He could have been lame for the entire of his life, but HaShem healed him. He could have been poor, but HaShem replaced what he had to give away. He could have had some mental-condition from the stress, trauma and aggravation, but HaShem protected him. In other words, when we walk the way of HaShem, HaShem, Himself, walks with us, even carrying us when there is need.

Bereishet 36:7, and the land where they lived could not, Rashi tells us, provide sufficient pasture for their animals. But, the Aggadic explanation is: because Ya'akov, his brother (v. 6) [means:] because of the bill of debt of the decree that your descendants will be foreigners [in a land that is not theirs] (15:13), which was imposed upon Yitzchak's descendants. [Esau] said, I shall go away from here. I [wish to] have no part [in this]; not in the gift of this land that was given to him, nor in the payment of the 'bill [of debt]' (i.e. the realization of the decree). And [another reason why he went away was] because of the shame [he felt] by having sold his birthright.
When Rashi provides two explanations, the first is fits the literal text best, while the second fits the spirit of the text.
In other words, it is very likely that Esau told others that his reasoning was what Rashi's first explanation, while Esau, himself, knew it was the second, if only to himself.
In either case, Esau was very big on appearance, thus, he knew that in comparison to Ya'akov, he came out worse. So it was best for his image to start over somewhere distance from his father's home.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
Wed, Dec 7, 2016 / 8 Kislev 5777 /

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Sefer Bereishet 28:10 - 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeitzei 5776, Vayeitzei 5775, Vayeitzei 5774, and Vayeitzei 5773

This week's Parsha Vayeitzei is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Bereishet and the seventh within the fifty-fourth Parshot of the entire Torah.

Bereishet 28:12, Ascending and descending, Rashi asks, [Why does it say about angels, whose permanent home is in Heaven, that they were] first ascending and then descending? [The answer is that] the angels who accompanied him in the Land [of Israel] were not [permitted] to leave the Land and [so] they ascended to Heaven, [whereupon] the angels [who serve] outside the land descended to accompany him.
One can ask, why were there angels in the first place? What function did they serve? After all, Ya'akov Avinu ( ) didn't even know they were there until he had his dream. We know from the story of Abraham and Sodom that an angel can only carry out one function/mission at a time.
Rashi tells us that they were accompanying him in his travels, and yet, until then, Ya'akov Avinu didn't know.
There is a message here.
Many times it seems that circumstance force us to act, such as a vengeful twin brother seeking to kill you and flee the country of your birth, and yet, it is all a part of the Divine plan. Not only was it a part of the Divine plan, but HaShem will ensure the way by having His angels accompany you, irrelevant if you know or not.

Bereishet 29:7, the day is yet young, Rashi comments, Since he saw [the flocks] crouching, he thought that they wished to gather in the livestock and they would no longer graze [that day]. He [therefore] said to them, the day is yet young! as if to say: If you are [daily] hired workers, you have not [yet] finished the day's work, and if the animals are young, nevertheless, It is not time to gather in the livestock...
So what is bothering Rashi here? Why does the Torah even tell us that Ya'akov Avinu mentions this to the shepherds? So we can be prompted to know that the shepherds had gathered not become they were lazy but to draw water. And that to draw water, it required all the shepherds working together to remove the rock that covered the well, which Ya'akov Avinu, miraculous lifted himself. We also get a sense of Ya'akov Avinu character here, as he felt the need to say something to the shepherds.

entry.title: Parsha Toldos
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 30, 2016 / 30 Cheshvan 5777 /

Parsha Toldos /
Sefer Bereishet 25:19 - 28:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Toldos 5776, Toldos 5775, Toldos 5774, and Toldos 5773

This week's Parsha is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet.

Bereishet 25:19, Abraham had fathered Yitzchak. Rashi states, Since the verse wrote: Yitzchak [was] the son of Abraham, it was [also] required to say: Abraham had fathered Yitzchak, because the critics of the generation were saying that Sarah had become pregnant from Avimelch, for she had lived many years with Abraham and had not become pregnant from him. What did the Holy One, Source of Blessing, do [to disprove them]? He made Yitzchak's facial features similar to those of Abraham, and [thus] all could testify that Abraham had fathered Yitzchak. And that is [what is meant by] what is written here: Yitzchak was the son of Abraham for there is evidence that Abraham had [indeed] fathered Yitzchak.
Our Sages say that Abraham represents Chesed (loving-kindness), while Yitzchak represents Gevurah (Character Strength). One would think that being the son of Abraham, Yitzchak would have been a carbon-copy of his father, and yet, he was in fact, something of a seemingly opposite, Chesed is on the right and outward, while Gevurah is on the left and inward. But Chesed follows to Gevurah and Gevurah follows to Chesed, there is a rhythm between them.

Bereishet 25:22, [the children] struggled, Rashi points out, This verse obviously calls for an interpretation, since it does not explain what this struggling was about, [yet] it writes [as Rivkah's reaction]: If this is how it is, (lit.) why did I [need] this? Our Rabbis expounded [the word ] as being an expression of running: When she passed by the entrance of the Torah [academies] of Shem and Ever, Ya'akov would hurry and wriggle to [try and] come out, [and] when she passed by the entrance of [a place of] idol-worship, Esav would wriggle to [try and] come out. Another explanation: They struggled with each other and quarreled over the inheritance of two worlds [this world and the World to Come].
Thus, we see that Ya'akov and Esav were fundamental opposites from conception. Both were Jews, born of Jewish parents. Yitzchak, a Tzadik and son of a Tzadik. While, Rivka was a Tzadikess, but the daughter of a wicked person. There are bits of Ya'akov and Esav in each of us. Ya'akov's service is that of spirituality from heaven to earth. While, Esav's service could have been taking mundane from earth and raising it to heaven. Both are born from Yitzchak and Rivka and Abraham and Sarah.
King David, the prototype Jewish King, and the father of Mashiach, was described has having many of Esav's traits, but unlike Esav that did not fulfill his potential, King David did.

Bereishet 26:12, in that land... in that year Rashi asks, Why are both [mentioned]? To tell [us] that the land was hard and the year was a hard one [and yet he found: a hundredfold increase].
Either situation would have been bad on its own, but together, it was worse. And yet, HaShem's blessing still materialized.
In modern terms, all the data and observations would have shown it was virtually impossible to grow crops in that field and that area, and yet, Yitzchak did not follow logic, but had faith in HaShem, and HaShem rewarded that faith. And that faith was rewarded many times over.
Based solely on science/logic, the Jewish people should have disappeared as ever other nationality throughout history did. But when one has the protect of Heaven, something outside of logic and science, anything is possible.

Bereishet 27:15, that were with her in the house, Rashi points out, Did not have several wives, yet he kept [them] with his mother?! However, [the reason for this was] because he was familiar with their [thieving] practices and was [therefore] suspicious of them.
And yet, Esav married these women, and yet, did not trust them not to rob him. Thus, we see that Esav was more fluffy over substance or appearance over character, and yet, he did not go in blindly, but knew what he was doing.

Bereishet 27:41, the days of mourning for my father will soon come, Rashi states, [Explain this] according to its plain meaning: [I will wait until then] so that I do not cause my father pain. There are, [however, several] Aggadic explanations [that give] various interpretations.
Here, Esav is planning on murdering his very own, twin brother and yet, he does not wish to cause his father pain. In other words, we can see that Esav did try to please and honor his father to his utmost, there was some spark of his heritage there. Esav could have used that spark and changed... and history would be very different. But we do see that as wicked as Esav was, there were sparks of something, which had they been fanned in the right way, could have lead to something that Yitzchak hoped for.

May we merit to see that spark and all Jewish sparks ablaze with the coming of Mashiach, where we will see that even the Esav's of the world are Jews and return to the family, and we will all see and know we are all the children of HaShem and all of humanity is one family.

entry.title: Parsha Chayei Sarah
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 23, 2016 / 23 Cheshvan 5777 /

Parsha Chayei Sarah /
Sefer Bereishet 23:1 - 25:18
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Chayei Sarah 5775, Chayei Sarah 5774, and Chayei Sarah 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Chayei Sarah, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet.

Bereishet 23:4, I am a foreigner and a settler among you to which Rashi expounds, [i.e.] I am a stranger [who came] from a foreign land and I have [now] settled among you. But the Aggadic explanation is: If you agree [to sell me the land] I will [act as] a stranger [and buy it from you], but if not, I will [act as] a settler and take it by right, for the Holy One, Source of Blessing, said to me, I will give this land to your descendants (12:7) Our Sages tell us that this concept, foreigner and settler is one that every Jew should have. We need to remember that first and foremost, we are foreigners, for we are souls, spiritual beings, born from HaShem, Himself. But, we must also remember that we are settlers, souls within bodies, placed here in the physical mundane world to create a place for HaShem amongst the lowest worlds.

Bereishet 24:1, Abraham was old What does the Torah come and teaches us here? After every thing we had read, we know that Abraham was old. Rashi doesn't comment on this seemingly unnecessary wording, so the answer should be obvious. We find in Talmud Baba Metzia 87 that the concept of physical age was unknown until this point, and that Abraham asked for this so that people could distinguish himself from Yitzchak, his son. There is also the concept that the old's thoughts to Heaven at the expense of Earth, but the Torah comes and tells us that Abraham was advanced in years (Bereishet 24:1), he still sought to be a father to Yitzchak and ensured Yitzchak was married. No matter how old our parents are, we are still their children and parents and children love another.

Bereishet 24:10, of his master's camels, Rashi remarks, They ere distinguishable from other camels in that they would go out muzzled [to avoid] stealing so that they would not graze in other people's fields. For Abraham knew that was the entire Land was given to him and his descendants from HaShem, but that did not give him the right to allow his camels to graze in another's field.

Bereishet 24:19, She finished giving him to drink, and then said, I shall also draw water for your camels until they have drunk their fill. Eliezer, the servant of Abraham, had asked HaShem that this would be a sign. Why? For it is one think to have kindness for a person, who could have done so on their own, it is a kindness towards an animal that could not get the water on their own. Some people are kind towards animals, but not people, and some are kind to people but not animal. The second Matriarch of the Jewish People would need to be kind to both, and kind of heart to consider both.

Bereishet 25:6, Abraham gave gifts, Rashi tells us, Our Rabbis explained [that this means] that he transmitted to them a Name of impurity. Another explanation: That which been given to him on account of Sarah and other gifts which were given to him everything he gave to them because he did not want to benefit from [these gifts]. For whatever reason, Abraham, himself, didn't want the items in question, and so he gave them away to those that could use it, instead of mere throwing them away. Everything has its use, whether we know it or not, and sometimes something is given to us, merely to pass it on to others.

Bereishet 25:6, to the eastern land. There are many who note the similarities between the eastern religion of Judaism and the other eastern religions, those that do, note this verse and suggest that these sons of Abraham took with them their father's religion (way of life) and carried it on in India and China.

Bereishet 25:7, one hundred years, seventy years and five years. Rashi points out, [Each unit of his life span is written separately to indicate that] when he was a hundred years old he was like a man of seventy, and at seventy he was like a child of five years old without sin. We need to remember that in those days, people were having children into their seventy, as well as, Divine punishment did not occur until one was over a hundred years old. But even if that was not the case, Abraham was as sinless at a hundred as a five-year old. Just as Sarah's life was divided into three parts, hundred, twenty and seven, so too, was Abraham, hundred, seventy and five.

May we merit to see the sleepers in the Cave of our Forefathers and Foremothers rise with the coming of Mashiach and they can teach us first-hand of what the Torah tells us of their lives.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeira
entry.content:
Wed, Nov 16, 2016 / 16 Cheshvan 5777 /

Parsha Vayeira /
Sefer Bereishet 18:1 - 22:24
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeira 5776 and Vayeira 5773

This week's Parsha is the fourth Parshot in Sefer Bereishet. This is the second Parshot that stars Abraham.

Bereishet 18:1, [The Eternal] appeared to [Abraham], Rashi comments, in order to visit the sick. Rabbi Chama the son of Chanina said: It was the third day after his circumcision [which it is most painful], and the Holy One, Source of Blessing, came and asked after his well-being. Chayenu footnote, The Gemara (Sotah 14a) learns from here the source of the mitzvah of visiting the sick, since we are commanded: You shall follow [the ways of] the Eternal, you G-d (Devarim 13:5). Just as the Holy One, Source of Blessing, visit the sick, so should we visit the sick.

So the Sages all agree that visiting the sick is very important, why? Because HaShem, Himself, did so. But was Abraham really sick? He had just performed a mitzvah of circumcision, and was healing naturally. Physically, Abraham was on the mend, but spiritual....

Spiritually, Abraham was distressed and in that he was sick. For the Torah tells us, he was sitting at the entrance of the tent in the heat of the day. Rashi points out, in the head of the day, was, The Holy One, Source of Blessing, took the sun out of its sheath in order not to bother Abraham with travelers, but because He saw that [Abraham] was upset that no travelers were coming, He brought the angels to him in the form of men. Abraham had worried that people would stop coming by if he circumcised himself, and from Abraham's perspective it seemed the case. Thus, he was spiritually sick that he could not host any guests, until HaShem sent angels disguised as men to visit him.

When HaShem visited Abraham, Abraham was healed, so too, we are told, when we visit a sick person, there is some healing that takes place as well. As we are not HaShem, the healing is not complete, but there is there is still a better difference.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
Thu, Nov 10, 2016 / 10 Cheshvan 5777 /

Parsha Lech Lecha /
Sefer Bereishet 12:1 - 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Lech Lecha 5776, Lech Lecha 5775, and Lech Lecha 5773

This week's Parsha is the third Parshot for Sefer Bereishet.

The previous week the Torah starred Noach, and the previous previous week starred Adam. So why is it that the Torah is now starring yet another person, Avram? Adam is the origin of all of humanity, for none can say they came from a better stock or breed, for we all came from Adam. And yet, the ten generations between Adam and Noach fell into idolatry, so HaShem required to start over, and again, all of humanity is descended from Noach, as from Adam, and Noach's descendants were both righteous and sinners. And then from Noach to Abraham/Avram, we have ten generations, and the start of the Jewish people. Just as the other nations of the world descended from Noach, so too did the Jewish people. Any other people could have done as the Jews, but did not for whatever reason.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
Mon, Nov 7, 2016 / 7 Cheshvan 5777 /

Parsha Noach /
Sefer Bereishet 6:9 - 11:32
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Noach 5776, Noach 5775, Noach 5774, and Noach 5773

Last week's Parsha was Parsha Noach, the second Parshot of Sefer Bereishet.

Bereishet 8:16, Leave the ark you, your wife and your sons and your sons' wives with you. The Midrash, Since he only entered the ark accordingly to G-d's instruction, he waited for G-d's command to leave (Tanchuma 8). The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out that Rashi did not comment on the situation of the animals living in the ark for a year, but Rashi did comment on when the animals came to the ark in a supernatural manner, so that it is logical that they lived in a similar manner. Thus, the Rebbe reasons that Noach didn't wish to leave what was a messianic environment. So he concludes, Nevertheless, G-d told Noach to leave the ark, since his mission in life was not to isolate himself in an atmosphere of holiness, but rather, to be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth! (9:2).

The world was created for a reason, and to accomplish our mission, we need to do so out in the real world, and not isolate ourselves.

entry.title: Parsha Bereishet
entry.content:
Wed, Oct 26, 2016 / 25 Tishrei 5777 /

Parsha Bereishet /
Sefer Bereishet 1:1 - 6:8
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarekhim Cheshvan, Molad: Monday morning, 3:24 am and 5 portions
Past Posts: Bereishet 5773

The Shabbat after Simcha Torah, we renew our reading of the Torah as we finished Vzos HaBeracha and read a bit of Parsha Bereishet, so this Shabbat, we read the full Parsha Bereishet that we previous began.

Bereishet 1:1, In the beginning. Rashi states, Said Rabbi Yitzchak: The Torah [which primarily teaches HaShems commandments] need only have begun [with verse]: This month is to you [the foremost of the months] (Shemos 12:2), which is the first commandment given to [the people of] Yisrael. For what reason, then, does it begin with [the Book of] Bereishet? Because [it wishes to communicate the concept in the verse] The strength of His actions He told His people, to give them the inheritance of the nations (Tehillim 111:6) -- for if the nations of the world were to say to [the people of] Yisrael, You are bandits because you conquered by force the lands of the seven nations [of Kenaan], they will reply, The entire earth belongs to the Holy One, source of blessing, He created it and gave it to whom He saw fit. When He wanted, He gave [this land] to them, and [subsequently] when He wished, He took it away from them and gave it to us.

The obvious question is why does Rashi go at length to tell us what Rabbi Yitzchak said? The Torah is HaShem's guide-book to humanity, and thus, it is a valid question why does a guidebook, a book of laws, start with a story? Rashi could have just said, that HaShem has done so, to proof that the world is His to do as He pleases. And why are the Jews called bandits, is it not the practice of the world that conquest through force is a valid way of claiming a land? People fight over land, since the dispersion that is recorded in next week's Parsha. Because the Jews in Joshua's time did not use conventional weapons to take possession of the land, but transformed it from the land of seven nations to the Holy Land. Once that took place, although others would conquer the land, the area would still be the Holy Land and the Land of Israel move it outside of the mundane, forever out of the reach of others. How did the Jews do this? Because HaShem willed it so.

entry.title: Parsha Vzos HaBeracha
entry.content:
''
Thu, 20 October 2016 / 18 Tishri 5777 / '' ''

Pasha Vzos HaBeracha / 
Sefer Devarim 33:1 -- 34:12
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
----
Past Posts: Vzos HaBeracha 5776 and Vzos HaBeracha 5773
----

This Parsha is read on Simcha Torah, which is this coming Tuesday, and not on Shabbat. This is also the last Parshot of the Sefer Devarim, thus, on Simcha Torah, we read this Parsha and the first aliyah of Parsha Bereisheit.

Devarim 33:1, "And this the blessing [...] before he died", Rashi points out, this was "quite near this death, "For", he said, "if not now, when?" (Sifri)." Why did Moshe wait until "now" to blessing the nation? For he followed the example of Jacob, our Father, who rebuked and blessed the Tribes from his death bed. And why this? So that if one is embarrassed, then one would not meet this person again to be more embarrassed. Also, as one is nearing the "end" of one's life here, their thoughts are directed towards Heaven, and thus we can assume that want they have to say is more spiritual than material in nature.

Devarim 33:2, "He said the Eternal came [out] of Sinai", Rashi remarks, "First he began with praise for the Omnipresent, and only afterwards did he begin with what concerned Yisrael; but in the praise of G-d with which he began there is also mention of Yisrael's merit. All this was by way of intercession, as though to say, "These are worthy that blessing should rest upon them" (Sifri)." What was bothering Rashi here? The opening of the Parsha said that Moshe Rabbeinu was going to bless the nation, then the very next verse (this verse) talks of HaShem and His glory. So the question might be asked, why the "change?" To which Rashi tells us that, before anything we should praise HaShem, for Whom it is due, And in blessing HaShem, one also blesses His nation. For HaShem and His nation are one.

Devarim 33:2, "some of the tens of thousands of holy [angels]", Rashi states, "i.e. and with Him were a part of the myriads of the holy angels, and not all of them and not even majority of them; not as is in the way of a human being who displays all the splendor of this riches and magnificence on his marriage day (Sifri)." The obvious question is what does this tell us? "Some" but not all, and we do not even know the count of angels there are, but comes the Torah tells us that this "tens of thousands" is not the majority, but a small number, as HaShem is using modesty and humility. Something that human beings are prone to do. In truth, HaShem does not need anyone, so why was it mentioned, to tell us the above.

Devarim 33:5, "And the tribes of Israel are together". The Lubavitcher Rebbe tells us, "Unity is achieved not by all constituent elements of a group becoming a life, but by each one fulfilling its unique purpose and acknowledging the necessity and contribution of all the other constituent elements." Each Jew has a mission for that individual to fulfill in their own way that is aligned with the national-level mission for all Jews. It is the diversity of the Jewish people that allows us to take different elements of society and life and forge them together to build a home for HaShem here on Earth. Every Jew is vital and their uniqueness is pivotal to their role. We cannot all be Moshe Rabbeniu's, nor can we all be water-bearers, for society to function. Just as complicated items are composed of multiple simple items, so too, the nation of Israel is composed of various Jews, each with their unique talents and assignments, all equal important and vital to the whole.

Devarim 33:8, "To Levi he said," the Rebbe writes, "The quality that enables the Tribe of Levi archieve this joy is their absolute devotion to G-d -- even to the extent of self-sacrifice, as mentioned in this very passage. Self-less devotion to G-d enables us to ascertain His will unencumbered by personal agendas or predispositions." When there is no doubt, one can enjoy confidence in what one needs to do. Doubt can and does hold us back and makes us feel terrible, like a dreary night with rain. But once that doubt is lifted, and a clear path/destination is available, we feel like the Sun as come out and shined upon us. And how much more so, when it's not the sun, but HaShem that shines upon us.

Devarim 33:17, "The myriads of Ephraim and the thousands of Manasseh". The Rebbe points out that Manasseh "symbolizes our awareness of our origins" and "In contrast, Ephraim symbolizes our awareness of how G-d has blessed us with powers beyond those with which we are endowed naturally". Thus, while we should not forget our origins, represented by Manasseh, we need to act like "Ephraim", understanding that "Our confidence in G-d's supernatural assistance elicits His infinite bounty, which we draw both into our world and into our own lives." With HaShem's help, we can do anything, even things that are "supernatural" if only we trust in HaShem and His mercy.

Devarim 34:5, "Moses, the servant of G-d, died". The Rebbe reminds us, "Moses' continued existence in this world is embodied in the Jewish religious leaders of each generation, whose bodies house a manifestation of his soul. This is similar to how we saw that Jacob live on in body of his descendants who remain loyal to his spiritual legacy." Just as Jacob laid the foundation of the physical body of the nation of Israel, so Moses brought the Torah, the spiritual foundation for the Jewish spiritual body.
Thus, both "live" on when we see the Jewish nation. We have carried the Torah, the Books of Moses, for literally, thousands of years, and our identity is tied up in the other. Which is truly expressed on Simcha Torah, for the Torah cannot dance on its own. And what is a Jew without Torah? Thus, on Simcha Torah we dance around with the Torah, showing our appreciation and continued learning of the Torah.

May the ultimate expression of joy and happiness come to us, the coming of Mashiach, when doubt will be lifted and all can see HaShem and His ways, speedily in our days soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Ha'azinu
entry.content:
Wed, Oct 12, 2016 / 11 Tishrei 5777 /

Parsha Ha'azinu /
Sefer Devarim 32:1 - 32:52
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ha'azinu 5776, Ha'azinu 5774, and Ha'azinu 5773

This week's Parsha is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Devarim and next to last Parsha, Parsha Vezot Haberakhah ( ), which is read on Simcha Torah.

Devarim 32:2 And the rain as the dew, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The extent to which rain falls depends upon on our merits, whereas the extent of which dew condenses is not. Thus, rain and dew allude to the two aspects of Divine revelations that we receive when we study Torah: one is commensurate with our efforts and similar to them, whereas the second is a Divine gift beyond both the intensity and nature of our effects. The water we have comes to us in two forms, rain and dew. But are water, and yet, they are different. Torah is like to water, so we have rain and dew as the Rebbe says, representing two forms of Divine revelation. Rain which we need to pray for, and dew, which happens without prayer. Regardless of its form, water is vital to our survival. We can do nothing and still get the dew, but is dew enough for us? Dew is the minimum of water. Whether as rain can come in different amounts and styles. Rain can be gentle, part of a storm or make a flood. Rain provides us more than enough water and sometimes too much. But then, that is where the metaphor of Torah, doesn't really come in, as there is not truly too much Torah study for its own sake. Although, one could get lost in Torah study and miss out on what is happening outside. Even the simplest of us, can get something out of Torah, some rain, along with the dew.

Devarim 32:13, He made them ride on the highest place of earth, the Rebbe tells us, G-d has made the Jewish people, as well as each individual Jew, above the limitations of physical reality. We are therefore, by nature, able to influence and affect the word. As we are not a part of the limitation, we are outside and can influence it from without. We can also be examples to others inside the physical reality to show there exist more than just the mere physical, but that the spiritual reality exists and interacts with the physical as well.

entry.title: Parsha Vayelech
entry.content:
Wed, Oct 5, 2016 / 4 Tishri 5777 /' ''

Parsha Vayelech /
Sefer Devarim 31:1 - 31:30
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayelech 5775, Nitzavim-Vayelech 5774, Nitzavim-Vayelech 5773, and Vayelech 5772

This week's Parsha is read during Shabbat Shuva, the Shabbat between Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur, the Ten Days of Teshuvah.

Devarim 31:2, I can no longer go and come. The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out that [...] something was missing from his [Moshe's] abilities was a signal that it was time to pass the leadership on to Joshua. Even though this lack was not directly related to leadership, it was still a sign to Moshe. The Rebbe tells us, We should consider every iota of knowledge of the Torah that we can possibly imbibe to be essential to our effective fulfillment of our Divine mission.
So how does this relate to Teshuvah? The theme of the week (well Ten Days between and including Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur)?
The literal meaning of the word teshuvah is return. So our Sages say that when we sin, we distance ourselves from HaShem, and through Teshuvah, we return or draw closer to HaShem (again). Thus, the very first step to Teshuvah is; recognizing that we lack something, identifying what that something is, and finding/obtaining it. The recognition and identification can be done through Torah study and self-examination. The Torah is literally the blue-print of Creation, and everything is within its mysteries. Through Torah, we know what HaShem expects from us and how we can find those missing pieces or repair what broke. It is not an easy process, there is a reason why there are ten days, a week and three days, for Teshuvah at the beginning of the new year.

Devarim 31:6, Neither fear nor be discouraged. The Rebbe remarks, The Jewish people, both in Moses's time and in our own time, have witnessed how they have survived miraculously, in the face of seemingly irresistible enemies and unsurmountable odds. We have seen how, in the words of this very verse, G-d is the one who goes with you; He will neither fail you nor forsake you. We must of course employ every natural means at our disposal to outsmart and outfight our enemies, but in the final analysis we must not deny the openly miraculous nature of how we receive Divine assistance and protection. The Rebbe continues that This holds true on the personal level [...]
The obvious connection to Teshuvah is there, HaShem is with us, both as a nation and as individuals. Just as HaShem helps us against our physical enemies, so too, HaShem helps us with our spiritual enemies and our spiritual faults. HaShem is there with the repentant, helping us to return to Him. HaShem has love for us, wants our return and morns our deaths. We should never fear that we have sinned too greatly or we have sinned too much that we should be discouraged from returning. HaShem knows us, inside and outside, and wants our relationship with Him to continue, thus providing assistance in knowledge and lending a hand to support us along the way.

Devarim 31:20, Flowing with milk and honey The Rebbe states, Since the Torah forbids the consumption of blood, and we are taught that the milk produced by mammals is derived from their blood, it would seem that milk should be forbidden for consumption. Furthermore, the Torah allows the consumption of any part of an animal only when the animal has first been properly ritually slaughtered, whereas milk issues from the animal before slaughtering, so on this account it should be also be forbidden. Nevertheless, the Torah does permit the consumption of milk, as evidenced in this verse and the many others where this expression occurs.
The permissibility of milk, despite its forbidden origins, alludes to the process of repentance, through which something negative a sin is transformed into something positive the impetus of renewing and strengthening our bond with G-d.

entry.title: Parsha Nitzavim
entry.content:
Wed, Sep 28, 2016 / 25 Elul 5776 / 5776

Parsha Nitzavim /
Sefer Devarim 29:9 - 30:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Nitzavim 5775, Nitzavim-Vayelech 5774, Nitzavim-Vayelech 5773, and Nitzavim 5772

This week's Parsha is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim 29:9-11, You all standing... the leaders... elders... young children... in order that you enter into a covenant with G-d The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out, In these verses, we are told that this covenant was made with all of us very type of Jew, without regard to status, gender, or age. [] We must therefore realize that regardless of our background or sophistication, the entire Torah is relevant us in a way that we can understand and appreciate [...]
Thus, the Torah is a heritage for every Jew, no exception. The Torah is Divine, and able to reach every Jew, in their own way. We are therefore reminded just before Rosh HaShanah, where the entire world, from the arch-angels to the microbes in the ocean are judged. Whereas even the arch-angels are but robots, Humanity moves from level to level, up and down. And the Torah is there to guide us, ever higher. When every Jew stands for HaShem, all our differences disappear and peace is realized.
Our Sages ask why does Moshe say You all standing, because many were afraid after hearing all the curses of the previous Parsha, so Moshe Rabbeinu reminds them that we are all still here, after the sin of the golden calf, the ten spies, the exiles, the pogroms, and the wars. We remain standing, why? For we are in covenant with HaShem. We are His people, and He is our God. Before Him, we are His children and He loves us unconditionally.

Devarim 29:14, And with those who are not here with us today Rashi states, i.e. with the generations that will be in future (i.e. Moshe is not referring to people who happened to be absent from the assembly, for it states, v. 10, that all were present: You are standing this day all of you before HaShem) (Midrash Tanchuma) Thus, we, ourselves, were parties to this covenant, so we have a direct relationship with HaShem. Unlike the other nations of the world, they are guided through guardian angels. The nation of Israel does not have a mere guardian angel, but HaShem, Himself, stands for us. We stand on Rosh HaShanah, as members of the covenant and knowing of Hashem's love for us. It is for that, that we pray

Devarim 28:15, Because you know how we dwelt in Egypt. Rebbe tells us, [...] Conscious of our absolute, G-d-given freedom, we will never be slaves to any form of negativity or evil. We can freely choose to ignore the voices both from within and from without that urge us to go against G-d's will or conform to the norms of Egyptian society.
Our Sages point out that the Hebrew word for Egypt, Mitzrayim, is actually the word, meitzarim, meaning constraints. Thus, the Rebbe is telling us that HaShem has freed us from the spiritual constraints of the world, so that while the majority of the nations are non-Jewish, we part from them to be Jewish. Each nation of the world has their own path to follow. The path for the Jews is Torah.

Devarim 30:3, will bring back. The Rebbe remarks, [...] We are taught that whatever God asks us to do, He Himself does. Thu, when God sends us into exile, He also sends Himself, so to speak, into exile with us. We are not alone. Nor have we been abandoned. The covenant remains unbroken. We are Jews, our parents are Jews, and our children will be Jews. The Torah is eternal, for HaShem is eternal. When the time or conditions are right, HaShem will leave this exile and take us with Him.

Devarim 30:10, When you return to G-d. The Rebbe reminds us, The Ba'al Shem Tov taught us that by returning to G-d, especially during times of trouble, we transform the trouble into Divine revelation.
Our Sages tells us that nothing evil comes from Heaven, everything that HaShem does is for the good. We see only see that the trouble we faced, was in fact, mere a stepping stone to raise us higher and understand more,

And when Mashiach comes, our understanding will be greater and we will see all the good that HaShem has blessed us with. We will look back and see all the pieces of the puzzle of life and finally know how they all fit. May the coming Mashiach come soonest, a new year, a new redemption, and a new peace.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Savo
entry.content:
Wed, Sep 21, 2016 / 18 Elul 5776 / 5776

Parsha Ki Savo / -
Sefer Devarim 26:1 - 29:8
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Savo 5775, Ki Savo 5774, Ki Savo 5773, and Ki Savo 5772

This week's Parsha is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Devarim. There are a total of twelve Parshot to Sefer Devarim, although the last Parshot, Parsha Vzos Haberacha, is read on Simcha Torah.

Devarim 26:1, When you enter the land that G-d, your G-d, is giving you. The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out that Allegorically, the notion of 'coming into the land' alludes to the descent of the soul into the body, and this descent is, of course, for the ascent of the soul, to do Mitzvot and loving-kindness on this world, to elevate the soul into a level higher of Divine revelation.
We forget that the goal we strive for, is creating a home for HaShem, here within the mundane and physical world. This is something that the Angels cannot do, for they are purely spiritual and have no concept of the mundane; and the animals cannot do it, for they are purely physical and no have no concept of the spiritual, only Humanity has both the concept and abilities of both of the spiritual and the mundane. It is our job to show that the physical and spiritual are not separated, but unified like their Creator.
Just as each People were assigned their own lands by HaShem, so too, each individual are assigned their own task. It is all planned out and overseen by HaShem. The dips in our lives are only to help us to lift us even higher.

Devarim 26:13, I have also given to the Levite, the Rebbe tells us, The Torah tells us to take 'some of' our first fruits. This indicates that there are 'first fruits' that are not given to the priest but remain at home. They, too, must be elevated to holiness such that it is evident to all that this produce was fit to be given to G-d.
These 'first fruits', while in Torah are limited to the seven species that bless the Land of Israel, we should also relate to any fruit of our labor. We can take a mere fruit, and elevate it by following the ways of HaShem. We need to remember that it was HaShem that made the seed, gave plants the ability to grow and provide for others. Our part in gardening is rather small and even unnecessary, and yet, HaShem allows us to take part and even benefit from His works. And we need to remember that it is His works, and be worthy of the gifts and talents He has given us.

Devarim 27:8, Very clearly Rashi explains this to mean, in seventy languages (Sota 32a; cf. Rashi on 1:5). Why seventy languages? For there are seventy nations/races of Man, each with their own language, because of the Towel of Babel. Thus, the Torah, which is in Hebrew (the original language), was to be translated into the (other) seventy languages that existed. The Rebbe offers this insight, expressing the Torah's concepts in secular idioms allows the sanctity and message of the Torah to permeate even those layers of existence that are a priori antithetical or antiagonistic to Divine consciousness.
Thus, we can discuss Torah concepts here in English, and reach out to others whom Hebrew isn't their native language.

Devarim 28:2, All the following blessings will pursue you and overtake you. The Rebbe states, this implies that even if we are foolish enough to flee from G-d's blessings, they will overtake us, and will receive them even against our will.
To me this seems to say, if you accidentally invoke a blessing without meaning to or knowing, HaShem will still reward you. We might feel we are unworthy of HaShem's love and blessings, but HaShem will still carry out His good.
Our Sages tells us that any prophecy of good-tidings will always come true, regardless of what happens, while a prophecy of ill-tidings can be stopped by teshuvah (repentance), tzedakah (charity) and tefillah (prayer). Here we see the power of blessing, you do not even have to search or run after it, it will find you with no effort on our part.

Devarim 28:9, and walk in His ways. The Rebbe points out that before the soul goes to the body, the soul is kind of just sitting there. In contrast, once the soul has entered the body and is able to study Torah and perform the commandments, it is able to move towards G-d with quantum leaps. This ability enables the individual to 'walk,' to truly progress in his relationship with G-d.
While in the spiritual realm, the soul does not move, only clothed with a body can the soul move or walk, and those movements are studying Torah and doing HaShem's will.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Seitzei
entry.content:
''
Wed 14 Sep 2016 / 11 Elul 5776 / '' ''
Parsha Ki Seitzei /
Sefer Devarim 21:10 - 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Seitzei 5775, Ki Seitzei 5774, Ki Seitzei 5773 and Ki Seitzei 5772

This week's Parsha is the sixth of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim: 21:10, If you go out to [an optional] war. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The primary spiritual war that we are all required to fight is the battle to rid ourselves of whatever evil resides within us. Thur, part of our Divine mission is to vanquish evil in the world at large, but our ability to succeed in this struggle is directly proportional to how successful we have been in subjugating and eliminating our own personal evil. The theatre of our inner spiritual battle with evil is daily prayer, in which we strive to empower our Divine souls over our human-animal souls. The Zohar does not mince words in this regard: The time of prayer is a time of battle. (Zohar 3:243a)
This being the case, what is the spiritual correlate to the optional war? Are we not obligated to confront every instance of evil we perceive within ourselves?
The answer is yes, but there is another way to eliminate evil besides the direct confrontation characteristics of prayer: Torah study. Studying the Torah fills out consciousness with Divine awareness can largely dissipate the evil within us. Whereas the direct confrontation in prayer requires strenuous effort, the effect of Torah study is virtually automatic, for its ways are ways of pleasantness and all its paths are peace. (Proverbs 3:17)
Thus, whenever there is an option to do away with evil peacefully, through Torah study, taking the alternate route that of direct engagement of prayer becomes an optional war. Eliminating evil through Torah study obviates the need to battle evil in prayer, transmuting prayer into the simple, serene expansion of Divine consciousness.
There are many ways we can accomplish our individual Divine mission, at no time, should we feel we are alone or poorly equipped. In either case, prayer or study, we are assisted by Heaven and those that came before us. In prayer, we have the words and formulas created by the Prophets and Sages, and the melodies of our souls. In study, we have the Mishna, the Talmud, Rashi, Rambam, and many others, who had labored over the words and concepts of Torah, and the desire of our Divine soul to reunite with the Divine.

Devarim 22:4, You must not see your brother's ox or sheep straying and ignore them The Rebbe tells us, Allegorically, the missing ox or sheep alludes to elements that are lacking from a fellow Jew's observance or the Torah and its commandments. The Torah tells us here that our Jewish nature will not allow us to ignore this shortcoming in our fellow; it will compel us to help him.
This is true even when, as the next verse continues, your brother is not near you, or you do not know him. Even in such cases, we must help our fellow Jews retrieve whatever spiritual wealth they have lost due to their inadvertent over-involvement in the mundane affairs of the material world. Furthermore, if necessary, we must educate these compatriots to value this spiritual treasure, until your brother seeks it out willingly.
The Torah is an inheritance for the entire House of Jacob, and it is a Divine wisdom presented to us in a form for us to study and learn from. This world was not created for us to be alone, but for us to work together, to harmonize the spiritual and the mundane together into a cohesive whole. We instinctively know this, feel this, and actualize this, by helping others when we realize they are having some issue. That we learned such things, do such things, is for the sake of Heaven and to help others. Just as a parent helps a child to learn, so too, a teacher helps their students. In teaching, one refines our own knowledge and gains wisdom on the matter.

Devarim 24:9, Remember what G-d did to Miriam, The Rebbe remarks, It is important to realize that Miriam did not lie or even criticize Moses. She merely voiced her disapproval of his behavior without bothering to discuss her grievances with him privately first. Nonetheless, she was immediately punished for having spoken against him.
This teaches us how careful we must always be when talk (or write) about other people. Even seemingly harmless discussion can easily slip into gossip or slander. Rather, we should always be careful to speak and write constructively. If someone's behavior seems inappropriate, we should clarify matters with them privately, thereby sparing everyone the grief that inevitably results from misunderstanding.
Miriam, herself, was one of the seven known Prophetess, sister to Moses and Aharon, and a learned person in her own right. She was just talking with her brother, Aharon, also a prophet and HaShem's Chosen Cohen HaGadol ( ). The problem was that she did so in public nor did she first consulting with Moses on why he was doing as he had done. When in public, we need to watch what we say, for once the words leave our mouth, they are but feathers upon the wind going all over the place.

entry.title: Parsha Shoftim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Sep 8, 2016 / 5 Elul 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Shoftim /
Sefer Devarim 16:18 21:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shoftim 5775, Shoftim 5774, Shoftim 5773 and Shoftim 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shoftim, the fifth Parshot of Sefer Devarim. It is only happens to be the first Parshot read during Elul. Shoftim is Hebrew for Judges, which is appropriate given we are in the period of the King is in the field and heading toward Rosh HaShanah, which is the Day of Judgment.

Last week, we read that HaShem gives us the choice between blessing and curse and this week, we read about the various leadership within the Jewish people. The prototype being judges, for there are times when there are no kings or prophets, and times where the Cohenim are not available, but there will still be judges available. To be a king or a Cohen, is something we are born with, something up to HaShem. To be a prophet, requires very special circumstances and something that in the modern age no possible, per se. And yet, with some Torah studying and abilities everyone is born with, anyone can become a judge.

Devarim 16:18, You must appoint judges and sheriffs for yourself in all your cities. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The Hebrew word for cities used here (she'arecha) literaly means gates. The gates of our bodies are our ears, eyes, nose, and mouth, through which stimuli from the external world enter our bodies and our personal world. This verse thus requires us to station judges and sheriffs to guard these gates against the intrusion of any stimuli that could be harmful to our spiritual health. Through studying the Torah, we learn which influences are beneficial (And therefore permitted) and which are harmful (and therefore forbidden). The job of the sheriff is to enforce the decisions rendered by the judge. Our inner sheriffs are the techniques tat each of us needs to cultivate in order to combat the voices within us that oppose the decisions of our inner judges.
Thus, regarding the Messianic future, G-d only promises to restore your judges as in former times, but not the sheriffs. In the Messianic future, negativity will not hold sway over us, so there will be no need for protective measures to ensure that we follow G-d's will.
As the saying goes, you only get out what you put in, therefore, if we will to get out Kosher, we need to put in Kosher. How do we do this, by making sure (judging) what goes in is Kosher. We can only choice the blessings that HaShem has laid before us, if we can properly understand and see that is good. There are bad/evil things in the world, that many accept as necessary, because in part, it was gradually introduced slowly in an incremental way. But if we place judges at our gates, we can stop the outside influence of negativity from affecting us, much like closing the gate to protect a city would.

Devarim 19:15, You may indeed appoint a king over yourself, whom G-d chooses. The Rebbe tells us, Although the Jewish people have not had a king since the destruction of the first Temple and will not have another until the Messiah himself, we are still enjoined to appoint a higher authority over ourselves, both, individually and collectively, when ever relevant.
The sages therefore say to each one of us: Provide yourself a teacher [of Torah], with whom we should consult on all matters of spiritual life. We should not delude ourselves into thinking that we can rely on our own judges and sheriffs. Nor should we think that there is no one capable of understanding us sufficiently to server as our king. The Torah assures us that if we search properly and diligently, we will indeed find the mentors best suited for our spiritual needs.
In Parsha Yisro, Moshe's father-in-law, Yisro, tells Moshe to establish a court of judges, over ten, over a hundred, over a thousand, and so on, with the Sanhedrin being the highest court. Just as there were the smallest court, those over ten, and the highest, the Sanhedrin. We, too, need to have our own set of judges; ourselves, a teacher, their teacher, and so on. Just none of the judicial courts were independent and by themselves, so too, our inner judges should not be by themselves as well.

entry.title: Parsha Re'eh
entry.content:
''
Thu, Sep 1, 2016 / 28 Av 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Re'eh /
Sefer Devarim 11:26 16:17
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Re'eh 5774, Re'eh 5773, and Re'eh 5772

This week's Parsha is the fourth Parshot of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim 11:26, See, I set before you today a blessing and a curse. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, A Divine curse is actually a blessing that is too great to be revealed within our limited world and must therefore be disguised as a curse. Our challenge is to see it in this perspective, rather than falling into the trap of becoming angry with G-d. Thus, pain and negativity exist in order to provide us with free choice. Free choice, in turn exists in order to enable us to earn the rewards for our choices, so we need not feel unworthy of the blessings that G-d bestows upon us.
When we recognize that evil exists solely to provide us with the free choice to reject it, our struggle with it becomes much easier.
Our Sages tells us that only good comes from Heaven, and that evil/corrupt comes from Man.

Devarim 13:4, G-d is testing you to determine whether you really love G-d with all your heart and all your soul. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, We are tested when we witness a lack of Divine favor that we assume is entitled to those who follow G-d's will. Voices from both within and without mock the sufferer's naive belief. When G-d's presence is hidden in these situations, it simply means that He wishes to grace us with a closer, more intense relationship with Him. In order to preserve our faith in G-d in the face of situations that test this faith, we have to draw upon deeper levels of commitment than we normally do.
When we pass the test, the test disappears its purpose having been served and our formerly deep, hidden connection with G-d becomes our new normative consciousness.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
''
Fri, Aug 26, 2016 / 22 Av 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Eikev /
Sefer Devarim 7:12 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarekhim Elul, Molad: Friday morning, 1:56 am and 3 portions
Past Posts: Eikev 5775, Eikev 5774, Eikev 5773, and Eikev 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Eikev, which is the third Parshot of Sefer Devarim. The Shabbat we read the second of seven Haftarahs of Comfort.

Devarim 7:12, If you heed [HaShem's] ordinances, safeguard them, and perform them... The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, If G-d were to bestow His goodness on us even when we do not deserve it, He would not be doing us any favors. First, we would feel like little children who parents overlook their infantile behavior because adult behavior cannot be expected of them. Worse yet, it would undermine our belief in Divine justice. We would thus live lives of shame and confusion.
The rewards for observing G-d's commandments are so great that they are out of proportion to the effort required to fulfill them.
Nonetheless, for the above-stated reasons, G-d made the bestowal their reward dependent upon our efforts, and the bestowal of their infinite reward dependent upon effort that specifically mirrors their infinite, unlimited nature.
Therefore, we must take care to fulfill the seemingly less-important commandments with the same devotion with which we fulfill the seemingly more-important ones. This shows that what matters to us is that G-d wants us to observe these commandments, not our own evaluation of which ones are important. G-d then bestows His goodness upon us beyond the strict dictates of what we have earned.
Notice the order that Moshe tells us to follow: heed, safeguard and then perform. If we but just heed HaShem, the reward is goodness... heed and safeguard, but not perform, the reward is greater... and the greatest is doing all three, heed, safeguard and perform. In doing HaShem's will, we connect with the infiniteness of HaShem, Himself, we move beyond our finite existence. It is that tapping that allows HaShem to reward us greater than our perspective would suggest. As well as, our realization that what we might think of as seemingly minor, can be more.

Devarim 8:17, you say to yourself, 'It is my own strength, and the might of my hands that have accumulated this wealth for me.' Rebbe remarks, Children often surpass their parents in many ways, even though they inherited their talents and abilities from their parents. The reason that children can manifest capabilities their parents do not seem to posses is because these talents remained dormant in the parents and only became active in their children.
Similarly, G-d calls the Jewish people His children. He has indeed left it up to us to bring the world to its completion, granting us a measure of power that He has relinquished. Thus, when we accomplish something that helps bring the world closer to its ultimate fulfillment, we might mistakenly ascribe this accomplishment to our own power.
Therefore, the Torah reminds us that just as children owe their superior powers to their parents, from whom they inherited them, so should we recall that we owe all our power to accomplish great things in this world exclusively to G-d.
When we come upon the conclusion of an activity or task, we tend to forgot all the trials and tribulations that we needed to go through in order to get to the end-point. We especially tend to forget that it is HaShem, who created our start-point, journey and end-point. It is HaShem who crafts the paths we walk, in accordance with our abilities and talents. Very few that cross the finish-line look back over the race-course. Those obstacles and hurdles along the way, where only to push us further and set our pace.

Devarim 9:17, I grasped the two tablets and hurled them from my two hands, shattering them before your eyes. Rebbe tells us, Moses was already carrying the two tablets, so he had no need to grasp them in order to break them. He grasped them as a gesture of ownership; he wanted to acquire them as his own personal property in order to assume full blame for breaking them.
We see here Moses' selfless devotion to the Jewish people. Not only did him he break the tablets in order to destroy the evidence of the Jewish people's covenant with G-d that they had just broken. Not only was he willing to give up his life in order that G-d forgive the Jewish people. He even took upon himself the blame for breaking the tablets. And let us recall that Moses had absolutely no part in the incident of the Golden Calf he was not even guilty of not trying to prevent it, since he was not present when it took place!
Moses' example is a lesson for all of us, for we are all leaders. We all are responsible for each other whether in the circle of the family, of our friends, of our associates, of the Jewish people, or of all humanity. We should be ready and willing to give up whatever necessary our resources, our reputations, even our lives in order to ensure the survival of the Jewish people and the furtherance of our Divine mission to transform the world into G-d's true home.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eschanan
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 18, 2016 / 14 Av 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Va'eschanan / 
Sefer Devarim 3:23 7:11
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Nachamu / 
Past Posts: Va'eschanan 5775,Va'eschanan 5774, Va'eschanan 5773 and Va'eschanan 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Va'eschanan, which is the second Parshot of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim 3:23, I entreated (). Rashi points out to us, [The word] [and its derivatives] in all cases is an expression signifying [requesting] a free gift. Even though the righteous may base a request on the merit of their good deeds, they request only a free gift of the Omnipresent. Because God had said to him [Moses],and I will favor () when I wish to favor () (Shemos 33:19), he [Moses], he spoke to Him [G-d], using the expression . Another explanation: This () is one of ten terms which denote prayer (Sifrei). It is interesting to note there are ten terms just for prayer. Which shows how important prayer is and prayer's many functions.

Devarim 3:27, You will not cross this Jordan River, The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Had Moses himself led the people into the Promise Land, their entry would have been miraculous: they would have been led by the Clouds of Glory and the pillar of fire, and the nations occupying the land would have offered no resistance. But since Joshua lead them, the Israelites had to battle the Canaanites nations without relying on open miracles, and were therefore required to evince self-sacrifice. They had to summon their deepest inner strength and dedication to their purpose in order to win the wars.
This is the inner reason why G-d did not allow Moses to cross the Jordan River along with the Jewish people. Our purpose is to reveal Divinity to the greatest extent possible in the world, and this was accomplished more profoundly when we demonstrated our unshakable dedication to our Divine mission that it would have been had this demonstration not been necessary.
Similarly, when confronted with challenges, we should always embrace them with this thought in mind. We give value to something in proportion to the effort involved, what comes easy, we value little, what takes blood, sweat and tears, we find precious. Thus, by having the Jews under Joshua conquer the land through mortal efforts, gave a high value to the land, which would be missing had Moses does the same with miracles.
If someone tells of something we have no experience with, we cannot fully appreciate it until we can experience it for ourselves. Miracles are something that we cannot truly experience save within the moment. Military campaigns, on the other hand, we can see on TV, read in a book, and unfortunately, be involved in.

Devarim 4:41, Three cities, the Lubavitcher Rebbe tells us, Allegorically, the study of Torah is our city of refuge. This is alluded to by the fact that in order for a city to be considered a city in Jewish law, there must be at least ten people living in it who do nothing all day other than study the Torah. The requisite number ten alludes to the ten powers of the soul (three intellectual, three emotional, three behavioral, and one of expression), indicating that in order for the Torah to function as a city of refuge for us, we must immerse ourselves in it fully, with all ten powers of our soul. Furthermore, the word of refuge () literally means absorption; thus, we must not only immerse ourselves in the Torah; we must fully absorb and internalize its message.
The Torah can shelter us and protect us when we accidentally do wrong, much like the City of Refuge would for an accidentally killer. Just as one would need to stay within the city for a certain period of time, so too, one needs to stay within Torah.

entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
''
Fri, Aug 12, 2016 / 8 Av 5776 /' ''

Parsha Devarim /
Sefer Devarim 1:1 3:22
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Chazon /
Past Posts: Devarim 5775, Devarim 5774, Devarim 5773 and Devarim 5772


This week's Parsha is Parsha Devarim, which is the first Parshot of Sefer Devarim. Parsha Devarim is the name-sake of this blog that I began back on July 26 2012. It is now, Aug 12, 2016, four years later.

Parsha Devarim and the entire Sefer Devarim is probably the most important Parshot/Sefer in the entire Torah/Tenakh. The first four Sefot of the Torah are HaShem's words dictated to Moshe word for word. But with Sefer Devarim, Moshe took the words from HaShem and express those words in his own words, which is what future prophets would do. It is in Sefer Devarim where we really see the prophet Moshe doing his prophecy. Although, the first four Sefot do show Moshe's uniqueness.

Devarim 1:1, These are the words, Rashi writes, Since these are words of rebuke and he [Moses] enumerates here all the places where they angered the Omnipresent, therefore it makes no explicit mention of the incidents [in which they transgressed], but rather merely alludes to them, [by mentioning the names of the places] out of respect for Israel (cf. Sifrei). Here we learn that when one rebukes, one has to be very careful and loving-kind in doing. If Moshe Rabbeinu needed to be so careful upon saying his 'last will', how much more so do we.

Devarim 2:5, [I have given Mount Seir] to Esau for an inheritance. Rashi points out, from Abraham. I gave ten nations to Abraham, seven of them for you [the seven of Canaan], and the Kenites, the Kenizzites, and the Kadmonites (Bereishit 16:18-21), who are Ammon, Moab, and Seir. One of them is for Esau, and the other two are for the children of Lot (Bereishit Rabbah 44). As a reward [for Lot] for going with him [Abraham] to Egypt and for keeping silent when Abraham said, regarding his wife, She is my sister, He treated him [Lot] as his [Abrahams] son [to inherit part of the land promised to Abraham] (Bereishit Rabbah 44). Thus, we see that each nation has it's own heritage from HaShem, planned out from the beginning. Where a people are, is by Divine design.

Devarim 2:9, and do not provoke them to war, Rashi comments, G-d forbade Israel only to wage war against Moab. However, Israel did frighten them, appearing before them, armed for battle. Therefore, it is written,And Moab was very frightened of the people (Bamidbar. 22:3) because Israel plundered and looted them. Regarding the children of Ammon, however, it says (verse 19),Do not provoke them-with any kind of provocation, as a reward for the modesty shown by their ancestress [Lots younger daughter], who did not publicize her fathers conduct, as did his elder daughter, who named her son Moab [ like , from the father] (Baba Kamma 38b). Thus, we see that past actions affect the present, as well as, future activities also affect the present, for our Sages say this was also done for the sake of dove of Moab, Ruth, who would be the ancestor of Kind David and Mashiach.

Devarim 2:10, The Emim dwelt there formerly. Rashi states, You might think that this is the land of Rephaim which I gave [promised] to Abraham (Bereishit 15:20), because the Emim, who are Rephaim, dwelt there before, but this is not that one, for those Rephaim I drove out and made the children of Lot settle there in their stead. Thus, we see that the Divine Providence is at work. To ensure that those lands destined for one, was received.

Devarim 3:2, Do not fear him Rashi points out, In the case of Sihon [however] it was not necessary to state, Do not fear him. But [in the case of Og,] Moses feared lest the merit that he [Og] had rendered service to Abraham might stand by him, as it says, And the fugitive came (Bereishit14:13), and this was Og. Thus, we see the power of a Mitzvah, this is why Moshe feared that this one Mitzvah Og's would protect him. How much more so, should we when we have six hundred thirteen that can protect us?

In the merits of our father's Mitzvot and our own, we should merit the coming of Mashiach and the peace on earth.

As a reward [for Lot] for going with him [Abraham] to Egypt and for keeping silent when Abraham said, regarding his wife, She is my sister, He treated him [Lot] as his [Abrahams] son [to inherit part of the land promised to Abraham] (Bereishet Rabbah 44)." Thus, we see that each nation has it's own heritage from HaShem, planned out from the beginning. Where a people are, is by Divine design.

Devarim 2:9, "and do not provoke them to war", Rashi comments, "G-d forbade Israel only to wage war against Moab. However, Israel did frighten them, appearing before them, armed for battle. Therefore, it is written,And Moab was very frightened of the people (Bamidbar. 22:3) because Israel plundered and looted them. Regarding the children of Ammon, however, it says (verse 19),Do not provoke them-with any kind of provocation, as a reward for the modesty shown by their ancestress [Lots younger daughter], who did not publicize her fathers conduct, as did his elder daughter, who named her son Moab [ like , from the father] (Baba Kamma 38b)." Thus, we see that past actions affect the "present", as well as, "future" activities also affect the present, for our Sages say this was also done for the sake of "dove" of Moab, Ruth, who would be the ancestor of Kind David and Mashiach.

Devarim 2:10, "The Emim dwelt there formerly". Rashi states, "You might think that this is the land of Rephaim which I gave [promised] to Abraham (Bereishet 15:20), because the Emim, who are Rephaim, dwelt there before, but this is not that one, for those Rephaim I drove out and made the children of Lot settle there in their stead." Thus we see that the Divine Providence is at work. To ensure that those lands destined for one, was received.

Devarim 3:2, "Do not fear him" Rashi points out, "In the case of Sihon [however] it was not necessary to state, Do not fear him. But [in the case of Og,] Moses feared lest the merit that he [Og] had rendered service to Abraham might stand by him, as it says, And the fugitive came (Bereishet 14:13), and this was Og." Thus, we see the power of a Mitzvah, this is why Moshe feared that this one Mitzvah Og's would protect him. How much more so, should we when we have six hundred thirteen that can protect us?

In the merits of our father's Mitzvot and our own, we should merit the coming of Mashiach and the peace on earth.
