entry.title: Parsha Matos-Masei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 4, 2016 / 29 Tammuz 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Matos-Masei / -
Sefer Bamidbar 30:2 36:13
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Matos-Mas'ei 5775, Matos 5774 and Mas'ei 5774 and Matos-Mas'ei 5773

This week's Parsha is a Double Parshot, Parsha Matos and Parsha Mas'ei combined. These two Parshot are the last two Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar, thus, we conclude the Sefer on Shabbat, and start the next Sefer next Shabbat.

Bamidbar 30:3, If a man makes a vow, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, In general, the Torah divides all we can do in this world into three categories: what we must do, what we may do, and what we must not do. The things we must do are essential for our fulfillment of our role as bearer's of G-d's message on earth. The things we must not do are detrimental to our purposes; under normal circumstances, these aspects of reality cannot be elevated to Divine consciousness by our efforts.
The things we may do are not essential but can, if used properly, enhance our spiritual lives and the fulfillment of our purpose. To do this, however, we have to possess sufficient spiritual fortitude not to be sucked into the sensuality of the material experience and thereby lose our Divine orientation.
Every individual goes through periods in his life when he is more or less fit to indulge in this or that material pleasure. In general, if a person can indulge in a pleasure that G-d has put in this world for our enjoyment without compromising his Divine consciousness, he is encouraged to do so.. In the future, every person will be called to account for the pleasures that he encountered but did not partake of, the sages said.
But when a person sees that a particular indulgence affects him negatively, he should at least temporarily renounce it. If he feels incapable of resisting the urge to overindulge, he can make a formal vow, which forbids the indulgence to him just as if it had been forbidden by the Torah. Thus, the sages say, vows foster abstinence. If, on the other hand, he feels that he is capable of controlling himself, it is better to abstain from the indulgence without the formality of a vow. Regarding this, the sages say, sanctify yourself with that which is permitted to you. In either case, every individual must be honest with himself about which aspects of life he is ready to elevate and which he is not, and what lengths he must go to in order to curb his appetites. By guarding himself from things that would be detrimental to his Divine consciousness, a person both weakens materialism's power over him and increases the power of holiness within him. This, too, gives him more power to resist evil.
A biblical vow is not something to take or given lightly. As the Rebbe states, it has the same force as a Biblical commandment. Just as the Torah exists to refine us, in general, a Biblical vow helps us to refine ourselves in a specific instance. HaShem created this world in all its forms, and we are to use all those forms for our Divine purpose and mission. There can be times where we feel, rightly or wrongly, weak and need a boost to helps us, and the Torah provides a remedy, a Biblical vow.

Bamidbar 35:6, cities of refuge, the Rebbe says, Allegorically, the Torah itself is the city of refuge, for when we are immersed in its study and internalize the Divine consciousness it gives us, we are protected from the machinations of the evil inclination. Furthermore, Torah study also protects us from the ill effects of wrongdoing, because it purifies us, inspiring us to regret our past failings and make amends for them. And when we repent properly, our sins are transformed into merits.
This is true if we are guilty of intentional sins, just as the cities of refuge also provided asylum for intentional murderers (at least until their case could be brought to court).
The Torah is the work of Divine Wisdom, making the infinite into some finite for us to study and learn from. As the Torah transcends mortal thought, it carries the one studying it with it in higher levels of spirituality and understanding. In Divine Wisdom, the Torah is a safe-haven for us, from the chaos of materialism. By studying Torah, we are connecting to its author, HaShem. Through Torah study, we learn of the world around us and the spirituality that exists.

Bamidbar 35:25, He must remain there until the high priest...dies. the Rebbe points out, On the ladder of morality, the inadvertent killer is on the lowest rung. True, he is not a deliberate criminal, but even so, his hands are stained with the blood of another human being. The only criminal that can be considered lower than him is the deliberate murderer. In contrast, the high priest is the most exalted personality in the nation, the highest example of holiness and purity to which anyone can aspire.
Yet the Torah says here that the inadvertent killer is linked specifically to the high priest: he must remain in exile as long as the high priest is alive, and the high priest must make it his business to pray that no one in his nation become an inadvertent killer. We see here that the Torah has effectively adopted the attitude of the first high priest, Aaron who loved all creatures and drew them to the Torah and institutionalized it as an integral aspect of the high priesthood.
This fact teaches us a great lesson in brotherly love and Jewish unity: no matter what heights we have reached on the ladder of spirituality or social status, we must remain concerned with all elements of society, even the lowest. And even if we think we exist on the lower echelons of humanity, we must remember that we are still connected with those on the highest echelons, for we are all one people.
We must remember that regardless of our standing, we can never be so high to forget others, nor so low to ignore others. Although, we come from twelve tribes, we are one nation. The high priest cannot forget the little people, nor can the inadvertent killer ignore the high priest.
It is become we can go so low in the Three Weeks, that we can rise up for the High Holidays. With the upcoming Rosh HaShanah, a new year and new chances. Just as the inadvertent killer can begin anew with the passing of the high priest, so too, with the new year, Rosh HaShanah, we can begin anew as well.

As we finish Sefer Bamidbar, we say, (Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen!)
May we truly be strengthen to the ultimate level, where we can study Torah directly with HaShem, with Moshe Rabbeinu and others, with Mashiach, speedily coming.

entry.title: Parsha Pinchas
entry.content:
''

Thu, Jul 28, 2016 / 22 Tammuz 5776 / Thu, Jul 28, 2016 / 22 Tammuz 5776



Parsha Pinchas /

Sefer Bamidbar 25:10 30:1

Shabbat Mevarekhim Menachem-Av, Molad: Wed, Aug 3, 2016; 1:12 (2 Chalakim) PM

Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

Past Posts: Pinchas 5774 and Pinchas 5773



This week's Parsha is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar. This is the first Shabbat within the Three Weeks, which began with the 17th of Tammuz and ends with the 9th of Av. This is a period of national morning the loss of the Holy Temple that stood on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. On the 17th of Tammuz the beginning of the destruction, which was then completed on the 9th of Av.



Which seemed to be contrary to our weekly Parsha, which is about the preparation of entering the land of Israel. So how does that fit in with our time of the Three Weeks, where we morn our current exile and the loss of the Holy Temple? It is a datum of the Torah that HaShem first sends the cure before sending the illness. Thus, we see this week's Parsha is about how we can return the Land and have the third Holy Temple.



Who was Pinchas? As the Torah tells us, Bamidbar 25:11, Pinchas, the son of El'azar, the son of Aharon the Priest. HaShem appointed Aharon to the Priesthood, HaShem included Aharon's four sons, Nadav, Avihu, El'azar and Ithamar, but did not include El'azar and Ithamar's living sons, whom Pinchas was among. Because he, Bamidbar 25:11, caused My anger to be withdrawn from against the Children of Israel, Pinchas was elevated from being a Levite to a Cohen, like his father, and his grandfather. Because he acted for HaShem's sake, without thought (zealotry), he shown how he was like his grandfather, Aharon the Cohen. Us, when we act with true zealotry, we can move boundaries and touch upon HaShem.



Bamidbar 26:9, Dathan and Aviram. The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out, It would seem unnecessary for the Torah to count Dathan and Aviram (as well as Eir and Onan) in a census whose purpose was to number those living at the time, since these individuals were long dead by this time as the Torah itself states in both cases.

The reason the Torah does count these individuals in this census, prior to the entry of the Jewish people into the Land of Israel, is to teach us that the negation of the faults that they manifested was (and remains) necessary in order for us to enter the Promised Land.

Eir and Onan did not honor the holiness of their procreative power; we are taught that this shortcoming delays redemption. Dathan and Aviram rebelled against Moses' leadership; since contesting Moses' leadership was tantamount to contesting G-d's leadership, they could not enter the Land of Israel.

From this we learn that both with regard to our personal redemption and the collective Redemption of the Jewish people and the world in general, we must honor the sanctity of our procreative energies and submit ourselves to G-d's will and the leadership of His representatives on earth.

The Final Redemption will be liken to the entering of the Land of Israel after the Exodus of Egypt. And just as that generation needs to learn and grow to emphasis the positive and diminish the negative, so we need to do as well. How much of our energies are wasted on non-Jewish activities? Dathan and Aviram had their reasons, but hindsight shows that they were wrong. We can see that as they were not humble.



Bamidbar 28:2, Command the Israelites. Rebbe comments, Besides requesting a physical, human leader for the people, Moses also was requesting that G-d ensure that the people always recognize that they are subject to Him, their Divine leader that He runs the world and that all aspects of life occur through Divine providence. G-d granted this request by instituting the daily sacrifices, which correspond to the daily prayers. The daily sacrifice/prayer rituals enhance our awareness and recognition that there is a G-d in the world.

HaShem is the author of the world and history. We need to remember there is a Divine plan, which is heading toward the messianic era, where HaShem, Himself, will reign opening and we will see, with our own eyes and hears, that HaShem is One, there is no other. We know the end will be good and we need to just follow the Torah on how to get there.



Bamidbar 29:35, A time of restriction for you Rebbe remarks, The word of restriction (atzeret) can also be translated as retaining, implying assimilation and integration.

Shemini Atzeret is described as a time of restriction for you, whereas the seventh day of Pesach is described as a time of restriction for G-d, you G-d.

This is because Pesach celebrates the Exodus from Egypt, when we were not spiritually mature enough to assimilate and integrate the significance and implications of the great Divine revelations we witnessed. Therefore, these revelations remained above, for G-d, kept in safekeeping, so to speak, until we were ready for them.

The holiday of Sukkot, however (which culminates in Shemini Atzeret), celebrates G-d's protection of us during our trek in the desert, most of which took place after the revelation of Mount Sinai, after we had achieved spiritual maturity. As such, we could integrate there revelations into our consciousness, and therefore they are for you.

On the personal level, we are all reborn into a higher level of relationship with G-d every year. On the seventh day of Pesach, a mere week after our yearly rebirth, we are not mature enough to appreciate the implications of this new awareness. Only after we have received and integrated the new Divine consciousness fully six months later, at Shemini Atzeret do these revelations become truly ours.

Understanding takes time to be processed. Whether we are capable or not, HaShem does carry us to higher levels of spiritual as we age. Thus, we respect age, as there is a wisdom to be found in longevity. We should not be discouraged if wisdom does not come to us, for it just takes some time for maturity to catch up with us.



May we be mature enough for Mashiach to come and bring peace to the world.

entry.title: Parsha Balak
entry.content:
''
Wed, Jul 20, 2016 / 14 Tammuz 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Balak /
Sefer Bamidbar 22:2 25:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Balak 5775, Balak 5774, and Balak 5773

This week's Parsha is the seventh Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar.

Bamidbar 22:5, He sent messengers to Balaam. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Both Amalek and Balaam were related to the Jewish people. Amalek was the grandson of Issac's brother Esau; Balaam was a descendant of Rebecca's brother Leban. This common ancestry with the Jewish people deluded them (along with their progeny and the specific type of evil they embodied and represent) into thinking that have should some say regarding what ought to be considered proper Jewish behavior or proper Jewish attitudes towards life.
The response to such claims, whether voiced from within us or without, is to assert unequivocally that the sole arbiter of Jewish doctrine and behavior is the Torah. And the only way we can be sure our own attitudes and behavior is determined by the Torah is by evincing humility which is the very opposite of the haughtiness evinced by Amalek and Balaam.
The commonality between Amalek and Balaam is alluded to by the fact that the last two letters of Balaam's name (ayin-mem -) are the same as the first two letters of Amalek's name. The fact that our humble love and fear of G-d is the antidote to their claims is alluded to by the fact that the Hebrew words for love and fear exhibit this same phenomenon: the last two letters of the word for fear (yirah   alef hef -) are the same as the first two letters of the word for love (ahavah ).
All too often those that have the slight, or even no, connection will butt-in to other people's affairs whether they wish to asset control, love their own voice, or some other reason. It was true then and it is true now, there are many out-there that say one should live this way, or even that way. Humanity is great at justifying itself and coming up rationale for anything. We have seen throughout history how human-made codes and laws have been used. Amalek was about being rational and cold, just doing something for just because, not for love, but robotic. Balaam is about serving HaShem only when it benefits yourself, and no more. Neither case is correct, but they both thought they could oppose their own views upon others. Only by standing by the Torah, a higher authority and unchanging one, can we truly have a moral and just society.

Bamidbar 22:17, Please come and curse this people for me. The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out, Balaam knew through prophecy that G-d had forbidden the Israelites to attack Moab, and that therefore Balak had nothing to fear. Nonetheless, he did not reveal this fact to Balak or his messengers, because he hated the Israelites to the point of irrationality, and jumped at this opportunity to curse them.
But G-d not only prevented Balaam from cursing the Jews; He forced him to bless them and even transformed Balaam's curses into blessings. And just as Balaam's anti-semitism (and the curses inspired by it) transcends the limit of logic. It is therefore no surprise that the chief reference to the messianic Redemption is found in Balaam's curses-turned-blessings, since the essence of the Redemption will be the revelation of the inner dimension of our Divine soul, which connects us with G-d in a manner that transcends the boundaries of logic.
There is a principle within Judaism of measure for measure, which is what is being referenced with Balaam and messianic era. As far as Balaam wanted to go, HaShem transformed that in the other end of the spectrum.

Bamidbar 24:19, A ruler shall come out of Jacob and destroy the remnant of the city. The Lubavitcher Rebbe explains, One of the defining characteristics of the messianic era is described by the prophet Isiah (Isiah 49:23), Kings will tutor your children and their princesses will be your wet nurses. The member of a royal family are normally the national figures who are the most steeped in the cultural values of their society -- and who most proudly and loyally identify with it, as well. As such, it would seem that these would be the last people to whom we should entrust the care and education of our tiny, impressionable children! But in the messianic era, the nations of the world will be purified of their dross and, awakened to the value of the Jewish people, transformed from adversaries into supporters.
This emphasized once more the connection between Balaam's prophecies and the messianic era. Balaam himself symbolizes this transformation as his attempted curses were transformed into great blessings of praise.

entry.title: Parsha Chukas
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 14, 2016 / 8 Tammuz 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Chukas /
Sefer Bamidbar 19:1 22:1
Translation: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Chukas 5774 and Chukas 5773

This is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar.

It is interesting that Chukas followings Korach, which follows Shelach. Having said that, what happened? Oversimplification, Shelach is about Torah study, Korach is about deeds/fulfilling the Mitzvot (), and Chukas is about mysticism. The lesson of Shelach is that Torah study alone is not a good thing, which is what the Spies wished, and the lesson of Korach is that, just doing good deeds is also not so good either, so the message of these two Parshot is a balance between the two. How does one achieve a balance between Torah study and fulfilling the Mitzvot, through mysticism. It is only through Kabbalah that we know that one's actions in the mundane world reflect and affects the spiritual world, and vice a versus. One needs to study to know what to do, thus, Shelach before Korach. One also needs to start performing the Mitzvot themselves, to feel and internalize that our actions have consequences, both mundane and spiritual, thus giving us a handle to start learning of mysticism, thus, Korach before Chukas.

Bamidbar 19:2, This is the rule of the Torah, to which the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, When confronted with the reality of death, we become exposed to the contagious influence of the law of entropy: the natural reality that everything is decaying, dying, headed towards oblivion, and that life is futile and meaningless. This depressing worldview results in a spiritual paralysis, as unwillingness or inability to act positively, and is therefore diametrically opposed to our Divine mission, which asserts that there is purpose to life and affirms that fulfilling it is indeed possible.
In order to regain entry into the realm of life, the individual must undergo a purification process, which serves to cure his depression (real or potential) and reorient him towards the enthusiasm and vitality of holiness.
All the varieties of defilement in the Torah and their corresponding purification rites can be understood in terms of their relative proximity to death. Clearly, though, the most fundamental form of defilement is the absolute, unmitigated apparition of death itself: a lifeless, human corpse. Because this form of defilement is the source of all others, its purification rite is the most extreme and mysterious in the entire Torah. As we said, the law of nature indeed decrees that sooner or later everything and everyone succumbs to death. To defy this law is to defy logic, and therefore, the rite of purification from death hails from a level of existence that defies logic; it is a rule, a seemingly arbitrary expression of G-d's will, devoid of rationale and even contravening logic altogether.

It has been said that death is life's way of telling you to stop, and there is truth there. But as Jews, we need to remember that there is more to mere life and death, even our own lives. What we do affects no only use but our descendants and ancestors. We affect the world around us and beyond our understanding, by connecting with the Source of All. By doing Mitzvot and studying Torah, we move beyond the mere shell of flesh and bones and travel into the spiritual realms and reconnect with our Creator. Staring death in the face, is a huge event and needs something greater to overcome. And overcome we need to, as although our beloveds have finished their task, we still have ours to do. We morn the past generation, and watch the future generation grow.

Bamidbar 19:21, Anyone who [carries enough of] the sprinkling water [to] sprinkle [with becomes defiled], the Lubavitcher Rebbe states, Herein lies the central paradox of the rite of the red cow: although the ashes purify the defiled, they also defile the pure. In other words, the priests who prepare and administer the ashes must be prepared to leave the Tabernacle precincts and be defiled temporarily excluded from all things holy in order to purify their fellow Jews. It is this altruistic self-sacrifice, the priests' willingness to transcend their personal interest, that elicits G-d's transcendent holiness and effects purification.
To be sure, G-d rewards all good deeds, and the priests surely know that in the long run they will only gain from putting aside their own purity and troubling themselves to purify their defiled brethren. But in order for the ritual to work, they cannot have this in mind; their motive must be pure.
From this example, we learn (1) how willing we should be to help another person reenter the dominion of purity and holiness, even if doing so requires us to become temporarily defiled ourselves, and (2) how much care we must take to ensure our motives are pure.
This is another way the rite of the red cow is the rule of the Torah: the purpose of the whole Torah is to help us rise above our self-centeredness, and this is expressed by selflessly helping our fellow Jew.
The fact that the Torah tells us to take the red cow for you, for Moses, means that we draw the inspiration and ability to be utterly selfless from Moses from the original Moses, from the leaders of each generation, and from the Moses within each of us.

entry.title: Parsha Baha'aloshecha
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 23, 2016 / 17 Sivan 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Baha'aloshecha /
Sefer Bamidbar 8:1 12:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Baha'aloshecha 5775 and Baha'aloshecha 5773

This week's Parsha is the third Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar.

Bamidbar 8:2, When you kindle the lamps, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Spiritually, lighting the lamps of the Candelabrum means igniting our own souls and the souls of others, as King Solomon says, The lamp of G-d is the soul of man. The flame of a candle constantly flickers upwards, as if yearning to leave the wick behind and ascend to the heavens. The soul shares this nature, constantly striving to break out of the boundaries imposed on it by the body and the physical world and reconnect with its spiritual source. So too, when we go out and attempt to connect with our source and with others, we should do so Bamidbar 8:2, towards the main shaft of the candelabrum. And what is the main shaft of our souls? HaShem. When we light the lamps in our lives, we must remember it for the sake of HaShem that we do so, not for our own sake or glory, but for HaShem's love (warmth) and glory (illumination).

Bamidbar 8:3, Aharon did exactly so, Rashi comments, This is stated in order to tell the praise of Aharon that he did not act different from what he was commanded. (cf. Sifrei) There is a wonderful series called _What is bothering Rashi?_, which asks the obvious question, what is bothering Rashi that he felt he needed to comment on this verse? Aharon was a prophet in his own right and Divinely-chosen to be the first Cohen HaGadol ( ), would we expect such a person not to do as HaShem had commanded him? Doctor Avigdor Bonchek points out that this verse is unnecessary, and as such, that is precisely what is bothering Rashi. So Rashi here using this verse to teach us a lesson, even when it may seem unnecessary or even expected, praise should still be given where it is due. Doctor Bonchek concludes with, A good act remains a good act, whether it is exceptional or not.

Bamidbar 9:7, We are ritually defiled, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, These Jews understood why they could not bring the sacrifice together with everyone else, but they still complained, Why should we be left out? They not only felt excluded from the same positive experience as everyone else; they felt that their very essence was at stake. Their cry caused G-d to grant us the holiday and the opportunity of the second Passover, a second opportunity for redemption. We must learn from their example. Because we are living in exile, we, too, are spiritually defiled, and cannot bring the Passover offering. But if we truly cry out to G-d demanding the opportunity to connect with Him, feeling that the missed opportunity to serve Him jeopardizes our very being, and reminding Him of His responsibility for our impurity He will surely redeem us from exile and afford us the opportunity to connect with Him fully. The lesson of the second Pesach is that there is always an opportunity to repeat and return to HaShem, and HaShem will change the very nature of the universe to allows us to return to Him.

Bamidbar 10:9, If you go to war, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, We are constantly fighting the war against our own evil inclination. This fight is particularly intense during prayer, when the evil inclination tires to distract us from concentrating on G-d and deepening our relationship with Him. The inner trumpet that we sound in order to enlist G-d's help is our awareness of our how vulnerable we are to the evil inclination's strategies. When we beseech G-d to have mercy on us, He comes to our aid and rescues us from our enemy. But we see here that we must blow the trumpets not only while in the thick of battle, but also when we have overcome the enemy and even on joyous festivals. Blowing the trumpets on these occasions reminds us that our victory over our evil inclination is not yet final; it is always devising new ways to ensnare us. Therefore, we must be constantly on guard, constantly enlisting G-d's help and mercy. We need to remind ourselves is not through might or speed that we prevail over our foes, but through the mercy and loving-kindness of HaShem that we do.

''

Parsha Naso /
Sefer Bamidbar 4:21 7:89
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Naso 5775, Naso 5774 and Naso 5773

This week's Parsha is the second Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar and deals with the finishing the counting of the Tribe of Levi, the Sotah, the Nazirite, the Priestly Blessings, and the Princes of Israel's offerings.

Shavuot has just passed, where we celebrate the giving of the Torah, where HaShem created a link between Heaven and Earth, by following the will of HaShem, our actions have spiritual counterparts to our material activities. Unfortunately, our understanding of spirituality is very limited and very rough.
In an article, Journey Toward Peace by Rabbi Menachem Feldman, Rabbi Feldman writes, How do we get to a place where there is no conflict between our spiritual goals and our physical needs? In the portion of Naso, the Torah teaches us how to move from spiritual folly to inner peace. It does so by describing three laws: 1) the wayward woman; 2) the Nazirite; 3) the priestly blessing, which concludes with the blessing for peace. Rabbi Feldman points out that the Talmud states, A person does not commit a transgression unless the spirit of folly enters him. Which is the Sotah is the prime example of, from the Sotah, having either been a Sotah (who is innocent) or someone that saw the process, they abstain from the material to concentrate on the spirit. Which the Torah points out isn't the ideal situation, as a Nazirite has to bring a sin-offering after their set time. Which then leads to the Priestly Blessings, where the material isn't abstained, but used to enhance or accomplish the spiritual into the material.

We read that each of the Princes of Israel gave what appears to be the same offering for the inauguration of the Mishkan, and yet, our Sages tells us, that each offering was unique to each Tribe and its mission. From these, we can learn that a single person cannot do everything, but everything can be done by many. Outwards appearance can be the same, and yet the meaning can be different.

entry.title: Parsha Bamidbar
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 9, 2016 / 3 Sivan 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Bamidbar /
Sefer Bamidbar 1:1 4:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bamidbar 5774 and Bamidbar 5773

Parsha Bamidbar is the first Parshot of Sefer Bamidbar.

Bamidbar 1:1, in the desert, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The silent desolation of the desert is a metaphor for the lack of Divine revelation in creation. Yet, despite its spiritual silence, the mute world can indeed be taught to express the Divinity hidden within it. By studying the Torah and observing its commandments, we can unveil the Divine purpose and potential behind every aspect of reality. In this way, we cultivate the barren desert, enabling it to express its Divine source and the purpose of its creation. We need to remind ourselves that the desert is the work of HaShem, just as the farmlands and the forests are. All things in creation have a purpose, whether we understand them or not. So why were the Jews given the Torah in a desert? As our Sages tells us, because the Torah was given in a desert, a place of ownerlessness and desolation, no one could claim it for themselves. Also, just as the Jews survived in the desert by miracles, so too, we continue to exist through the miracles and mercy of HaShem.

Bamidbar 1:20, Twenty years old and over, the Lubavitcher Rebbe tells us, Although counting expresses the importance of each individual, G-d instructed Moses to count only the Jews over 20, the age of conscription into the army. This is because the army is the representative of its nation. As the soldiers go out into the world, they are expected to act as a living example of their people. The same is true of all of us, since we are all charged to act as G-d's soldiers. We are expected to wear out uniforms proudly, acting in a manner that makes it obvious that we serve in G-d's army. Any observer should easily recognize that we have been drafted by G-d and have been charged with the mission to conquer the world with goodness and holiness. We are counted only when we have reached the point in our spiritual maturity where we identify with our Divine soul strongly enough to enlist in G-d's army. As long as we exhibit this readiness, no distinction is made regarding the level of spirituality or degree of Torah study we have achieved; no matter what, each of us counts as one. Each individual is counted, marks them as important, but still a part of the whole. One single person can do everything, rather, each of us have been given a part in the over-all mission of Israel, and our part, collective, moves us closer to the goal.

Bamidbar 2:17, Just as they camp, so must they travel, the Lubavitcher Rebbe points out, Even when they journeyed, the Jewish people kept the same positions on their respective sides of the Tabernacle. This teaches us that we are bidden to protect our inner sanctuary and the Torah within it at all times and under all circumstances, whether relaxed or restless, tranquil or unsettled, even when we are engaged in our struggle against the wilderness of the spiritual desert. If something is precious, its worth and value does not change from moment to moment or day to night. Just as the Torah and commandments protected the Jewish people in the Sinai desert, so too, today, Torah and HaShem's commandments protect us today. While we do not have the Tabernacle or the Holy Temple today, we still have Torah and commandments we can still do, and they stand in our defense.

entry.title: Parsha Bechukosai
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 2, 2016 / 25 Iyyar 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Bechukotai /
Sefer Vayikra 26:3 27:34
Shabbat Mevorchim / (Rosh Chodesh Sivan Mon night/Tuesday Jun 7)
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bechukosai 5774 and Behar-Bechukosai 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bechukotai, which is the last Parsha in the Sefer Vayikra. That means at the end of the Parsha, we say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! ) which means, Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen! This Shabbat is also the last Shabbat before Rosh Chodesh Sivan, which starts Monday night and continues through Tuesday, June 7th.

Vayikra 26:4, I will give your rains in their time The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Let us note that when people are profoundly emotional, they have to express their emotions physically, by smiling, clapping, dancing, crying, and the like. When the core of our being has been touched, the effect is felt throughout our entire person, down to our physical beings. Similarly, when we archive true oneness with the Torah as in the opening of this passage, where the Torah says that the condition for the rewards it promises is our dedication to G-d's rules our entire being is affected, even the physical aspects of our lives. In order to indicate that this is indeed the case, the results of such oneness must therefore also be physical. Hence, the material rewards spoken of here are not only an incentive to keep the Torah but the true indication that the Torah has permeated our lives so much that our observance produces tangible results.

Why does HaShem promise us rains ()? Why not mere say we will be successful or wealthy? Or even skip that part and just start with Vayikra 26:4, the land will yield its produce.I have not seen anything written on this, but some of my thoughts on this....

To start with what is rain (), drops of water falling from the sky. Think about that. Water, which seeks the lowest places on earth, through evaporation ends up within the sky, and falls back down again. Water is also said to be the basic building block of life. For without rain/water, there are no plants and no life. Also, the Torah says, rain, not down-pours or storms, but rain, which is gentle. More so, Rashi tells us, at such moments when people do not usually go out, as, for instance, in the nights preceding the Sabbaths (Siphra; cf. Taanis 23a). So it would not even be an inconvenience. We might recall that when the World was first create rain did not fall until Adam HaRoshan (Adam the first Human) prayed for it. In other words, Adam (and humans) had to pray for it, cause/effect relationship. Yet here, HaShem is saying, because we are busy with HaShem's Will, we do not also have to add for the rain, rather, the rain, here it becomes a bonus. Not only that, but HaShem will ensure that the rains do not inconvenience anyone and yet come at the proper times.

We also see that just as we benefit from HaShem's reward(s), so too, those around us, are blessed as well. For the rain that comes as our reward, as the Torah says, your rains (), rewards the lands and trees with water in our merit. Which in turns feeds the animals, so we see that rain is a blessing that gives and gives more. So others benefit with us.

entry.title: Parsha Behar
entry.content:
''
Thu, May 26, 2016 / 18 Iyyar 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Behar /
Sefer Vayikra 25:1 26:2
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Behar 5774, and Behar-Bechukosai 5773

This week's Parsha is the ninth Parshot and the next to last Parsha of Sefer Vayikra.

Vayikra 25:1, Mount Sinai, Rashi asks, What special relevance does the subject of Shemittah have with Mount Sinai? Weren't all the commandments stated from Sinai? But this statement is intended to suggest the following comparison: How is it the case of the law of Shemittah? Its general rules and minute details were ordained on Mount Sinai! So, too, were all commandments with their general rules and their minute details ordained on Mount Sinai. This is what is taught in Toras Kohanim (25:1). It seems to me that the following is the explanation of this: Since we do not find the laws of Shemittah - release of the land reiterated on the plains of Moab in Devarim, we learn that its general principles, finer details, and explanations were all stated at Sinai. The expression of here appears therefore to be unnecessary but Scripture states this phrase here to teach that just as in the case of Shemittah, every statement, i.e., every commandment that was conveyed to Moses came from Sinai, including their general principles and finer details and that the commandments delineated in Devarim were merely repeated and reviewed on the plains of Moab not originally given there. This does explain what is used to introduce the laws of Shemittah, but it is also the name of the Parsha, the Parsha that deals with Shemittah, laws of business, and conduct towards a bondsman. What do all these topics have in common?

The concept of Shemittah, allowing the land to rest, once every seven years, seems on the surface to be a practical agricultural concept.

entry.content:
''

Thu, May 5, 2016 / 27 Nissan 5776 / '' ''



Parsha Acharei Mot /

Sefer Vayikra 16:1 18:30

Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

Past Posts: Acharei Mos 5774 and Acharei Mos-Kedoshim 5773



This week's Parsha is Parsha Acharei Mos and is the sixth Parshot of Sefer Vayikra.



Vayikra 16:1, The Eternal spoke to Moshe after the death of Aharon's two sons, Rashi asks, What is this intended to tell us? (i.e. why it is at all stated when G-d spoke this to Moshe?) Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah illustrated this by a parable:a sick person whom the physician visited. He (the physician) said to him: Do not eat cold, and do not lie down in a cold, damp place. Then, another [physician] visited him, Do not eat cold foods or lie down in a cold, damp place, so that you will not die the way so-and-so died. This put him on his guard more than the former; that is why Scripture states after the death of the two sons of Aharon. [i.e. G-d effectively said to Aharon, Do not enter the Holy in a prohibited manner, so that you will not die as your sons died] (Siphra).



From here we see that Aharon's two sons got their desire to be close to HaShem, from their father, and that Aharon himself wished to be closer to HaShem. However, HaShem warned Aharon not to do so. Yes, there is a need and a desire for the spiritual, so great, the entire Yom Kippur Holy Day we spend it as if we are angels. And yet, HaShem reminds us that Yom Kippur is but one day out of the entire year. Just as only one day out of the week, is for spiritual, so too, we need to remember the world around us the rest of the year. Just as HaShem created the Heavens and spirituality, so too, did He create the Earth and the mundane, but have a purpose, and we have a job to do on Earth that we cannot lose sight of. Our heads should not be so lost in the Heavens that we forget our feet are upon the Earth.



Animals are creatures of the Earth, Angels are creatures of Heaven, and Humans are creatures of both, Heaven and Earth. Only human beings are connected and interact with both.

entry.title: Parsha Metzora - Shabbat HaGadol
entry.content:
''
Thu, Apr 14, 2016 / 6 Nissan 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Metzora /
Sefer Vayikra 14:1 15:33
Shabbat HaGadol /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tazria-Metzora 5775, Metzora 5774, and Tazria-Metzora 5773

This week's Parsha is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Vayikra, and this Shabbat is called Shabbat HaGadol, to recall the Shabbat that every Jew celebrated during the Exodus. It is Chabad's custom that the special reading of Malachi 3:4 3:24 is publicly read only when Shabbat HaGadol falls on Erev Pesach, other times, it is read privately, and the regular Haftarah (Kings II 7:3 7:20) is publicly read.

Vayikra 14:2, This shall be the law of the Metzorah, Rashi states, The words on the day inform us that we may not pronounce him clean at night (Siphra; Megilah 21a). The obvious question is, why cannot pronounce a person suffering from Metzorah at night? A quick search did not find an answer, nor does Rashi provide one, which suggests that the answer is also obvious. What is it about night that we are avoiding here? Night means a lot of things, but most would say that night-time is dark, hidden, and concealing, which is the opposite of what is needed to cure Metzorah. Metzorah, our Sages say, was caused by Lashon Hara ( ), evil gossip. Such things are done in the dark, at night, covertly. Thus, the cure for such, needs to be done in the light of day.

Vayikra 14:2, he shall be brought to the priest, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Someone afflicted with Tzara'as is banished from society altogether even from the least holy domains of the camp (or later, his city or town) in order to teach him that the behavior that brought on his affliction is the very antithesis of holiness. (Tzara'as usually resulted from the sin of slander or expressions of haughtiness, as mentioned in the previous Parsha.) It is for this reason that G-d found it necessary to provide for the person afflicted with Tzara'as to be brought to the priest to begin his purification process even against his will. Such a person, having fallen so low on the ladder of spirituality, might lose the motivation to re-enter the domain of holiness, and therefore means had to be provided to extricate him from his situation without his initiative. G-d promises us that He will not give up on even on such individuals; and will bring him back to the fold in one way or another.
Why is this?
Why is one, who fallen so low, brought back? Because each and every Jew is precious to HaShem. In every Jew there is a desire to be spiritual, and sometimes, in our desire for that spirituality, we drift into problematic areas, of silliness/foolishness or carelessness. It those areas that Lashon Hara ( ) tend to happen. And when it happens, guilt and other situations can get in the way of finding a way to undo what happened. While in truth, it cannot be undo it can be prevented from happening again. This prevention is like any other recovery process, where the first step is admitting that there was problem and preventing it from happening again. So the author of humanity created those steps to recover from Lashon Hara, by being sent out of society, and then seeking out the Cohen, the descendent of Aharon the Cohen, a pursuer of peace.

Vayikra 14:21, If he is poor and cannot afford the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The offerings that someone afflicted with Tzara'as had to offer up as part of his purification process are subject to his financial means. We see here an example of the principle that G-d asks of us only what we are capable of. The holds true of what He requires of us materially and also what He requires of us spiritually. The spiritual dimension of sacrifices is our G-d-given mission to elevate the physical world by sanctifying it, thereby bringing it closer to G-d. (The word for sacrifice, korban, means something brought close.) G-d requires us to fulfill this mission to the maximum extent we possibly can, but not beyond this.
As one is forced to be purified of Tzara'as, one has to bring an offering. HaShem could have standardized the offering, but to teach a lesson to us, the Torah mentions that one can bring what they can afford, thus a rich person brings a large offering, while a poor person brings a small offering, and each is equally accepted. Which should also teach us that the actual offering is immaterial rather it is HaShem's will that matters and the desire to be closer to Him.

Vayikra 14:36, Before the priest comes, Rashi states, For so long as the priest has not yet engaged himself with it, no law of uncleanness is applicable there. In other words, the quarantine does not take effect until after the Cohen's pronouncement. This flies directly into the misconception that Tzara'as is a physical ailment, as even just a hint of an infection causes a quarantine to take place. But as Tzara'as is a spiritual ailment, the quarantine can wait for the Cohen's pronouncement.

entry.title: Parsha Tazria Parsha HaChodesh
entry.content:
''
Thu, Apr 7, 2016 / 28 Adar II 5776 / '' ' ''

Parsha Tazria /
Sefer Vayikra 12:1 13:59
Rosh Chodesh Nissan /
Sefer Bamidbar 28:9 28:15
Parsha HaChodesh /
Sefer Shemos 12:1 12:20
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tazria 5775, Tazria 5774, and Tazria-Metzora 5773

This week is the third Parshot of Sefer Vayikra and two other occasions as such, we take out three Torahs, for the three different readings. The first reading is the usual weekly reading of Parsha Tazria, the second reading is for Rosh Chodesh Nissan, which falls of Shabbat, and the third reading is for Parsha HaChodesh, which we go back to Sefer Shemos to read how HaShem commanded Moshe and Aharon to instruct the Children of Israel that we are to follow a Lunar calendar with Nissan the first month of the year and Pesach, which is in two weeks or so, will always be in the spring time.

The Book of Our Heritage, by Eliyahu Kitov, says about The Month of Nisan: The future redemption will burst forth from the midst of darkness. At the very moment when every heart trembles at the point of despair, the glory of G-d will shine forth. And when will that moment be? In the month of Nissan, for G-d has appointed it as a time of redemption. Every misfortune which befalls Israel during this month is nothing else but an assurance that the deliverance is about to begin. When G-d chose the Jewish people as His nation He established for them a month of redemption, a month in which the Jewish people would be redeemed from Egypt, a month in which they are destined to be redeemed in the future. Each month of the Jewish Calendar, even the very calendar itself, is established by HaShem for a purpose. A purpose which was encoded into the essence of Creation and manifests as the Jewish months. Pesach was always destiny to come in Nissan because of this. In the Megillah Ester, Haman and his plot was foiled in Nissan. Just as Nissan comes every year, so too, redemption comes again and again, with the final redemption with the coming of Mashiach.


Vayikra 12:2, If a woman conceives (tazria)[...] The Lubavitcher Rebbe in a talk, Sichot Kodesh, 5744, says, The Hebrew word tazria derives from the root zeria, which means sowing. Two aspects are present in sowing: Sowing is not a one-time affair, but continues to exert an effect even afterwards, similar to seeds which when sown in the ground lead to growth; The purpose of sowing is to harvest produce of a much greater amount than that sown. The lesson from this is that all aspects of man's service should be in the manner of sowing: A Jew may not remain content with a one-time effort, but instead, that effort should produce growth. Moreover, the growth produced should be in a large amount. In the words of Rabbi Sholom Dovber of Lubavitch: A Jew should be a light to illuminate, giving light to other Jews, and in such a way that they in turn become lights to illuminate, ad infinitum similar to sowing seeds, which produce fruit which contain seeds, which in turn produce fruit, ad infinitum. The link between sowing and having children should be obvious, but to state, one never stops being a child of one's parents. It is the duty of parents to guide and educate their children, regardless of age, throughout their lives, as examples and resources to be called upon. And children grow into parents of their own, to continue the traditions of their parents, producing fruit as it is. Just as we sow wheat and other food stuff to live, so too, our children are our future.


Vayikra 12:3. And on the eighth day the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised In the Sefer HaChinunch, it is written, What does the mitzvah (commandment) of brit mila circumcision emphasize? Brit mila draws attention to the fact that G-d did not create man in a perfect state from the womb. Just as perfection of man's physical form is by man's own hand, so is it within his means and power to complete his spiritual form by the worthiness of his actions. We learn from this mitzvah that through our actions we have the opportunity to perfect ourselves and the entire world both physically and spiritually. In other words, we are to be partners with HaShem in the creation of the world and working it to be a place where HaShem can dwell among us. Our physical actions have spiritual counter-parts, and the reverse is also true. There are things in both the physical and spiritual worlds for us to do that HaShem as set for us. The Torah guides to what those things are and how we might accomplish them.

Vayikra 13:14, On the day that live flesh appears in it, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Rashi tells us that this expression teaches us that a priest may not examine someone suspected of suffering from Tzara'as during the festivals, not may he inspect a bride-groom during the seven days of rejoicing following his wedding. Similarly, the Torah instructs the priest to make sure that everything has been removed from a house that he is about to examine, lest his verdict be negative, causing these articles to become defiled and thereby causing loss to their owner.
There are two ways of explaining these laws. From one perspective, we see how on account of the inviolate holiness of every Jew, even one guilty of whatever misconduct causes his house to contract Tzara'as, G-d takes whatever measures necessary to spare him from unnecessary loss. From another perspective, we see how the positive deeds of even such a Jew (his marriage or his observance of the pilgrim festivals) is so prized by G-d that He insists that his process of repentance be delayed so as not to mitigate his joy. Thus, we see HaShem's love and care for us, even when we mess up. We also see that Tzara'as is a spiritual condition, as an medical practice of such, would not work.

entry.title: Parsha Shemini
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 31, 2016 / 21 Adar II 5776 / '' ' ''

Parsha Shemini /
Sefer Vayikra 9:1 11:47
Parsha Parah /
Sefer Bamidbar 19:1 19:22
Shabbat Mevarekhim /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shemini 5775, Shemini 5774, and Shemini 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemini and it is Parsha Parah, which is read on the Shabbat before Rosh Chodesh Nissan, which means it is also Shabbat Mevarekhim. As it happens, next Shabbat is also Rosh Chodesh Nissan. Which means that Pesach is getting closer and closer...

Vayikra 9:7, Moses said to Aaron, Approach the altar and perform your sin offering... atoning for yourself and for the people... as the L-rd has commanded. In the Hitva'aduyot 5747, vol. 3, it is written, Rashi explains that Aaron hesitated to approach the altar because he felt bashful. Yet, G-d had chosen him for this honor and Aaron had been preparing for this G-d-given honor the entire week. However, as bashfulness is one of the three inherent traits of the Jewish people (the other two being mercifulness and kindness), Aaron was naturally bashful about assuming a position of greatness. As praiseworthy as the trait of bashfulness is, Aaron had to step up and serve as the emissary of the Jewish people in the Divine service of the Tabernacle, so Moses told him not to let his natural bashfulness get in the way. We, too, while cherishing the positive traits that we possess, must learn when to override these traits in order to perform G-d's will. We need to move beyond ourselves and our limitations when helping others. Aaron received his position for the sake of the Children of Israel, and for their sake, he need to surpass his own limitation that was holding him back from helping.


Vayikra 10:20, Moses heard and it pleased him, It is written in Sichot Kodesh, 5739, vol 2, According to Rashi, when Moses heard Aaron's reasoning, he acknowledged that it made more sense than his own, admitting that he had not received any instruction from G-d in the matter. The obvious lesson is never to be afraid to admit the truth, even if doing so may prove embarrassing. Moreover, we should admit the truth even if we might think that our social or religious standing obligates us not to. G-d Himself had appointed Moses as the transmitter of the Torah, and it was therefore paramount that the people truth his integrity. Moses was fully aware of this, and could have thought that any admittance of fallibility on his part might compromise his authority as G-d's messenger. But he correctly realized that, on the contrary, admitting his fallibility and demonstrating his readiness to bow before the truth would only enhance his repute and the people's respect of him. The truth is one of the stamps of HaShem, and thus it is very important. One should not hide from the truth to hide from their own embarrassment, although, one may for other's, as the truth should be important.

entry.title: Parsha Tzav
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 24, 2016 / 14 Adar II 5776 / '' ' ''

Parsha Tzav /
Sefer Vayikra 6:1 8:36
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tzav 5774 and Tzav 5773

This is the second Parshot of Sefer Vayikra.

Vayikra 6:2. Command Aaron and his sons, saying. Chatam Sofer writes, As Rashi, the foremost Torah commentator explains, the word command is used to encourage and hasten immediately, and for future generations. When a person performs the same action every day it becomes routine, done by rote. He thus needs special encouragement to ensure that he will have the proper intentions. Doing something by rote is something that involves minimum interaction with the mind and nothing of the heart, by rote is something robotic, lifeless. This is not what Judaism is. Judaism is about life, action, and joy. HaShem wishes us to be humans, not robots. But when we get into a routine, there is the danger of falling into a rote. So need to guard against that.

Vayikra 6:6, A perpetual fire The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes within Likutei Sichot, There were two types of fire in the Sanctuary and Holy Temple: one that burned on the outer altar, and one that burned in the menorah inside. The priest whose job it was to light the menorah did so with a flame taken from the outer altar. This teaches an important lesson: The outer altar is symbolic of our Divine service with other people; the kindling of the menorah alludes to Torah study, as it states in Proverbs, The Torah is light. Thus in order to merit the Torah's light it isn't enough to concern oneself with one's own spiritual progress; the concern should be extended to others as well. We are to love our fellow Jews, and when you love someone, you try to help them and care for them. That love and care is learning about what it means to be a Jew. How does one learn to be a Jew? Study Torah, do Mitzvos, and sharing that knowledge with others. One has not truly learned the material until one can teach it to others.

Vayikra 6:21, And any earthen vessel in which it may have been boiled shall be broken Kli Yakar writes, An earthen vessel that has been used to cook non-kosher food and absorbed its flavor cannot be made kosher; it must be shattered. Similarly, the heart of a person who has become accustomed to sin must be broken before he can become pure. A broken vessel no longer services the purpose that it was created for, but if it can be reformed, it becomes something greater than before. But its nature, earth is something of parts, and thus breakable. The human heart is the work of HaShem, thus, unlike a clay-pot, can be rebuilt and renewed, despite having had a favor for sin.

Vayikra 7:15, And the flesh of the sacrifice of his thanksgiving-peace-offering shall be eaten the same day that it is offered Ma'ayanot HaNetzach write, Why is eating this type of sacrifice limited to only one day? Asks Rabbi Avraham Mordechai of Gur. Because it is brought to thank G-d for a miracle He has wrought on our behalf; indeed, G-d performs new miracles every day... So we should not be locked in the past to miss the future. We should also not forget the present for the future as well.

entry.title: Parsha Vayikra - Parsha Zachor
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 17, 2016 / 7 Adar II 5776 / ' ' ''

Parsha Vayikra /
Sefer Vayikra 1:1 5:26
Parsha Zachor /
Sefer Devarim 25:17 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayikra 5775, Vayikra 5774, and Vayikra 5773

This week's Parsha begins the Sefer Vayikra. This is also Parsha Zachor, which is a special reading for the Shabbat before Purim.

Vayikra 1:1, And the Eternal called to Moses Tanchuma writes, Of all the righteous people who lived in that generation - Aaron, the Seventy Elders, Betzalel and Chur - why did G-d call only to Moses? Because Moses was a person who fled from power, as our Sages stated: He who pursues authority and power, authority and power flee from him; he who flees authority and power, authority and power pursue him. Recall that when Moshe was first told to redeem the Jews from Egypt, he asked that HaShem send someone else, like Aharon, if not Mashiach. Those that seek power, are like candles that move from place to place trying to get lite. They may, in fact, get lite, but they are not where they were originally and may cause damage in their travels. The candle that stays in one spot, lights up where it was supposed to.

Vayikra 1:3, If his offering is a burnt-offering from cattle, the Zohar teaches, Three types of burnt-offerings may be brought on the altar: cattle, sheep, and fowl. A wealthy person is self-assured and prideful, and therefore most likely to sin. For this reason he must bring the largest and most expensive offering, from the cattle. A less affluent person, less likely to sin, fulfills his obligation by offering a sheep. But the poor man, who is already humbled by his poverty, need only bring of the fowl, the least costly type of offering. A wealthy person can be liken to cattle, as they tend to stay in one place and are generally cared for by others. Whereas a poor person is like to a bird, who has to fly around, moving to find shelter and food, all on their own. With a cow, they need not look to Heaven, for the farmer is there for them. But the bird has no farmer, and so realizes there is nothing between them and Heaven.

Vayikra 2:11: You shall burn no leaven (chametz), nor any honey, in any offering of the L-rd made by fire, Rabbi Shmuel of Lubavitch has said, Leaven is symbolic of the kind of person who is angry at the world. Morning or evening, Shabbat or a regular weekday, he is always sour - chamutz, (from the same Hebrew root as chametz). Honey, by contrast, alludes to a person who is affable by nature. No matter what happens, he remains buoyant. The Torah teaches, however, that a person must learn to control his emotions, even positive ones. For there are times when it is appropriate to be leaven, and times when it is appropriate to be honey. Interesting enough, neither leaven nor honey are made by itself, leaven comes from making something and letting it rest, while honey is the by-product of bees getting food and storing it for later. Leaven is passive, while honey is active. So there are times to be passive and other times to be active. One cannot get through life by being only passive or only active, for the Torah says, you shall work (active) for six days, and on the seventh your shall rest (passive).

On the same verse, Rabbi Yosef Shaul Nathanson writes, Leaven and honey are two extremes; by taste and attributes, they are opposites of each other. The Torah teaches that any kind of extreme should be avoided. A Jew must always seek the middle road, the golden path. Or as the saying goes, everything in moderation, including moderation There needs to be a balance for a person to exist. We live in two worlds, mundane and spiritual. Our actions affect both and both are important.

Vayikra 4:2-3, When a person will sin unintentionally from among all the commandments of G-d that may not be done...for his sin that he committed he shall bring...a sin-offering Rabbi Moses Alshich asks, Why should a person be expected to bring an offering for a sin he committed accidentally, i.e., without prior intent? The answer is that had he not already committed the same sin deliberately, G-d would have prevented him from being in a situation where he repeated it unintentionally. This is alluded to by the text itself: When a person will sin unintentionally...for his sin that he committed. And ultimately the unintentionally sin was caused because we aren't playing enough attention or learned enough to know better, so there is a bit of fault there.



Parsha Zachor
We are told by our Sages that we are to read the portion Remember what Amalek did to you [...]
Who was Amalek, our Sages tells us that they were a people that knew their Creator and intentionally rebelled against Him. As well as, it was Amalek that had cooled down the nations of the world after all that HaShem had done for Israel in their redemption from Egypt. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, In spiritual terms, this means that a Jew must ensure that within himself there is no Amalek, even on a subtle level.
What is this subtle Amalek that might be within us? The Rebbe tells us, This subtle Amalek is not that bothered by a Jew's knowledge of G-dliness and Torah; on the contrary, Amalek himself is regarded as possessing knowledge of G-d He knows his Creator. What Amalek rebels against is the translation of this knowledge into love and fear of G-d in thought, speech and deed, i.e., leading a life based on Torah and Mitzvos. [] On an even more subtle level, knowing the Creator and being intent on rebelling against Him does not only mean that one's knowledge does not lead to any feelings or actions; it also means that one's knowledge of Torah and G-dliness is not translated into commensurate feelings. [] Amalek sought to keep the Torah from affecting deeds. Remembering and obliterating Amalek consists of always translating our knowledge of Torah and G-dliness into practical feels and actions.
We see time and time again, where those that rise up against us, wish to throw off the yolk of Heaven and do as they please. We see this everywhere in the modern world, the not hurting anyone, it's my life, or that is so outdated/old-fashion arguments are Amalek's legacy. Our Sages tells us that Haman of Megillah Ester was a descendant of Amalek that King Sha'ul did not kill, and Ester, a descendant of King Sha'ul had to finish the job.
Just as Ester remained true to her roots, so too, need we, stand up against the Haman's and Amalek of the world, and even our own doubts.



May the coming of Mashiach is speedily, and all doubt will be removed when HaShem reveals Himself to all. Peace will reign. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Pekudei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 10, 2016 / 30 Adar I 5776 / ' ' ''

Parsha Pekudei /
Sefer Shemos 38:21 40:38
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayk'hel-Pekudei 5775, Pekudei 5774, and Vayk'hel-Pekudei 5773

This week's Parsha is the last Parsha of Sefer Shemos, after the last verse, we say Chazak! Chazak! V'Nitchazek! ( ) which means Be strong! Be strong! And let us strengthen each other! As we close one chapter of the Torah, we assimliate it into ourselves to strengthen ourselves to carry on.

Shemos 38:21, These are the accounts of the Sanctuary (Mishkan), the Sanctuary of the testimony. In a talk given on Shabbat Mishpatim, 5752, The Lubavitcher Rebbe was heard saying, Our Sages said that G-d did not take the Holy Temple from the Jewish people permanently, but is holding it as a mashkon (collateral - a play on words) which will one day be returned. Furthermore, the repetition of the word Sanctuary in the verse alludes to the two Temples that would be destroyed before Moshiach establishes the third, eternal Holy Temple, speedily in our day. Why were the two Holy Temples destroyed, for it was better that they were destroyed rather than the Children of Israel. As the Parsha speaks of the garments that the Cohenim (), so too, the Holy Temples were garments that the Children of Israel wore, as the Cohenim's garments were only worn when in the service of HaShem and Israel, so too, the Holy Temples stood when the people were following HaShem's ways. As we read about the original instructions for the priestly garments, may we merit the ability to make them again and wear them proudly.

Shemos 39:3, And they beat the gold into thin plates, and cut it into threads, to work in the blue and the purple yarn, Siftei Tzadik relates, Rashi explains how this was done: They would spin the gold together with the threads, beating the foils thin and cutting from them threads along the length of the foil, making the threads intertwined with every kind of material on the breastplate and ephod. From this we learn that people whom G-d has blessed with wealth must not consider themselves superior to others. Rather, they should act humbly and mingle with those people who have not been similarly blessed, like the thread of gold that was interwoven with the other components. It would seem by combining the gold with other threads, they both benefitted. Gold on its own is weak, but with others, can be stronger. HaShem blessed those with gold so that they can benefit from others, working together.



Shemos 39:32, And the Children of Israel did according to everything that G-d had commanded to Moses, they did it. In the collection of talks gathered together called Likutei Sichot, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The Sanctuary, about which G-d commanded Moses, is described in the Torah portions Teruma and Tetzave. The Sanctuary which the Children of Israel actually built is discussed in the portions Vayak'hel and Pekudei. The first two portions refer to, in actuality, a spiritual sanctuary, while the second two portions a physical sanctuary. For this reason, every detail concerning the Sanctuary was given twice. In essence, it was about two totally different Sanctuaries that these portions speak. The Torah is written in brevity, thus, the Torah could have used this verse to cover the previous and this week's Parshot. So there is a reason why there seems to be a repetition of what happened. The Lubavitcher Rebbe offers the above as an explanation. Our Sages also suggest that the first set of Parshot refer to the potential and the last set to the actualization, which then the Torah is shows us that the two are not the same. Even more, our Sages tells us that HaShem loves us, and cherish us. Thus, because the entire Children of Israel united as one, in building the Mishkan, HaShem repeated the details of the Mishkan, to express that love.

May that love take the ultimate expression of HaShem's revelation that will come with the Mashiach. May we merit to serve in the Holy Temple, and learn as Moshe Rabbeinu did, from HaShem, Himself.
May we feel the love of HaShem, and share it with our fellows.

entry.title: Parsha Vayak'hel - Parsha Shekalim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 3, 2016 / 23 Adar I 5776 / '' ' ''

Parsha Vayak'hel /
Sefer Shemos 35:1 38:20
Parsha Shekalim /
Sefer Shemos 30:11 30:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayak'hel-Pekudei 5775, Vayak'hel 5774, and Vayak'hel-Pekudei 5773

This week's Parsha is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Shemos and the next to last one. The last two Parshot of Sefer Shemos deals with the actual construction of the Mishkan.

Shemos 35:1, These are the things that the Eternal has commanded [you] to do. In Sifrei Chasidut, it is written, Immediately following this verse we read about the commandment to refrain from work on Shabbat. Why are we first instructed to actively do something, and then immediately instructed not to do something else? Shabbat is not merely a passive cessation of labor, but is something in which we must take an active, vital role. It is up to us to make the holiness of Shabbat felt, by investing our efforts towards this goal during the first six days of the week. So we see that the six work days and the Shabbat are connected, a pairing if you will. For six days, we deal with the mundane, and on the seventh, we separate it from the others and deal with the spiritual.

If Shabbat is so important, why is that we have only one Shabbat for six work-days? Why not a ratio of one to one, or even one Shabbat to two work-days? HaShem could have created everything at once, and there would be no days at all. And why work-days and holy-day? Why the ratio is beyond my understanding, what the Chassidic masters have pointed out, just as work-days are active, so too, Shabbat should be active as well.

Shemos 35:5, Take from yourselves an offering. Tz'enah Ur'enah mentions, The words from yourselves show that one shouldn't say that he will wait until he is rich to donate. Rather, he should take from what G-d has given him now. One should always take what they can do now over what they could do in the future. The future is basically unknown, there could be various circumstances that could interfere with your desire to do a mitzvah, so it is better to do it now, and make it an actuality than a potential, which might not happen. Realization is more important than potential.



Shemos 35:10, All the wise-hearted among you shall come, and make all that G-d has commanded. HaDrash Vehaiyun writes, When a person has the opportunity to do a mitzvah (commandment), it is preferable to do it immediately and not procrastinate. Doing a mitzvah with alacrity prevents all kinds of obstacles from arising to forestall the performance of the mitzvah at a later time. That is why the verse says, All the wise-hearted among you shall come - one who is truly wise - shall come - without delay. Again, action is better than theory, and now is better than later.



Shemos 35:26, And all the women whose hearts stirred them up in wisdom spun the goats' [hair]. It is written in Likutei Sichot, Rashi explains that the way in which the goats' hair was spun, actually on the back of the goat, was a special skill granted to certain women. The women were not commanded or instructed concerning how to spin the hair, but learned by themselves. They understood, therefore, that this special talent, given them by G-d, was meant to be used for the Holy Sanctuary. From this we learn that when G-d gives a person certain talents or skills, it is incumbent upon that person to use those talents to make a sanctuary for G-d in this world. We each have been given a task to perform, and thus the necessary skills to accomplish that task.



Parsha Shekelim
Shemos 30:11-30-16, The Eternal spoke to Moses saying: when you take a census of the Israelites by number, each man must give the Eternal a ransom for his soul when they are counted. There will not be a plague among them when they are counted. This is what everyone who passes through those counted must give a half-shekel of the holy shekel, at 20 gerah to the shekel a half-shekel as a contribution to G-d. Whoever passes through those counted, 20 years old and over, must give the contribution to G-d. The rich must not give more, and the poor must not give less than a half a shekel, when giving the contribution for G-d to atone for your souls. You must take the atonement money from the Israelites and allocate it to the service of the Tent of Meeting. IT will serve the Israelites as a remembrance before G-d, to atone for your souls.
It is interesting that the Torah says that the rich should not give more, and the poor should not give less, why is that? It should not enter the mind of the rich that since they have more, they are worth more. Comes the Torah and says, the rich should not give more. The poor should not think they were worth less, as the Torah says, the poor should not give less. Before HaShem, the rich and the poor are equal.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Sisa
entry.content:
''
Thu, Feb 25, 2016 / 16 Adar I 5776 / '' ' ''

Parsha Ki Sisa /
Sefer Shemos 30:11 34:25
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Sisa 5775, Ki Sisa 5774, and Ki Sisa 5773

This week's Parsha is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, with but two more Parshot for Sefer Shemos.

Shemos 30:12, When you [wish to] obtain the amount (lit. head) of the Children of Israel [] each man shall give, Alshich states, When the time will come for you to appoint a head - a leader of the Jewish people - make sure it is one who is willing to give up his very soul on behalf of his brethren; only one such as this is worthy. For we see that every Jewish leader must lead, be the first among the people. A Jewish leader is an example for others to follow, place himself before others. Thus, we see Moshe Rabbeinu as the archetype Jewish leader, who was willing to give up his reason for existing to save the Jewish people.

The Torah verse, Shemos 30:13, half a shekel of the holy [type of] shekel, has such meaning...
The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes in Likutei Sichot, Vol. 3, A Jew is only half an entity in two senses, attaining completion and wholeness by uniting with G-d, or alternately, with another Jew. Yet these explanations are interrelated, for when a person helps his fellow Jew and unites with him, he simultaneously merits G-d's blessing and draws closer to Him.
Baal HaTurim writes, This verse contains an allusion to the commandment of charity for the word shekel has the same numerical equivalent as nefesh, soul (430). This teaches that giving charity has the power to effect atonement for the soul.
Reb Simcha Bunim writes, The commandment to give a half-shekel was to make an atonement for your souls, to atone for the Jewish people's sins. The amount was therefore set at precisely half a coin, to show that G-d Himself is responsible for the other half. Had He not created the Evil Impulse to tempt us in the first place, we would never transgress.
The Torah states of the holy [type of] shekel, means that the half shekel is also holy. Many times we think that we have to cover/do everything ourselves, but that is impossible. Rather, we each have our halves to cover/do, and someone else or HaShem, Himself, will be there to complete us. It takes a man and a woman (plus HaShem) to bring a child into this world. Neither man nor woman can do it alone. We learn what our parents and fore-parents have done, to build upon their work to strive to further than they.


Shemos 30:18, A copper laver, The Lubavitcher Rebbe teaches. The Tabernacle and its furnishings reflected the process of spiritual refinement we undergo as part of our ongoing aspiration towards unity with G-d. When entering from outside, one first went into the Courtyard, encountering the laver and the Outer Altar. On a personal level, when we leave our own affairs in order to enter our personal Tabernacle and being the process of spiritual renewal, we must first cleanse ourselves of whatever residual materialism we may carry. This is why the first furnishing one confronts when entering the Courtyard from outside is the laver. In a sense, this purification process begins when we are still outside the Tabernacle and involved in our mundane pursuits. Assuming that we are not doing anything forbidden, even our so-called mundane affairs can be entirely holy, and even help us ascend to advanced levels of spiritual consciousness, rather than dull our spiritual sensitivities. For what was the laver made from the copper mirrors of the women. Those copper mirrors were used to preserve the Children of Israel in Egypt, and were given wholeheartedly, with great desire. As the Rebbe writes it was the last listed in the construction notes, but it was the first object that was seen upon entering. It was also used every day. We need to remember that even the most based activities can be done with holy intent, if we so desire to do so.


Shemos 31:16, The Children of Israel shall keep - veshamru - the Shabbat, Ohr HaChaim relates, Keeping Shabbat means much more than just refraining from certain kinds of work; the Hebrew root shin-mem-reish also implies waiting in anticipation and looking forward to something. The Torah teaches that rather than being considered a burden, Shabbat should be eagerly awaited and longed for each day of the week. Shabbat is a time to regroup and recover from the mundane work-days. Shabbat is a time to reflect on HaShem and the miracles and blessings He has bestowed upon us.


Shemos 31:18, When G-d finished speaking with Moshe on Mount Sinai, He gave him the two Tablets of the Testimony. The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out, G-d finished teaching Moshe and gave him the Tablets on the fortieth day of his stay upon the mountain. But the people had already made the Golden Calf on the thirty-ninth day! In other words, even after the people committed this most heinous sin G-d continued to teach Moshe the Torah and gave him the Tablets in order that he transmit them to the people. The lesson for us here is that we must always relate to people in their best light, inviting and encouraging them to learn the Torah and fulfill its commandments even if they do not seem presently fit for this. The Torah is a heritage for the Children of Israel, and we have no right or mandate to withhold it from any Jew. No matter how a Jew appears on the outside, he or she is still a Jew, a descendant of Abraham and Sarah, Yitzchak and Rivka, and Ya'akov and Leah and Rochel. They need only be washed in the water of Torah to be returned.


Shemos 33:7, Everyone who sought G-d went out to the Tabernacle of Meeting, which was outside the camp. The Jerusalem Talmud, in Eruvin, tells us, They were actually looking for Moses, yet the Torah states that they were seeking G-d. We thus learn that receiving the leader of the generation is the same as receiving G-d Himself. Just as HaShem sits with the judges, so too, HaShem is with the leader. Especially a leader that immerse himself in Torah and the People.


Shemos 33:14, My Presence will [again] go [with you], The Lubavitcher Rebbe teaches, By virtue of our Divine Soul, we are all inherently and irrevocably bound to G-d and are incapable of severing or denying or even wanting to sever or deny that bond. A Jew can contravene G-d's will in even the slightest way only when this intrinsic bond recedes into his subconscious mind and his conscious mind is overtaken by the temporary illusion that ignoring or denying this bond is somehow advantageous. But even then, deep down, the Jew remains faithful to his intrinsic bond with G-d. He knows that the illusion is a ruse and refuses to be duped. Thus, repentance is always possible. As the saying goes, No matter how far you may roam, you can always come back home. HaShem transcends reality and our bond with HaShem does as well. We have a bond with HaShem that has existed for thousands and thousands of years, no single moment or incident can erase that. As our Sages say, sin comes from foolishness.
