It is not our nature to sin, but mistakes and foolishness can happen to the best of us. Since our relationship with HaShem transcends time and space, we can easily return to HaShem.


Shemos 34:7, He preserves the kindness a person does for 2000 generations.... He remembers the premeditated sins of the fathers. The Lubavitcher Rebbe points out G-d also articulated these ideas in the second of the Ten Commandments, but in reverse order: who remembers the premeditated sins of the fathers who shows kindness for at least 2000 generations. Furthermore, in the second commandment G-d shows kindness while here, preservesthe kindness.... We can explain these differences by noting that G-d evinces two types of kindness. The first is the kindness He shows towards someone who has transgressed His will. Such a person needs G-d's kindness in order to rectify his misdeeds. The type of kindness is referred to in the second commandment, which describes G-d as showing kindness after the premeditated sins of the fathers. The second type of kindness is that which G-d shows us simply because He loves us. This is an essential kindness, which is not occasioned by any need. This is the kindness referred to here, in the list of G-d's attributes of mercy, where G-d is described as preserving, i.e., storing up His essential kindness, before any mention of sin. A sin is not punished out of anger or vengeance, but rather out of love and desire to correct. HaShem knows who we are and what we can do, as such, He has kindness for us, and knows our weakness. He exposes those weaknesses within us, only to strength us.


Shemos 34:28, He ate no bread and drank no water. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Just as the physical food we eat nourishes our bodies, the Torah that we study and internalize nourishes our Divine soul. Thus, although, Moshe did not consume physical food during the 40 days he was atop Mount Sinai, he most certainly consumed spiritual food, as he spent the entire time learning the Torah from G-d. Referring to Moshe on Mount Sinai, it is said in the Psalms (78:25), A [mortal] man ate the bread of the Angels. The angels subsist off whatever G-d grants them to comprehend about Him; they internalize this and it fuels their existence; moreover, their sweet delight in this comprehension inspires them to Divine ecstasy, which they express in their constant songs of praise to G-d. When Moshe was on Mount Sinai, he too subsisted off his comprehension of Divinity and the delight such comprehension produces. Similarly, we can taste something of this spiritual nourishment and delight whenever we study the Torah, provided that we approach it as did Moshe, constantly cognizant that we are hearing it directly from G-d. The Human Being is unique in all of creation in which he has one foot in both the physical world and another in the spiritual world. Just as our bodies need food, so too, does our souls. Earthly bread is produced from the ground and through effort to grin the flour into bread, so too, Heavenly bread is produced through effort of studying the Divine Wisdom, the Torah, and understanding it comes from HaShem. Just as HaShem nourished the generation of Egyptian redemption through Mana, so too, HaShem can nourish us with words of Torah and mitzvot.


Just as we were redeemed from Egypt, so too, shall we be redeemed from the current exile. As our ancestors saw HaShem in the desert, so too, shall we see Him. As HaShem forgave our ancestors for the Golden Calf, so too, shall He forgives all that has befallen us.


May the day of our redemption be speedily and may we need the 13 attributes of mercy only to praise HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Tetzaveh
entry.content:
''
Thu, Feb 18, 2016 / 9 Adar I 5776 / ' ' ''

Parsha Tetzaveh /
Sefer Shemos 27:20 30:10
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Tetzaveh 5774 and Tetzaveh 5773

This week's Parsha is the eighth Parshot of Sefer Shemos. This Parsha deals with the Priestly garments and the one-time initiation process for the Cohenim () to start their service.

Just as the world was created before Man, so too, the instructions for the Mishkan were given before the instructions for the Cohenim as well. The Parsha also starts with the Menorah lighting before talking of the Cohenim.

Shemos 27:20, And you will command the Children of Israel that they obtain for you clear olive oil [...]. The Midrash Rabba writes, The Jewish people are likened to the olive, at it states in Jeremiah (11:16): An evergreen olive tree, beautiful in fruit and form, did the L-rd call your name. In the same way that all other liquids can be mixed together, whereas oil always floats to the top, so too is it impossible for the Jewish people to fully assimilate among the nations of the world. And when Jews carry out G-d's will, they merit to stand above the entire world.

Shemos 27:20, to light up the lamp regularly ( ), Rashi notes, [The term lit. to make rise is used here to indicate that] he is to kindle [it] until the flame rises by itself (Shabbos 21a). It is not enough that the Menorah is light, but it is required that each lamp is able to continue on its own and reach heavenly. This is lesson for the Cohenim and everyone, one needs not say that the doing the minimum is enough or that is all one should do, rather, one needs to ensure that our actions and deeds should raise up on their own. For example, it is not enough to teach a child the basics, rather a parent needs to ensure that their children have the tools and foundation to surpass their parent's education.

A thought occurred to me as I read Shabbos 21a, the discussion was about kindling a light on Shabbos, and the discussion brought in our verse to discuss wicks, as the Talmud relates that worn-out Cohen garments were used as wicks in the Holy Temple. And then the Talmud also includes a discussion of the kindling of the Chanukah Menorah. Who were involved in the story of Chanukah, the Maccabees, the Cohenim of their time. What was the purpose of the Menorah, to light up the world with HaShem's word/mitzvah, to do so, one must be of the highest level purity, to ensure the successful continuation to the next generation.

Shemos 28:2, And you shall make sacred garments for your brother, Aharon, for [his] honor and splendor. Sefat Emet writes, The commandment to make special priestly clothes comes directly after the mitzvah to prepare pure olive oil for the menorah. Oil symbolizes the intellect, which should be kept pure and unsullied. The priestly garments symbolize the physical body, the garment of the soul, which should be utilized for glory and ornament. The Torah teaches that purity of thought and cleanliness of body must go together. As is stated in many places, in Judaism, there is a connection between Heaven and Earth, what affects one, affects the other. There is nothing completely mundane or completely spiritual, there is a component of each in the other. For every person, they have a body and a soul, components of both Earth and Heaven, working together to be human.



Shemos 29:43, and it will be sanctified () [] with My glory () Rashi writes, in that My Divine Presence will rest there. But the Aggadic explanation is: Do not read [this word as] but , [i.e.] with My honored ones. He [thus] alludes to him here [about] the death of Aharon's sons on the day of the erection of [the Mishkan]. And this is what Moshe said [then]: ' "This is what the Eternal spoke about, saying, 'I shall be sanctified through those who are close to Me.' (Vayikra 10:3) and where had He spoken [about this]? [When He said here:] "and it will be sanctified through My honor[ed ones] (Zevachim 115b). Thus, we see here that HaShem knew the future, and hinted about it to Moshe. Our Sages tell us that when Moshe originally hear this, as in this Parsha, he thought it would be Aharon and himself, not Aharon's two sons. There are other places in the Torah were we see HaShem's foresight hinted out. For HaShem knows the past, present and future, for all and everyone. Why did he let that tragedy happen? That will be discussed in the Parsha it happens in. But we see here, that even though HaShem knows that events will not come out rosy, He allows free-choice to take place and elevates us, lowly human beings, to partners in Creation.



Shemos 29:45, I will dwell among the Children of Israel, and I will be to them G-d. On this verse, a Chassidic story is told, An older chasid once posed a question to Rabbi Naftali of Ropshitz, while he was still a young boy: I'll give you this gold coin if you can tell me where G-d can be found, he said. The youngster responded by saying, I'll give you two gold coins if you can tell me where He is not found! For HaShem is everywhere, every-when, and every-way.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
''
Thu, Feb 11, 2016 / 2 Adar I 5776 / ' ' ''

Parsha Terumah /
Sefer Shemos 25:1 27:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Terumah 5775, Terumah 5774, and Terumah 5773

This week's Parsha is the seventh Parshot in Sefer Shemos, and introduces the Mishkan () and its construction. It should be noted that the Parsha begins, Shemos 25:1, And the Eternal spoke ( '). The And signifying that this Parsha and its concepts are a continuation of the previous Parsha, Parsha Mishpatim that dealt with Civil Law, which was also connected to the prior to that Parsha, Parsha Yisro, in which the Torah was given. Thus, we see a linearization of events: with the Giving of the Torah, the spiritual was brought down to Earth from Heaven, then the spreading of that spiritual throughout the Earth in the form of civil laws, and the reaching back upwards from the Earth to the Heaven and concentration of spiritual within the Mishkan. There is a loop here, starting in Heaven, then to Earth, to spread around on Earth, then concentrating on a point, which then returns to Heaven.

Why is that?

The order of the Parshot of the Torah are Divine and hold wisdom. We know from Parsha Yisro, before the Jews could receive the Torah, they had to purify themselves and prepare themselves. Our Sages tells us that HaShem, Himself, spoke the entire Ten Commandments in a single utterance that was still understandable, and then repeated the first two commandments in a more mundane manner. So too, there had to be preparation and purification of the people before they could build the Mishkan. What was that process, the observance of Divine civil laws. Only a people that were truly lawful and just could build a dwelling place that the Divine could be made obvious. And it was simply obvious not revealed, as the observance of the civil (and spiritual) laws of Torah were the true revelation of the Divine in their midst.

From the building of the Mishkan, we learn several lessons as well:

Of the holy ark,
Shemos 25:11, Within and without shall you overlay it, Kiflayyim L'Toshiya points out, A true Torah scholar is one whose inside matches his outside. Merely learning the lofty principles contained in the Torah is not enough its lessons must also be internalized. That is why we say in Psalms (45:14), All the glory of the king's daughter is within. The splendor and glory of the Torah is the internal purity it leads to.
In other words, your words/study should match your actions/deeds and the reverse as well. One should not pretend to be something they are not for the sake of pretending or deceiving.


From the lid of the holy ark.
Shemos 25:19, From the cover (itself) shall you make the cherubim Rabbi Yosef Ber of Brisk points out, The cherubim were made with the faces of small children, one a boy and one a girl. From this we learn that providing the proper Jewish education for even our tiny children is a basic principle necessary for our keeping the Torah.
We see the importance of Jewish education, both for immediate reasons and reasons of preservation.


From the Menorah:
Shemos 25:31, The menorah shall be made, The Lubavitcher Rebbe states, Rashi explains that the words "shall be made" are passive, indicating that the menorah would be made by itself, and not by Moses, who was in the midst of receiving instructions from G-d how to fashion all the other utensils to be used in the Sanctuary. Rashi states that Moses did not fully understand how the menorah was to be formed, so G-d told him to throw the gold into the fire, and He would make the menorah Himself. Why was Moses so perplexed by the menorah, but not by any other command even more complex? Our Sages said that the purpose of the menorah was to serve as a testimony to all who saw it that the Divine Presence rested among the Jewish People. Moses, for his part, had difficulty understanding how it was possible for one small menorah to light up the entire physical world. G-d answered him: You are right--this is beyond the power of mere flesh and blood. Therefore, throw the gold into the fire and I Myself will make the menorah.
In other words, we need to our part, and HaShem will fill-in the rest.


Shemos 27:9, Crocheted netting made of twined linen, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, These nettings were made of linen because flax, from which linen is made, differs from other plants in that only a single stalk grows from each seed. One of the words for linen is biblical Hebrew (had) reflects this attribute, since it also means alone. Since the Jew is distinguished from other nations by virtue of his absolute monotheism, it is appropriate that the curtain separating the Tabernacle from the surrounding world was made of this material. In addition, the flax plant alludes to our mission to spread of the knowledge of G-d's oneness to the world at large. Our sages tell us that flax depletes the land [i.e. the soil of its nutrients], and land signifies the earthly, materialistic consciousness that opposes the faith of one G-d. This is the mystical meaning of the phrase a single people in the land, which is used to describe the Jews: they are a people who bring awareness of G-d's oneness to the materialistic world.
We need to draw from Torah to protect ourselves from the outside world, but not forget that it exists. We draw materialistic elements form the world around ourselves and use it, elevate it for usage of the Divine.


When Mashiach comes, the entire world will witness the oneness of HaShem and everyone can see that HaShem dwells among us, as He did in the days of Torah. May that day come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Mishpatim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Feb 4, 2016 / 25 Shevat 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Mishpatim /
Sefer Shemos 21:1 24:18
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Shabbat Mevarekhim /
Past Posts: Mishpotim 5775, Mishpotim 5774, and Mishpotim 5773

This week's Parsha is the sixth Parshot in Sefer Shemos, and deals with civil laws.

Shemos 21:1. And these are the laws, Rashi states, Wherever [a section begins with] these (), [it] rejects something previous, [but where a section begins with] and these (), [it] adds to something previous (Shemos Rabbah 30:3). [Thus here it says and these () to teach us that] just as [the commandments written in] the previous section [where received at] Sinai, so, too, these [written in the section were received at] Sinai (Mechilta, Parsha Mishpatim, sec. 1). Why, then, is the section dealing with civil laws placed following the section [about the construction] of the altar? To tell you that you shall place [the seat of] the Sanhedrin next to the Temple. What Rashi and others are telling us is that the same G-d that gave us lofty spiritual concepts dealing with a relationship between Him and us, also gave us practical concepts to help relationships between us and our fellows. Both are important to HaShem, and thus to us. It is said that the Love of Israel is the Love of HaShem, one cannot love one without the other.

Shemos 21:2, If you buy a Jewish bondman, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, The case of a Jew who is sold by the court as a bondman in order to repay what he stole is quire rare and it reflects negatively on the Jewish people, focusing on the sinners among them. It is nevertheless chosen to open the Torah's presentation of civil law.
One could argue that such a Jew is not important; after all, he succumbed to the materialistic desires of his body, rather than following the calling of his soul. Why bother with him? Therefore, the Torah begins by dealing specifically with this type of person and immediately informs us that even this sinner must be treated with respect and compassion. Regardless of a Jew's spiritual state, he is still one of Gd's chosen people.
This compassionate approach to justice, exemplified in the Torah's treatment of the bondman, is the very heart of the Jewish civil law system, whose thrust is the refinement and elevation of the physical and material day-to-day life of a Jew. The case study of a bondman, therefore, is a fitting introduction to the ensuing legal discussions.

Oxford Dictionary defines prison as a noun referring to A building in which people are legally held as a punishment for a crime they have committed or while awaiting trial. The punishment of a crime is incarceration, but is it humane and just? Comes the Torah and says no. Locking people up as punishment does not benefit society nor help the criminal. So the Torah comes up with a way to help both the society and the sinner/criminal. First, the Torah points out that when someone does something wrong against society/individuals, that person is also acting against HaShem as well. Next, the Torah ensures that the damages are corrected and then in the process, seeks to teach the individual how to improve themselves. In society today, someone who has been convicted a crime is called a criminal and a convict, a label that stays with them. For the Torah, once the restitution has been met, the sin/crime is forgotten, and the person is given a new start.

Shemos 21:2, For six years he shall serve and in the seventh year he shall be set free, Sefer HaParshiot has, These six years hint to the six kingdoms in which the Jewish people served, i.e. were enslaved: Egypt, Assyria, Babylonia, Media, Greece and Rome (the exile in which we presently find ourselves). Soon we will be set free by Mashiach, who will redeem us from our present exile. Thus, we see that we are like the bondman, sold to repay our debts, and are promised to be redeemed like the bondman with no effort on our part, at the proper time, or by a family member to pay off the debt.

Shemos 21:34, The one responsible for the pit must make restitution, the Rebbe writes that while the laws here seem logical, there are within these verses reminders that Torah is Divine will. This law is such reminder: Logically, there would seem to be no reason to differentiate between the damages inflicted by the same pit. Even so, the owner is only liable for certain damages and not for others. Thus, we see the Divine, which understands the situation much more than mere mortals can, and shares with us some insight, some of which we can comprehend, and some we cannot.

Shemos 22:3, If the stolen object shall be found in his possession... he shall pay double. Pardes Yosef writes, A thief must pay back double what he stole. When a thief steals $100, his intention is to gain $100 at the expense of $100 dollars of his victim. By paying back double, the thief is losing $100 and at the same time the victim is gaining $100. This demonstrates how punishments in the Torah are measure for measure; what is done to the thief is the same as that which he meted out for his victim. We see the Divine Justice in the measure for measure that the Torah takes. For by measure for measure, you see the Divine of truth, justice and mercy.


Shemos 22:5, If a fire breaks out and spreads, the Rebbe points out that the Talmud considers lighting a fire and drawing a bow with an arrow as similar, thus, when either action is done by man, the fire and arrow are out of our control. When HaShem does something or promises something, it is always in His control, thus, the outcome of HaShem's action is always for the good, just and true. Thus, when a prophet predicts something good, it must always come to fruition. The future redemption, in its highest form, already exists; it is only concealed. When we recognize that the confusion and obstacles we encounter are mere illusions that obscure the truth, G-d will remove them, and we will be able to perceive the light of redemption. Just as man cannot stop a fire, so too, no one can stop the final redemption. Just as fire reaches heavenly, so too, the final redemption will elevate the world to untold levels.

Shemos 22:21, You shall not afflict any widow or orphan, it said that Whenever Rabbi Levi Yitzchak of Berditchev reached this verse he would cry out. Master of the Universe! You instructed us in Your holy Torah to be kind to widows and orphans, and yet we are like orphans in this bitter exile! You must therefore take us out of this exile at once! In our exile, we feel like orphans, without guidance of parents or other obvious care, but HaShem is always there, watching and guarding us. Although we have been through so much, we remain. Our Parent in Heaven is always there for us.

Shemos 22:24, When you lend money to My people, the poor among you, Reb Shmelke of Nikolsburg writes, The words among you seem to be superfluous. The Hebrew word for among you is imach, which also means with you. Sometimes a person might establish an amount of money that he will give to a particular charity, and even if his wealth increases, the amount he gives remains the same. The Torah is telling us that when we are enriched, the poor should be enriched with us. Why are there poor? So we may merit the mitzvah of helping others, we refine ourselves, and become G-d-like. And it need not be material poorness, but spiritual poorness as well. In teaching, we learn the material in greater detail and refine our understanding.

Shemos 23:1, You must not accept a false report. You must not join forces with a wicked person to be a corrupt witness. The Ba'al Shem Tov connected the two halves of this verse as follows: Every soul is granted its particular, individual strength as it is dispatched to this world. Of course, we all have our shortcomings, too, but our particular, individual strength the arena in which we truly shine normally compensates for them. However, if two witnesses testify that we have betrayed our mission, this unique asset is taken away from us. Therefore, the Torah warns us: Do not listen to slander. If you do, you incrimination of your fellow will join forces with that of your evil inclination, and you will thus rob your fellow of his special Divine strength.

Shemos 23:25, And He will bless your bread and your water, and I will remove sickness from your midst. Kli Yakar writes, Most illnesses are caused either by food that is ingested, or from an intensification of internal forces within the body. G-d therefore promised to send His blessing in both of these areas, blessing the food one eats your bread and water and removing sickness from your midst - making sure that illness does not come from within. HaShem is our Healer, He heals both our material illness and spiritual ones as well.



May the ultimate medicine come and heal the world, which is the coming of Mashiach, who will bring peace to the world, and HaShem will reign supreme with truth, justice and mercy.

Rosh Chodesh Adar I will be this coming Tuesday and Wednesday.
'

entry.title: Parsha Yisro
entry.content:
'' Thu, Jan 28, 2016 / 18 Shevat 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Yisro /
Sefer Shemos 18:1 20:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi Past Posts: Yisro 5775, Yisro 5774, and Yisro 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Yisro, which is the fifth Parshot of Sefer Shemos. Parsha Yisro deals with the Giving of the Torah and visit of Moshe Rabbeinu's father-in-law, Yisro. Why Yisro was needed and got a Parsha named after him, I have dealt with in previous posts.

Shemos 18:12, To eat bread with Moshe's father-in-law, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, Rather than focusing on his own meal, Moshe ensured that the others were provided for (see Rashi). The lesson here is that regardless of our social status (and who can claim a higher social status than Moshe?) we should consider it more important to take care of someone else's needs than to see to our own. This applies both to physical needs as well as to spiritual advancement. It did not matter to Moshe that there were others to help out, rather, he felt it was his duty to help others as every Jewish Leader since has done. Moshe was the father of the Prophets, a priest(-like), military commander, and law-giver. All on the express commandment of HaShem, Himself, and yet, he did not pause in his duty, think it beneath him. All that he did, was for the betterment of the Children of Israel. Our Sages tell us that Moshe was on or above the level of the Angels, and yet, he served others food and drink to ensure everyone was taken care. Did Moshe know what was best cut of beef, what wine went with it, or such things, highly doubtful, but ensured others were provided for

Shemos 18:14, Why are you sitting alone, and all the people stand, to which Chizkuni from Tz'ena Ur'ena writes, Why did Yisro, Moses' father-in-law, ask Moses why he was sitting? The law is that a judge sits while the plaintiffs stand. Further, how could Yisro dare rebuke a man of Moses' stature? The important word here is, all alone. Yisro was not rebuking Moses, but rather encouraging him to appoint more judges to help him. The Lubavitcher Rebbe writes that the lesson is is that Moshe was not to do everything all alone rather involve others, by doing so, Moshe elevated others from their level up towards his.

It was not enough for HaShem to give the Torah to Moshe, whom could have received it anywhere and then brought it to the Children of Israel. HaShem brought the entire people to Mount Sinai, and proclaim the Ten Commandments as a single utterance to the people. Thus the Torah was given directly to the people, by-passing Moshe, proofing the Divinity of the Torah. But also proofing the importance that the Torah (and involvement) should not be confined to a few, but open to all. Before HaShem, we are all equal, whether we are Moshe Rabbeinu or a mere water-carrier. We all have our parts to play in the Game of Life.

Shemos 19:1, They came to the Sinai desert, the Lubavitcher Rebbe writes, In order to receive the Torah, the Jews had to venture into the desolate desert and trust that G-d would provide for them. To their credit, they did this without hesitation. Today, as well, the proper way to study the Torah is to immerse oneself in it completely and abandon all other worries. When we devote ourselves to the Torah in this way, we are guaranteed success. In addition, G-d promises that He will also provide for all our material needs. Why a desolate desert? To show us as the Rebbe said that even where we would not assume there would be even possible life, there is, HaShem made the desolate desert into a paradise where our ancestors studied Torah and experience HaShem, Himself. If we, as our ancestors did, trust in HaShem, so too, will we be supported that we can be in a desert and survive.

Shemos 19:2, Israel encamped opposite the Mountain, Sefer Hama'amarim writes, Why was the Torah given on a mountain, specifically? A mountain and a plain are both made of earth; a mountain is just higher. The intention of giving the Torah was so that the Children of Israel would elevate and spiritually purify the physicality of the world. This is hinted to by the mountain, which is dust of the earth but is high, symbolizing the elevation of matter and its purification. For our duty here is on Earth is to be a gardener/caretaker of Creation. We are to take the so-called mundane, and reveal the spirituality that is has.

Rabbi Moshe of Kovrin writes, Rashi, the foremost Biblical commentator, explains that the word encamped in Hebrew is written in the singular form because the Jewish people were like one person with one heart they were totally united. Only through the power of unity are the Children of Israel capable of standing opposite the mountain - opposite the mountain of hatred that surrounds them. There is power in unity and harmony. When the Jews are united in peace, miracles happen as we have seen throughout history.


Shemos 20:20-21, You must not make with Me idols [] You must make an altar for Me upon the earth The Rebbe points out the first part of these verses is passive, while the next is active, and yet, it is an altar of earth. One should not in building an altar become exalt ourselves, but remember to be humble.
I see this as one should not deal with falsehoods but reality, but in spirituality one needs to be grounded. Yes, we can soar to the Heavens, but we remember there is a reason why were born on Earth.


The world will realize this truth when Mashiach is revealed, speedily in our days.

entry.title: Parsha Beshalach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jan 21, 2016 / 11 Shevat 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Beshalach /
Sefer Shemos 13:17 17:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Beshalach 5774, and Beshalach 5773

On the 15th of Shevat, is Tu B'Shevat, the New Year for Trees, there is a very nice explanation of Tree/Man at L'Chaim Weekly #1406 "Produce Potential", which you should check out. The Link is http://www.lchaimweekly.org/lchaim/5776/1406.htm#caption1.

Of the fourth Parshot of Sefer Shemos, L'Chaim has a bit of the Lubavitch Rebbe's the songs that are read in this Parsha and Haftarah in a section called Living with the Rebbe is also of note.

Shemos 13:17, that G-d did not lead them through the land. Yalkut points out, The manner in which G-d led His people through the desert was above the limitations of the laws of nature. The natural way of the world is for rain to fall from the sky and bread to be sown from the earth, but for forty years, the opposite held true for the Jews: their bread fell from the sky, and their drinking water was provided by a well that traveled with them.

HaShem could have taken the Jews out of Egypt and straight into the Land of Israel instantaneously, or if some travel was required, made some miracle to travel from Egypt to Israel via the Mediterranean Sea going north then east, instead of going east then north. Or some other way that only HaShem knows... All that HaShem does, is done for a reason, whether we know that reason or not. What Yalkut points out emphasizes that when one follows the way of HaShem, what we think of nature will not get in our way, in fact, nature will be revealed to assist us in what needs to be done.

Shemos 14:10, [The Children of Israel] became very afraid [so they] cried out to the Eternal. Ma'or VaShemesh writes, The reason the Children of Israel cried out was the fact that they were fearful. It disturbed them greatly that they were afraid of the mortal Egyptians, rather than only of G-d. I believe what Ma'or VaShemesh is trying to tell us that, at that moment, the Children of Israel were weak because they were thinking in terms of the mundane, instead of having faith in HaShem, thus we see Rashi's comment, They took to hand the craft of their forefathers. About Avraham it says: in the place where he had stood [in prayer] (Bereishet 19:27), about Yitzchak [it says]: to pray in the field (ibid 24:63), [and] about Ya'akov [it says]: He prayed to the Omnipresent (ibid 28:11) (Mechilta ibid). In their moment of weakness, they returned to their roots to connect to their Rock to seek strength. Even today, we seek comfort from our Father in Heaven in prayer. As Jews we also seek connection through prayer when things are going well as well.

Shemos 14:14, you shall remain silent The Rebbe writes, This command was directed against those Jews who wished to engage in prayer instead of actually proceeding into the sea. We learn from this that there are times when a Jew must close his prayer book, remove his tefilin, fold his talit and leave the synagogue -- in order to save the thousands of Jews who are in danger of drowning in the sea of assimilation, splitting the sea and uncovering the light of the Jewish soul that exists within. In other words, HaShem created the Heavens and the Earth, and we should not forget that as lofty as the Heavens are, we were placed on Earth for a reason.

Shemos 14:22, with the water acting for them as a wall, the Rebbe in his writings, Likutei Sichot , writes, When a Jew observes Torah and mitzvot faithfully to the extent that he is willing to jump into the sea, not only does the sea disperse, but it is transformed into a protective wall that safeguards him. Or as I see it, the very thing that way an attacker, can become an defender.

Shemos 16:5 [...] sixth day [] there will be double portions of Manna, from here, our Sages taught that we should have two loaves of Challah for hamotzi on Shabbos, to recall the double portion of Manna that was in the desert.

As we read the redemption of the Jews from the first exile, so may we experience the final redemption soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Bo
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jan 14, 2016 / 4 Shevat 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Bo /
Sefer Shemos 10:1 13:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Bo 5774 and Bo 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bo, the third Parshot of Sefer Shemos, and the Parsha that deals with the last three plagues of the Ten Plagues and the consecration of the firstborns.

The Lubavitch Rebbe writes, Torah reading Bo means come. More particularly, the term is also interpreted as meaning enter. Moses was commanded to come and approach Pharaoh. As the Zohar, the fundamental text of Jewish mysticism states, he was told to enter room after room, penetrating to the very core of Pharaoh's palace. The Zohar continues, explaining that Moses shrank at this command. He was daunted by the charge to confront evil at its very core. To reassure him, G-d told him, Come. Come, i.e., come with Me, and not go, go alone. G-d promised that He would accompany Moses and face Pharaoh with him. This command thus requires personal initiative, and simultaneously, promises that such initiative will be rewarded by G-d's assistance. Moses was required to act on his own, but not independently. G-d would support his efforts. The Rebbe continues to write that this is the situation that we face every day, when we do our part, HaShem is with us, allowing us to transforms the seemingly negative elements of the world, the Par'ohs, into forces assisting us, as the Torah states that Par'oh, himself, urged the Jews to leave Egypt.

The Rebbe also writes, Pharaoh's evil decrees and the trials and tribulations of the Jews during the Egyptian exile did not come about because Pharaoh had so decided of his own accord. Rather, G-d hardened Pharaoh's heart, eventually causing all of His wonders and miracles to be revealed. The lesson we can learn from this is that everything comes from G-d; when a Jew encounters something that prevents him from properly serving G-d, this is meant only as a test, whose purpose is to awaken the powers hidden within the person's soul. When the person overcomes this test, and perseveres in his holy mission in life, he is then rescued from all difficulties.

Shemos 10:9, We will go with our young and with our elderly, [] for it is a festival to the Eternal for us. Shem MiShmuel points out an important truth, For in truth, what kind of a holiday would it be without our children? Any holy celebration that does not include the younger generation is no celebration at all... From here as well, we share the celebration with our elderly as well, to give thanks that our elders have shown us the way and have the continuation of generation to generation present.

Shemos 12:29, And the Eternal struck all the firstborn in the land of Egypt Rashi writes, Whenever the Torah states and the Eternal, it refers to G-d and His heavenly court. Nezer HaKodesh adds, When it comes to meting out punishment, G-d gives the decision over to the heavenly angels, who do not know the thoughts of man. (A Jew is not punished for negative thoughts, as it states, A bad thought is not considered part of deed.) By contrast, when it comes to reward, G-d does not consult with His heavenly court, as a good thought is considered part of deed, and only G-d knows our thoughts and intentions. Thus, we see mercy in dealing misdeeds to limited them, while good deeds are expanded.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eira
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jan 7, 2016 / 26 Teves 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Va'eira /
Sefer Shemos 6:2 9:35
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Va'eira 5774 and Va'eira 5773

This week's Parsha is the second Parshot of Sefer Shemos, and the beginning of the redemption of the Jews in ancient Egypt.

Shemos 6:2, G-d then spoke to Moshe said to him, I am the Eternal. ( ), which Rashi comments, He [HaShem] took him [Moshe] to task for having spoken critically and said (5:23) Why have You caused this people to be mistreated? (Shemos Rabbah 6:1). How did Rashi know this?

As the Lubavitch Rebbe writes, Why are there different names for G-d? And what is the significance in using one name over the other? The Midrash asks these questions and, in resolution, quotes G-d as
saying: I am called according to My deeds, i.e., each of the different names of G-d is associated with a particular quality or attribute. Kabbalah expands further on this concept, deriving different insights
from the letters of the names and their vocalizations.

So we know that the Divine Name of is used for HaShem's quality/attribute of Judgment. Thus, our Sages tell us that the words that HaShem used where words of judgment/reproach. And yet, HaShem, Himself, says in His words of Judgment, I am the Eternal, using the four-letter name Y-H-V-H, which the Rebbe writes, represents the revelation of G-dliness in all its infinity. For that reason, the name Y-H-V-H is not pronounced. Its light is too powerful and all-encompassing to be expressed in speech. It is also the attribute/quality of Mercy. So we literally see that in the words of judgment, there is still mercy.

Until this Parsha, HaShem had acted in a natural manner, using nature to conceal Himself, but starting with this Parsha, HaShem acts in a completely divine manner that could not be attributed to nature. Of course, one should not forget that nature is HaShem, what is nature and miracle is solely on its repeatability, as both come from HaShem.

Shemos 6:12, Moshe spoke before the Eternal, saying, [If] the Children of Israel did not listen to me, then how will Par'oh listen to me? To which Rabbi Yonatan Eibeschutz states, Why was Moses comparing the Children of Israel to Pharaoh? The Jews had a legitimate reason for not listening to Moses they were too preoccupied with their own suffering. But why would Moses think that Pharaoh would refuse to heed his words? Rather, Moses was afraid that Pharaoh would listen to G-d's warning thereby making the Children of Israel look bad by comparison. He therefore refused to appear before Pharaoh to carry the message. And thus, we see that Moshe was willing to forgo his own honor/mission for the sake that the Jews should not look bad.. This is what a Jewish Leader, and every true leader does... He leads by being an example to follow.

Shemos 7:2, You shall speak (tedaber) all that I command you, Torat Chaim writes, The word tedaber is related to tadber -- and you shall rule over. The defeat of Pharaoh, the epitome of arrogance and pride, could only be brought about by an individual such as Moses, the epitome of humility and nullification before G-d. Thus, we see why HaShem selected Moshe, who was the opposite of Par'oh, in many ways, to be the redeemer of the Jews from Egypt. Moshe grew up in the House of Par'oh and could have become like him, but instead, Moshe was, as the Torah states, the most humble man. And yet, this humble man, upon command of HaShem, went to Par'oh, the ruler of (then) known world, and spoke the words of HaShem to him.
Shemos 7:12, But Aaron's staff swallowed up their staffs, the Zohar tells us, From Aaron's staff we learn about the resurrection of the dead that will take place in Messianic times: If a lifeless staff, a dry piece of wood, can be transformed into a living entity, how much more so can a human being, consisting of a physical body and soul, be restored to life! Our Sages tell us that a staff represents power or sovereign, so HaShem was showing that His sovereign swallows up/removes the sovereign of others. But just as HaShem controls Life and Death, more over Life to Death, so too, He can control Death to Life as well.

As we learn about the first redemption, so may we learn first-hand the last redemption. May Mashiach come soonest, and we shall see the dead come back to life and peace throughout the world.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 31, 2015 / 19 Teves 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Shemos /
Sefer Shemos 1:1 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Shemos 5775, Shemos 5774, and Shemos 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemos, the first Parshot of Sefer Shemos, and in the secular world, we are having a New Year from 2015 to 2016. Thus, we open a new Sefer and a new year. And what does the Parshot Shemos deal with? The beginning of the end of the Egyptian Exile. The Lubavitch Rebbe has said that just as the generation within Parsha Shemos were the last of the Egyptian Exile and those redeemed, so too, we are the last generation of the current and last exile.

What can we learn from Parsha Shemos?

Shemos 1:1, These are the names of the children of Israel coming into Egypt. To which, Ohel Yehoshua, states, The verse says coming, in the present tense, rather than who came, in the past tense. For the duration of the 210-year exile in Egypt, the Jews felt as if they had just arrived in that land. They never adopted Egyptian ways and always considered their sojourn temporary.

The Rebbe writes, In Chassidic thought, it is explained that Egypt is not only a geographical location but also a state of mind. In fact the Hebrew name for Egypt, Mitzrayim, is almost identical to the word meitzarim, which means straits or limitations. The Rebbe also writes that one of the big physical difference between the Land of Israel and the Land of Egypt is that in the Land of Israel, the water comes from rain, while in the Land of Egypt, the water comes from the Nile river. Thus, in the Land of Israel, one has to look up to the Heavens for life, while in Egypt, look down. Thus, the Rebbe concludes, When viewed in that light, the exodus was an inevitable occurrence. Yes, it took years and, at a certain point, even the Jewish people's faith was somewhat weakened. But since the Jews, as individuals and as a people, were continually looking to Gd, ultimately, it was to be anticipated that Gd would turn to them and redeem them.

Meaning that we should not be too comfortable in exile, we must recall that we are in exile and need to look to the Heavens for redemption.

Sefat Emet states, Rashi explains that even though they were already counted while they were alive, the Jews were again counted after their passing, to show how dear they were to G-d. They were likened to the stars, each of which G-d counts and names, as it states, Who takes out His hosts by number, to each He calls by name. From this comparison to the stars we learn that every Jew should realize the full extent of G-d's love for him. Furthermore, the same way that the stars were created to light up the surrounding darkness of the night, so is each Jew created in order to spread the light of Torah and holiness throughout the darkness of the physical world.

Shemos 3:2, An angel of G-d appeared to him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a thorn bush, and he looked, and behold the bush was burning with fire, but the bush was not consumed. The Baal Shem Tov taught, Man is likened to a tree in a field; Torah scholars are likened to fruit bearing trees, while unlettered Jews are likened to trees that do not bear fruit. The flame of fire was burning in the humble bush the simple Jew. The simple Jew, who prays and recites Psalms with a simple faith in G-d, even without understanding the meaning of the words, has within him the flame of fire, a holiness because of his purity of heart. The bush was also not consumed. This fire can never be extinguished, for it is the simple Jew who is forever thirsty for Torah, always burning with a desire and longing for Torah, while the scholars quench their inner fire with the waters of Torah. One should not ever feel that there is nothing they can do to help Judaism. Every small part adds to the whole. A tiny spark can set ablaze a roaring fire.

entry.title: Parsha Vayechi
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 24, 2015 / 12 Teves 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Vayechi /
Sefer Bereishet 47:28 50:26
Shabbat Chazak /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayechi 5775, Vayechi 5774, and Vayechi 5733

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayechi, which translates to and he lived. This is also the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, so why does the last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet is named, Vayechi ()? Not only that, but the Parshot, itself, deals with the last 17 years of Ya'akov Avinu ( )'s life, and Ya'akov's blessing of his children, Yosef's two children, and expressed his desire to be buried not in Egypt but back in Israel. With the end of the Parsha, Bereishet 50:25, Yosef made the sons of Israel swear, saying, G-d will surely remember you, and you shall take up my bones from here.

A hint to the solution, I believe, comes from Rashi's comment to Bereishet 49:33, he then passed away and was gathered, which is, but death () is not mentioned concerning him; and our Rabbis said, Ya'akov, our forefather, did not die.. For our Sages tell us, as long as the children follow in the footsteps of their father, the father remains with them. For the children of Ya'akov were trying the Sons of Israel, the teachings of Israel/Ya'akov were alive with them, and their descendants. Even today, that chain of tradition continues, for we are still the Children of Israel, Ya'akov's descendants, and still connected to us, and us to him.

Every Jew in the world can trace their heritage back to Ya'akov Avinu, and each Jew continues his teaching, which have been passed on from father to son, mother to daughter, generation to generation. Just as we read of Ya'akov's live in Sefer Bereishet, so too, we are reading of the model/flow of our own lives.

Just like with Ya'akov Avinu, those that should be brothers to us, hate us, even claiming we stole from them, forgotten that they sold it away to us. We need to build our families away from what we know, yet keeping the teaches of our forefathers alive. At every opportunity, we try to make peace with others, even at our own expense, for we are pursuers of peace. Those around us, try to take advantage of us, but we rise to our defense against seemingly impossible odds, and the world cannot act against us in a truly significant way. We move to other countries, and make our homes there. But we must recall that our final resting place is the Land of Israel.

Our Sages tells us that the last 17 years of Ya'akov Avinu's life were among the best. And why not? He saw Yosef, his beloved son, the Vice Royal of Egypt, a land known for being steeped in sin, and yet, Yosef was still righteous as he had been within in his father's home. Ya'akov also knew that the Egypt Exile had started with Par'oh's dream, and yet, thanks to HaShem, and the preparations that he made, Ya'akov Avinu that his children would survive the exile to be redeemed (in the next Sefer).

And what preparations did Ya'akov take? Establishing a yeshiva (last Parsha), and assigning each of his children a task, and all the children were given a task to do together. Each son knew what was expected of him and his line, as well as, task(s) that he and his brothers had to preform together.

At the end of the Parsha we are told of Yosef made the others promise to bring his remains/bones back to the Land of Israel, when HaShem would redeem them, and that he was buried within Egypt. For Yosef was the leader of his time, and even in death, literally, he remained with his people.

Just as HaShem promised to redeem our ancestors from the Egyptian Exile, so too, the Prophets had foretold that we too, will be redeemed from our exile that we are currently in. Just as preparations were made before the Egyptian Exile, so too, there were preparations made before the current exile, as our Ancestors survived the first exile, so too, will we survive the last exile.

As Yosef said, Bereishet 50:25, G-d will surely remember you and take you back to Israel. It was true then, it is still true now. HaShem will remember us and take us back to land of Israel, with the coming of Mashiach, may he arrive swiftly.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 17, 2015 / 5 Teves 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Vayigash /
Sefer Bereishet 44:18 47:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayigash 5775, Vayigash 5774, and Vayigash 5773

This week's Parsha is the next to last Parshot of Sefer Bereishet. It opens with the confrontation between Yosef, the Vice Royal of Egypt, and Yehudah, the leader of the brothers. The Lubavitch Rebbe writes that the confrontation between Yosef and Yehudah, represents the two sides we need during our lives. Yosef was righteous among the Egyptians while Yehudah (and his brothers) were righteous on their own, with their flocks. Yosef, the Rebbe writes, represents creativity and self-development so that the world can be used for holy purposes, while Yehudah represents humbleness to follow HaShem. Thus, the Rebbe writes that we need to give Yosef precedence as we need to work within the world, with the world, so that HaShem may dwell among us.

Bereishet 44:18, Yehudah then stepped forward, although, Yehudah only had his nine brothers with him, and the Vice Royal had the entire land of Egypt at his call, when Yehudah felt he had to act, he did so, not intimidated by Yosef's position. At first, Yehudah tried to work within the system by talking with the Vice Royal and reason with him, but if that failed, he planned to destroy Egypt. In fact, the Midrash relates that all ten brothers were ready to do to Egypt as two brothers had done to Shemech that in part, prompted Yosef to reveal himself.

Bereishet 45:3, for they were bewildered before him. Our Sages said, the brothers followed a solitary lifestyle of shepherds, alone in the field, to meditate and pray without involving themselves. They could not conceive of the concept of being Jewish within a pagan world, especially not as one of its rulers.

How could this be? Yosef tells the brothers (and us), Bereishet 45:8, So now, it was not you who sent me here but G-d, and He made me Par'oh's counsellor, master of his entire household and ruler of the whole land of Mitzrayim. In other words, HaShem had set up the world in this way. As the Creator of the world, HaShem knows what works and what doesn't. Just as it was foretold of the Egyptian exile, Yosef was sent to ease the way.

Bereishet 46:28, And he had sent Yehudah head to Yosef, to prepare in Goshen prior to his [arrival], Rashi states, And the Aggadic explanation is: to establish a house of study from which teachings [Torah] would emanate. It was this house of study (and others) that helped the Jews survive the exile, as our houses of study help us now.

entry.title: Parsha Mikeitz
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 10, 2015 / 28 Kislev 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Mikeitz /
Sefer Bereishet 41:1 44:17
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition
Past Posts: Mikeitz 5775, Mikeitz 5774, and Mikeitz 5773

This week is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, with just two more Parshot left to the Sefer. This week is also Chanukah. How does Chanukah fit into this week's Parsha?

To recap this week's Parsha, Par'oh had two dreams, which Yosef interpreted for him, thus raising from being a prisoner to the Vice Royal of Egypt, second only to Par'oh, to carry out the Divine Plan that was revealed within Par'oh's dreams. In comparison, Chanukah is about the re-dedicated the Holy Temple, after the sons of Mattityahu defeated the army of Antiochus.

Yosef in no effort on his own, was able to defeat the might kingdom of Egypt in spirit, while the Maccabees defeated the army of Antiochus in material. Both Egypt and the Syrian-Greeks sought to destroy the Jewish spirit, but HaShem sent those to defeat them. Yosef's arena was dreams, thus, HaShem had Yosef defeat Egypt through Par'oh's dreams, turning the material wealth of Egypt into something spiritual, under Yosef. The Maccabee's arena was combat, for not only were they fighting for Judaism, but also for the Land of Israel as well.

The miracle of Chanukah is not the battles/war, but the oil that was used to re-ignite the Golden Menorah in the Holy Temple. After all, had the Maccabees broke down and used impure oil or waited until new oil could be made, all their battles/war for Judaism would have been lost. The lighting of the Golden Menorah was a Temple Service that was done every day, illuminating the night. It was not the sacrifices of the animals, birds or food offering, but the simple lighting of the Golden Menorah that was the accumulation of Chanukah.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeishev
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 3, 2015 / 21 Kislev 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Vayeishev /
Sefer Bereishet 37:1 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Post: Vayeishev 5775, Vayeishev 5774, and Vayeishev 5773

This week's Parsha is the ninth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet, with only three Parshot left. In this Parsha we see the transition from individuals of the fore-fathers, to the nation/children of Israel.

The Parsha opens with Bereishet 37:1, Ya'akov settled in the land of his father's sojourning, in the land of Kena'an. From this point on the Torah takes up the story of Yosef and his brothers, who are known as the Tribes, for they are the founders of each of the familial houses that makes up the Children of Israel. Each of the sons of Ya'akov were different and such, each Tribe had a characteristic and mission within the over-all mission of each Jew. With the sons of Ya'akov, no longer is Judaism rested upon the single shoulders, but upon many. And as history as shown, too often, when there is a group of Jews, there are difference of opinion on how one should express that Judaism. Yosef felt one way, and his brothers felt another.

Bereishet 37:4, They could not speak with him in a friendly manner. to which Rabbi Yonasan Eibeschitz writes, The main component of all controversy is the absence of dialogue, the unwillingness to listen to what someone else has to say and understand it from his perspective. If people would really know how to talk to each other, most of the time they would discover that they have nothing to argue about. Rashi writes, From their discredit, we learn their credit: they did not speak one thing with their mouths, with another thing in their heart. Our Sages tell us that the brothers thought they should follow as B'nai Noach as Sinai had not happened yet, while Yosef felt that he and his brother should follow as if the Torah had already been given. Both sides felt they were in the right, and the other was wrong. Interesting enough, Ya'akov does not get involved in this argument and the Torah itself seems to be somewhat silent as well. It is noted that Yehudah emerges as the leader of the brothers and his Tribe continues to lead, while Yosef leads but his sons do not.

Bereishet 38:27-30, When she gave birth there were twins...and he called his name Peretz, ... he called his name Zerach. The Lubavitch Rebbe writes, Our Sages compare Zerach to the sun and Peretz to the moon. The sun continuously shines in an unchanging manner; thus it symbolizes the constant way that the righteous serve G-d. The moon's appearance, however, waxes and wanes. The moon thus symbolizes ba'alei teshuva (penitents), who strayed and then returned. The royal house of David, the very source of Moshiach, is precisely from Peretz (the moon), because Moshiach will bring even the righteous tzadikim to return to their Divine source. Thus, we see the importance of repentance, as Moshiach comes from the son of Yehudah that symbolizes it. For Judaism is like an onion, there are many layers within, peel one and another layer is revealed. Even the most righteous of people, can do more.

Bereishet 40:10, And on the vine were three branches, to which the Lubavitch Rebbe writes, According to our Sages, the Jews are likened to the vine, the fruit of which gladdens G-d and man. For within every Jew exists this attribute of wine - the innate ability to delight in G-dliness, an inheritance from our ancestors. This love for G-d is hidden deep inside, much like the wine is hidden in the grape. Likewise, just as squeezing the grape releases the treasure within, so does personal refinement and self-nullification reveal this inner love and bring it to its potential. Our Sages tells us that our soul is an actual piece of HaShem, Himself, within us. This is part of the meaning that we are made in the image of our creator. It is this piece that separates us from the animals and motivates to draw near to HaShem. The Rebbe tells us that we each have within ourselves the wine that gladdens, only we need to make that wine from the grapes that we have been given within ourselves. Just as there are different types of wines, so too, there are different types of Jews, but all can gladden those around them to drink.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Nov 26, 2015 / 14 Kislev 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Vayishlach /
Sefer Bereishet 32:4 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Post: Vayishlach 5775, Vayishlach 5774, and Vayishlach 5773

Bereishet 32:4, Ya'akov sent messengers ( ), which Rashi points out, real angels. The Hebrew word messengers () can refer to human messengers or angelic messengers, so there is a debate about which were sent. And Rashi answers that as this is continuation of the previous Parsha, and the end of that Parsha, spoke of actual angels, therefore, these should be angels as well.

The Torah tells us that Esau was a wicked people, extremely set in his ways, and yet, he was able to withstand the appears of angels. In Shoftim 13:22, And Manoah said to his wife, We shall surely die, because we have seen God. upon seeing an angel. And yet, Esau had no fear of going to Ya'akov.

Because, in his essence, Esau was the son of Yitzchak and Rivkah, the same as Ya'akov. He had the same potential as Ya'akov. That he chose to do evil, is why he is so wicked. But the potential and the ability to withstand the angels is still there.

Bereishet 32:23, and his eleven children. Rashi asks, And where was Dinah? He had put her in a chest and locked her in, so that Esau should not cast his eyes upon her. And therefore, Ya'akov was punished for keeping her away from his brother, she might have brought him back to the right path, and she fell into the hands of Shechem.

The Rebbe writes that this seems to be an outrageous assertion at first glance. The Rebbe states, that this could only be, if Ya'akov knew that Dinah actually had the ability to make Esau repent his ways, but Esau would still have his free choice, which is why Rashi wrote might have. The Rebbe writes that from here, we see that Dinah was blessed with precious talent of bring, estranged Jews closer to Judaism with her wonderful, outgoing personality. Thus, when Rashi says, Was she not the daughter of Ya'akov? However, because she went out, she was called the daughter of Leah, since she two was outgoing, as the verse states, Leah came out towards him (30:16) (About her, they coined the saying, Like mother, like daughter). But just as Leah went out for the sake of Heaven, so too, did Dinah. The Rebbe points out, Thus, despite the fact that the men of Shechem were ultimately liable for the death penalty, nevertheless, Dinah's saintly desire to bring the people closer to Judaism did reach partial fruition, since all the people of the town ended up converting because of her. For, even those the men were killed, the women were not as the verse states, They captured and plundered all their wealth, all their infants their wives and everything that was in the house. (v.29). And we can presume that these women actually became part of Ya'akov's household.

And as said, if Dinah was success with the women of Shechem, a place worthy of the death penalty, she could have redeemed Esau. But because of the doubt on Ya'akov's part of Esau's free choice, the tragedy of Shechem happened.

If Ya'akov withheld his daughter, who could have moved Esau to repent, why did he send angelic messengers in the first place? Because, despite his wickedness, Esau was still a Jew, and Ya'akov hoped to make peace with him, on his part. Ya'akov was willing to sacrifice himself, but not his daughter. And yet, Dinah went out herself, and was partial successful in bring Judaism to the daughters of the land.

Bereishet 35:22, Ya'akov sons were twelve, Rashi explains, It starts with the previous subject: When Binyamin was born, [Ya'akov's] bed was complete and [his sons] were now fitting to be counted, so [the verse] counts them. And our Rabbis explained: comes to teach us that they were all righteous, because Re'uven did not [really] sin. More over, the Torah calls him, Ya'akov's firstborn., which Rashi points out, even at the time of [his] disgrace, [the verse nevertheless] called him the firstborn. With Abraham, he had Yitzchak and Ishmael; Yitzchak had Ya'akov and Esau; and yet, all of Ya'akov's children were righteous.

Bereishet 35:29, Yitzchak passed away and was gathered until his people, old and his days fulfilled, and his sons, Esau and Ya'akov, buried him. Although Esau had sold Ya'akov his first-born-ship, Esau still did not like Ya'akov and would not acknowledge what had happened. The Torah goes on to tell us of the wickedness of Esau's wives.

Bereishet 36:7, and the land where they lived could not, Rashi expounds this thus, provide sufficient pasture for their animals. But the Aggadic explanation is: because of Ya'akov, his brother (v. 6) [means:] because of the bill of debt of the decree that your descendent's will be foreigners [in a land that is not theirs] (15:13), which was imposed upon Yitzchak's descendants. [Esau] said, I shall go away from here. I [wish to] have no part [in this]; not in the gift of this land that was given to him, nor in the payment of the 'bill [of debt]' (i.e. the realization of the decree). And [another reason why he went away was] because of the shame [he felt] by having sold his birthright. The Midrash points out that at no point in history were Esau and Ya'akov both wealthy, when Esau was wealthy, Ya'akov just had a stick and on his way to Laven. When Ya'akov returned, Esau was on his way to Mount Seir.

Bereishet 35:12, Timna was a concubine. Rashi writes, [This is written] to tell us of Abraham's greatness, [by expressing] how eager people were to attach themselves to his descendants. This Timna was a daughter of chieftains, as it is said: and the sister of Lotan was Timna (v. 22), and Lotan was one of the chieftains of the inhabitants of Se'ir, of the Chorim who were the original inhabitants. She said [to Elifaz], [Maybe] I may not be worthy to be your wife. If only I could be [your] concubine! In Divrei Hayamin (I 1:36) she is counted among the children of Elifaz. This teaches [us] that he had relations with the Se'ir's wife and Timna born from them, and when she grew up, she became his concubine. That is [why it says] and the sister of Lotan was Timna, yet she is not counted among the descendants of Se'ir, for she was his maternal sister but not his paternal [sister]. She was daughter of chieftains, but settled for less, because it was important to be a part of Abraham's family. This is not the last time we see this, but she was the first.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Nov 19, 2015 / 7 Kislev 5776 / ''

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Sefer Bereishet 28:10 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeitzei 5775, Vayeitzei 5774 and Vayeitzei 5773

In this week's Parsha, Parsha Vayeitzei, the Torah speaks of Ya'akov's departure from his father's house, and goes out into the world, gets married, raises a family and gathers material possessions, and eventually returns to the land of his birth. The Lubavitch Rebbe tells us that we can take this section of Torah as an analog, for Ya'akov is likened to the soul, and thus this Parsha is about our purpose here on earth. Chassidus teaches that the soul is born in Heaven, analog to the Holy Land of Israel in our Parsha, and thus, the soul needs to leave Heaven in order to descend upon the earth and involve itself with earthly affairs, children and possessions. Why? Because we are partners with HaShem in Creation, but having children, we are involved in the creation process. In gathering possessions we interact with creation. There are Leban in the world that we have to watch out for, but HaShem is there to protect us, if we just follow His ways. Just as Ya'akov returned to the Holy Land, so too, does the soul return to Heaven. And our thoughts should not depart from Heaven as it is part of Creation as well.

entry.content:
