Parsha Toldos /
Sefer Bereishet 25:19 28:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Toldos 5775, Toldos 5774, and Toldos 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Toldos, which introduces us to Ya'akov and Esau, the sons of Yitzchak. Both are equally the sons of Yitzchak, and yet opposites of each other. Chasidus goes so far as to say that Ya'akov represents the soul, while Esau represents the body. Ideally, both sons would have worked together, but while the soul's mission is obvious, the mission of the body is hidden. We do not see the characteristics of Yitzchak within Esau, as we do Ya'akov. They come from the same source, and yet, seem so different.

Why is that? Because of the nature of the soul is seemingly closer to HaShem than the body, we more easily see the similarities, while the nature of the body is further way, we see the differences. The Soul we think of as something lofty and intangible while the body is something course and solid. And yet, they both come from the same source.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeira
entry.content:
''
Thu, Oct 29, 2015 / 16 Cheshvan 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Vayeira /
Sefer Bereishet 18:1 22:24
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Vayeria 5773

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayeria, the fourth Parshot of Sefer Bereishet.

Bereishet 18:1, appeared to [Abraham], Rashi tells us, in order to visit the sick. R. Chama, the son of Chanina said: IT was the third day after his circumcision [when it is most painful], and the Holy One, Source of blessing, came and asked after his well-being. From here, our Sages learned that one should visit the sick, just as HaShem visited Abraham.

And what is the point of visiting the sick? We learn that HaShem healed Abraham when He did so, so too, our Sages tell us that by reacting the scene, HaShem believes a bit of healing to those we visit. Just as HaShem brought three angels in the shape of man to comfort Abraham, so too, we, when we visit the sick, bring some comfort to them.

Bereishet 18:24, What is there were fifty righteous people? Rashi states, Ten righteous people for each city, for there were five localities [involved]. If you say [however] that the righteous cannot save the wicked, why [then] kill the righteous? Why the number ten? Mizrachi writes, He did not request a smaller number for each city, since ten people are an congregation. and have the power to save. Less than ten, however, are considered only individuals, who do not possess this capacity, as we find concerning No'ach, that he and his sons and their respective wives (eight people) were only able to save themselves. So how did the jump from No'ach, eight, to ten? For Abraham counted HaShem as the ninth, thus ten is the next logical step. What is also interesting is that Rashi says that Abraham said, righteous cannot save the wicked, why kill, meaning that the righteous are actually deserving of death, if they do not act to save others. Thus, we see that those truly righteous seek to save others as part of their character.

HaShem already knew the outcome and the entire situation, which Abraham did not, and yet, HaShem allowed Abraham to argue with Him, and record it within the eternal Torah. For this is a lesson for us. Just because the outcome is not in doubt, does not mean we are free from our character and duty. The pursuit of Justice must always be undertaken, even when the outcome might out turn out in our favor. While only Lot and his family was saved from the destruction of Sodom, it is likely had not Abraham argued at all Lot might not have been saved. And of course, from here, Moshe Rabbeinu learned how to defend the Jews of his generation from the example of Abraham.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
''
Wed, Oct 21, 2015 / 8 Cheshvan 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Lech Lecha /
Sefer Bereishet 12:1 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posting: Lech Lecha 5775 and Lech Lecha 5773

Parsha Lech Lecha is the third Parshot of Sefer Bereishet. The first Parsha dealt with Adam the First Human, the prototype of all humanity; the second Parsha dealt with Noach, the forerunner/father of all the nations; and now, the third Parsha, deals with Abraham, the father of Jewish nation and the prototype Jew. Just as with Adam and Noach, others descended from them, so too we see Ishmael and Esau descend from Abraham. Each generation is a refinement of the previous, but also a separation from the Source. Adam was the work of the Divine, while Abraham worked for the Divine.

In fairness, Adam had no one to learn from, while Noach had just Adam to learn from. Abraham, had both. It is interesting to note, if you line up the years, you will not that there is no overlap between Adam the First and Noach, as the Torah tells us that Noach was born after Adam the First passed away. And there is an overlap between Noach and Abraham, as both were living in the time of the Tower of Babel. In fact, Abraham was in his fifties when Noach passed away, and yet, we have no knowledge of the two ever meeting. However, Bereishet 14:18, And Malkitzedek (-), Rashi points out, An Aggadic Midrash says, he is Shem, the son of Noach. So Abraham meet his son, Shem, but not the father, Noach. We also know that Ya'akov Avinu studied at Shem's academy.

So what difference did Abraham make over Noach, the Lubavitch Rebbe writes about the opening of our Parsha: Usually translates as Go for yourself, it could also be rendered as go to yourself. Reveal your true identity as a Jew you are a child of Abraham. To do this: from your land Go away from your worldliness, from your physical desires. "from your birthplace. Do not do mitzvos by rote, as a habitual routine which you were brought up to follow. "from your father's house. In Chassidic thought, wisdom is referred to as father. In this verse, the father refers to the wisdom of the Evil Inclination. The Torah tells us: Go away from your father! Don't be a wise guy when it comes to mitzvos. Don't rationalize them away. And through all of the above, we come: "to the land which I will show you. G-d will lead us to, and reveal to us true spirituality, G-d's supernal land..

Thus we see the difference between Abraham and Noach, Noach was content with his lot in life, but Abraham was not and he went out of his home to encourage others to follow HaShem's ways. And HaShem came to Abraham and basically said, that is not enough, you need to out further, leave your father's house, and go out into the world, to the land that I will show you.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Oct 15, 2015 / 2 Cheshvan 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Noach /
Sefer Bereishet 6:9 11:32
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Thoughts: Noach 5774, Noach 5773, and Noach 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Noach, which is the second Parsha within Sefer Bereishet. Parsha Bereishet was as Rashi explains, our introduction to HaShem and who He is. In many ways, we see in Parsha Bereishet the Father aspect as He is our Creator/Parent, who cares for His children, of the Avinu Malkeinu ( ) [Our Father, Our King] that we talked about during the Days of Awe. In Parsha Noach, we see the other side, the King, who rules over all and looks after all.

Although the generations before Noach, had Adam and Eve's first hand account of HaShem, they strayed from the path that He had set in Parsha Bereishet. As the Torah records, Bereishet 6:13, The end of all flesh come before Me. Has come, present tense, and yet, that had not happened just yet. But because civilization was falling, the end was near. And yet, for the good of the world/humanity, HaShem stepped in and saved Noach and his family.

As Rashi also explained, the Torah is a book of law, not history, while each event within the Torah happened, it was not recorded for the sake of recording or entertaining, but rather to instruct.

So what can we learn from Noach and the Flood of Noach?

The Torah tells us, Bereishet 6:9, Noach was a righteous man and followed G-d's ways. Much as Adam, himself, had. And both were the founders of humanity. Every human being can be traced back to Noach and through Noach, to Adam. Adam was perfect, the work of HaShem's Himself, and Noach was perfect in his generations, and yet, around them, humanity became corrupt and requested direct Divine intervention to save humanity. Adam is and was the prototype human, designed and built by HaShem, Himself, was perfect by definition, the work of the Divine. Noach, on his own, reached that level, but like Adam, he was not able to share that perfection with others. No other human could have the same relationship that Adam had with HaShem, nor Noach's relationship as well.

Bereishet 6:14, make for yourself an ark, Rashi asks a question, There are many possibilities of relief and deliverance. Why, then, did He burden [Noach] with this construction? In order that the people of the generation of the Flood should see him working on it for one hundred and twenty years and ask him, What do you need this for? and he would tell them, The Holy One, Source of blessing, is going to bring a flood upon the world. Maybe they would [then] repent. And yet, the generation of the Flood did not, and HaShem knew that. Then why did HaShem have Noach go through all that trouble of building an ark for one hundred twenty years, knowing it would not save others but Noach and his family?

The Hebrew word for Ark is , which also means chest or box, we learn that Noach placed himself in a box, separating himself from the others, even for a good reason, he was not able to affect his generation. We see that although Noach was perfect, it was limited to his generation because he was in a box. Next week's Parsha we are introduced to Abraham Avinu, who did not live in isolation, but among the people of the world, so he was able to do more than Noach did. Of course, Abraham Avinu learned from Noach and his son, whereas Noach had only Adam to learn from. And Adam had no one but HaShem, to teach him. Had Noach had the examples of Abraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov, could Noach been more? Maybe... but who he still had been Noach? No. HaShem placed each of us in a specific place in a specific reason for us to fulfill our destiny. Noach was to restart the human race and give birth the seventy nations of the world, to whom everyone is descended from.

The Generation of the Dispersion did learn from the Generation of the Flood, the power of unity. But they too, tried to live in a box, and HaShem saw fit to fix that.

entry.title: Parsha Vzos HaBeracha
entry.content:
''
Thu, Oct 1, 2015 / 18 Tishrei 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Vzos HaBeracha /
Sefer Devarim 33:1 34:12
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Thoughts: Vzos HaBeracha 5773

This Parsha is read on Simcha Torah, not on Shabbat. This Parsha is the eleventh and final Parshot of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim 33:2, Came from Sinai, Rashi states, He went forth towards them when they were about to take their stand at the foot of the Mount, as a bridegroom goes forth to welcome his bride, as it is said (Shemos 19:17) And Moshe brought the people forth to meet G-d: this teaches us that He (HaShem) was Himself going forth facing them (cf Mechilta and Rashi on the verse quoted). Meaning we are in a relationship between ourselves and HaShem, and that relationship is reflected by Rosh HaShanah, Yom Kippur, and Sukkot. On Rosh HaShanah, we renew our relationship with HaShem. Yom Kippur, we acknowledge that we are not perfect and made mistakes, but we still wish to have a relationship with HaShem despite those mistakes. Sukkot is a celebration of the relationship.

Devarim 33:2, and shone forth to them from Se'ir, Rashi points out, because He [HaShem] first addressed Himself to the sons of Esav (the inhabitants of Se'ir) that they should accept the Law, bu they refused.

Devarim 33:2, He appeared from Mount Paran, Rashi adds, because He went there and addressed Himself to the sons of Yishmael (who dwelt in Paran; see Bereishis 21:21) that they should accept it and they also refused (Sifri, Avoda Zara 2b).

Thus, the other nations of the world cannot say that they could not have had the relationship we have with HaShem themselves, for they were given the opportunity to do so, and refused. Both the sons of Esav and Yishmael were the descendants of Abraham, so they had the potential, but for whatever reason did not fulfill that potential.

entry.title: Parsha Ha'azinu
entry.content:
''
Thu, Sep 24, 2015 / 11 Tishrei 5776 / '' ''

Parsha Ha'azinu /
Sefer Devarim 32:1 32:52
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ha'azinu 5774 and Ha'azinu 5773

This is the tenth Parshot of Sefer Devarim and next to last Parsha, Parsha Vezot Haberakhah ( ), which is read on Simcha Torah. Our Sages refer to Parsha Ha'azinu as a song, which our Sages say prophesized that there are ten songs, nine are recorded within the Tanach, and the tenth will be sung with Mashiach.

Devarim 32:1, Listen carefully, heavens, and I shall speak, and let the earth hear the utterances of my mouth. Why did Moshe Rabbeinu call upon the heavens first? Our Sages tell us that this is the day that Moshe would pass away, hence, the Heavens were nearer to him than the earth. Rashi also points out that Moshe was called them, the Heavens and earth, as witnesses, who would be a part of the reward and punishment, of what Moshe was speaking about.

Devarim 32:2, Let my teaching drip like rain Rashi states, This is the testimony that you shall testify, that in your presence, I declare, The Torah, which I gave to Israel, which provides life to the world, is just like this rain, which provides like to the world, [i.e.], when the heavens drip down dew and rain (cf. Sifri). Just as the rain provides water and life to plants, animals, and humans, so too does Torah provide life to the soul. In many places, our Sages refer to Torah as water, and we believe that just as a person cannot go too long without water, so too, a Jew cannot go too long without Torah, be it a story or song like dew, or a studying like a rainstorm. So too, as water is constantly moving, so a Jew is moving with his studying to action.

Devarim 32:3, When I proclaim the name of the Eternal, Rashi expounds this thus, when I proclaim and mention the Name of HaShem, You ascribe greatness to our G-d, and bless His name. From here they (the Rabbis) derived the law that people make the response, Blessed be the Name of His glorious Kingdom forever and ever, after the recital of a benediction in the Beis HaMikdosh (Sifri, Mechilta on Shemos 13:3; Berachos 21a; Taanis 16b). Here we learned to say to bless HaShem when His name is mentioned during our prayers.

Devarim 32:4, the rock, His actions are perfect Rashi states, Although He is strong, when He brings punishment upon those who transgress His will, He does not bring it in a flood, but in judgment, because His actions are perfect.

Devarim 32:4, A faithful G-d, Rashi comments, to reward the righteous their righteousness in the world to come; and even though He defers their reward, in the end He will prove faithful to His promise.

entry.title: Parsha Vayelech
entry.content:
''
Wed, Sep 16, 2015 / 3 Tishrei 5776 / ' ''

Parsha Vayelech /
Sefer Devarim 31:1 31:30
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Nitzavim Vayelech 5774, Nitzavim Vayelech 5773, and Vayelech 5772

This week's Parsha is the ninth Parsha of Sefer Devarim. Last year and the previous year, this was coupled with Parsha Nitzavim. This year, it is not.

Devarim 31:1, Moshe then went and spoke these words to all Israel., the Torah is telling us and all Jewish leaders, one can not sit back and lead, but must go out among the people. A leader must lead from the front, as an example, and not follow behind the people. This is true of the relationship between Man and Man, we need to interact and inquiry of our fellow's welfare. Whereas in the previous Parsha, we stood before HaShem, when we are among our people, we need to move and interact with our fellow human beings. Before HaShem, we are all similar, but among ourselves, we have our leaders, our water carriers, and our children. We cannot be isolate from our fellow Jew, but must go out and speak with them, regardless of their level or our level.

Devarim 31:2, Today I am, Rashi expounds this thus, Today my days and my years become full; for on this day (the seventh of Adar; cf. Rashi on 1:3) I was born and on this day I must die (Sota 13b). Another explanation is: I can no longer take the lead in matter of the Law; this teaches us that the traditions and the well-springs of wisdom were stopped up for him (Midrash Tanchuma; cf. Sota 13b). The Lubavitch Rebbe points out that what Rashi is saying that Moshe Rabbeinu's life was complete and nothing left unfinished, he did everything that HaShem assigned him and what was asked of him. The Rebbe also points out that Moshe's life had no separation between the mundane and the spiritual, his body and soul were used fully in the serve of HaShem, and this is the goal that every Jew to strive for. HaShem is One, and in truth everything is a part of Him, what we see as mundane is but the spiritual hidden, as if pretending to be something else. It is in us that we see a division that in reality does not exist, and like Moshe, we need to strive to get to such a level.

Devarim 31:6, He will not let you slip, Rashi states, that you should be abandoned by Him (cf. Rashi on 4:31). We need not feel lost in our Judaism, for HaShem is always there for us. Our Creator knows what we can handle and operates the world according. We might think we can run away from Judaism, but HaShem is everywhere, the same HaShem that is everywhere, is the same HaShem that can provide assistance everywhere as well.

Devarim 31:7, for you will enter with this people into, Rashi comments, Moshe said to Yehoshua: The elders of the generation will be with you: everything according to their opinion and their advise. The Holy One, blessed be He, however, said to Yehoshua, (v. 23) for you will bring the Children of Israel to the land that I promised to them, you shall bring them even against their will; everything depends on you alone; if necessary take a stick and beat them over the head: there can be but one leader for a generation, and not two leaders for a generation (Sanhedrin 8a). From this, we learn that every generation has its own leader. Although, Moshe had another leadership model for Yehoshua in mind, HaShem said there is but one leader. In each generation, the leader may not be on the same level as Moshe, as Yehoshua himself was not, but Yehoshua was still HaShem's selected leader. Yehoshua had to apply the Torah to the land of Israel, while Moshe taught the Torah in the desert. Both are the same Torah, but being applied by different generations and different situation, and yet, both situations are HaShem's selected. The Torah is eternal as HaShem, Himself, is, but He allowed each leader to apply the Torah's teachings to the issues of that generation. Eternity includes all, past, present and future, to deny one is to deny all. The Torah is eternal, so it is not something of just the Past and not of Present, let alone the Future, but something of all time.

This Shabbos is Shabbos Shuvah, the Shabbat during the Ten Days of Repentance, may the final repentance come for us and Mashiach should lead us in our prayers for Yom Kippur, which will become a celebration.

May we all be inscribed in the Book of Life and Good.
May we all be inscribed in the Book of Love and Peace.
May we all be inscribed for joy and redemption.

entry.title: Parsha Nitzavim
entry.content:
''
Wed, Sep 9, 2015 / 25 Elul 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Nitzavim /
Sefer Devarim 29:9 30:12
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Nitzavim Vayelech 5774, Nitzavim Vayelech 5773, and Nitzavim 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Nitzavim, which is the eighth section of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim 29:9, You, all [together], are standing today, Rashi writes, This teaches that Moshe assembled them in the presence of the Omnipresent on the day of his death, in order to initiate them into a covenant with G-d. Our Sages tell us that after hearing all the curses mentioned in the previous Parsha, the Jews were worried about survival, so Moshe pointed out to them that they were still standing after all that had befallen the Jews within the Sinai desert.

And it is not coincidence that we read this Parsha just before Rosh HaShanah, the Day of Judgment. Just as we reflect back on what we could have done better and what has happened to our people in past year, we are reminded once again by the Torah's immortal words, You, all, are standing today before the Eternal, your G-d; How have we survived until now? Because HaShem, the Eternal, our G-d, made a covenant with our fore-parents and with us, that we would be His people, and He, our G-d.

And you should know, before HaShem, Blessed be He, it does not matter if you are leaders of your tribe or small children, all are equal before HaShem. Everyone deserves of HaShem's mercy, loving-kindness and justice. All of us are standing before HaShem, we are upright and tall before HaShem, not hiding or bent over. We are Jews, our parents are Jews, and our fore-parents are Jews. We are tall, upright and proud before HaShem.

HaShem knows who we are, by name, there is nothing hidden from Him, we have sinned in the past year, and probably sin again in the coming year, but HaShem only expects from us what He knows we can and cannot do. HaShem judges us as we are, not as we were or might be. HaShem knows who will be children and who will be leaders among their kin. We each have a mission to fulfill on the Earth, although we may not know what it is, it exists, and we need to reflect on what we do know and work to improve ourselves.

Devarim 30:1-2, (1)And it will be, when all these things happen to you the blessing and the curse that I put before you you will then reflect upon [them when you are] among all the nations where The Eternal, your G-d, expelled you. (2) You will return to The Eternal, your G-d, with your whole heart and your entire being, and heed His voice according to everything that I am commanding you and your children today. Although, there are many curses listed and mentioned, in truth they are all but consequences of one, so too, there are many blessings listed, but in truth, they are all but the reward of one, and that one is following HaShem's will.

Devarim 30:3 The Eternal your G-d will then come back with the captives Rashi points out, it ought to have written then He will bring back your captivity. But our Rabbis learned from this that, if one can say so of G-d, His Divine presence dwells with Israel in all the misery of their exile, so that when they are redeemed, He makes redemption written for Himself that He will return with them (Sifri on Bamidbar 35:34; Meg. 29a). Furthermore, the following may be said, that the day of the gathering of the exiles is so important and is attended with such difficulty that it is as through He (G-d) Himself must actually seize hold of each individual's hand dragging him from his place (so that G-d Himself returns with the exile), as it is said, (Yishayah 27:12) And you shall be gathered one by one, O you children of Israel. And also regarding the exiles of other nations we have found this, (Yechezkel 29:14) And I will return the captivity of Egypt. In all that we do, HaShem is with us. We might think we can distance ourselves, but in truth, it is not possible. Even in our lowest state, HaShem is there, and will take us by the hand to uplift us once more. We are never alone, for HaShem is will us, whether we know it or not, and that He loves us, for we are the children of Abraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov, we are the children of those that left Egypt so long ago, and we are the children that still stand before HaShem each year, praying for a good and sweet year.

May this year be a year of peace.
May this year be a year of love and joy.
May this year be a year of harmony and happiness.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Savo
entry.content:
''
Wed, Sep 2, 2015 / 18 Elul 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Ki Savo /
Sefer Devarim 26:1 29:8
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Ki Savo 5774, Ki Savo 5773, and Ki Savo 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Savo, the seventh Parshot of Sefer Devarim.

Devarim 27:9, This day you have become the People, Rashi expounds this thus, On each day it should appear to you as thought it were today that you have entered the covenant with Him (Berachos 3b). Each day is unique and never repeated, it a gift from HaShem, and we are to make the most of it. How do we do this? By being godly, and how can be like HaShem? By doing as He does, which is what He commands. By following His Torah, we model ourselves after Him and make the most of day on Earth. Each day is separate from its past and future.

This is a powerful lesson for us, as we are in the month of Elul, preparing for Rosh HaShanah, which is around the corner. We may think that our past sins are weighing us down, but we need to remember they are in the past, gone in the wild, and we have a new start, a new day, to do what we should. Each day is a new opportunity for us to do better than before, thus elevating the past from the wind into a stepping stone for us to reach higher than before. Teshuvah, tzedakah, and tefillah are pathways to literally change the past from something invisible and vague into something tangible and supportive.

Just as important as each day, the Torah also states, People, we need not standalone, we are among our brothers and sisters. We are all equal before HaShem, all, His people, whom He has chosen out of all of Creation. We have others to support us and lean on, as family do. Every Jew has family, even if the connection dates back to our Fore-Father, Ya'akov. We are one people, one nation, under HaShem's wings and protection.

Just as Creation, itself, is constantly renewed, so too, are we, the People of HaShem, the Children of Israel, are renewed, each and every day. Each day there are new opportunities to correct our past, as we can, forge a better tomorrow, and have a good day today. We have HaShem on our side. Just as HaShem is eternal, so too, are the Children of Israel, there will always be Jews around. As the Haggadah said, In each and every generation they rise up against us to destroy us. And the Holy One, blessed be He, rescues us from their hands.

The entire world is against us, in various forms and degrees, and yet, the Children of Israel remain. Surrounded by those that have repeatedly called for our destruction, and yet, we remain. Mathematically and logically, the odds are against the Jew, and yet, miraculously, we remain. How do we survive? Because of HaShem, who renews us each and every day, as His people and He, our G-d.

Devarim 28:2, All these blessings will come upon you and reach you, because you heed the voice of the Eternal, your G-d. Why should blessings need to come upon you and reach you? Does one hide from blessings? When does a mitzvah, even unknowingly, the blessing, the reward of that mitzvah, is comes to you. Are we worthy of that reward, not really, but HaShem's mercy pours out and overflows us with blessings. When we walk in the way of HaShem, we need not worry about blessing finding us, as the blessings will found us, without any effort on our part. Yes, we need to make a vessel to hold onto those blessings and make the most of them, but the blessings come upon us on their own, no matter how far away you are. It is never too late to do Teshuvah, it is never too late to do Tzedakah, and it is never too late to do Tefillah. There are always ways to connect to HaShem, and HaShem will always connect to us. No matter how far your roam, HaShem will always find us and bless us. It is up to us to make the most of those blessings that HaShem was bestowed upon us.

In this time of Elul, we prepare for the Ten Days of Teshuvah and the coming new year, let us remember each day is a present, a gift, and each day, HaShem is with us, and His blessings overflow.

May this new year be a year of happiness and you.
May this new year be a year of free of sorrow and pain.
May this new year be a year of peace and love.

entry.title: Parsha Shoftim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 20, 2015 / 5 Elul 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Shoftim /
Sefer Devarim 16:18 21:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Previous Posts: Shoftim 5774, Shoftim 5773, and Shoftim 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shoftim, Shoftim () means Judges, as Rashi states, who pronounce sentence Moshe states, Devarim 16:18, You shall appoint for yourselves judges and policemen according to your tribes, in all your towns which the Eternal, your G-d, is giving you[...]

Rashi points out, throughout your tribes mean This teaches that judges must be appointed for each tribe separately and each city separately (Sifri, Sanh. 16b). In other words, not only is there to be judges for each and every city, but also for each tribe, and also for the nation as a whole (the Sanhedrin). And it is biblically commanded that there should be a separation between the tribe-level judges and the city-level judges.

The Torah points out that the source of the commandment is the same source as the inheritance of the Land, it is all from HaShem. Just as HaShem gave us the Land of Israel, so too, HaShem has given us a Judicial system. For the Jew, there is no separation of secular and theological, HaShem is the source of both. In the material world and the spiritual world, Humanity affects both, and our acts heals or harms both. It is both HaShem that told the Children of Israel where to live, the Holy Land/Land of Israel, and how be just. History has shown time and time again, when humans try to be moral on their own, righteousness and justice is lost. Only when one follows the ways of HaShem, is there true justice within the land.

One can look with their own eyes and see the world and its corruption by those that do not follow the ways of HaShem. As our Sages say, the corruption is not in Heaven but ourselves. And that corruption usually starts when one departs from HaShem's teachings, take it piecemeal instead of the whole. To many think they know better than the Creator of the world, and decide on their own what is acceptable and not, the slop they are on just gets steeper and steeper, and then they fall down with no one to blame but themselves.

Devarim 16:20, Justice, Justice shall you pursue. This is a warning, for true justice, you must be just in your pursuit of justice. The ends do not justify the means, for the end is but the summation of the means.

Devarim 17:9, and to the judge that shall be in those days Rashi expounds, and even though he is not as eminent as other judges that have been before him, you must obey him. You have none else but the judge that lives in your days (R. Hash. 25b). Each generation has its own judges and righteous people. Those to us, they may seem somehow less than previous generations they are still be respected and followed as the judge/righteous of their generation. There was only one Moshe Rabbeinu, who is liked to the sun, while Joshua was liked to the moon. Still those of Joshua's generation followed him as their parents followed Moshe. Tales passed down speak of miracle workers and extremely righteous people that seem impossible today, we are not to discount these tales completely as past generations were of a higher level than us. As it has been said, we are children resting upon the shoulders of our parents, as they rest upon theirs and so on. Thus, allowing us to see higher and further than they.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 6, 2015 / 21 Av 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Eikev /
Sefer Devarim 7:12 -- 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi
Past Posts: Eikev 5774, Eikev 5773, and Eikev 5772

This week's Parsha is Parsha Eikev, the third Parsha of Sefer Devarim. Rashi opening comment is, If, even the lighter commands which a person treads on with his heels (i.e. which a person in inclined to tread lightly), you will listen to. Then, Devarim 7:13, He [HaShem] will love you, bless you and make you numerous; and He will bless your progeny, the fruits of your land your grain, your wine and your oil the offspring of your cattle and the robust ones of your flock, upon the land that He swore to your forefathers to give to you. HaShem's loving-kindness exceeds what we give/do for Him. As we see, there were only three weeks of Rebuke, and yet there are seven weeks of Comfort. Seven is more than twice three.

Our Sages also point out what might seem to be a lighter commandment may not actually be that. We cannot see the spiritual forces and worlds that we cause when we perform a Mitzvah, so we cannot truly say this is a light or heavy Mitzvah. Rather, we should give equal weight to all Mitzvot as they come from HaShem.

Moshe points out, Devarim 7:17, and you say to yourself, My strength and the power of my hand have amassed his wealth for me. To which, he responds, Devarim 7:18, You shall then remember the Eternal, your G-d, for it is He who gives you the ability to amass wealth. Everything that we do and have, is because HaShem has allowed us to do so and has given us the ability to do that which needs to be done. Either we use our G-d given talents for good or ill, is up to us. Hopefully, we use our gifts to the best of our abilities and for good reasons. How do we know if what we are doing is good? It is good if it follows the way of HaShem.

Devarim 8:5, Not because of your righteousness or your rectitude are you entering to take possession of their land, but because of the wickedness of those nations, the Eternal, your G-d, is driving them out from before you, and in order to fulfill the word that the Eternal promised to your forefathers, Avraham, Yitzchak, and Ya'akov. One should not say, it's the Land of Israel, therefore, Israel should be there, rather, one should say, the Holy One, blessed be He, ordained that the Children of Avraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov should live in this land to carry out that which the Creator of the World has decreed. One mortal has any true claim on any land for the entire world belongs to HaShem, who out of His mercy and loving-kindness has allocated places on His Earth for His children to live there. For the Children of Avraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov, HaShem allocated the Holy Land, also known as the Land of Israel.

Devarim 10:12, Yet now, Israel, what does the Eternal, your G-d, request of you? Only to fear the Eternal, your G-d, to follow His ways and to love Him, and to serve the Eternal, your G-d, with your whole heart and your entire being; HaShem does so much for us, and yet, all that He asks of us is that we fear and love Him. How do we do this? By studying His words (the Torah) and follow His ways. Just as HaShem is kind, truthful and justice, so too should we be. We can be like Abraham that loved HaShem and go out in the world to spread the word about Him, or we can be like Yitzchak, remain in our dwelling place and study His ways. Both are valid paths for a Jew to follow.

Rashi points out from this verse that Our Rabbis derived from this (and now, what does G-d ask from you) that everything is in the hands of G-d expect the fear of G-d (Berachos 33b). If one truly fears HaShem, then one will not sin. If one truly loves HaShem, then one will carry out the Mitzvot with happiness.
