entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 23, 2015 / 7 Menachem Av 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Devarim /
Sefer Devarim 1:1 3:22
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition
Past Posting: Parsha Devarim 5774, Parsha Devarim 5773, Parsha Devarim 5772

Once again, we come upon the Parsha Devarim of the Sefer Devarim. As I said before, the Sefer Devarim differs from the rest of the Torah in that, in the previous four Seforim Moshe Rabbeinu was but a messenger, in this last book of the Torah, Moshe Rabbeinu is a Prophet, who takes what HaShem told him and communicates it in his own words to the people. Before, Moshe Rabbeinu used HaShem's words for HaShem's wisdom, now, Moshe uses his own words for HaShem's wisdom. For forty years, Moshe was the student, and now, after forty years, Moshe is a teacher.

In the first four Seforim, Moshe was a student in the Heavenly school, now in Sefer Devarim, Moshe goes out of the Heavenly school and teaches on the earth. What Moshe Rabbeinu teaches is still HaShem's wisdom and from HaShem, Himself, but now, having learned from HaShem, Himself, he is able to express the Divine Wisdom in his own words.

Rashi tells us that Moshe Rabbeinu began the Sefer Devarim with a veiled rebuke. Our Sages tell us that the Sefer Devarim is Moshe's Rabbeinu's last will and testament. That he's last wish was to review the Torah with the Children of Israel, whose that were the children of those that come out of Egypt with him, so they did not witness the miracles that HaShem had performed at those times. Yet, the women and the tribe of Levi were not included in the decree of those counted to remain in the desert, so they, too, saw the events that Moshe described first-hand. But they were not on the same level as Moshe. They did not see as he did, so they too share in Moshe's recount as the children did.

Just as Moshe rebuked the generation that was entering the Holy Land, we find ourselves coming upon the Tish B'Av (' ), the fast day and saddest day of the Jewish calendar. And yet, this year, Tish B'Av falls on a Shabbat, which postpones the fast to the next day, the 10th of Av (' ).

There is a lesson here.

Despite, or maybe because of, the fact that Tish B'Av is the saddest day of the year, when it falls upon Shabbat; we do not morn as we usually do, we do not fast as we usually do, nor do we do anything that on a regular Tish B'Av would happen. During the Nine Days we observe various customs to fell the lost of the Holy Temple, with no joyful events like weddings, we do not eat meat, and we do not listen to music for enjoyment. But on Shabbat, we do not observe those customs, for Shabbat is a time of joy. One day of the year versus one day of the week, does not seem to compare, and yet, this is the reality.

Moshe Rabbeinu rebukes the Children of Israel, but he does so out of love and a desire to see the Jews do better. It is tough love but love nonetheless. Just as Tish B'Av is the same, so it is not a coincidence that we read Parsha Devarim on or around Tish B'Av. Tish B'Av is also a time of rebuke, three weeks of rebukes in the Haftarah that are read.

And yet, in our time of morning, there is Shabbat, a light in the darkness of the rest of the week. In the rebukes our Prophets told us, there is hope of improvement and redemption to be had, for it is done out of love. We know this because of Shabbat and we are still here, despite all that has befallen our people. Just as Shabbat comes around every week, so too, do we remain after all the mundane people in the world.

We can take comfort in the final sentence of the Parsha, Devarim 3:22, Do not fear them, for it is the Eternal, your G-d, who does battle for you. While Moshe Rabbeinu was speaking of the conquest of the Holy Land, the fact remains, HaShem is our Protector and Guardian. It is He that fights for us and defends us. Just as the Shabbat is greater than Tish B'Av, so too, the Torah stands out from the rest.

Despite the fears of the world, of the Goyim, and what is happening, we do not fear them, for HaShem, our G-d, does battle for us.

May the need of battle/fighting be over, and fasting of Tish B'Av no longer, with the coming of Mashiach. Just as Shabbat transforms this Tish B'Av, so too, all future Tish B'Av should be transformed.

entry.title: Parsha Matos-Mas'ei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 16, 2015 / 29 Tammuz 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Matos-Mas'ei / -
Bamidbar 30:2 36:13
Shabbos Chazak /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is a double Parsha of Matos and Mas'ei, Mas'ei is the last Parsha of Sefer Bamidbar, so we say Be strong! Be strong! Let us be strengthen! ( ) upon the completion of Sefer Bamidbar. And we begin the Nine Days of the Three Weeks, and we say , for we end one section/book, and then move to another. We move through the Three Haftarah of Chastisement to the 9th of Av, after which comes the Seven Haftarah of Comfort, we just need to be strong and we will journey (Matos) from our current Egypt (exile) into the Hoy Land (redemption).

Why is the first Parsha called Matos () and what does Matos () mean? It is translated to tribes [of the Children of Israel]. The past four Parshot have been named for individuals (person or concept), Korach, Chukas, Balak, and Pinchas... The dichotomy of Judaism is that we are a People, and, also an individual. Thus, we saw the individual, now we return to the group, the Tribes of Israel. We have a responsibility to care out as an individual but also a responsibility to care out as a group, both are equally important, and Matos touches on the cross-over between group and individual, such as vows and oaths. It takes only one to say a vow/oath, but it takes at least three to nullify it (if possible, not all vows/oath can be). I said three because there are always three parties involved, HaShem, the vow/oath-taker, and the one(s) whom HaShem has authorized to act. All three parties are involved.

In speaking of vows and oaths, I am reminded of the old saying your word is your bond. Which, unfortunately, has fallen out of favor. We do not know the power of the word, too many believe a word is merely a sound, a vibration in the air, something of no substance. But it was through Divine Speech that Creation was created, while we do not have that power, our words are more than mere sound, but spiritual force that we do not fully appreciate. Like rose petals in the wind, once separated from the rose, they are gone forever never to be returned. So too our words are gone after we speak them, but their scent and touch lasts forever.

Words are concepts, intellectual manifested and communicated to others. So how does that go from Oaths/Vows to the War against Midyanim? The war against Midyanim was for revenge for the sin that they performed among the Children of Israel. Midyanim took words of Balaam and put then into action. A vow or oath is a measure of restrain for the betterment of the taker, but as the B'nai Noach had taken upon themselves not to be liken to the Generation of the Flood. Yet, Midyan decided to forgo that measure, that vow, in order to seek the destruction of Israel. Since Midyan broke their vow to follow, they were Divinely punished by Israel fighting them in war.

How does vows/oaths fit into the Tribes of Re'uven and Gad wishing to live east of the Jordan? Our Sages tells us that the Tribes of Re'uven and Gad expressed to extend the Land into the east-side of the Jordan and to stay with Moshe Rabbeinu, as he is buried somewhere in east of the Jordan.

The second half of the double Parsha is called Mas'ei, which is translated as journeys. As has been said, life is a journey. We are birth in one point in time (and space) and we pass on in another point in time (and space), from birth to death is a journey. Death is not the goal but just a transition place. There are many journeys throughout the Torah and life. Our Sages tell us that Parsha Mas'ei took place at the end of the forty years in the desert and the Children of Israel were on the verge to taking position of their heritage. Our heritage is tied back to the Tribes of Israel, for it was they whom HaShem promised the Land, as the Torah states, Bamidbar 33:54, You shall have [the land] settled according to your fathers' tribes. For we should not forget we are not the only ones journeying through world, our immediate family and extended family (tribe) are with us. Our ancestors journey with us, they brought us to where we are, we journey on, and our children will continue where we left off.

Sefer Bamidbar concludes with, Bamidbar 36:13, These are the commandments and laws that the Eternal commanded the Children of Israel through Moshe, in the plains of Mo'av by the [River] Jordan [at] Yerecho. Just as the Sefer started with Bamidbar 1:1, The Eternal spoke to Moshe in the Sinai Desert We see the journey that the entire book of Bamidbar is a journey from freemen leaving Egypt to becoming a Kingdom of Priests of HaShem, although there were dips along the way, struggles to overcome, and hardship requiring faith to endure, endure the Jewish People did.

As we close the Sefer Bamidbar and prepare to open the Sefer Devarim, so too, may we merit the closing of the exile and the opening of redemption. Just as this 9thof Av be postponed by the Shabbat, may all fast days be indefinitely postponed and removed by the ultimate Shabbat, the Era of Mashiach.

entry.title: Parsha Pinchas
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 9, 2015 / 22 Tammuz, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Pinchas /
Bamidbar 25:10 30:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Pinchas, whom the Torah testifies, Bamidbar 25:11, Pinchas, the son of El'azar, the son of Aharon the Priest, comes after Parsha Balak, who represents evil turned to good for the final redemption, in theory. Pinchas, we are told, shares the same soul as the Prophet Elijah, who heralds the final redemption, in actuality. What changed from the mere theory of Balak to the actuality of Pinchas? The Torah tells us, Bamidbar 25:11, his acting zealously among them.

Rabbi Pinchas of Koretz states, In enumerating Pinchas' praise, the first thing the Torah mentions is
that he acted among them. In Judaism, true zealousness for G-d does not mean withdrawing from society and becoming a recluse, but expressing it on the communal level.

We see the difference between Balak and Pinchas; Balak acted alone, away from his people, calling upon Balaam to do his work for him somewhat invisible, while Pinchas did his own work and among the people as clear as day. Also, why Pinchas did as he did was also clear. And yet, Rashi points on the reason why the Torah need to mention Pinchas's lineage is, Because the tribes spoke disparagingly of him, Have you seen this grandson of Puti, whose mother's father used to fatten calves for idolatrous sacrifices, and he has dared to slay a prince of one of Israel's tribes!, therefore Torah comes and connects his genealogy with Aharon (Sanhedrin 83b).

Why did the tribes disparage Pinchas, after all, the reason for his action was done in public, as the act itself was done in public. Because the tribes were trying to lessen the severity of Zimri and Cozbi's act, for their own sake, Moshe Rabbeinu's sake, and their own reasons. Our Sages tell us that one of the reasons why Zimri did take Cozbi was an act of kindness to show mercy for his tribe, and so the tribes said that look towards this merciless grandson who took the opportunity to do violence not for the sake of Heaven, but for his own sake. And the only way to disprove this, was HaShem, Himself, telling the people that Pinchas acted not as a grandson of Yisro, but as a grandson of Aharon HaCohen.

For his act of bravery, HaShem gave him and his descendants, Bamidbar 25:12, My covenant of peace and Bamidbar 24:13, a covenant of everlasting priesthood. For the past 39 years, Pinchas had been a mere Levite (as if one of HaShem's appointed can be mere anything), but now, in the last year of exile, Pinchas is elevated to same level as his grandfather, Aharon HaCohen. El'azar had been a Cohen only because his father, Aharon was established as a Cohen, and his sons and their future descendants would be Cohenim, so Pinchas, an existing descendant was excluded, until now.

While Pinchas is rewarded for his zealotry, the actual act was done in the previous Parsha, Parsha Balak. Here, in the Parsha that bears his name, Parsha Pinchas, tells us of the aftermath and the greatness of the zealotry of Pinchas.

Rashi states on Bamidbar 25:14, This is stated to tell the praiseworthiness of Pinchas: that although this man was a prince he did not refrain from showing his zeal against the profanation of the Divine Name on this account the Torah tells you who it was (a prince!) that was smitten by him. On the next verse, Rashi comments, This is states to show you the hatred the Midianites bore to Israel that they abandoned even a princess to prostitution in order to make Israel sin (Tanchuma).
In other words, this was a major event, involving major forces that required beyond-normal action. For it said by our Sages that the law of zealot is a law that cannot be taught or commanded, and a zealot can only be innocent in the very act of zealotry as it happens, a moment before or a moment after, it is a punishable act (as any other).

Just as Pinchas's zealotry was for HaShem, so too, the daughters of Tzelofchad, acted as well. If Pinchas inherited his zeal from Aharon HaCohen, where did the daughters of Tzelofchad get theirs? Rashi tells us in his comment to Bamidbar 27:1, Of the families of Menashe, the son of Yosef, which is, Why is this stated? Has it not already been said?! But it is to suggest to you: Yosef held the Land dear, as it is said, (Bereshis 50:25), And you shall bring my bones up from here, so, too, his daughters held the Land dear, as it is said, (v 4) Give us a possession among our father's; and to teach you that they were all righteous, for in every case where a person's doings and his ancestors' doings are not described and Torah enters into details of one of them, tracing his genealogy back to someone worthy of praise, it is evident that the person in question is himself a righteous man and the son of a righteous man. But if it gives his genealogy in connection with something deserving of reprobation, as, for example, (Melachim II 25:25) Yishmael the son of Nesaniah the son of Elishama [came and smote Gedaliah], then it is quite certain that all who are mentioned in connection with him were wicked people (Sifrei). So we see that the daughters of Tzelofchad were zealous of the Land as their ancestor Yosef was. The fact that the Torah placed this story here, so they were zealots like Pinchas for them to be placed within his Parsha. For our Sages tell us that HaShem, the Children of Israel, and the Land of Israel are connected in ways that are not understood by Science and interconnected to each other and among themselves. So true zealotry for one, need to be zealotry for all (three).

Bamidbar 27:22-23, And Moses did as the L-rd commanded him, and he took Joshua...and he
laid his hands upon him, and gave him a charge In Tractate Sanhedrin we are taught, The Talmud relates that Moses passed the mantle of leadership to Joshua even more generously, and to a greater degree than he was commanded. Commented Rabbi Yossi Bar Chanina: From this we learn that a person is not jealous of his disciple. For we see later that when Moshe foretells the People of that they would sin after he passes away that they do not do so until after Joshua passed away, for Moshe linked his honor with his students. Which we also learn the student reflects upon the teacher, and the teacher the student.

We started with zealotry between man and man, Pinchas, then zealotry between man and Land, the daughters of Tzelofchad, and the Parsha ends with the zealotry between man and HaShem, the offerings and Festivals. Just as Pinchas and all the daughters of Tzelofchad went beyond the law to act, so too, we need to take that positive energy into the Festivals and everyday life to go beyond the normal.

As we are in the Three Weeks, and yet, the 17th of Tammuz was a Shabbos, and the 9th of Av is a Shabbos, and we are reading Parsha Pinchas, linked to Eliyahu HaNavi (may he bring his good tidings soonest), we see that zealotry can take one beyond where they were, be it spiritual or mundane, and place us in a greater position, so too the Holy Days place us into a better position among the mundane days. Our Sages tell us that we are last of the exiled, we just need that bit of push to get over the hump into the Era of the Final Redemption, as Pinchas and the daughters of Tzelofchad both pushed the Children of Israel into the actual Land when our ancestors left the first exile, so too, those that push us, our Sages, into the Final Redemption with the coming of Mashiach, may it be soonest. May the Shabbos of 9th of Av be a day of celebration of thanksgiving instead of morning what we had lost and do not currently have.

entry.title: Parsha Balak
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 2, 2015 / 15 Tammuz, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Balak /
Bamidbar 22:2 25:9
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Balak, Balak is a non-Jew, Moavites king, who hired a non-Jewish prophet Balaam to cure the Jews. Why is Balak awarded an eternal place by having a Parsha named for him?
The Lubavitch Rebbe tells us: one point, Being that the Torah is the blueprint of creation it follows that even the lowest and most debased aspects of the world are included in th Torah. Thus, the whole Parsha of the Torah is named Balak indicating that the existence of even the most wicked inhabitants of the world are included in the Torah's overall plan for this world.. Second point, Furthermore, the Torah brings to light that, ultimately, evil exists in order to be transformed into good [] Thus, Balak, as he is written into the Torah, represents the good that will eventually arise from people as Balak, when they are transformed to goodness. Third point, This is also the inner meaning why the promise of Mashiach's coming appears in the Torah here, because with the Redemption we will witness the complete transformation of the non-Jewish nations to actually assist the Jewish people. The Rebbe's last point on this subject, Often, Parshot Chukas and Balak are read together on one Shabbos. At first glance, the themes of these two Parshot appears diametrically opposite: Chukas, meaning super-rational law, represents the highest level of Torah observance, where a person loyally follows HaShem's commands even when they make no sense to him; whereas Balak represents the wicked motives of a debased anti-Semite, contrary to HaShem's wishes. However, based on the above explanation that Balak represents the transformation of evil to good, it follows that the two Parshot pf Chukas and Balak actually correspond to the two path of serving HaShem; that of the righteous ( Chukas) and that of the ba'al teshuvah ( Balak).

Interesting enough, our Sages point out that Balak is the ancestor of Ruth, who was the ancestor of King David, the ancestor of Mashiach. Thus, we see the transformation of Balak to Ruth, Ruth to King David, and King David to Mashiach. So we see the seeds of Mashiach in Balak, twisted as they are but present nonetheless.

Bamidbar 22:23, the she-donkey saw, Rashi points out, but he did not see, for the Holy One, blessed be He, gave an animal power to see more than the man, for just because he possesses the sense his mind would become perturbed if he sees noxious beings. Balaam pride himself on seeing, but sometimes we put too much stock into seeing, forgetting there are things not worth seeing/knowing. It is a clich but ignorance is bliss has some merit to it.

entry.title: Parsha Korach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 18, 2015 / 1 Tammuz, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Korach /
Bamidbar 16:1 18:33
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Korach, in which I have talked about beforeabout Korach himself, how he went in the too far in the opposite direction of the Ten Spies that took. So I am going to skip Korach this time, and look into the rest of the Parsha.

Bamidbar 18:1, The Eternal then said to Aharon, Rashi writes, To admonish him regarding the precautions to be taken for the benefit of Israelites in order that they might not enter the Sanctuary (cf. Rashi on vessels; cf Chapter 4). The Israelites worried about the maintaining the necessary precautions and respect for the holy vessels and service of the Mishkan. So HaShem tells Aharon and his descendants will guard the service, to protect the Israelites. Although this was spoken to Moshe to tell Aharon, the Torah hides Moshe's role and goes directly to Aharon. Why is this? For Aharon was a pursuer of Peace, for he went out of his way to make peace between friends and husbands and wives. So he that made peace between Man and Man, who make peace between Man and his Creator.

Bamidbar 18:3, and that they serve you, Rashi explains, by guarding the Temple gates and by appointing from among them (cf. Arachin 11b) keeps of the Temple treasury and superintendents over these (Siphre). Rashi is telling us that those that are not a part of the primary service are still a part of those doing Holy work.

entry.title: Parsha Shelach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 11, 2015 / 24 Sivan, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Shelach /
Bamidbar 13:1 15:41
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shelach, which needs with the sin of the Spies. Rashi asks the obvious question, Why is this section with the spies put in juxtaposition with the section dealing with Miriam's punishment? To show the grievousness of the spies' sin: because she (Miriam) was punished on account of the slander which she uttered against her brother and these sinners witnessed it and yet they did not take a lesson from her (Tanchuma).

Why did the spies conspire to give a bad report about the Holy Land? Our Sages have several answers/suggestions, among them is: the spies did not understand that Judaism values both the spiritual, the physical/mundane and the interaction between them. They, the Spies, only saw the spiritual side and felt that Judaism and the people would become lost in the mundane/physical world. They thought that how they lived in the desert was the ideal way to live, as all their material/physical needs were taken care of by HaShem, Himself, with the Mana, the Clouds of Glory, and the Well of Miriam. All the Children of Israel had to do when they were in the Sinai Desert was to study Torah with Moshe Rabbeinu. But HaShem did not wish for the Jew to be isolated and dependent upon Him, rather, He wanted the Farmer to pray to Him for rain, He wanted justice to be carried out in business affairs, He wanted us to thank him for the food we eat and the beverages we drink. HaShem wants us to understand and see for ourselves that there is but One G-d, and one reality. There is spirituality within the mundane, and the mundane within the spiritual. HaShem created both the Heavens and the Earth, and the two are intertwined together. What we do here on Earth is reflected upon what happens within the Heavens.

Bamidbar 13:22, And came as far as Chevron, Rashi points out, Kalev alone went there and prostrated himself on the graves of the Patriarchs, offering prayer that he not be enticed by the his colleagues to be part of their counsel. You may see that it was Kalev who went there, for so indeed it (Scriptures) states, (Devarim 1:36) [Save Kalev the son of Yefuneh, he shall see it] and to him will I give the land upon which he walked! and it is written, (Shoftim 1:20) And they gave Chevron to Kalev (Sota 34b). That Kalev need to pray shows that the reasoning of the spies concerns were not completely unfounded, as it was, HaShem granted their request as the Children of Israel lived an additional forty years as they had before they entered the land.

This also demonstrates what a Jew should do when faced with a difficult situation/decision, just a Kalev prayers to HaShem, calling upon the Patriarchs to assistant him, so too, should we turn to HaShem for guidance and strength to do what we must, even when our peers might have what at first seems a good idea.

Bamidbar 14:40, They rose early the [next] morning and went to the top of the mountain, saying We are ready and will go to the place where Eternal has said [to go], for we have [indeed] sinned. The day before, many of the people did not believe that HaShem could do as He said, and yet, after being rebuked and their error was pointed out, they were ready to follow HaShem once more. For such is the faith of a Jew, it can be shaken but never completely lost.

Bamidbar 15:2, When you come [to your homeland] Rashi states, He informed them that they would enter the land. After the seemingly defeat of those that changed their minds and wanted to enter were denied, the Children of Israel were at a lost. Our Sages tells us that many of that generation were then afraid that just as they had sinned, so too would their children, thus delaying the entry even more. But HaShem then countered that by saying they would enter land, not their parents, but themselves, and not their children on their own as they were to do. And the parents would take comfort that their children would enter and not sin as they themselves had. For HaShem is called the Comforter of Israel.

Bamidbar 15:15, The [entire] congregation there shall be one [uniform] law for you and for the proselyte who lives [among you]. It is an everlasting statute, throughout your generations, [that] the proselyte be the same as you before the Eternal. Comes the Torah and tells us there is no double-standard in Judaism, whether one was born to the King of Israel or a convert, all are equal before HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Beha'aloscha
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 4, 2015 / 17 Sivan, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Beha'aloscha /
Bamidbar 8:1 12:16
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Beha'aloscha, the word Beha'aloscha () translates to when you light up, which Rashi comments on saying, Why is the section of the candelabrum put in juxtaposition with the section dealing with the princes? Because when Aaron saw the dedication of the princes he felt distressed because neither he nor his tribe was with them in the dedication, whereupon the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, By your life! Your part is greater than theirs, for you will kindle and prepare the lamps (cf. Tanch.; see also Nachmanides). The Tribe of Levi did not present an offering to the dedication of the Mishkan, a once-in-history event, so they and their prince, Aaron, felt left out. Comes HaShem, Himself, and tells Aaron, that the service of the Candelabrum is greater than the once-in-history dedication offering. This is very important aspect of Judaism, while once-in-history is a unique opportunity, doing something daily is considered greater. Our Sages tell us that is better to give a dollar a day for five days, then giving five dollars on a single day in the same time frame. There is strength in repetition, building upon the previous action, for our ends is nothing more than the summation of our means. By doing something daily, we show our commitments and dedication. Some can reach a spiritual high, but it is empty if it does not carry you somewhere.

There were several services that were done daily, why was the Candelabrum chosen as a service greater than the Princes' offerings. Of all the services, the Candelabrum service, the lighting of the candles, seems at first the least, as neither the Mishkan nor the Holy Temple needed the Candelabrum's light, per say. Rather the Candelabrum served as a metaphor for the light of Torah and the wisdom of HaShem. It was a daily ritual to clean and light the Candelabrum, so it would be light all day and night. Not as a source of light, but showing how something so mundane can be elevated into something Divine.

Bamidbar 8:22, Just as the Eternal had commanded Moshe concerning the Leviyim, so did to them, Rashi points out, to the praise of those who performed the rite (Moshe, Aaron, and the Israelites) and those who it performed on them (the Levites) that none of them put any obstacle in the way. The Leviyim were shaved, waved, and had the hands of the Israelites placed upon them. All the Leviyim were involved directly, and all the Children of Israel, (in)directly.

Bamidbar 8:24, He who is twenty-five years old, Rashi remarks, But elsewhere (4:3), it says, from thirty years old! How are these reconciled? From twenty-five years on he (the Levite) comes to learn the laws regulating the service, and he studies for five years, and at the age of thirty he may do the service. From here that a student, who does not experience success in his learning for five years, will never experience it (Sifrei; Chullin 24a). So the Levite would study for five years, and serve for twenty years, so we see here that doing/actions are more than studying/theory. First we study, but it is meaningless if we do not put it into practice.

Bamidbar 9:10, or is on a journey of some distance Rashi states, There is a dot on it, in order to tell that he does not really have to be far away, but he was outside the threshold of the courtyard during the whole time of slaughtering the Passover sacrifice lasted. (Pes. 93B, cf Sifrei). On the Second Passover one may have with him unleavened and leavened bread in his house, and there is no festival in connection with it, and the eating of leaven is forbidden only together with it (the Passover Sacrifice) i.e. while is being eaten (cf Pesachim 95a). In other words, regardless of the reasons why one was literally or figuratively distance during the first Pesach, one can always return for the Second Pesach. No sin is so great that Teshuvah is not possible. If HaShem can forgive the Golden Calf and all that our foreparents have done, so He can give us. No matter how low or how far away a Jew can be, HaShem will always welcome them back. It is never too late, done too much, for a Jew and HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Naso
entry.content:
''
Thu, May 28, 2015 / 10 Sivan, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Naso /
Bamidbar 4:21 7:89
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Naso, which is a continuous of Parsha Bamidbar, where we left off with the counting of the Tribe of Levi, the sons of Kehas carried the Ark, the Table, and other holy vessels. Because the sons of Kehas carried the Holy Ark, they were separated into last week's Parsha, and we resume the other two children of Levi, Gershon and Merari.

Bamidbar 4:21, Also calculate the total number of the sons of Gershon, them as well, Which Rashi tells us implies, As I [HaShem] commanded you with regards to the children of Kehas; to see how many there are that have reached to be included for service. We might think that because the Sons of Kehas were singled out to carry the holy vessels of the Mishkan that the other tasks involving the Mishkan might be considered less important or even trivia, comes the Torah and says, them as well. For where one carried the Ark or the curtains of the Mishkan, each part of the Mishkan is important, and can only function as a whole.

Bamidbar 4:32, [...] You shall designate by name the implements charged to them for their burden. So there should not be confusion or favoritism of any item of the Mishkan, as Aharon HaCohen or one of his sons would appoint each person their duty within their families.

Bamidbar 5:2, to banish from the camp, Rashi explains, At the time of their encampment, there were three camps: within the hangings of the courtyard of the Mishkan was the camp of the Shechinah. The encampment of the Levites surrounding it as described in the portion of Bamidbar Sinai (1:50) was the Levite Camp; from there until the edges of the camp of the divisions, in all four directions was the camp of the Israelites. Anyone afflicted with tzara'ath was expelled from all three of them. One with a discharge was allowed into the Israelite camp, but banned from the other two. And one defiled by a dead body was permitted into the Levite camp, and is banished only from the camp of the Shechinah. Our Sages derived all this from the verses in Tractate Pesachim (67a,b). From Rashi's description, we see that at the center of all encampments was the Mishkan, where the Presence of HaShem, the Shechinah manifested and the Holy Service was conducted. From here, we see that Judaism, its practices and studying should be at the heart of all our undertakings as well.

Bamidbar 5:13, But it was hidden from her husband's eyes Rashi states, it excludes the case of a blind man. It follows therefore that if he sees her improper conduct and willfully choses his eyes to it, the waters cannot try her (Sifrei; Sota 27a). In other words the trial of a Sotah, only works if the husband is ignorant where she is still permissible or not. And he, himself, has not done anything to become non-permissible as well. We should take note that while there are questions for mortal eyes, there are none for HaShem.

Bamidbar 5:15, He shall neither pour oil over it, Rashi expounds, so that her offering should be beautiful because oil is called light while she acted in darkness (Tanch.; Sota 15a).
Bamidbar 5:15, nor put frankincense on it, Rashi adds, Because the matriarchs are termed frankincense, as it is said, (Shir HaShirim 4:6) I will get me to the hill of frankincense (which is taken as an allusion to the matriarchs), while she deviated from their paths (Tanch.)

Bamidbar 5:15, a meal offering of jealousies Rashi explains the plural being used because it arouses against her two outbreaks of jealousy the jealousy of the Omnipresent and the jealousy of her husband (Tosefta Sota 2; Sifrei; cf. Rashi's second comment on v. 12).
From these three, we see that this suspected adulteress acted against not only her husband but against HaShem as well.

Bamidbar 5:17, Holy water, Rashi states, which has been sanctified in the washstand. Because the washstand was made from the copper of the mirrors of the women who had gathered (see Shemos 38:8), whereas this one had abandoned their ways. They had intercourse with their husbands in Egypt beneath the apple tree (Song 8:5), whereas this one, who had corrupted herself with another let her examined through it. The water was holy because it came from the washstand, which was created for holy purposes. And as a Sotah has acted against her fore-mothers, so their work tests her.

entry.title: Parsha Emor
entry.content:
''
Thu, May 7, 2015 / 18 Iyyar, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Emor /
Vayikra 21:1 24:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Emor. Parsha Emor deals with the sanctity of the Cohenim and the sacrifices and the sanctity of the days of the Festivals. Our Sages tells us when the Torah uses speak it is a command to relate the Divine Words directly to the people as HaShem, Himself, said to, while when the Torah uses say, it is a statement that HaShem wishes for Moshe to relate in his own words the concepts to ensure it is understood by the listener. Here, in this Parsha, we are to understand in our own words what HaShem wishes for us to learn in our own ways.

Vayikra 21:1, Say to the Priests Rashi points out, 'Say' and again 'You shall say to [your children]' - to admonish the adults about their children also (Yevamot 114a). The very first lesson that we are to learn here, is that education, the very eduction of our children, is very important.

Vayikra 21:2, Except for his relative ( ) Rashi tells us ' denotes his wife (Siphra; Yevamot 22b).' For who is closer to a man, than his wife? For a husband and wife share a heart, a mind, and soul. Just as Chava/Eve came from the flesh of Adam HaRoshan, so too, a husband and wife are one unit. Many times in the Torah, when it speaks of a man, the Torah is really speaking of a husband and wife together as one, like Adam HaRoshan before HaShem separated Chava/Eve from him.

Vayikra 21:6, They shall be sanctified, Rashi states, even against their will the court shall force them to remain holy in respect to this (cf Siphra). A Cohen might think, if he is defied for one reason why not continue to be defied for another. The Torah comes and tells us, They shall be sanctified for their G-d and must not profane the Name of their G-d. For the Cohenim are the priests of HaShem, and they reflect upon Him.

Vayikra 21:21, has a deformity Rashi explains, so long as he has the bodily blemish he is unfit; consequently, if his blemish disappears, he becomes again fit (Siphra). Just as the sacrifice should be perfect, so too that the one that offers the sacrifice should appear to be perfect as well. In Temple days, the physical reflected the spiritual, and spiritual reflected the physical, hence Tzara'as. Nowadays, while this is still true, we are not at the same spiritual level as our ancestors were, so it is not as apparent as those days.

entry.title: Parsha Tazria-Metzora
entry.content:
''
Thu, Apr 23, 2015 / 4 Iyyar, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Tazria-Metzora / -
Vayikra 12:1 15:33
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is a double-portion as it combines Parsha Tazria and Parsha Metzora into one. This is done to ensure that we complete the Torah readings on Simcha Torah.

Vayikra 12:2, If a woman conceives, Rashi writes, Rabbi Simlai said: Just as the formation of man took place after that of every cattle, beast and bird when the world was created, so, too law [concerning the cleanness], regarding him is set forth after the law [concerning the cleanness] regarding cattle, beast and bird (Vayikra Rabba 14). There is no coincidence within the Torah, everything is placed according to Divine Wisdom. So it is not a mistake or coincidence that after the animal cleanness is handled, then Mankind cleanness is handled. Rashi also does not name his source without reason, so who was Rabbi Simlai, he was an Amora living in the Holy Land and he taught, The Torah begins and ends with acts of kindness (Sotah 14a). So greater act of kindness is there then new life and what better place to start than creation/birth of a person.

A classic question asked in the Gutnick edition is, Why does a woman who gave birth need to bring a sin-offering in atonement? What sin did she commit? (Vayikra 12:6-7) Ramban answers, Our Sages said that that when a woman is giving birth she swears that she will never come to her husband again and conceive (Nidah 31b). Thus, she requires atonement. Bachaye answers, The woman is required to bring a sin-offering due to Chava (Eve)'s sin with the Tree of Knowledge, for when the roots are damaged the branches are affected too.. Sefer HaChinuch answers, The sacrifices are to thank G-d for the miracle of safe childbirth. So the Torah understands that human nature is to say things we regret later when in pain, that we are connected from the First to last, and child-birth is a miracle to be thankful for.

Vayikra 13:2, [He shall be brought] to Aharon, Rashi points out, It is a Scriptural decree that the uncleanness and purification of leprous plagues are pronounced only by the mouth of a priest (Siphra). The Sages ask, why Aharon (or a priest), because Aharon was a pursuer of Peace and Harmony. This person came and through speech caused hurtful feelings and dissent. So let the Pursuer of Peace and Harmony come and try to repair which is needs repair.

Vayikra 13:14, on the day, Rashi asks, Why is this word used? To inform us that there are days when you may see (examine) the plague and there are days when you may not examine. One this account they (the Rabbis) said: A bridegroom is given a respite of all the seven days of the marriage festivities t him, and to his clothing and his house (i.e. whether he himself or his clothing, cf. v. 17, or his house, cf. 14:33 ff., has been affected by a leprous disease), and similarly on a festival he (everyone) is given a respite all the days of that festival and during these periods the priest may not come to examine him or his clothing or his house (Negaim 3:2; Moed Katan 7b; cf. Bechoros 43b). This is to remind us that Tzara'as is not actually leprosy as we know it, but a Divine condition to reflect upon the physical the spiritual illness of a person.

Vayikra 13:46, He shall live alone Rashi expounds this thus, that people who are unclean from other causes than that of leprosy shall not abide with him (Pesachim 67a; cf. Siphra). Our Rabbis said: Why is he (the leper) treated differently from other unclean persons that he should abide solitary? Because he, by slanderous statements, (cf. Bamidbar XII. 10) parted man and wife, or a man from his friend, he must be parted from everybody (Arachin 16b). In other words, measure for measure, as this person separated others, so too, shall this person be separated from others.

Seeing as Tzara'as isn't possible now, what does it mean to us? The Lubavitch Rebbe tells us: The Talmud states: The son of David (Mashiach) will only come when every government becomes heretical. Rabah said, Where do we see this is Scripture? From the verse, He has turned completely white, he is ritually pure (Sanhedrin 97a).
Rashi (ibid) explains: Just as when the affliction has spread throughout the entire skin the person is ritually pure, so too, when all the governments have become heretical, the redemption will come.
This sign of redemption could be seen as either: (a) A negative sign, that people have become so corrupt that G-d is forced, so to speak, to save the world and bring redemption. (b) A positive sign, that the world has become so refined that it is clear to everybody that any regime or government which is not based on Torah is heretical and corrupt.
This parallels the two views expressed above:
(a) If the corruption of governments is a negative sign, it follows that G-d is forced to bring the redemption, so to speak, despite the world. This corresponds to the view that the law (he has turned completely white, he is ritually pure) is a suprarational decree of Scripture, which is followed despite the fact that it is illogical.
(b) But if the corruption of governments is a positive sign, it follows that G-d is bringing the redemption because the world has become good. This corresponds to the view that the law is logical. (Based on Likutei Sichos vol 32, pp 82-83).

In what order was Tzara'as inflicted? When the Children of Israel were in very high spiritual state such as they were in the Desert of Sinai, the order is as the Torah says, upon a person, upon his clothing, and finally upon his house. In a time of lower spiritual, such as in the Days of the Holy Temple, first his house was afflicted, then his clothings, and finally his body.

Vayikra 14:4, Living [birds] (), Rashi mentions, this term excludes , such birds which suffer from some fatal organic disease ( does not only mean living, but also capable of continuing to live.).
Vayikra 14:4 [Ritually]-Pure, Rashi points out, this term excludes an unclean bird (of a species that may not be eaten) (cf. Chullin 140a). Because the plagues come as a punishment for slander, which is done by chattering, therefore birds are compulsory for his (the leper's) purification, because these chatter, continuously with a twittering sound (Arachin 16b).
Vayikra 14:4 Cedar Wood, Rashi comments This lofty tree was used because plagues come also as a punishment for haughtiness (cf. ib.).
Vayikra 14:4, A thread of scarlet [wool] and [a bunch of] hyssop ( ), Rashi asks, What is the remedy he should use, that he may be healed? Let him, abandoning pride, regard himself lowly as a worm () and as hyssop (cf. Yalkut 1:559).
Thus we see that Scripture provides the cure for the Tzara'as and a warning about being haughty. In other words, if we get too big for your breeches HaShem will be there to put us in our place.

Vayikra 14:34 and I put a Tzara'as mark [on a house] Rashi explains, This was an announcement to them that these plagues would come upon them (Siphra: Horiyos 10a), because the Amorites concealed treasures of gold in the walls of their houses during the whole 40 years the Israelites were in the wilderness , and in consequences of the plague they would pull down the house and discover them (Vayikra Rabba 17). So we learn from here that what might seem like a tragic thing, can in fact be a positive thing.

We may think that the current Exile is a punishment, like Tzara'as, but we should recall Rashi's comment to Vayikra 14:34, above, just as the mark on the house was a punishment, there was a greater benefit waiting for us. Although we may not see if now, when Mashiach comes, then we will see.

May Mashiach come soonest, so we see the treasures and not the torn down walls.

entry.title: Parsha Shemini
entry.content:
''
Thu, Apr 16, 2015 / 27 Nissan, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Shemini /
Vayikra 9:1 11:47
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week Parsha' is Parsha Shemini, the Hebrew word Shemini, means Eighth, as the Verse says, Vayikra 9:1, And it was on the Eighth day, which brings up the question of eighth what? Rashi answers, of the inauguration of the priests into their sacred office (cf. Siphra); this was the New Moon on Nissan on which the Tabernacle was finally erected (cf. Rashi on Shemos 40:29) and it (that day) received ten crowns (it was distinguished in ten different ways) what are enumerated in Seder Olam (ch. 7; Siphra; Shabbos 87b).

Shabbos 87b, A Tanna taught: That day took ten crowns; (1) the first day the act of Creation, (2) the first day of the offerings of the Princes, (3) first day of the Kenunah, (4) the first day of the communal service, (5) the first day of the descent of the Heavenly fire upon the Altar, (6) the first day of eating sacrificial food in a prescribed place, (7) the first day of the Shechinah's residing in the Temple, (8) the first day for the Kohanim to bless the People, (9) the first day of the prohibition against Bamos, and (10) the first of the months of the year.

So our Sages points out that this day that the Torah talks about, a lot of firsts happens upon it. Our Sages also point out that the first of the ten crowns relates back to the Days of Creation, which are seven, and eight is defined as one more than seven, thus, eight is one beyond the natural. So the day that the Tabernacle was completed and actually put into use, was likened to an additional day, an eighth day of Creation, for the whole purpose of Creation was to establish a dwelling place for HaShem among His children was done on that day. It should be pointed out that our Sages say that Creation is an ongoing process that does not stop, so just as HaShem continuously does the seven days of creation, so also do we need to continuously do our part of the eighth day, making room/place for HaShem among ourselves.

Vayikra 9:23, And they came out and blessed the people, Rashi states, They said the words that conclude The Prayer of Moses (Tehillim/Psalm 90:17): May the beauty of the Lord our G-d be upon us i.e. May it be HaShem's will that the Shechinah may rest upon the work of your hands. They invoked just this blessing and not another formula because during the whole seven days of the installation when Moses was setting up the Tabernacle and officiating therein and dismantling it daily, the Shechinah had not rested upon it and the Israelites felt ashamed, saying to Moses: Our Teacher Moses! All the trouble which we have taken was only that the Shechinah may dwell amongst us, so that we may know that the sin of the golden calf has been atoned for on our behalf! He therefore had said to them (v. 6): This is the procedure that the Eternal has commanded you [to] do, and the Glory of the Eternal will [then] be revealed to you (i.e. only after these offerings will have been brought by Aaron (cf v.7) will G-d's glory appear unto you). My brother Aaron is more worthy and excellent than I am, so that through his sacrifices and ministration the Shechinah will rest upon you, and you will thereby know that the Omnipresent G-d has chosen him to bring His Shechinah upon you.

Only after the above does the Torah say, Vayikra 9:23, and the Glory of the Eternal was then revealed to the people. Not after all the animal sacrifices, not after the sacred services, but after its conclusion and the blessings of Moshe and Aharon, did the Shechinah comes to earth. There is a very powerful lesson here for us to learn. We can do everything correctly as prescribed by the Torah and we will not see a Heavenly sign that we can perceive. While Moshe and Aharon were in the Mishkan, the Israelites did not see the Shechinah, only when they had come out, in peace and in blessing, after all had been done, did the Israelites see the Shechinah. Sometimes we can do all that the Torah requires of us, when we ask HaShem for assistance, and sometimes the answer is 'No' or 'Not this way.' It was not the sacrifices or the service that brought the Shechinah to Israel but going out in peace and blessing that did it. We cannot bribe HaShem, nor understand His plan for us, but we must acknowledge that His plan exists and He has our best interest in heart.

entry.title: Parsha Vayikra
entry.content:
''
Fri, Mar 20, 2015 / 29 Adar, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Vayikra /
Vayikra 1:1 5:26
Rosh Chodesh Nissan /
