This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayikra, the first Parsha of Sefer Vayikra. It is also Shabbos Rosh Chodesh Nissan, which called Shabbos HaChodesh. So we have a special Maftir and Haftarah to help prepare us for Pesach that is coming.

entry.title: Parsha Vayakhel-Pekudei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 12, 2015 / 21 Adar, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Vayak'hel-Pekudei / -
Shemos 35:1 40:38
Shabbos Chazak /
Parsha Parah /
Bamidbar 19:1 19:22
Ezekiel 36:16 36:36
Shabbos Mevarekhim /
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is a double portion Parsha of combining Parsha Vayak'hel and Parsha Pekudei, which are the last two Parshot of the Sefer Shemos. As we finish the Sefer Shemos, it is Shabbos Chazak, where we say (Be strong! Be strong! May we will be strengthen!) after the last verse of Sefer Shemos. It is also the last Shabbos before Rosh Chodesh ( ), which we call Shabbos Mevarekhim, also this is a special Shabbos Mevarekhim, as it is the Shabbos Mevarekhim that welcomes in Rosh Chodesh Nissan, which has a special name, Shabbos Parah, which we read to recall the purification rituals that were done in preparation for Pesach.

Interesting enough, the Torah takes the final two Parshot of the Sefer Shemos to tell us the details of the actual construction of the Mishkan, which follows the instructions that where given, in detail, in two Parshot before. The Torah, which is brief and to the point, could have easily just mentioned that the Children of Israel did as HaShem commended Moshe, and that would be brief, and yet, the Torah goes into details of the actual construction of the Mishkan, just as it went into details of the description of what they should make. From this, we learn a very valuable lesson of Judaism. The first two Parshot are study of the Mishkan's construction, while the final two are the actual practice of the Mishkan's construction. By giving both two Parshot each, we see that the Torah holds both study and actual practice, to be on the same level of importance. There is a dichotomy within Judaism, we study in order to know what to do, and we practice what we study. Both are equally important.

The Torah tells at the beginning of the actual construction of the Mishkan, Shemos 35:1, And Moshe assembled the entire congregation of the Children of Israel [...], in order to construct the dwelling place of HaShem, the people had to be united as one. Every Jew had a part in the construction of the Mishkan. No matter the actual object created, it was all a part of the Mishkan, and all was holy. Just as with the Mishkan, so too, with Life itself, each Jew as a mission, a part to create, which when taken as a whole of the Jewish People, creates a dwelling place for HaShem, here on Earth. The most mundane object, a copper mirror, can be transformed into the holy copper basin that allowed the Holy Service in the Mishkan and the Holy Temple to be carried out.

Shemos 35:2, Work may be done for six days, but on the seventh day it shall be holy for you a complete cessation of work for the Eternal. Rashi points out that the work of the Mishkan, did not override the Mitzvah of Shabbat. Why did Moshe point this out? Our Sages tell us for two reason, one that the Jewish People were so eager to construct the Mishkan, there was a worry that the Shabbat might be forgotten, hence Moshe's warning; two, within the Mishkan (and the Holy Temple), in pursuit of the Service, exceptions were done on the Shabbat and Yomim Tovim that may lead others to think that the forbidden work might be permitted elsewhere or in a similar fashion, comes the Torah and reminds us that the Mishkan and Holy Temple were extremely holy places and miracles happened there so that was forbidden elsewhere was permissible there, after a fashion.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Sisa
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 5, 2015 / 14 Adar, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Ki Sisa /
Shemos 30:11 34:35
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Sisa, it is read after Purim, and deals with the final instructions on the Mishkan and the Sin of the Golden Calf.

Shemos 30:12, When you [wish to] obtain the total amount, the Hebrew is , which literally means, when you raise up the heads, so the Parsha is about raising/elevating, so the question becomes how could the recording of the Sin of the Golden Calf be in a Parsha named for raising/elevating, when talking about one of the lowest points in the Torah.

The answer can be found here, Shemos 30:13, half a shekel of the holy shekel, twenty gerah to the shekel. Half of shekel [they shall give as] a selected contribution to the Eternal. Shemos 30:15, the selected contribution for the Eternal to atone for yourselves. The incident with the Sin of the Golden Calf shows us that regardless how low one can go, there is always salvation and atonement to be had. And atonement can be as simple as a half shekel. Why a half shekel? To show that we are not alone, and only with others can we be full, complete.

Rashi tells us, Shemos 30:13, G-d showed Moshe a coin of fire weighing half a shekel, and He said, They should give one like this. Based on the teaching of the Lubavitch Rebbe's Sichas Shabbos Ki Sisa 5766, fire differs from all other elements on this earth, in that it strives upward, reaching ever higher, dancing, flickering, until finally it frees itself of its chains when the wick burns out and it unites with its source. Fire is the paradigm of self-effacement, having no district shape or form of its own. A coin, however, is hewed from the depths of the earth, the lowest of the four elements that constitute the makeup of this world. The antithesis of fire, the coin falls ever downward, clearly defined in its shape and form. Fire represents the transcendence of the spiritual; a coin represents the crassness of the physical. It was not despite the sharp contrast between them, but specifically because of it, that G-d showed Moshe a coin of fire. G-d taught Moshe that the coarse and the unrefined is not necessarily the antithesis of the most holy and pure. The physical does not repel the spiritual, rather they can work in harmony, until they reach complete fusion, absolute unity, as represented by a coin of fire. On a practical level, G-d taught Moshe that even coarse human beings who are naturally driven by selfish motives, self-love being their basic instinct, can also serve the Divine with the most noble of services, as represented by the complete selflessness of fire. We see here that through HaShem, opposites can create harmonies and from the depth of the Sin of the Golden Calf, a metal, Teshuvah () can reach upward like fire, returning to its source.

Shemos 30:19, Aharon and his sons shall wash their hands and feet from it. Other form of cleansing is through water, which always flow down, thus is said to be humble. As fire reaches up to reunite with its source, so water flows down to find its source. One cannot distinguish among drops of water from different sources, as water is water, and will unity with itself very easily.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
''
Thu, Feb 19, 2015 / 30 Shevat, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Terumah /
Shemos 25:1 27:19
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Terumah, which discusses the creation of the Mishkan or Tabernacle, which was a portable temple that the Jews carried with them throughout the journey in the desert. The Mishkan remains with the Jews in service, until the Holy Temple was built by King Solomon.

The Torah relates, Shemos 25:8, They shall make a sanctuary for Me, [so that] I may dwell among them. Our Sages point out that HaShem said, dwell among them, not dwell within it. For in truth, no structure of any kind can withstand or enclose HaShem. Nor is that the reason why HaShem instructed us to build a Mishkan. The verse starts out with they, plural, then a sanctuary, singular and yet can encompass many people, and then goes among them, plural. In other words, if the many work together for HaShem's sake, there you will find HaShem in all His glory, whether it is the building of a Mishkan, a Jewish community, or praying together at a Shul. Where there is harmony and spirituality for the sake of others, that is what HaShem desires of us.

Shemos 25:11, You shall overlay it with pure gold from inside and outside you shall overlay it Why was this? Why should the inside of the Holy Ark be pure gold when no one would see it? Our Sages tells us this to tell us a lesson, just as the same gold is outside of the Holy Ark is inside, so too, what you show others is what should be inside of you. How you act in public and private should be the same. Also, just as it is important to beautify the outside of our homes, appearances, and our actions, so to do we need to beautify what is inside of us as well. One should not decorate the outside with gold, and and leave mere copper for the inside, nor the reverse.

Shemos 25:15, The poles shall remain in the rings of the ark; they must not remove from them. Chassidus teaches us that this verse teaches us, paraphrasing, just as the pole allow access to the Holy Ark, so too, must we connect (attach) ourselves to Torah at all times. Thus as our Sages tell us that the Holy Ark carried its bearer (instead of the natural way around), so too when we support the Torah, the Torah carries us.

Shemos 25:24, a gold rim Rashi points out that this gold rim is A symbol of the crown of royalty (Shemos Rabbah 34:2), for the table is a mark of wealth and importance, as [people] say [in reference to wealth]: the royal table (Yevamos24b). This it the Show Table upon which the Show Bread was placed before Shabbos, and removed after the following Shabbos. Just as the Holy Ark represents Torah, the Show Table represents wealth and livelihood. As the bread's exchange revolved around the Shabbos, so too, our livelihood revolve around the Shabbos as well. For we are commanded, Shemos 20:9-10, (9)Six days may you work and perform all your labor, (10)but the seventh day is a Sabbath to the Lord Both are equally important, the mundane work of the six days balances the spiritual rest of the seventh day. Our livelihood is working for six days and also resting on the Shabbos.

Shemos 25:31, the candelabrum shall be hammered out, Rashi explains, shall not make it out of separate pieces, nor shall he make its branches and its lamps out of separate parts and afterwards attach them by a welding process called solder in Old French, but rather it shall be made entirely out of one piece [of gold which] he beats with a hammer and cuts with his craft tools and [thus] makes separate branches on both sides (Meleches Hamishkan, ch 9). The candelabrum represented the light of Torah, and we can learn that just as the candelabrum was made from a single piece and worked into its proper form, so too must we take our education from a single piece or in this case, single place, Mount Sinai. As Pirkei Avot (Ethics of our Fathers) states in the very first verse, Moses received the Torah from Sinai and gave it over to Joshua. Joshua gave it over to the Elders, the Elders to the Prophets, and the Prophets gave it over to the Men of the Great Assembly. Moshe and Joshua represent the base/truck, while the Elders, Prophets and Men of the Great Assembly represents the branches and lamps of the candelabrum, that is Torah study. All of one piece, in accordance with HaShem's command.

Shemos 26:1, And the Dwelling [cover] you shall make, The Torah includes And () to teach us that just as important are the Holy Ark, the Show Table and the Candelabrum, so too, are the drapes and the outer structure of the Mishkan important as well. That the dwelling covers are connected to the previous chapter, detailing the interior objects. Although their importance is shown by being mentioned first, the outer structure and all was built first, as they saying goes, one does not furnish a house that has not been built first. Just as details were given for the furniture of the Mishkan, so too were details given for the structure/housing itself.

entry.title: Parsha Mishpatim
entry.content:
''

Thu, Feb 12, 2015 / 23 Shevat, 5775 / '' ''



Parsha Mishpatim /

Shemos 21:1 24:18

Maftir: Parsha Shekalim /

Shemos 30:11 30:16

Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi



This week's Parsha is Parsha Mishpotim, and we add a special Maftir reading of Parsha Shekalim, in preparation for Purim that is coming up. Purim is always on 14th of Adar, which this year falls on Thursday, March 5th, starting the night before.



Shemos 21:1, And these are the laws, Rashi points out, Wherever [a section begins with] these, [it] rejects something previous, [but wherever a section begins with] and these, [it] adds to something previous (Shemos Rabbah 30:3). [There here it says and these to teach us that] just as [the commandments written in] the previous section [were received at] Sinai, so, too, these [written in this section were received at] Sinai (Mechilta, Parashas Mishpotim, sec. 1). Why, then, is the section dealing with civil laws placed following the section [about the construction] of the altar? To tell you that you shall place [the seat of] the Sanhedrin to the Temple. We see that just as spiritual matters came from Heaven, so too does moral and civil law come from Heaven as well. We can trace any moral law back to the Torah, for HaShem is the Source of Morality. We judge society by the standard of Torah, and we know if something is just or not by what we know of the Source of Justice.



Shemos 21:1, that you shall present before them, Rashi expounds this thus, The Holy One, Source of Blessing, said to Moshe, Let it not enter your mind to say, I shall teach them [this] chapter or Halacha two or three times until they are fluent in it [exactly] according its wording, but I will not take the trouble to make them understand the reason of [each] thing or its explanation [the verse] therefore says: that you shall (lit.) place before them like a table laid before a person, ready for eating. (ibid.) We see here (and others places) that Judaism is not about the letter of the law, but more importantly about its spirit and implementation of various Halacha. This is one of several instances where Judaism believes very strongly in understanding and true teaching. Teaching is not memorization or doing something by rote.



Shemos 21:3, If he enters alone, he shall leave alone, [but] if he has a wife, his wife shall leave with him. Rashi relates, But who brought her in[to service, that the verse tells us now] that she shall leave?! However, [by saying this] the verse tells us that he who buys an Ivri servant is obliged to provide food [also] for his wife and children (Kiddushin 20a, 22a). Chassidus plays on this concept, substituting a slave for a soul and a wife for Torah, in which, if a person does not do any good deeds, he departs alone, but if he studies Torah or does good deeds, Torah goes with him to Heaven. When we enter this world, we enter this world alone. Along the way, we can acquire for ourselves a wife/partner, and the Torah tells us that such a union is not broken by outside circumstances. Also, what good deeds and Torah-learning we gather upon ourselves does not depart from us, even when we depart from the material world.



Shemos 21:8, who should have designated her for himself, Rashi tells us this means, as a wife and married her, and [in such a case] the money with which she was acquired [would be] the money for her kiddushin (Kiddushin 19a). Here Scripture indicates to you that it is [the master's] duty to designated her [as his wife], and it [also] indicates to you that [when he does designated her as his wife], she does not require a further act of kiddushin. Thus, the Torah is ensuring that a daughter of a poor man is taking care of.

entry.title: Parsha Yisro
entry.content:
''
Wed, Feb 4, 2015 / 15 Shevat, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Yisro /
Shemos 18:1 20:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Yisro, which contains the given of the Torah at Mount Sinai. It is this event that everything before it was leading up to. Everything after this, is the implementation and internalization of this event. This is THE event in all of creation, and it is named after a Goy.

The Torah states of this person, Shemos 18:1, Yisro, the lord of Midyan, Moshe's father-in-law. He was the leader of an entire people and Rashi points out on the phrase, Moshe's father-in-law, Here Yisro felt honored through Moshe, [saying]: I am the father-in-law of the king. But previously Moshe had attributed [his] greatness to his father-in-law, as it says, and he returned to Yisro, his father-in-law (4:18) (Mechilta, ibid.). As much as other honored Yisro, he, himself, felt honored through Moshe.

The Torah goes on to say, Shemos 18:5, to the desert, which Rashi comments, We, too, are aware that they were in the desert, [so why does the Torah have to mention this specifically? The answer is] that the verse [wishes to] mention Yisro's praise, that he had been living with the [greatest] honor in the world, yet he voluntarily went out to the desert, a desolate place (Mechilta, ibid.), in order to hear the words of Torah.

Shemos 18:9, Yisro rejoiced, Rashi points out, this is its straightforward meaning. But its Midrashic explanation is: His flesh became full of goose pimples [because] he was distressed about the destruction of the Egyptians. This is [an example of the proverb] that people say: A proselyte up to ten generations [after his conversion] do not deride a non-Jew in his presence (Sanhedrin 94a). Amar Nekei explains, For Yisro, himself, was a descendant of Egypt for he was a Midyani, and Midyan was a son of Keturah, who is Hagar, who was an Egyptian woman. Thus Yisro felt a certain degree of distress at hearing what had happened to the Egyptians, for they were his kith and kin. Although, the Halacha is that a proselyte is reborn, severing all previous ties, the reality is that some ties linger.

Shemos 18:11, Now I know that the Eternal is greater than all [other's] gods, for by the very thing that [the Egyptians] plotted [against Israel was punishment brought] upon them. Rashi adds to Now I know, as if Yisro was saying, I [already] recognized Him previously, but now [I recognize Him] even more. Rashi points out for than all [other's] gods that [This] teaches [us] that [Yisro] knew about every [form of] idol-worship in the world, for there was no idol-worship which he had not practiced. And to for by the very thing that the Egyptians plotted against Israel was punishment brought upon them, Rashi states, they had planned to destroy [Israel] by water, but [in the end] they [themselves] were destroyed by water. For we have the principle of measure for measure. By which the Egyptians inflicted upon the Jews, so in turn did HaShem inflict them with.

Shemos 18:14, from morning until evening, Rashi asks, Is it possible to say this, [that he actually sat from morning until evening]?! Rather, [it is understood in the sense that] any judge who judges a case absolutely truthfully, even [if] the time [spent on it is only] short, Scripture considers him as if he had been occupied with Torah the entire day, and as if he became a partner with the Holy One, Source of Blessing, in Creation, of which it says, It became evening and became morning [of] one day (Mechilta; Shofteim 4:11, Shabbos 10a). For such is the study of Torah, just as an architect studies a blueprint is involved within the construction of a building, so to when one studies the blueprint of Creation, the Torah, so too they are involved with the construction of Creation itself. For HaShem has a seal by which we know Him, this seal is a combination of loving-kindness, truth, and justice. These three things are always present when HaShem does something, and when Yisro was told all that had happened to the Jews and the Egyptians, he understood that all that HaShem did was merely a measure for measure, in keeping with truth, justice, and loving-kindness.

Shemos 18:19, I shall advise you, but let G-d be with you Rashi comments, in [considering] the advice; [i.e.] he said to him, Go and consult the Almighty Which for Moshe was actually very literal, and not something that anyone but Moshe could do. For figuratively, we can only consult our Rabbis and Chumash.

Shemos 19:1, On this day, Rashi expounds this thus, [i.e.] on the first day of the month (Mechilta, Parsha Bachodesh, sec. 1) [According to the context, the Torah] ought to have written [here[, on that day. [For] what [reason, then, does it write] on this day? {To indicate] that the words of Torah should [always] be to you like something new, as if they had been given [to you] today (Tanchuma Yashan 13). One should not think of Torah as some ancient book of a by-gone era. Rather, the Torah is the Living Word of HaShem, the Torah is the instruction manual that HaShem has given to us to make a dwelling place for Him in the lowest and the highest of the realms.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
''
Wed, Jan 7, 2015 / 16 Teves, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Shemos /
Shemos 1:1 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemos, the first Parsha of the Sefer Shemos. The word shemos () translates into English as names. There is a lesson here for us, Sefer Shemos deals with the redemption of the Jews from the first exile, their journey through the Sinai desert, and the building of the Mishkan, the first years of the nation of Israel. Yet, it is a nation made up by people, whom we know the names of. For the Nation of Israel is also the Children of Israel, the sons and daughters of Ya'akov Avinu ( ), individuals. Within the nation of Israel, there are the twelve tribes, each with their own talents , and within each tribe there are houses, with their own tasks to perform.

Shemos 1:1, And these are the names of Israel's sons, Rashi states, Even though [the Torah already] enumerated them by name during their lifetimes [when they went down to Egypt (Bereishet 46:8-27), it enumerated them here [again] upon their death, to show [us] how loved they are [by G-d, which is manifest by] that they are compared to stars which [G-d also] takes out and brings in by number and by name (Tanchuma Yashan 2), as it says, He takes out their multitude by number, He calls each one by name (Yeshayah 40:26). Thus, we learn that using another's name, calling them by their name, is a sign of affection. Just as the stars can be used for navigation, so too can the Tribes, the sons of Ya'akov, can be used to navigate our life.

Bereishet 1:8, who did not know [Yosef], Rashi says that this actually means, he pretended to not know Yosef. The Sages differ whether the new Par'oh was truly known or not, regardless, everyone knew of the savior of Egypt. As is the case, the reality was that the Egyptians owed Yosef and his family their lives and should act honorable towards them. Instead, they pretended that they did not know Yosef and their debt to him. Which is the case with Antisemitism, the local Jews are blessed and share their blessing with others, when it becomes inconvenient, the Goyim forget all the blessings their receive from the Jews and plot against them, for their own ends.

Bereishet 1:10, let us deal cleverly with him, Rashi expounds this thus, [i.e.] with the nation. Let us consider wisely what to do with it. But our Rabbis explained [the word to him as referring to G-d, ans the verse means:] Let us outwit [G-d], the Savior of Israel, by sentencing them [to death] by water, for He had already sworn that He will never bring [another] flood upon the world (Sotah 11a). The world knew that HaShem punishes measure for measure, thus they thought if they drown the Children of Israel, because of HaShem's promise to Noah, they, the Egyptians, would be safe. The Egyptians did not take into account that the oath that HaShem swore not to flood the entire world, flooding parts of the world is still possible. Not to mention the fact, even if it was such a case, HaShem would have found another way to still punish the Egyptians measure for measure, as the Ten Plagues show.

entry.title: Parsha Vayechi
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jan 1, 2015 / 11 Teves, 5775/ '' ''

Parsha Vayechi /
Bereishet 47:28 50:26
Shabbos Chazak
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This Parsha is the last Parsha of Sefer Bereishet. Upon completion of Sefer Bereishet we say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! Be strong! Be Strong! May we be strengthen! For we are sadden to see Sefer Bereishet go, and hope that what we had studied within it would strengthen us and help us.

And what of the Parsha itself? The Parsha is called Vayechi () meaning And he lived as the Torah states, Bereishet 47:28, And Ya'akov lived seventeen years in the land of Egypt[...] Ya'akov lived the last seventeen years of his life in Egypt, a land not his own or of his birth. The Parsha speaks of Ya'akov's last days, in which he blessed his children, and passed away.

Bereishet 49:44, (He then passed away and was gathered) to which Rashi writes, but death () is not mentioned concerning him; and our Rabbis said, Ya'akov, our forefather, did not die. The Gemara (Ta'anis 5b) asks: What, then, does it mean that Ya'akov was eulogized (50:10), embalmed (50:2), and buried (50:13)? The Gemara answers by expounding the verse in Yirmeyah (30:10), which teaches us that just as his descendants are alive, so is he also alive. Guy Aryeh explains this to mean that since his relationship with his offsprings continues, even though he is not physically with them, it is considered as if his life continues; for thought the Jewish People who are called the Children of Israel, and about whom the verse says: But you, who adhere to [the worship of] the Eternal, your G-d, are all living today (Devarim 4:4) i.e. they are truly living Ya'akov is considered to be still alive. Furthermore, the Midrash (Bereshis Rabbah 49:4) says: We have learned: Rabbi Shim'on ben Yochi says: Whoever brings up a son who toils in [the study of] Torah is considered as if he did not die. Thus we see that although physically Ya'akov had left this world, his existence here continued through his direct offsprings who were all righteous --- and it still continues through his living descendants, the Children of Israel, who bear his name. Just as Parsha Chai Sarah spoke both of her death and the life of her son, so too, our forefather Ya'akov lives on in us, even though we are several thousand generations physically separated. We are still the Children of Israel/Ya'akov, for his ideals and beliefs are still taught and practiced upon us.

Also of note, Bereishet 47:28, Ya'akov lived Rashi points out here, Why is this Parsha closed up? (The normal separation of nine letter spacing is missing here) Because when our father Ya'akov passed away, the eyes of the hearts of [the Children of] Israel became closed up from the misery of the bondage that [the Egyptians] began to impose on them. Another explanation: [Ya'akov] wished to reveal to his sons [when would be] the end [of all exiles], but it was concealed from him. Although the harsh bondage would only come after the deaths of Ya'akov's sons, the Tribes, while Yosef was still Vice-Royal of Egypt, our Sages tells us that plans for the enslavement of the Children of Israel were already being formed. And the sons of Israel knew the prophecy that was told to their great-grandfather Abraham, of being strangers in a strange land, whom would treat them poorly. They knew that HaShem had told Abraham, Bereishet 15:13, And He said to Abram, "You shall surely know that your seed will be strangers in a land that is not theirs, and they will enslave them and oppress them, for four hundred years. So they knew that their exile would only be four hundred years, whether it was from the time that HaShem told Abraham or from the time that their grandfather Yitzchak was born was not know to them. But they had hope and knew that their exile would have an end. Although we do not know the end-point for our own and final exile, we know and hope that it will be over soon, with the coming of Mashiach.

Bereishet 47:29, please do not bury me in Egypt Rashi explains, [Because] ultimately its soil will become lice which would swarm under my body; and [because] the dead of outside of the Land of Israel will only be resurrected by suffering [the pain of] rolling through underground passages [to the Land of Israel]; and [so that] the Egyptians should not make me an object of idol-worship. For Ya'akov blessed Pharaoh that the Nile rive would rise up when he came upon it. Which showed to the Egyptians and others that Ya'akov was not an ordinary mortal. Our Sages also say that Ya'akov did not wish to be buried in Egypt to remind his children that their place was not among the Egyptians but within the Land of Israel. It is said, I forgot the source, that when Yosef died, the Egyptians placed his tomb into the Nile, so that he could continue to bless Egypt, as he had done in life. If they did this to Yosef, a vice-royal, what might they have done to Ya'akov, Yosef's father and prophet of HaShem.

Bereishet 48:2, So Israel summoned his strength Rashi points out, He [Ya'akov] said: Although he is my son, he is a king, [so] I will give him honor. From here [we learn] that we must show honor to [a person of] royal rank. Similarly, Moshe showed honor to royalty, [for he said to Par'oh]: All these servants of yours will then come down to me (Shemos 11:8); and so [did] Eliyahu: and [Eliyahu] girded up his loins [and ran before Achav] (Melachim I 18.46). For Moshe, in this case, was actually speaking about what Par'oh himself would come down to him, and Eliyahu the Prophet did so for Achav the King. Our Sages tell us that nothing happens without Heavenly approval, and that if some one is born or raised to royal rank, it is because it was so decreed. Whether they become a good monarch or corrupted, is up to them. So because these people have been given something extra in receiving royal rank, we as Jews, need to recognize HaShem's providence involved by reciting a blessing, Blessed is the One Who has given of His glory to human beings.For HaShem is the true King of All, but He allows those whom He wishes to rule with Him.

Bereishet 48:7, As for me, when I came from Padan, Rochel died on me in the Land of Kena'an, on the road, still a certain distance from reaching Efras, and I buried her there on the Efras that is Beis Lechem Road. The Lubavitcher Rebbe wrote in Likutei Sichos vol 30, pp 239-240, Rochel lost her own spiritual luxury the privilege of being buried in the Cave of Machpeliah in order to help her children. This represents the unparalleled quality of the Jewish mother who is always willing to sacrifice her own needs, spiritual or physical, for the sake of helping her children.
And this is the inner reason why Jewish identity follows the maternal and not paternal route. For even though the father possesses a greater degree of spirituality since he has the privilege of observing more Mitzvot than a women the quality of a Jewish mother is nevertheless greater. She is willing to forego much of that spirituality in order to enable her to raise a family with tender loving care. And since this quality is even more quintessentially Jewish than the spirituality of the man, it is the mother that actually makes her children Jewish. While it might seem that women get the short-end of the stick, in fact, it is the Jewish mothers that has allowed us to survive and life as we have throughout the ages.

Bereishet 48:20, My Israel bless with, Rashi expounds this thus, [i.e] he who wishes to bless his sons will bless them with the same blessing as they were blessed, and each will say to his son: May G-d make you like Efrayim and Manashe. Who were Efrayim and Manashe? They were Yosef's sons born in exile, and they were worthy to be counted among the sons of Israel as tribes (when Yosef and Levi are not mentioned). They were born and raised among the immoral Egyptians and the children of the Vice-Royal, and yet, they remained as Jewish and righteous as their father and Yosef's brothers.

Bereishet 49:28, And this what their father spoke to them, and he blessed them Rashi states, but were there not some of them whom he did not bless but reproached? However, this is the explanation [of the verse]: And this is what their father spoke to them [i.e.] that which was said above. Maybe [this means] that he did not bless Re'uven, Shim'on, and Levi the verse [therefore] tells us: and he blessed them implying [that he blessed] all of them. Each tribe was blessed with its own mission to carry out, so we might have thought that they were to go their separate way, comes the Torah and reminds us, he blessed them. For they were still the sons of a single man, with a single over-all mission, which they each had a part to play in that mission.

Bereishet 50:4, and wept for him for seventy days Rashi explains, forty days of embalmment, and [another] thirty days of weeping. [The Egyptians kept this lengthy period of mourning] because a blessing come [to them] upon [Ya'akov's] arrival [in Egypt], that the famine stopped and the waters of the Nile increased. Even the immoral Egyptians knew from where they were blessed came from and respected Ya'akov.

Bereishet 50:6, As he made you swear Rashi adds, but were it not for [this] oath, I would not allow you [to go]. But [Par'oh] was afraid to tell [Yosef]: Break the oath! so that he should not answer: If so, I will [also] break the oath that I swore to you not to reveal the fact that I know the Holy Language (Hebrew), besides the [other] seventy languages, but which you do not know as is stated in Tractate Sotah (36b.) Thus we see the power of an oath and why Ya'akov made Yosef so swore his oath to his father. And we see that if you break one oath, then it can be as if you break all your oaths.

Bereishet 50:26, Yosef died at the age of one hundred and ten, and [the Egyptians] embalmed him and placed him in [his] coffin in Egypt. From here, we see the love of Yosef for his father's children, for even in death he did not depart from them. He made his brother's children swear to bring him up when HaShem brought the Children of Israel up with them. To remind them that their exile was only temporary.

Just as the Egyptian exile had an end-point, so too does our current exile. Just as the Children of Israel had to wait for Moshe Rabbeinu's birth and assuming his mission, so too, do we await the coming of Mashiach. May his coming be speedily in our day.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
''
Fri, Dec 26, 2014 / 4 Teves, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Vayigash /
Bereishet 44:18 47:27
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayigash, the word vayigash which means and he approached, as the Torah tells us, Bereishet 44:18, And Yehudah then stepped forward. With Yosef, we see a Tzadik who is able to serve HaShem within involved with the day-to-day affairs of the mundane world, with the brothers, they are Tzadikim that separated themselves from the mundane world. Here, we see the leader of the brothers, Yehudah, confront the disguised Yosef, which is seemingly out of character of the brothers, but required by the circumstance. Whatever we are involved with, we should not allow that to interfere with what HaShem expects of us. Even the shepherd, such as Yehudah, needs to stand up to the leaders of the mundane worlds when called for.

Bereishet 45:5, Now, however, do not be upset or angry with yourselves that you sold me here, for G-d sent me ahead of you to be [a provider of] sustenance [for you]. Which shows much a Tzadik that Yosef was, to know and believe that all that had happened to him was preordained and accepting of it. In truth, Heaven has planned out our lives, much as Yosef's live was, but only a few, the Tzadikim, know the details within their lives.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeishev
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 11, 2014 / 19 Kislev, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Vayeishev /
Bereishet 37:1 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi


This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayeishev, which translates to He settled. Rashi points out, Ya'akov wished to live in tranquility [but] the troubles with Yosef were thrust upon him. [When] the righteous wish to live in tranquility, the Holy One, Source of Blessing, says: Is it not enough for the righteous what has been prepared for them in the World to Come, that they [also] wish to live in tranquility in this world?!

What is so wrong with living in tranquility? After all, in the last years of his life, Ya'akov does live a tranquil life in Egypt. Immediately two points from the previous sentence should pop out, in the last years and in Egypt, not in the Land of Israel. Why is that? It is because Ya'akov's mission in life had not been completed yet. At this point in his life, Ya'akov still had a blemish upon his soul for the time that he had been a way from his parents, thus, the troubles with Yosef lasted the same amount of time as he had been a way from his parents. Ya'akov also had to provide the seeds that would permit his children and descendants to survive the Egyptian Exile. It was only after he had done all that HaShem sent out for him to do, that HaShem allowed him to be tranquil.

Bereishet 37:10, Is it possible that [] will come, Rashi expounds this thus, for is your mother not already dead?! But [Ya'akov] did not realize that these things were referring to Bilhah, who raised [Yosef] as if [she was] his [own] mother. Our Rabbis learned from here that there is no dream without irrelevant information, but Ya'akov intended to talk his sons out of believing this matter so that they would not be jealous of [Yosef]. He therefore told him, Is it possible that I... will come...? Just as [the dream] is impossible to be realized with your mother, so the remainder [of the dream] is meaningless. The Torah tells us that Ya'akov considered Yosef, his heir. And it is interesting that of all that Ya'akov did, Yosef thought Ya'akov's dream of the ladder was what he felt was the highlight, which Yosef tried to emulate. It was Yosef's dreams dealing with his brothers that caused jealous among them and brought him low. It was the dreams of the Egyptian servants and Par'oh's dream that raised Yosef up. Unlike his fathers and his brothers, who were shepherds, Yosef's attention was on more spiritual matters. While Yosef did have some standing among the Tribes in their fathers' life-time, it was Yehudah upon whom the Kingship of Israel was given and retained.

Bereishet 37:14, and [Yosef] came to Shechem. Rashi points out, A place destined for misfortune: there the tribes (the sons of Ya'akov) sinned [by selling Yosef]; there Dinah was abused; [and] there the kingdom of the House of David was divided, as it says, Rechavam went to Shechem... (Divrei Hayamin II 10:1). Thus, we see that every word in the Torah is measured and weighed to give up insight and wisdom.

Bereishet 37:15, a man discovered him, Rashi tells us, This was [the angel] Gavri'el, as it says, and the man, Gavri'el (Daniyel 9:21). Mizrachi explains the Rashi, This does not mean that whenever the term man is used without qualification it refers to the angel Gavri'el. However, since we understand from the way that Yosef conversed with him that he was an angel, we know that this angel was Gavri'el because Gavri'el is the only angel who is referred to as man. The fact that Rashi points out that this angel, is not just an angel, but a named and known angel is something that is important to understanding what is happening, or in the case, what HaShem is preparing Yosef for.

Bereishet 37:20, But we shall see what will become of his dreams. Rashi states, Rabbi Yitzchak said: This verse calls out for an interpretation. [In fact] the Divine Spirit is saying this [phrase]. [The brothers] were saying, Let us kill him.... and the verse ends off [in response]: But we shall see what will become of his dreams, [i.e.] we shall see whose words will be fulfilled yours or Mine! It is impossible, thought, that it was [the brothers] who said: and we shall see what will become of his dreams, because once they would have killed him, his dreams would have turned to nothing. From here and other place, we need to recall that the Torah is not a narrative of history, but the recording of HaShem's Words to Moshe. We see that HaShem, Himself, is informing us, the readers, of His involvement in our lives.

Bereishet 37:22, in order to save him, Rashi informs us, The Divine Spirit testifies [here] about Re'uven that he said this only in order to save [his brother], so that he would come [later] and draw him up from there. He said [to himself], I am the firstborn and the oldest of them all. The blame will be put only on me. HaShem knows the hearts of His creations and knows what we shall do. All is recorded in the Torah to teach us life lessons. Re'uven had the idea of saving Yosef, but for various reasons was not able to complete his task. That he tried shows of his character.

Bereishet 38:26, From me, Rashi explains the verse thus, she is pregnant. And our Rabbis of blessed memory interpreted this [to mean] that a Heavenly Voice answered: from Me and through Me these things came about. Since she was modest in her father-in-law's home I have decreed that kings will descend from her, and I have [also] decreed that from the tribe of Yehudah kings will be appointed in Israel. Thus the entire situation of Tamar getting pregnant from Yehudah was engineered by HaShem, Himself, had not the sons of Yehudah sinned, they would have fathers the children of Tamar. Since they did, HaShem arranged for the sons of Tamar to come directly from Yehudah.

Bereishet 38:27, there were indeed twins ( ) Rashi points out, [Here the word (twins) is written] in full, while there (25:24 taking of Ya'akov and Esau twins) [it is written] without [an ], because [there] one [of them] was wicked, whereas there [here] were both righteous. Thus, we see that even a letter, or missing letter as this case, can teach us something.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Dec 4, 2014 / 12 Kislev, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Vayishlach /
Bereishet 32:4 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayishlach, and he sent, and what did Ya'akov send? Bereishet 32:4, Ya'akov sent messengers (), which Rashi points out that here, messengers () means real angels, as opposed to mere human messengers. Real angels upon whom when faced with such, those of the days of the Judges feared death, and yet, not only did not Esau fear seeing the angels but he had four hundred men with him to face Ya'akov.

Bereishet 32:7, We have been to your brother, to Esau, Rashi relates, [i.e. to him about whom] you used to say, He is my brother, but who behaves towards you like Esau the Wicked, [i.e.] he still has his hatred [for you.] Thus, we see that Ya'akov thought of Esau as his brother, but Esau had hatred in his heart for Ya'akov. Esau was still wicked, and yet, he could stand before the angels as others could not.

Bereishet 32:9, then the remaining camp will escape, Rashi expounds this thus, against [Esau's] will, for I will fight against him. [Ya'akov] prepared himself for three things: to [give] a present, for prayer and for war to [give] a present, [as it says]: The gift went on ahead of him (v. 22); for prayer, [as it says]: G-d of my [grand]father Abraham,... (v. 10); for war, [as it says]: then the remaining camp will escape. Ya'akov Avinu did all three things before he actually met Esau, in preparation. It is told that before the Sages would deal with Rome, they would study this Parsha and these verses of Ya'akov preparation to deal with Esau, and they would succeed. The one time that they did not prepare thus, they failed. Ya'akov knew that while HaShem had promised him safety, he still had to take steps of his own/ We were created to be a part of Creation and to complete it with HaShem's help. We are not meant to be passengers on this journey, but participants.

Bereishet 32:23, and his eleven children, Rashi asks a question, And where was Dinah? He had put her in a chest and locked her in, so that Esau should not cast his eyes upon her [to marry her]. And therefore Ya'akov was punished for keeping her away from his brother, [when] she might have brought him back to the right path, and she fell into the hands of Shechem. Thus, we learn that a woman has the power to help even a wicked man like Esau to repent. A man will do great and terrible things for the sake of a woman.

Bereishet 33:4, and kissed him (), Rashi points out, There are dots over [this word in the Torah]. There is a difference of opinion in the beraisa of the Sifrei (Beha'alosecha 69) about this: Some explain these dots [to mean] that he did not kiss him wholeheartedly, [but] Rabbi Shim'on ben Yochai said, It is an established fact that Esau hates Ya'akov, but at that moment his compassion was aroused and he kissed him wholeheartedly. In general, when there are dot (nakud) over a letter in the Torah, it is to draw attention to it, either to say the letter that is dotted is weak or strong, depending upon the Oral Torah. Here with this word, all the letters are dotted, which the Sages believe means that Esau was not sincere. Which might seem to be the obvious case, so Rashi quotes Rabbi Shim'on ben Yochai that in this one case, it's the opposite of what we would have thought as Jewish Law (Halacha) states that Esau hates Ya'akov. While an interesting point, why bring this up? Because a mere dot, a one-dimensional object, can change everything. If a mere dot has the power to do this, how much more so than we would can write a dot can do.

Bereishet 33:7, Yosef drew near, with Rachel Rashi points out, With all [the other], the mothers drew near before the children, but in the case of Rachel, Yosef drew near before her. He said, My mother is beautiful [and] maybe that wicked man will take a fancy to her. I will [therefore] stand in front of her and prevent him from looking at her. As a result of this Yosef merited the blessing: upon the eye (49:22). Ya'akov hide Dinah, and was punished. Yosef hide Rachel, and was blessed. The obvious difference? Dinah was single and Rachel was married.

Bereishet 33:11, I have everything, Rashi states, [i.e.] all that I need; but Esau spoke proudly: I have plenty (v. 9) for more than my needs. Our Sages tell us, who is rich? One who is satisfied with what they have.

Bereishet 33:16, On that day Esau went on his back. Rashi mentions, Esau [returned] alone, [for] the four hundred men who had accompanied him had slipped away from him one by one. And where do [we find that] the Holy One, Source of Blessing, rewarded them [for this]? In the time of [King] David, as it says: [None of the Amaleki escaped] except for four hundred young men who rode on camels. (Shemuel I 30:17). No good deed goes without reward, HaShem balances the book in His own time.

Bereishet 34:1, the daughter of Leah, Rashi asks a question (and answers it), And [she was] not the daughter of Ya'akov?! However, on account of her going out she is called the daughter of Leah, who was also a woman who would go out, as it says: and Leah went out to meet him (30:16). {The saying like mother, like daughter (see Yechezkel 16:44) was coined in reference to her.} Some commentators praise Leah for going out to meet Ya'akov, for a good cause, some question the way in which she did it. Like mother, like daughter, there are those that say Dinah went out for a good reason, but there was some question in the way she did it that caused this incident to happen.

Bereishet 34:13, who had defiled, Rashi states, the verse tells [us] that there was no [real] deceit, for he had defiled their sister [and therefore deserved punishment]. Thus, the Torah is testifying that Shechem were deserving of punishment, and Shim'on and Levi would carry it out.

Bereishet 34:11, and kings Rashi explains, [This refers to] Sha'ul and Ishboshes, who were from the tribe of Binyamin [and] were not yet born. And it was this verse that Avner explained when he made Ishboshes king. The tribes also explained it [so] and [therefore] drew [the tribe of] Binyamin close [again] for it is written: No man among us shall give his daughters to [the tribe of] Binyamin as a wife (Shofetim 21:1), but they retracted and said, If [Binyamin] were not counted among the tribes, the Holy One, Source of Blessing, would not have said to Ya'akov [regarding Binyamin]: 'and kings will descend from you.'

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Nov 27, 2014 / 5 Kislev, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Bereishet 28:10 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu, Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayeitzei, which translates to and he left. The obvious question is how can the Torah have an entire Parsha entitled and he left? The first part, the obvious part, is that this is a continuation of the previous Parsha as it begins with and, or the word starts with a Vav (). We are still left with the leaving/departure.

So the question is what is this departure and how does it affect the entire Parsha? What is the entire Parsha about? Ya'akov Avinu ( ) gets married, has children and starting a family. The other focal point people that the Torah had previous had mentioned had gotten married, had children and obviously had a family as well. So how is this time different?

We are departing from the individual focus and moving into the family focus. No longer are we dealing with just an individual but with a family as a whole. Yosef's story is not about Yosef alone, but of Yosef and his brothers. Next is Moses and B'Nai Israel ( ), and down the line. We are departing from a single person upholding the world to a period where a family, a nation takes that burden upon ourselves. Our Fore-fathers and Fore-mothers upheld the Torah on their own, with their own understanding. Now the Torah is being passed to the Tribes themselves, and as they grow, to B'Nai Israel. Our Fore-fathers and Fore-mothers could keep the world up on their own, but that was not the point of Creation, rather, Creation was to involve the many, not just the individual.

This Parsha is the seeds of the foundation upon which our Jewish people and nation is founded upon.

Bereishet 28:11, He stopped at the place, Rashi points out, The verse does not mention which place, but at the place [i.e. the one] mentioned elsewhere. This is Mount Moriyah, about which it says: and [he] saw the place from a distance (32:4) This is THE place in the world, Adam HaRoshan ( ) was born and sacrificed there, as did Noah, and Abraham brought Yitzchak up upon there. It is this place where King Shmolo built the first Holy Temple, second Holy Temple was built, and Herod expanded with the Temple Mount, which will be the place of the third and final Holy Temple.

entry.title: Parsha Toldos
entry.content:
''
Thu, Nov 20, 2014 / 27 Cheshvan, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Toldos /
Bereishet 25:19 28:9
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Toldos, which seems to focus on Yitzchak, but also on the birth and upbringing of Ya'akov and Esau. If fact, the name of the Parsha, Toldos, means descendants. It is referring to both Ya'akov and Esau, equally. Which is interesting in itself as the Torah itself tells us that Esau was wicked, while Ya'akov was good, but both are introduced to us as, Bereishet 25:19, And these are the descendants of Yitzchak Making no distinction between the twins, telling us that both Ya'akov and Esau had the same potential, and yet, each of the twins expressed themselves differently, producing different results.

Bereishet 25:21, responded to his pleas, Rashi points out, but not to hers. Since there is no comparison between the prayer of a righteous person (Yitzchak) who is the son of a righteous person (Abraham), and the prayer of a righteous person (Rivkah) who is the child of a wicked person (Besu'el), [HaShem] therefore [responded] to [Yitzchak's prayer] and not to hers. What is noted here is that Yitzchak was himself righteous in his own merit, not in the merit of being the son of Abraham, which is why it is such an importance. Yitzchak was not a copy of Abraham, but his own man and had his own way.

entry.title: Parsha Chayei Sarah
entry.content:
''
Thu, Nov 13, 2014 / 20 Cheshvan, 5775 / ' ''

Parsha Chayei Sarah /
Bereishet 23:1 25:18
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Chayei Sarah, which translates to, Sarah's life, last year's post, I mentioned how Sarah's life was reflection of her son, her maidservant, and her maidservant's son. Thus, she lived on in her son, his children, and in us. In every Jew, there is a spark of Sarah within us.

Who was Sarah? She was the wife of Abraham, the mother of Yitzchak, and the first Matriarch of the Jewish People. What does the Torah tell us of her? Bereishet 23:1, Sarah's life spanned one hundred and twenty years and seven years; Rashi explains this strange phrasing of her age as, The reason the word (years) is written with every unit [of her age] is to tell you that each [unit] is expounded individually: When she was one hundred years old she was a like a woman of twenty with regards to sin; just as a twenty year old is [considered as] not having sinned, for she is not [yet] subject to [Divine] punishment, so, too, she was without sin at the age of a hundred; and at the age of twenty she was as beautiful as a seven-year old. Mizrachistates, The beauty of a seven-year old is greater than that of a twenty-year old in that her skin is fairer and finer. Also, a girl of seven-year old is innocent of the way of women that a twenty-year old is not.

Bereishet 23:2, to eulogize Sarah and to weep for her Rashi points out, Sarah's death is [written] immediately following the binding of Yitzchak, because through [her] hearing about the binding that her son had been designated to be slaughtered and was [indeed] almost sacrificed her soul departed from her and she died. Mizrachi says, that before the messenger had a chance to tell Sarah that Yitzchak had actually not been sacrificed, her soul departed. Her soul departed from her body... In other words, for no other reason, Divine or mundane, did our Matriarch Sarah died but because her own soul departed from her. It was not the Angel of Death, disease, injury or anything, but grief and lost that killed her. Upon the news that her son was gone, she too departed.

Bereishet 23:6, Listen to us, sir. You are a prince of G-d among us, such was the standing of Abraham in the eyes of the people that he was called a prince of Elokim, the Divine Aspect of Judgment, which is interesting as Abraham's virtue was Chesed (). Chesed is not normally aligned with Judgment. The Midrash tells us that the Sefirot of Chesed complained that while Abraham was alive, it had nothing to do. A wife, especially one mentioned in the Torah, is a match for her husband, thus, while Abraham was Chesed shown outward, Sarah would be Chesed shown inward, which explains she chose not to be in a world without her son.

Bereishet 23:10, Efron was [then] sitting Rashi expounds this, though read in the present tense, meaning here was sitting, is written without [the Vav (), suggesting the mean he sat. This indicates that] on that very day they appointed [Efron] to be an officer over them. On account of the high standing of Abraham who needed him, he was promoted to an important position. Thus has been the case with all that deal one-on-one with the Jewish People, even our enemies are not mere nobodies, but somebodies of some renounce (usually for not-good reasons).

Bereishet 24:1, [The Eternal] had blessed Abraham with everything, Rashi comments, The numerical value of [the word] is the same as (a son), and since he had a son, he had to find him a wife. For it was not enough that Abraham served HaShem, but he needed and wanted his service to continue to the next generation, Yitzchak, and beyond. For Abraham, that was everything, a son to carry on his work. We are told in the next Parsha that Abraham begot Yitzchak, and Yitzchak was the son of Abraham. If Yitzchak was to continue Abraham's work, why would this be necessary? Because while Abraham was Chesed, Yitzchak embodied Gevurah (), which is opposite of Chesed. And yet, that is exactly what Yitzchak did, he carried on his father's work, in his own style.

Bereishet 24:8, however, [take] my son Rashi points out, [The word] denotes a limitation: my son may not go back there, but Ya'akov, my grandson, will eventually go back. To the prophets of HaShem the future is known, and the prophets words reflect this.

Bereishet 24:13, Let her be the one whom You have designated ( ) Rashi explains, she is fit for him, for she will be charitable and [thus] worthy of entering Abraham's household. The expression means [here] selected; aprivest in Old French. Our Sages say that when we are born, a Heavenly Voice proclaims, such-and-such shall marry so-and-so. Sometimes, we are allowed this information, other times, we are not, but we know that HaShem has prepared our match for us. It was said, I think within a Chassidic story, that making a true match is as difficult as splitting the Sea of Reeds.

Bereishet 24:42, I came today Rashi expounds this thus, I started out today and arrived today. [We can deduce] from here that the land shrank for him. R. Acha said: The conversion of [our] forefathers' servants is more pleasing to the Omnipresent than the Torah expositions of [their] descendants, for the passage concerning Eli'ezer is repeated in the Torah, yet many principles of the Torah are given by only [slight] indications. Why is this? Because with the passage concerning Eli'ezer, we see Torah principles in action, whereas with indications are principles in concept/theory. Like the old saying, a picture is worth a thousand words. We can learn more from a visual example of a concept in play than trying to learn the laws in theoretical example.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
''
Thu, Oct 30, 2014 / 6 Cheshvan, 5775 / ''

Parsha Lech Lecha /
Bereishet 12:1 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash-Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Lech Lecha, and it is the third Parsha of Sefer Bereishet. The first two Parsha of Sefer Bereishet dealt with an introduction to whom HaShem is and the origin of mankind. They cover over two thousand years, and yet mostly focus upon Adam HaRoshan ( ) and Noach, a period of twenty generations. The rest of the Sefer Bereishet deals with Abraham, Yitzchak, Ya'akov and the twelve tribes, four generations and about two hundred fifty odd years. One sixth of Sefer Bereishet deals with two thousand odd years, and the last five-sixth deals with a mere two hundred fifty odd years (yes, I am approximating my math). And yet, those five-sixth of Sefer Bereishet is the foundation stone of the Jewish people and the rest of history.

Avram was (about) fifty years old when HaShem spoke to him, and said Bereishet 12:1, Go for yourself (-). To which Rashi points out, [means: Go] for your own benefit and for your own good. There I will make you into a great nation, [but] here you will not merit having children. Furthermore, I will make your character known throughout the world. Why was this? HaShem can do whatever He desires, if He willed it, He could have made Avram great where he was, just as He could have saved Noach on His own. But then we would miss the lesson.

Why did Noach had to make an ark? Why did Avram need to leave his father's house/land behind? Because HaShem wishes for us to participate in Creation. We must not forget that Creation is an ongoing phenomenon that we cannot be mere observers but we were created to be players, involved in what is happening. Avram had to leave his father's home and travel beyond what he knew, just as Noach had to build an ark. Just as Noach while building the ark, told those that inquired about HaShem, so too, Avram as he traveled told others of HaShem.

Rashi points out for Bereishet 12:2, I will make you into a great nation, that, Since traveling causes three things: it restrains childbirth, it decreases [one's] wealth and lessens [one's] reputation he therefore needed these three blessings, that [HaShem] promised him children, wealth and fame.

Until this point in history, we have only seen HaShem work within nature and implying the supernatural. Now, with Avram, we see that HaShem is not limited by nature and can bring the supernatural to the natural.

History has proven HaShem's promise, Bereishet 12:3, I will bless those who bless you, and him who curses you, I will curse [...] Look how the Jews, the descendants of Avram/Abraham, are treated, if they are treated well, blessed, the hosting nation is blessed in turn. Those that treat Jews poorly, are but dust in the wind of time. You can graph a nation's rise and fall through this concept. It has been said that the Jews are light unto the nations, whether that light is feed or smothered, is reflective of the nations.

Bereishet 12:6, and the Kena'ani were just then [occupying] the land, Rashi explains, They were in the process of conquering the Land of Israel from the descendants of Shem, for it had fallen to the share of Shem when Noach divided the earth among his sons, as it says, Malki Tzedek, the king of Shalem (Yerushalayim) (14:18). Therefore the Eternal said to Avram, I will give this land to your descendants (v. 7) [i.e.] I will return it in the future to your children who are descendants of Shem. Recall that Noach had cursed Kena'an that he would be slaves to the children of Yefet and Shem. And what a slave has, belongs to his master. Thus we see that HaShem had prepared history to unfold has it has.

Bereishet 12:8, his tent () Rashi expounds this thus, [Although read with a male suffix as if it were written ,] it is written [meaning her tent]. [This teaches us] that he first pitched his wife's tent and afterwards his own. From Rashi, we learn a lesson that a single letter can make a different and teach us a lesson. It is spoke as if it was a vav () and yet it is written with a hay () , showing the importance of tradition that tells us how it is pronounced to ensure the lesson is taught. As well as how each letter of the Torah is meaningful.

Bereishet 12:12, It will be when the Egyptians see you, they will say, This is his wife, and they will kill me and keep you alive. Thus, we see the corruption of Egypt, that it was well known to others what they practiced. What the practiced was that they accepted the law against adultery, by simply removing the husband and forcing the widow. In other words, the ancient Egyptians thought that two wrongs would make a right. Neither murder nor adultery should be acceptable to civilized people.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Oct 23, 2014 / 29 Tishrei, 5775 / '' ''

Parsha Noach /
Bereishet 6:9 11:32
Shabbos Rosh Chodesh Cheshvan /
Maftir: Bamidbar 28:9 28:15
Haftarah: Isaiah 66:1 66:24

Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Noach, the second Parsha of Sefer Bereishet. In Parsha Bereishet, we read the creation of the world and of Mankind. After interacting with Adam and Cain, HaShem seemed to have remained silent afterward, and Mankind, on their own, became corrupt as the Torah states, Bereishet 6:11, The earth became corrupt before G-d [...]

How did the earth get this way? The verse continues, the earth became filled with larceny. Not just general robbery, but larceny, which is the crime of stealing personal property. There was an anarchy and disregard for personal property.

For ten generations did HaShem wait for Noach, and when Noach was six hundred years old, Bereishet 6:12, G-d said to Noach, The end of all flesh has come before Me, [...] HaShem knew that with all that was happening, humanity was doomed. In order to remove the corruption, the world had to be submerged in a Mikvah, i.e. the Flood. Only because HaShem made a covenant with Noach did he and his family survive to start anew.

Why was Noach chosen? For the Torah tells us, Bereishet 6:9, Noach followed G-d. It is interesting that the aspect that Noach followed for HaShem is Elokim (), the attribute of Justice and within Nature. Which shows that Noach was rescued through natural means, an ark.

The Torah tells us of the Flood, Bereishet 7:19-20, (19)The waters swelled tremendously high over the earth, so that all the high mountains where are beneath the entire heavens were covered.(20) The waters swelled fifteen cubits higher [than where] the mountains were covered. The tallest mountain is Mount Everest, which stands 29,029 feet tall or approximately five and half miles above sea level. And that was covered an additional, fifteen cubits or approximately twenty-two and half feet, a bit more than three times the height of an average male. We will learn in dealing with Sodom that in addition to the obvious water, there was fire and brimstone as well. So you had five and half miles of additional water, all boiling and acidic.

HaShem states to Himself, as recorded in the Torah, Bereishet 8:22, As long as the earth exists, the sowing-season and the harvest-season, the cold-season and the hot-season, summer and winter, and day and night will not cease. Which Rashi states, from which we can deduce that they ceased during the entire period of the Flood, for the constellations did not function and [therefore] there was no distinction between day and night. How is day and night distinguished? By the Sun, therefore, the Sun did not function during the year of the Flood or the constellations. The laws of astrophysics (and more) where suspended, which means any scientific examination of anything during or before the Flood is suspect as science as a hole that our understanding cannot cross.

There was another ten generations between Noach and Abraham, which also sinned and became corrupt. But their corruption did not include larceny. All of note, Noach, himself, was still live during the generation of dispersion, and Abraham was about fifty (given or take a decade) when the incident with the Tower of Babel occurred.

Rashi points out something among the descendants of Shem, Bereishet 9:25, Dispersed. Rashi states, The languages were mixed up, and [thus the people] were scattered from the plain an dispersed throughout the world. [From here] we learn that Ever was a prophet, since he named his son for what was to happen in the future, [for] we learned in Seder Olam (ch. 1) that the Dispersion took place at the end of [Peleg's] life. Should you claim that in fact it took place at the beginning of his life Yoktan was his younger brother and he had fathered several families beforehand, as it says: Yoktan fathered... (v. 26) and [only] aftewards: The whole world... (11:1). And if you claim that [the Dispersion occurred] in the middle of his life, the verse does not leave itself ambiguous when it can be expressing a specific [time, and] therefore you can deduce that they were dispersed in the year of Peleg's death.

Unlike the generation of the Flood, the generation of the Dispersion were not wiped out completely, rather they were scattered. Why a different punishment for their rebellion? Because Bereishet 11:1, The whole world [spoke] one language, and was of a united cause. Because there was respect and love between them, the generation of the Dispersion were treated more softly.

What was one of the reasons for the Tower? The Torah tells us, Bereishet 11:4, They then said, Come, let us build for ourselves a city, with a tower who top teaches until the heavens, and let us make for ourselves an idol, so that we not be dispersed over the face of the entire earth. For they rebelled against their Father in Heaven, fearing dispersion, so they were, in fact, dispersed.

Bereishet 11:8, The Eternal dispersed them from there. Rashi tells us, in this world. What they had said, so that we not be dispersed (v. 4) actually happened to them, and of this Shelomo said: What the wicked person fears will come upon him (Mishlei 10:24). They rebelled become of their fear, and for their rebellion, their fear came to pass.

Two rebellious generations, two fates. Two events that affects the entire human race, and two righteous men were born before these events happened. Noach before the Flood and Abraham before the Dispersion. While Noach acted before and during the Flood, Abraham has no recorded actions before or during the Dispersion. From Midrash, we know that Abraham defied Nimrod who was the leader of the people of the Dispersion. But then Abraham continued to speak the Holy tongue, where as the rest of the human race's language was mixed up.

This Shabbat (and the prior day, Friday) is Rosh Chodesh Cheshvan. The mark of Cheshvan is that there are no special days within the entire month of Cheshvan, for which some call it Mar-Cheshvan, the bitter Cheshvan. I was born in the month of Cheshvan, so I cannot call my birth-month bitter. Also, it is easy to see HaShem in the High Holy Days of Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur, and the Holy Days of Sukkot, Shemini Atzeret, and Simcha Torah. The true strength and test of Judaism and a Jew is finding HaShem in the month of Cheshvan. How can we do this? As Noach and Abraham did, building an enclosure, separating ourselves from outside forces, walking in the way of HaShem. Noach had to build an ark to do so, Abraham merely built a tent/lifestyle. While Abraham is a descendant of Noach (as all of humanity is), it is after Abraham, not Noach, that we are called. In other words, we do not have to completely isolate ourselves like Noach in an ark, rather, like Abraham, we need to surround ourselves with HaShem and walk in His ways.

As the water of Noach surrounded him, so in the days of Mashiach will we be surrounded by HaShem, and has HaShem protected Noach and Abraham, so He protects us. And may He bring the final redemption, where all of humanity will once again speak a single language, Hebrew, and have a single heart that follows the ways of HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech
entry.content:
''
Thu, Sep 18, 2014 / 23 Elul, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech / -
Devarim 29:9 31:30
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech, a double portion, Shabbat Mevarekhim ( ) the Shabbat before the New Month, and as it happens, the last Shabbat of the Year 5774 (''). Rosh Chodesh Tishrei ( ) falls this year on Thursday, September 25, 2014, which is also Rosh HaShanah ( ) of the Year 5775 (''). It is said that the previous Shabbat blesses the coming week. Thus, this Shabbat, a double-portion, blesses the New Year that we will be entering.

What verse does this double-portion Parsha begin with? Devarim 29:9, You, all, are standing today before the Eternal, your G-d Our Sages tell us, after hearing all the curses of the previous Parsha, the people were panicky about them, thus Moshe Rabbeinu reassured them by saying all of you are still standing after those curses. Which we, today, can testify, after all the curses and hardships of the past, we, Jews, still stand. How are we still standing? Before the Eternal, our G-d, who has protected us and saved us, as the Haggadah states, in every generation, there arises someone seeking to destroy us, but HaShem preserves us.

Devarim 29:12, Today, Rashi expounds this thus, like this day which endures forever, for though it becomes dark for a period it shines again, (cf. Sanhedrin 100b); so has He made you shine and will again make you shine; and it is the curses and the sufferings that give you permanence and stability before Him. So, too, the section preceding this consists of comforting words: You have seen all HaShem did. Another explanation of : Because the Israelites were now passing from one leader to another, from Moshe to Yehoshua, there he (Moshe) made them stand in ranks () that he might address admonitions to them. Similarly did Yehoshua (cf. Josh. 24:1) and similarly did Shmuel, who said, (Shmuel I 12:7), Now therefore take your stand () that I may reason with you, when they were leaving his hand (leadership) and were coming under the hand of Shaul (cf. Midrash Tanchuma). The Jewish people are liken to the Sun, to a day, in that there is always another day that comes after night. Throughout the year, the Sun is a constant, as HaShem's relationship is with us. Just as we mark the anniversary of our own relationships, so too do we mark the anniversary of our relationship with HaShem. Rosh HaShanah is not the anniversary of the birth of the world, but rather the anniversary of the sixth day of Creation, the birth of Adam and Eve. Creation was not complete until there was someone to exist and live within the lower world. For the purpose of Creation to bring harmony between the higher and lower worlds, and that is job is Mankind's. While there have been a passage of leadership over the ages, the Jewish People have remained and our mission of Torah remains.

Devarim 30:3, Then HaShem your G-d will return your captivity, Rashi explains, It ought to have written; then He will bring back our captivity. But our Rabbis learned from this that, if one can, His Divine presence dwells with Israel in the misery of their exile, so that when they are redeemed, He makes redemption written for Himself that He will return with them (Sifri on Num 35:34; Meg. 29a). Furthermore the following may be said, that the day of the gathering of the exiles is so important and with difficulty that it is as though He (G-d) Himself must actually seize hold of each individual's hand from his place, as it is said, (Is. 27:12) And you shall be gathered one by one, O you children of Israel. And also regarding the exiles of other nations we have found this, (Ezek. 29:14) And I will return the captivity of Egypt. HaShem, Himself, will ensure that every exile will be redeemed, taking each by their hand and carrying them home.

Devarim 30:15, Life and good, Rashi says, The one is dependent upon the other; if you do good, behold, there is life for you, and if you do evil, behold, there is death for you. Torah goes on to explain how this is: For like begets like, good brings life, and evil brings death. A metaphor, the closer you move to the fire, the warmer you are; conversely, the further you move away from the fire, the colder you get. Doing good is moving closer to HaShem, the Source of Life, so there is life for you. Doing evil, on the other hand, is moving away from HaShem, for whom without, there is no life, only death.

So how does one go about doing good? The Torah says, Devarim 30:16, to love HaShem your G-d, as we say in the Avinu Malkeinu ( ) prayer, HaShem is our Father and our King. We should love Him as a parent and as a ruler/guiding light, in both private (as our Father), and public (as our King) lives. Other religions believe in a separation of physical and spiritual, not so with Judaism. The very same G-d that is among us, is the very same G-d that is within me. We are all the children of HaShem.

Such was the quality of leadership of Moshe Rabbeinu that upon the day of his death, Devarim 31:1, Moshe then went and spoke these words to all of Israel. To each and every person under him, he went to, to speak face to face with each person, individually, thus, honoring all of them, he that spoke face to face with HaShem, Himself, spoke with each Jew, face to face, as well.

Devarim 31:2, I can no longer go out and come in, Rashi expounds thus, One might think that this was because his physical strength failed him! Torah, however, states (34:7), His eye was not dim nor his natural force abated! What then is the meaning of I can no longer? It means: I am not permitted (cf. Rashi on 12:17 and 24:4), because the power (leadership) is being taken from me and given to Yehoshua. Moshe was not unable to lead, rather, the Divine Plan, was to have a different style of leadership for the Jews when they entered Israel. Why this is so, please, discuss with a Rabbi.

Devarim 31:2, I am this day, Rashi comments, Today my days and my years become full; for on this day (the seventh of Adar; cf. Rashi on 1:3) I was born and on this day I must die (Sota 13b). Another explanation is: in the matter of Law; teaches that the traditions and the well-springs of wisdom were stopped up for him (Tanch. cf. Sota 13b). So Moshe Rabbeinu lived exactly one hundred and twenty years, which is the full allotted time that had been decreed upon Humanity as a whole, in the time of the Flood.

Devarim 31:9, Moshe then wrote down this Torah and gave it to the priests the sons of Levi, who carry the ark of the covenant of the Eternal, and to all the elders of Israel. Our Sages tell us, each of the tribes complained to Moshe, that he had only gave his own tribe a copy of the Torah. How precious the Torah was to each and every tribe, they demanded from Moshe, a copy for themselves as well. So that possible future generations could not say, to the Leviyim only was the Torah given to, but rather, as it is said, The Torah which Moshe commanded us is the heritage of congregation of Yaakov. (v 33:4) The Torah is a heritage for all. Thus, HaShem performed a miracle, and allowed Moshe Rabbeinu to write an additional eleven other Torahs, so that each of the twelve tribes had a copy by his hand. It is a miracle for it takes, approximately several months to do so, but Moshe Rabbeinu wrote eleven within the very day of his death.

Devarim 31:12, and the small children Rashi asks, Why did they come? For no other purpose than that a reward should be given to those who bring them (Chag. 3a). To the seventh year gather, everyone came, in order to learn and even to merely hear the words of Torah spoke, whether the small children understood them or not, they gave reward to those that brought them.

Devarim 31:21, For it shall not be forgotten out of the mouths of their offspring Rashi tells us, This is an assurance to Israel that the Torah will never be entirely forgotten by their descendants. It is because of HaShem's promise that despite all that has befallen us, I can write on what the Torah has to say and expound it today.

Devarim 31:29, After my death you will surely corrupt yourselves Rashi counters, But, you see, all the days of Yehoshua they did not corrupt, for it states, (Judg 2:7) And the people served HaShem all the days of Yehoshua?! But from here that one's pupil should be as dear to him as his own self; it appears to Moshe that so long as Yehoshua would live it would be as though he himself would be living (he thus alluded by the words after my death to a period after Yehoshua's death). For the future was known to His prophets, for HaShem, Himself, is beyond time. Past, present and future have no meaning to Him, the Creator of Time.

May we all be inscribed for a good and sweet year. May the year 5774 be a year of redemption and peace with the coming of Mashiach. May this year, we all stand before HaShem in Jerusalem, for good, for life, and for peace.


May you be inscribed and sealed for a good year!

entry.title: Parsha Ki Savo
entry.content:
''
Tue, Sep 9, 2014 / 16 Elul, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Ki Savo /
Devarim 26:1 29:8
