Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Savo. This is the month of Elul, which our Sages tells us is like a time that the King is in the field. One does not need to look far for HaShem, for He is among us (which He always is) but at this time, we know it too. The weekly Parsha is a part of the Living Torah. So what does this week's Parsha have to do with Elul, the month of repentance?

The first verse of our Parsha says, Devarim 26:1, It shall be, when you come to the land that the Eternal, your G-d, is giving to you as permanent property [...] We can also say that when you come to the land make an effort on your part in the mundane/physical world, the Eternal, your G-d, is giving to you, HaShem, who is transcendent has decided to turn that mundane effort, as permanent property, into something infinite yet tangible. HaShem has given us His mitzvot, which are infinite, into a finite form for us to performance. While all things mortal and mortal-made disappear, our mitzvot do not. No matter our past, it is HaShem, Who is both transcendent and works within Nature, that gives us the ability to claim the mitzvot as permanent inheritance.

Devarim 26:2, of the first, Rashi expounds this thus, but not all the first, for not all fruits are subject to the duty of their first fruits, only the seven kinds of products of Israel alone, for it mentions here the land and it states there (8:8) a land of wheat, and barley, etc. (thus suggesting that the fruits of the land referred to here are those enumerated there). What is there? Of the seven products through which the Land of Israel is distinguished! So, too, here the distinguished of the Land of Israel which are seven species (Sifri, Menachos 84b). So, of all the fruits, only the fruits that praise the Land of Israel are to be offered to HaShem, in other words, of the best, the best of the best. We must remember that all that we do, we are only doing with HaShem and His assistance. One can not grow wheat from acorns, or from nothing. That in fact, all of the fruits and everything, in truth belong to He that created them. And yet, HaShem wishes only some, and from those some, only the first of the distinguished fruits that everyone in the Land of Israel would know and respect.

Devarim 26:16, This day HaShem your G-d commands you, Rashi tells us, each day they (HaShem's commandants) should be to you as something new (not antiquated and something of which you have become tired), as though you have received the commands that very day (Tanchuma; cf. Rashi on 11:13). This is not just Moshe Rabbeinu speaking to the people about to enter the Land of Israel, this is Moshe Rabbeinu speaking to us. We should not think mistakenly thinking: oh... these commandants were given three thousand odd years ago, they are ancient and have no baring on today's society. Comes the Torah and points out, this Torah is a living Torah, from the Everliving G-d, the Infinite, Who speaks of tomorrow, today, and yesterday as one. While society comes as goes, HaShem and His words, the Torah, are eternal. They are not old, they are not out-dated, nor are they antiquated of a time long gone. The Torah and HaShem's commandants still apply more so today. When those so-called enlightened around us are lost and corrupt, we remain upright and strong, for the eternal words of HaShem are with us. The world does not change. A mountain is still a mountain. A pool of water remains wet. Our understanding of the world around us might change, but the human condition and Torah remains. History has shown time and time again, those that think themselves above the words of HaShem only to fall a way before the transcendence of HaShem.

Devarim 27:8, explaining them well, Rashi translates this as, in seventy languages (Sota 32a; cf. Rashi on 1:5). In other words, Moshe Rabbeinu explained the Torah in all the languages of humanity, breaking any language barrier that might have existed. One cannot say, oh I do not know Hebrew so I will not study Torah. Not so!! While not as complete as in the original Hebrew, one can study in the language that they know. There are translations out there.

Devarim 27:9, This day you have become the people, Rashi says, On each day it should appear to you as though it were today that you have entered the covenant with Him (Berachos 3b). As each Jew is born, he or she enters the covenant with HaShem, which is renewed each and every day. Each day is a blessing and a chance to come closer to HaShem. If yesterday you were far, today you can start anew and come closer.

Devarim 29:1, Moshe then called all Israel and said to them: You saw everything that the Eternal, after all the curses from chapter twenty-eight, which have come upon us, Moshe Rabbeinu points out that all of Israel is still here and that we see everything that HaShem has done to us and for us, and we remain in His mercy.

One could say that the world is stone and unchanging, society to fickle to do anything about, comes the Torah and tells us differently, Devarim 29:8, You shall keep the words of this covenant and carry them out, so that you may achieve success in everything that you do. By partnering with HaShem anything is possible and success attainable regardless what is opposing you. It does not matter what you seek to do, as long as you do so in a Torah-manner, you will be successful.

As this week's Parsha mentions the wonders, signs, and trials in the Egyptian exile and redemption. So too may we see our redemption soonest with the coming of Mashiach and peace throughout the world that so badly needs it.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Seitzei
entry.content:
''
Wed, Sep 3, 2014 / 8 Elul, 5774 / ' ''

Parsha Ki Seitzei /
Devarim 21:10 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Setzei, which means when you go out. While the Torah is, on the literally level, talking about going out to war, Chasidism takes a metaphoric view, and relates how just as one needs to prepare and guard oneself when going out to war against a physical enemy, so too, should one prepare and guard oneself when going about their daily life and dealing with others.

Devarim 21:11, that you would take her for your wife, Rashi expounds this thus, Torah is speaking only in view of man's evil inclination (Kidushin 21b). For if the Holy One, blessed be He, would not permit her, he would marry her although she would then be forbidden. However, if he does marry her, in the end he will hate her, for Torah writes immediately afterwards, (v. 15), If a man has two wives, one beloved, and another hated, etc., and ultimately he will beget a wayward and rebellious son by her (v. 18). It is for this reason that these sections are put in juxtaposition (Tanchuma). In other words, the Maker of the Human Heart understands it all too well, and takes that into our account. Thus, the Torah is warning us that in a moment of passion, the heart might desire something which may seem to be beneficially, but is in fact, harmful to us. Just a historical note, in the olden days, women would dress up in order to seduce the victor into taking care of her.

Devarim 21:15, If a man has two wives, one who is loved and one who is hated [...] But is not being hated grounds for a divorce? And did not our Fore-fathers Abraham and Ya'akov have multiple wives? This verse is the bases (and there are others) that the Rabbis ruled that multiple wives is not a practice that should be followed anymore. In all cases, there were complications. It is a bit logical, two people, four times the complexity, three people, nine times the complexity, and so on.

The old saying, Finder keeper, etc. is not a Jewish one, for the Torah tells us, Devarim 22:1, you must return them to your brother.

entry.title: Parsha Shoftim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 28, 2014 / 2 Elul, 5774 / ' ''

Parsha Shoftim /
Devarim 16:18 21:9
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shoftim, which means Judges, while the Parsha begins with the appointment of Judges and policemen, the Parsha also deals with other matters; prohibition of idolatry, laws of sacrifices, the establishment of the Jewish monarchy, the priests' entitlements and divisions, divination versus prophecy, cities of refuge, theft, testimony, perjury, war, and unwitnessed murder. How does this all fit into the theme of Judges?

Devarim 16:22, Because [HaShem your G-d] hates, Rashi explains, An altar of stones and an altar of earth He has commanded you to make; this, however, He hates, because it was a religious ordinance amongst the Canaanites. And although it was pleasing to Him in the days of our ancestors (cf. Bereishet 28:18), now He hates it because these (the Canaanites) make it an ordinance of an idolatrous character (cf. Sifri). Because the Canaanites tainted the practice with idolatry, the one-block altar which our fore-fathers used, became hateful to HaShem. Was it hateful that the practice of the one-block altar that once pleased HaShem, was turned into a mockery as it was used by the Canaanites for their idols? Maybe. The Torah tells us that we should not adapt any ritual/practice from the Goyim for ourselves. For example, any kosher wine that is used in an idolatrous act is forbidden to a Jew thereafter. The reverse is also true, in that, the Goyim play music to their prayers, but we do not, even if it seems like a good idea. But then, in the days of the Holy Temple, the Leviyim used to play music and sing during the sacrificial services, and because the Holy Temple does not stand, we do not include music in remembrance of the loss of the Holy Temple.

So how does the theme of Judges fit into this? We might think since it was originally a Jewish practice that the Goyim have adapted, we could resume it. Comes the Torah and tells us that is not the case outright. We would have to judge the practice to see if the Goyim have truly corrupted it as the Canaanites did or it is still kosher.

Devarim 17:6, Two witnesses or three, Rashi points out, If evidence can be established by two to what end does it mention to you by three? In order to compare three witnesses to two. How two? Their evidence forms one testimony; so, too, does the evidence of three (or many) form one testimony and they cannot be declared plotting witnesses unless all of them are proved to be plotting witnesses (Makos 5b). In other words, a group of two or more, are still only one testimony and used as a whole. There is a lesson here; two, a hundred, or a thousand all saying something it is only one testimony, in truth.

Devarim 17:16, [The king] must not, however, have many horses [...] Devarim 17:17, And he must no have many wives [], nor may he have too much silver or gold. The Jewish king is not like the other monarchs in the world, for the mere mortal monarchs of the world believed as Par'oh did that could ignore HaShem and do as they pleased. Comes the Torah and emphasize that a Jewish king must be different. That a Jewish king leads by example and is merely the first among his people. Just as a judge needs to remember that true Judgment comes from HaShem, a king's authority comes from HaShem as well.

Devarim 18:2, The Eternal is their [Priests'] permanent portion. We, the descendants of Aharon the Cohen, and the Leviyim, do not have a portion among the Land of Israel as the other tribes do. Rather, HaShem, Himself, is our portion. As we give our all to HaShem, HaShem matches it for us. This is also true for every Jew, all material things, even the very land of Israel, is finite and mortal, and yet, we all have a portion within the Eternal/Infinite that is HaShem.

Devarim 18:10, one that uses divination, Rashi asks, What is a diviner? One who takes his stack in hand and says, (as though he were consulting it) Shall I go, or shall I not go? So does it states, (Hoshea 4:12) My people ask counsel of their stick, and their staff declared to them (Sifri) Something we would call superstitious and illogical today.

Devarim 18:10, a sorcerer, Rashi explains is one who forecasts from the fact that the bread fell from his mouth, or that a stag crossed his path, or that his stick fell from his hand (Sifri; Sanhedrin 65b; cf. Rashi on Lev. 19:26). Someone that takes minor events and tries to justify themselves with them.

Devarim 18:15, from your midst, of your brethren, like me, Rashi states, This means: One who is am I [Moshe] am, from your midst, of your brethren. In other words, a prophet cannot just come out the blue, for Moshe was the son of Amram, the spiritual leader during the Egyptian exile, the brother of Miriam the Prophetess and Aharon the Cohen, both known to the people and admired. Thus, Moshe was known to the people and his family was known to them as righteous people. All future prophets followed the same template as Moshe as well as following the Torah as Moshe did.

Devarim 18:22, you shall not afraid of him, Rashi points out, do not refrain from advocating his guilt (Sifri) and do not fear that you may incur punishment on his account (because you have contributed to his death). In other words, if this person is a false prophet, justice needs to be done. Do not fear a prophet that went bad, nor a false prophet to begin with.

entry.title: Parsha Re'eh
entry.content:
''
Wed, Aug 20, 2014 / 24 Menachem Av, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Re'eh /
Devarim 11:26 16:17
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Re'eh, the fourth Parsha in the Sefer Devarim. The Parsha begins with Devarim 11:26, Look! I am putting before you today blessings and curses. Moshe Rabbeinu is talking not alone to those that stood before him, but to us, the reader, as well. Our Sages tell us that each and every day, we should consider that we have two choices to make, shall we receive blessings for fulfilling the will of HaShem or will we incur the curses for ignoring HaShem? Notice that Moshe Rabbeinu is not telling us that it's reward or punishment, but blessing or curse.

It is a Jewish belief that all our actions have consequences, spiritual as well as physical. If our action is positive, the effect is positive, which is termed a blessing. The reverse is also true, if the action is negative, the effect is negative, which we call a curse. In other words, because you did this, therefore, that happened. Whether we can see the consequences or the effects of our actions, is immaterial to the fact that it exists. So each day, this very day, today, we have a choice, will we choose correctly?

Devarim 12:4, You shall not do so, Rashi explains, to burn offerings to G-d at any place, but at the place which He will choose. Another explanation: It is a prohibition to one who would blot out the Name, or would pull out a stone from the Altar or from the Courtyard. Rabbi Ishmael said: But can the idea enter your mind that the Israelites would pull down the altars? But that you should not do like their doings so that your sins would cause the Beis HaMikdosh of (built by) your fathers to be laid waste (Sifri). Rashi normally does not incite his sources directly, only to emphasis something. Who was Rabbi Ishmael? He was a descendant of Aharon the Cohen, and like him, a pursuer of peace. For our Sages say that the Beis HaMikdosh was taken from us for our sins. Rather than taken it out upon the people, HaShem took it out of a structure.

Devarim 12:20, I will eat flesh You may eat flesh, Rashi explains, The Torah teaches the proper rule of life the one should not desire to eat flesh (meat) except amidst abundance and wealth (cf. Sifri; Chul. 84A; see also Rashi on Lev. XVII. 13). In other words, meat is a luxury item and not required in human diet.

Devarim 12:21, Then you may slaughter as I have commanded you, Rashi points out, This teaches us that there was already a commandment regarding the slaughtering of animals as to how one should slaughter. It is not written in the Torah but it comprises the traditional regulations regarding the slaughter of animals that were given orally to Moshe on Mount Sinai (Sifri; Chul. 28a). This is an example of the Written Torah referring to the Oral Torah.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
''
Thursday, August 14, 2014 / 18 Av 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Eikev /
Devarim 7:12 -- 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Eikev and the second Haftarah of the seven Haftarah of Comfort. This is the second Parsha of Moshe Rabbeinu's final address to the Jewish people before he passes way.

The Parsha starts with Devarim 7:12, And it will be because of () your listening. Rashi comments, If, even the lighter commands which a person treads on with his heels (i.e., which a person is inclined to tread lightly), you will listen to. And if we do so, Devarim 7:13, He [HaShem] will love you, bless you and make you numerous[...]. Thus, we should know that what might seem minor, a heel, in our eyes, can and could be important to HaShem, as well as, even if we but listen, a small thing, HaShem's love for us is out of proportion to what we do. We can do a small thing, and yet, HaShem will respond majorly. As it is said in the Thirteen Attributes of HaShem, those whom hate Him, he will deal with for three generations, and yet, for those that love Him, he deals with for two thousand generations.

Devarim 7:17-18, (17) If you say to yourself, These nations are more numerous than I. How can I possibly drive them out? (18)do not be afraid of them. You shall constantly remember what the Eternal, your G-d, did to Par'oh and to all the Mitzrim. This applies even to today. We look at see, Israel is literally surrounded on all sides by those that seek our utter destruction, they are more numerous than us. This is a fact, and yet, because of HaShem, our G-d, we are commanded not to be afraid, for HaShem has assigned the Land to us and no mortal can say otherwise. Trust in HaShem, and He will care for you.

Devarim 7:22, lest the beasts of the field increase upon you, Rashi points out, But is it not a fact that if people perform the will of the Omnipresent they will not have to fear the beasts, as it is said, (Iyov V. 23) And the beasts of the field shall be at peace with you?! But it was manifest before Him that they would in future sin. Thus, we see the future is known to HaShem, and taken into account in the present.

Devarim 8:1, Every commandment, Rashi states, And a Midrashic explanation is: If you have made a beginning with a meritorious deed, carry it out to the end, because it bears the name only of he who does the last part of it, as it is said, (Yehoshua XXIV. 32) And the bones of Yoseph which the children of Israel brought up from Egypt they buried in Shechem. But did not Moshe alone busy himself with them to bring them up (cf. Shemos XIII. 19)? But because he had no opportunity to complete this, Israel completed it, it was called by their name (Tanchuma). In other words, finish what you start, for you never know what will come tomorrow. Moshe believed that he would bury the bones of Yoseph in Israel, and yet, it was decreed not to be the case. If one such as Moshe, this is true, how much more so for us?

entry.title: Parsha Va'eschanan
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 7, 2014 / 11 Menachem Av, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Va'eschanan  /
Devarim 3:23 7:11
Shabbos Nachamu /
Isaiah 40:1 40:26
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Va'eschanan as well as Shabbos Nachamu. This Shabbos starts the seven Haftarah of Consolation, and the Haftarah begins, Isaiah 40:1, Console, console My people. From here, we call this Shabbos, Shabbos Nachamu (Shabbos of Console/comfort). For after the hardship of the Three Weeks, we need comfort.

So how does this fit into this week's Parsha? Rashi explains, All forms of the verb signify a gift for free. Although the righteous might make a claim to reward dependent upon their good deeds, they solicit from the Omnipresent only a gift without payment. Because [G-d] had said to [Moshe], I will show grace () to him to whom I shall show favor, Moshe, when referring to his entreaty of G-d uses the expression I implored grace (). Another explanation of the word is that this is one of the ten terms by which prayer is described, as are enumerated in Sifrei. So this Parsha is named after a term of prayer and the Haftarah is about comfort. There is a connection between prayer and comfort.

Devarim 3:25, That fine mountain, Rashi tells us, this is Jerusalem (Sifrei on Bamidbar 27:12).

Devarim 3:25, and the Levanon, Rashi explains, this is the Temple (Sifrei).

Devarim 4:6, You shall safeguard and do Rashi expounds this means, study and action. Both are important.

entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 31, 2014 / 4 Menachem Av, 5774 / ' ''

Parsha Devarim /
Devarim 1:1 3:22
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Devarim, which means words. I call this blog of mine Words from Desire because I started with Devarim, and my name translates into desire. As well as, it is my desire to share my words of Torah with others. While I do not consider myself a great scholar, it is said one learns more from teaching than from mere studying. There is a lot of lessons to learn from the words of Torah, too many to include here or in any single work. So I am trying to highlight various phrases from the Parsha and Rashi, and a bit of my own.

Devarim 1:1, These are the words, Rashi states, Because these are words of reproof and Torah is enumerating here all the places where they provoked G-d to anger, therefore it suppresses the matters and refers to them allusion out of regard for Israel (Sifri, Onkelos and Targum Yonasan). From here we learn that when we reproof another, we should be careful and thoughtful in our reproof and not directly mention the item in question.

Devarim 1:3, It was in the fortieth year, in the eleventh month, on the first of the month, Rashi tells us, This tells us that he reproved them only shortly before his death. From whom did he learn this? From Ya'akov, who reproved his sons only shortly before his death. He said, Reuven, my son, I will tell you why I have not reproved you during all these years: in order that you should not leave me and go and join Esau, my brother. From here, we see that after reproving, we should not bring up the item again as a person that passes a way so there would not bring it up again as they are beyond.

Devarim 1:10, and here you are the day, as the stars of the heavens, Rashi asks, But were they that day as the stars of the heavens? Were they not, indeed, only six hundred thousand? What, then is the meaning of ? Behold you may be compared to the day (the sun), existing forever just as the sun and the moon and the stars (Sifri). As Mark Twain said, All things are mortal but the Jews. For Moshe Rabbeinu liked us to the Sun, and HaShem is with us. All that has befallen us, yet, we remain because of HaShem's mercy and loving-kindness.

Devarim 1:17, you shall bring to me, Rashi points out, On account of this utterance the law regarding the daughters of Tzelofechad evaded him. Similarly, Shmuel said to Sha'ul (Shmuel I 9:19), I am the seer. The Holy One, blessed be He, then said to him, By your life, I will let you know that you are not a seer. And when did He let him know? When he came to anoint David. (Shmuel I 16:6, 7) And when he saw Eliav he said, 'Surely before G-d stands his anointed one', The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, Did you not say, I am the seer? Look not at the outward appearance. (Sifri). Thus, we must be careful in our speech, for simple utterances can trip us up, and if such great ones as Moshe Rabbeinu and Shmuel HaNavi tripped up by their tongues, how much more so can we get ourselves in trouble?

Devarim 1:27, out of the Eternal's hatred of us, Rashi teaches us, He loved you, but you hated Him. A common proverb says: What is in your own mind about your friend, you imagine is what is in his mind about you (Sifri). From the beginning, HaShem has loved us, even when we feel as if that is not the case, but that is but a reflection of our own misunderstanding of what is occurring.

Devarim 2:5, I have given Mount Seir as an inheritance to Esau The Torah tells us to respect the boundaries of others. Just as we inherited the land of Israel, so too, other lands were given to others.

Devarim 2:16-17, It was when [all the men eligible for battle] had finished [dying] etc. that the Eternal spoke to me etc. Rashi informs us, But from when the spies were sent forth until now, is not mentioned, but , to teach you that during these entire thirty eight years during which the Children of Israel were lying under G-d's censure, the divine Utterance was not specially directed to him in affectionate language, face to face, and with tranquility of mind. This teaches you that the Shechinah rests upon the prophets only for Israel's sake (Mechilta Shemos 12:1; Sifri Vayikra 1:1; Rashi on Vayikra 1:1). Prophecy does not exist for prophecy sake, but rather for the people. Only by the people supporting a prophet can they reach so high.

Devarim 2:25, that are under the entire heavens, Rashi points out, This teaches us that the sun stood still for Moshe on the day of the battle with Og, and the matter was known under the whole heaven (Avoda Zara 25a). Thus, we hear of a miracle that was not mentioned but only hinted out, showing Moshe's humbleness and Torah's not wasting even a letter.

The parsha ends with Devarim 3:22, Do not fear them, for it is the Eternal, your G-d, who does battle for you. Unlike the other nations of the world, the Children of Israel's might is not in our physical prowess that gives us victory, but it HaShem, Himself, that does battles for us that has allowed us to survive to this day.

May it be Your will, Lord of the Universe, that Your messenger, the righteous Mashiach, shall come and show the world the truth and bring justice to our world. May He that brings peace to the heavens, bring peace to Earth and all within it. May our days of sorrow be final and transformed in days of joy.

entry.title: Parsha Masei
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 24, 2014 / 26 Tammuz, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Masei /
Bamidbar 33:1 36:13
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Masei. This is also the last Parsha of Sefer Bamidbar, and it is the second Shabbos of the Three Weeks. This is also the Shabbos Mevarekhim, as Rosh Chodesh Av is Monday, July 28, 2014. On a bit of side-note, according to my calculations, this is my hundredth blog entry.

The Torah begins this Parsha with Bamidbar 33:1, These are the stopping places of the Children of Israel. Rashi points out that in the forty year exile decree, the Children of Israel only made twenty journeys, showing the mercy and kindness of HaShem. Rashi also states, Rabbi Tanchuma gave another explanation of it. A parable! A king whose son was ill and whom he took to a distant place to cure him. When they returned home the father began to enumerated all the stages, saying to him, He we slept, here we caught cold, here you had the head-ache, etc. Who in the parable is the king/father, HaShem, of course, and the son, who was ill, was the Children of Israel, for it said had not HaShem taken our fore-parents out of Egypt when he did, all would have been lost, for the difference between Israelite and Egyptian was dimming and dimming. Thus the illness of sin had been upon the Children of Israel, therefore, they stay in the Sinai desert was part of the cure of their illness. It may seem harsh at times, but all that HaShem does, is for our benefit. May it be soonest that we can only see the goodness of HaShem and none of the seemingly harshness anymore.

Bamidbar 33:30, The Kena'ani heard, Rashi teaches us, to tell you that Aharon's death was indeed the news he heard because the clouds of glory had departed, and he therefore believed that liberty was now given to war against Israel. It is on this account that this is again recorded (Rosh HaShanah 3a). For the clouds of glory were given in Aharon's merit, and protected the Children of Israel in the desert, from the desert sun, scorpions, snakes, and other harmful elements. Thus, they disappeared upon Aharon's death. The clouds returned in Moshe's merit, as did the Miriam's well.

Bamidbar 33:55, But if you do not drive out the inhabitants of the land from before you, it will be, that those of them whom you leave over like pins in your eyes and like hedges of thorns on sides, and they will harass you in the land where you are living. And history has shown this time and time again.

entry.title: Parsha Matos
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jul 17, 2014 / 19 Tammuz, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Matos /
Bamidbar 30:2 32:42
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash and Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Matos. To summarize Parsha Matos simply, there are three events happening within this week's Parsha: one, the laws concerning the annulment of vows; two, the war against Midyan; and three, the request of the Tribe of Re'uven and Gad to settle in what would nowadays be Trans-Jordan.

Why annulment of vows? We went from Chukas, super-rational decree, to Pinchas, Zealotry, and now, Matos, with annulment of vows. What's the connection? The connection between the super-rational and zealotry should be somewhat obvious, but we should note that Chukkim are a part of the Torah, zealotry is not. In fact, the Tribes thought that Pinchas's zealotry was not kosher, until HaShem, Himself, said so, but HaShem did not directly say so, rather the Torah points out that Pinchas inherited his zealotry from Aharon, the pursuer of peace. Why Pinchas's zealotry was kosher and he was rewarded, comes this week's Parsha, and says somewhat, one should be very careful of such things. Zealotry in a form of vow, usually taken to an extreme. Comes the Torah and says, there are vows that we should not carry through with. There are forms of zealotry that can seize us in a moment, but upon reflection, are not something we should do.

Bamidbar 30:2, This is what Rashi points out, Moshe prophesied with the words, So says G-d, 'About midnight' (Shemos 11:4), and other prophets prophesied with Thus says G-d, Moshe, however, had an additional in that he prophesied also with the expression (Exactly) This is what [The Eternal has commanded] (Sifri). Another explanation of This is what it is a restrictive phrase to intimate that the Sage uses invalidating and the husband the expression annulling, as is the language of Torah here, and that if one of them exchanges, it is not invalidated nor annulled (Sifri, Nedarim 77b). There is a comparison between Moshe Rabbeinu and another Prophet, as there is between a Sage and a husband. Since both of Rashi's explanations are within the literal meaning of the verse, which is the introduction of annulment of vows.

A Sage can look into the vow itself and see that the vow is not truly a vow, and thus, has no mean and no value, thus making it disappear. While a husband can annul the vow of his wife, for the sake of peace in the home. For the second case, the vow itself is fine, in and of itself, until it affects others. So I suppose I could say, as a metaphor, that a vow is like a ball of string that is in the way, for a Sage's invalidation there is depth and it is as if he had unwound ball of string so it was no longer in the way, while a husband's annulment is breath, as if moving the ball somewhere out-of-the-way. In analogue, Moshe Rabbeinu could either make a string into a ball, or a ball into a string, while other prophets could only move the ball of string, but still leaving the original ball of string there.

Bamidbar 30:6, and the Eternal will forgive her, Rashi asks, Of what is Torah speaking? Of a woman who, vowed that she would become a Nazarite, and whose husband heard and annulled for her, but she did not know, and transgressed her vow and drank wine or made herself unclean by means of a corpse. It is such a woman who requires forgiveness even though it (her vow) has been annulled. And if those whose vows have been annulled require forgiveness, how much more is this so for those whose vows have not been annulled! (Kiddushin 81b). Thus, we learn how sacred a vow is; even breaking an annulled vow requires forgiveness, how much more so a valid vow requires.

I do find it interesting that the examples that the Torah gives is a father and his daughter, and a husband and his wife. Both are relationships dealing with love and the home. I would suggest if you are curious about this, study Chasidism. In some beautiful metaphoric level on this that I have heard many years ago; how HaShem can be seen as the father and husband, and we are the daughter and wife, in our relationship with HaShem and our service to Him, in a metaphor of vows.

Bamidbar 31:2, from the Midyanim, Rashi notes, but not of the Moavites, for the Moavites entered into the matter out of fear, because they feared that they might be plundered, since it was stated only, (Devarim 2:9) Do not contend with them in battle; but the Midianites, however, had become enraged over a quarrel that did not concern them. Another explanation (Devarim 2:19) because, of the two fine young doves (virtuous women) which I am to bring forth from them- Ruth the Moavitess, and Naamah the Ammonitess (Bava Kama 38b). Thus the future and the past are one and the same for HaShem, and what happens in the future affects the past and vice-a-versa.

Bamidbar 31:3, the Eternals revenge, Rashi points out, because whoever attacks Israel is as though he attacks the Holy One, blessed be He. As our Sages said, HaShem and Israel are in a relationship/partnership, so what happens to one, affects the other. It is because of our relationship with HaShem that we are attacked, for others try to deny the Torah and HaShem, they try to deny (fight) us.

Bamidbar 31:5, were given over, Rashi tells us, to tell you in what high esteem the shepherds of Israel were really held how dear they were to Israel. Before they had heard of his death what does it state? They are almost ready to stone me (Shemos 17:14). But when they heard that Moshe's death was associated with the vengeance upon Midian (v. 2), they refused to go to war until they were handed over against their own will (Sifri). Thus, we see some of the zealotry of Moshe, even though the vengeance upon Midian was connected with his own death, how dear the commandments of HaShem were to him, Moshe even carried out that which was associated with his own death. Moshe, while commanded to bring vengeance upon Midian, he was not given a time-frame. He could have delayed it for however long he wished, to be sure of the battle and all, but Moshe desired to perform the commandment of HaShem he rushed to do.

Bamidbar 31:8, by the sword Rashi informs us, He [Bil'am] came against Israel exchanging his medium (the sword) for their medium (the mouth), for they conquer only through their mouth through prayer and petition, and he came and availed himself of their craft to curse them with his mouth. They, therefore, also came against him and exchanged their craft for the craft of the heathen peoples who come with the sword, as it is said (Bereishet 27:40) And by your sword shall you live (Rashi on 22:23). We see the principle of measure for measure, Bil'am switch his craft, so he was killed with a switch of craft as well.

Bamidbar 31:14, Moshe then became angry with the army commanders, Rashi teaches us, Those appointed over the soldiers, to teach you that every misdeed of a generation is attributed to the leaders since these have the power to prevent it (Sifri). In other words, look towards the leaders to see of the people they lead. To be a leader, one needs to lead, by charging first and setting an example to follow. Which if you think about it, says a lot about America (and other countries) if you look towards their leaders.

Bamidbar 31:21, El'azar the Priest then said, Rashi asks why El'azar and not Moshe, he answers, Because Moshe fell into anger (v. 14) he fell into error: there escaped him the laws concerning the removal of impurity of heathens. This, too, do you find on the eighth day of the installing of the priests, as it is said, (Vayikra 10:16) And he was anger with El'azar and Itamar, he fell into anger; he fell into error. Similarly, also, (20:10, 11) Hear, now, you rebels, he smote the rock; it was through his anger that he made the mistake (Sifri; Pesachim 66b). If one such as Moshe Rabbeinu errs through anger, how much more so should be cautious of anger.

Bamidbar 31:49, and not one man of ours is missing. The officers realized that a miracle occurred as they had not lost a single soldier in the war, which is not the norm. As such they realized that they should thank HaShem for His mercy, and when we are put in peril, we too should thank HaShem that He saved us and brought us out.

Bamidbar 32:16, we will build here for our livestock Rashi points out, They paid more regard to their property than to their sons and daughters, because they mentioned their cattle before their children. Moshe said to them, Not so! Make that which is primary primary, and that which is secondary secondary. First build cities for your little ones and afterwards enclosures for your flocks, (v. 24) (Tanchuma). How often are our priorities in the wrong order, first comes family, then everything else? Comes the Torah, while the Tribes of Re'uven and Gad were discussing where they would live, the Torah and Moshe comes to remind them and us what comes first.

The commentators asked why did the Tribes of Re'uven and Gad with to have land outside of Israel? The Torah itself only mentions livestock, but there are some deeper influences at work. Some of our Sages say that the two tribes knew that Moshe was going to be buried within that area, so they wished to stay near him. For the burial place of a Tzadik ('), is a holy place, just as Kalev went to Chevron, the burial place of the Fore-fathers and Fore-mothers to pray and was rewards with the site, so too the Tribes of Re'uven and Gad wished to be by the burial place of Moshe Rabbeinu.

At this time, during the Three Weeks, we emphasis the lost of the Holy Temple and our exile from the land. May this Tish B'Av be a day of celebration instead of morning, a day of rebirth instead of lost, and may the complete land of Israel be in peace, with Mashiach, Moshe Rabbeinu and all the tribes of Israel, speedily in our day.

entry.title: Parsha Pinchas
entry.content:
''
Wed, Jul 9, 2014 / 11 Tammuz, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Pinchas /
Bamidbar 25:10 30:1
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Pinchas.

The Torah states, Bamidbar 25:10, Pinchas the son of El'azar the son of Aharon the Priest, Rashi tells us, Because the tribes spoke disparagingly of him, Have you seen this grandson of Puti, whose mother's father used to fatten () calves for idolatrous sacrifices, and he has dared to slay a prince of one of Israel's tribes! therefore the Torah comes and connects his genealogy with Aharon (Sanhedrin 83b). It is impossible to know the heart of a person, and zealotry is not encouraged. So the tribes thought that Pinchas was a person of violent heart, and simply took this opportunity to fulfill his need for violence. As Rashi points out, the Torah comes and corrects that assumption, stating that he took after his paternal grandfather, Aharon the Priest. What was Aharon's character, that of Peace. From where did Pinchas's zeal come from? It came from he that HaShem, Himself, chose as his very first Cohen HaGadol ( ), who served HaShem will all his heart and soul.

Bamidbar 25:15, And the name of the slain Midyani woman Rashi points out, to show you the hatred the Midianites bore that they abandoned even a princess to prostitution in order to make Israel sin (Tanchuma). A princess is usually protected and held above the rest of the people, but because of the hatred that Midyan had for Israel, even the highest was sent out to sin.

Bamidbar 26:5, the Chanochi family ( ), Rashi explains, Because the heathen nations spoke slightingly saying, How can those trace their descent by their tribes? Do they think that the Egyptians did not overmaster their mothers? If they were masters of their bodies, it is quite certain they did the same to their wives! On this account the Holy One, blessed be He, set His name upon them the letter on one side and the letter on the other side, to intimate: I bear testimony for them that they are the sons of their fathers. This it is that is expressed by David, (Tehillim 122:4) that the tribes bear the name of G-d (Yud-Hey) is a testimony regarding Israel this Divine Name (Yud-Hey) bears testimony regarding their tribes. On this account in all of them it is written and but in the case of (v. 44) it was not felt necessary to state of the family of , because the Divine Name is already attached to it the at the beginning and the at the end (Yalkut 2:988). For the Holy One, blessed be He, is the Source of Holiness, and we see that holiness and purity go hand-and-hand. It is but a two-letter name, and yet it is a part of the four-letter name of HaShem's transcendence.
