entry.title: Parsha Balak
entry.content:
''
Fri, Jul 4, 2014 / 6 Tammuz, 5774 / ' ''

Parsha Balak /
Bamidbar 22:2 25:9
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Balak, which is a bit unusual as the Parsha is named after Goy, the second of such Parshot. The first being Parsha Yisro. However, unlike Yisro, who converted to Judaism, Balak did not. In fact, he was king of the Moabites, and he hired Bil'am to cure the Jews. It should be noted that at no point did the Jews of that time know what Balak and Bil'am were up to. It is only through Prophecy that the story of Bil'am and Balak is known.

Bamidbar 22:4, to the Elders of Midyan, Rashi points out, But did not these (Moav and Midyan) always hate one another, as is stated (Bereishet 36:35) who had smitten Midyan in the country of Moav, that Midyan had come against Moav in war? But out of fear of Israel they made peace between themselves (Tanchuma; cf. Sanhedrin 105a). And what induced Moav to take counsel of Midyan? When they saw that Israel was victorious in a supernatural manner they said: the leader of these people grew up in Midyan; let us ask them what is his chief characteristic. They replied to them: His power lies only in his month (in prayer). Whereupon they said: Then we must come against with a man whose power lies in his mouth (Tanchuma). Such is the power of fear, for it can make peace among those who would otherwise be against each other.

There is another lesson or two here. That this point in time, the Children of Israel were about ready to enter the Land of Israel and assume their inheritance within it. And yet, these two people sought to prevent that. And yet, HaShem, Himself, Blessed be He, turned the attempt into something else. From a curse into blessings, and not just any blessings but blessings and prophecy about Mashiach and the final redemption. All without the Jews of that time knowing, until Moshe's prophecy told them about it when he recorded it into the Torah.

A question that can be asked is, of course, who was Bil'am, to which on the comment about Bamidbar 22:5, The country of his people Rashi expounds, of Balak's, for he come from there, and this man (Bil'am) had prophesied saying to him, You are destined to be king. And if you ask: Why did the Holy One blessed be He, let his Shechina rest upon so wicked a heathen, in order that the heathen peoples should have no excuse to say, If we had prophets, we would have changed for the better, He raised up prophets for them. Yet they (these prophets) broke down the fence of the world, because at first they (the heathens) were fenced in against immoral living, but this man (Bil'am) counseled them to freely offer themselves to prostitution (cf. Rashi on 24:14).

So Bil'am's prophecy was on par with Moshe's, who Bil'am could have corrected Balak's statement of Bamidbar 22:5, and are living [right here, about] to destroy me. For HaShem had commanded no such thing, for the sake of the dove, Ruth, who would be born from Moav, and was the grandmother of King David and Mashiach.

Rashi points out the difference between the Jewish Prophets and the Goyim Prophets in his comment about Bamidbar 22:8, stay here tonight, saying, The Holy Spirit rested upon him only at night time, and similarly in the case of all the prophets of the heathen peoples, and similarly to Lavan in a dream at night, as it is said, (Bereishet 31:24) And HaShem came to Lavan in a dream of the night as a man who comes to his concubine furtively (cf Tanchuma, Vayikra R. 1; Rashi on Iyov 12:4).

Bamidbar 22:9, Who are these men with you? Rashi responses, He intended to delude him. He (Bil'am) said, It seems, then, that there are times when everything is not manifest to Him; His knowledge is not always alike. I will select a time when I can curse and when He will not observe it. (Tanchuma). For such is the wicked, they will justify what they are doing. Instead of realizing that HaShem was simply giving him an opening out of kindness, Bil'am used it to do as he had planned all along.

Bamidbar 22:12. You must nor curse the people, Rashi tells us, He (Bil'am) said to Him (HaShem): If so, I will bless them. He replied to him, They do not need your blessing. For what can a mortal's blessing compare to the blessing of the Source of Blessing?

Bamidbar 22:12, For they are blessed Rashi explains this thus, A parable! People say to the hornet: neither any of your honey nor any of your sting! (Tanchuma) Of the wicked, we should have no part, for even their blessing is wicked, as Lavan and Rivka's mother blessed her, and she had a troubled birth, for example.

Bamidbar 22:17, as much silver and gold as fills his house Rashi states, This tells us that he was avaricious and covetous of other peoples wealth. He said: He ought to give me all his silver and gold, for, behold, he would have to hire many armies. It is doubtful whether he would conquer or not conquer, but I would certainly conquer (Tanchuma). Thus we see that Bil'am was not righteous in any sense.

Bamidbar 22:21, Saddled his she-donkey Rashi points out, From here we may learn that the hatred makes one disregard the rule, for he, himself, did the saddling. The Holy One, blessed be He said: You wicked man! Their ancestor Abraham, has already anticipated you, as it is said, (Bereishet 22:3) And Abraham rose up early in the morning and saddled his donkey (Tanchuma cf. Sanhedrin 105b). Normally, those of wealth or power have servants to do such work, to show their position.

Bamidbar 22:22, and his two lads were with him Rashi teaches us, From here we have a rule for a distinguished personage who is going on a journey, he should take with him two men to serve him, so that these in turn may serve one another (i.e., act for one another by taking over the other's duties if he must leave his master for a short time). (Tanchuma). (See Rashi Bereishet 22:3). So we rule that a single attendant of a personage is not enough. So we can learn some things from even the wicked.

Bamidbar 22:23, The She-donkey saw, Rashi adds, but he (Bil'am) did not see, for the Holy One, blessed be He, gave an animal power to see more than the man, for just because he possesses the sense his mind would become perturbed if he sees noxious beings. And Bil'am prided himself on his ability to see, and yet, here, he could not.

Furthermore, with a drawn sword in his hand, Rashi states, He (HaShem) said: This wicked man has abandoned the tools of his own craft, for the offensive weapons of the heathen peoples consist in the sword, and he is attacking them with his mouth which is their weapon; I will take his implement and come against him with his own weapon. Thus, indeed, was his end (31:8); And Bil'am the son of Beor they slew by the sword.

Bamidbar 22:24, a wall on one side and a wall on the other, our Sages tell us that at first, HaShem gave Bil'am the opportunity of take two paths instead of the three, referring that Bil'am could curse two of Abraham's descendants, Hagar and his third wive, but not the descendants of Yitzchak. The next time, there were two paths, but one was blocked, for Bil'am could curse the descendants of Esau, but not not the descendants of Ya'akov. And finally, all the paths were blocked for all the sons of Ya'akov were righteous.

Bamidbar 22:33, and let it remain alive Rashi expounds, but now because it spoke and rebuked you and you could not stand against its rebuke, just as it is written, He answered, No. I have killed it in order that people should not be able to stay: This is the animal that silenced Bil'am by its rebuke, so that he could not reply. For HaShem has regard for human dignity. Similar is (Vayikra 20:15), And the animal shall you slay, and similarly (ib. 15): And you shall slay the woman and the animal (with which sin was committed) (Tanchuma). Even the wicked Bil'am's dignity,, did HaShem protect.

Bamidbar 22:37, Am I indeed not capable of honoring you, Rashi points out, He prophesied unwillingly that he (Bil'am) would eventually leave him in disgrace (Tanchuma). Our own words can trip us up, if we do not take care in what we say.

Bamidbar 23:8, How can I curse [whom] HaShem [Himself] has not cursed. Rashi reminds us, Even when they deserved to be cursed, they were not cursed. When their ancestor, Ya'akov, made mention of their sin (Bereishet 49:6) For in their anger they slew a man he cursed their anger only, as it is said (ib. 7), Cursed be their anger. When their ancestor, Ya'akov, went to his father with deceit he deserved to be cursed, but what is stated there (ib. 27:33)? Yea, he shall be blessed. In the case of those tribes who had to recite the blessing it is said, (Devarim 27:12) These shall stand to bless the people, but in the case of those who had to pronounce the curses it does not state, And these shall stand to curse the people, but, And these shall stand for the curse, it does not wish to mention the term cursing in direct reference to them (the people) (Tanchuma). Although the people are rebuked, never has HaShem cursed us, for since the beginning, He has blessed up and never revoked those blessings.

Bamidbar 24:2. Bil'am looked up, Rashi comments, he wished to case the evil eye upon them. Thus you have this three characteristics an evil eye, and pride and greed which have been mentioned about.

After all that Bil'am had to do by the command of HaShem, he did not learn his lesson, instead he continued his wickedness by saying, Bamidbar 24:14, come I shall advise you. Which Rashi comments, you you have to do. And what is the counsel? The G-d of these people hates immorality as is related in Sanhedrin 106a. You can know that it was Bil'am who gave this counsel, to make them fall by immorality, for it is stated, (31:16), Behold, these were an enticement to the children of Israel through the word of Bil'am.

Bamidbar 25:7, Pinchas [] saw, Rashi expounds, He saw what was being done and he was reminded of the law (Sanhedrin 82a), He said to Moshe, I have received a tradition from you: he who has intercourse with an Aramean (heathen) woman, zealous people may attack him, He replied to him, Let him who reads the letter be the agent for executing it; straightway, he took a spear in his hand Etc. (ib.). Thanks to Pinchas, the plague was ended and peace restored.

May He who brings peace to heaven, bring peace to Earth.

entry.title: Parsha Chukas
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 26, 2014 / 28 Sivan, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Chukas /
Bamidbar 19:1 22:1
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Chukas. Chukas is a super-rational decree of HaShem that we do not understand. Jewish Law can be divided into three parts: one, Mishpotim/Judgments, these laws that are logical and given time humans might have created on their own: two, Eidos/Testimonials, these laws that humans would not know of or understand but which HaShem has told/explained within the Torah; and three, Chukkim/Decrees, these laws are given in the Torah without explanation nor can the human mind fully understand.

The Torah begins with Bamidbar 19:2, This is the statue of the Torah, which Rashi expounds, Because Satan and the nations of the world taunt Israel, saying, What is this command and what reason is there for it, on this account it (Scripture) writes (uses) about it: It is an enactment from before Me; you have no right to question it (Pesikta Rabba Rabb.; Yoma 67b).

What the Torah is talking about is the decree of the Red Heifer ( ), which is a process by which someone who is majorly impure becomes pure once more. How it works and the side-effects of the ceremony are something beyond human understand, especially as we cannot see the spirituality-side of the process.

It is interesting to point out that first we had the incident with the Spies, then Korach's rebellion, and now this. The idea of the Spies was about study and a mistaken belief that spirituality and mundane was mutual exclusive, with Korach, about action and the separation of spirituality and mundane, and now, we have this super-rational decree.

In many ways, Judaism as a whole is like this decree of Red Heifer, which combines the spiritual and the mundane in ways we do not understand, but is given by HaShem, Himself, to us to assist us. By doing something physical, there is a spiritual reaction, and something spiritual will have a physical reaction as well. We may not understand the process or even the full outcome, we can trust the Source of All to know how He set up the world.

The next section deals with Miryam's death, Rashi asks about this and answers, Why is the death of Miryam placed immediately after the section of the red cow? To suggest to you: What is the purpose of the sacrifices? They effect atonement! So, too, does the death of the righteous effect atonement! (Moed Katan 28a). Our Sages further say, why not place then the death of Miryam by any sacrifices, why the Red Heifer? Because just as the Red Heifer is a Divine Decree, we do not understand, so too the death of Miryam was a Divine Decree that we do not understand as well.

entry.title: Parsha Korach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 19, 2014 / 21 Sivan, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Korach /
Bamidbar 16:1 18:32
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Korach. Korach is an interesting character, he was a member of the Tribe of Levi and a leader of a rebellion against Moshe Rabbeinu. And yet, there is a Parsha in the eternal Torah named after him. Within that same Parsha we are told, Bamidbar 17:5, And he not as Korach and his group. Which Rashi tells u, in order that he be not as Korach. What is going on? On one hand, the Parsha is named after him, and yet the Torah itself says not to be like him.

In additional to all this, this rebellion occurred soon after the misfortune of the Ten Spies. Did they not learn from them?

Our Sages tell us that in fact, they did learn from them, but went too far in the opposite direction. The Ten Spies thought only of the Spiritual, and refrain the mundane. Korach understood that the mundane, Action with a capital A, was very important, as important as the spiritual. Yet, like the Ten Spies, Korach too thought that spiritual and mundane could not coexist. Korach seemed to feel that there should be a separation, a division, between the mundane and spiritual. Korach seemed to believe that the spiritual had its place and mundane had its own place independent of the other. Or in modern terms, a absolute division between religion and state.

Korach asks Moshe and Aharon with Bamidbar 16:3, You have for yourselves too much, since the entire community, all of them; are holy and the Eternal is among them. So why do you elevate yourselves over the Eternals congregation? His argument was that there was no need for prophets, as the entire congregation are holy and heard HaShem speak to them. Everyone is equal before HaShem, so what was there need for leadership? In the Egyptian exile, the Tribe of Levi studied the Torah (in what form it had in that time) and the rest of the Israelites did their work. Korach seemed to want a continuation of this model (although with himself as the head of the spiritual), instead of having a spiritual leader over the mundane, as implied by HaShem's set-up (for lack of better words).

What was Moshe's reply to Korach's rebuke? Bamidbar 16:5, In the morning, the Eternal will make known those who are for and who are holy, and He will bring near to Himself; and the one He chooses He will bring near to Him. Basically saying, it is HaShem's will we do it this way. Just as clear as the morning, so too HaShem makes His ways known to us. He brings out the sun to provide for the world is there for both the spiritual and mundane. The same sun sees both the service of the Temple and the farmers in the field. HaShem is the same in both cases.

Bamidbar 16:12, Moshe then sent, Rashi expounds this thus, From here, we may learn that one should not persist in strife, for, you see, Moshe sought them out in order to conciliate them by peaceful words (Sanhedrin 110a). Moshe did not have to do this, as he was clearly in the right and Korach's congregation was in the wrong. But one should not allow matters to neither escalate nor fester. Even if we are in the right, like Moshe, we should be like Moshe who sought to conciliate with others by peaceful means.

Bamidbar 16:27, with their wives, children and infants Rashi tells us, Come and see how grievous a sin dissension is; for, you know, an earthly tribunal does not punish a person before he shows sings of puberty, the heavenly tribunal does not punish a person until the age of twenty. And nevertheless, here, even nursing infants were destroyed. (Tanchuma). For we saw by the generation of the Flood, who fought with each other, they were destroyed completely, in their rebellion against HaShem. And yet, the generation of the Tower of Babel also rebelled as the first, and yet, because they worked together in harmony, they were merely spread out. So we also see here, where others rebelled they were punished with regular methods, because of the strife and dissension of Korach and his congregation, they were wiped out completely using a method not before seen or seen.

Bamidbar 17:2, for the firepans have been sanctified Rashi points out, and are therefore forbidden for any profane use, since they have made them into vessels of service. So while Korach and his congregation went too far, there was a spark of Divine there. I do not know if each individual that offered the incense thought he would survive as Aharon did, or took it as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to perform such a sacred service. Our Sages tell us that the individual who took the Yom Kippur goat out to the desert to atone for Israel's sin would not live out the year, and yet, because of the desire to be a part of such an awesome service there were many that applied knowing they would not survive the year. Were the congregates of Korach of such a spirit and mind, I do not know, but I would like to think there was some spark there.

Bamidbar 17:11, And make atonement for them Rashi states, This secret the Angel of Death communicated to him (Moshe) when he went up to heaven to receive the Torah, viz.,that the incense checks the plague as is related in Treatise Shabbos (89a). The Jews had saw nothing but death come from the service of the incense, now, HaShem was showing them that it brought live and atonement. Rather it was the sin of the individual that brought death, not the incense.

Bamidbar 17:24, and each recognized his staff and took [it] Our Sages tells us the praise of the leaders of the Jewish people. Each of the twelve tribal leaders' staff was placed within the Holy of Holies, and Aharon's staff blossomed into almonds. The other tribal leaders could have felt rejected They could have not wanting a reminder of their rejection, forgone their staff and got new ones, as they were all mere wood. But as the demonstration was a commandment of HaShem, and He commanded their participation, they ensured its completion by acknowledging they were not chosen by HaShem and showed others so there would not be any more disputes.

Bamidbar 17:28, Whoever draws near in any way to the Eternals dwelling dies! Will we ever stop dying? the People asked Moshe. What was the reply, Bamidbar 18:1, The Eternal then said to Aharon, you and your sons, and your father's family with you, shall bear the sins concerning the Temple, while you, and your sons with you, shall bear the sins concerning your priesthood. Thus, HaShem appoints the Cohenim and the Leviyim to safeguard the Eternals dwelling. What does this mean? That each of us has a task to perform and no one can exchange their task for another's. We are born for our task, be we Cohen, Levi or Israelite; for us to carry out that task and each task is important and part of the Divine Service.

Bamidbar 18:19, It is an everlasting covenant of salt, Rashi explains to us, This means that He made with Aharon by means of something which is wholesome and lasting and keeps others things wholesome (Siphre). Salt never goes bad, and helps other foods to prevent their going bad as well. The priesthood is likened to salt, as it is the duty of the Cohenim and Leviyim, in the Temple days, to educate themselves and to educate others in other tribes. It was never intended for the Tribe of Levi to have solo possession of the Torah, rather it is an inheritance of all the Children of Israel.

May the day come soonest, when we can once more learn Torah from its Source and the source of heavenly peace bring peace to us and all.

entry.title: Parsha Shelach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jun 12, 2014 / 14 Sivan, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Shelach /
Bamidbar 13:1 15:41
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shelach, which means send.

Rashi asks a question about Bamidbar 13:1, You send men, writing, Why is the section dealing with the spies put in juxtaposition with the section dealing with Miriam? Because she (Miriam) was punished on account of the slander which she uttered against her brother and these sinners witnessed and yet they did not take a lesson (Tanchuma). What is the connection?

Who was Miriam, Miriam was the older sister to Aharon and Moshe, and a Prophetess in her own right. She led the women, the same as Moshe and Aharon led the men. Miriam's slander was based on correctly a slight she thought was occurring, not knowing the unique position and prophecy that Moshe Rabbeinu had, and wanting to correct it. So her slander was meant with the best of intentions, but was still considered slander.

Who were the spies, Bamidbar 13:3, they were all men ( ), which Rashi points out, Wherever men (), is used in Scripture it is a term denoting worthiness. These men, it is true, sinned later but at that time they were worthy men. And, Bamidbar 13:3, the heads of the Children of Israel, there were not mere commoners but leaders of the Jewish nation. So how could such great men, sin? Our Sages tell us that the Spies figured that the spiritual life they lead within the desert was superior to the one that could be led within the Land of Israel, for they say, Bamidbar 13:32, is a land that destroys its inhabitants. They could not conceive how one could lead a spiritual life while engaged within the mundane. Rashi states on this, 'In every place which we passed we found them burying their dead'. But, the Holy One, blessed be He, did this for the best, to keep them (the inhabitants) occupied with their mourning so they should not notice them (the spies). Our Sages tell us that the spies were saying that the Jewish people would be lost within the mundane world, as they could not conceive of merging the spiritual and the mundane.

Bamidbar 13:33, We viewed ourselves like locusts, and so did they view us. Our Sages teaches us a lesson here. How we view ourselves reflects how others view us. The spies said first, viewed ourselves, and then they view us. The world is but a mirror, reflecting ourselves back at us. For how can one view themselves, but through a mirror? Since they thought so lowly of the mundane world around them, they felt lowly. Since they felt lowly, they acted lowly, and others picked up on that. If we feel good, others will notice this and react accordingly, as the saying goes, like attracts like. If we feel down, then others around us will be brought down as well. We must remember what Chassidus teaches us, in each pocket, a person should have two slips of paper. In one pocket, the paper should read, for my sake, the world was created, and in the other pocket, the paper should read, I am but dust and ash. The trick is knowing when to apply which and when. The mundane world was created as it was for HaShem to have a place among us, in the lowliest of places. In both the beginning, the creating of the world, and the end, dust and ash, HaShem is with us and helps to guide us. Because the spies were so down upon themselves, instead of the miracles that HaShem had brought for them to make their job easier, they viewed it negatively, negative for negative. While their intentions were questionable, much as Miriam, like Miriam they did not leave the matter to HaShem to know best. Which seems to be obvious and easy, but that was the case, then neither episode would have occurred.

Bamidbar 14:9, for they are our bread, Rashi explains that this expression means, we shall consume them as bread. What does this mean? That the spies were completely wrong, for they said that they inhabitants and land would destroy them. Yehoshua and Kalev meant that not only would they be easy to conquer, but that they would satisfy and strengthen the people as eating bread fills a person up.

Bamidbar 14:27, this evil group ( ) Rashi points out, This refers to the spies (not to the whole congregation); from here that an a congregation is technically a gathering of at least ten persons (Megillah 23b). From even a bad situation, we can learn something. And because they were a congregation and caused others to sin, so great was their sin.

The Midrash tells us that after the sin of the spies and disaster of the arrogant ones, the moral of the Jewish people was low. For the generation that sinned, feared that their children would sin too. How was this fixed? Bamidbar 15:2, Speak to the Children of Israel and you shall say to them: When you come to your homeland that I am giving you. Thus, HaShem, Himself, promised that the next generation (plus Kalev, Yehoshua, the entire Tribe of Levi, those older than 60 and younger than 20 and all the women) would enter the land. To emphasis this, HaShem told the people about what the people could do, Bamidbar 15:3, you offer a fire-offering for the Eternal, to act as a pleasing aroma so that just as in the desert, offering where brought to the Mishkan, so too, could offerings be brought within the land. Thus the Judaism of the desert, would continue within the Land, despite the spies fear.

Bamidbar 15:15, The congregation there shall be one law for you and for the proselyte who lives [among you]. It is an everlasting statue, throughout your generations, [that] the proselyte be the same as you before the Eternal. In other words, everyone is equal and the same under Jewish law, be they Moshe Rabbeinu or a new converter. Each Jewish soul is precious to HaShem, but a person born to a Jewish mother, or converted out of one's own will.

Bamidbar 15:16, There shall be one Torah and one law, both for you and for the proselyte who lives with you. Not only is a proselyte and offering of Abraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov equal before HaShem, but they are equal before the law and Torah. Each has an equal opportunity to do mitzvahs and be judged the same way, regardless of the matter.

Bamidbar 15:19, it shall be, when you eat bread of the land, you shall separate a select portion for the Eternal. This is called Challah. The Sages tell us many things about this commandment, both that it was reinsurance for the People that the children would enter the land, but also to remind/show the people they are reliant upon HaShem. For everything in the world is His, thus we separate out a portion for HaShem, to recall this, and thank Him for His mercy.

Bamidbar 15:20, As the selected portion from the threshing-floor, Rashi states, for which no quatity is stated, and not as the Terumah of the Tithe for which a quantity is stated (cf 18:26) (Siphre) The Sages, however, have stipulated a quantity for it, for a private person one twenty-fourth, and for the baker one forty-eighth (Siphri; Challah 2:7). While the Torah does not ask for a minimum amount, so one can give as much or as little as one needs to, but the Sages knew that there are those of us that need to starting point, so they stated a minimum amount to use.

Bamidbar 15:39, Remember all HaShem's commandments, Rashi explains, Because the numerical value of is six hundred, and there are eight threads and five knots, so that you have six hundred and thirteen, which is also the number of the commandments of the Torah. Thus we see gematria at play and symbolism used to help us.

Bamidbar 15:41, on the corners of their garments, Rashi expounds this, in allusion to And I carried you on wings of eagle. The Tzitzis are to be placed on a garment having four corners but not on one that has three or one that has five, alluding to the four terms describing the deliverance from Egypt, for it states (Shemos 6:6-7) And I will take you out, and I shall save you, and I shall redeem you, and and I shall take you. For the Tzitzis is also a remind of our redemption, for we were brought out of Egypt for HaShem to be our G-d and to do His commandments.

May we have the strengthen of Kalev and Yehoshua to separate ourselves from those that fail to see the G-dliness in the mundane and think they know better than HaShem. Just as the generation of Egyptian exile sinned but were kept by HaShem, so too, we shall be redeemed as well. As it was, so shall it be again. May we see our redemption soonest, and HaShem once more fulfill the verse, And I will take you out, and I shall save you, and I shall redeem you, and I shall take you. Take us out of this exile, save us even from ourselves, redeem us for Your sake and the sake of those that came before us, and take us as a people as in the days of old.

entry.title: Parsha Bamidbar
entry.content:
''
Thu, May 22, 2014 / 22 Iyyar, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Bamidbar /
Bamidbar 1:1 4:20
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bamidbar, the first Parsha of Sefer Bamidbar, which is the fourth of the Five Books of Moses. We had just finished Sefer Vayikra, which dealt larger with the Spiritual and the Service of the Holy Temple. From there, we go into Parsha Bamidbar, which starts off, Bamidbar 1:1, And the Eternal spoke in the Sinai desert... on the first of the second month, Rashi states, Because they were dear to Him, He counts them every now and then: when they went departed from Egypt He counted them (Shemos 12:37), when of them fell in He counted them to ascertain the number of those left (cf. Rashi ib. 30:16); when He was about to make His Shechinah dwell amongst them (i.e. when He commanded them to make a Tabernacle), He took their census; on the first day of Nissan the Tabernacle was erected (ib XL. 2) and on the first day of Iyyar, He counted them.

So Sefer Bamidbar is a continuation of Sefer Vayikra, and yet, one thinks of a desert, one does not link it to the divine service that was talked about in th Sefer Vayikra. How is this? I have not heard of this, but I feel the following: after learning of the divine service in Sefer Vayikra, then what? Then, we can go into the desert, which seems empty and abandoned, and still perform the service to HaShem. How? Because HaShem is with you and we are very dear to Him.

One might think that they must adapt to their environment to survive, but comes the Torah and says, even in the empty desert, where one would think they would need to everything they could to just survive, one is not alone, for HaShem is with us, for we are dear to Him. Whether we are, we are there because it is part of the Divine Plan, and HaShem is there for us.

The desert is useless and so owner-less and yet that very same desert, HaShem gave His Torah to the descendants. Teaching us that even the lowest and least of the world, a desert, can be elevated by the Divine Service that was instructed in Sefer Vayikra and within Sefer Bamidbar as well.

It is in the desert of Sinai, Bamidbar 1:2, Calculate the total number of the entire community of the Children of Israel, by their family, following their father's lineage; [...] It was here, that the Children of Israel entered fully into the service of HaShem, as their G-d and King.

Bamidbar 1:49, However, the Tribe of Levi you must not count Rashi points out on this verse, The legion of the King deserves to be counted on its own (Tanchuma). Another explanation: The Holy One, Blessed be He, foresaw that a decree was destined to be enacted against all those counted from twenty years and upward to die in the desert (14:29). He therefore said: Let theses not be included, because they are Mine, since they did not sin by worshiping the golden calf. (cf Tanchuma; Bava Basra 121b). Those dedicated their entire lives to HaShem were not counted as the others were, for they were near still to HaShem, and known to Him, which they others could see.

Bamidbar 2:9, They shall travel first, Rashi expounds, When they saw the cloud departing, the priests blew the trumpets and the camp of Yehudah moved off first, but when marching, they marched retaining the positions in which they encamped: the Levities and the wagons in the center, the division of Judah in the East, that of Reuven in the South, Ephraim's in the West and Dan's in the North. In other words, they moved in formation and formally, like an army. Everything in its place, a place for everything.

Bamidbar 3:1, And these are the descendants of Aharon and Moshe Rashi points out, But it mentions only the sons of Aharon! But they are called the sons of Moshe because he taught them Torah. This tells us that whoever teaches the Torah to the son of his fellow man Scripture regards it to him as though he had fathered him (Sanhedrin 19b). Just as a son reflects upon a father, so too, a student reflects upon a teacher. We see this with Moshe and Yehoshua and among the Sages.

Bamidbar 3:29, The families of the sons of Kehas would camp along the south, Rashi states, and next to them was the division of Reuven who, too, were encamped in the south Woe to the wicked, woe to his neighbor! It was on this account that some of them Dathan and Aviram and together with Korach and his congregation, because they were dragged into the quarrel with them (cf. Tanch).

Bamidbar 3:38, Moshe, and Aharon and his sons, Rashi also states, and adjacent to him was the division of Yehudah, and next to the later were encamped Yissachar and Zevulun It is good for the righteous, and it is good for his neighbor! Because they were neighbors of Moshe who occupied himself with Torah, they themselves became eminent scholars in the Law, as it said, (Tehillim 60:9) and of the child of Yissachar which were men that had understanding of the times to know what Israel had to do i.e. two hundred heads of the Sanhedrin; (Melachim 5:14) and out of Zevulun came those that handle the pen of the writer (Tanch).

Thus we see we have affect upon our neighbors, for good, if we are good, for bad, if we are not. And of course, they upon us.

May we all have a positive affect upon ourselves and upon our neighbors, so the verse from this week's Parsha, It is good for the righteous, and it is good for his neighbor! be applied to us. And the ultimate in righteous and goodness for our neighbor shall come with Mashiach, when we once again can form ourselves under the divine banners and the world will be filled with HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Bechukotai
entry.content:
''
Thu, May 15, 2014 / 15 Iyyar, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Bechukotai /
Vayikra 26:3 27:34
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bechukotai, which is the last Parsha in the Sefer Vayikra. That means at the end of the Parsha, we say, Chazak! Chazak! V'nitchazek! (! ! ) which means, Be strong! Be strong! May we be strengthen! Each Sefer of the Torah is precious, something to treasure and hold unto, something to fight for. The Torah is our heritage, which has allowed the Jewish nation to survive and thrive while other nations have perished.

And how are we strengthen? By studying the Torah, as this week's Parsha states, Vayikra 26:3, If you pursue My statues, which Rashi comments, One might think that this denotes the fulfillment of the commandments; but when Scripture states and [thereby] keep My commandments and do them, it is plain that in this passage there is mentioned the fulfillment of the commandments. How then must I explain If you pursue My statues? As an admonition that you should study the Torah laboriously (Siphra) The purpose of this world is to carry out the Divine Will, but in order to do so, we need to study the Torah to learn what the Divine Will is. Only through study of the Torah, and we act upon the Torah, to fulfill the Divine Will in this world.

If studying the Torah is the beginning of the Parsha, what is the end of the Parsha? What does the Sefer Vayikra send us off with, Vayikra 27:34, These are the commandments that the Eternal commanded Moshe at Mount Sinai for the Children of Israel. Why should we pursue the commandments, because as stated, they are the words of the Eternal, as He exists, so too does His words still exist. We must remember that there was but One voice and One source, and that voice spoke from and is forever.

Vayikra 26:6, I will grant peace in the land, Rashi remarks, Perhaps you will say, Well, there is food and there is drink; but if there is no peace, then all this is nothing! Scripture therefore states after these promises I will grant [you] peace in the land. Hence we may learn that peace counterbalances everything. In a similar sense it states: Who makes peace and creates all things (Yishayah 45:7) In a sense, the goal of Creation, is to make peace with Heaven and Earth. Many, in their own way, have tried to make peace on Earth, but because it was made by human hands, it was finite and fleeting. But peace made by He who created peace that is a blessing and something that is literally divine.

Vayikra 26:11, I will put my dwelling [among you], Rashi explains, This means the Temple at Jerusalem (Siphra; Eruvin 2a). In listing the blessing one receives for doing the will of HaShem, the Temple is among the last, and those among the most important. For through the Temple, we had a place to and connect directly with HaShem.

Notice the order, Vayikra 26:14, do not carry out all these commandments, then Vayikra 26:15, you then despise [those who observe] My statues and utterly reject [those who interpret] My laws, [such that you] prevent all My commandments from being carried out. As a cause of not carrying out, one then despises, then rejects, and then prevents others from doing so. When one is in a downward spiral, there are only two directions to go; up or down. If one rejects up towards the Divine, one is left only to go furtherer and furtherer away, like a black hole, dragging in others behind you. Just as blessing spread around you, so too does one's folly.

Vayikra 26:23, you are not subdued before Me, how can we avoid that which the Torah states will happen (and has happened), if one does not follow the Way of HaShem? By repenting, for no matter how far a Jew falls, s/he is still a Jew and HaShem still loves them. Our Sages say, hate not the sinner, but the sin. In our heart of hearts, a Jew is near and dear to HaShem, and He to us. While we can see the curses as punishment, they can also be seen as ways back to HaShem, if we just realize that HaShem wants us back and is trying to direct us back to Him. When we distance ourselves from Him, it is only on our part, HaShem is still with us. Rather, we and only ourselves, have placed things in between us and HaShem to say that, but for HaShem is with us and within us. HaShem is out there with the distant most star in the sky, and yet, closer than the very breath we take to live. By distancing ourselves from HaShem, we fall further into the mundane entropy that exists to challenge us. The more entropy in our lives, the worse our lives are, for that is the nature of entropy. So how do we avoid entropy, by cling to the Divine, transcending beyond entropy and the very nature of limitation.

Vayikra 26:32, I will make the land desolate, Rashi points out HaShem's mercy, This was a kindly measure for Israel that the enemies would find no satisfaction in their (the Israelites) land and so it would become desolate of its inhabitants (of their enemies also, and Israel might again easily take possession of it) (Siphra). For all in HaShem's doing, there are Justice, Truth, and Loving-Kindness. One should ask of the Chassidic teachings of this Parsha to learn more of HaShem's mercy and loving-kindness.

Chassidic teaching of Vayikra 26:33 that I heard, and you I will scatter among the nations, while this too is a harsh measure, it too is a blessing in disguise. For by scattering us among the nations, none can destroy us, for one attacks one segment in one place, other segments can escape elsewhere. When Europe was aflame, Jews in Asia and America were relatively safe and Jews that could (and did) have somewhere else to go. Throughout history, where one door closed for the Jews, another would open, ready and waiting for us. For even when HaShem is harsh with us, His promise to our fore-father Abraham remains, Those whom bless you, I will bless. Those that curse you, I will curse. as is said regards to the Jews expulsion from Spain in 1492, Sultan Bajazet welcomed them warmly. How can you call Ferdinand of Aragon a wise king, he was fond of asking, the same Ferdinand who impoverished his own land and enriched ours?

HaShem promises us, Vayikra 26:41-42, (41) [...] If then, their stubborn hears is humbled and they then gain appeasement for their transgression, (42) I will recall My covenant with Ya'akov, and also My covenant with Yitzchak, and I will even recall My covenant with Abraham and take account of the land. For our current exile is not eternal, but just waiting for the right conditions to occur, the repentance of our people. And if that is not enough, HaShem will add the merits of our Fore-Fathers, and if that is not enough, HaShem will recall the purpose of the Land of Israel.

HaShem even says, Vayikra 26:44, And even though [I will bring upon them] these [calamities] when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not have despised them nor rejected them to completely destroy them [or] to annul My covenant with them, for I am the Eternal, their G-d. For these are the words we live by, the hope and desire of when the righteous Mashiach will come to fully redeem us, and we will once again be a People and HaShem will be our G-d. As HaShem is forever, His people are forever and forevermore His people. Nothing can change that.

Having seen all the promises and blessing that HaShem has in store for us, one decides to dedicate something or part of something to HaShem to express, is also among the commandments as Chapter 27, which talks of such dedications, ends, Vayikra 27:34, These are the commandments that the Eternal commanded Moshe at Mount Sinai for the Children of Israel.
With all the troubles and entropy in the world, may we be humbled in a loving-kind way and not through harshness. May all the suffering we and our parents have endured, with the covenant of our fore-fathers and fore-mothers, and the Land of Israel itself, may it all be in merit to bring Mashiach and the final redemption to us, today, now. May we be strengthen by HaShem's promise of the final redemption and may it be speedily in our day that we may once more be seen to HaShem's people and that HaShem is our G-d.
