Parsha Behar /
Vayikra 25:1 26:2
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Behar. Rashi writes about the Torah stating, Vayikra 25:1, Mount Sinai, saying, What does the subject of Shemittah have with Mount Sinai? Weren't all the commandments states from Sinai? But this statement is intended to suggest the following comparison: How is it in the case of the law of Shemittah? Its general rules, and minute details on Mount Sinai! So, too, were all commandments with their general rules and their minute details ordained on Mount Sinai. This is what is taught in Toras Kohanim (25:1). It seems to me that the following is the explanation of Moab in Devarim, we learn that its general principles, finer details, and explanations but Scripture states this here to teach us that, every statement that was conveyed to Moses came from Sinai, their general principles and finer details and repeated and reviewed on the plains of Moab.

entry.title: Parsha Kedoshim
entry.content:
''
Thu, Apr 24, 2014 / 24 Nissan, 5774 / '' ''

Parsha Kedoshim /
Vayikra 19:1 20:27
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Kedoshim. Kedoshim means holy, as the Parsha has, Vayikra 19:2, You shall be holy, for I, the Eternal your G-d, am holy. Rashi comments on the phrase, You shall be holy, stating, keep aloof from the forbidden sexual relations and from sinful thoughts. Because wherever you find in the Torah a command to fence yourself in against such relations you also find mention of holiness. (Vayikra 21:7) [They shall not take] a wife that is a harlot, or a profane etc., and in the next verse for I, the Lord, who sanctified you, [am holy]; (ib v. 15) Neither shall he profane his seed for I the Lord do sanctify him; (ib v. 6) They shall be holy followed by (v. 7) [they shall not take] a wife that is a harlot or a profane (cf. Vayikra Rabba 24). So we see that there is a concept of separation that sanctifies something that makes it holy. We also see that holiness and spirituality is not always obvious to a mundane observance, we need insight that HaShem provides us to understand.

Vayikra 19:10, I am the Eternal, your G-d Rashi states, the Judge Who punish and will exact from you nothing less than your souls, as it said (Mishlie 22:22, 23), Do not rob a poor man... for the Lord will plead their cause, and rob those who rob them, of life (Siphra). Why such a severe punishment for action against the poor and the proselyte? Because they have been separated by HaShem, and they have no other but He. An evil person might think since they are alone, they can be victimize. Comes the Torah and warns this evil person that HaShem, Himself, will side with them. And if such people as the poor and the proselyte have none but HaShem, then others, our fellow Jews should involve themselves with each other.

Vayikra 19:14, You must not curse [even] a deaf person, Rashi comments, I know only that one may not curse a deaf person. But from where do I that know that this prohibition includes cursing any person even if he is not deaf? Therefore, Scripture says, You shall not curse.... among your people (Shemos 22:27). But if this is so that this law is not exclusive to deaf people, why does it say here, a deaf person? The answer is that just as a deaf is special insofar as he is alive, likewise, one is prohibited from cursing anyone who is alive. This excludes cursing a dead person, for he is not alive. (Siphra; cf also Sanhedrin 66a). Torah goes out of its way to say not to curse someone that would not be bothered by the action of another, for the deaf would not hear the curse being said. It is not the deaf person that is being harmed, but the one who curses that is. How often the materialism of today is justified by saying, I am not hurting anyone etc.. Comes the Torah and tells us that we are hurting someone, ourselves. Because we neglect or reject our foundation, how much has crumbled with just an attitude.

Vayikra 19:14, Nor put a stumbling block before an undiscerning person. Rashi explains, This implies: Before a person who is blind regarding a matter, you shall not give advice that is improper for him. Do not say to him: Sell your field and buy from the proceeds of the sale a donkey, the fact that being that you are endeavoring to circumvent him and to take it (the field) from him (Siphra). In other words, we should not lead another astray for our own benefit. HaShem knows our heart, and what we intended, so while an Earthly court cannot handle this matter, the Heavenly court will.

entry.title: Parsha Emor
entry.content:
''
Thu, May 1, 2014 / 1 Iyyar, 5774 / ' ''

Parsha Emor /
Vayikra 21:1 24:23
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Emor.

The Hebrew word, Emor () means say as the opening verse says, Vayikra 21:1, The Eternal said to Moshe, Say to the priests, the sons of Aharon; you shall say [...] Rashi comments on this, 'Say' and again 'You shall say to' this repetition is intended to admonish the adults about their children also that they should teach them to avoid defilement (Yevamot 114a). In other words, Rashi is saying that the Torah is saying, not only are the adults to be educated but the children as well. While it is not practical for the children, as they will not perform the service, it is still relevant that a child should know. For it is through education of our children that traditions and understanding are passed on.

Rashi states that Vayikra 21:2, except for his [closest] relative, means denotes his wife (Siphra; Yevamot 22b), which, of course, a child does not have. But an educated child is an enlighten adult, who can fully function in society and prepare for what is expected of them. As a son of Aharon, I remember very fondly being under my Father's tallit () when he gave the Priestly Blessing ( ) and from him and this, I learned how his father, my grandfather, and he learned from his father, so on, performed this ancient and awe blessing that is mentioned in the Torah. And some day, I pray, I will be able to have a son, and teach him as I was taught. A tradition that literally spans the generations to generations, and the importance that laws and traditions are passed on, not by memorization but by doing, by example, and by participating in. Thus the Birkat Cohenim is not some ancient custom or bizarre ritual, but something living and something I share with my father, as he shared with his, and so on, connecting us all. As it is said, one does not truly understand something until one can teach it to others.

Vayikra 21:6, They shall be sanctified for their G-d and must not profane the Name of their G-d, for they offer up the fire-offering of the Eternal, the food of their G-d; and they will be holy. And thus, we, Cohenim, have special/additional rules to follow to fulfill the commandments of HaShem, for as descendents of Aharon the Cohen, we reflect upon HaShem and His service. Although the Holy Temple is not yet restored to us, it is simply a matter of time until it is, and we need to be ready for it. Rashi points out that when the Torah says, they shall be sanctified, it means, even against their will the court shall force them to remain holy in respect tothis (Siphra).

Vayikra 21:8, You are to regard him as sanctified, Rashi expounds this, treat him with sanctity (as someone holy) that he should be the first in all holy matters (e.g. the reading of the Torah) and that he should have the first right to recite the benedictions at a meal ( and ) (cf. Rashi on Nedarim 62b). For in honoring the Cohen, one honor's He that chose him to perform His service.

Inversely, Vayikra 21:9, She disgraces her father, Rashi explains, by her conduct she has desecrated and degraded his honor, in that people say about him, Cursed be he who has engendered this woman cursed be he who has reared this woman (Sanhedrin 52a). For our children reflect upon us, for if we protected them and guided them properly such a disgrace would not happen.

Vayikra 22:9, [The Priests] shall safeguard My restrictions, [so that they do] incur sin through [the holy foods] and thereby die because they desecrated [them]; I am the Eternal Who sanctified them. And how does the Cohenim safeguard HaShem's restrictions? By teach them to their children, ensuring they know it, in order to teach, and to ensure it is passed on, by teaching it to their children, the next generation. And why should we still do this, in this day and age? Because HaShem is the One who sanctified them. Just as HaShem still exists, so too the Cohen's sanctity still exists, for the sanctification is not from the Cohen, but from HaShem, Himself.

And how would one know if a Cohen is sanctified or not, Rashi expounds this, Vayikra 22:9, And thereby die, teaches us that this means death through Heaven (not through the sentence of the [earthly] court) (cf. Sanhedrin 83a.) For it is HaShem, Himself, that knows and will judge us accordingly.

Vayikra 22:27-28, (27)When an ox, a sheep or a goat is born, it shall remain with its mother for seven days, and from the eighth day onwards it will be acceptable as a fire-offering for the Eternal. (28) And an ox or sheep it and its child you must not slaughter on the same day. I have heard that these laws are to teach us to be humane. In my own heart, I feel that also teaches us importance of parenting and the Shabbat () as one Shabbat would fall within those seven days.

Vayikra 23:2, Speak to the children of Israel... the Eternals periodic occasions, Rashi states this means, regulate the festive seasons that all Israel should become practiced in them (their observance). Hence we derive the law that they (the Sanhedrin) proclaim a leap-year for the sake of the diaspora who have already left their homes in order to go up for the festival but have not yet arrived in Jerusalem (Siphra; cd. Sanhedrin 11a). It is the Sanhedrin's job to ensure that Pesach is in the spring and when the New Moon, Rosh Chodesh is.

Vayikra 23:3, Six days work may be done Rashi asks a question, What relation is there between the Shabbos (the day that is invariably fixed by HaShem as the holy day) and the festive seasons (the times of which are variable, being dependent upon the proclamation of the Sanhedrin)? But by pulling both into juxtaposition Scripture intends to teach you that he who desecrates the festivals is regarded as though he had desecrated the Shabbos, and that he who keeps the festivals is regarded as though he has kept the Shabbos (Siphra). Thus we see a linkage between the fixed Shabbos and the variable festive seasons. One is declared by HaShem, Himself, and the other is declared by the Sanhedrin, one might think that the level of holiness between the two would be different, given their source, but comes the Torah and teaches us that is not so. For it was HaShem, Himself, that declared that the Sanhedrin would decided when the festive seasons would be. There is a story, and I only recall parts of it, but it was said that the Heavenly Court knew that Rosh HaShanah was on that day and thus began the judgment and recounting of everyone, but for reason that I forgot, the Sanhedrin decreed that Rosh HaShanah would be on the following day, thus the Heavenly Court stopped what it was doing, and began anew upon the Sanhedrin's established day. One would know that the Heavenly Court knows absolutely, but HaShem gave it to the Sanhedrin to decide when the festive seasons would be, so the Heavenly Court follows the Sanhedrin's ruling.

Vayikra 24:11, of the tribe of Dan, Rashi points out, This mention also of the parent and the tribe of the woman teaches us that the wrong doer brings shame upon himself, shame upon his parents, shame upon his whole tribe. Similarly we find the name of the tribe Dan mentioned to express praise: (Shemos 31:6) Oholiav, the son of Achisamach; of the tribe of Dan, where the details of Oholiav's descent imply praise for him, praise for his father and praise for his tribe (Siphra). For what we do, for good or ill, reflects upon us, upon our parents (who taught us), and our ancestors (who taught our parents). No one lives in a vacuum. We learn from our parents, where our parents meant for us to teach that or not.

Vayikra 24:15, he shall bear (the consequences) of his sin, Rashi says, shall be punished with excision if there was no legal warning preceding the offence (Siphra; cf Rashi on 20:27). In other words, if justice cannot be carried out by the Earthly Court, then the Heavenly Court will step in to ensure that justice is done.

Vayikra 24:20, so shall be imposed upon him, Rashi expounds this thus, Our Rabbis explained that this does not mean the actual infliction of a blemish but that it means monetary compensation that we estimate his (the injured man's) value as a slave and the offender has to pay the difference between his value as an unmarried man and that which he represents after the infliction of the injury. It is for this reason that the term to give is written here referring to something that is given (passed) from hand to hand viz. money (Kesubos 32b; Bava Kama 84a). I do recommend reading up on the Sages' explanation for why an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, etc. is not meant to be taken as inflicting such upon another, but that the money compensation should make the injury itself and not something else.

Vayikra 24:22, You shall have one law, with proselytes being the same as natives, for I am the Eternal, the G-d of you [all]. In other words, we are all the same under the law, as Rashi comments, the G-d of all of you. Just as I attach My Name to you, so do I attach it to the strangers. Just as we are the children of HaShem, so too are others, and those that join us, are equal under the law, for HaShem, is G-d of all of us.

May the day come soonest when we all will realize that HaShem is the G-d of us all as it was said, Zechariah 14:9, And HaShem shall be king over the entire earth, on that day HaShem will be One and His name one. May this prophecy and promise be fulfilled with the coming of Mashiach speedily in our day.

entry.title: Parsha Metzora
entry.content:
''
Thu, Apr 3, 2014 / 3 Nissan, 5774 / ' ''

Parsha Metzora /
Vayikra 14:1 15:33
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Metzora, this Parsha deals with the curing of Metzora, which a form of , which was introduced in the previous Parsha. The cure Scripture tells us involves a ritual with Vayikra 14:4, [...] two pure living birds, a piece of cedar wood, a thread of scarlet [wool] and [a bunch of] hyssop. Why these?

Rashi states about pure; excludes an unclean bird (cf. Chullin 140a). Because the plagues comes as a punishment for slander, which is done by chattering, therefore birds are compulsory for his purification, because these chatter, continuously with a twittering sound (Arachin 16b).

Rashi relates about the cedar wood, saying, This lofty tree was used because plagues come also as punishment for haughtiness (cf. ib.).

Rashi explains a thread of scarlet (wool) and (a bunch of) hyssop ( ), What is the remedy he should use, that he may be healed? Let him, abandoning pride, regard himself lowly as a worm () and as hyssop (cf. Yalkut 1:559). Hyssop is considered a lowly plant.

The cedar stick, thread of scarlet and hyssop, as Rashi tells us, is Scripture's way of saying, not be so prideful as the cedar but as humble as hyssop. The two birds represents one's choice, one could continue with their slander and die as the bird that is sacrificed, or they can stop and live as the bird that is released.

Vayikra 14:6 spring water ( ) literally water of life, this too is symbolic, for Torah is called living water. Such as a person cannot go without water for too long, so too we need Torah to live. Also, as water cleanse, so too does Torah.

Vayikra 14:34, and I put a Tzara'as mark, Rashi states, This was an announcement to them that these plagues would come upon them (Siphra; Horiyos 10a), because the Amorites concealed treasures of gold in the walls of their houses during the whole 40 years the Israelites were in the wilderness, and in consequence of the plague they would pull down the house and discover them (Vayikra Rabba 17). Thus we learn that something seemingly bad, this plagues, out of it comes something good, treasure of gold. There is a bit of a hidden rebuke here, in that, had the Jews not sin with the Spies, such an indirect method would not have been needed. Because of the sin of the Spies, the Jews were held within the Desert for 40 years, thus giving time for the Amorites to conceal their treasures, hoping that the Jews would be expelled as they were, thus allowing them to reclaim their treasures. Comes the Torah and shows that the Land of Israel is unique among all the lands of the world. All other lands ownership come be changed by occupation or warfare, but the Holy Land, because it's holy, is different, as it has been elevated beyond the mundane and into the spiritual. The entire world belongs to HaShem, but He allows various nations of the world to settle as they wish. But come the Land of Israel, there the Owner of the World decrees that this land is to be a place for Jews to serve Him and His Torah.

Vayikra 14:35, There appears to me to be [something] like a [Tzara'as] mark on [my] house, Rashi explains, Even if he [the owner of the house) is a learned man and knows for sure that it is a plague he shall not decide the matter as certainty saying, There [is] a [Tzara'as] mark on [my] house. but There appears to me to be [something] like a [Tzara'as] mark on [my] house. (Negaim 12:5; Siphra). This comes to teach us that there is a purely spiritual situation here. If it was a mere physical plague, then it should be acted upon quickly and anyone that knows, being he a specialist or just someone informed, could handle the situation, but because it is solely spiritual, it must be handled by the Cohen, even if the Cohen needs to seek the counsel of a learned man. We all have a niche in life, and we should respect that.

Vayikra 14:36, Before the priest comes, Rashi teaches, For so long as the priest has not yet engaged himself with it, no law of uncleanness is applicable there. Again, pointing towards spiritual, not mundane plague.

entry.title: Parsha Tazria + Parsha HaChodesh
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 27, 2014 / 25 Adar II, 5774 / '' ' ''

Parsha Tazria /
Vayikra 12:1 13:59
Parsha HaChodesh /
Shemos 12:1 12:20
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Tazria, and this also Shabbos HaChodesh, the Shabbos before the Month of Nissan begins.

Vayikra 12:2, If a woman conceives, Rashi points out, Rabbi Simlia said: Just as the formation of man took place after that of every cattle, beast and bird when the world was created, so, too law [concerning the cleanness], regarding him is set forth after the law [concerning the cleanness] regarding cattle, beast and bird (Vayikra Rabbah 14). Thus the Torah reminds us that we, humans, were last of Creation, even the lowly gnat came before us, and yet, the world was all prepared and ready for us as well. Also with the animals, the Torah speaks of the animal and no more, of humans, the Torah talks of birth and death, and what is in-between.

Vayikra 12:5, If she gives birth to a female child, she will be impure for two weeks, but Torah says for a male child only one week (seven days). Why is this? I do not have the definite answer, but I have heard it said that here we see the mother taking on her own impurity but also that of her daughter's, thus a mother does for herself and for her daughter, doubling her time; another I have heard, is that originally for a son, a mother would need to go two weeks as well, but in order for the mother to be present for the bris of her son, the Torah made an exception.

Vayikra 12:6, [...], and a young dove or a turtledove as a sin-offering [...] Why does a mother, regardless of the gender of the child, need to bring a sin-offering for giving birth? I have heard two answers to this: the first, is for any swearing or oaths the mother may have said in the pang of labor pain, the second, is in part because of Eve's sin in the Garden of Eden.

Vayikra 13:2, to Aharon, Rashi states, It is a scriptural decree that the uncleanness and purification of the leprous plagues are pronounced only by the mouth of a priest (Siphra). Thus, we learn two things from here. One that leprous is not a good translation of as one needs to wait upon a Cohen and only a Cohen to pronounce about , as if it was a true natural disease one should treat it immediate. Two, by stressing Aharon, we look towards his attribute, which was peace/harmony. So in dealing with one must have both peace of his fellow and peace between HaShem and man in mind.

Vayikra 13:13, the priest shall look, and the Tzara'as has covered [the person's] entire flesh he shall be declared the mark as pure. How can this be? A mere spot, makes him impure, and yet, everything is pure? According to Chassidus, this can be taken two ways; it can be taken negatively that such a person is so far gone that has no meaning anymore; or it can be taken positively that the has been taken in fully driving the person to full repentance.

Vayikra 13:46, He shall live alone, Rashi expounds this thus, This means that people who are unclean from other causes than that of shall not abide with him (Pesachim 67a; cf Siphra). Our abbis said: Why is he (the suffer of ) treated differently from other unclean persons that he should abide solitary? They replied: Because he, by slanderous statements, parted man and wife, or a man from his friend, he must be parted from everybody (Arachin 16b). Such is the danger of that such a specific and obvious consequences are given to it.

Vayikra 13:47, And if a garment, while the Torah first speaks of upon a person, then upon his garments, then upon his house. In practice, HaShem in His mercy, began with his house, if the lesson was not taken, it came upon his garment, if he still did not heed the lesson. Then he found himself with . And it is for all, be it upon a human being, a garment, or a house; for it was a spiritual ailment.

Shemos 12:2, This [moon's] renewal will signal the beginning of every new month. Why the moon to start the Jewish month? I have heard two ideas upon this: one, the Egyptians were sun-worships to distinguish us from them, HaShem had us look to the Moon and not the Sun, and two, just as the Moon renews itself, peeking out a bit, showing its full face and then disappearing, waxing and waning, so too, the Jewish people, rise and fall, but remain as the Moon itself does. Just as no nation has the power to truly affect the Moon, so too, no nation can truly affect the Jewish people. It should be noted that this is very first commandment directly specifically to the Jewish nation, and to the nation as whole.

Shemos 12:3, let each one take a lamb for each parental home, a lamb for each household This is the second commandment and it's directed towards the family. For after the nation, comes the family. For just as important is the nation as a whole, it is still a family that makes it up and is acknowledged as important.

Shemos 12:10, And you shall not leave over any of it until morning, and whatever is left over of it until morning, you shall burn in fire. We need to remember, to give it our all and leave nothing behind when we serve HaShem. And if there is something behind, that too can be give/dedicated to HaShem, through fire/passion.

Shemos 12:13, And the blood will be for you for a sign upon the houses, does HaShem need a sign? No, rather, this is a sign of our commitment to HaShem, for back then they lack any merit, but they were redeemed for the merit of the Pesach offering and following HaShem's commandment of placing blood upon door-post.

As it was once, so we are again, in exile. As our fore-parents were told of their redemption by Ya'akov Avinu, so our Prophets have told us our redemption through Mashiach. As we read of our fore-parents' redemption, may we join them in our own redemption. May we once more give the Pesach-offering in Jerusalem and rejoice with our family. The month of redemption, Nissan, is upon us, may we be redeemed speedily now, for we have waited long enough. May the Source of Peace bring peace to His children.

entry.title: Parsha Shemini
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 20, 2014 / 18 Adar II, 5774 / '' ' ''

Parsha Shemini /
Vayikra 9:1 11:47
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemini, which translates to eighth, Vayikra 9:1, It was on the eighth day, as Rashi states, of the inauguration (cf. Siphra); this was the New Moon of Nisan on which the Tebarnacle was erected and it (that day) received ten crowns where are enumerated in Seder Olam (Ch 7; Siphra; Shabbos 37b). What is there about the number eight? In Kabbalah, the number seven, as in seven days of Creation, is a complete set, thus, eight is one more than complete, in other words, something supernatural, beyond nature. Thus, this entire Parsha is something beyond nature, in which the first day of the actual service was performed within the Mishkan and laws were shared with the Jewish people.

Vayikra 9:23, Moshe and Aharon then entered the Time of Meeting and they came out and blessed the people, and the Glory of the Eternal was then revealed to the people. Aharon had spent the entire day performing offerings and even giving the people a blessing, and yet, the Glory of HaShem was not revealed, it was only after Moshe and Aharon prayed and blessed the people, that the Shechinah was revealed to the people. Aharon did all that HaShem had commanded through Moshe, but it was not enough. Rather, Moshe and Aharon, on their own, prayed on behalf of the people, and only then did HaShem revealed Himself. There is a lesson here, one can do the utmost for themselves, but not easily see Heaven's favor, but when they work behalf of the people, then Heaven's favor can be seen.

Vayikra 10:2, A fire came out from before the Eternal the fire that took Nadav and Avihu was the same fire that accepted the offerings of the Mishkan. Also note that the fire came from before HaShem, the four-letter name, denoting Divine Mercy and Transcendence. It was not the Divine Attribute of Judgment as denoted by Elokim that consumed them but that of Mercy. Our Sages say that Nadav and Avihu wished to be united with HaShem, which is the bases of why they did what they did. The issue was that they had reached such a height of spirituality, the mundane held no restraint so they were consumed as a match within the flame of a candle is.

Vayikra 10:3, And Aharon remained silent Rashi expounds this thus, He received a reward for this silence. And what was the reward he received? That the address was made to him alone for to him alone was spoken the section [v 9 11) dealing with those who are intoxicated by win (see v 8) (Zevachim 115b; Vayikra Rabbah 12). Why was Aharon silent? Or why should have Aharon made a sound? Because his sons were consumed by a Heavenly fire. So why was his silent? Because Moshe's words to him comforted him and he accepted fully what had happened as divine. That in such a tragic situation, one could fit such comfort... if only we all could find such comfort and acceptance as Aharon did. Aharon understood the desire to be so close to HaShem and the temptation to leave the mundane behind, for his sons got that desire from him. We must remember that HaShem created this world for a reason and that reason is for HaShem to dwell among us in the lowest realms were godliness seems impossible yet with HaShem's help does happen. Spirituality in the upper realms is relative easy. It is a true miracle and effort to put Spirituality into the mundane 

Vayikra 10:5, "By their shirts" Rashi points out, "of the dead (not of their own garments). This tells us that their garments had not been destroyed by fire, but their souls alone (neither their clothing nor bodies showed signs of burning; they had been struck by fire inwardly): there entered into their nostrils something like two threads of fire which burnt them to death (Siphra; Sanhedrin 52a)." That their bodies were preserved and unmarked, we can learn that what they did while not correct was not completely wrong either.

Vayikra 10:16, "[He became angry] with El'azar and Isamar", Rashi tells us, "Out of respect to Aaron he turned towards his sons and showed himself angry with them of with Aaron (Siphra)." From here, we should learn that we should have some control over our emotions so that we are not carried away with them that we disrespect people around us, and also that respecting others is so important.

Vayikra 10:19, "Aharon then spoke", Rashi says, "The term 'saying' denotes a hard utteranc, as it is said (Bamidbar 21:5) 'And the people spoke against Moses, etc.' -- Is it likely that when Moses expressed his indignation with Elazar and with Isamar, Aaron should reply to him in such hard language? You must consequently know (conclude) that it was only by way of respect that these remained silent. They thought, "It would not be right that our father (Aaron) should be sitting  here (be present) and that we should speak in his presence, nor would it be right that a disciple should retort on his teacher (Moses)". You might think, however, that Elazar did not possess the ability to reply, and that on this account he was silent. This is not so for it is stated (Bamidbar 31:21) "And Elazar the priest spoke to the men of the army, etc." -- and so when he wished he did speak in the presence of Moses and in the presence of the princes (cf. ib v 13). This I found in the (see Yalkut 1:185)." This shows one should have respect for one's parents and teachers.

Vayikra 10:20, "[Moshe listened] and approved" Rashi states, "He admitted his error and was not ashamed to do so, saying, instead of admitting it, "I have not heard." (Siphra; Zevachim 101b)." How great are our Jewish leaders that they are willing to listen to others and accept that they made a mistake.

Vayikra 11:2, "This is the living creature", Rashi expounds this thus, "an expression denoting life: because Israel cleave to the Omnipresent and therefore deserves to remain in life. He therefore separated them from what is unclean, and imposed commandments upon them, while the nations of the world who do not cleave to Hum prohibited nothing. A parable! A physician who goes to visit a sick person: as nay be found in the Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma." The full parable is: "a physician who goes to a visit a sick person, who is incurable he permits to eat whatever he chooses, while to a patient who may recover he gives directions as to what he may eat and may not eat." The ultimate reason is HaShem's will, but we see some of HaShem's intention was to separate and holy the Jewish people from the entire of the world. That the first teaching of kushruit is given in Parsha Shmini, shows the supernational characteristic of keeping kosher.

entry.title: Parsha Tzav-Zachor
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 13, 2014 / 11 Adar II, 5774 / '' ' ''

Parsha Tzav /
Vayikra 6:1 8:36
Parsha Zachor /
Devarim 25:17 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Tzav, with the special Maftir of Parsha Zachor, which is read upon the Shabbat before Purim. Purim this year falls on Saturday night and Sunday. The Parsha is named Tzav () Command as Vayikra 6:2, Command Aharon and his sons, saying [...] Rashi comments on this stating, The express Command always implies urging on to carry out a command, implying too, that it comes into force at once, and is binding upon future generations (cf. Rashi on this passage in Kiddushin 29a). R. Shimon said: Especially must Scripture urge on the fulfillment of the commands in a case where monetary loss is involved. (Siphra; Kiddushin 29a). This is in regard to the burnt-offering, which is all of it is offered up to HaShem, unlike other offerings which the Cohen and the owner receive parts. In other words, this burnt-offering is as important as others that a Cohen could benefit from. Nor should we be neglectful of something that is done each night just because we do not personally benefit from it.

Vayikra 6:3, and separate [some of] the ash, Rashi explains He raked a full pan of ashes from the innermost consumed mass of ashes and deposited them at the east side of the included plan leading up to the altar. (Siphra; Yoma 45; cf. Jerusalem Talmud , Yoma II. 1). This was the very first service within the Temple that started the day. Nothing else could be done until the service of removing the ash from the previous day's offerings. Thus, there was a symbolic connection between the days, the previous day's ash and the current day's offerings.

Vayikra 6:5, The fire on the altar shall be lit on itself and must not be extinguished; [...] Even though there was a fire that descended from Heaven, it was still required of the Cohenim to add wood to the altar and make sure that the fire upon the altar did not go out. Our efforts here on Earth are matched by efforts in Heaven, and we can not depend upon Heaven to allows bring down the fire, but ensure we have a fire of our own, so when the fire from Heaven comes, it will multiple that which we have already.

Vayikra 6:13, [...] on the day when is anointed [as High Priest or installed as priest]: a tenth of an eifah of fine-quality [wheat] flour. Who else brings such an offering, a poor man that cannot afford an animal or bird offering. Thus the Torah protects their dignity as their offering is the same as the High Priest's offering. Also the priest should not feel too haughty as their offering is a poor man's offering and hopefully be as humble as well.

Vayikra 6:21, An earthenware vessel in which it is cooked shall be broken, but if it was cooked in a copper vessel, it shall be scoured and rinsed in water. The Torah does not wish to trouble a person greatly, for the copper vessel should be broken as well, whereas the earthenware was cheap, a copper vessel was not, so the Torah has a way to purified to save a person from having to buy another.

Vayikra 7:18, And if [he offers his sacrifice with the intention that] the meat of his peace-sacrifice be eaten on the third day, it will not be accepted. Thus to teach us that one's thoughts are as important as one's actions. Just having the mere thought of extending the sacrifice beyond its allotted time from the start invalidates it.

Vayikra 8:5, This is the procedure [that the Eternal has commanded] Rashi explains this thus, The things you will see me doing in your presence has the Holy One, blessed be He, bidden me do and do not think I am doing them for my own glory and for my brother's glory. The whole of this matter treated in the present chapter I have already explained in Shemos Ch 29. Thus, Moshe wished to ensure that the people saw what HaShem had commanded him and regarding the Priesthood as well, and that everything he was doing was only at the command of HaShem. Moshe was not doing the prom and ceremony for his or his brother's sake, but for the sake of Heaven.

Vayikra 8:36, Aharon and his sons carried out [all the things] Rashi states, to tell their praise that they did not turn to the right nor to the left (cf Siphra). Even though they did not hear it directly from HaShem, but through His prophet, Moshe, Aharon and his sons did as they were commanded.

Devarim 25:17-19, (17) Remember what Amalek did to you traveling, when you were going out of Egypt, (18) how they surprised upon you on the way, and cut off all stragglers at your rear, when you were faint and weary. They did not fear HaShem. (19) Therefore, it will be, when G-d, your G-d, grants you respite from all your enemies around you in the land which G-d, your G-d, gives to you as an inheritance to posses, that you shall obliterate the remembrance of Amalek from beneath the heavens. You shall not forget! This plus the Haftarah for Shabbat Zachor which deals with King Saul failed to wipe out Amalek and its king Agag. For it was from Agag that Haman (from the Megillah Ester) came from. Our Sages say, those who are kind to the cruel, will be cruel to the kind. As we saw King Saul tried to be kind to Agag, and his descendant, Haman was cruel to Ester, King Saul's descendant, and her people.

May all forms of hatred be banished and peace reign supreme with the coming of the Mashiach speedily in our day.
