entry.title: Parsha Vayikra
entry.content:
''
Thu, Mar 6, 2014 / 4 Adar II, 5774 / ' ' ''

Parsha Vayikra /
Vayikra 1:1 5:26
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week we begin Sefer Vayikra, which is the third of five books of the Chumash. This Parsha and Sefer begins with Vayikra (), which means And [he[ called., so while this Sefer deals with all the offerings and laws about the offerings, we should not feel it is disconnected from the previous Sefer, Sefer Shemos. While the Sefer Shemos was about the Egyptian Exile and Redemption from there of, the Sefer ended with the construction of the Mishkan, Sefer Shemos does not cover what are the details of the offerings and their laws, thus comes Sefer Vayikra to tell us. From this we should learn it is not enough to be redeemed from our personal Egyptian Exiles and build a Mishkan for HaShem, but we need to do more, to actual uses the Mishkan daily and for our Yomim Tovim ( ). We should also be cautious that we have the proper foundation (from Sefer Shemos) before we dive into Sefer Vayikra for offerings without the proper thoughts and actions are invalid.

Vayikra 1:! , [HaShem] called to Moshe Rashi comments, All were preceded by a call (to prepare him for the forthcoming address) (Siphra). It is expressing affection, the mode used by the ministering angels, as it is said, (Yishayahu 6:3) And one called unto another [and said, Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of Hosts]. To the prophets of the nations of the world, however, HaShem revealed himself in a of a casual character and of uncleanness, as it is said, (Bamidbar 23:4), and HaShem happened to meet Balaam (cf. Bereishis Rabba 52; Vayikra Rabba 1). What issue is Rashi addressing here? The obvious question is why did HaShem called to Moshe then speak to him as well? Would not the calling cover both calling and speaking? Rashi told him it is a sign of affection and to differentiate the Jewish Prophet from the non-Jewish Prophet.

Vayikra 1:2, Man () Rashi asks, Why is this employed? What was the first man ( )? He did not offer of robbery, since everything was his! So you, too, shall not offer anything acquired by way of robbery (Vayikra Rabba 2). In Judaism the saying the ends justify the means does not hold. Think about it, the ends are merely the summation of the means. One cannot justify the braking of one commandment (Shall not steal) to fulfill another commandment (an offering), the first negates the second.

Vayikra 1:3, He shall bring it, Rashi states, Teaches us that they (the Court) must put pressure upon him to bring it if he is remiss in bringing the sacrifice he had promised. One might think that this means that they shall force him against his will! Scripture, however, states, [he must bring it] so that it shall be favorably accepted for him. How is this possible? They press him until he says, I wish to do it. (Siphra). If two wrongs do not make a right, how is this possible? It is said, I have heard, because at the heart of every Jew is the desire to do as HaShem wills. But it can come to pass that something blocks our attempt to fulfill our Creator's will, therefore, it is up to the Court to pave the road to help this individual fulfill our Creator's desire, even if it requires some tough love.

Vayikra 1:7, [the sons of Aharon....] shall put fire [on the altar] Rashi expounds, Although the fire descended from heave, it was a religious duty to bring also some fire of profane origin (Siphra; Yoma 21b; cf, Rashi on 10:2). In other words, we are required to add own our bit, even if it might seem unnecessary as adding an earthen-fire to a heaven-fire.

Vayikra 1:9, Pleasing [aroma], Rashi explains this term, one that causes satisfaction to Me by the knowledge that I gave commands and that My will was executed (Siphra; Zevachim 46b). This is the purpose of an offering that HaShem's will was done, the rest is symbolism.

Vayikra 1:17, With its feathers [still attached] Rashi points out, But surely you will not find even a common man who can smell the odor of burnt feathers without being disgusted with it! Why, then, does Scripture say that it shall be offered? In order that the altar should appear full up, and adorned with the sacrifice of the poor (since the bird with its feathers makes a finer show than without them) (Vayikra Rabba 3). For Scripture knows that a poor person could only afford a bird, and not to belittle such an offering, HaShem commands to include the feathers which would normally make an offensive sense, but because it is an offering of the poor, HaShem makes it a pleasing aroma. There is a Chassidic Story told that in the days of the Holy Temple, the king commanded that the altar be secured for his personal use for the entire day, for he would offer sacrifice after sacrifice throughout the entire day. On that day, a poor man come to offer two birds, but the Cohenim in keeping with the king's order would not take it. The Cohen HaGadol ( ) asked what was going, and poor man informed that his livelihood was four birds, two for his family and two that he offered upon up to HaShem in thanks-giving offering for his livelihood. Moved by this simple man, the Cohen HaGadol, himself, offered up the two birds. That night the kind had a dream and a Heavenly voice told him that the poor man's offering was more pleasing than the thousands of offering of the king, for the poor man's offering was half of his life. The story concluded with the king summoning the Cohen HaGadol and informing that he was correct to offer the poor man's offering. Yes, the king had offered thousands upon thousands of offerings, but for a king this was a simple thing, but for a poor man that had only four birds to feed his family and himself, to offer two of them up to HaShem was far more a sacrifice on the poor man's part. The Torah states that all offerings be it an ox, sheep, or a bird, it will bring a pleasing aroma, and yet, the three different offerings should have different smells, but because the offering, HaShem's will, was done, the end was the same, a pleasing aroma.

Vayikra 2:1, A person who [wishes to] present Rashi points out, Nowhere is the term employed in connection with free-will offering except in connection with the meal-offering. For who is it that usually bring a meal-offering? The poor man! The Holy One, blessed be He, say is, I will regard it for him as though he brought his very own soul () as an offering (Menochos 104b). For it is not the actual physical offering but that one fulfills HaShem's will.

Vayikra 2:13, Salt of covenant, Rashi states, because a covenant was established with salt as the six days of Creation when the lower waters (those of the oceans) received an assurance that they would be offered on the altar in the form of salt and also as water in the ceremony of the libation of water on the Feast of Tabernacles. There are many Kabbalistic and Chassidic meanings to this. One that I recall hearing is that on the altar you have three of the four classical elements; fire, earth (the altar itself), and the air (the aroma and smoke), but you lack water, comes the Torah and completes the four with salt, representing the waters if the oceans, thus, all facets of Creation is involved with an offering.

Vayikra 3:1, peace-offering, Rashi explains, They are so called because they bring peace () into the world. Another explanation is: they are called because through them there is peace (harmony and lack of envy) to the altar, to the priests and to the owners (since all these receive a portion) (cf. Rashi on Shemos 29:22; see also Siphra).

entry.title: Parsha Vayakhel
entry.content:
''
Wed, Feb 19, 2014 / 19 Adar I, 5774 / '' ' ''

Parsha Vayakhel /
Shemos 35:1 38:20
Translation Source: Artscroll; Sapirstein Edition Rashi Chumash

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayakhel, the next to last Parsha in Sefer Shemos. And it begins with Shemos 35:1, And Moses assembled the entire assembly of the Children of Israel [...] The And means that this is a continuation of the previous Parsha. The past three Parsha talked of design of the Mishkan. And this week's Parsha, and the next, deals with the actual construction of Mishkan. After given so much information on its design, why did not the Torah just say that they did it, why take additional two Parsha to cover the actual construction?

Why is that? I have not seen any answers but I have some thoughts. The very name of the Parsha, Vayakhel, means and [he] assembled. Moshe did not assemble the Mishkan but the entire assembly of the Children of Israel. That was the purpose of the Mishkan to focus and centralized the people. HaShem knew that the realization of Mount Sinai would not hold the Jewish People for long. It was a fixed point in our History that defined us as Jews, but it is something that we cannot carry with us all the time. But the Mishkan that we can. For it was an assembly place, a meeting place, and a House of HaShem. The Mishkan, later the two Temples in Jerusalem, and the modern-day Shuls, Jewish Community Centers, and such, places where Jews assemble together for the sake of HaShem and His service. That can carry us through our days.

As the Torah spends its precious time/space of two Parshot on the actual construction of the Mishkan after spending two Parshot on the design of the Mishkan, we learn an important lesson as well. That study alone is not enough, we need to put our studying into practice. Words are powerful, conveying meanings of theoretical knowledge and wisdom, but the words disappear after they are spoken, lost in their moment. Actions are powerful too, they apply the words and make objects out of them. One can write the most moving, emotional-felt poem about hunger, but that will not feed anyone's body, but one that give food to the hungry does. If we all just got together, there is no problem we cannot solve, no issue we cannot overcome, and no challenge we cannot face together. As the Torah tells us, Moshe gathered all the people, for only together could they build the Mishkan, and make a dwelling place for HaShem among them.

Shemos 35:2, For a period of six days. Rashi reminds us, [Moses] first told them the prohibition of working on the Shabbos before the commandment of the construction of the Mishkan, to say that [the work of the Mishkan] does not override the Shabbos. Our Sages tells us that the Jewish People were very anxious to build the Mishkan, which would be their atonement for the Sin of the Golden Calf. Moshe Rabbeinu caution them that, yes they should be zealous for the Mishkan, but not at the price of given up the Shabbos and other obligations that they had. Personally, I feel this is a lesson of no matter the importance of the task at hand, one should not forget one's surroundings. It is said that life is a journey from Point B(irth) to Point D(eath), and what happens is that too many people focus solely on Point D that they miss the scenery and other points that are along the way. Points B and D are inevitable but other points are optional and worth the trip.

Shemos 35:27, And the princes brought, Rashi states, The Tanna Rabbi Nassan said: What the princes saw that made them contribute first at the inauguration of the Mizbe'ach, while they did not contribute first to the construction of the Mishkan? But the princes had said the following: Let the public contribute whatever they contribute, and what they leave wanting, we will complete. Since the public completed everything, as it says, And the work was sufficient for them, the princes said, What is there for us to do? They brought the shoham stones, etc. Therefore they contributed first at the inauguration of the Mizbe'ach. And because they lagged at the outset a letter was deleted from their name; princes () is written . From this we can learn that we should not assume others are incapable of finishing something without us, but rather we should join in as soon as we can, and not procrastinate.

Shemos 35:34, And Oholiab Rashi points out, Of the tribe of Dan, of the lowest of the tribes, of the sons of the maidservants. The Omnipresent put him on the level of Bezalel with regard to the work of the Mishkan, who was of the greatest of the tribes, to fulfill which it says, And the nobleman is not recognized ahead of the pauper. In the eyes of HaShem, all are equal, be they of the line of King David, or of the tribe of the lowest maidservant. One can ask, who are we? One answer is we are those that have been given a task by HaShem to fulfill. Each of us as our own tasks, and neither task is less or more important than another. Each of us has our own tasks that only we can do, as Bezalel and Oholiab had theirs.

Shemos 37:1, [And] Bezalel made, Rashi states, Because he devoted himself to the work more than the other wise men, it is called by his name. As the saying goes, what you put into it is what you get out of it. Because Bezalel put so much of himself into the construction of the Ark, he is rewarded by being known as the maker of the Ark.

Shemos 37:8, with the mirrors of the women who congregated. Rashi expounds this thus, The daughters of Israel had in their possession copper mirrors which they would look into when they would beautify themselves. Even those they did not withhold from bringing for the contribution toward the Mishkan. But Moses rejected them because they were made for the Evil Inclination. The Holy One, Blessed is He, said, Accept, because these are the dearest to Me of all, for by means of them, the women established many legions in Egypt. When their husbands would be exhausted by the racking labor, they would go and bring them food and drink, and feed them. Then they would take the mirrors, and each one would view herself with her husband in the mirror, and entice him with words saying, I am handsomer than you. By these means, they would bring heir husbands desire, and would have relations with them, and conceive and give birth there, as it is said, Under the apple tree I aroused you. This is that which is said, with the mirrors of those who congregated. They Kiyyor was made of them, because it is to make peace between man and wife, to give drink from the water in it to one whose husband warned her , and she secluded herself. You can know that they are mirrors having substance, for it says, And the copper of the offering was seventy kikar, etc., and he made with it, etc. but the Kiyyor and its base was not mentioned there. You have learned that the copper of the Kiyyor was not from the copper of the offering. Thus did Rabbi Tanchuma expound. And so, did Onkelos render, with mirrors of women. Which is all interesting, but begs the question, why did Moshe reject them in the first place, even knowing that the mirrors had allowed the Children of Israel to be fruitful and multiple, a biblical commandment. I have heard that it is said that Moshe wanted everything of the Mishkan to be transparently holy, and these mirrors might thought solely of objects of vanity. That such mirrors were designed and created for the vanity of women, and yet or because of the Righteous daughters of Israel used them to ensure the survival of the Jewish People HaShem cherished them above all the offerings made to the Mishkan, and used those mirrors to test the Sotah, who could have betrayed her fore-mothers, and bring peace between husband and wife.

May the day come soonest when there will be an everlasting peace between the Heavens and the Earth and between HaShem and His people with the coming of Mashiach.

entry.title: Parsha Tetzaveh
entry.content:
''
Thu, Feb 6, 2014 / 6 Adar I, 5774 / ' ' ''

Parsha Tetzaveh /
Shemos 27:20 30:10
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

As a reminder, I am not writing this as a summary of the weekly Parsha nor an in-depth discussion on it, rather, this is a stream-of-thought of various verses that pop out at me as I study the Parsha. This is me, putting my thoughts, Parsha highlights, and comments on the Parsha into words that are recorded here.

This week's Parsha deals with the Priesthood and the garments that wear used in their service. Just as with Creation, itself, first came the physical structure, and only afterwards did HaShem turn His attention to Humanity. Here too, HaShem first gave the overall structure and vessels of the Mishkan, and only afterwards does HaShem deal with those that will serve within the Mishkan.

The Parsha opens with, Shemos 27:20, And you will command the Children of Israel that they obtain for you clear olive oil, pressed for lighting, to light up the lamp regularly. Why did HaShem feel the need to command the Children of Israel in this matter, especially after asking for donations for the Mishkan itself. Our Sages tells us that a lamp is a metaphor for Torah and Torah study. What fuels this lamp, olive oil, which continuing the metaphor is doing Mitzvot. Our Sages are telling us that when we go to study Torah with others or even on our own, we need to be sure that it's clear, no hidden agenda or any ulterior motive. We should direct our fulfilling the Mitzvot for the sake of Torah, and Torah for the sake of Mitzvot. There are those that say you can use any liquid to put out a fire, saying that dirty water works as well as pure water, but our Sages point out that gasoline is a liquid that will not put a fire out, on the contrary it will make it worse. We should not feel that lighting other lamps will diminish ourselves, for if you take a light candle and light another, the original remains the same. Chassidus tells that we are all lamp-lighters, we all have something to teach others and illuminate their Yiddishkeit.

And whom does the Torah direct this commandment to? Aharon and his sons, and what was Aharon known for, love of his fellow and making peace between his fellows. When we seek to enlighten our fellow, we must do so in a peaceful and loving way, just as Aharon and his household would.

Shemos 28:1, [...] your brother, Aharon, [] Nadav, Avihu, El'azar and Isamar, the sons of Aharon. Did we not know that they were Aharon's sons from previous Parshot? So why did the Torah feel fit to repeat sons of Aharon, to acknowledge that they inherited Aharon's traits of loving-kindness and pursuit of peace. Also that they were worth through their father, not necessarily through their own merits. Our own merits might be small, but we stand upon the giants of the merits of our fore-fathers and fore-mothers. Each generation adds to the previous, reaching higher and higher than the last. Today, we have no Prophets nor Judges or even Kings, but their merits still sustain us.

Where do we see this in the Torah? Shemos 28:12, as a reminder, which Rashi states, that the Holy One, Source of Blessing, should see [the names of] the tribes written before Him and remember their righteousness (See Shemos Rabbah 38:8). This was done upon the two shoham stones that rested upon the should straps of the Ephod. The name of the Tribes were also placed upon individual stones within the breastplate of Judgment.

Thus we see that upon the Cohen Gadol ( ) we found that the Tribes were engraved both as individuals and as a group. There is a lesson for us here, as Jews, we need to have a unique identity of our own but also have an identity with the Jewish community as well. We are individuals, members of a tribe, and member of a nation, and all three versions are equally important. Which is one of many reasons why we, Jews, have been unique throughout history, either a people saw themselves as individuals or a single nation. For the non-Jews, it was either or, but with us, it is both.

Shemos 28:30, The Urim and Tumin, Rashi tells us, This is an inscription of the Explicit Name [of HaShem, written on parchment,] that was put between the fold of the breastplate, by way of which [the breastplate] makes its words clear and it fulfills it words (Yoma 73b). [Even] in the Second Temple there was the breastplate, for it is impossible that the High Priest be without [any one of his holy] garments, but this [inscription of the] Name was not inside it (Sotah 48b). And on account of this inscription it is termed ruling as it says: and he will enquire of him the ruling of the Urim. (Bemidbar 27:21).

Shemos 29:10, [...] Aharon and his sons shall rest their hands upon the bull's head. Why was this done? Because HaShem commanded it, is the ultimate answer. But what I know is that this is symbolism that Aharon and his sons (or anyone else that does so) transfers something of themselves upon what they touch. Here, they are spiritually transferring their sins to the bull. Elsewhere, Moshe Rabbeinu rests his hands upon Yehoshua to transfer some of his prophecy to him. So why an animal offering to atone for our sin? I have heard it said that we have two souls within us, a G-dly soul and an animal soul, and it was the animal soul that caused us to sin. Therefore, the animal soul is worthy of the death penalty, but because of HaShem's mercy, we can transfer our sin from our animal soul onto an animal (a representative) that does receive the death penalty. My person view of animal offerings is likened to a family BBQ where one invites HaShem, Himself, to partake together of the animal offering as food, either all given to HaShem or shared among everyone.

Shemos 29:30, [One] of his sons... in place of him. Rashi writes, This teaches that if the High Priest has a son who is [qualified] to fill his place, they should appoint him as High Priest in his place. Thus, if a son is worthy, he should succeed his father, but if he is not worthy, another will be chosen.

Shemos 29:44, I shall sanctify the Tent of Meeting and the altar, and [also] sanctify Aharon and his sons to act as priests for Me. Despite everything Man does, it is still only up to HaShem, Himself, to sanctify as He wills. Yet, it is only after all the details are complete, thus, all the work has been done that the sanctity give to the Mishkan and the Cohenim. So why HaShem is the Source, we still need to do our part of the work.

Our fore-fathers and fore-mothers have done their building and we are doing our parts, may our merits and the merits of those that came before bring the ultimate and final redemption. Just as we study the redemption from Egyptian exile, so may we experience the redemption from our last exile. May Mashiach come soonest so we may put in to practice what we have studied in this Parsha.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
''
Jan 30, 2014 / 5774 Shevat 29 / '' ''

Parsha Terumah /
Shemos 25:1 27:19
Translate Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Terumah. Parsha Terumah started the discuss on the Mishkan, which is the major topic for the next four Parshot (Tetzaveh, Ki Tisa, Vayahei, and Pekudei) which finish up the Sefer Shemos. So the Sefer Shemos began with the Egyptian Exile and our redemption and ends with the Mishkan.

So what was the Mishkan? The Torah tells us, Shemos 25:8, They shall make a sanctuary for Me, I may dwell among them. This is the purpose and goal of the Mishkan. The Mishkan allowed the Children of Israel to make a dwelling place for the sanctity of HaShem, and in turn, HaShem dwells within us. Notice that the verse says, dwell among them, not dwell within it. For ultimately, HaShem exists everywhere and every-when, no place or time is without HaShem. It is not the physical structure of the Mishkan that allowed HaShem to dwell there, for He was there all ready. It was the act of creating the Mishkan in accordance with HaShem's commandments, and going there seeking HaShem that allowed HaShem to be known and seen within the people. It was not HaShem that changed but the people's perception of HaShem that changed. By carrying out HaShem's will/commandments, our perception of Him is strengthened and we feel a closeness that actualized.

Shemos 25:11, from inside and outside you shall overlay it, our Sages say that the purpose of this was to tell us that just as we might have gold on the outside, we should also have gold on the inside. What is gold? It reflects light back in a pleasing way and can be used to make other things more pleasing. Just as we should have a pleasing outlook, so too, should we have a pleasing in-look as well. What's inside is as important as what's outside.

Shemos 25:15, The poles shall remain in the rings of the ark; they must not be removed from them. Our Sages teach us that this can be taken as a metaphor, with the poles being support and the Ark, itself, being Torah study, in other words, we should always support the study of Torah and those that do so. Also one's study of Torah should never be detached from its source.

Shemos 26:34, You shall place the partition under the clasps, and position the ark of the testimony on the inner side of the partition; the partition will separate for you between the Sanctuary and the Holy of Holies. The Mishkan was a micro-microcosm of Creation, itself, and we see here that there is a separation between the holy () and the holy of holiest ( ). The only thing in the Holy of Holies was the Ark of Testimony, which is the Torah, the foundation, and the Holy, is the expansion of that foundation. But there is a limit to that expansion. There are boundaries for the foundation the expansion, and what is beyond. One can not stand a cube upon a corner by itself without support. So there are levels, the Divine holiness, the holiness we can sanctify and then there is the rest, the mundane.

Shemos 27:19, [...] all its pegs and all the pegs for enclosure [shall be] of copper. One of the greatest physical representation of spiritualism needs pegs to hold it down. Does that seem... fitting? At first glance, it does not. One might think that such a mystical place would not need such, or from a more mundane view, the weight alone of the structure should be enough. And yet, the Torah decrees in the same Parsha as the instructions to create the Ark of Testimony, to also create pegs for the Mishkan. Were the pegs decoration or functional? Rashi says he does not know, but the term that the Torah uses lends itself to what we know of pegs that are fixated into the ground. If they were truly required for such a structure, our ancestors could have figured that out on their own, and yet, HaShem commanded them in regards to copper pegs as the golden Ark. The Torah could have implied the use of pegs by just saying that it should be fixed in its place, but does not. Would it have entered the minds of the people to make golden pegs? I cannot see how, gold is not a material that could be made into pegs. Decorative pegs maybe, but what would be the point? I do believe that these copper pegs fixed the Mishkan to the ground, and that is a lesson for us. No matter how lofty something is, we should always be grounded. HaShem created both the Heavens and the Earth. We were placed on the Earth for a reason, for we could have easily been left in the Heavens with the angels. We have a place on Earth, which we should not forget in our search for Heaven, such as the Mishkan represented. Just as the Mishkan was tied down by rope and pegs, so too, we should secure our spiritual endeavorers as well.

May the ultimate endeavorer of the coming of Mashiach comes quickly to us, were HaShem, Himself will connect us to the ultimate reality that is He. As we study of the Mishkan, so may we merit to study and work in the Third Temple in our own days.

entry.title: Parsha Mishpatim
entry.content:
''

Jan 22, 2014 / 5774 Shevat 21 / '' ''



Parsha Mishpatim /

Shemos 21:1 24:18

Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi



This week's Parsha is Parsha Mishpotim, which deals with civil laws. One might think that that civil laws should not have anything to do with religion, but that is not so, for comes this week's Parsha which starts, And these are the laws. Rashi points out, Wherever [a section begins with] these, [it] rejects something previous, [but whenever a section begins with] and these, [it] adds to something previous (Shemos Rabbah 30:3). [Thus here is says, and these to teach us that] just as [the commandments written in] the previous section [were received at] Sinai, so, too, these [written in this section were received at] Sinai (Mechilta, Parashas Mishpotim, sec. 1). Why, then, is the section were the civil laws placed following the section [about the construction] of the altar? To tell you that you shall place [the seat of] the Sanhedrin next to the Temple. While there is a separate of State and Religion in Judaism, as shown by the Kingship resides solely with the Tribe of Yehudah and the Priesthood with the Tribe of Levi, the Torah also tells that as Rashi wrote, the Sanhedrin next to the Temple. Just as the laws of morality were given at Sinai, so too the laws of civilization were given as well.



The Sanhedrin was the supreme court of all matters within Israel that contained 71 Sages. If there was a matter of Jewish law, it was they would have the final say. If a matter of money could not be decided upon by one of the smaller courts, the Sanhedrin would decide on that matter as well. It was HaShem, Himself, that said, remember My Shabbos to keep it holy, and Thou shalt not bear false witness against they neighbor. Which are the fourth and ninth commandments, which were given in set of five. As our Sages taught us, there are parallels between the commandments, the fourth commandment seems to be merely spiritual, while the ninth commandment seems to be merely secular/civil, and yet, both are a part of the Ten Commandments. We know that bearing false witness is wrong, why? Because HaShem said so. It's that simple. History has shown us the horror of groups of highly intelligent people going off on their own, using only their own intellect to decide what is right and what is wrong, as it has been said in many ways, in many times, and in so many words, logic can justify anything. But if there is a standard, a set of unchangeable, absolute rules of conduct, only then can we see what is justifiable is not necessarily correct. What better set of instructions than the very blueprint of the world, the Torah.



The very first civil law we are introduced to is, Shemos 21:2, If you buy a Hebrew servant. Why start with a law about servitude? I am unsure of this, but as I ponder this, I have to admit that servitude has existed since literally Biblical days through and including the modern day. I know of nowhere where servitude in some form is not practiced in some form. It is something that seems to me to be inescapable. Entire industries are dependent upon it and it has been abused greatly throughout time and world today. From the Pesach Haggadah we know that a servant is seemingly one whose time is not their own. Think about that.



Now, think on own our time, who truly controls it? For our employment, are we not required to work certain amount of time throughout the week? And yet, no mortal can put in a twenty-five hour day. No mortal can stop the Sun and Moon from their appointed tasks. Regardless of what you are doing at any moment, time marches on.



Getting back to servitude as the first civil law, we should see how important it is. We know that the Egyptians during the Exile took servitude to an extreme, in order to crush the spirit of the Jewish nation and that they did so to the point where only one-in-five, if not one-in-fifty were able to have the faith and spirit to raise up from that oppression to follow Moshe Rabbeinu into the Sinai desert. The Egyptians had justified and rationalized what they had done to the Hebrews, and they were punished for it. Why, because HaShem, the Source of All, saw that they did was wrong, regardless of what justification they thought they had.



Now, having experienced first-hand the wrong way, HaShem as it were, set the record straight. There are rules and guidelines for servants and slaves, just as there are for the common citizen.



Shemos 21:3, If he enters [service] alone, he shall leave alone, [but] if he has a wife, his wife shall leave with him. Chassidus takes a spin on this verse and plays a bit on what a wife is. The Torah in Bereishet told us that a wife is to be a helpmate against him, either she can help him reach for the heavens or wallow in the dirt. In speaking genderless, what helps a person, intelligence and emotions. So Chassidus can rephrase this verse along the lines of: if one enters the service of HaShem alone, meaning without intellect or emotions, that person will gain nothing. But if one enters the service of HaShem with intellect and emotions, those shall stay with him, in this world and the next. Or one might think erroneously that one can enter the sphere of the workspace without Torah and yet still be blessed, but only by entering the workspace with Torah, can one's work be blessed. As the old saying goes, what you put into it, is what you get out of it.



Shemos 21:7, And if a man sells his daughter Why would such a father do so, Shemos 21:8, designated her [as a wife]. A poor man would could not support his daughter had to ensure that she was taken care of, to which the Torah instructs such a man that is to arrange that his daughter is taken into a household where she will be cared for and made a part of. To the Torah, stealing is stealing, regardless if it is stealing to survive, comes the Torah said there are better ways.



What is the Torah's definition of a murder, from Shemos 21:13, he who lies in wait, or as the legal term is premeditated murder.



Shemos 21:13 But G-d caused [it] to happen to him. Rashi points out, And why was this decreed by HaShem? This is what David said: 'As the dictum of the Ancient One says: 'From wicked people comes forth wickedness' (Shemuel I 24:14) and 'the dictum of the Ancient One is the Torah, for it is the dictum of the Holy One, Source of Blessing, Who is the One Who proceeded the world. And where did the Torah say: From wicked people comes forth wickedness? but HaShem caused [it] to happen to him. What [case] is the verse speaking about? About two people, one who killed unintentionally and the other who killed premeditatedly, and there were no witnesses to the fact who could give evidence. [thus] the one [who killed premeditatedly] was not killed, and the other [who killed unintentionally] was not exiled. The Holy One, Source of Blessing, then arranged them to come to one inn. He who killed premeditatedly sits beneath the ladder, and he who killed unintentionally climbs up the ladder, and he falls upon the one killed premeditatedly and kills him, and witnesses testify against him and impose upon him to be exiled. The result is the one who killed unintentionally is exiled, and the one killed premeditatedly is killed. (Makkos 10b). Thus, Rashi's example is a case of Divine Justice and how wickedness begets wickedness. The premeditated murder was decreed by Heaven to be killed, technically, by anyone, but HaShem, in His ways, has someone whose guilty of a sin does it in a way that that guilt can be addressed.



Shemos 21:18, And if men are quarreling. Rashi asks, Why was this [section] said [with its particular wording]? Since it says, [Payment of] an eye [shall be given] for [the loss of] an eye (v. 24), [from there] we learn only [that he must pay] compensation [for the loss] of his limbs, but we did not learn [that he must pay for the victim's] lost work time and medical treatment. Therefore this section was stated (Mechilta, sec. 6). Thus, the Torah and Jewish Law takes it for granted that medical treatment will be given to a person that needs it.



The misunderstood verse, Shemos 21:24, an eye for an eye, Rashi explains, [This means: If] he blinded the eye of his fellowman, he must pay him the value of his eye, [i.e.] how mush his value has depreciated to be sold [as a servant] in the market [as a result of losing his eye]; and similarly with all [the other cases mentioned in the verse]. [It does] not, [however, mean] the actual removal of [the offender's] limb, as our Rabbis explained in Chapter Hachovel (Bava Kamma 83b/84a). Thus, the Torah speaks of payment, not so called barbarism. The issue is that many seeks to justify themselves and take this verse out of context, nor look further into the Oral Law ( ) where the details of the Laws resides. Both the Oral Law and Written Law were given at Sinai. The Written Law is known as the Five Books of Moshe or Chumash, while the Oral Law was not written down, but pass from teacher to student until Rebbe Yehudah HaNasi compiled it into the Mishnah () around the Jewish Year 3980, or 220 of the Common Era.



Shemos 21:28. And if an ox gores a man or a woman and he [or she] dies, the ox must be stoned and its meat may not be eaten There is an old saying, you are what you eat. While it's an oversimplification, there is truth to that. Thus, the Torah does not wish that such an animal that would normally be permitted for consumption to actually eaten.



Shemos 22:1, he has no blood Rashi explains this thus, It is not [considered] murder [if one kills him for] he is as though he were a dead man [already] from the start [of his criminal act]. Here the Torah teaches you [that] if someone comes to kill you, preempt [him] by killing him [first]; and this [burglar definitely] came to kill you, for he is fully aware that no person holds himself back and sees someone stealing his property before [his eyes] and stays silent, [and] so he came with the intention that if the owner of the property stands up against him, he will kill him (Sanhedrin 72a). In other words, self-defense is a Torah given right to all.



Shemos 22:4, If a man lets his animals loose into a field he shall pay with the best of his field We are responsible for those under our authority such as our animals. We cannot say, goats will be goats, rather we are responsible for what our animals do and must compensate for the damage they do to other people's properties.



Shemos 22:6, If a man gives his fellowman money or articles for safekeeping. The Torah talks of the four guardians: each have different level of responsibility depending upon if they are paid or not, and if they use the item in question or not. The Talmud discusses this at length. To oversimplify, the more involved one is, being paid and using the item, the more responsibility one has. Chassidus also looks at the four guardians as how some can look towards our service to HaShem with the item in question being our souls/lives.



Shemos 22:26, For it is his only cloak, [or] his [only] shirt to [clothe] his skin. One what will he lie?! When he [then] cries out to Me, I will heed [his cry] because I am compassionate. It is known before the Heavenly Throne what we hold in our hearts and mind, the Torah here is warning that we should not overly inconvenience a borrower. If a borrower uses a blanket as guarantee, we are not allowed to hold onto it during the night, for it is the borrower's only blanket. In other words, we are to treat those that borrow from us, kindly and gently.



The Torah warns, Shemos 23:2, You must not follow the majority to do evil, nor may you respond in a dispute according to the majority so as to pervert. In other words, just because everyone else is doing it, does not make it right. While we should follow the majority for good, we should not be peer-pressured into evil or pervert.



Shemos 23:5, Would you see the donkey of someone whom you hate buckling under its load and refrain from helping it?! You must help him [unload it]. The Ba'al Shem Tov interpreted this verse allegorically with the donkey being the body; hate the material desires; crouching, not doing so well; so you refrain from material desires, inflicting yourself through fasting and punishments. The Ba'al Shem Tov says this is not the way of Torah, that you are to strength the body both physically and spiritually, so that one should use both the material and the spiritual in service to HaShem.



Shemos 23:19, [...] You must not cook a young animal in its mother's milk. Our Sages tels us that this verse means that we are not to cook, eat or benefit of mixing meat and milk, as this prohibition is mentioned three times for the three activities. Our Sages also say this is a cruelty and desensitize us to further cruelties.



Shemos 24:2, Moshe alone shall then draw near to the Eternal. Why Moshe alone? Even though the seventy elders were allowed further up Sinai the others, but because they did not actual go with Moshe and Aharon to Par'oh, they lost the privilege to go further. Moshe and Aharon were permitted as they had followed HaShem's command. Although, Moshe was allowed further than his brother, for he was the Prophet, while Aharon was the Cohen.



Shemos 24:3, Moshe then came and told the people all the Eternals words and all the laws. The entire nation answered with one voice and said, We will carry out all the words that the Eternal has spoken. This is the attitude that a Jew should have, as our ancestors had, while we do not understand what HaShem has said, nether the less we should do it, if only because the Source of Truth, Justice. And Loving-Kindness commanded it. That is not to say we should not study the words of HaShem, for only through studying can we fully carry out the purpose of each commandment. Regardless, not understanding should not stop us from doing mitzvot.



Shemos 24:11, The tablets of stone, and the Torah and the commandments that I have written down to instruct [the people] Rashi states, All six hundred and thirteen commandments are [implicitly] included in the Ten Commandments, and Rebbenu Sa'adia [Ga'on] explained in the Azharos that he composed for each for the [Ten] commandments the [other] commandments which are associated with [each other]. So its not just the Ten Commandments that matter, but all six hundred thirteen commandments, which are inter-related, as important, for it all came from Mount Sinai.



Shemos 24:17, The appearance of the Glory of the Eternal before the Children of Israel was like an all-consuming fire on the top of the mountain. Thus, we come full-circle, Moshe at the beginning of his mission saw a burning bush, and now, the entire nation of Israel saw a burning mountain. For when the Children of Israel were as one, one voice, one purpose, all of Creation was in harmony.



When Mashiach comes, the world will once more be in harmony as it was at Sinai. Whereas, Sinai was a one-time event, after the coming of Mashiach, it will be come a natural thing. May that day come soonest, when we all will be one people, one voice, with one goal in servicing HaShem once more as it was in the days of Sinai, so it should be again.
If you gotten this far, please, leave me a message, a comment, something, anything, that you've read this. Feedback can help me improve where I miss something. One cannot learn in the dark, for there needs to be light to show the mistakes and gains that occur.
