entry.title: Parsha Beshalach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Jan 9, 2014 / 5774 Shevat 8 / ' ''

Parsha Beshalach /
Shemos 13:17 - 17:16
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Beshalach. This week's Parsha deals with the actual departure from Egypt, the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, and the miracles that the Jews experienced there.

Shemos 13:18, "Children of Istael had gone up armed", Rashi comments that the Torah said "armed" so that we would know that HaShem ensured that they had everything they would need for traveling in the desert, as there would not be anyone in the desert for them to trade with as well as to prepare the reader to know where the weapons that they used in their wars against Amalek, Sichon, Og, and Midyan. Rashi also points out that this could be interpreted as , meaning that only one in five left, there are some Sages that say only one in fifty left. The rest were buried in Egypt as they did not wish to leave. Either way, I am amazed that so many wished to stay in Egypt, but I suppose after two hundred and ten years, it would not be unreasonable to understand that Stockholm syndrome had set in.

Shemos 14:2, Directly opposite Ba'al Tzefon" Rashi states, "This remained of all the gods of Egpypt, in order to mislead [the Egyptians into] saying [that this] idol is difficult [to overcome]; and it was this that Iyov stated: "He caused nations to err and [then] destroys them/" (Iyov 12:23) (Mechilta)" Thus Par'oh could err and came the splitting of the Sea of Reeds was a natural occurrence or to his idol, instead of the divine trap that it was.

Shemos 14:4, "[the Children of Israel] did so" Rashi tells us that this is written "to tell [us] their praise, that they listened to Moshe and did not say: "How can we draw near to our pursuers?! We must flee!" but rather they said: "We have only [to rely on] on the words of [Moshe] the son of Amram"" Such was the faith tat our ancestors had in Moshe Rebbeinu.

entry.title: Parsha Bo
entry.content:
''
Jan 1, 2014 / 5774 Teves 29 / '' ''

Parsha Bo /
Shemos 10:1 13:16
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bo, which deals with the last three of the Ten Plagues and several Mitzvot (). 

The eighth Plague was the plague of locust that eat everything, leaving the Egyptian people to starve. The ninth Plague was the plague of darkness, a darkness so encompassing that an Egyptian was forced to remain as they were when the plague hit. The tenth and final Plague was the plague of killing the firstborn. If the Plagues were in order of severity, how is it that the Plague of Darkness was ninth, one less than the final and tenth Plague?

The answer is simple, the Plague of Darkness was against the very idol of Egypt called "Ra", who was depicted as the Sun. In essence, HaShem slew the Egyptian "god" of the sun. Through the ten plagues, HaShem has control over the elements, plants, animals, humans, and even the "gods" of other nations. As it is said, "HaShem is One, and His name is One." There is none besides HaShem. He took Egypt's "strength," used it against them and humbled them with their own strength.

Shemos 11:3, "The Eternal  made the Egyptians look favorably upon the people. The [great] man, Moshe, was very highly respected in the land of Egypt, [both] by Par'oh's servants and by the people." It says that HaShem only made the Egyptian look favorably upon the people, in general, and yet, it goes on to say that the servants of Par'oh and people of Egypt highly respected Moshe. One would think that, if someone came into your house, caused great property damage and such that they would not highly respected. And yet, the Torah tells us that Moshe was. All that I can think of is that the Egyptians understood that Moshe was only the messenger, and that what had befall them was merely measure for measure against their own actions.

Shemos 11:4 " " The Margolin Edition Chumash translates it to mean "at midnight," but Rashi translates this as "when the night divides." What is "midnight", it's the middle of the night.  The question we can ask is, it's the middle of what or the division of what? Our Sages tell us that the night has two "periods", the first one Gevurah () has dominance while the second half Chesed () has dominance. So HaShem struck between Gevurah and Chesed, having both and neither. What is neither, I don't know nor could phantom. As for both, that too is something of HaShem's nature. Chesed and Gevurah are opposites, like right and left. So HaShem struck the Egyptians with both Chesed and Gervurah.

Before the Tenth Plagues, HaShem gives Moshe and Aharon the first Mitzvot, which is the setting the Jewish calendar so that Nissan is the first month of the Jewish calendar. The second Mitzah is the commandment of the Pesach offering. Both these Mitzot are non-individual based. The calendar is given to the community as a whole, while the Pesach offering is to the family as a whole. From this, we should learn that when we begin, we should consider ourselves with the group, the larger community, and then the family, before the individual Only once the community and family is established, can we then turn to individual issues. By establishing a community, we help ourselves as the saying goes, there is strength in numbers. The community can support the individual and family.

Shemos 12:30, "and there was a great cry in Egypt" Why was that? Because not only was the obvious firstborn killed, but any first born was killed as well. It is recorded that the Ancient Egyptians were immoral, among them there were many adulterers and the first born of those affairs would be stuck down as well.

Shemos 12:33, "We are all dying" Rashi states the Egyptians said, "[What is happening] is not as Moshe decreed, for he had said, "Every firstborn... will die" (11:5), but here even the ordinary [non-firstborn] sons are dying, five or [even] ten in one house! (Mechilta)." For the average Egyptian did not know of the extramarital affairs, they thought the died were ordinary sons, not the firstborn of those affairs. the more affairs, the more that were killed within the house.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eira
entry.content:
''
Dec 26, 2013 / 5774 Teves 23 / '' ''

Parsha Va'eira /
Shemos 6:2 9:35
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Va'eira, which begins the redemption of the Jews out of the Egyptian exile, and the telling of the first seven plagues or wonders that HaShem performed for us, in those days. Our Sages tell us that the final redemption will be modeled after the first with signs, wonders, and leadership. As we learn of the first redemption, we can look towards the final redemption.

In the previous week's Parsha, Moshe Rabbeinu was given his task and gave Par'oh HaShem's warning, which Par'oh did not believe. Alas, just as Moshe Rabbeinu is an archetype of redeemer, Par'oh is the archetype of secular power. The Par'ohs of the world only believe in themselves, what they can see and what they can make others believe in them. In Par'oh's eye, he did nothing wrong.

To Par'oh, he was the law of the land and followed the natural order as he shaped it. As far as Par'oh was concerned there were only two types of beings in the world, the Par'oh and the non-Par'ohs that served him. It was Par'oh that only mattered in ancient Egyptian life. As you were born, so you remained until you died.

The first verse of our Parsha refutes Par'oh's thinking, Shemos 6:2, G-d then spoke to Moshe and said to him, I am the Eternal. Not the Par'ohs of the world nor the Moshe's out there, but HaShem only is eternal and the center of the universe. It is from HaShem that all comes from. It is HaShem that is the Source of Everything. Unlike Par'oh, Moshe carries of others, placing them before his own interest. HaShem cares for all of His Creation, from the unfeeling rocks to the heavens and all in-between, receive HaShem's special attention and love.

Shemos 6:13, And regarding Par'oh, King of Egypt Rashi remarks, He commanded them concerning [Par'oh], to show him respect with the words [with which they addressed him]. This is its Midrashic explanation (Shemos Rabbah 7:3). But its straightforward meaning is: He commanded them about a matter [that concerns] Yisrael and regarding the mission on which He had sent [them] to Par'oh. And what [exactly] they were commanded is stated explicitly [only] in the next section after the order of [their] lineage, but since [the Torah] mentioned [here] Moshe and Aharon, it interrupted the subject with: These are the heads of their ancestral houses (v. 14 ff.) to inform us how Moshe and Aharon were born and from whom they descended. From here we learn that respect should be given to any king or leader of people. If to Par'oh whom was doomed to suffer the ten plagues and the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, we are to give respect, how much, more so, we are to give respect to those that lead us. It is also important that we see that Jewish leadership does not happen all of a sudden nor comes from a void. Moshe and Aharon were not strangers to the Jewish people. Their father, Amram, was a spiritual leader, Aharon and Miryam were known Prophets among the people. Their tribe, the tribe of Levi was known for their spiritual guidance during the Egyptian exile (and beyond). Moshe and Aharon were not nobodies, but people of renown, born from others of renown. It was never a question of Moshe and Aharon's leadership abilities, rather why them first and not others joining in.

Shemos 6:23, Nachshon's sister Rashi asks what can we learn from here, he answers, From here we learn [that] he who marries a woman should [first] inquire into [the character of] her brothers (Bava Basra 110a). And why should we not inquire of her parents? Why her brothers? For our Sages tell us that sons take after their mother, and daughters their father. Therefore, the son's uncles will reflect how one's son might be. That is not to say that sons are solely the reflections of their mother's brothers, for there are elements of the father within them. And it is important to note that Rashi says brothers plural. For example, Yitzchak Avinu's had two sons, Ya'akov and Esau, their mother's brother was Lavan. But neither Ya'akov nor Esau were swindlers like him. But we do see some elements of Lavan within Esau. Ya'akov Avinu had twelve sons, none like Esau, their uncle. Of course, from a single sample, one cannot make a good estimate, which is why it says plural and not single.

Shemos 6:26, These are Aharon and Moshe Rashi remarks, There are some places where [the Torah] mentions Aharon before Moshe , and some places where [the Torah] mentions Moshe before Aharon, to indicate to you that they were equal [in greatness] (Bereishis Rabbah 1:15) Moshe lived in Midian and married there, while Aharon remained in Egypt, and yet both, retained their greatness. Nor did their missions change them either, for the Moshe and Aharon of Shemos Chapter 6, are the same Moshe and Aharon from the end of Sefer Devarim. Despite of, or maybe in because of, all the miracles and wonders that they witnessed, Moshe and Aharon remained the same before their mission as after.

Shemos 7:3, And I will strengthen [Par'oh's resolve] (lit. Par'oh's heart) Rashi expounds this, Since he was wickedly resisted Me, and it is clear to Me that the [idolatrous] nations have no sense of [spiritual] pleasure in applying themselves wholeheartedly to repent, it is better that his resolve (heart) be strengthened, in order [that I be able] to increase [the number of] My [wondrous] signs [which I bring] against him, and you will [thus] recognize [the extent of] My power. So is the way of the Holy One, Source of Blessing, [that] He brings punishment upon the [sinful] nations so that Yisrael should hear [about it] and fear [Him], as it says, I wiped out nations; their towers have become desolate... I said [to Myself]: Surely you will [now] fear Me [and] learn a lesson (Tzefamyah 3:6-7) (Yevamos 63a) Nevertheless, with the first five plagues it does not say: The Eternal strengthened Par'oh resolve, but: Par'oh's resolve was strengthened (Tanchuma 3) From this translation, we understand the old saying, hardening his heart to mean strengthening his resolve. After all, Par'oh prided himself on his reasoning and understanding, he could not have withstood the full force of HaShem without assistance from the same. Just as HaShem gives a sinner enough rope to hang themselves, so too does HaShem give aid to those who truly wish to repent as well.

Shemos 7:12, But Aharon's staff swallowed up Rashi points out, After it had turned back into a staff it swallowed up all of them (Shabbos 97a; Shemos Rabbah 9:7). A miracle within or after another miracle. Our Sages debate whether there is magic or not, but rather, all agree that HaShem performed a miracle to actually change an inanimate stick into a living reptile and back again. And it was not the living reptiled that swallowed the Egyptian magicians' staffs, but Aharon's inanimate staff that did so. It is not in the nature of the world for inanimate wood to swallow anything or do anything, but if HaShem so decrees, then the inanimate can do so. Why the staff? The staff is a symbol of might and strength. A staff can uphold a person that leans upon it as well as be used as a weapon to defend its holder. And yet this same power, HaShem can use this strengthen against its holder. Why was Egypt chosen, because it was a place very steeped in magic and immorality, so they would understand that it was HaShem, Himself, causing the plagues and all, as the magician later admit to.

Shemos 7:15, Just when he goes out to the water Rashi explains, to relieve himself; for [Par'oh] pretended he was a god and claimed that he had no need to relieve himself, so he would rise early [each morning] and go out to the [River] Nile and take care of his [personal] needs there [in secret] (Tanchuma 14). The question that Rashi is answering, if Moshe was to respect Par'oh, why was he commanded to meet with Par'oh at such an improper place and time? To remind Par'oh that was still a mortal human being and not the godling that he pretended to be.

Shemos 7:19, Say to Aharon, The obvious question is why Aharon, Rashi answers, Since the River protected Moshe when he was cast into it, therefore it was not smitten through him, not in [the plague of] blood nor in [the plague of] frogs, but it was smitten through Aharon. This is a lesson, despite it being inanimate, Moshe was not to smite the River for the benefit it gave him. How much more so, should we not smite those human beings that help us?

Shemos 7:22, Par'oh's resolve was strengthened, Rashi adds, by saying, You are doing this through witchcraft. Would you bring in straw to Afarayim, a city that is full of straw?! You, too, are bringing witchcraft to Egypt which is [already] full of sorcery! (Shemos Rabbah 9:9; Menachos 85a). But because Egypt was full of witchcraft/sorcery, they would understand that the miracles are not magic but miracles directly from HaShem.

Shemos 7:25, A seven day period was completed Rashi explains, The amount of seven day period that the River did not revert to its former state; for [each] plague would last a quarter of a month, and for three [quarters of a month before that Moshe] warned and cautioned [the Egyptians about the forthcoming plague] (Tanchuma 13). Such is the mercy of HaShem, for He warned those about the plague for three weeks (four weeks to a month), and only then carry out the plague.

Shemos 7:28, Into your house Rashi states, and [only] afterwards into your servants' houses. [Par'oh] initiated the idea [of enslaving the Children of Yisrael, as it says]: He said to his people... (1:9), and [so] with him the punishment began (Shemos Rabbah 10:3, Sotah 11a). Thus, punishment fits the crime for HaShem was the One that acts in a measure for measure manner.

Shemos 8:6, He replied, for tomorrow! Rashi comments, pray today that they should be destroyed tomorrow. Why tomorrow? A test and a sign of Par'oh's attitude, rather than allowing the Jews to go, he would suffer the frogs another day.

Shemos 8:12, This is the finger of G-d Rashi adds, this plague was not [done] through sorcery; it is from the Omnipresent (Shemos Rabbah 10:7) Even in praising HaShem, the sinner does so begrudgingly trying to down play it a finger.

Shemos 8:18, So that you will realize that I am the Eternal, right here on Earth Rashi adds, even though [the seat of] My Divine Presence is in Heaven [above], My decree is enacted in the lower spheres. In other words, HaShem resides in the Heaven, but He is on the Earth as well. There is no limitation upon Him.

Shemos 9:20, Whoever of Par'oh's servants feared the Eternals decree made his servants and livestock flee into the houses. From here, we know that that which was in the houses was permitted to escape and would be used later.

Shemos 9:24, Blazing within the hail Rashi states, [There occurred here] a miracle within a miracle: the fire and the hail were mixed together, [even though] hail is [made out of] water. [However,] in order to carry out the will of their Creator they made peace with one another (Shemos Rabbah 12:4).

The Parsha ends with Shemos 9:35, Par'oh's resolve was strengthened and he did not release the Children of Yisrael just as the Eternal had spoken through Moshe. Have gone through seven plagues, Par'oh still had his doubts and thinking he had ways around HaShem. Such is the way of humanity. We see miracles every day and yet, we blame them upon science or nature, not understanding that miracles can be channeled through such. It is all from HaShem that like Par'oh we must acknowledge.

Whether we will be forced to like Par'oh or accepting like Moshe, HaShem is there for us, guiding us, and our Redeemer. Just as we read of the redemption of the Jews from Egypt, may we soon see the fulfillment of Moshe's request, may the final redeemer come and reunite us with all those that came before us. May we learn Torah from Moshe, love and peace from Aharon, and may HaShem grant our deepest wish of world peace with the coming of Mashiach and the final redemption.

Please, leave some feedback or acknowledgment that you have read this. I would love to hear what you have to say about what I have written.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
''
Dec 19, 2013 / 5774 Teves 16 / '' ''

Parsha Shemos /
Shemos 1:1 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemos, the first Parsha of Sefer Shemos. The entire Sefer is named Shemos, which means names, and our Sages tell us that in three merits, did our ancestors merit to be redeemed from the Egyptian Exile; the first and foremost what that the Children of Israel kept their Jewish names, secondly they kept their language, and lastly, they kept their mode of dress.

Of the three, the Torah emphasis the merit of names, why is this? The British Playwright William Shakespeare wrote in his play, Romeo and Juliet, A rose by any other name would smell as sweet. Yet if you can a rose esor you would not know what I meant until you realize that I just reversed the word. Names and what they represent are very powerful and important. To any English speaking person upon hearing the word rose, immediately jumps to mind a flower that has a pleasant fragrance. If I said, an English-speaker would have no idea what that means until you look it up as I did, which if I did correctly, means rose in the Japanese language. So names are important for recognition and expressing commonality.

Because they kept their Jewish names, there was a connection to the Forefathers and Foremothers, and separate identity from the Egyptian society. They knew who they were, where they came from, and the promise of their future.

Shemos 1:1, And these are the names of Israel's sons which Rashi comments, Even though enumerated them by name during their lifetimes, it enumerated them again upon their death, to show how loved they are that they are compared to stars which [HaShem also] takes out and brings in by number and by name (Tanchuma Yashan 2), as it says, He takes out their multitudes by number, He calls each one by name (Yeshayah 40:26). The first obvious thing to say is that this Sefer truly began with And these () thus, it starts with a Vav (), meaning this is a continuation of the previous Sefer. We saw in Sefer Bereishet how the world descended from Adam HaRoshan ( ) to Noach (), and several other descents. Seemingly from Sefer Bereishet the natural order of the world is descent, and Sefer Shemos continues that theme. The Jews were originally the brothers and sisters of the Vice Royal Yosef, the highest of the high, and after the deaths of all the brothers, where made into slaves of slaves, the lowest of the low. It was foretold to Abraham Avinu ( ), Bereishet 15:13, And He said to Abram, You shall surely know that your seed will be strangers in a land that is not theirs, and they will enslave them and oppress them, for four hundred years. Since the Brothers were precious to HaShem, He waited until they passed away before the full oppression upon their children took place, so they would not see it. The Egyptians did not have to be the ones to enslave and oppress the Jewish people, but for whatever reasons they felt entitled to do so. For this entitlement, they were punished.

Shemos 1:8, There then arose a new king. Rashi points out, Rav and Shemuel [differed in their interpretation of these words]: One said that he was really a new [king]; and the other said [that he was actually the same king, but] that he made new edicts (Sotah 11a). For such as been the Jewish exiles, Jews elevate themselves by servicing HaShem and Goyim try to take us down to their level to justify themselves.

Shemos 1:8 Who did not know [Yosef], Rashi explains that this new king pretended to not know Yosef and that he had done for Egypt. Again and again, Goyim have looked for excuses and justifications for what they do and what they had done to the Jews. The Goyim know in their Heart of Hearts what they are doing is wrong, but they make up anything to silence that small voice of conscious.

Par'oh was only able to do as he planned because (a) HaShem allowed it, and (b), he got the people involved saying, Shemos 1:9, He said to his people, Look! The nation of the Children of Israel is more numerous and stronger than we are. Meaning they pose a threat to them. The ancient Egyptian culture was one of very highly fragmented with very rigid caste system. As we saw in Sefer Bereishet, one could become the chief butler, the highest of that caste, but was still a mere butler, no more. To appease the amasses, the ruling caste gave the lower castes someone for them to oppress as they were. This practice, unfortunately, has repeated many times throughout history, with the Jews being the scapegoat.

Shemos 1:13, Rashi translates as, with hard labor that crushes () the body and shatters it (Sotah 11b). It was not enough to just physical enslave the Jews, but to spiritually enslave them as well.

Shemos 1:15, Shifrah () Rashi points out that This was Yocheved, [but she was called ] because she would improve () [the physical condition of] the infant [by the care she provided] (Sotah 11b). Yocheved was the daughter of Levi, wife of Amram, and mother of Aharon, Miryam, and Moshe.

Shemos 1:15, Pu'ah () Rashi explains This was Miryam, [but she was called ] because she used to call out and speak and croon to the infant in the way of women soothe crying babies. is an expression of crying out, as in: Like a woman in childbirth I shall cry out () (Yeshayah 42:14)

At this point in time, Amram was the leader of the Jewish people, and his wife and daughter were out helping as midwives for the Jewish women. In modern times, the First Lady and First Daughter were out among the masses and working as mere midwives.

As reward for their G-d-fearing ways, Shemos 1:21, He made from them houses. Rashi expounds this thus, dynasties of priesthood and Leviyim and of royalty, which are termed houses, as it is written: [It was after] HaShem had built [the two houses,] the House () of the Eternal and the place () of the king. (Melachim I 9:10) priesthood and Leviyim from Yocheved (Shifrah), and royalty from Miryam (Pu'ah) as is stated in Tractate Sotah (11b).

Shemos 2:5, Par'oh's daughter then came down to the River to bathe Some of our Sages say that the reason why Par'oh's daughter had gone to bathe was to immerse herself as part of her conversion to Judaism. Even at the darkest hour of our existence, there are those brave souls that see the truth and join us.

Shemos 2:5, her maid ( ) Rashi expounds this, Our Rabbis, explained [it] as meaning hand (Sotah 12b), though according to the grammar of the Holy Language it should [then] have been punctuated , with a dagesh. [Nevertheless] they explained [as meaning] her hand [to indicate that] her hand increased in length many cubits () [in order for her to reach the box.] Because she took a risk and put herself in danger, HaShem performed a miracle for her so that she, herself, could reach out beyond human means, and collect the basket containing Moshe Rabbeinu ( ). In fact, it was Par'oh's daughter that named him, Moshe. Amram and Yocheved had named him upon his birth something else, but the Torah only calls him by the name Moshe. Rashi points out that Moshe is a Hebrew name derived from an expression of drawing out. Our Sages tell us that Moshe had ten names, and yet, only Moshe is used in the Torah. For this is the name that HaShem, Himself, used for him. For Moshe Rabbeinu drew down the Torah from Heaven and drew out the Jews from Egyptian exile.

Shemos 2:15, Now, the lord of Midyan, Rashi says, the chief among them; but he had abandoned idol-worship so they ostracized him (Shemos Rabbah 1:32). The word for lord here is which usually means priest, but here, Rashi points out it means lord. And yet, this lord had to resort to having his daughters tend his flock, why was this? Rashi answers, he had abandoned idol-worship [...]

Shemos 2:20, Why did you leave? Rashi states, [Yisro] recognized that [Moshe] was a descendant of Ya'akov, because the [well] water rose towards him [as it did for Ya'akov] (Shemos Rabbah 1:32) As a child of Ya'akov, Yisro knew he would make an excellent husband for one of his daughters.

Shemos 2:20, and let him eat bread. Rashi explains this euphemism to mean, Maybe he will marry one of you. [It is of similar meaning to] what which is says [about Potifar]: except the bread he would eat (Bereishet 39:6) (Shemos Rabbah 1:32). Thus the euphemism equates bread with wife for just as bread is necessary for a man's survival, so too, a wife is necessary for survival as well.

Shemos 2:23, that the king of Egypt died Rashi expounds this, He [did not actually die, but] was stricken with Tzara'as, and he would [therefore] slaughter Israelite babies and bathe in their blood [as a cure] (Shemos Rabbah 1:34).

Shemos 3:1, past the desert Rashi explains, to distance himself from [the possible theft of] private property, that [his sheep] should not graze in other people's fields (Shemos Rabbah 3:3). Thus, Moshe took up the occupation of his forefathers, being a shepherd as well as going to a well to find his wife, as Ya'akov did.

Shemos 3:2, from within [a certain thorn] bush Rashi addes, but not [from] another [type of] tree, to convey [the idea]: I am with him in [his] distress (Tehillim 91:15) (Shemos Rabbah 2:5). For HaShem is with us, even in our darkest hour/place of exile. Although the thorn bush was on fire, it was not consumed, it survived, as the thorn bush survived, so too would the Jewish people. The fire was not around the bush but within it.

Shemos 3:6, He then said [to him], I am the G-d of your father, the G-d of Abraham, the G-d of Yitzchak, and the G-d of Ya'akov. From here, we learn that Amram passed away while Moshe was away from Egypt, for HaShem does not use the living to identify himself. It also tells us that Amram was worthy to be listed among the Forefathers.

Shemos 3:12, REPLIED, FOR I WILL BE WITH YOU Rashi interweaves with the verse, He answered his first [question] first, and his second, second. About that which you asked, Who am I that I should go to Par'oh? This is not your [individual task] but it is [also] Mine, for I will be with you. AND THIS phenomenon which you saw with the bush IS THE SIGN FOR YOU THAT I HAVE SENT YOU and that I am competent to save [you]: Just as you saw the bush carrying out [its] mission for Me and it was not consumed, so [too] will you go on [your] mission for Me and you will not be harmed. And [regarding] that which you asked: What merit do Israel have that they should go out of Egypt? I have a great purpose for this liberation, for they are destined to accept the Torah on this mountain at the end of three months after they have left Egypt (Shemos Rabbah 3:4). A person can wonder why me? but the answer is for HaShem will be with you. Each of us were created for a purpose, a mission for HaShem, and we are not abandoned upon this mission, but HaShem, Himself, is with us. With HaShem's help, anything and everything is possible. Never before nor since, as one nation been taken out of midst of another nation. In all of human history, nations within nations are usually lost and assimilate into the greater nation. But HaShem showed the world that if He wishes it, it will be done. And because of the Egyptian exile and our redemption from it, no nation has the power to swallow us up.

Shemos 3:13, I will be as I will be Rashi explains this, I will be with them during this trouble as I will be them during the subjugation of other kingdoms. [Thereupon Moshe] said before [HaShem], Lord of the Universe! Why should I mention to them another trouble? They have enough with this trouble! [HaShem] answered him, You have spoken well. This also means that HaShem, and HaShem only, has completely free will. Whatever HaShem desires, He does. We, his children, can only choose among the various choices He has presented to us. We are bound by the laws of nature and only HaShem can go beyond them.

Shemos 3:15, This is My name forever Rashi expounds this, [The word is written] without a [between the and ], implying: Conceal it that [My Name] should not be pronounced as it is written (Pesachim 50a). Thus, we do not say the actual name, but HaShem which means The Name Thus we do not know who to pronounce the Y-H-V-H name, the twenty-four letter name, and the seventy-two letter name, which I do not know even the letters of the last two.

Shemos 3:16, The elders of Israel Rashi reasons, those designed to [participate in communal leadership] meetings (Yoma 28b). And if you say old mean in the ordinary sense, how was it possible for [Moshe] to gather [all] the old men of six hundred thousand [men]? One does not take leave of their senses upon studying Torah, rather, we must apply as much of our reason as we can to it but knowing there is a limitation to human wisdom, as well as, Torah/HaShem being the foundation of human wisdom.

Shemos 3:19, The king of Egypt will not let you go Rashi adds, if I do not show him My powerful force; in other words: as long as I do not make him aware of My powerful force, he will not let you go. Showing us that HaShem knew ahead that Moshe would meet resistance to his mission, and that by forcing Par'oh's hand, HaShem was showing the entire world His might.

Shemos 4:2, What is this in your hand Rashi states, The reason why [ ] is written as one word [] is to expound: With this () [staff] that is in your hand you deserve to be beaten, because you suspected those who are innocent (Shemos Rabbah 3:12). And the straightforward explanation is: Like a man says to his fellow, You agree that this in front of you is a stone? He answers, Yes. [The first one then] says to him, [Well,] I'm going to turn it into wood.

Shemos 4:13, With whom You usually send Rashi expounds this, and that is Aharon (Shemos Rabbah 3:16). Another explanation: with some other person whom You wish to send I [myself] am not destined to bring them to the Land [of Israel] and to be their future redeemer, [and] You have many [other] messengers. Moshe was asking HaShem to send Mashiach, the final redeemer. Why should there be other exiles, why not, skip ahead to the final redemption? But this is not HaShem's plan, obviously, as we still await Mashiach, may he come soonest.

Shemos 4:15, and he will see you and feel happy, Rashi explains, [and] not as you suppose that he will resent you that you are rising to greatness (Shemos Rabbah 3:17). And as a result Aharon merited to [wear] the breastplate ornament which was placed upon the heart (Shabbos 139a). Thus, we see into the character of Aharon, and why he was selected by HaShem to be the first Cohen HaGadol ( ).

Shemos 4:20, on the donkey Rashi states the special donkey; this was the donkey that Abraham saddled for the binding of Yitzchak (Bereishet 22:3), and it is the one on which Mashiach will [ride when he is] revealed, as it says, a humble man, riding on a donkey (Zecharyah 9:9) (Pirkei de Rabbi Eli'ezer, ch 31). So while Moshe could not get Mashiach to come, he merited to use the donkey that Mashiach will use, and that Abraham did use, connecting the three.

Shemos 4:23, I am going to kill [your firstborn son]. Rashi points out, This was the final plague, yet [HaShem] warned him about it the first since it was the most severe. This is what it says: Since G-d is mighty in His strength, therefore who is like Him, a guide (Iyov 36:22): A human being who wishes to take revenge against his fellow, hides his intentions so that [his fellow] should not seek [ways to] escape; but the Holy One, Source of Blessing, is mighty in His strength and there is no possibility of escaping His [punishing] hand except by repenting before Him therefore He guides [the sinner] and warns him [of his punishment so that he will] repent (Tanchuma, Va'era 14). There are no unknown for HaShem, and nothing He cannot do.

Shemos 5:2, Par'oh said, Who is the Eternal that I should heed His voice to let Israel go? For this, Par'oh was stuck by the ten plagues, for they were a punishment and an answer to Par'oh's query.

Our Sages tells us that before anyone dies, they will acknowledge their Creator. I am not sure of the source, but to me, this is one of them, for Par'oh asked, Who is HaShem? and he was answered by the ten plagues. Shemos 5:22, Moshe returned to the Eternal and said: O Lord! Why have You caused this people to be mistreated [and] why have You sent me?

Shemos 6:1, Now you will see... Rashi explains, You questioned My ways unlike Abraham to whom I said: for though Yitzchak will be considered your descendants (Bereishet 21:12), yet afterwards I said to him, Take him up as a burnt-offering (ibid 22:2) and he did not question; therefore now you will see what will be done to Par'oh you will see, but not what will be done [later] to the kings of the seven nation [of Kena'an] when I bring [the Children of Israel] to the Land [of Israel] (Sanhedrin 111a). Here, Moshe is educated on the ways of HaShem.

We can learn from here, we will be answered either in the manner of Par'oh or in the manner of Moshe. I, for one, wish to be educated in the manner of Moshe. Like most, we cannot see what HaShem does and is planning, but we need to strive to understand like Moshe and submit our will to HaShem's. And when we do, miracles abound.

As we study the first redemption, so may we merit the final redemption, for whom Moshe prayed for. May we be reunited with Moshe Rabbeinu and all our ancestors. May we learn from HaShem as Moshe did. May we merit the desire of Moshe that all of Israel will be prophets of HaShem. May that day come soonest.

Please, leave some form of feedback or even just acknowledgment that you read this.

entry.title: Parsha Vayechi
entry.content:
''

Dec 10, 2013 / 5774 Teves 7 / ' ''



Parsha Vayechi /

Bereishet 47:28 50:26

Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Rashi, Silbermann Edition Rashi



This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayechi, which is the last Parsha of Sefer Bereishet. The Parsha talks of the last years of Ya'akov Avinu ( ), and talks of Yosef, his relationship with the brothers, and the very beginning of the Egyptian exile.



Our Parsha begins, Bereishet 47:38, And Ya'akov lived Rashi asks a question, Why is this Parsha (section) closed up? Because when our father Ya'akov passed away, the eyes and the hearts of [the Children of] Israel became closed up from the misery of their bondage that [the Egyptians] began to impose on them. Another explanation: [Ya'akov] wished to reveal to his sons [when would be] the end [of all exiles], but it was concealed from him. Why does Rashi ask this question, because unlike other Parshot, this one is not separated out, but rather appears as if it part of the previous Parsha, thus, this Parsha is called closed. So the obvious question is why is it closed? We only know through Tradition, that this is the start of Parsha Vayechi.



Why did Ya'akov Avinu wished to tell his children when the final redemption would be, when we, ourselves, are still waiting for it? Thus, they would have been waiting three thousand years for it, as we have been, and past generations could have been crushed spiritually knowing they had to wait so long. Which is why our Sages say that HaShem concealed it from him. But that is the second explanation, not the first. It was prophesized to Abraham Avinu ( ), Bereishet 15:13, And He said to Abram, You shall surely know that your seed will be strangers in a land that is not theirs, and they will enslave them and oppress them, for four hundred years. The counting of the four hundred years began with the birth of Yitzchak Avinu ( ). So the Hebrews were only in Egyptian for two hundred ten years. Of which, Sefer begins with the last eighty years of that bondage.



We see the nature way of things with the Patriarchs, Abraham was acknowledged by all as the Prince of HaShem;Yitzchak, HaShem is with him in a material/physical sense; and with Ya'akov, HaShem is with him in a dream/abstract sense. There is a descent from high to low, and this is the nature of things. Science calls this entropy. From Yosef, who was vice-royal to the brothers who were mere shepherds, and Yosef lived in the Egyptian capital city, while the others lived far away in Goshen. The exile, our Sages tells us, began as simple duty to country and then ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country. And downwards until the Hebrews became slaves of slaves, the lowest of the low, someone the oppressed could in turn oppress. All this started when Ya'akov passed away.



Bereishet 47:28, please do not bury me in Egypt, Rashi explains this request of Ya'akov, as Ya'akov saying, [because] ultimately its soil will become lice which would swarm under my body, and [because] the dead of outside the Land of Israel will be resurrected by suffering [the pain of] rolling through underground passages [to the Land of Israel]; and [so that] the Egyptians should not make me an object of idol-worship. Rashi's first explanation is usually the most literal, and here it shows that although Ya'akov could not reveal the final redemption, he still retained his prophecy to know of the Ten Plagues that the Egyptians were to face. The second is a lesson about the importance of burying within the Land of Israel. And the last, is a warning about idol-worship. All these from four Hebrew words.



Bereishet 47:31, Israel then bowed, Rashi states, [as the proverb says:] When the fox has his moment, bow to him. Although, the fox is among the lowest of animals, when it has its spotlight, respect him. It is said, one does not know from where salvation might come. That salvation could come from the lowest of things, but when it is doing HaShem's will, that which has carried out its Creator's will, is elevated and merges with its Creator, which we should respect and be thankful for.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
''
Dec 5, 2013 / 5774 Teves 2 / ' ''

Parsha Vayigash /
Bereishet 44:18 47:27
Translation Source: Chayenu; Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayigash, which next to last Parsha in the Sefer of Bereishet. It is a continuation of last week's Parsha. The Parsha begins, Bereishet 44:18, Then Yehudah stepped forward to challenge and if need be, battle, the vice royal of Egypt. Not that it mattered to Yehudah for he even said you are like Par'oh. It is here, that we see Yehudah stepping up and being the leader of the brothers. Yehudah was prepared to face the vice royal and all of Egypt, and none of them would stop him. Such a sight such a confrontation would have been. For there was more than just words spoken, but spiritual forces as well. Just Shimon and Levi had taken out an entire city, and now there were eleven of them.

Just before violence could come, Bereishet 45:3, Yosef said to his brother, I am Yosef! The Midrash tells us this stunned the brothers, and allowed Yosef to calm things down. Our Sages tell us, when Mashiach comes, HaShem, Himself, will say, I am HaShem. And we, like the brothers, will be stunned, and putting things into perspective, like the brothers at that moment, we too will be shamed. Yosef tried to console them and explain by saying, Bereishet 45:5, For G-d sent me ahead of you to be [a provider of] substance. So too will HaShem tell us, This is according to My plan.

Bereishet 45:14, he then fell on the neck of his brother Binyamin and wept Rashi asks why did Yosef do this and answers that through Ruch HaKodesh, Yosef wept for the two Holy Temples that in the future were in Binyamin's territory and would ultimately be destroyed. And in the same verse, And Binyamin wept on his neck. Why, Rashi tells us, for the Shiloh Dwelling which in the future was to be in Yosef's territory and would ultimately be destroyed. For those that knew of the future, wept for what would be, how much more so, for us, who have seen and lived through the events.

Bereishet 45:18, The best part of the land of Egypt, Rashi expounds this thus, the land of Goshen. He [thus] prophesied without knowing what he was prophesying, [for] eventually they were to make it like the depths that have no fish. Even the Par'oh's of the world can touch prophesy, and when one is doing the will of HaShem, how much more so one can do.

Bereishet 45:26, but his heart rejected it for he did not believe them. Why didn't Ya'akov believe that Yosef was still alive? Because Ya'akov believed that that they had lied to him before, so he doubted them now. Plus, Ya'akov could not conceive of how Yosef could still be a righteous Jew and also the vice royal of Egypt, a land known for over three generations of being immoral. The Forefathers and the Tribes, minus Yosef, had serviced HaShem as shepherds, away from the distractions of others, and yet, here was Yosef servicing HaShem in the very heart of other.

Bereishet 45:27, and the spirit of Ya'akov... was revived. Rashi tells us that, The Divine Presence that had departed from him rested upon him [again]. Why did the Divine Presence depart from Ya'akov? Because HaShem's spirit only resides upon the happy and joyful, while HaShem is with the heart-broken, while He is among them, not upon them, for only in joy can one be joined up with our Creator.

Bereishet 46:4, "and I will bring you up" Rashi states that this refers to "He [HaShem] promised him [Ya'akov] that he would be buried in the Land [of Israel]."  Our Sages also say that this is HaShem's promise that HaShem would redeem Ya'akov's children from the Egyptian exile.

Bereishet 46:15, "These are the sons of Le'ah... as well as Dinah, his daughter." Rashi expounds this thus, "The males are associated with Le'ah, and the female is associated with Ya'akov. [This] teaches you that when the wife inseminates first she gives birth to a male, but when the husband inseminates first [the wife] gives birth to a female." For the opposite begets opposite, male to female, and female to male.

Bereishet 46:27, "All the people of Ya'akov's household who entered Egypt [were] seventy" Rashi explains that the actual count was sixty-nine, plus Yocheved, the daughter of Levi, who was "born between the walls" and conceived in the Holy Land. Some Sages point out that the word for "people" here is "", which means "souls", and thus, the count includes "The Soul", HaShem, among those that went to "down" to Egypt. For it is said that HaShem is with us in our exile.

Bereishet 46:28, "Prior to his arrival" Rashi tells us "And the Aggadic explanation is: to establish a house of study from which learning [Torah] would emanate." In other words, Forefather Ya'akov knew that Jewish survival was dependent upon the study of Torah. It is this studying of Torah that has allowed the Jewish people to survive and touch the Infinity of HaShem.

Bereishet 46:29, "Yosef harnessed his chariot and went up to Goshen to meet Israel, his father." Rashi tells us that at the meeting Yosef wept, while his father recited the Shema. Ya'akov took the opportunity of the joy of reuniting with his son, Yosef, to elevate himself to a higher standing of Israel and channel that energy into his service and pray to HaShem, in the form of the Shema.

Bereishet 46:34, "For [any shepherd] is an abomination to the Egyptian." Rashi explains, "because [sheep] are considered by them as gods." I have heard, and I don't recall from where (and I wish I did), that another "version" is that as the Egyptians worshiped sheep, thus shepherds were their priests, and it was the Torah calling this animal worship an abomination. Or as the Egyptian shepherds were priests, they were separate from the common folk, and it was "wrong" in the Egyptian eye for others to intrude upon this "sacred" domain.

Why was Moses told to give respect to Par'oh? Because Par'oh told Yosef, Bereishet 47:6, "the land of Egypt is at your disposal. Settle your father and your brothers in the best part of the land; they shall live in the land of Goshen." For the original kindness that Par'oh did to the House of Israel, HaShem was "kind" to Par'oh when the redemption of Israel came.

Bereishet 47:10, "Ya'akov then blessed" Rashi adds, "in the manner of all who leave the presence of princes: they bless them and obtain permission [to leave]. And what was the blessing that he gave him? That the [River] Nile should rise at his approach, since Egypt is not irrigated by rain water, but the Nile rises and irrigates it; and from the blessing of Ya'akov onwards Par'oh would come to the Nile and it would would rise towards him and irrigate the land." Because of Ya'akov's blessing, the years of famine was reduced from seven to two. And later, Par'oh would use this rising water blessing as claim for his "divinity."

Bereishet 47:20, "Yosef acquired the entire land of Egypt for Par'oh". Our Sages tell us that Yosef did so in preparation of the Egyptian exile, so that the Egyptians could not say to the Hebrews, this isn't your land, as it did not belong to them either.

Bereishet 47:22, "an allowance for the [Egyptian] priests", Yosef repaid their kindness with kindness. Our Sages say that because Yosef gave special attention of the Egyptian priests, the Tribe of Levi were allowed similar standing.

Bereishet 47:27, "[The family of] Israel lived in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen. They established themselves there, and were extremely fruitful and increased tremendously." So even in the heart of the corrupt, immoral Egypt, Jews survived and thrived. And so even in our current exile, Jews establish themselves among the Goyim and thrive, but we must remember, even though we thrive in exile, we are still in exile. And we must pray and hope for redemption to come for us.

As the end of Sefer Bereishet is coming upon us, may the end of our exile too come upon us. As we just celebrated Chanukah, the rededication of the Holy Temple, may we merit a new Chanukah, the dedication of the Third and final Holy Temple in Jerusalem with the coming of Mashiach, soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Mikeitz
entry.content:
''
Tue, Nov 26, 2013 / 5774 Kislev 23 / '' ''

Parsha Mikeitz /
Bereishet 41:1 -- 44:17
Shabbos Chanukah /
Maftir Bamidbar 7:24-35
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Mikeitz, which while continuing the story of Yosef, does not designate within the name of the Parsha (meaning it starts with a Vav ()). Although the verse itself does, Bereishet 41:1, And it happened at the end of ( ). So it's a continuation, and yet not. It's a continuation of the story of Yosef, who because he was favored by Ya'akov bared the burden of the family, and yet, it's the start of the story of Yosef in his own right. There is a transition from the Fore-fathers, to Yosef and his brothers. Despite being the desired and favored son, Yosef is still one of the twelve sons of Israel. So the age of the Patriarchs as ended, and the age of the Tribes has begun. Since Yosef is the desired and favored son, it begins with him.

As his descent began with a dream, so too, his ascent began with a dream, Bereishet 41:1, that Par'oh was dreaming.

Bereishet 41:8, Par'oh told them his dream, but no one [could] interpret them [suitably] for Par'oh. Rashi comments, There were [indeed] those who interpreted them, but not for Par'oh, for their words were not heard by him and he was not content with their interpretation, for they were saying, Seven daughters you will father and seven daughters you will bury. In other words, there was something within the dream that stumped them. What stumped them was that both the cows and ears of corn were the same message. Why was this? Our Sages tell us that to the Goy, there are two worlds, Heaven and Earth, to a Jew, there is one world, HaShem, Who is everywhere. The dream interpreters of Egypt could not see how the world of animals, the cows, could relate to the world of plants, the ears of corn. But being a Jew, Yosef did see it as well as that HaShem was not just sending a warning but instructions on what Par'oh was to do.

Bereishet 41:12, An Ivri youth, a servant Rashi points out, The wicked are accursed, for [even] the good that they do is incomplete. [The wine-butler] mentioned him in disparaging terms: [signifying that he was] a fool and unsuitable for high position; "an Ivri [signifying that] he does not even know our language [Egyptian language]; "a servant and it is written in the protocol of Egypt that a servant may not become a ruler nor wear the robes of nobility (). So the wine-butler was covering himself, but in doing so tried to make Yosef look worse in Par'oh's eyes. And this was the one that Yosef had hoped his redemption would come from. Oh, Yosef knew that HaShem would save him, but he also knew that HaShem would not do so directly, but rather through an agent. Thus, rather than Yosef's designated agent, the wine-butler, HaShem used Par'oh for his redemption.

This is a powerful lesson for us. We might think small and hope that someone as minor as the wine-butler will help us, but HaShem has other plans for us, and He uses kings as his agent. As in Tehillim 81:8, In distress you called out, and I release you, I answered you [though you called] in secret [I answered you] thunderously; [...] We talk in whispers, fearing those around us, but HaShem shows us that He, and He alone, is the true power, as none can oppose Him.

Bereishet 41:14, He took a haircut Rashi responds why did the Righteous Yosef get a haircut; he dis do out of respect for the king. Although, Par'oh was but a mortal king, Yosef still respected him as such. No one cannot ignore the material saying, HaShem is King thus every mortal leader is irrelevant. Rather, these leaders are agents of HaShem in some fashion, for it is HaShem who placed these people in those places at that time.

Bereishet 41:16, It is not from me Rashi expounds this thus, the wisdom [to interpret dreams] is not my own, but HaShem will answer, He will put an answer in my mouth for Par'oh welfare. For it is said, Give praise to Him that it is due. Yosef could have claimed it was just him, but by stating it is from HaShem, he explained what was truly happening.

Bereishet 41:39, Par'oh then said to Yosef, Since G-d has made all this known to you Par'oh knew HaShem, from Abraham and Sarah, and that He meant business. Par'oh also saw that since Yosef knew HaShem and that HaShem was working for Yosef, Par'oh understood what needed to be done, should be done through Yosef.

Bereishet 41:48, the food of the surrounding fields of the city he stored inside (lit.) it Rashi explains, since each and every district preserved its own produce. [Therefore, people] put some of the earth that place among the grain and it [thus] prevents the grain from rotting. That is its literally interpretation. Our Sages also say, figuratively, that one's strength should be tempered by its beginnings to prevent corruption. If one is a Torah scholar, one should not boost of his Torah learning, but understand that the wisdom of the Torah comes from HaShem, not the scholar.

Bereishet 41:55, do what he tells you. Rashi expounds this, [Par'oh gave them this order] because Yosef had told them to be circumcised; and when they came to Par'oh and told him, This is what he is telling us [to do; otherwise he will not give us grain], [Par'oh] asked them, Why did you [yourselves] not store up grain? Did [Yosef] not publicly announce that years of famine were coming? They answered him, We collected a large amount, bu tit has rotted. He said to them, If so, whatever he tells you [to do], do. He has laid a decree upon the grain and it has rotted! What if he lays a decree upon us? We shall die! Why did Yosef have the people of Egypt circumcised? Because he knew that the Jewish people would be enslaved by the Egyptians and did not wish for them to stop circumcision because their neighbors did not, thus marking them as different. But if everyone was doing it. While it was noble of Yosef to do, it took away from HaShem's work.

Bereishet 42:1, Ya'akov saw that there was produce in Egypt. Rashi points out, How did he see? Surly he did not see but heard, as it says, I have indeed heard... (v. 2). What, then is saw? He saw in a holy vision that he still had hope () in Egypt, but it was not a full prophecy which told him clearly it was Yosef. Because he was in morning, Ya'akov's prophecy was hidden. For only in joy can we be close to HaShem.

Bereishet 42:2, go down there Rashi states, and did not say: go. This is an allusion to the two hundred and ten years that they were enslaved to Egyptians, the numerical equivalent of . In other words, nothing is just happenstance within the Torah.

Bereishet 42:3, brothers of Yosef went down. Rashi remarks, [The verse] does not write [here] the sons of Ya'akov. It [thus] teaches [us] that they regretted having sold him, and had made up their minds to behave towards him in a brotherly way and to redeem him at whatever price would be demanded of them. Now that HaShem's plan for Yosef and the sons of Ya'akov was in play, the angry towards him disappeared as there was no need for it.

Bereishet 42:4, So that a fatal accident not happen to him. Rashi expounds this, And at home it would not happen to him?! Rabbi Eli'ezer ben Ya'akov said: From here we learn that Satan accuses at a time of danger. In other words, when one is up for notice, others can say something then that can be bad, or as a Japanese saying goes, The nail that sticks out gets hammered down.

Bereishet 42:11, We, all of us, are the sons of one man. Rashi states, They had a spark of the Divine Spirit and included him with them, for he, too, was the son of their father.

Bereishet 42:15, By the life of Par'oh Rashi explains, [means:] If Par'oh lives! When he would swear falsely, he would swear by the life of Par'oh. So we can infer what Yosef thought of Par'oh at this point. But also how respectful of HaShem he was as not to swear falsely, even if necessary.

Bereishet 42:22, his blood, as well. Rashi comments, The participles and imply the inclusion of something additional,. [It therefore means here:] his blood and also the blood of the elder [Ya'akov]. For they realized that Ya'akov would be affected as well.

Bereishet 42:24, Shim'on, Why did Yosef select Shim'on, Rashi explains, It was he who had thrown him into the pit, [and] it was he who had said to Levi, Look! That dreamer there is coming (37:19). Another explanation: Yosef intended to separate him from Levi [for fear that] the two of them might conspire to kill him.

Bereishet 42:28, What is this that G-d has done to us. Rashi adds to explain this, by bringing us to this accusation, for it was [surely] only put back [into our sacks] in order to make an accusation against us. The big thing is that the brothers believed that it was HaShem, Himself, that had done this to them? They did not believe it was an accident nor happenstance, but by Divine Decree. There is no coincidence nor chance, it is all up to HaShem. There is a reason for everything that happens to us, whether we are privilege to that reason is another matter. The Tribes understood this and thus prompted their question.

Bereishet 43:11 Rashi comments on the Hebrew word, , and says, I do not know what they are, but I saw in Rabbi Machir's dictionary [that they are] pistachios, and it seems to me that these are peaches. Rashi the greatest Torah commentator, whom, is listed in just about every Chumash out there, was not embarrassed to admit that he did not know something. In fact, Rashi was not familiar with pistachio nuts at all, so he thought, maybe, they are peaches, which would have been something that he was familiar with. That he listed Rabbi Machir's opinion first, means that he believed it was correct, but unfamiliarity suggested that he went with something he knew.

Bereishet 43:14, The All-Sufficing G-d, Rashi points out, Now you are lacking nothing [for the journey] except prayer, [so] I am [now] going to pray for you. While we can make all the preparations we can think of for a task ahead of us, no preparation is complete without prayer. For success only comes from HaShem.

Bereishet 43:33,The firstborn according to his seniority, Rashi explains this as, He [Yosef] struck the goblet and called out: Re'uven, Shim'on, Levi, Yehudah, Yissachar and Zevulun, the sons of one mother! Take your place in that order, which is the order of your birth! And so [he did] with all of them. When he came to Binyamin he said, This one has no mother and I have no mother. Let him sit beside me. Thus, Yosef passed off his family knowledge as mysticism, thus, protecting his identity and allowing his full brother to sit with him.


Bereishet 44:16, G-d has found, Rashi expounds this, We know that we have done nothing wrong, but it has been caused by the Omnipresent that this happen to us. The Creditor has found an opportunity to collect His debt. Meaning that HaShem arranges things so that the balance of the books is done as His wills.

All that happens to a Jew is the decree of Heaven, what we do with that decree is up to us. Let us pray that this Chanukah, the Festival of Lights, will be a true festival with the coming of Mashiach so that the end of our exile of darkness will be ended speedily in our days.


Please, leave some form of feedback, so I know that there are readers out there. I would appreciate feedback to improve or correct something I have gotten wrong. Or even a discussion on why I believe as I do.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeishev
entry.content:
''
Nov 21, 2013 / 5774 Kislev 18 / '' ''

Parsha Vayeishev /
Bereishet 37:1 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayeishev, another continuation Parsha as it's name starts with a vav (), which is a conjunction prefix. We go from the "focus" of Ya'akov to the focus of "Yosef". It was for Yosef that Ya'akov worked fourteen years for and whom Ya'akov treasured for he was the first-born of Rachel, his beloved wife. And it is because of this favoritism that was one of the causes of the distrust between Yosef and his brothers. 

That distrust grew as torah tells us, Bereishet, 37:2, "Yosef reported evil gossip about [his brothers] to his father." All the children of Ya'akov are righteous, as their names were engraved upon the breastplate of the Cohen HaGadal ( ). But there was a disagreement between Yosef and the brothers. The Talmud tells us that Yosef felt that they held the status and observance of B'Nai Israel ( ) as after the Torah was given, while the brothers believed that they had the status of B'Nai Noach () as the Torah had not been given. That's not to say that all twelve brothers did not keep the Torah, but it was the Torah they were to follow a personal obligation like their parents or the commandments that HaShem had not given them personally.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
''
Thu, Nov 14, 2013 / 5774 Kislev 11 / '' ''

Parsha Vayishlach /
Bereishet 32:4 -- 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayishlach, "and he sent", thus, as it begins with a "" meaning a continuation from the previous word, or in this case, the previous Parsha. Basically, Ya'akov Avenu ( ) went from the frying-pan (Lavan) to the fire (Esau).

The Parsha opens with Bereishet 23:4, "And Ya'akov sent angels ahead to Esau, his brother" Various Sages are of the opinion that it would have been better for Ya'akov if he had not approached Esau at all, being the saying, "out of sight, out of mind." The Talmud does state that before the Sages would go before the Roman (Esau's descendents) government, they would study this Parsha, and do as our Fore-father did, and the one time the Sages did not study this Parsha before going, things did not go well.

Rashi comments that "angels" here could have meant a human messenger, but in actuality, Ya'akov sent actual Angelic messengers. And of course, that Ya'akov hoped for his brother, Esau, not Esau the wicked, would respond to him, as a brother. But the Torah replies, Bereishet 32:7, "We have been to your brother, Esau." To which Rashi writes, "you used to say, "He is my brother," but who behaves towards you like Esau the wicked, he still has his hatred." It is said that in the Code of Jewish Law that "Esau hates Ya'akov" There are many that foolishly believe that Antisemitism can be quote "cured" unquote by understanding. Just thinking is flawed. Such hatred is not rational, and cannot be understood or countered by knowledge. The only "cure" for Antisemitism is the coming of Mashiach, when HaShem, Himself, will be revealed and Divine harmony will exist throughout the mortal world.

Bereishet 32:8, "[Ya'akov] was... afraid and distressed." Rashi expounds this, "He was afraid that he might be killed, and he was distressed that he might have to kill others." Thus, we see that first and foremost, Ya'akov was merely afraid for himself, but distressed (more than mere afraid) over killing others. He knew from his messengers that Esau was coming to kill him, so he knew there were two outcomes possible, his being killed or his killing Esau. Either options were desired but highly likely. While Ya'akov was distressed to have to kill others, he prepared himself to do so, in other to prevent others from killing him.

How did Ya'akov prepare to encounter Esau? He sent gifts, divided his camp, and prayed to HaShem. So he tried to appeal to Esau's emotions, then tried to ensure his family's survival if the first failed, and finally, having done what was humanly possible, turned to that which is Beyond.

For his presentation, Ya'akov said, Bereishet 32:17, "Go on ahead of me, but leave an interval between one herd and the next." Thus, Esau would enjoy one gift fully, then another would appear, more important/valuable than the previous one.

Bereishet 32:23, "And his eleven children." Rashi explains, "And where was Dinah? He had put her in a chest and locked her in, so that Esau should not cast his eyes upon her [to marry her]. And therefore Ya'akov was punished for keeping her away from his brother, [when] she might have brought him back to the right path, and she fell into the hands of Shechem." For such is the power of a woman, she can bring out the best/brightest of her man or bring out the worst/darkest.

Bereishet 32:29, "No [longer]... Ya'akov" Rashi expounds it thus, "it shall no longer be said that the blessings came to you through deceit () and trickery, but rather with nobility () and openly, [for] eventually the Holy One, Source of Blessing, will appear to you at Beis El and change your name (35:10) and there He will bless you, and I will be there and admit to your right to [the blessings]/ And to this the verse refers: "He championed over the angel and over [him]. He wept and implored him" (Hoshe'a 12:5), the angel wept and implored him. And what did he implore him? At "At Beis El [HaShem] will meet us, and there he will speak with us" (ibid.) wait for me [to bless you] until [HaShem] will speak with us there. But Ya'akov did not wish [to wait], and [so the angel] was forced to admit [now] to [his right] to [the blessings]. And this [the meaning of[: "He then blessed him there" (v. 30), [implying] that [the angel] was pleading with [Ya'akov] to wait for him [to bless him], but [to this] he did not agree." There will always be others to challenge us, but we, like Ya'akov, must be strong and struggle to overcome them, acknowledging our rights to the blessings from HaShem and all that He has done for us.

Bereishet 32:30, "Why do you ask?" Rashi explains, "We do not have a fixed name. Our names change, all depending on [the nature] of command of the mission on which we are sent." Thus, angels differ from humans. Angels have no purpose outside of their mission, and are static in their nature. Humans, on the other hand, can fulfill multiple missions and grow and change as we desire.

Bereishet 33:4, "and kissed him" Rashi expounds, "There are dots over [this word]. There is a difference of opinion in the beraisa of the Sifrei (Beha'alosecha 69) about this: Some explain those dots [to mean] that he did not kiss him wholeheartedly, [but] Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai said, "It is an established fact that Esau hates Ya'akov, but at that moment his compassion was aroused and he kissed him wholeheartedly." The "rule of thumb" for dots over the letters is that if there are more dots over letters than not, the word made from the dotted letters is the meaning, while if the dotted letters are outnumbered, the other way. Here, every letter is dotted, which is why some believe it means that the word should not be taken literally. But in such a moving moment, even the Esau the wicked, could become Esau the brother (of Ya'akov).

Bereishet 33:7, "Yosef drew near with Rachel" Rashi points out, "With all [the others], the mothers drew near before the children, but in the case of Rachel, Yosef drew near before her. He said, "My mother is beautiful [and] maybe that wicked man will take a fancy to her. I will [therefore] stand in front of her and prevent him from looking at her." As a result of this Yosef merited the blessing: "upon the eye" (49:22)." Because Yosef stood before the "evil eye" for the sake of his mother, he was rewarded with protection against the "evil eye."

Bereishet 33:14, "Until I reach my master at Se'ir" Rashi expounds this, "He mentioned to him a much longer journey [than he intended to make],for [in face] he intended to travel only to Sukkos. He said [to himself]: "If he wishes to harm me let him wait until I come to him [to Se'ir]," but [in reality] he did not go. And when will he go [there]? In the time of Mashiach, as it says, "The liberators on Mount Tzyion will then go up to carry out judgment on the mount of Esau (i.e. Se'ir)" (Ovadyah 1:21). There are [also] many Aggadic explanations for this section." Although, Esau did seem favorably toward Ya'akov, he did not wish to "press his luck," so he was cautious in his dealing with Esau.

Bereishet 34:1, "the daughter of Le'ah" Rashi asks, "And [she was] not "the daughter of Ya'akov"?! However, on account of her "going out" she is called the daughter of Le'ah, who was also a woman who would "go out," as it says, "and Le'ah went out to meet him" (30:16). {The saying "like mother, like daughter" (see Yechezkel 16:44) was coined in reference to her.}" Our Sages say that Le'ah went out for good reasons, and like Le'ah, so too, did Dinah, but our Sages criticize Dinah for she was "bejeweled in the ways of the local girls. (Be'er Basadeh)."

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
''
Nov 7, 2013 / 5774 Kislev 4 / ' ''

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Bereishet 28:10 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi
This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayeitzei where Ya'akov has his famous dream, meets and marries his wives, and raise his children, the Tribes. works for his uncle, Lavan, and departs from Lavan. This and the next five Parshot deal with Ya'akov and his children.

The Parsha begins with "[Ya'akov] Left ()", to which Rashi expounds thus, "In needs only have written: "Ya'akov set out for Charan." Why, then does it mention his leaving? [In order to] tell [us] that the departure of a righteous person from a place makes an impression -- for while the righteous person is in a town, he is its glory, he is its brilliance [and] he is its splendor. [but] once he has left there, its glory has gone, its brilliance has gone [and] its splendor has gone. Similarly, "She left the place" (Ruth 1:7) that is mentioned in connection with Naomi and Ruth [has the same significance." Why is this mentioned? To show that our actions have an impact upon where we live. You can take a photography of a person and based solely upon the photo can you say if that person is righteous or not? No. Why? Because "righteousness" is a spiritual matter. It is something internal. It is one's action and mannerism that makes one righteous or not. Glory, brilliance, and splendor; these can be photographed, for these are material elements that can be catch in a moment. Thus, what the Torah and Rashi is telling us is that our spiritual actions have physical elements to them. Not only that, but that these spiritual acts upon the physical only exists while there are such actions. As one might think that spiritual should be external, but that's not the case, for we see that if the righteous person leaves (figuratively or literally), these physical manifestations departs with him.

Beresishet 28:12, "He then dreamed that there was a ladder" I have a question upon reading this, why a "ladder?" Obviously, it could not be a jet plane, elevator, or such, as those did not exist then, but why not a piece of rope or a tree? Have you wondered about that? I have. Please, leave your own interpretation.

Why a ladder? Well, what is a ladder? The definition of a ladder is "a tool to allow a person to ascend and descend". Unlike a tree, a ladder is something humanly made. As for rope, maybe it was a rope ladder, but for a mere piece of rope, it was important that there were rungs and two sides. With a piece of rope, ascension and descension is done through pure muscle-power and there are not sides and its all or nothing. But a ladder its one rung at a time, moving up or down in stages, where one can rest in "comfort" between rungs. In the end, a ladder is a human invention that can be used to ascension to great heights or descend into great depths. In order for the angels to ascend and descend, there was a human created tool that permitted their movement. First the angels ascended, human actions reaching towards the Heaven, and then (another group of) angels descended, Heaven response to human action. Also, while a righteous person's mere presence and actions can affect their environment, so too there are actions, such as creating a dream ladder that can have a more affect as well.

Bereishet 28:19, "and this is the gateway to heaven" Rashi explains, "it is a place of prayer[for] their prayers to ascend to the Heaven. Its Midrashic explanation is: The Holy Temple Above is situated direcly corresponding to the Holy Temple below." For we see here that what is in his world, is also in Heaven, they, Heaven and Earth, are mirrors of each other. The Angels  exist in Heaven and the animals exist on the Earth, and only Humans are in both worlds.

Bereishet 28:20, "And the Eternal acts for me as G-d", Rashi states, "His Name will rest upon me from beginning to end, that no unworthy person will be found among my offspring; as it says: "[until I have carried out] what I have promised for you" (v. 15) -- and this promise had made to Abraham, as it says:, "[that I will] act as G-d for you and for your descendents after you." (17:7)" Thus, Ya'akov knows that the Jewish nation will come from him, based that all of his children will be righteous. Abraham had Ishmael, and Yitzchak had Esau, but all of Ya'akov's children are righteous.

Bereishet 29:1, "Ya'akov felt light-footed (lit. Ya'akov raised his feet.)" Rashi explains this expression, "When he received the good news that he was assured of [Hashem's] protection, his heart lifted his feet and it because easy for him to walk. So it is explained in Bereshis Rabbah (70:8)." Since his spirits were high, his body followed as well, making physical activity, such as walking, easier. The opposite is true too, when one is depressed or "heavy-hearted", one just mopes and stays put because they have neither the energy or care to move.

About Lavan the Torah writes, Bereishet 29:6, "Rachel, his daughter, is coming with the sheep." So, Lavan sent his younger daughter to tend his sheep among a group of shepherds, strange men, so he does not care that he is putting his daughter in danger nor that he is being cheap. And what more, others know this and Lavan does not care.

Having criticize Lavan's action, it is surprising that, Bereishet 29:12, "and she told her father." Rashi explains saying, "because her mother had died, and she had no one to tell besides him." So it was just her sisters and Lavan. Lavan had a very small household and makes one wonder about where all the gifts that Eli'eizer, Abraham's server, had brought went and what type of woman married Lavan, producing daughters like Le'ah and Rachel.

Bereishet 29:14, "Nevertheless, my own flesh and blood," Rashi expounds this thus, "Really, I have no obligation to take you into [my] home since you have nothing with you. However, because of [our] relationship I will look after you for a month." So he did, but even this, not for nothing, for [Ya'akov] tended his sleep." Even to his own nephew, Lavan was wicked.

Bereishet 29:17, "tender", Rashi tells us, "for she thought that she would fall into the lot of Esau, and she was weeping; for everyone was saying, "Rivkah has two sons, and Lavan has two daughters -- the elder daughter is for the elder son, and the younger daughter for the younger son." thus, Le'ah's eyes were tender because in her crying and prayers to avoid being sent to Esau. Which shows how bad a reputation that Esau must have had, that Le'ah wished to avoid him.

Bereishet 29:31, "The Eternal saw that Le'ah was hated, so He opened her womb, while Rachel remained infertile." How could it be that our fore-father Ya'akov hated Le'ah and remain married to her? For the Torah says that if a man finds disfavor with a woman, he is to divorce her. Ya'akov worked fourteen years for Rachel as if they were mere days makes everything else pale in comparison. This also ties into the Torah view on polygamy, while "acceptable", the Torah relates that there will always be a "loved" and "hated", implying that there will be problems with it, even when as here, it is necessary and approved by HaShem, Himself.

Bereishet 29:24, "This time, my husband will become attached." Rashi states that, "Since the Matriarchs were prophetesses and knew that twelve tribes would be produced from Ya'akov and that he would marry four wives, [Le'ah therefore] said, "From now on, he has no reason to complain against me, for I have assumed my full share of [bearing him] sons." And yet, only our Matriarch Sarah is listed among the seven prophetesses in Megilah 14a. But then, we only know that the Matriarchs were prophetesses because the Torah told us, whereas those listed in Megilah 14a were known to others.

Bereishet 29:24, "He named him Levi", Rashi points out that all the other children, it says "she named," and yet here, it says, "he named." Thus the question, whose "he?" According to Rashi, it's HaShem, Himself, for the Tribe of Levi would be dedicated to Him, and this shows that it was so from the start.

Bereishet 30:1, "I am dead." Rashi expounds this thus, "From here [we learn] that someone who has no children is considered like dead." For what was the first mitzvah to the world, "be fruitful and multiply." By not having any children, one is not fulfilling that mitzvah.

Bereishet 30:15, "He will therefore lie with you tonight," Rashi states, "[Rachel said to Le'ah:] "I had the right to lie [with Ya'akov] tonight, but I am giving it to you in exchange for your son's mandrakes." And because she treated lightly [the privilege] of lying with this righteous man, she di not merit to be buried with him." Which is why in the Cave of the Forefather, the couples there are: Adam and Ev, Abraham and Sarah, Yitzchak and Rivkah, and Ya'akov and Le'ah. Even though, only Rachel is mentioned as the wive of Ya'akov, although he did marry all four of them.

Bereishet 20:21, "Dinah", Rashi informs us, "Our Rabbis explained that Le'ah passed judgment on herself: "If this one is a male, my sister Rachel will not be even like one of the maidservants." So she prayed and it changed into a female." For they knew that there would only be twelve sons, the Tribes of Israel, and Le'ah had given birth to six already, and the two maidservants have given birth to two sons, leaving only two sons for Rachel.

Bereishet 20:22, "G-d took account of Rachel", Rashi expounds this, "He took account that she had given over her signs to her sister; and that she was distressed that she might fall to Esau's lot, [because] Ya'akov might divorce here since she had not any children. And indeed, this had entered the wicked Esau's mind when he heard that she had no children. This is expressed by the payat: "the ruddy one [Esau], when he sat that [Rachel] had not given birth, wished to take her as his [wife], and she was shocked."

Bereishet 30:23, "My disgrace" Rashi states, "for I was in disgrace because I was barren, and were saying about me that I would fall to the lot of Esau the wicked. And the Aggadic [explanation is:] As long as a woman has no child she has no one to blame for her faults, [but] once she has a child, she blames him. [Where her husband asks:] "Who broke this object?" [she can answer:] "You son!"; "Who ate these figs?" "You son!" It is surprising to be that the great Rashi wrote that a woman should lie like that, save to keep the harmony of the home. For the harmony of the home is so important, the Name of HaShem may be erased to ensure it's continuation.
