May the final and complete harmony come to us, with the arrival of Mashiach speedily in our day.

entry.title: Parsha Toldos
entry.content:
''
Oct 31, 2013 / 5774 Cheshvan 27 / '' ''


Parsha Toldos /
Bereishet 25: 19 28:9
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Parsha is Parsha Toldos, which covers the birth of Ya'akov and Esau, and the blessings that their father, Yitzchak bestowed upon them. The Torah does not speak of Yitzchak much, unlike his father, Abraham, and his son, Ya'akov.


The question can and should be asked, why is this? Why does Yitzchak, one of the Fore-fathers of the Jewish people not get much screen time, as the modern term goes. Our Sages tell us that Abraham represented Divine Aspect of Chesed (), while Yitzchak represented Divine Aspect of Gevurah (). Chesed is outgoing, while Gevurah is ingoing. Some would even say that Chesed and Gevurah are opposites. But the Torah states, Bereishet 25:19, Yitzchak, the son of Abraham Abraham had fathered Yitzchak. Chesed is loosely translated as loving-kindness and Gevurah is loosely translated as (inner character) strength, they can also be called, love and fear. So we can re-state the Torah verse as fear is the son of love, and love fathered fear. We are supposed to both love and fear HaShem, our G-d. Love is easily to display, by doing the positive mitzvot, while fear is not so easy to display as one cannot show not doing something. Love reaches out while fear retreats. So Abraham reached out and showed the world Chesed, while Yitzchak, continued his father's teachings but with his own spin, emphasizing on Gevurah. As the Tribes came from Ya'akov, we know that both Chesed and Gevurah are needed for our service to HaShem.


The Torah also tells us that even in the womb, Ya'akov and Esau were opposites, the verse Bereishet 25:22, [the Children] struggled, Rashi states that this means that when Fore-Mother Rivkah was around a place of idol-worship, Esau would be excited, but when she was around a place of Torah-learning, Ya'akov was excited. Which confused Rivkah, as she thought she was only have a single child, not twins.


Rashi states, Bereishet 25:22, will diverge from inside your body, means they are separate [already] from [when inside] the womb --- one to his evil ways and the other to his straight ways. That is not to say that Esau had to be evil. King David, himself, was liken to Esau, but unlike Esau, King David used his nature for good and HaShem. We are all given certain abilities and talents, which we can use for good or evil. As twins, Ya'akov and Esau were polarized, but both could have used their gifts for HaShem, but for some reasons, known only to HaShem and Esau, Esau decided not. The friendship between Rebbe Yehudah HaNassi and Antoninus is held as an example of what Ya'akov/Esau could have been and should have been.


Bereishet 25:27, The boys grew up; Esau became. Rashi expounds this thus, As long as they were young they were not distinguished by their actions and no one paid much attention to their characters. [However,] once they reached the age of thirteen, this one, [Ya'akov,] went his way to the houses of study, and the other, [Esau,] went his way to idol-worship. From here, we see that both Ya'akov and Esau had the same upbringing and the same opportunities, and yet, they ended up different characteristics.


The Torah tells us that, Bereishet 25:34, And Esau scorned the service of the Omnipresent, thus, he sold his right to to preside over the service to Ya'akov for a mere pot of red lentils.


And HaShem was with Yitzchak, for the Torah tells us in time of famine, Bereishet 26:13, Yitzchak sowed in that land, and in that year he found a hundredfold increase


And we see here in this chapter the first anti-Semitic action, Bereishet 26:16, Avimelech said to Yitzchak, Go away from us, for you have become much more powerful than we are. Although, Avimelech was blessed for having Yitzchak there, he and his people felt threaten by him.


Bereishet 26:20-22, speaks of the three wells that Abraham dug, and that Yitzchak re-dug. The first two there were disputes, but not the third. Our Sages of Blessed Memory say that the Holy Temple in Jerusalem has been liked to these three wells. The first two Temples, there was disputes, but the third Temple will be, Bereishet 26:22, Rechovos (open spaces), he said, For now, the Eternal has granted us space and we shall be fruitful in the land.


Bereishet 26:24, Forty years old, Rashi expounds this as, Esau was compared to a pig, as it says: The pig from the forest ravages (Tehillim 80:14). The pig, when it lies down, stretches out its hooves to say, See, I am pure. Similarly, these rob and extort, yet they pretend to be reputable. For forty years Esau would abduct wives from their husbands and abuse them, when he was forty years old he said, My father married when he was forty. I will do the same. So like the pig which has split hooves, the outer sign of kosher, but lacks the inner sign, so too, on the outside of Esau and his descendents tried to appear to be righteous and civilized, when in fact they were not. One needs only to look how the Romans lived to see this. Yes, Rome build many marvels and had very advance infrastructure, and yet, the Romans enslaved many and institutionalized cruelty and torture.






Bereishet 27:2, I do not know the day of my death, Rashi explains, Rabbi Yehoshu'a ben Korchad said, If a person approaches the age at which his parents died, he should worry for five years before [that age] and for five years after. Yitzchak was in his one hundred and twenty-third year [and] he said, Perhaps I will [only] reach my mother's age, and she died at one hundred and twenty-seven, and I am now within five years of her age. Therefore I do not know the day of my death maybe I will [only] reach my mother's age, or maybe I will reach my father's age. For Man does not know then day of his death, for HaShem, in His mercy and wisdom, kept such knowledge from us. If our Fore-father Yitzchak, who was perfect to be brought as a offering, did not know, how much less would we? As with Yitzchak, we can only base our lives upon our parents', let their lives be a guide for us.


Bereishet 27:22, The voice of Ya'akov, Rashi expounds thus, for he speaks in a conciliatory manner: Please arise (v 19). But Esau in a harsh way: My father should arise (v. 31). For ultimate the difference between Ya'akov and Esau, Ya'akov would pray to HaShem, while Esau tried to make his own way in the world.


Bereishet 27:29, Those who curse you [shall be] cursed, and those who bless you [shall be] blessed], Rashi points out, But in Bil'am it says, those who bless you are blessed and those who curse you are cursed (Bemidbar 24:9). Righteous people first [endure] suffering and eventually [gain] tranquility, and those who curse and afflict them precede those who bless them. Therefore, Yitzchak mentioned curse of those who curse before blessing of those who bless. Wicked people [however] first [enjoy] tranquility and eventually [endure] suffering. Therefore Bil'am mentioned blessing before curse. Thus, we can see that in the end, the wicked are cursed, and the righteous are blessed, and the books are balanced.


Bereishet 27:33, He will still be blessed. Rashi states, So that you do not say, If Ya'akov had not deceived his father he would not have received the blessing, [Yitzchak] therefore confirmed [them] and blessed him [now] consciously. As Abraham thought favorably upon Ishmael, so too Yitzchak thought favorably upon Esau, but now sees that his hope in Esau did not materialized.


Bereishet 28:9, Esau went to Ishmael and married Machalas, the daughter of Ishmael, [] in addition to his [other] wives. For see once again that Esau was outwards trying to appear good, but he did evil upon evil, for before marrying this one, he remained married to his previous wives, whom he knew that Yitzchak did not approve of for the Torah states, Bereishet 28:8, Esau then realized that Yitzchak, his father, regarded the Kena'ani girls as evil. So he married a daughter of Ishmael, but still kept the evil girls that he had married.


Alas, now, the time of Esau is high, and the world is filled with corruption that claims like the pig that it's pure, but within, it's not. May the the Light of HaShem guides us to see the truth, to be pure both within and without, and may the Source of Blessings, bless us eternally with the coming of the Righteous Mashiach soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Chayei Sarah
entry.content:
''
Oct 24, 2013 / 5774 Cheshvan 20 / ' ''

Parsha Chayei Sarah /
Bereishit 23:1 25:18
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Parsha is Parsha Chayei Sarah, the life of Sarah, and yet, we are introduced to her death in the beginning of the Parsha and the rest of Chapter 23 deals with her burial. We can say that the her eulogy encompasses her life and what affect she had on her contemporaries. But the rest of the Parsha, Chapters 24 deals with finding a wife for Yitzchak and Chapter 25 finishes off about Ishmael and his descendants. How is Yitzchak's finding a wife and the descendants of Ishmael apart of the life of Sarah?

The answer to finding a wife for Yitzchak is easy, for through Yitzchak we know what type of mother, Sarah, was. Our immortality and our legacy are our children. There is a special bond between parent and child that shapes the children into who they are. While it was Abraham that sent out his servant to find a wife for Yitzchak, the Torah writes, Bereishit 24:67, Yitzchak brought her into the tent, [and she was like] Sarah, his mother. He married Rivkah, and she became his wife and he loved her, and [thus] Yitzchak was comforted after [the death of] his mother. Abraham was still alive, but he could not comfort his son about his mother's death. Rivkah could, for Rivkah was able to continue Sarah's work, as Yitzchak continued his father's.

So how does the listing of Ishmael's descendants fit into the life of Sarah? While Ishmael was not Sarah's child, he was brought into the world on her behalf, as it was Sarah's idea to give her handmaiden to her husband so they could have a child. We know that Hagar was a daughter of Par'oh and the Talmud tells us that Par'oh thought it would be better for her to be the handmaiden of Sarah than a princess of Egypt. This tells us of Sarah's character. Her name, Sarah, means Princess, and she was viewed as Abraham was, a Princess of HaShem.

We also see that the Torah states, Bereishit 25:12, Ishmael, the son of Abraham, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah's maidservant, bore to Abraham. Thus, who had the biggest impact upon Hagar, Sarah. Who had the biggest impact upon Ishmael, Sarah. Bereishit 25:17, He passed away. Rashi tells us [This expression] pass away is used only in reference to the righteous. Thus, at the end of Ishmael's life, he was righteous, and since it is mentioned in this Parsha, we can infer that Sarah was the cause of this.

Not only did Sarah impact upon Yitzchak and Rivkah, but upon Hagar and Ishmael as well. And that is truly the life of Sarah, how she took something and made it better. Sarah was the first Jewish mother, and the template for all Jewish mother thereafter. She shaped her child(ren) and shaped those around her. Last week's Parsha, Abraham was told by HaShem, Himself, that Sarah's prophetic powers were great than his, and we also see that although Abraham lived until Ya'akov and Esau's thirteenth birthday, Sarah had a greater impact upon her son, daughter-in-law and her grandchildren.

The three mitzvahs that Sarah kept were: lighting the Shabbat candles, taking Challah from the dough, and family purity. Not having met her, Rivkah followed her example and kept those same mitzvahs as well. A mother has a huge impact upon the family and home. It is the mother that makes (or breaks HaShem forbid) the Jewish home. That is her HaShem's given role and task. Like Sarah, a Jewish mother can have a huge impact on generations to come.

May all Jewish wives and mothers be like our fore-mother Sarah, and may the day come soonest when we may learn from her and others with the resurrection of the dead with the coming of Mashiach.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
''
Oct 10, 2013 / 5774 Cheshvan 6 / ' ''


Parsha Lech Lecha /
Bereishit 12:1 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Parsha is Parsha Lech Lecha, where we are officially introduced to Abraham Avinu ( ), we meet him when he is 75 years old, and was then called Avram (). Our introduction to Abraham is HaShem telling him, Bereishit 12:1, Go for yourself ( ) Which Rashi translates as, for your own benefit and for your own good. There I will make you into a great nation, [but] here you will not merit having children. Furthermore, I will make your character known throughout the world. From here, our Sages learn that one can change their mazal () in three ways; changing one's place of residency (here), changing one's name (later in the Parsha), and changing one's lifestyle (this one I'm not sure if I am recalling it correctly). Rashi in his comment on Go for yourself is pointing out the first case, changing one's place of residency. In his father's home, Avram did not merit to have any children. But by going where HaShem directed him, Avram merited to have children as Rashi said.


If someone changes their residency, how does this change their mazal? That should be a bit obvious for we are the product of our environment as well as our genetics. In addition to that, there are physical and spiritual forces associated with a location and one's neighbors. An extreme example is, a simple Jew lives in a very non-Jewish neighborhood, where being Jewish is extremely hard, lacking resources and examples to follow. This simple Jew then moves to where a strong, robust Jewish community is, and this simple Jew has the opportunities to learn and grow that they would not have at all in the previous place. Spiritually, one needs to release themselves from their past, their father's house, and grow into an adult of their own. The Talmud tells us that Avram discovered HaShem on his own at a very young age in a society around him that was very heavily into idol-worship. Terach, the father of Avram, was an idol-maker. Avram while associated with Terach, did not merit having children, but Avram in the Land of Israel, did.


Our Sages tell us that Avram's leaving his father's house was the third of the ten tests that he faced. Why does the Parsha start the introduction of Avram/Abraham with the third test and not with the first? The first and second tests were of personal courage. The third test was of courage but also of faith, not only for himself but for his entire household as well. Abraham taught the world that HaShem was the Source of Mercy, the world believed in honoring one's parents, and yet, here, HaShem, Himself, said to him to leave his father (who was still alive at the time) and go off, himself, Sarah, and his entire household of servants and followers of his teaching. Abraham's decision to obey the Word of HaShem would not only affect him but everyone. And I think this is why the Torah begins the story of Abraham here. For like Abraham, regardless of what we think of where we are in life and in the world, we must go forward, and not sit idle within the past. We need and must forge a future for ourselves. But only in keeping with the Words of HaShem, for then we will be blessed as Abraham was.


Bereishit 12:1, and be a blessing, Rashi expounds this thus, Blessing are entrusted to you. Until now they were [entirely] in My hands: I blessed Adam and Noach; but from now on you may bless whomever you wish. HaShem said, Bereishit 12:3, I will bless those who bless you, and him who curses you, I will curse History has shown us that those nations that are favorable to the Jews have prospered, while those that tried to harm the Jews have fallen. It is said of the Spanish Expulsion that Sultan Bajazet welcomed the Jews warmly and said, How can you call Ferdinand of Aragon a wise king, the same Ferdinand who impoverished his own land and enriched ours? For the Sultan knew this Biblical verse and which has been proven time and time again throughout history.


Bereishit 12:5, they had amassed in Charan Rashi explains this, whom he had brought under the wings of the Divine Presence. Avraham would convert the men and Sarah would convert the women, and the verse [here] considers this as if they had made them. However the straightforward meaning of the verse is: servants and maid-servants that they had acquired, as in: he has acquired all this wealth (31:1); and Israel will acquire wealth (Bemidbar 24:18). It is an expression of acquiring and amassing. From here, we see that Abraham and Sarah taught others Torah, and that converters are reborn. Alas, upon Abraham's death, these converters did not stay with Yitzchak, who had his own converters.


Bereishit 12:6, as far as the site of Shechem, Rashi informs us, in order to pray for the children of Ya'akov, [prophetically anticipating the time] when they would come to fight against Shechem. For the Prophets of HaShem are aware of the future, for HaShem is Eternal and timeless. Time is part of Creation as well as the Earth.


Bereishit 12:12, It will be when the Egyptians see you, they will say, This is his wife, and they will kill me and keep you alive. Here we see the character of the Egyptians, while they kept the commandment of not committing adultery, they did so by murdering the husband.


Bereishit 12:19, take and go, Rashi tells us another characteristic of the Ancient Egyptians saying, Unlike Avimelech, who said, My land is here before you.... (20:15), [Par'oh] told him: Go, and do not remain! for the Egyptians are steeped in indecent behavior, as it says: And whose issue is like the issue of horses (Yechezkel 23:20).

entry.title: Parsha Ha'azinu
entry.content:
''
Sep 3, 2013 / 5773 Elul 28 / '' ''


Parsha Ha'azinu /
Devarim 32:1 32:52
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This Shabbat is Shabbat Shuva, the Shabbat between Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur, which is also marks the ten days of Repentance. So it is fitting that this Shabbat is also the Parsha of Parsha Ha'azinu. For Parsha Ha'azinu contains the third of the ten prophetic songs. The first song was sang at the Sea of Reeds, after the miracle of the drowning of the Egyptians. The second song was of Miriam's Well, after it had washed away the blood and such of those that wished to attack Israel on their way to their heritage, but HaShem caused a miracle to prevent the attack. This is a third song, which HaShem instructed both Moshe Rabbeinu and Yehoshua to tell the Children of Israel, for it would foretell the future and what's to come. Our Sages say the tenth and final song of prophecy will be sang by us when Mashiach comes, may he speedily come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
''
Oct 2, 2013 / 5774 Tishrei 28 / '' ''


Parsha Noach /
Bereishit 6:9 11:32
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Shabbos is Shabbos Rosh Chodesh Cheshvan and we read the Parsha Noach.


The Parsha begins with, Bereishit 6:9, There are the descendants of Noach. Noach was a righteous man, perfect in his generation [...] Rashi comments that in his generation some Sages say it was to his credit, while others say that it was to his discredit. Regardless, it was his generation that I find interesting, a single human being is compared to an entire generation of people. It is also telling us that it was not a mistake that Noach existed when he did, nor any other person when they do. We, all, are meant to be in the time and place we are. Noach was the righteous of his generation, as such, we know of the generation of the Flood regarding Noach himself. A single light in a dark ocean of people that had lost their way.


In other ways, Noach wasn't Adam HaRoshan ( ), nor was he Abraham Havinu ( ), but Noach was Noach. The right person in the right place, as HaShem had designated. Noach had his place in flow of time and that was to be the savior of the human race. Some of our Sages discredit Noach because unlike those that came after, Noach did not pray for his generation. But then, from whom could he learn this? Those that said discredit him, say if he lived in Abraham's generation, Noach would not stand out, but thing is, Noach did not pass away until around the time of the Tower of Babel, and Abraham was born a bit of time before the Tower was started. So there is an overlay. While the Torah (in)directly tells us that Abraham meet Shem ben Noach, but not that Abraham ever met Noach, himself, but Abraham, in his arguing for Sodom based his case upon what he knew of Noach and his case. Case Biblical person came upon the world in the Divine Providence, which a building block upon which the previous was placed. HaShem could have done everything Himself, but for reasons of His own, He decided to include us in His plans. There is natural progression from Adam to Noach, Noach to Abraham, Abraham to Moshe, and so on. There is a Divine design involved. It is up to us to decide to see it or ignore it.


HaShem said, Bereishit 6:13, the end of all flesh, Rashi states, Whenever you find immorality and idol-worship, indiscriminate punishment comes upon the world, killing good and bad alike. Meaning that immorality and idol-worship, actions of everyone, affect the world. There is a saying, evil exists because good does nothing. Such we see in history over and over again. Noach's life and his generation is among the first examples of such. It also shows how HaShem is involved in our world, both allowing us free choice and yet directing the world at the same time. Which is, of course, impossible for a finite being to understand but the way we are made.


Bereishit 6:16, Light Rashi comments, Some say that this was a window, and others say that it was a precious stone which gave them light. A stone that gives off light would be a miracle, but those that say that this light was such a stone, also say that Creation paused during the Flood. Those that say it was but a window, say that Creation continued.


Bereishit 6:17, Flood, Rashi expounds the Hebrew word saying, because it ruined () everything; because it put everything into confusion (); because it brought everything down () from high to low. This that of Onkelos who translates , because caused everything to float about () and brought it to Bavel which is a low-lying place. It was therefore called , because all those who died in the Flood were shaken out () there. In other words, the Hebrew words aren't just sounds put together, but have deeper meaning to them.


Bereishit 6:18, you and your sons, and your wife Rashi points out, The men by themselves and the women by themselves. From this that they were forbidden to have marital relations [while in the ark.] While the world was being cleansed, they were not to relax. When others are distressed, we too should help them with their issues.


Bereishit 7:2, Pure, which Rashi tells us means that this refers to the animals which in the future will be pure for Israel. We learn that Noach learned Torah. For only in the Torah do we, humans, know what is pure and what is not. So for Noach to know what is pure, he would have to have known Torah. It should be understood that the Torah that Noach learned, is the Torah we know, although it was in the Heavenly form that Moshe Rabbeinu had to retrieve from heaven. Our Fore-fathers, Abraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov also knew of the Torah as well.


Bereishit 7:12, rain then [fell] upon the earth, Rashi states, But further on (v. 17) it says, the Flood, however, that when [HaShem] made [the rain] fall, He made it fall mercifully, if [the people] would repent it would be blessful rain, but when they did not repent, [the rains] became a flood. As the Sages tell us, HaShem does not desire the death of even one deserving of death, rather, they should repent and HaShem will save them. Had the generation of the Flood repented, the Flood would not have happened. Such is the power of repentance, prayer and charity, as we say during the Ten Days of Repentance.


Bereishit 7:13, in broad daylight, Rashi expounds this verse thus, the verse teaches us that the people of his generation were saying, If we see him enter the ark, we will smash it up and kill him. The Holy One, Source of Blessing, said, I will have him enter in full view of everyone, and we shall see whose words prevails. Many have thought they could defile HaShem, but HaShem shows all that in the end He is HaShem, and no other. In fact, our Sages say that for each of us, before we die, HaShem shows us that He is HaShem, it is up to us, to decide, whether that epiphany will be a blessing or not.


Bereishit 7:20, fifteen cubits higher, Rashi explains this verses as, higher than the peaks of all the mountains, after the water had reached the level of [all] the mountain peaks. According to The Practical Talmud Dictionary a cubit is equivalent to 18.9 inches. So 15 cubits would be about 283.5 inches or 23 feet, 7.5 inches. To calculate the amount of water involved, one would need to calculate the volume a sphere with the diameter of the surface of the earth inside a sphere with the diameter of the highest mountain plus 23 feet, 7.5. The difference, minus the irregularity of mountains and such, would be the amount of water. The complete mathematics is let to the reader to work out themselves. Obviously that is a lot of water, more importantly, that is a lot of pressure from that water, plus there was literally fire and brimstone as well, heating everything up, adding to the event.


Bereishit 8:2, The wellsprings... closed up. Rashi points out, When they opened it is written: all the wellsprings (7:11), but here all is not written, because those [wellsprings] for which the world had use remained [opened], e.g. the hot springs of Tiberias and other.


Bereishit 8:11, it had plucked Rashi comments, But the Aggadic explanation is that it means food, and interpreted as an expression of speech: It said, Let my food be bitter like the olive [but] from the hand of the Holy One, Source of Blessing, rather than sweet as honey from the hands of human beings. No mortal can compare in any way to his Creator and Source. The kindest of humanity is cruel when compared to the Source of Kindness. But we strive to emulate our Creator, to the best of our abilities. The fish were not affected by the Flood, for they had not sin, but the others had to depend upon Noach and his family to survive, for they did not merit to survive on their own.


Bereishit 8:23, and day and night will not cease, Rashi points out, from which we can deduce that they ceased during the entire period of the Flood, for the constellations did not function and there was no distinction between day and night. Hence, why some Sages say that the light Noach had to add to the Ark was a stone that gave off light.


Bereishit 11:1, one language When the world spoke one language, what language was that? Rashi tells us, the Holy Language (Hebrew).


Why did the people of the time build the Tower of Babel, Rashi tells us, in explaining the verse, and was of a united cause, saying, They decided on one plan and said, He has no right to select the heavens for Himself. Let us ascend to the sky and wage war with Him. Another explanation: about the Unique One of the world. Another explanation They said, Once every 1,656 years (the period between Creation and the Flood) the skies collapse, as they did during the Flood. Let us make supports for them. The theories of Global Warming is not a new one. For those who would build the Tower of Babel thought they could dominate their environment as well.


Bereishit 11:5, the sons of Man (Adam). Rashi asks, Who else's children, then, could it have been? Perhaps the children of donkeys or camels? However, to the children of [Adam] the first man who was ungrateful and said: The woman whom You gave [to be] with me... (3:12). These people, too, were ungrateful by rebelling against the One who had showered goodness upon them and had saved tehm from the Flood. Alas, such ungratefulness still lingers with us, even today.


Bereishit 11:6, Even thought they are all one people, Rashi points out, they have all this good that they are one people and have all the same language, yet this they have begun to do! Thus, did HaShem punish them, by dividing them by geography and language.


Bereishit 11:29, Yiskah, Rashi tells us, This was Sarah, [but she was also called Yiskah] because she could see [the future] through Holy Inspiration, and because everyone observed her beauty. Furthermore, Yiskah is an expression of princeliness, just as Sarah is an expression of rulership. Many Biblical figures have several names, each to describe a special aspect or concept of that person.

entry.title: Parsha Bereishit
entry.content:
''
Sep 22, 2013 / 5774 Tishrei 18 / '' ''


Parsha Bereishit /
Bereishit 1:1 6:8
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


Thursday night and Thursday day is Simcha Torah ( ), on which we read the very last Parsha of the Torah and immediately read the first part of the very first Parsha of the Torah, beginning again the cycle of Torah Parshiot. Just as HaShem, Himself, renews His Creation each Rosh HaShanah ( ), so we as well renew the Torah Parshiot cycle from the beginning as well. Thus, this Shabbat is Shabbat Bereishit ( ), as we read the very first Parsha of the Torah, of the very first Sefer of the Torah.


Parsha Vzos HaBeracha ( ) is Devarim 33:1 34:12, which is the very last Parsha of the Sefer Devarim and the end of the Torah with the passing of Moshe Rabbeinu. While Moshe Rabbeinu did pass away, as he was mortal, the Torah did not end with him. We have carried it with us from the establishment of the Land of Israel by Yehoshua ben Nun and throughout the world in all our journeys, until this very day. The Torah is eternal, as the One, whose words they are. The Prophets carried on the work of Moshe, so their works are also called Torah as well. The entire Tanakh ('') is also referred to as simply Torah. For the record, Tanakh ('') is made of the first letter of the three groups of works which are: Torah (), Nevi'im (), and Ketuvim ().


The last Parsha of the Torah begins, Devarim 33:1, And this is the blessing with which Moshe, the [prophet] of G-d, blessed the Children of Israel before he died. Rashi comments on this, saying, quite near to his death, For if not now, when? (Sifri) Our Sages ask where did Moshe learn of this? He learned from Ya'akov Avinu ( ), as he blessed his children before he passed away.


Devarim 33:2, And he said, HaShem came from Sinai, Rashi expounds, First he began with praise of the Omnipresent, and only afterwards did he begin with what concerned Israel; but in the praise which he began there is mention of Israel's merit. All this was by way of intercession, as though to say, These are worthy that blessing should rest upon them (Sifri).This too, Moshe learned from our fore-fathers.


So those are the obvious connections... but what of others? Our Sages say that for HaShem, the end is in the beginning, and the beginning in the end.


The very last verse in the Torah is Devarim 34:12, and regarding everything [carried out with his] strong hands, and everything [performed in] the fearful [and] great [desert], that Moshe did in full view of Israel.


The very first verse in the Torah is Bereishit 1:1, In the beginning of G-d's creating the heavens and the earth,

entry.title: Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech
entry.content:
''
Aug 29, 2013 / 5773 Elul 23 / '' ''


Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech / -
Devarim 29:9 31:30
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Parsha is Parsha Nitzavim-Vayelech, a double portion, Shabbat Mevarekhim ( ) the Shabbat before the New Month, and as it happens, the last Shabbat of the Year 5773 (''). Rosh Chodesh Tishrei ( ) falls this year on Wednesday, September 7, 2013, which is also Rosh HaShanah ( ) of the Year 5774 (''). It is said that the previous Shabbat blesses the coming week. Thus, this Shabbat, a double-portion, blesses the New Year that we will be entering.


Recall that Rosh HaShanah is a Holy Festival, it is also the beginning of the Ten Days of Teshuvah, which it is aid, On Rosh HaShanah it is written, and on Yom Kippur it is sealed for we are judged by HaShem, in His Mercy, for a good and sweet year. This is a time to reflect on the past year, and how we may improve ourselves for the new year. How can we do this? Let us go back to the Source, to the words of our Creator, recorded by Moshe Rabbeinu in the Torah.


What verse does this double-portion Parsha begin with? Devarim 29:9, You, all, are standing today before the Eternal, your G-d Our Sages tell us, after hearing all the curses of the previous Parsha, the people were panicky about them, thus Moshe Rabbeinu reassured them by saying all of you are still standing after those curses. Which we, today, can testify, after all the curses and hardships of the past, we, Jews, still stand. How are we still standing? Before the Eternal, our G-d, who has protected us and saved us, as the Haggadah states, in every generation, there arises someone seeking to destroy us, but HaShem preserves us.


Mark Twain (September 1897) wrote, If the statistics are right, the Jews constitute but one quarter of one percent of the human race. It suggests a nebulous puff of star dust lost in the blaze of the Milky Way. Properly, the Jew ought hardly to be heard of, but he is heard of, has always been heard of. He is as prominent on the planet as any other people, and his importance is extravagantly out of proportion to the smallness of his bulk.
His contributions to the worlds list of great names in literature, science, art, music, finance, medicine and abstruse learning are also very out of proportion to the weakness of his numbers. He has made a marvelous fight in this world in all ages; and has done it with his hands tied behind him. He could be vain of himself and be excused for it. The Egyptians, the Babylonians and the Persians rose, filled the planet with sound and splendor, then faded to dream-stuff and passed away; the Greeks and Romans followed and made a vast noise, and they were gone; other people have sprung up and held their torch high for a time but it burned out, and they sit in twilight now, and have vanished.
The Jew saw them all, survived them all, and is now what he always was, exhibiting no decadence, no infirmaties, of age, no weakening of his parts, no slowing of his energies, no dulling of his alert but aggressive mind. All things are mortal but the Jews; all other forces pass, but he remains. What is the secret of his immortality?


What is the answer to this supposed secret that Mark Twain wonders, the answer is in the Pesach Haggadah, for it states, For not just one alone has risen against us to destroy us, but in every generation they rise against us to destroy us; and the Holy One, blessed be He, saves us from their hand! As Moshe Rabbeinu said, You, all, are standing before the Eternal, your G-d, mere know before whom you are standing, and you will survive, live by the words of Torah, and you will live!
Know that before HaShem, we are all the same. It matters not if we are, Devarim 29:9-10, (9) [] princes of your tribes, your elders and officers, every man of Israel, (10) your small children [and] your wives, and proselytes who are within your camp [even] from your wood chopper to your water drawers Where you are a prince or a child, a proselyte or born-Jewish, or man or woman, it matters not to HaShem, we are all His children, the children of His beloved, Abraham, Yitzchak, and Ya'akov.


On Rosh HaShanah, we all stand, once again, in Judgment and Mercy, as the Jews whom Moshe, himself, addressed, You, all, are standing before the Eternal.


Devarim 29:14, and also with whoever is not here, Rashi expounds this saying, with the generations that will be in the future (i.e. Moshe is not referring to people who happened to be absent from the assembly, for it states, v. 10, that all were present: You are standing this day all of you before HaShem) (Tanch.) The covenant that Moshe Rabbeinu made with his generation and his generation's children, included us, their descendants as well. We should never feel that we are left out, for our Jewish leaders think not only of their current charges, but of the future and their children as well. For HaShem is eternal and His people are as well.


Devarim 30:3, Then HaShem your G-d will return your captivity, Rashi explains, It ought to have written; then He will bring back our captivity. But our Rabbis learned from this that, if one can, His Divine presence dwells with Israel in the misery of their exile, so that when they are redeemed, He makes redemption written for Himself that He will return with them (Sifri on Num 35:34; Meg. 29a). Furthermore the following may be said, that the day of the gathering of the exiles is so important and with difficulty that it is as though He (G-d) Himself must actually seize hold of each individual's hand from his place, as it is said, (Is. 27:12) And you shall be gathered one by one, O you children of Israel. And also regarding the exiles of other nations we have found this, (Ezek. 29:14) And I will return the captivity of Egypt. HaShem, Himself, will ensure that every exile will be redeemed, taking each by their hand and carrying them home.


Devarim 30:15, Life and good, Rashi says, The one is dependent upon the other; if you do good, behold, there is life for you, and if you do evil, behold, there is death for you. Torah goes on to explain how this is: For like begets like, good brings life, and evil brings death. A metaphor, the closer you move to the fire, the warmer you are; conversely, the further you move away from the fire, the colder you get. Doing good is moving closer to HaShem, the Source of Life, so there is life for you. Doing evil, on the other hand, is moving away from HaShem, for whom without, there is no life, only death.


So how does one go about doing good? The Torah says, Devarim 30:16, to love HaShem your G-d, as we say in the Avinu Malkeinu ( ) prayer, HaShem is our Father and our King. We should love Him as a parent and as a ruler/guiding light, in both private (as our Father), and public (as our King) lives. Other religions believe in a separation of physical and spiritual, not so with Judaism. The very same G-d that is among us, is the very same G-d that is within me. We are all the children of HaShem.


Such was the quality of leadership of Moshe Rabbeinu that upon the day of his death, Devarim 31:1, Moshe then went and spoke these words to all of Israel. To each and every person under him, he went to, to speak face to face with each person, individually, thus, honoring all of them, he that spoke face to face with HaShem, Himself, spoke with each Jew, face to face, as well.


Devarim 31:2, I can no longer go out and come in, Rashi expounds thus, One might think that this was because his physical strength failed him! Torah, however, states (34:7), His eye was not dim nor his natural force abated! What then is the meaning of I can no longer? It means: I am not permitted (cf. Rashi on 12:17 and 24:4), because the power (leadership) is being taken from me and given to Yehoshua. Moshe was not unable to lead, rather, the Divine Plan, was to have a different style of leadership for the Jews when they entered Israel. Why this is so, please, discuss with a Rabbi.


Devarim 31:2, I am this day, Rashi comments, Today my days and my years become full; for on this day (the seventh of Adar; cf. Rashi on 1:3) I was born and on this day I must die (Sota 13b). Another explanation is: in the matter of Law; teaches that the traditions and the well-springs of wisdom were stopped up for him (Tanch. cf. Sota 13b). So Moshe Rabbeinu lived exactly one hundred and twenty years, which is the full allotted time that had been decreed upon Humanity as a whole, in the time of the Flood.


Devarim 31:9, Moshe then wrote down this Torah and gave it to the priests the sons of Levi, who carry the ark of the covenant of the Eternal, and to all the elders of Israel. Our Sages tell us, each of the tribes complained to Moshe, that he had only gave his own tribe a copy of the Torah. How precious the Torah was to each and every tribe, they demanded from Moshe, a copy for themselves as well. So that possible future generations could not say, to the Leviyim only was the Torah given to, but rather, as it is said, The Torah which Moshe commanded us is the heritage of congregation of Yaakov. (v 33:4) The Torah is a heritage for all. Thus, HaShem performed a miracle, and allowed Moshe Rabbeinu to write an additional eleven other Torahs, so that each of the twelve tribes had a copy by his hand. It is a miracle for it takes, approximately several months to do so, but Moshe Rabbeinu wrote eleven within the very day of his death.


Devarim 31:12, and the small children Rashi asks, Why did they come? For no other purpose than that a reward should be given to those who bring them (Chag. 3a). To the seventh year gather, everyone came, in order to learn and even to merely hear the words of Torah spoke, whether the small children understood them or not, they gave reward to those that brought them.


Devarim 31:21, For it shall not be forgotten out of the mouths of their offspring Rashi tells us, This is an assurance to Israel that the Torah will never be entirely forgotten by their descendants. It is because of HaShem's promise that despite all that has befallen us, I can write on what the Torah has to say and expound it today.


Devarim 31:29, After my death you will surely corrupt yourselves Rashi counters, But, you see, all the days of Yehoshua they did not corrupt, for it states, (Judg 2:7) And the people served HaShem all the days of Yehoshua?! But from here that one's pupil should be as dear to him as his own self; it appears to Moshe that so long as Yehoshua would live it would be as though he himself would be living (he thus alluded by the words after my death to a period after Yehoshua's death). For the future was known to His prophets, for HaShem, Himself, is beyond time. Past, present and future have no meaning to Him, the Creator of Time.


May we all be inscribed for a good and sweet year. May the year 5774 be a year of redemption and peace with the coming of Mashiach. May this year, we all stand before HaShem in Jerusalem, for good, for life, and for peace.




May you be inscribed and sealed for a good year!

entry.title: Parsha Ki Savo
entry.content:
''
Thu, Aug 22, 2013 / 5773 Elul 16 / '' ''


Parsha Ki Savo /
Devarim 26:1 29:8
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi



This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Tavo. Our Sages say that in the beginning is the end, and in the end is the beginning. Our Parsha begins, Devarim 26:1, It shall be when you come to the land that the Eternal, your G-d, is giving to you [...] and the seventh aliyah (the end), has, Devarim 29:1, Moshe then called all Israel and said to them: You saw everything that the Eternal did in the land of Egypt before your eyes, to Par'oh, all his servants and his entire land. The first aliyah speaks of the commandment to bring the offering of first-fruits to the Holy Temple in Jerusalem The first of the fruits, which are the best, we dedicate to HaShem, our Source.


The Torah could have easily could have started this Parsha by saying, since HaShem was the One that took you out of Egypt, He has the right to demand the first of our labors. Instead, the Torah instructs us to say, Devarim 26:3, I have declared today the Eternal, your G-d, that I have come to the land which the Eternal promised to our fore-fathers, to give to us. HaShem does not demand anything from us, even that which is due Him. Rather, He wishes for us to acknowledge our Source in our own understanding. Yes, HaShem, my G-d, brought us up to the land, not in our merits, but simply because HaShem had sworn to our fore-fathers that He would do so. HaShem is the Source of all things.


As Rashi points out in his comment about Devarim 26:3, you have none other than the priest who lives in your days (cf. Sifri; Rosh Hashana 25b). For such is the way of mortals, Eleazar ben Aharon HaCohen, was not like his father, Aharon HaCohen. Nor Yehoshua like Moses. The term priest () can also refer to nobles, for King Shlomo was not his father, King David. Moshe Rabbeinu saw the work of HaShem first-hand at Mount Sinai, but the Men of the Great Assembly did not. But it thanks to them that Judaism survived.


The Torah gives a speech that a Jew gave to the Cohen (), HaShem's representative, when giving the first-fruits, it mentions Lavan and the Egyptian Exile, two times where the entirety of the Jewish people were in one place and vulnerable to total destruction, and would have according to the laws of nature and logic. And yet, despite that, or because of that, HaShem, on our behalf, created miracles, operated outside of nature and logic, so that the Jewish people could survive. As the Pesach Haggadah states, In every generation they rise against us to destroy us; and the Holy One, blessed be He, saves us from their hand! According to nature and logic, the Jews with the odds against us, should have disappeared into the annuls of history, and yet, today, and every day, we remain. For we say, in various ways, Devarim 26:10, And here, now, I have brought the first of the fruits of the land that you, the Eternal, have given to me. It is the land and the first-fruits that were given to us.


The Midrash and stories of old tells of the parades and celebrations of the various Jews that brought the first-fruits to the Holy Temple. Jews would go in groups, families, friends, and whole communities would go, making it an enjoyable festival of celebration, celebrating the blessing that HaShem had bestowed upon them.


Devarim 26:16, This day HaShem your G-d commands you, to which Rashi comments, Each day they (HaShem's commandments) should be to you as something new (not antiquated and something of which you have become tired), as through you have received the commands that very day (Tanchuma; cf. Rashi on 11:13). Each day, each and every day, we should look anew upon the commandments of HaShem, as something beyond and transcending of time. The six hundred thirteen commandments that our fore-fathers and fore-mothers received at Mount Sinai, are still as applicable today as they were then. For those commandments are eternal as He would spoke them. HaShem was not commanding just talking to them, but to us, as well. Everything within the Torah is Divine Truth, many have tried to disprove the Torah and all have failed. It is not the world that changes, it's the people, and even then, the people just come up with different names for the same old things. As King Shlomo said, there is nothing new under the Sun. History repeats itself, the actors may change, but the stories remain the same.


Devarim 27:3, And when you cross over, you shall write all the words of this Torah on them So that any that entered the land will know what is expected. For the Children of Israel were commanded to engrave the Torah, in multiple of languages, in various stones, so no stranger could say they did not know the way of Jews, for it was craved in stone before them. And the later generations could see that what they had, was the same as before. Judaism does not hide anything, all are welcome and learn of Divine Wisdom of Torah, be they Jewish or Goyish. Goyim can learn of the Laws of Noach and more. Because of this, modern Western society exists based upon some Jewish concepts, mixed with their paganism. The American Fore-fathers looked towards the Torah for a blueprint to build their new society. We can only measure a society, but using an universal standard. And what better standard is there, then the Divine standard?


Devarim 27:8, explaining them well, Rashi expounds this to say, i.e. in seventy languages (Sota 32a; cf. Rashi on 1:5). These seventy languages, the languages that came out of the Tower of Babel, are the foundation of every spoken/written language on the planet. If you knew all seventy languages, there is no place on Earth, you would not be understood. And even, with but a few, you could make yourself understood in various regions.


Devarim 27:2, All these blessings will come upon you and reach you If you only heed the voice of HaShem, you need not worry about gathering in the blessings, they, the blessings, will come to you. Wherever you are, you can be blessed there. There is no place on or off the Earth, HaShem's blessing can not reach. Even if you obey HaShem's voice by not doing nothing when HaShem commands you to do so, meaning, you did not even have to lift a finger to fulfill the commandment, HaShem will come to you and bless you. You can be passive, when HaShem commandments it, and HaShem will do the work and bless you where you are. How much more so, if you are active and pursue HaShem's commandments will your Heart and Mind, will HaShem's blessing rain upon you.


Devarim 27:7, The Eternal will cause your enemies who rise up against you to be smitten before you. Along one path they will go out to you, but will flee before you in seven directions. Because you heeded the words of HaShem, HaShem, Himself, will fight for you. You need but fulfill the will of HaShem, then HaShem, Himself, will take care of the rest for you.


Devarim 27:15, then all these curses will come upon you and reach you. The reverse is also true. If you do not heed HaShem's words, if you do nothing when HaShem commanded you to do something, then, HaShem will bring the curses to you as well. The saying, No Pain, No Gain means in order to improve, you need to exercise, and to exercise, you need to use your muscles., and by using your muscles, especially in new ways, causes pain as the body adjusts to a new condition. We have so many ways to heed HaShem's words, and receive so many blessings, but on the other hand, there are many ways to fail HaShem, and cause misfortune to befall us.


The Parsha ends with Devarim 28:8, You shall keep the words of this covenant and carry them out, so that you may achieve success in everything that you do. How can you be successful, follow the ways of HaShem. If you partner with HaShem, HaShem, Himself, will work with you.


May the day come soonest, when the entire world will see with their very own eyes that we walk in the Ways of HaShem, and HaShem, Himself and no other, walks with us. May His righteous Mashiach come speedily in our days, so all the blessings of words of all His prophets be fulfilled for us.




Like? Dislike? Feedback always welcome.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Seitzei
entry.content:
''
Aug 14, 2013 / 5773 Elul 8 / ''


Parsha Ki Seitzei /
Devarim 21:10 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi



This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Seitzei. The Torah speaks of when the Israeli army of old fought, a soldier could take a captive to, Devarim 21:11, take her for your wife. To which, Rashi expounds, Torah is speaking only in view of man's evil inclination (Kidushin 21b). For if the Holy One, blessed be He, would not permit her, he would marry her although she would then be forbidden. However, if he does marry her, in the end he will hate her, for the Torah writes afterwards, (v. 15) If a man has two wives, one beloved, and another hated, etc., and ultimately he will beget a wayward and rebellious son by her (v 18). It is for this reason that these sections are put in juxtaposition (Tanchuma). Basically, the Creator of man's heart, knows His work, and therefore, fashioned safe-guards and warning for us to protect ourselves. While the Torah is talking here of human captives, metaphorically this can also be applied to Torah and non-Torah items or concepts as well. When we go out into the world, we are faced with many non-Torah concepts and practices that might catch our eye and fascination that we might wish to bring home. He that fashions the human heart knows and explains to us, not everything out there is a bad thing(tm) but we should not rush into it blindly, examine it over time, if it passes, it is a diamond in the rough, meaning it has value but also requires great effort to perfect it. Or after having some time to cool off, we realize that it is not for us, and move on.


Devarim 21:13 And she shall remove the clothes of her captivity. Rashi explains thus, Because these are fine, for the women of the heathen peoples adorned themselves in order to lure others (the enemy) to unchastity with them (Sifri). To continue the previous metaphor, non-Torah concepts can and will adorn themselves to appeal to our baser desires, and instead of prohibiting out-right, HaShem set up a process for us to help us through it.


Devarim 21:22, And if there is in a man a sin deserving of the judgment of death Rashi points out, The juxtaposition of these sections tells us that if a father and mother spare him (the rebellious son), he will in the latter end turn to mischief and commit sins for which he will become liable to the death penalty by the court (cf. Tanch.). For a sin will bring another sin, from a small big will over time lead to larger and larger sins. The opposite is also true, a blessing/good deed will bring another blessing/good deed, from a small blessing/good deed, will lead to larger and larger blessings/good deeds. Mitzvot/good deeds bring life, while sin will eventually bring death.


Devarim 22:5, For an abomination Rashi says that, This implies that the Torah forbids only the wearing of a garb that leads to abomination (unchastity) (cf. Sifri). The Torah forbids cross-dressing of the genders for the purpose of immorality. Thus, it is permitted for a woman to wear pants to protect her legs that a skirt would not. It would be permissible for a man to dress as a woman to hide from those that are hunting him to kill him.


Devarim 22:7, That is may be well with you Rashi points out, If an easy command which involves no monetary loss, Torah states, Do this in order that it may be well with you and you may prolong your days, it follows a fortiori the grant of the reward of commands which are more difficult (Chullin 142a). This is true of every commandment, every mitzvah, bring a bit of life to you when you do them so that teshivah, teffila and tzadakah, all commandments, can bring salvations from death.


Devarim 22:17, And they shall spread the cloth Rashi expounds this verse thus, This is a figurative expression; they must make the matter as white (as clear) as a sheet (Sifri; Kesubos 46a). While every word of Torah is truth, it is not limited to the literal meaning. If the matter does not include a cloth, all is not lost, if the matter can be made clear as a white sheet.


Devarim 23:8, You shall not abhor an Egyptian Rashi states, all in all (utterly), although they cast your male children into the river. And what is the reason? Because they were hosts in time of need; therefore although they sinned against you do not utterly abhor him. Although, the Egyptians did evil unto us, we should not hate them, for there was some good in them that they treated us well during Yosef's reign.

Devarim 23:9, The children that are born to them in their third generation Rashi comments, other nations, however, may be admitted at once. Thus you learn that he who causes a man to sin does him greater harm than if he kills him, for he who kills him, kills him as regard this world, whilst he who causes him to sin puts him out of this world and the world to come. Therefore Edom, though he met them with sword was not to be abhorred, and similarly the Egyptians who drowned them, while those (the Ammonites and Moabites) who caused them to sin where to be utterly abhorred (Sifri). One can take from this that the physical is temporally while the spiritual is eternal.


Devarim 23:14, you shall dig [a hole] with it, again and cover your excrement. One is not allowed to spoil nature or act like a mindless animal. Rather, one is to cover over one's self. Long before humans invited going green, HaShem instructed His children in how to live a green life.


Devarim 24:1, Because he has found some scandalous thing in her, Rashi remarks, It is his duty to divorce her because she should not find favor in his eyes (cf. Gittin 90a). Rashi is saying that the husband should not condone what immoral act she has done. Or should she condone an immoral act that her husband has done either.


Devarim 24:5, and make his wife whom he married happy. It is the duty of a husband to ensure his wife's happiness, and his wife, his happiness. For marriage is a partnership.


Devarim 24:12, You shall not sleep in his pledge Rashi explains, you shall not go to sleep having his pledge with you (Sifri; Bava Metzia 111b) In other words, the Torah is protecting the rights of the debtee from the debtor. If the debtee used something that he sleeps with, the debtor may hold it in guarantee only during the day, but come the night, when it is needed, the debtor may not hold on to it. Thus, the Torah protects the modest and emotions of the debtee.


Devarim 24:14, You must not withhold the wages of a poor or destitute hired worker Thus, HaShem wants to ensure that they that need their wage gets it promptly and considers it a sin if it is delayed. Know that every commandment that HaShem gives us, He too, performs Himself. Thus, we know if that when we are poor, our Employer, ensures we are paid in a timely and humane manner.


Devarim 24:17, You must not pervert the judgment of a proselyte [or] orphan For know that there is only One to whom we all can rely and call upon, especially those that have been placed in HaShem's care.


Devarim 24:19, When you reap your harvest in your field, and you forget a sheaf in the field, you must not go back to take it. It shall remain for the proselyte, the orphan and the widow, so that the Eternal, your G-d, may bless you in all your actions. How many are the wonders and mercies of HaShem, for merely forgetting, a passive action, we are blessed for all our actions. A simple thing, a absent-minded thing, no work on our part, and yet, we are blessed for it. Simply because HaShem decreed it. For something so simply, so passive, there is great reward, how much more so for something difficult and active!


Devarim 25:3, when your brother will be degraded, Rashi points out something that has been forgotten in our time, All the time it has been calling him wicked (vv. 1 and 2), but as soon as he has received the lashes it calls him your brother! (Sifiri) Once the punishment is finished, the crime is forgotten. Yes, we all mess up from time to time, but as HaShem forgives, so too must we, and we should not recall such thing again. For the punishment erases the crime.


The Torah speaks of a levirate marriage, and what is the purpose of a levirate marriages, Devarim 25:6, that his name be not wiped out. That the name of the deceased brother be forgotten. The common Jewish Law about this is that we don't perform this levirate marriage anymore. For details, please, ask a Rabbi.


Devarim 25:12, Then you shall cut off her head, Rashi explains this thus, she must pay money that is the equivalent of the shame to which he has been put; all according to the person who put him to shame and of him who was shamed. But perhaps this is not the meaning, but that you should cut off her hand, literally?! It states, however, here Your eye shall not pity her and it states there (19:21) in the laws concerning the plotting witnesses You shall not pity them; now, what is the case there? It is monetary compensation! So, too, here the intent is monetary compensation (Sifri; cf. B. Kam 28a). Which is why the Oral Torah is so important to properly understand the Written Torah.


Because Amalek did not fear HaShem when the Jews left Egypt, the Torah decrees, Devarim 25:19, You shall wipe away the remembrance of Amalek Rashi states, both man and woman, infant and suckling, ox and sheep, stating how the Amalekites should never again be mentioned even in connection with a beast, in that one could say: This beast belonged to Amalek (Pesikta Zuta). For such is the sins of Amalek such that nothing of them may remain.


In dealing with such non-Jewish ways, as Amalek, the only answer is total destruction. We cannot appease it nor compromise with it. We can only destroy it completely, if we wish to survive. It is said that HaShem took an oath saying that His throne is incomplete until Amalek is no more. May that day when Amalek is consumed by the holy fires of HaShem, on that day, HaShem's name will be one and there will be peace on Earth. May that day come soonest.


If you're read, make a comment/suggestion/feedback. Just say hi.

entry.title: Parsha Re'eh
entry.content:
''
Jul 31, 2013 / 5773 Av 24 / '' ''


Parsha Re'eh /
Devarim11:26 16:17
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi


Devarim 11:26. "Look! I am putting before you today blessings and curses." Each and every day, we have a choice, do we choose a blessing or a curse? Every action has a consequences that affects us and those around us, whether we see/feel them or not. As the saying goes, "no one is an island unto themselves."


So how can we distinguish between a blessing and a curse? Simple, Devarim 11:27, "The blessings that you heed the commandments of the Eternal, your G-d". Following the ways of HaShem will guarantee blessings, while the inverse, not following will result in curses. Like calls to like. Blessings causes other blessings, and curses causes other curses to come.


Devarim 12:2, "You shall utterly destory", Rashi comments, "Destroy and destroy agian! From here that he who eradicates an object of idol-worship must thoroughly root it up (Avodah Zara 45b)." Idols are stumbling blocks, and it is not enough to set them aside, but they must be removed completely, least others go astray.


Devarim 12:11. "the place where the Eternal, your G-d, chooses to establish". This is referring to Jerusalem, where the Holy Temples once stood and will again.


Devarim 12:15, "you may slaughter and eat meat in all your [towns] with all your heart's desire" Thus, it is permissible to eat meat besides the offerings. And unlike the offerings which could only be done inside the Holy Temple, regular slaughtering of meat for consumption can be done anywhere.


Devarim 12:20, "You may eat flesh" Rashi teaches us, "The Torah teaches the proper rule of life -- that one should not desire to eat flesh except amidst abundance and wealth (cf. Sifri; Chul. 84a; see also Rashi on Lev. XVII. 13)." While permitted, eating meat should be seen as a luxury, not a common thing.


Devarim 13:2, "If a prophet or a dreamer of a dream arises..." Here Moshe Rabbeinu tells us how we can tell if a prophet or dreamer is true or not. Basically, the Prophet or Dreamer has to be a follower of HaShem, and a follower of those Prophets or Dreamers that came before.


Devarim 13:13, "If you hear in one of your cities", here Moshe talks of a wayward city, and how it is to be dealt with. Our Sages say that this never happened, but its concepts and practices have much for us to learn from which is outside the scope of this blog.

Devatim 14:1, "You are children of the Eternal, your G-d. You must not slash yourselves or make a bald patch between your eyes for a dead person." This is the practice of the Goyim of that time, and we are not to follow it. We have our own mourning practices and need not follow the ways of others. Nor should be in such a state that when we lose someone we fell the leave to make a permanent taint upon us, for our love ones never truly depart from us, nor is death something unnatural.

Devarim 15:1, "At the end of seven years you shall institute a remissions [of loans]." On the Sh'mitta year, we recognize that our money isn't truly ours, but everything belongs to HaShem. What we are given is borrowed from HaShem and for us to use as He wills. We should not be so fixated on money that we come to worship it, as many Americans and others in our own days do. By remissing loans, we acknowledge our Creator and that money is not our reason for living. This is only for personal loans, loans owned to the community has separate laws and needs to be consulted with a Rabbi.

Devarim 16:17, "Each man according to his ability to give, in accordance with the blessing of the Etenral, your G-d, that He has given to you." We need to give to our ought most, for everything we have, we are given it by HaShem, so that we may give to others as we ourselves have been given. The poor can only give "poor" and the rich the "rich", that's not so say the poor can't give the rich, but the rich can't give poor. We must follow the example that HaShem, Himself, has set for us. Give as we have been given. From HaShem's hand, to ours, and from ours, to others that need. For this is why we are given that which we receive.

May HaShem give us the ultimate blessing the coming of Mashiach, speedily in our days.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
''
Jul 24, 2013 / 5773 Av 17 / '' ''

Parsha Eikev /
Devarim 7:12 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Eikev, the word Eikev () means because of for the Parsha opens by talking about consequences with, Devarim 7:12, It will be, you heed the seemingly insignificant of the these laws, and safeguard and carry tout, then the Eternal, your G-d, will keep for you the covenant and the kindness that He promised to your forefathers. One follows the other. The commandments are the way HaShem created the world. It can be liken to following a recipe: follow the recipe, correctly, and you get a lovely dish; but if you disregard it, you will end up with something unrecognizable and very possibly inedible.

Also of note is the wording of the statement, Devarim 7:12, seemingly insignificant for the Torah is talking to us, for to us, a commandment or stature might seem insignificant but comes the Torah and says, seemingly insignificant that in fact it is not actually insignificant. For we really do not know what the end result of the recipe of life is, but we do know that it involves the six hundred thirteen commandments. We do not know why affect the lack of an ingredient or substitution of an ingredient might have on the final result. A pinch of this or a dash of that, might not seem like much, but if they are concentrated or catalysts for other ingredients, their reaction might be disproportional to the end product.

He who fashioned the human heart, knows the heart, so the Torah says, Devarim 7:17, If you say to yourself, These nations are more numerous than I. How can I possibly drive them out? To which, the Torah itself answers, Devarim 7:18, do not be afraid of them. You shall constantly remember what the Eternal, your G-d, did to Par'oh and to all the Mitzrim. In other words, if one thinks to himself, according to logic and science, the many outweigh the few, or the one; therefore, there is no physical way to defeat a superior enemy. And the Torah agrees, this is true. For when the Jews were slaves to Par'oh, Egypt was the super-power of the ancient world, bar none, Par'oh ruled without question or foreign opposition. But then the Torah reminds us, Par'oh and Ancient Egypt, the super-power that it was, was no match for HaShem. The very power that made Ancient Egypt into a super-power, HaShem reversed and made it its down-fall.

Devarim 7:22, "lest the beasts of the field increase upon you", Rashi asks, "But is it not a fact that if people perform the will of the Omnipresent they will not have to fear the beasts, as it is said, (Iyov V. 23) "And the beasts of the field shall be at peace with you"?! But it was manifest before Him that they would in future sin." HaShem knows how things are going to plan out, but still leaves us hints and hope that we can do better on our own.

Devarim 8:1, "every commandment", Rashi explains, "And a Midrashic explanation is (taking it to mean "the whole of the commandment ... shall you be heedful to do"): If you have made a beginning with a meritorious deed, carry it out o the end, because it bears the name only of he who does the last part of it, as it said, (Yehoshua XXIV. 32) "And the bones of Yoseph which the Children of Israel brought up from Egypt they buried in Shecham". But did not Moshe alone busy himself with them to bring them up (cf Shemos XIII. 19)? But because he had no opportunity to complete this, the Israel completed it, it was called by their name. (Tanchuma)." This is how we merit the coming of Moshiach, for our forefathers started the meritorious work before us, and we will come it to bring Moshiach to us. As the saying goes, "the child upon the giant's shoulder can see far." Each generation allows its children to reach higher and higher.

Devarim 8:4, "did not swell", Rashi explains this phrase meaning, "like dough, as is usual with those who walk barefoot -- that their feet become swollen." Which, thank G-d, is not something I knew or familiar with.

The Land of Israel is blessed with Devarim 8:8, "a land of wheat, barley, vines (grapes), figs and pomegranates, a land of oil-producing olives and [date]". These are the seven species that the Holy Land is especially blessed with.

The Torah warned that we should not say, Devarim 8:17, "My strength and the power of my hand have amassed this wealth for me." To which the Torah answers, 8:18, "You shall then remember the Eternal, your G-d, for it is He who gives you the ability to amass wealth." While there is some truth that we have to put in the effort to amass wealth, it is HaShem who gave us the tools and the means to put in the effort to get that wealth.

The Torah further warns us, Devarim 8:19, "It will be, if you progressively forget the Eternal, your G-d, and follow the "gods" of others and worship them and bow down to them -- I am warning you today that you will surely perish." This can be liken to a metaphor, we are flowers and HaShem is the Sun, if a flower forgets the Sun, it will perish, for it needs the Sun to live. So too, do we need HaShem to live. Just as a flower can survive for a little while without the Sun, through the night, so too can those that sin, and just as the Sun return each day, so too, a sin can repent and bath in the light of HaShem again.

To what do we Jews have a right to the Land of Israel, the Torah tells us, Devarim 9:5, "Not because of your righteousness or your rectitude are you entering to take possession of their land, but because of the wickedness of these nations the Eternal, your G-d, is driving them out from before you, and in order to fulfill the word that the Eternal promised to your fore-fathers, Avraham, Yitzchak, and Ya'akov." It is not our merit that entitles us to the Land, but HaShem and His promise to our fore-fathers.

Devarim 10:10, "As the former days", Rashi tells us, "of the first tablets. How was it with those? In goodwill! So these, too, were in goodwill. But the intervening when I remained  there to pray for you in anger." So this tells us that Moshe stays on Mount Sinai for a total of one hundred twenty days, three sets of forty days. The first set of forty days in goodwill, receiving the first set of tablets. The second set of forty days were fulfilled with praying to pardon Israel, and the third and final set of forty days were in goodwill as well.

Devarim 10:12, "And now, O Israel", Rashi expounds this thus, "Although you did all this, yet His mercy and His love are over you, and in spite of all that you sinned against Him, He asks nothing of you." Although, HaShem could demand everything from us, He does not, because of His love and His mercy. He wishes for us to express our free choice and to choice Him.

Devarim 10:12, "Except to fear", Rashi says, "Our Rabbis derived from this everything is in the hands of HaShem except the fear of HaShem. (Berachos 33b)."

Devarim 10:18, "He executes judgment of the fatherless and the widow" Rashi explains this verse, saying, "You have power and together with His power you find His humility." We should learn that whereas a human being can only do one thing in one way, HaShem does many things in multiple ways. HaShem can and does show His power and humility at the same time. The ten Sefirot (attributes) that we describe to HaShem, are not separate, but all are present in HaShem, whereas in a human can only show one at a time.

Devarim 10:19, "[Love the stranger] for you were strangers" Rashi expands this verse, "Do not reproach your fellow man for a fault which is also your own (cf. Rashi on Shemos XXII. 20, B. Mets. 59b)." In the modern saying, "don't call the (black) kettle calling the pot black." Chassidus teaches us that others are mirrors into ourselves, we can only see faults in others because we ourselves have those faults within us. If we did not have those faults ourselves, we would not recognize it in others. How does someone describe "red" to a blind person whose been blind all his life? How does one describe an ocean to a desert-dweller? Only by using something that these people recognize can we describe something to someone else.

Also in blessing the Land, the Torah states, Devarim 11:11, "It is a land, which the Eternal, your G-d, cares for, the Eternal, your G-d, keeps a constant eye on it, from the beginning of the year until the end of the year." For the Holy Land has the special attention of HaShem, Himself, where he plans out everything for the Land from Rosh HaShanah to Rosh HaShanah. Never is the Holy Land out of the mind of HaShem, it is constantly before Him. Other nations are left to the "care" of Guardian Angels, but not Israel. Both the Land of Israel and Children of Israel are directly cared for by HaShem, Himself, not an angel.

Devarim 11:13-21 is the second paragraph of the Shema. The first paragraph of the Shema was in the previous week's Parsha. The first paragraph of the Shema was directed towards the individual, while the second paragraph is directed towards the community. A Jew needs to always remember that s/he is an individual, but also a part of the community. As the saying goes, "no one is an island onto themselves." As the Sage Hilel said, "If I am not for myself, who will be? But if I am only for myself, why am I here?" Yes, I am an individual but also a part of the Jewish Community. It is that duality that shapes us, neither is more important than the other, but both must exist

Devarim 11:22, "to walk in all His ways", how can we do this? Rashi tells us, "He is merciful, be you merciful. He bestows loving-kindness, bestow you loving-kindness (Sifrei)." We are created in HaShem's image, which is never more truer than when we act as HaShem does. As He is merciful and kind in loving-kindness, so too, we should be.

Devarim 11:22, "And to cleave to Him" Rashi asks, "Is it possible to say this? Is He not "a consuming fire" (IV. 24)? But it means cleave  to the scholars and sages, and I will account it to you as though you cleave to Him. (Sifrei)." For no human can truly grasp HaShem, we can only hold onto that which He has shared with us. By holding onto those that study Him, we too can be close to him.

Devarim 11:25, "No man shall stand" Rashi questions, "I have here the statement only regarding a man! Whence may I derive that the same applies to a nation or a family or a woman with her witchcraft? Because it states: "there shall be no standing before you" under any circumstances. -- If so, why does it speak of a man? It means a man, be he even as Og, king of Bashan. (Sifrei, cf. Rashi on III. 11)."

When we stand with HaShem, walk in His ways, no one shall stand in our way. May the day come soonest when the world will see HaShem, Himself, lead us to our Land and none will stand against us, for there will be peace in the land and the world. Amen.





Please leave a comment, suggestion, or something to say you exist and are reading these words of mine.
Shabbat Shalom.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eschanan
entry.content:
Jul 17, 2013 / 5773 Av 10 /

Parsha Vaeschanan /
Devarim 3:23 7:11
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This Shabbat is called Shabbat Nachamu ( ), it is the first of the seven Haftarahs of Consolation. It is also interesting of note that there are only three Haftarahs of Reproach, and yet there are seven Haftarahs of Consolation. Thats double plus one, for HaShems mercy is always greater than His wrath. As it has been said, Aprils showers bring Mays flowers. Out of HaShems correction comes comfort and many blessings.

While the Haftarah is about comfort, the Torah Parsha is Parsha Vaeschanan. The word Vaeschanan means I begged, which Rashi comments, All forms of the verb signify a gift for free. Although the righteous might make a claim to reward dependent upon their good deeds, they solicit from the Omnipresent only a gift without payment. Because [G-d] has said to [Moshe], I will show grace () to him to whom I shall show favor, Moshe, when referring to his entreaty to G-d uses the expression I implored grace (). Another explanation of the word is that this is one of the ten terms by which prayer is described, as are enumerated in Sifrei.

So we have a Torah Parsha named for praying and a Haftarah Parsha about comforting. The connection should be obvious. Even in our darkest of hours, we have prayed for comfort and salvation from the Eternal, Blessed be He, who has saved us. If it was not for HaShems mercy, we, the Jewish People, would not exist. Nor have existed for so long.

Rashi comments on Devarim 3:26, You have enough, saying, so that people should not say, How harsh is the Master, and how obstinate and persistent is the disciple (Sota 13b). Another explanation of there is much for you, more than this is reserved for you: much is goodness that is stored up for you (Sifrei). Moshe Rabbeinu had requested/prayed to enter the Holy Land, so that he could perform the Mitzvot that are unique and limited to the Land of Israel. But HaShem said to him that it was not needed of him to do so, it was others duty. We should be mindful of the limits that HaShem has placed upon us, and tread very carefully at their edges. The Talmud relates to us that four Sages entered the mystic orchard (a place/event beyond Human understanding): Ben Azzai died, Ben Zoma went insane, Elisha ben Avuyah became a heretic, and Rabbi Akiva entered in peace and left in peace. Those are not good odds It was not that Moshe was greedy wanting more for himself, rather, he wished to fortify the Jewish people and praise HaShem more, for HaShems sake.

HaShem instructs Moshe regarding Yehoshua, Devarim 3:28, and strengthen him and make him steadfast. Rashi expounds this, saying, through your words, so that he may not become faint-hearted, saying, Just as my master was punished on account of them, so eventually will I be punished on account of them. I promised him for he will cross over before the people, and he will settle them. (Sifrei). For Moshe was likened to the Sun, and Yehoshua to the Moon, and Yehoshua knew this.
