If Moshe was not allowed to finish his mission, how could Yehoshua hope to? And he was right, the reason that Yehoshua could fulfill his mission was become HaShem commanded it. We should never forget, it is not our success, but HaShems assistance that allows us to be successful.

Devarim 4:2, You must not add to that I am commanding you, nor subtract from [it]. Rashi uses five passage of Tefillin as an example of what we cannot add to the commandments. The passages for the Tefillin are mentioned in the Torah, but which four are from the Oral Torah. We might think that to enhance a mitzvah it would be okay to add another passage to enlarge the Tefillin. Comes the Torah and says dont. The Torah is perfect, it needs neither addition nor subtraction to whats there. It is this reason that Judaism has lasted as long as it has. A Jew of today could easily go into a Shul of yesterday, a century ago, a thousand years ago, and they would hear the same prayers, the same Torah wisdom, and the same Judaism. Other religions over time change, drift as they are man-made and change with those that made it.

Devarim 4:6, You shall safe-guard and do, for this you wise and intelligent in the eyes of the nations, who will hear about all these statues and say, This great nation is purely a wise and intelligent people.' And where does this wisdom and intelligence come from? From the Torah, its study and practice. Torah is Divine wisdom, and our practice of the commandments is our intelligence.

Devarim 4:20, The Eternal took you and brought you out of the iron furnace, Egypt, to be His designated people, as today. Rashi comments that furnace as in a vessel to which one refines gold. Our Sages say that the Egyptian exile was the prototype of all the exiles, including our current one. Just as the Torah says that the Egyptian exile was a crucible, so too, is the current exile a refinement for us as well. Gold is held to be the most important and special of the metals. Its value comes from its scarcity and appearance. So too, the Jewish People are of small in number and our deeds shine brighter than another nation. Once our refinement is complete, our exile will end. May it be soonest.

Devarim 4:25, And will have been for a long time, Rashi expounds this verse and informs us, He gave them a vague intimation that they would be exiled from it at the end of 852 years, according to the numerical value of , but He sent them into exile earlier, at the end of 850 years. He did this two years earlier than , in order that you will be completely destroyed should not be fulfilled in them (c 26). This is what is said, (Daniel IX. 14) For G-d hastened in regard to the evil, and He brought it upon us, for G-d our G-d is charitable -- He acted charitably with us, in that He brought it (the evil) two years before its time (Sanhedrin 38a, Gittin 88a). For Moshe knew through prophecy what would happen to the Children of Israel and warned them. Alas, the warning was not heeded. Evil prophecies can be avoided through prayer, repentance, and charity.

Devarim 4:26, I hereby call the heavens and the earth as witnesses today, Why was the heavens first? Our Sages say, as Moshe knew the time of his death was upon, his thoughts were more on spiritual/heavenly matters rather than material/terrestrial matters. Moshe called both as it is said, let the witnesses come and fulfill the punishment, as the heavens/rain and the earth/planting would be part of the punishment, they would serve as witness to Moshes warning as well.

Devarim 4:31, He will not let you slip, Rashi explains, from holding onto you with His hands. The expression is an expression signifying: He will not cause something (Hiphil). He will not separate you from Him. Similar is (Song. III. 4) I hold him fast, and I will not let him loose (), which is not vowelled. Always the expression letting slack () refers to one who causes looseness to others or to one who caused it to himself. For example (2 Kings IV. 2) give her looseness; (IX. 14) Give looseness to yourself from off me. For such is our relationship with HaShem, there is an eternal bond between us. Each mitzvah is a cord connecting us to our Source. Our very souls are a piece of HaShem, Himself, as we are made in His image. Even when a Jew acts foolishly and dirties themselves, HaShem is still with us. It is a bond that transcend the present, grounded in the past and future.

Devarim 4:33, Did people hear the voice of G-d speaking from within the fire as you heard, and remain alive? This is what separates Judaism from other religions. Other religions, some individual had something happened to them, they told others as there wasnt anyone else there, and others followed them to learn that something. Judaism, we all heard directly from HaShem, and saw HaShem speak to Moshe Rabbeinu. No one had to tell us what had happened, we were there. Our Sages also say that after HaShem spoke, the people could not handle the experience and expired, only for HaShem to revive them.

Devarim 4:45, These are the testimonies etc. that [Moshe] had told Rashi remarks that, Those are the very same testimonies etc., which he spoke when they came out of Egypt; and he again repeated it (this law) to them in the plains of Mo'av. The entire Sefer of Devarim is a repetition of the previous commandments, as well as some new information, for Moshe wished to ensure that the Jewish People knew all of what he had taught from Sinai. So like a teacher that he was, he reviewed the material before it was tested/used.

Devarim 5:3 with us, we who here today, all of us alive. Seems redundant to me, and the Torah is very picky in what is written. Moshe said today, but he said then, but he said today to include us as well, we that came after those he addressed directly. He was speaking not only to them, but to us, would come after, each of us in our present, when it is our present.

Devarim 5:28, But you, yourself, stay here with Me and let Me tell you all the commandments, statutes and laws that you shall teach them[...] Here, the Torah refers to the literal, the Written Law, and the Oral Torah. For HaShem said He would teach all, but the Written Law only has hints of the various commandments, statues and laws, the rest is recorded within the Oral Torah.

The first paragraph of the Shema can be found starting at Devarim 6:4, Listen, Israel, The Eternal is our G-d, and The Eternal is one.

Devarim 6:20, Your child asks you, from this verse to the rest of the chapter, we are instructed to teach our children of the Exodus and Torah. This (and others) are the bases for the Haggadah that is used at the Pesach night sedar.

Devarim 7:1. seven nations, more numerous and mightier than you. It is not but might or virtue that the Jews inherited the Land of Israel, but simply because HaShem, the Creator of the World decreed it. In the logical world, the Israelites could never have done so, for the seven nations had both numbers and strength greater than the Children of Israel had. But because HaShem was with them and Yehoshua, the Holy Land became their to be made holy.

Devarim 7:9, for a thousand generations Rashi points out, But elsewhere (V. 10) it states to thousands (plural)! Here where it is adjacent to those who keep His commandments out of fear of G-d, it states to a thousand (singular); but there where it is adjacent with those who love Him, who server G-d out of love, whose reward is greater, it states to thousands (plural) of generations (Sota 13a). What Rashi is pointing out that the reward for loving HaShem is far greater and more preferred over fearing Him. Back in Bereishit 25:19, Isaac the son of Abraham; Abraham begot Isaac, our Sages say that Abraham represents love of HaShem and Isaac represents fear of HaShem and thus, Chassidic thought is that fear of HaShem is born from thelove of HaShem, and from fear of HaShem a love of HaShem comes as well. Each are connected as father and son.

Devarim 7:10, But to those who hate Him, he repays during their lifetime time what good they may have done Why? Rashi tells us, in order to cause them to perish from out of the future world (Onkelos). For HaShem repays all His debts. For the righteous, He stores them for when needed/later, for the wicked, He pays them immediately, so their wickedness may be paid in full as well.

What future world does Rashi speak of? The world to come, when Mashiach comes. Our world of darkness will then be illuminated by HaShem Himself. On that day, His name will be One, and we will live with Moshe Rabbeinu and our ancestors once more, and we will learn Torah directly from HaShem, as Moshe once did. May that day come speedily in our days. Amen.


Please, leave a comment, thank you, that's nice, suggestion, or some form of feedback.
Every bit counts.

Shabbat Shalom

entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
''
Jul 11, 2013 / 5773 Menachem Av 4 / '' ''

Parsha Devarim /
Devarim 1:1 3:22
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Devarim, the first Parshiot of the Sefer Devarim. I began this blog with Parsha Devarim, and I will continue it, G-d willing, for many years to come. It has been an interesting task to do a weekly blog on the weekly Parsha. The Divine words are the Torah, it all comes from HaShem.

Words began Creation and words keep it going.

The word "Devarim" means "words," as the Parsha begins, Devarim 1:1, "These are the words." Up until now, what has been recorded as tradition tells us via HaShem commanding Moshe Rabbeinu to write it down, letter by letter. Now, here, the student is presenting what he has learned to others. In Moshe's final and last moments in this life, we see Moshe presenting HaShem's words not as HaShem dictated, but through Prophecy. A transition has taken place. All other Prophets received their "instructions" from HaShem, and they carried it out in their own way, which Moshe, himself, does here.

Moshe, unlike others, knows that he is about to pass-away, and like our Fore-father Ya'akov, he begins by reproaching the People, but he does so indirectly, as Rashi points out, Devarim 1:1, "These are the words," Rashi writes, "Because these are the words of reproof and is enumerating here all the places where they provoked G-d to anger, therefore it suppresses the matters and refers to them by allusion out of regard for Israel (Sifri, Onkelos and Targum Yonasan)."

What a scene that must have been. The entire nation of Israel stood there, on the verge of entering the Holy Land, and Moshe is reproofing them for the sins of their parents, for all that had sinned had passed away. They, who stood before Moshe, were but children, spouses, or the Tribe of Levi that had not taken part int he sins of their fellows.

But they were all silent.

None replied, but that wasn't us... or we were but children... or the sinners you have mentioned are gone.

They were silent.

Not only were they silent, but they accepted upon themselves the reproof from Moshe Rabbeinu as if it was their own.

Why?

The Sages have many reasons why, but this is my blog, let us see what I can come up with.

My first thought is, of course, simply because it came from Moshe Rabbeinu. Moshe was to his generation as Ya'akov Avinu was to his children. Both reproofed their children out of love and desire to see them improve.

Yes, they had not done any of the sins directly, But, they did not rebuke or stop the others from sinning. And that is why we are, where we are now. Yes, we acknowledge that we have sin, and our fathers before us has sin, but do we stop others from sinning? Alas, no. most have the attitude, it's hard enough not sinning myself, how much more so to prevents others from sinning.

Comes Moshe Rabbeinu and tells us, it is very important to watch out for our brothers and sisters, as the children of the generation that left Egypt stood and took the rebuke of what their fathers had done. Because the potential of the parents is passed onto the children. Passed on in tradition, in speech, in our words.

When you listen to the Torah reading this Shabbat, know that you are hearing the very words of Moshe Rabbeinu, speaking not only to those that stood before him then, but to you as well. Words to Words.
From HaShem's "mouth" to Moshe's ear. Moshe's mouth to Yehoshua's ear, and so on, from Rabbi to Rabbi. The words reverberate throughout history.

Even in Moshe's reproof, it took the time to reassure the people that the land was good. Devarim 3:9, "Tzidonim would call Chermon", Rashi informs us, "But in another passage it states, Devarim VI 48, "Even to Mount Sion which is Chermon." So you see it had four names. And why had they all to be written? To tell the praise of the land of Israel: that there were four kingdoms priding themselves in this -- one saying, "After me shell it be named", and another saying, "After me shell it be named" (Sifri, Chullin 60b)." History repeats itself, there are so many that try to claim Israel for their own. For the land, itself, has Holiness. But HaShem, Himself, has decreed that the Land of Israel is for Israel, and no other.

As it is said, the medicine is bitter but it will help heal you. Just as Moshe Rabbeinu reproofed the People before entering the Land, so too as HaShem, Himself, reproofed us over the centuries. Just as within that reproof of Moshe there were blessings and assurances, how much more so, in HaShem's.

This is Shabbat Chazon, the Shabbat of Vision, in some way, our Sages tell us, we will receive a vision of the Third Temple on this Shabbat.This coming Monday night and Tuesday,, we morn the loss of the Holy Temple that stood in Jerusalem. May it be that this Shabbat Chazon should be more than a mere vision but an actuality. From Moshe's mouth to our own, we beg for the coming of Mashiach to take us out of this final exile and into the redemption. An end to the reproofs and the start of the blessings. As it was, so shall it be again.

entry.title: Parsha Matos-Masei
entry.content:
''
Jul 4, 2013 / 5773 Tammuz 26 / '' ''

Parsha Matos-Masei / -
Bamidbar 30:2 36:13
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is a double Parsha of Parsha Matos-Masei, combining Parsha Matos and Parsha Masei into one Parsha. Parsha Masei is also the last Parsha of the Sefer Bamidbar, so it's the Shabbat before Rosh Chodesh Av, making it Shabbat Mevarekhim. Thus, on this Shabbat, after the completion of seventh aliyah reading, we say, ! ! ! (Chazak! Chazak! Venischezeik! Be strong! Be strong! And may we be strengthen!) Which we say after the ending of each of the Sefer of Torah.

And yet, is very fitting upon the Shabbat that will bless the Month of Menachem Av we say, Be strong! For the month of Av has been a dark time within our History, accumulating on the (the Ninth of Av) the Fast Day marking the passage of the First and Second (Holy Temple in Jerusalem) fell and other disasters, for further reading check out Aish HaTorahor Chabad in Cyberspace. Out Sages say that with the coming of Menachem Av our joy is lessen. It is important to note that they say lessen not eliminated or removed, merely lessen. It is interesting that the Jewish month of Elul (), a month of healing and reflection, follows Menachem Av. We need to take the lessons of Sefer Bamidbar into ourselves to strengthen ourselves to fully understand and learn what the coming month and future holds for us.

So what is Parsha Matos-Masei about?

The Parsha Matos starts about vows and their nullification. It starts with Bamidbar 30:2, This is what [the Eternal has commanded], which Rashi points out, Moshe prophesied with words, So says G-d, 'About midnight (Shemos XI. 4), and other prophets prophesied with Thus says G-d, Moshe, however, had an additional superiority in that he prophesied also with the expression (Exactly) This is what [The Eternal has commanded] (Sifrei). Another explanation of This is what [the Eternal has commanded it is a restrictive phrase to intimate that the Sage uses invalidating, and the husband the expression annulling, as is the language of Torah here, and that if one of them exchanges, it (the vow) is not invalidated nor annulled (Sifrei; Nedarim 77b). Three words, and we learn about the specialty of Moshe's prophesy and the procedure for removing vows. For such is the power of vows that they can not be ignored, but if there is a valid case against the vow there is a strict procedure that must be followed to clear them. Anything less, is a sin, for the Torah tells us, Bamidbar 30:3, he must not violate his word.

Bamidbar 30:6, and the Eternal will forgive her, Rashi explains this verse, thus, Of what is Torah speaking? Of a woman who, vowed that she would become a Nazarite, and whose husband heard and annulled for her, but she did not know, and transgressed her vow and drank wine or made herself unclean by means of a corpse. It is such a woman who requires even through though it (her vow) has been annulled. And if those whose vows have been annulled require forgiveness, how much more is this so for those whose vows have not been annulled! (Kiddushin 81b) Vows should not be taken lightly or handled loosely.

Bamidbar 31:2. [exact the revenge of the Children of Israel] from the Midyanim, Rashi points out, but not of the Moavites, for the Moavites entered into the matter out of fear, because they feared that they might be plundered, since it was stated only, (Devarim II. 9) Do not contend with them in battle; but the Midianites, however, had become enraged over a quarrel that did not concern them. Another explanation, because, of the two fine young doves (virtuous women) which I am to bring forth from them Ruth the Moavitess, and Naamah the Ammonitess, King Shlomo's wife (Bava Kama, 38b). HaShem takes into account the motives of the people's actions, both for blessing and for cursing. Blessed is the Righteous and cursed is the wicked. For these two sakes, their people were protected, for such is the power of a virtuous/righteous person. Their merits protect their people.

Bamidbar 31:3, Moshe then spoke Rashi tells us the trait of a Jewish leader, Although he had heard (v 2) that his death was associated with this matter, he did it gladly and did not delay. And thus, Moshe Rabbeinu is the standard upon which all Jewish leader are held to. This also tells us of the righteousness of Moshe that so eager was he to do HaShem's commandment, regardless what it entailed, he did it joyfully and as soon as he could, even when it meant hasten his death.

Bamidbar 31:3, The Eternals revenge Rashi notices that the original verse mentioned the vengeance of the Children of Israel (v. 2) but here it's vengeance for HaShem, to which, Rashi says, because whoever attacks Israel is as though he attacks the Holy One, blessed be He. It is because of HaShem and all that He has done for us that the nations of the world attack us. For those that challenge Israel, are truly challenging HaShem, Himself.

Bamidbar 31:5, [A thousand men from each tribe, from the thousands of Israel] were given over, Rashi expounds this verse thus, To tell you in what high esteem the shepherds of Israel were held how dear they were to Israel. Before they had heard of his death what does it state? They are almost ready to stone me! (Shemos XVII. 14). But when they heard that Moshe's death was associated with the vengeance of Midian (v. 2), they refused to go to war until they were handled over against their own will (Sifrei). For the Children of Israel did not wish to see Moshe Rabbeinu die, while he was alive, they might complain, but as his death neared, they held him dear.

Bamidbar 31:6, them with Pinchas, Rashi says, tell us that Pinchas was regarded as equal to all of them together. But why did Pinchas go and El'azar did not go? The Holy One, blessed be He, said, He who made a beginning with this meritorious work, in that he slew Kozbi the daughter of Tzur, let him complete it. Another explanation that he went to take vengeance for Yosef, his mother's ancestor, as it is said, And the Midianites sold him [to Egypt]. And from where that Pinchas' mother was of Yosef? Because it is said, (Shemos VI 25) one of the daughters of Putiel of the seed of Yisro who used to fatten calves for idolatrous worship, and of the seed of Yosef who overcame his passions (Sifrei; Sota 43a). Because he was the high priest anointed for war purposes (Devarim XX 2) (Sota 43a). In other words, what one starts, he should finish.

Bamidbar 31:8, [and Bil'am the son of Be'or they killed] by the sword Rashi tells us, He came against Israel exchanging his medium (the sword) for their medium (the mouth), for they conquer only through their mouth through prayer and petition, and he came and availed himself of their craft to curse them with his mouth. They, therefore, also came against him and exchanged their craft for the craft of the heathen peoples who come with the sword, as it is said, (Bereishit XXVII. 40) And your sword shall you live For thus justice was served, an exchange for an exchange. Measure for measure is the justice and righteous way.

Bamidbar 31:14, Moshe then became angry with the Army commanders, Rashi explains why saying, Those appointed over the soldiers, to teach you that every misdeed of a generation is attributed to the leaders since these have the power to prevent it (Sifrei). A commander is responsible for his followers, but physically and spiritually. If you have the power to prevent a person from sinning, and not, you are accountable, for the reason why you had that power was to prevent it.

Bamidbar 31:21, El'azar the Cohen then said, why was it El'azar not Moshe that said it? Rashi answers, Because Moshe fell into anger (v. 14) he fell into error: there escaped him the laws concerning the removal of impurity of heathers. This, too, do you find on the eighth day of the installing of the Cohenim, as it is said, (Vayikra X. 16) And he was angry with El'azar and Itamar, he fell into anger; he fell into error. Similarly, also, (XX. 10, 11) Hear, now, you rebels, he smote the rock; it was through anger that he made the mistake (Sifrei; Pesachim 66b). As our Sages say, it is foolishness that causes one to sin, and it is anger that causes one to err. Our emotions can get the best of us. How do we combat this? Chasidism teaches us, the mind should rule the heart, so that foolishness and anger should not lead us to stray.

Bamidbar 31:49, They [army commanders] said to Moshe, Your servants have calculated that total number of troops who are with us, and not one man of ours is missing. Thus, the Army Commanders brought an offering to HaShem for thanksgiving of their deliverance. It is the nature of war that there will be causalities and injuries. The commanders knew this, so when they saw that all their soldiers had survived (against the nature of war), they knew it was a miracle and thanks their Shield for His mercy.

Bamidbar 32:5, They then said, If you regard us favorably, may this land be granted by your servants as a permanent possession. While the Torah states they had said this because of their livestock, our Sages say that they wished to have the merit to be near the burial place of Moshe Rabbeinu, thus it was a favor that they should reside there.

Bamidbar 32:16, We will build here for our livestock Rashi points out, They paid more regard to their property than to their sons and daughters, because they mentioned their cattle before their children. Moshe said to them, Not so! Make that which is of primary importance primary, and that which is of secondary importance secondary. First build cities for your little ones and afterwards enclosures for your flocks (v. 2) (Tanchuma). This is a lesson for us. We need to put what's important first, and after that, everything else in its place. Our family comes first, then our property. People before animals. Life before inanimate. How many of us are more worried about what our houses look like than how well they are a home.

Bamidbar 32:33, and to half the tribe of Menashe the son of Yosef Where did that come from? It was the Tribes of Gad and Re'uven that were asking for an inheritance on the east side of the Jordan (now called Jordan). How did the tribe of Menashe get involved? Our Sages tells us that Moshe wished to protect the tribes of Gad and Re'uven by splitting the tribe of Menashe, who held a love of the Land of Israel as their father Yosef did. Thus, Moshe hoped to save Gad and Re'uven on the other side of the Jordan with Menashe's influence and their going between there and the Holy Land. I think this is interesting in that Moshe troubled himself with making so Yosef's bones made it to the Land of Israel, thus, his children would trouble themselves to watch over Moshe's bones.

Bamidbar 33:1, These are the stopping places, Rashi asks, Why are these stations recorded here? In order to make known the loving acts of the Omnipresent: that although He had decreed against them to make them move about and wander in the wilderness, you should not think they wandered and moved about without cessation from one station to another station all the forty years, and that they had no rest, for you see there are here only forty-two stages. Deduct from that fourteen, all of which were in the first year, before the decree was made, from when they journeyed from Ra'amses until when they came to Rismah, from where the spies were sent out as it said (XII 16): And afterwards the people journeyed from Chatzeros, Send for you men; and here (v. 18) it states, They journeyed from Chatzeros and encamped at Rismah, you learn that it (Rismah) is in the wilderness of Paran. Further deduct from them the eight stations which were after Aharon's death, those from Mount Hor to the plains of Mo'av in the fortieth year (v 38). It follows that during the whole of the thirty eight years they made only twenty journeys. This is from the work of Rabbi Moshe the Preacher.
Rabbi Tanchuma gave another explanation of it. A parable! A king whose son was ill and whom he took to a distant place to cure him. When they returned home the father began to enumerated all the stages. Saying to him, Here we slept, here we caught cold, here you had a head-ache, etc.
Thus it should not be said that the Jews wandered aimlessly in the desert for forty years, rather there was a purpose to where and when HaShem took our ancestors within the desert. And even today, HaShem gives us to each of the places we are for a reason, whether we understand that reason or not, it is there. As the saying goes, life is a journey, not a destination. We are journeying through life, each with a starting point, milestones/stations, and end point in mind of HaShem. We may not recognize them as such, but is our fault.

Bamidbar 33:44, But if you do not drive out the inhabitants of the land from before you, it will be, that those of them whom you leave over like pins in your eyes and like hedges of thorns on sides [...] No truer statement had been made. History has shown us that in allowing the Goyim to stay with us and continue to practice their "ways" has caused nothing but problems for us. Having said that there is a difference between Goyim that follow the ways of B'nai Noach, and those that don't. It those that don't that are the issue. Their corruption spreads like a cancer to all that surround them. As was said, "woe to the sinner, woe to his neighbors." When a Jew allows his foolishness to overcome him, it is but temporarily. But with a Goy, they take it to another level. One need only to look around us at the various countries to see the corruption and the acceptance of corruption spread.

What does the Torah mean by Bamidbar 35:2, open spaces? Rashi answers, an area consisting of an open space round about the city outside, serving to beautify the city. It was not permitted to build houses there nor to plant vineyards nor to sow a plantation (Rashi Arachin 33b). In other words, land conservation is a Biblical commandment. While we may have a city to live in, the surrounding area outside of the city should be left alone to enhance the appearance of the city.

Bamidbar 35:11, refuge cities, what were these? In Biblical times, an accidental murderer had to escape to one of these cities, where he would be tried proving it was an accident, and he would remain there until the Cohen HaGadol () passed away. If the accidental murderer did not do so, a related of the murdered man may take his life, whether this is a Biblical commandment to do or merely the consequence of such an action, the Sages debate. This is only if it was an accident, if it was deliberate, then the court carries out its Judgment. Why does an accidental murderer have to go through this? Because some sin of his caused him to be selected as the one to carry out this action. Our Sages tells us that Moshe asked about this, and HaShem answered that what was happening that the murdered man, in this example, was actually a killer whom no Earthly court could convict, therefore, the Heavenly court arranged it such that a sinner of some magnitude, also unconvictable by Earthly court, would accidental murder the intentional murder before witnesses, and this sinner would stay in the city of refuge as his penance for his sin(s). The city of refuge were run by the Tribe of Levi. The forty-two cities given to the Leviyim also had this protective quality as well. And what did the Leviyim do in these cities? They lived, studied Torah, and prepared themselves for their Temple service. While the accidental murderer would be there, some of those good traits might rub off, for our Sages say, blessed is the righteous, blessed is their neighbors. The Torah gives concepts what is murder and what is accidental murder.

Whether or not a murderer is done intentional or accidental, the Torah tells us, Bamidbar 35:27, his [death] is not [considered] bloodshed As Rashi explains, He is as one who has killed a dead man, who is one who has no blood (Rashi on Shemos XXII. 1).

The Torah warns, Bamidbar 35:31, and you must not accept ransom money. For you might say, one Israelite has already been killed, shall we not be merciful and allow this murderer to live so there would not be more bloodshed? The Torah says this is not so. In fact, this is against justice and mercy.

Bamidbar 35:34, For I am the Eternal who dwells among the Children of Israel, Rashi adds, for even when they are unclean MyShechinah remains among them (Sifrei). In other words, HaShem is with us, even when we are not deserving of it, but because of HaShem's love for us, He remains and is among us.

The Sefer Bamidbar is finished with Bamidbar 36:13, These are the commandments and laws that the Eternal commanded the Children of Israel through Moshe, in the plains of Mo'av by the [River] Yarden [at] Yerecho. Thus, we are told that HaShem, through Moshe Rabbeinu, prepared the Children of Israel for their settlement of the Land of Israel. Just as HaShem was with Moshe and the people at Sinai, so too was HaShem with the people just outside the Land of Israel, and would be with us to this day. So the commandments and laws at the beginning of their journey from Egypt was the same commandments and laws at the end of their journeying.

!! !
Chazak! Chazak! Venischezeik!
Be strong! Be strong! And may we be strengthen!

May we be strengthen and allow Sefer Bamidbar to enter into our lives for blessing and for peace.
May the ultimate peace and blessing, the righteous Mashiach come this day, so that this Tisha B'Av might as the Sages say be changed from a very tragic day into a joyful day.
May we not need to fast anymore but sing to HaShem in wonder and awe, forever more.


If you got this far, please, please, leave me a note, comment, suggestion on how I'm doing. A writer of any kind lives for feedback, to improve himself and acknowledgment that he is writing.

entry.title: Parsha Pinchas
entry.content:
Jun 26, 2013 / 5773 Tammuz 18 /

Parsha Pinchas /
Bamidbar 25:10 30:1
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This weeks Parsha is Parsha Pinchas. This is the sixth and last Parsha that is named after a person. The first was Noach. The others are the Matriarch Sarah (Chayei Sarah), Yisro, Korach, and Balak. While each of these persons were honored with a Parsha named after them, none of them we say of Be like ..., in fact, we are warned dont be like Korach. And yet, their names are immortalized as names of the Parshiot.

Which begs the question, who was Pinchas? The Torah tells us, Bamidbar 25:11, Pinchas, the son of Elazar, the son of Aharon the Priest. To which Rashi tells us why this stated, Because the tribes spoke disparagingly of him, Have you seen this grandson of Puti, whose mothers father used to fatten calves for idolatrous sacrifices (see Shemos 6:25 that Elazar, his father, had married a daughter of Putiel who is identified with Yisro; see Rashi on that verse and Shemos 18:1), and he had dared to slay a prince of one of Israels tribe!, therefore Torah comes and connects his genealogy with Aharon (Sanhedrin 83b). Whats the deal?

We know from the previous Parsha that the daughters of Moav and Midyan were given to harlotry to sin with the Israelites, which caused HaShems anger to flare against them. By Pinchass zealotry, the Israelites were saved. So why were they disparaging Pinchas, who calmed HaShem down? And why bring up that Pinchass grandfather was Yisro (whom another Parsha is named after)? Whats going on? Our Sages have several explanations, of which I cant do justice to so I suggestion looking that up or asking a Rabbi about.

There is a lesson here, I think, that needs to be addressed. Our Sages say that Zimri the son of Salu, a prince of the tribe of Shimon, did what he did for the sake of his brethren. In other words, he jumped on the bandwagon of what was currently happening. How many of us have done the same? Whether our intentions are noble or not, how often do we bow to peer pressure or the like and just accept things in the name of :tolerance or progress? Comes the Torah and tells us that even through Zimri's intentions were for the good of his tribe, he was still wrong and his punishment at the hands of Pinchas was just. Not only was it just, but it was the true way of Peace. Yet, the several critics of Pinchas felt that he was cruel in his actions, an excuse to use violence from someone who, they thought, was cruel by nature (as an idolater that fattens up his sacrifices). But, HaShem, Himself states that his zealotry is born from Aharon HaCohen, a man of peace and a pursuer of peace. The message here is that we should not tolerate wrongs others accept it. Wrong is wrong, be it a prince or a commoner, old or young, man or woman.

Bamidbar 25:15, And the name of the slain Midyani woman, Rashi tells us, to show you the hatred of the Midianites bore that they abandoned a princess to prostitution in order to make Israel sin (Tanchuma). For such it the madness of hate that they who worship madness seek to destroy even themselves. Alas, it is something we see in the news every day. Hatred of the Jews clouds everything.

Bamidbar 25:18, For they harassed you through the matter of Pe'or, Rashi points out, in that they abandoned their daughters to prostitution in order to lead you astray after Pe'or. But He did not command them to destroy the Moavites, on account of Ruth who would later on issue from them, just as we state in Bava Kamma (38b). For the sake of one, the world was created. For the sake of Ruth, the Moavites were not destroyed, although they were worthy of destruction. Such is the power and standing of the Righteous. For their sake, the world continues.

Bamidbar 26:5, the Chanochi family Rashi explains this different form of naming using a Hey () at the beginning and a Yud () at the end: Because the heathen nations spoke slightly, saying, How can these traces their descent by their tribes? Do they think that the Egyptians did not overmaster their mothers? If they were masters of their bodies, it is quite certain that they did the same to their wives! On this account the Holy One, blessed be He, set His name upon them: the letter on one side and the letter on the other side, to intimate: I bear testimony for them that they are the sons of their reputed fathers (and not the Egyptians). This it is that is expressed by David, (Psalms 122:4) that the tribes bear the name of G-d is a testimony regarding Israel this Divine Name (Yud-Hey) bears testimony regarding their tribes. On this account in all of them it is written and but in the case of (v44) it was not felt necessary to state of the family of ", because the Divine Name is already attached to it the at the beginning and the at the end (Yalkut 2:988). Which gives us insight in the character of those in the day and the character of our ancestors in those days, they could have easily assimilated into Egypt claiming they were but slaves at the mercy of their masters, but they remained true to their heritage.

Bamidbar 26:46, and the name of Asher's daughter was Serach Rashi comments on this, saying, because she still remained alive after all these long years it exceptionally mentions her here (Seder Olam, Ch. 89). Serach was born in Israel and merited to return to Israel, unlike her father and his brothers. She was of the original generation that went down to Egypt, witnessed the Exodus and the return of the Jews to Israel, all firsthand. To what did she merit such old life? The Midrash says that when the Tribes brought news to their father, Ya'akov, that Yosef was alive, they did not wish to startle him, so they, the Tribes, asked of Serach, who used to play music for her grandfather would slip it in that her Uncle Yosef was alive in a calm manner. In gratitude, Ya'akov blessed her with long live, which the Torah attests to, as she was still alive some two hundred years later. It is also said that Serach learned from her grandfather, Ya'akov, the signs of the redeemer (Moshe), and she shared this with others, so when Moshe came to tell the Jews that HaShem was redeeming them, they had Serach as a first-hand witness to that tradition (and the others learnt it from their parents). For such is the power of a Tzadik's blessing.

Bamidbar 27:1, of the families of Menashe the son of Yosef, Rashi asks, Why is this stated? Has it not already been said son of Menahse! But it is to suggest to you: Yosef held the Land dear, as it is said, (Bereishit 50:25), And you shall bring my bones up from here, so, too, his daughters held the Land dear, as it is said, (v. 4) Give us a possession among our father's; and to teach you that they were all righteous, for in every case whereas a person's doing and his ancestors' doings are not described and Torah enters into the details of one of them, tracing his genealogy back to someone worthy of praise, it is evident that the person is himself a righteous man and the son of a righteous man. But if it gives his genealogy in connection with something deserving of reprobation, as, for example, (Melachim II 25:25) Yishmael the son of Nesoaniah the son of Elishama [came and smote Gadaliah], then it is quite certain that all mentioned in connection were wicked (Sifrei). In other words, there is something to be said for inherited traits, for good or bad. The Matriarch Rivkah was born into a wicked family, her brother was Lavan, but she was able to overcame her background and was worthy to be the mother of Ya'akov.

entry.title: Parsha Balak
entry.content:
''
Jun 20, 2013 / 5773 Tammuz 12 / '' ''

Parsha Balak /
Bamidbar 22:2 25:9
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

To reiterate, my purpose is not to summarize the Parsha nor to fully analyze it, but to highlight parts of the Parsha that moved me and try to convey a sense of why they moved me. There are certain verses or Rashi comments that I feel stand out, catching my mind or my heart that I am addressing here. I am using only a copy of Chayenu, with Chumash and Rashi, and my memory of various materials I have studied in the past or currently. I am not a Rabbi, I am but a simple Jew studying the words of our Creator and our heritage. My words that I type come from my heart, and hopefully translate into something meaningful on the reader's part. I know not who will read these words, today, tomorrow or beyond, but I hope that they convey my heart and share it with you, the reader.

The very first thing of any Parsha is the Parsha's name. This week's Parsha is Parsha Balak. Who is Balak, the Torah tells us, Bamidbar 22:4, Balak, the one of Tzippor was over Mo'av at that time. Which Rashi points out, he was not entitled to the kingdom; he was one of the Midianite princes, but when Sichon died they (the Moavites) appointed him as king over them to meet the needs of the time (Tanchuma). Which is interesting as Rashi also relates early that But did not these (Mo'av and Midyan) always hate one another, as it stated, (Bereishit XXXVI. 35) who had smitten Midyan in the country of Mo'av, that Midyan had come against Mo'av in war? But out of fear of Israel they made peace between themselves (Tanchuma; cf. Sanhedrin 105a). So, Balak, who was from a hated people, was placed over them, because of fear of Israel. This teach us that fear can do strange things to people. Also of note, Balak was the ancestor of Ruth, who is the ancestress of King David, the ancestor of Mashiach. Like Korach, Balak foresaw greatness coming from him and wished to take it for himself.

Bamidbar 22:6, the country of his people, Rashi explains, of Balak's people, for he came from there, and this man (Bil'am) had prophesied saying to him, You are destined to be king. And if you ask: Why did the Holy One, blessed by He, let his Shechina rest upon so wicked a heathen, in order that the heathen peoples should have no excuse to say, If we had prophets, we would have changed for the better, He raised up prophets for them. Yet they (these prophets) broke down the fence of the world, because at first they (the heathens) were fenced in against immoral living, but this man (Bil'am) counseled them to freely offer themselves to prostitution (cf. Rashi on XXIV. 14) Thus, it could not be said that the Goyim did not have real Prophets of their own, for they did, but instead of improving their people, they broke them down. Whereas Moshe Rabbeinu desired that all of Israel should be prophets like him, Bil'am desired that all should be immoral. So if the Goyim can and have had prophets of their own, how do we know that if they are true prophets or not? The Book of Devarim deals with this issue by basically saying that no prophet has the authority to counter that which a previous prophet said, with the foundation upon the teaching of Moshe Rabbeinu and what the entire people heard from Mount Sinai. While the Goyim do not have to follow all six hundred and thirteen mitzvot, they do have the seven laws of Noachide. So Judaism does recognize two paths to HaShem, the paths of B'nai Israel and B'nai Noach.

Bamidbar 22:33, and let it remain alive Rashi states, -- but now because it spoke and rebuked you and you could not stand against its rebuke, just as it is written, He answered, No, I have killed it in order that people should not be able to say: This is the animal that silenced Bil'am by its rebuke, so that he could not reply. For HaShem has regard for human dignity. Similar is (Vayikra XX. 15): And the animal shall you slay, and similarly (ib. 15): And the you shall slay the woman and the animal (with which sin was committed) (Tanchuma). Rashi stated that without question that Bil'am was a wicked person! A sinner in himself and he caused others to sin. And yet, Rashi also writes that Bil'am's donkey was killed to spare Bil'am's dignity. The fate of the wicked is death, and yet, HaShem has mercy upon them, if but they return/repeat they could be spared. This should teach us, if even the wicked deserves dignity, how much more so, our friends and family, who are cherished.

Bamidbar 23:4, chanced Rashi tells us, This is an expression ordinarily used to denote events of a casual character, an expression fro something shameful, an expression for an unclean happening. As much as to say: with reluctance and in a contemptuous manner. And on this occasion He revealed to Himself to him by day, only to show how dead Israel was to Him (cf. Bereishit R. 52; Rashi on Vayikra I. 1). For it is said for the sake of the people, a prophet arose. The prophet is reflective of the people, and the people a reflection of the prophet. Such was the state of the Children of Israel that they could have Moshe Rabbeinu, Aharon Ha-Cohen, and Miryam the Prophetess. Meaning those of the generation of the Exodus were on a very high spiritual level. For the Children of Israel's sake, Bil'am was able to receive HaShem during the day, whereas before, HaShem would happen upon him at night.

Bamidbar 23:8, How can I curse [whom] HaShem [Himself] has not cursed, Rashi informs us, When they deserved to be cursed, they were not cursed. When their ancestor made mention of their sin (Bereishit XLIX. 6) For in their anger they slew a man he cursed their anger only, as it is said, (ib. 7) Cursed be their anger. When their ancestor went to his father with deceit he deserved to be cursed, but what is stated there (ib. XXVII 33)? Yea, he shall be blessed. In the blessings it is said (Devarim XXVII. 12) These shall stand to bless the people, but in the case of those who had to pronounce the curses it does not state, And these shall stand to curse the people, but, And these shall stand for the curse, it does not wish to mention the term cursing in direct reference to them (the Children of Israel) (Tanchuma). The blessing of HaShem is eternal and cannot be denied. And why is it that Bil'am the wicked prophet was the one that blessed the Children of Israel, why not Moshe? I can answer this with a side question (how Talmudic); why is it if some stranger tells us we are beautiful/handsome, we believe them, but when our parents say the exact same thing we don't? For our parents we can justify they saying it but not being true, but for some stranger that we don't know or put in the effort to know, we cannot justify why what they say is not true. Thus, a stranger (to the ways of HaShem) blessed the Children of Israel, especially one that hated them so, we have to accept that the blessing he said are true and from HaShem, for only HaShem would be able to force him to say such. Whereas, if Moshe said it, we would know that Moshe's love of the people would be a part of it. The hardest advice to take is one's own advice, for usually we cannot be subjective of ourselves. Whereas an outsider can see the big picture much easier.

Bamidbar 23:19, The Eternal is not a man Rashi expounds this to tell us, He has already sworn to them that He will bring them there and give them as a possession the land of the seven peoples, and you think to slay them in the wilderness?! (cf. Tanchuma). Such are the enemies we face, they think they can triumph over HaShem, He that fashioned them. Not only enemies but non-believers think they can outwit HaShem. Someone once told me that she did not believe in HaShem simply because she could not conceive of a god that could create something that god could not carry. This was some time back, so I don't recall what I answered back. Now, I would point out that a black-hole would fit her description, it can not be carried, but it obviously a creation of HaShem. Of course, physics does break down in and around a black-hole, much as some like to joke that a black-hole is nothing more than HaShem dividing by zero.

Bamidbar 23:21, The Eternal, their G-d, is with them, Rashi remarks, Even when they provoke Him in anger and act rebelliously before Him, He does not depart from their midst. As was told to Moshe when he was called to redeem Israel from the Egypt, HaShem is with us in our exile, in our joy, and in our sorrow. The only constant in the cosmos is HaShem. Despite of all the sins of our ancestors and our own sins, HaShem is still our G-d. HaShem has stayed with us through the our misdeeds, how much more so when Mashiach comes and HaShem will be open to all to see as the Prophets saw.

Bamidbar 23:23, a time like this, Rashi expounds this, saying, Once again there will be a time as this time when the love which G-d bears them will be made manifest in the sight of all, because they sit before Him and learn Torah at His mouth, and the place assigned to them will be inward of that of the ministering angels and these will enquire of them. And when will this time be? The era of the final redemption, led by Mashiach. In those days, may they come speedily, we will learn Torah directly from HaShem Himself, as Moshe Rabbeinu did. And Moshe Rabbeinu and our families, past and present, will be there with us.

Bamidbar 23:28, the top of Pe'or, Rashi tells us, Balak was a great soothsayer and he foresaw that they would once be punished on account of Pe'or, but he knew not by what. He said: Perhaps the curse will fall upon them from there. So, too, all astrologers: they see something that will once happen but they know not exactly what they see (cf. Sota 12b). So it would seem that Rashi believed there was something to soothsaying and astrology, but it is not reliable. For our Sages say, he who places his trust in Heaven, will not tumble on the Earth. It is said, He made the heavens with wisdom. There is a reason behind everything in Creation, and when we find the pattern, we can learn more. But in our search for knowledge, we cannot forget wisdom. HaShem is both a part of and beyond His creation.

Bamidbar 24:14, come I shall advise you, Rashi relates to us, what you have to do. And what is the counsel? The G-d of these hates immorality (Sanhedrin 106a). You can know that it was Bil'am who gave this counsel, to make them fall by immorality, for it is stated (XXXI. 16), Behold, these were an enticement to the children of Israel through the word of Bil'am. For such is the hatred that Bil'am carried, even after being shown that HaShem had no wish to curse the Jews, Bil'am taken it upon himself to get them to sin. Bil'am could not leave it alone. Our enemies will try to strike at us, no matter the cost to themselves, even contrary to common sense.

Bamidbar 25:3, Pe'or, Rashi mentions to us, It was so named because they bared their buttocks and relieved themselves before it: this was its ceremonial rite (Sanhedrin 60b). And they were people that followed such an idol. We cannot understand this, for it is said that the Men of the Great Assembly prayed and received that the desire of idolatry to be removed. But such was it's power that people would do such ridiculous things. Even in our own days, we have smart people doing dumb things for money or something else.

Bamidbar 25:6, And they were weeping, Rashi explains this as such, the law escaped him and they all burst out into weeping (ib.) in calf Moshe successfully resisted six hundred thousand men, as it is said, (Shemos XXXII. 20) And he ground it to power, and here his hands were weak?! But in order that Pinchas might come and receive that which was meant for him (Tanchuma). What a sight that must have been, Moshe not knowing what to do when not forty years earlier he acted right away. That HaShem concealed the law from Moshe so that Pinchas might come was not known to them. Why did it have to happen this way? I am unsure. Was it to help the transition from Moshe to Yehoshua, Aharon to Pinchas? Was it a slight against Moshe that under his leadership some could sin like that? Just thought, I don't know, but suggest a couple. Your thoughts?

Bamidbar 25:7, Pinchas saw, what did he see? Rashi tells us, He saw what was being done and he was reminded of the law (Sanhedrin 82a). He said to Moshe, I have received a tradition from you; he how has intercourse with an Aramean (heathen) woman, zealous people may attack him. He replied, Let him who reads the letter be the agent for executing it; straightway, he took a spear in his Etc. (ib.). For such was the sin that logical and reason could not combat it, only zealotry and passion could. Zealotry cannot be commanded or placed on, but carried out by the one that acts.

May the passion and desire of HaShem be stirred in us as it was for Pinchas that we may through our tefillah, tzedakah, and teshuvah bring Mashiach to us this very moment. Ahem.


Any comments, suggestions, or corrections are more than welcome to improve my writing. Please, leave a comment, even a mere comment that you have read this and enjoyed it.

entry.title: Parsha Chukas
entry.content:
''
Jun 12, 2013 / 5773 Tammuz 4 / ''

Parsha Chukas /
Bamidbar 19:1 22:1
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Chukas. What is Chukas ()? A Chukas is a Divine Super-rational stature. The laws of the Torah fall into three categories: (1) those that deal with remembrance, such as the Festivals; (2) those that are logical and needed for civilization, such as shall not murder; and then there are the super-rational laws, which we don't understand.

In this week's Parsha, we are introduced to The Chukas, the Red Heifer. Basically put, a completely red cow (a heifer) is completely burnt and its ashes are then used to purify a person that comes in contact with a dead person. Even in its simplest, there is a lot going on. The Sages and everyone have worked on trying to understand this law, and gets parts, but not the whole. It is said that even King Shlomo ( ) with his Divine-given wisdom could understand all but this stature. This simple ritual removes the major-impurity from a person, leaving them pure. I know of no one that can explain the spiritual physics that purification involves, that's part of why this is a stature. Something also strange about this ritual is that, unlike any other offering; one, it's completely burnt with nothing including dung left over, and two, it is done outside the Mishkan/Holy Temple which is normally not permitted save for this ritual. Which all marks it special. While the ritual results removes the major-impurity of a person, those involved in setting up the ritual are made minor-impure. So it both pure and impure. In contrast, a Mikvah only purifies a person (minor-impurities) through water. Kashering something is done through either water or fire, not ash. Fire and water are natural and elemental. Ash is the product of something else. Ash does not exist on its own, there has to be something burnt for there to be ash. So there is several transitions going on; for pure to impure, from living to dead, from big (cow) to small (ash), and from impure to pure.

From a mathematical view, it does not add up, nor seem logical, hence why it's a Divine-stature. So why does it exist? Only HaShem knows for sure, but I am willing to suggest this: it is a sign and a proof that we, Jews, truly follow HaShem not out of some logical reason, but because there is a deep, meaningful relationship between us that is beyond understanding. Our Sages teach that a relationship that is based upon something, while only exist while that something exists. Such as a couple that are together solely because of lust, will remain until that lust runs its course. But a relationship built upon multiple things, like an interwoven thread will be stronger than a single-threaded line. Our relationship with HaShem has a chord that has six hundred thirteen interwoven threads, some of which we would have done anyway, and some we do because we desire a personal and direct relationship with HaShem. For any Jew, there is nothing between him or her and HaShem. For that relationship, there are things we do, simply because the other desires it.

The Torah states, Bamidbar 20:1, there Miryam died. Why did she die? What sin caused her death? None. It was a stature of HaShem. Why was it placed here, Rashi tells us, Why is the death of Miryam placed immediately after the section of the red heifer? To suggest to you: Why of the sacrifices? They effect atonement! So, too, does the death of the righteous effect atonement! (Moed Katan 28a). This tells us that the sacrifices, in and of themselves, are meaningless, but rather it is the carrying out of HaShem's Will that achieves the purpose of the offering. Just as the righteous align their lives with HaShem, so too the offerings (and prayers) need to be as well.

The Torah states, Bamidbar 20:2, there was no water for the community, which Rashi tells us they had water in the desert for forty years for the merit of Miryam, and Bamidbar 20:3, the people quarreled about the lack of water. It is interesting to note for a couple of reasons: one, HaShem did not punish the people for this quarrel; and two, the water returned in Moshe's merit, so disruption of water only served to inform us (and them) that they had water originally because of Miryam's merit. Why was this? Because we don't say the praise of someone until they have passed away. By showing the people that they had water because of Miryam, her praise was great, for just as Moshe and Aharon were prophets to the men, Miryam was a prophetess to the women. Miryam married the prince of the tribe of Judah and her child was the ancestor of King David and Mashiach. While we know Judah and his wife that gave birth to the Davidic line,Miryam and Ruth stand out more.

Bamidbar 20:16, messenger, Rashi informs us, This was Moshe; from this we may learn that the prophets are termed angels, so too, it says, (Chronicles II 36:16) And they grieved the angels of the Eternal (Vayikra R. 1) This is interesting in that when we think of angels we think of celestial beings without sin or understanding of such, beings of pure spirituality. Something that mere mortals cannot comprehend nor compare to. Comes the Torah and says not so. The prophets and those that follow their ways, have risen above their material existence and into the sphere of the angels. We can be literally like angels, if we but follow HaShem's ways like the prophets did.

Bamidbar 20:20, Edom come out to meet [Israel] with a large army and show of strength. Why was this stated? After all, Edom had already declared that Israel should not pass through their land. I have not seen what the Sages have said, but upon reflection, I think it is a sign of how things are in the world. Edom was found by Esau, the brother of Ya'akov. Moshe and the Children of Israel called upon Edom, the Children of Esau, in a brotherly fashion asking for a little help that would not interfere and even benefit them, but such is the world that those that should help us not only will out but go out of their way to trouble us. In Tehillim, it's said, better to rely upon HaShem than in man. Even though that should help us and even benefit from helping us, won't; for such is their view of the world. As it is said on the dollar bill, In G-d we trust. In HaShem, but not in man.

Rashi writes on Bamidbar 20:23, because the Children of Israel sought to make a relationship of some kind with the Children of Esau, Aharon passed away. Why Aharon the High Priest? For Esau was a man of war, and what's the opposite of war, peace, and Aharon was a man of peace. The leaders of the Jewish people take on the responsibility and protection of their people. Aharon's passage helped the breach from trying to work with Esau.

For such is the power and praise of peace: Bamidbar 20:29, and everyone of the House of Israel, which Rashi comments, Men and women, because Aharon used to purse peace and promoted love between contending parties, and between man and wife. (cf. Avos d'R' Natan XIL).

Bamidbar 21:7, "So Moshe prayed", Rashi informs us, "From this that he of whom one seeks forgiveness should not be so cruel as not to forgive (cf. Tanchuma)." If one is honest is seeking forgiveness, it should be granted, for this is the way of HaShem.

Bamidbar 21:20, "the engraved", Rashi explains this verses, "by command of Moshe who is called , the Lawgiver, as it is said, (Devarim XXXIII. 11) "for here is the portion of the lawgiver (Moshe's grave) concealed.". But why is Moshe's not mentioned in this song? Because he was punished through the well! And since Moshe's name is not mentioned, the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, is also not mentioned. A parable! To a king whom his subjects invited to a feast. He said: If my friend will be there, I, too, will be there, but if not, I will no go (Tanchuma)." This demonstrates the bond between HaShem and His prophet.

Bamidbar 21:21, "Israel then sent messengers," Rashi points out, "But in another passage it attributes this embassy to Moshe, as it is said, (Devarim II. 26), "And 'I' sent messengers from the wilderness of Kedemos"! And so, too, (Bamidbar XX 14), "And Moshe sent messengers from kadesh to the king of Edom"; while in Yiftach, it says, "(Shoftim XI. 17) "And Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, etc.". Each of these verses is necessary one to the other: one keeps back information and other discloses it, that Moshe is Israel and Israel is Moshe, thus telling you that the prince of any generation is the equal of the whole generation, for the prince is the whole (Tanchuma)." For a leader is one with his people, and his people are one with him. A leader must know and understand his people, and his people must know and understand their leader. There is a partnership between the people and their leader, one of give and take, on both parts, with the understanding that neither is complete without the other. Each generation has its own leaders, reflects of them. A leader must lead, by explain and by understanding his people.

How powerful is the doing a good deed, such that Moshe Rebbeinu had to be reassured by HaShem, Bamidbar 21:24, "Do not fear him." Simply because Og had told Abraham about the capture of Lot, Moshe feared Og, when he had not feared Pharaoh, because of a single good deed Og had done. If such a small deed could carry such weight, how much more so our deeds for HaShem will carry us.

May our parents and ours good deeds carry us to the days of Mashiach, where the final redemption shall take place, and as the Children of Israel sang of  Miryam's well in praise of HaShem, so too shall we, with Moshe, Aharon and Miryam. Speedily in our day. Ahem.





If you read this, please, let me know what you think of it.

entry.title: Parsha Korach
entry.content:
''
Jun 5, 2013 / 5773 Sivan 27 / '' ''

Parsha Korach /
Bamidbar 16:1 18:32
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Korach, which is interesting as Korach rebelled against HaShem, and yet, there is a Parsha named after him. The Torah, itself, testifies to his lineage and character by stating, Bamidbar 16:1, Korach, the son of Yitzhar, the son of Kehas, the son Levi. He was the cousin of Moshe and Aharon, of the Tribe of Levi, and a distinguished member of the Jewish community. So why did he rebel? In the same verse, the Torah states, Korach took.

What did Korach take? Rashi answers, He took himself on one side with the view of separating himself from out of the community so that he might raise a protest regarding the priesthood. This is what Onkelos renders he separated himself from the rest of the community in order to maintain dissension. Similar is, (Iyov XV. 12) Why does your heart take You aside, it takes you aside to separate you from other people. Another explanation of Korach took is: he attracted the chiefs of the Sanhedrin amongst them by words. Just as, (Vayikra VIII. 2) Take Aharon; (Hoshea XIV. 3) Take words with you (Tanchuma).

So Korach's rebellion was that he took on too much. Korach's desire for the priesthood while desirable, as Rashi comments that Moshe Rabbeinu himself desire it too, HaShem has His plan for each us and we should not take too much or take on something meant for another. It is that desire to reach towards priesthood that is worthy of having an eternal portion of Torah named for him, but the way he went about it was wrong and lead to his rebellion.

Bamidbar 16:1, with Dasan and Aviram, Rashi informs us, Because the tribe of Re'uven had their place, when they encamped, in the South, this being neighbors of Kehos and his sons, who, encamped in the South (cf III. 29), they joined Korach in his quarrel. Woe to the wicked, woe to his neighbor! Why is the neighbor included with the wicked? For we are influenced by our environment and those around us. We see our neighbors more than we see other people. As such, we use them as examples and standards for our community. Thus, if our neighbor is wicked, their influence upon us is in a negative way.

Because Korach felt as he had, Bamidbar 16:3, They congregated against Moshe and Aharon and said to them, You have for yourselves too much, since the entire community, all of them, are holy and The Eternal is among them. So why do you elevate yourselves over The Externals congregation? [...] Taking the sin of the spies of desiring too much spirituality to the other side, Korach's congregation complained that there should not be an individual over everyone, as everyone is equal, therefore, everyone could fulfill the position/duties/concept of High Priest/priesthood.

Bamidbar 16:6, do this take for yourselves fire-pans, Rashi explains, What reason had he to speak to them thus? He said to them: according to the customs of the heathens there are numerous forms of divine worship, and numerous priests, for they cannot assembly for worship in one temple; we, however, have One G-d, one Ark, one Law, one Altar, one High Priest; and you, 250 men, all demand the High Priesthood? I would like this myself. Here you have a rite which is dear to G-d more than any other it is the incense (offering), which is even dearer to Him than all the sacrifices, but a deadly poison is contained in it, for through it Nadav and Avihu were burnt! (cf. Vayikra X. 2). It was on this account that he warned them, It will then be that the man whom G-d chooses, he [will be] the holy one he is already in his state of holiness; for do we not know that he whom He would choose would become holy? But this is what Moshe said to them: I am telling you this in order that you may not imperil your lives, he whom He will choose will come out of this alive, but all of you will perish (Tanchuma).

Knowing their fate, these 250 men and Korach continued with Moshe's tests. Why? I don't know. Neither have I seen anything writing about them. Of Korach, himself, Rashi writes that
Korach knew prophetically that from him, the Shmuel HaNavi, would descend, as Rashi writes, who was equal in importance to Moshe and Aharon together (cf. Tehillim XCIX. 6: Moses and Aharon among His priests, and Shmuel among those who invoke His Name, called to the Eternal, and He answered them.) (Berachos 31b), and he said, On his account I shall escape.) So Korach felt that if he was the ancestor of Shmuel HaNavi and twenty-four watches of Leviyim, then surely, he must be chosen by HaShem for greatness. As Rashi points out, He mistakenly applied this to himself. But he had not seen correctly, for his sons repented. And from them, did Shmuel HaNavi and the others descend from.

Bamidbar 16:12, Moshe then sent, Rashi teaches us, From here that one should not persist in strife, for, Moshe sought them out in order to conciliate them by peaceful words (Sanhedrin 110a). Moshe did this for those whom had tattled on him to Pharaoh causing he to leave for Midian, how much more so, for a fellow Jew whom we have no previous history with.

Bamidbar 16:37, with their wives, children and infants, Rashi informs us, Come and see how grievous dissension is: for, you know, an earthly tribunal does not punish a person before he shows signs of puberty, the heavenly tribunal does not punish a person until the age of twenty. And here, even nursing infants were destroyed (Tanchuma).

The fire-pans that were used, the Torah states, Bamidbar 17:2,for the fire-pans have been sanctified. Why was this, Rashi tells us, and are therefore forbidden for any use, since they have made them into vessels of service.

When the congregation complained against Moshe and Aharon, HaShem brought a plague upon them, in response, Bamidbar 17:11, Moshe then said to Aharon, Take the fire-pan, put on it fire from on top of the altar and place incense, and go quietly to the congregation and make atonement for them [...] Rashi explains this thus, This secret the Angel of Death communicated to him (Moshe) when he went up to heaven, that the incense check the plague as is related in Treatise Shabbos (89a).

Why was the incense used to halt the plague, Rashi tells us, Wherefore by means of the incense? Because the Yisraelites were traducing and speaking ill of the incense, saying, It is a deadly poison: through it Nadav and Avihu died; through it the two hundred and fifty men were burnt! the Holy One, blessed be He, said, You will see that it is restraining the plague, and it is only sin that brings death (Mechilta on Shemos XVII. 5)

Bamidbar 17:18, for one staff Rashi explains, although I have divided them into two families, the family of priests apart, and that of the Leviyim apart, yet it is only one tribe.

Bamidbar 17:24, and each recognized his staff and took [it]. This is said in praise of the tribal leaders. Each acknowledged that his staff was unchanged and claimed it. They could have ignored their staff or claimed it was another, or discarded their staff, but each took their staff back.

The people worried, Bamidbar 17:28, Whoever draws near in any way to the Eternal Dwelling dies! Will we ever stop dying? To which HaShem answered, Bamidbar 18:1, You [Aharon] and your sons, and your father's family with you, shall bear the sins concerning the Temple, while you, and your sons with you, shall bear the sins concerning your priesthood. So it is the duty of the entire Tribe of Levi to protect the Israelites from over-stepping their place within the Mishkan/Holy Temple, and the Priests to protect the Leviyim from over-stepping their place.

The last part of the Parsha deals with the Priestly gifts and the Levite gifts, why did the Parsha entitled Korach start with his rebellion and end this way? For Korach and his congregation disputed the Priesthood and Leviyim's position, Since there was a disagreement about the station, HaShem spelled out the duties and gifts in detail to avoid any further disputes.

May the day come soonest when there will be no more disputes at all, and we all will live in harmony with all the nations of the world, under the solo banner of HaShem. May the Days of Mashiach come upon us soonest.


Please, your comments and feedback will help me improve and show that there are those out there reading this.

entry.title: Parsha Shelach
entry.content:
''
May 30, 2013 / 5773 Sivan 21 / '' ''

Parsha Shelach /
Bamidbar 13:1 15:41
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shelach, which deals with the episode of the spies being sent to the Land of Israel and returning with a bad report, and the consequences of those actions.

To frame this Parsha correctly, Rashi has a comment on the title phrase of this Parsha, Bamidbar 13:1, [If] you [wish] to send, which is, Why is the section dealing with the spies put in juxtaposition with the section dealing with Miriam? Because she (Miriam) was punished on account of the slander which he uttered against her brother and these sinners witnessed it and yet they did not take a lesson (Tanchuma). The ten spies slandered the land and did not take lesson from Miriam's punishment. This implies two things, one that Moshe and the Land of Israel are similar, and two, Miriam and the ten spies spoke slander.

It is interesting to note Rashi's description of the spies, Bamidbar 13:3; They were all men, saying, Wherever men is in Scripture it is a term of denoting worthiness. At that time (when they were appointed) they were worthy men.

Which begs the question, so what happened to them? How did they go from worthy men to sinners? More so, both Yehoshua and Kalev needed to pray for strength to resist the ten spies' plan. Meaning they required super-natural means to overcome the ten spies' plan, that mere logic or rationale would not have worked. How could this be?

I am sure there are several answers, but here is what I know, the Torah states that one of the spies' defense against going up to the Land was, Bamidbar 13:32, a land that destroys its inhabitants[...] What does this mean? Chassidus explains that the spies believed that if the people took over the land, they would have to work it, to provide food, shelter, clothing, and other manual tasks that are required for civilizations. Things that they did not need to do while in the desert, as HaShem provided all that for them, so they spent all their time studying Torah. The spies wanted to have an almost purely spiritual existence, dependent upon HaShem to take care of them, so they could continue to study Torah as they had been doing. Their mistake was that they not understanding that HaShem and His ways are in the mundane and physical world as well as the spiritual and intellectual world. We are placed here on Earth, and not in Heaven, for a reason. In fact, we, Humans, alone, exist in both worlds, the bridge one might say, between the two worlds. Angels exist only in the Heavens and the animals only on Earth. It is for Human beings to join them, so that HaShem is truly the L-rd of Heaven and Earth, not each one separately, but together.

Interesting enough, the spies' generation did in fact remain in the desert, while their children went into the land, so the spies got their wish, after a fashion and costing them their lives. So there is something to it, but as they were punished, there is something wrong with it as well.

Bamidbar 14:40-41, "(40) They rose early the morning and went to the top of the mountain, saying, "We are ready and will go up to the place where The Eternal has said, for we have sinned." (41) Moshe said, "Why is it you are disobeying The Eternal's order? It will not succeed." Just is the way of sinners that foolishness follows foolishness. Of them, the expression, "wanting their cake and eating it too," comes to mind. Yes, they sinned in not desiring the land, but also in trying to dictate to HaShem instead of following, which they still tried to do. Since HaShem was not with them, their "fears" of the Canaanites being too strong for them, came true.

After the disaster involving the spies and those that still tried to go up to the Land without HaShem, the people worried what would happen if the children sinned as their parents had, would they be stuck in the desert too. To assure them, HaShem said, Bamidbar 15:2, "When you come to your homeland that I am giving you." For the HaShem said to them, "when", not "if," so that they would know and rejoice for their children. Also one should understand the whole point of the Land of Israel is "I am giving you," I, HaShem, and no other. I, HaShem, the Creator and Maker of All, has designated the Land of Israel for the Children of Israel. Unlike other lands, the Land is named for its children, not the other way around. To further assure the people, HaShem told the people of the commandments/offerings that could only be done within the Land.

Bamidbar 15:7, "[] a pleasing aroma [before] the Eternal." What was pleasing about the offering? That HaShem's will was followed. The offering themselves was not a pleasant smell, but the devotion and desire to be closing to HaShem was. One did not just bring an animal offering to the Temple, but also a meal-offering and wine-offering accompanied the animal-offering. Not only that, but one did not just go to the Temple, but stayed over, as well. For bring an animal-offering for reasons of thanksgiving, were joyous times, a virtual party with whom made HaShem, Himself, a guest/part of. One had a meal, from the offerings of the sacrifices, in Jerusalem, and that meal was a festive meal to enjoy with family and friends. Oh what a sight and joy to see people coming to the Temple with their thanksgiving-offerings and other reasons to go there.

The commandment of "challah" is stated in Bamidbar 15:21, "Some of the first part of your dough you shall give to the Eternal as a selected portion []". Rashi comments on the part "as a selected portion, "Because we have not heard quantity for the Challah it is stated here "you shall give," that is shall contain sufficient to constitute a "gift" (Siphri)." HaShem could demand everything from us, for it is all His, but rather, HaShem wishes for us to give not because of a demand, but that we should give as a gift to Him for one was moved to give as one gives to a friend out of desire.

Bamidbar 15:33, "Those who found him gathering," Rashi explains, "They warned him and yet he did not refrain from picking them up even after they had found him and warned him. (cf Siphri, Sandhedrin 41a)." For such is Jewish law, the death penalty cannot be used unless a sinner has been warned of what the punishment of the sin he is going to do is and still does it before witnesses.

Bamidbar 15:41, "I am HaShem, your G-d," Rashi informs us, "From the commentary of Rabbi Moshe HaDarshan I transcribed: Why is the passage of the wood gatherer juxtaposed with the passage addressing idolatry? To inform that one who desecrates the Shabbath is regarded as one who worships idols, for it is as important as all the commandments. So Scripture says in the Book of Ezra (Nehemiah 9:13-14) "You descended upon Mount Sinai and you gave Your people the Law and the commandments (sic). And your holy Shabbath You made known to them." Likewise, the passage of fringes (Tzitzis); why is it juxposed with these? Since it too is equally important as all the commandments, as it states, "and carry out all My commandments."" For there is a reason why everything within the Torah is placed as it is. There are lessons to learn from what follows what, or is near.

May the day come soonest when we all can learn directly from HaShem in the days of Mashiach, in peace and security in our own land. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Baha'aloshecha
entry.content:
''
May 23, 2013 / 5773 Sivan 14 / '' ''

Parsha Baha'aloshecha /
Bamidbar 8:1 12:16
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Baha'aloshecha, the third Parsha in the Sefer Bamidbar.

The word, baha'aloshecha means when you light up. Rashi comments on this, saying, Why is the section of the candelabrum put in juxtaposition with the section dealing with the princes? Because when Aharon saw the dedication of the princes he felt distressed because neither he nor his tribe was with them in the dedication, whereupon the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, By your life! Your part is greater than theirs, for you will kindle and prepare the lamps. (cf Tanch.; see also Nachmanides). What was the merit of the dedication offerings that the Torah records it and ignores the other offerings of that day, for there are offerings that are brought up daily. And yet, comes the Sages and says that the mere lighting of the golden candelabrum is greater than the dedication offerings of the tribes. How is this so? The Sages have several explanations, and here is mine: the dedication offerings of the tribes was a one-time thing, never to be repeated, it was a grand gesture on their part but it was not sustainable.
