The dedication-offerings were very spiritual and emotional event, so much so that the Aharon felt distressed that he could not participate in it. Each of the princes gave a princely offering, each fitting and because of the prince of their tribe. While grandiose is not something that could have been continued, even if anyone wished it. The lighting of the candelabrum, on the other hand, was done by Aharon his entire life, and his son, his successor, and their successors after them, continued the commandment of lighting the candelabrum. The miracle of Chanukah commemorate the Maccabees commitment to continuing to follow that commandment given to Aharon, their ancestor.

Rashi said that HaShem said to Aharon, by your life, why that? Rabbi Akiva, I believe it was, said be like Aharon the Cohen be a pursuer of peace. By saying, by your life, HaShem was saying that like the menorah itself, Aharon was a light as well. Just as a menorah gives off light to assist a person in seeing, so too, Aharon helped others, bringing peace between friends and between husband and wife. Just as the candle that lights the menorah is not diminished, but grew with each additional flame to itself, so too, with peace; peace between individuals brings peace between groups, from among the groups, peace can grow to communities, from communities it can grow to the nation, and from a nation, to the world. Blessing following blessing, light birthing light.

Bamidbar 8:3, Aharon did exactly so, Rashi translates this as, This is in order to tell the praise of Aharon that he did not act different from what he was commended (cf. Sifrei). Although, Aharon did not receive the commandment directly from HaShem, but via, His prophet, Moshe, Aharon still carried out the commandment as if HaShem, Himself, directly commanded him.

Bamidbar 8:22, Just as the Eternal had commanded Moshe concerning the Leviyim, so did to them Rashi tells us, This is to tell the praise of the those who performed the rite (Moshe, Aharon, and the Israelites) and those who had it performed on them (the Leviyim) that none of them put any obstacles in the way. The Israelites did not protest over the Leviyim taking the Firstborn's place, and the Leviyim did not protest over the shaving and waiving. And miraculously, Aharon was able to waive all two thousand Leviyim for this entire process. And however long the rite took, no one was impatient.

Bamidbar 8:24, he who is twenty-five years old, Rashi points out, But elsewhere (4:3) it says, from thirty years old! How are these? From twenty-five years on he (the Levite) comes to learn the laws regulating the service, and he studies for five years, and at the age of thirty he may do the services. From here that a student, who does not experience success in his learning for five years, will never experience it (Sifrei; Chul. 24a). In other ways as the saying goes, if you don't succeed at first, try, try again, but the Torah points out, even if you do keep trying, after a lot of effort there is no inkling of progress, then one has to move on and let go. In today's society we measure things in hours, days, or maybe months, giving the measured object little of true value and trying to get the most out of the littlest. Comes the Torah and says, you have to try for years, not months, days, or hours. But don't become obsessed with it either, after truly trying for five years, then it would seem that Heaven has something else in mind for you. Just because a Levite did not success in his studies did not mean he was a failure, but rather his place was not in the direct service. For there was many tasks for Leviyim to do.

Aharon was commanded concerning the golden menorah in the Mishkan, and his tribe by extension. Throughout the ages, the tribe of Levi has served HaShem, by performing His service, and teaching others His torah. In doing so, they become like the golden menorah in the Mishkan, sharing their light with others, yet not diminishing themselves in the least. For one candle, alone, can banish a great radius of darkness, two candles can banish more and more candles, greater still. Light and peace goes hand and hand.

Bamidbar 9:10 or is on a journey of some distance, Rashi informs us, There is a dot on it (the of ), in order to tell that he does not really have to be far away, but he was outside the threshold of the courtyard during the whole time of slaughtering (Pes. 93B, cf. Sifrei) On the Second Pesach one may have with him unleavened and leavened bread in his house, and there is no festival in connection with it, and the leaven is forbidden only with it (the Pesach offering) while it is being eaten (cf Pes. 95a). As our Sages tell us, although you may be distance from Judaism, it is never too late, to come back. Yes, you may have missed the first Pesach because of your spiritual distance or whatever the reason, but comes the Second Pesach to give you another chance. No, the Second Pesach isn't like the first, one can have leavened and unleavened together, the Torah gives you a way to come home again.

Bamidbar 9:14, [...] There shall be one law from you, for proselytes and for natives of the land. Whereas other nations have different laws for others, Judaism has but one set of laws. Jewish law is the same for the rich and the poor, for the Jewish-born and the convert, all are equal under Jewish law, even the King must follow the law as everyone else. In Judaism, there is no above the law or am the law

Bamidbar 10:10, I am the Eternal your G-d Rashi tells us, from here we derive (HaShem's) kingship () must be recited together with reference to Divine remembrance () and the blowing of the Shofar (), because it states here which is an allusion to ; and () which is an allusion to ; and ' which is an allusion to etc. (Sifrei; cf. Rashi on Lev. XXIII 24 and Note thereon). We know this is true from the Oral Law, but here is an hint of it in the Written Law. One needs both the Written and the Oral Laws to fulfill understand.

Bamidbar 10:33, a three-day journey", Rashi informs us, "A distance of three days' journey they travelled in one day, because the Holy One, blessed be He, desired to bring them straight away into the Land (cf. Sifrei)." For such is the love of HaShem for Israel that HaShem bent His own "rules" to shorten Israel's travel in the desert. It is interesting that Rashi comments on this because for Abraham's servant, Elizer, and for Ya'akov Avinu, HaShem also shorten the physical distance for them to ensure a quick travel. Of course, from our perspective there would be a difference between one and a nation over three million. But to HaShem, there is no difference.

Bamidbar 10:33, and the Eternal's cloud was over them by day", Rashi mentions, "Seven times is the word "" used in their journeys alluding to four clouds which screened them on all four sides, one that was above them, one beneath their feet, and one in front of them which leveled the elevations and raised the depressions, and killed all serpents and scorpions (Sifrei; Mech. on Ex XIII 21; Bor. d'Melechet ha-Mishkan 14)." Not only were we protect from all four sides, but from the top and bottom, and yet another cloud to make the journey even easier, but leveling the hills, filling in the valleys and removes hidden dangers. And for these seven clouds of glory, we celebrate the Festival of Sukkot.

Bamidbar 10:35, it was, whenever, the Ark traveled" Rashi remarks on this verse, saying, "The Torah made (for this section) dividing marks (inverted "Nuns ()", in front and behind it, in order to indicate that this is not in its proper place (it would be more fitting to find a place in the section dealing with the march of the people in Chapter II, After v. 17). But why, then, is it written here? In order to make a break between the narrative of one punishment and that of another punishment etc., as is stated in the Talmudic chapter commencing with (Sabb. 115b, cf Sifrei)." Why is this? For there is a saying, "once is random, twice is coincidence, but three times is a pattern." The Torah went out of its way, deliberately, to avoid making a "pattern" of Israel's punishment for sinning. This is a lesson for us, we should avoid even the potential of making it seem that someone is "worse" than they actually are.

Bamidbar 11:5, the cucumbers", Rashi states, "Rabbi Shimon said, "Why did the manna change into everything except these? Because they are harmful for nursing mothers. We tell a nursing woman, "Do not eat any garlic or onion, for the baby's sake. A parable to a king, etc. as it is related in the Sifrei." For the sake of the nursing woman and children, the manna did not have the taste of what is harmful to them. Thus, our Sages knew of this, from the Torah, the blueprint of life, to aid nursing women throughout history.

Bamidbar 11:16, whom you recognize as being", Rashi explains this thus, "Those whom you know, that they were appointed as officers over them in Egypt to oversee the rigorous labor, and they had mercy on them, and were beaten on their account, as it says, "the officers of the children of Israel were beaten (Ex. 5:14)". Now they shall be chosen in their greatness, just as they had suffered in their Israel's distress." For a Jewish leader must lead and stand between his people and suffering. Both Moshe and King David were shepherds, for it is said, before HaShem entrusted them with His people, he tested them with sheep. Those who protect others, are themselves blessed. For it is said, to save, even one, life, is to save the entire world.

Bamidbar 11:17, I will then descend, Rashi states, This is one of the ten instances of the use of the term coming down written in the Torah to describe a Divine manifestation on earth (Sifrei). For the honor of the new Elders, HaShem descended from Heaven and manifested in some physical manner for the people to see that HaShem had commanded Moshe to appoint these people as the Elders over the People, for they, with Moshe, would form the first Sanhedrin, the highest court in Judaism and final authority in Jewish Law.

Bamidbar 11:17, placing upon them, Rashi tells us, What was Moshe like to at that moment? To a light that is placed in a candlestick at which everybody lights and yet its illuminating power is not diminished at all (Sefrei). From this (and others) we learn that a Torah scholar is like a candle, lighting others without losing it's own power.

Bamidbar 11:26, two men, remained in the camp, Rashi informs us why they remained in the camp, by saying, of them that had been selected. They said, We are not worthy of this distinction (Sifrei) As such, unlike the other sixty-eight Elders, these two continued to prophesized beyond their peers.

Bamidbar 11:28, eliminate them, Rashi comments, Impose on them communal responsibilities and they will of themselves soon come to an end. Another explanation is: put them into prison because they prophesying, Moshe will die and Yehoshua will bring Israel into the Land (cf. Sifrei, Sanh. 17a). What is Moshe's reply to the seemingly challenge to his leadership, Bamidbar 11:29, If only all the Eternal's people were prophets, that the Eternal would put the spirit of His upon them!

Bamidbar 12:1, the Cushite woman, Rashi informs us this is an expression, This tells us that all agreed as to her beauty just as all agree as to the blackness of an Ethiopian (Sifrei). Thus the Torah is being modest of Zipporah's beauty.

Bamidbar 12:1, The beautiful woman Rashi explain why this phrase is used, Because of her beauty she was called, the Ethiopian (Cushite) just as a man calls his handsome son Cushite, in order that the evil eye should have no power over him. Not just the evil eye, but the green eyes of jealous as well.

Bamidbar 12:2, Did He not speak with us? From here is proof that both Aharon and Miriam were prophets in their own right. In fact, it was Miriam who prophesized that Moshe would be born to save the Jews in Egypt.

Bamidbar 12:4, suddenly, Rashi tells us, He revealed Himself to them suddenly just when they were unclean as result of marital intercourse, so that they cried, Water, water! (for purification). He put them in this situation, to help them understand that Moshe had acted rightly in that he had separated from his wife, since the Shechinah used to reveal Itself to him at all times and there was no definite time fixed for the Divine communication (cf. Yalk.). For the bases of Miriam's complaint was the fact that although all three were prophets, only Moshe had separated himself from his wife, and Miriam and Aharon had thought this incorrect of him. Thus, HaShem, Himself, showed through action that it was needed for Moshe (but not necessarily from other prophets).

Bamidbar 12:9, The Eternal became angry with them and left Rashi points out a lesson for us, Only after He had informed them of their offense did He decree excommunication against them. All the more so, should a mortal not become angry with his friend before he informs him of his offense. (Sifrei).

Bamidbar 12:13, G-d! Please! Please heal her, Rashi points out another lesson for us, Scripture intends to teach you the correct altitude in social life that if one is asking a favor of his fellow man he should first say two or three words of supplication and then present the request (Sifrei).

Bamidbar 12:15, but the people did not travel, Rashi comments, This honor was accorded her [Miriam] by the Omnipresent because of the time she remained with Moshe when he was cast into the river, as it says, (Exod. 2:4) His sister stood by from afar to know what would be done to him (Sotah 9b). For HaShem repays us measure for measure, the people wanted upon Miriam's healing just as Miriam had waited on Moshe's period upon the river.

Just as the people wanted for Miriam in the desert, so too we now wait for Mashiach in our desert of exile. As was in the desert, so too, HaShem will once again save us and surround us in clouds of glory, may that day come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Naso
entry.content:
''
May 17, 2013 / 5773 Sivan 8 / ''


Parsha Naso /
Bamidbar 4:21 -- 7:89
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi
and the Gutnick Edition Chumash


This week's Parsha is Parsha Naso, the second Parsha within the Sefer Bamidbar, that occurs after Shavuot (this past Wednesday and Thursday), which is why this is very late in coming out. I have actually debated with myself where to just let this go or not, but decided that I wish to have an entry per Parsha, so I will still do it, borrowing from Parsha Beha'aloscha.


My practice is to review during the weekdays just with a regular Chumash with Rashi, mostly Chayenupublication, and then after the Evening Shabbat meal, to review the Parsha more in-depth; using the Gutnick Edition Chumash, the Midrash Says, and other source material. And of course, listen to the Rabbi's speech during Shabbat Shacharit. What I read during the week, what gets posted, and what I reflect upon after Shabbat Musaf service, can be different.


There is also a life lesson here, I focused on Shavuot to the exclusion of most everything else, then Shabbat was upon me, and I had hoped to use the time between the two to work on this Parsha. But alas, that did not work out because of poor planning. During Shavuot, someone asked me how many aliyot there are for Shavuot, which the answer is five, and why not seven? Seven aliyot is reserved for Shabbat Shacharit, six aliyot for Yom Kippur, five for the other Festivals (Pesach, Shavuot, Sukkot, and Rosh Hashanah), four aliyot for Rosh Chodesh and Chol HaMoed, and three aliyot for all other times. This practice was established/codified by Ezra the Scribe. I have heard that this is on scale with the holiness and importance of the occasion. Those Shabbat stands out, by having seven aliyot, while Shavuot only has five aliyot. So I got lost in the festival that comes once a year (and has cheesecake, must not forget the cheesecake), and did not fully prepare properly for the weekly Shabbat. This is an oversight many of us make. Since Shabbat is weekly, we tend to not think about it as much as we should. But if not for Shabbat, we would not have anything else, for Shabbat is the crown of creation. I will have to plan out my week better from now on.


Now, on to the Parsha Naso...


Bamidbar 4:21, The Eternal spoke to Moshe, saying: Single out those from Gershon's descendants too. Rashi comments, Single out those from Gershon's descendants too, as I commanded you with Kehos' descendants (4:1), to see how many have reached the age to serve. There are three sons of Levi: Kehos' descendants were counted in the previous Parsha; Gershon's, who are counted here, and the Merari's, who are counted next. Rashi commented because he was troubled as to why our Parsha emphasizes that Gershon should be singled out like Kehos, and the Rebbe wrote how each son of Levi represents a different level of sanctity, Kehos' descendants carried the Holy Ark, while Gershon's descendants carried the tapestries, and Merari's descendants carried the supporting structure. Kehos' descendants carried the most holy while Merari's descendants carried the least holy. And Gershon's descendants carried the medium holy objects. And yet, all three descendants were required for the Mishkan to be moved and established again.


Bamidbar 5:2, Command the Children of Israel to send out from the camp: all those afflicted with Tzara'as, [...] Having established the holiness of the Leviyim and their sacred tasks for the Mishkan; HaShem then instructs that although the Tribe of Levi had a duty to protect the purity of the Mishkan/Holy Temple, the Children of Israel as a whole, the non-Leviyim/non-Cohanim, also had a duty to ensure the sanctity of the camp as well. One cannot say, oh, I'm not a Levite or Cohen, thus, I don't have to worry about such lofty concepts and sanctification or purity. Come the Torah to remind us that we all, Cohan, Levi, and Israelite, all have a share in such a task, and it is a task that can be done at the level of any of the three.


Bamidbar 5:5-7, (5)The Eternal spoke to Moshe, saying: (6)Tell the children of Israel: If a man or woman commits any sins against man, acting treacherously against the Eternal, and that person is guilt: (7) They should confess the sin they committed. (The person) should pay back the amount he is guilty of, and add a fifth to it, giving it to the one against whom he was guilty. What amazing thing! HaShem, the source of mercy, says when we sin against a fellow, we are also sinning against HaShem, Himself, and we can atone for ourselves by verbally confessing out-load and return the amount we were guilt of, plus a fifth. For other systems, the forgiveness of sins is impossible, and yet, Judaism has a simple solution. And the first step to atonement is a simple verbal admittance of guilt, and only afterward there is monetary penalty involved (which is also part of the process). So we have, first the thought, then the words, and finally the action of repentance. Yes having the proper thoughts are good to have, but without verbal confession and the physical action, it's incomplete.


Then the Parsha introduces the concept of the Sotah, who is a suspected adulteress. In dealing with the Sotah, the husband and the Court cannot prove either the wife's innocence or guilt. If it's clear that she's guilt, she's not a Sotah. If it's clear that she's innocent, she's not a Sotah. Comes the Eternal who says, for the sake of harmony of the house, let My Name be erased to prove if the Sotah is innocent or guilty. If she is guilty, she will be Divinely punished but if she is innocent, then she is Divinely blessed. This only worked when the husband of the Sotah was pure, himself, and desired to keep his wife.


Bamidbar 5:18, He should uncover (the hair on) the head of the woman. Rashi asks why was this done? To which he answers, to humiliate her. From here we learn that an uncovered head of hair is considered a disgrace for the daughters of Israel. From the negative, we can learn the positive, for such is the splendor of the daughters of Israel, that the mere uncovering of hair is a disgrace to them.


Bamidbar 6:2, If a man or woman sets himself apart by making a nazirite vow Rashi states, Why is the section dealing with the nazirite placed next to the section of the Sotah? To teach you that whoever sees a Sotah in her disgrace will make a nazirite vow to abstain from wine, for [drinking wine] leads a person to adultery. The Torah is not a history book, where the chronological order of events is important. Rather, the Torah is an instruction book, or in the modern vernacular, a user manual for Humanity. Thus, what is placed next to each other is not coincidence, but Divine Wisdom. Our Sages tells us that for a person to sin, the spirit of foolishness enters them. How does this foolishness enters a person, through alcohol/drunkenness.


Bamidbar 6:24-26, (24)May the Eternal bless you and guard you. (25)May the Eternal cause His face to shine to you and favor you. (26)May the Eternal raise His face towards you and grant you peace. This is (the Priestly Blessing), which we, Cohenim, say, in Israel and among the Sephardi, during the daily Shacharit, while Ashkenazi say it only on Festivals. It is a biblical commandant to recite this blessing and is a part of the Temple Service. It is the only part of the Temple Service that remains today. Why is that? I am not sure. The obvious part is that the offerings could only be performed within the Temple, itself, therefore, no Temple, no offerings. In morning for the Temple, we don't copy the Leviyim service of using musical instruments to accompany the service. And yet, the Priestly Blessing, continues.... The offerings could be for good, thanksgiving, or for not-so-good, atonement. The musical accompaniment was meant for the enhancement of the service, so without the obvious service, the purpose of the musical accompaniment is not possible. But the Priestly Blessing is always for the good. Negative decrees can be averted through teshuvah, tefillah and tzedakah. A positive decree can not be averted by anything. Thus, when the Priestly Blessings continue as a positive decree.


Bamidbar 6:3, [...] They presented them in front of the Mishkan Rashi asks why in front of the Mishkan, Because Moshe did not accept [the wagons] from their hands until he was instructed by G-d to do so. The commentators ask why six, and not twelve, or some other number. Our Sages have various rationale for the number of six, and the Rebbe writes on this, expressing that the Tribal Leaders wished to help the Tribe of Levi in their Divine task of carrying parts of the Mishkan but not for the Tribe to lose out in it's privilege as well, for the carrying of the parts of the Mishkan was a honor and duty of the Leviyim. While Moshe wished for the Tribe of Levi not be denied any privilege and honor of carrying the parts of the Mishkan, the Tribal Leaders with HaShem's approval, realized that the Tribe would need assistance in carrying some of the heavy objects, and thus donated six wagons to assist them.


Bamidbar 7:10 7:88 details each tribe's offering to dedicate the altar, upon the day their offering was given. It is interesting of note that each Tribal Leader gave the seemingly exact same offering, and yet, the Torah records each one, individually. The Torah is written with Divine Wisdom, thus, it's concise and economical with its words. The mere fact that the Torah listed each seemingly identical offering of a silver bowl, silver sprinkling basin, spoon filled with incense, one young bull, one ram, one lamb, a sin-offering, and a peace-offering, is significant. The fact that each Tribe seemed to offer the same thing, tells us that the over-all meaning of the offerings was shared by each of the Tribes, or they were all the children of Ya'akov/Israel, while the fact that the Torah records each one as if it was different, tells us that specific meaning of the offerings different from Tribe to Tribe. The Gutnick Edition Chumash has a lovely table on the significance of the offering, which basically states that: the silver bowl, reflects on Adam HaRoshan; the silver sprinkling basin, reflects upon Noach; spoon with incense, reflects upon Torah; the bull, ram, and lamb, reflect upon the Patriarchs; the sin-offering, reflects upon atonement for the sale of Yosef; and the peace-offering, reflects upon Moshe, Aharon, and/or the Cohenim, Leviyim, and Israelites. Each Tribe had its own characteristics and tasks to perform and yet adhere to an over-all mission given to them from their father.


As it was true then, so it is true now, such as we all are individuals, but we are also one-people, unity in purpose and family. May the day come soonest when we can see and share our unity and peace of a single G-d, single family, and yet still individuals, in the ultimate harmonious state of being with the coming of Mashiach, speedily in our day. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Bamidbar
entry.content:
''
May 9, 2013 / 5773 Iyyar 29 / '' ''

Parsha Bamidbar /
Bamidbar 1:1 -- 4:20
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bamidbar, the first Parsha of the Sefer Bamidbar ( ), the fourth book of the Chumash. The Hebrew word "bamidbar" means "in the desert." Why is this the name of the entire fourth Sefer of the Chumash, let alone why it's the name of our Parsha.

The Sefer Bamidbar deals with many of social laws and of proper conduct, while the previous Sefer, Sefer Vayikra, dealt with the Cohenim, their service, and the Mishkan, all very spiritual matters. So why name the Sefer of social laws and proper conduct "Bamidbar?" There are many reasons.

Here are some ideas I have. The obvious answer, I think, is the "desert" in question is the Sinai desert, which is synonymous with Mount Sinai, meaning that the same god that gave us all the laws, decrees, and supranational commands concerning the spiritual matters of Sefer Vayikra, is the very same god that concerns Himself with our social conduct and lives discussed in Sefer Bamidbar. Just as the first five commandments of the Ten Commandments dealt with spiritual matters, and the last five commandments dealt with more "mundane" matters, so too, the Sefer Vayikra and Sefer Bamidbar parallel each other as well.

Another reason, I think, is a bit more complex, when one thinks of a desert, they think of place that's empty, devoid of anything beneficial, and a sense of being alone. If one is in a desert, there is only that
person there, and no other. Isolated. Separated. In other words, if one is in a (moral) desert), a person might use one of the big so-called "defense" for the moral-decay of our generation, which I believe is the phrase, "I'm not harming anyone(, so what does it matter what I am doing). Comes the Torah and tells us, Bamidbar 1:1, And the Eternal spoke to Moshe in the Sinai Desert[...] Even in the desert, in nothingness, solitude, HaShem is there. The very same G-d that set done the very foundation for civilization, working with others, is the very same G-d that set done how one conducts oneself, regardless of anyone. Even in the vast desert, the Infinite One, Blessed be He, is there. There is no part of Creation, disconnected from its Creator. Be it a mountain or a desert, HaShem is the same, and so should we.

The first chapter of Bamidbar deals with the counting of the male Israelites, non-Leviyim, who are Bamidbar 1:3, who are eligible for army service. To which Rashi comments, This informs that no one went out to the army below the age of twenty. Which is also interesting to me, here, there no upper cap upon the service in the army. Meaning that there is no concept of retirement, of being too old to service. It does not matter how old you are, you can still serve HaShem. While not necessarily in the same fashion as a younger person, there is still a part for you to perform.

In contrast, the tribe of Leviyim was counted from the age of one month and up. Why the difference? To serve HaShem, physical, one needs to be maturity and education, while to server HaShem, spiritually, one only needs to be alive.

Bamidbar 1:39, However, the Tribe of Levi you must not count to which Rashi states, The legion of the king deserves to be counted on its own (Tanchuma). Another explanation: The Holy One, Blessed Be He, foresaw that a decree was destined to be enacted against all those counted from twenty years and upward to die in the desert (14:29). He therefore said: Let these (the Leviyim) not be included, because they are Mine, since they did not sin by the calf (cf. Tachn.; B.B. 121b). When Rashi gives two explanations, the first fits the literal meaning of the text best. And the second explanation, while non-linear still fits as well. For we know that the Leviyim were in fact counted. The fact that the Tribe of Levi was counted, is covered by the first explanation, while the fact that our Tradition states that Moshe Rabbeinu did not count the Leviyim but a Heavenly Voice (3:16) did covers the second explanation. This also, again, shows the difference in physical service and spiritual service to HaShem. Whereas for physical, Moshe, Aharon, and the Princes of the Tribes needed to physically go through each person, have their lineage verified and recorded, while for the spiritual service, a Heavenly Voice did the count (in a manner beyond our understanding).

From here, our Sages also learned that what is counted can be cursed, while something not counted cannot be. Hence, why we do not take a direct count of Jews, even for a minyan, rather, we count either kippot/hats, by a verse of known quantity, or by not counting: not one, not two, not three, ...

Bamidbar 2:2, [...] each [tribe] to its flag [...] Each of the twelve Tribes had its own banner. For while we are all the descendents of Ya'akov, we are all descendents of different mothers, thus while over-all we all have the same mission in life, our methodology and characteristics of that mission differs. Each Tribe had its own characteristics and part of the same over-all mission.

Such is the praise of Israel, Bamidbar 2:34, The Children of Israel did [so]; in accordance with everything the Eternal had commanded Moshe, so they camped according to their flags and so they traveled, each man according to his family, following his father's lineage. None did not say they were more important than another so they should go there, instead of where HaShem said they should go. Each man (and his wife) went through all their documentations of their lineages without complaint about all the paperwork involved, and they camped in unity, for the camp of Israel was the camp of HaShem as well. And even with the divisions of the camp, there was a unity to the whole, an organization that everyone accepted.

Bamidbar 3:1, And these are the descendents of Aharon and Moshe to which Rashi states, But it mentions only the sons of Aharon! To which he continues, But they are called the sons of Moshe because he taught them Torah. This tells that whoever teaches the Torah to the son of his fellow man Scripture regards it to him as though he had fathered him (Sanh. 19b). Such is the power and importance of Torah that the teacher of Torah is considered a father of the student. This is also in play when the Prophets (who taught Torah) are called our fathers.

Just as the twelve Tribes had placements among the Camp of Israelites, so too did the Tribe of Levi, each family within the Tribe had its placement among the (inner) Camp of Leviyim. In the very center of the encampment was the Mishkan. Just as the spiritual focus of our lives is the Mishkan/Holy Temple/Divine Service, so too it should be our physical focus as well. While there are the Heavens and the Earth, there is but One G-d, existing in both. Thus, ultimately, spiritual and physical are the same.

Bamidbar 3:41, You shall then take the Leviyim for Me I am the Eternal [...] Is there some question as for whom the Leviyim were taken for that the Torah needed to add I am the Eternal ( ') when it had already said, for Me () when HaShem is speaking directly to Moshe? Rather one could question which aspect of HaShem was taking the Leviyim, and so the Torah tells us it is the aspect of Divine Mercy and transcendence. For Rashi points out although it's written here, this applied after the sin of the golden calf where the First-born lost their privilege to serve HaShem as priests and ministers. Thus, this a bit out of sequence. On the other hand, this could be seen as confirmation of Ya'akov's separating his son, Levi, from his non-firstborn children as a tenth of everything he had. And the fact that the entire Tribe of Levi, out of all the Tribes was the only one not to be apart of the sin of the golden calf merely confirmed the separation. As this involved Divine Mercy, it's substituting one (the first-born) for another (Leviyim), instead of losing it (the priesthood/service) completely. It also explains how the Leviyim cound stand in the place of every firstborn among the Children of Israel as it was an Heavenly Decree. This decree gave the firstborns atonement for their part in the sin of the golden calf by substituting the Leviyim for the first-borns, instead of what Strict Justice would decree.

Bamidbar 4:2, Calculate the total number Rashi states, Count those that are fit among them for the service of carrying, and these are from thirty to fifty years, less than thirty has not yet attained his full strength, - from here they (our Sages) said (Avos V. 21) a man of thirty has reached the age when he enters into full strength, as for one who is older than fifty, his strength gradually diminishs from then. Although, a man reaches full maturity at 20, he does not reach his full strength until 30. So which is more important that which comes first. It should also be noted, while a man's strength starts to dimish after the age of fifty, there is not a verse saying the same of a dimishing of a man's maturity. Thus, we could say that once one matures, they are always mature, but one who is strong, there is only a limited time for that strength. The strengh of mind is lasting, while the strength of body is fleeting. The soul is eternal like the body is finite.

Bamidbar 4:15, Aharon and his sons shall finish covering [] after that the sons of Kehas shall enter Thus we see a separation between the House of Aharon, the Cohenim, and the House of Levi, the Leviyim. And left unsaid is a further separation between the Tribe of Levi and the rest of the Children of Israel. For while the Cohenim were permitted to cover the vessels directly, the Leviyim carried them, indirectly, and the Israelite could not even do that. Is this bad-mouthing the Israelite? Heaven forbid. Rather, it illustrates the different approaches or levels of service to HaShem; each is required and necessary for the Holy Service is incomplete without all three.

May the day come soonest for the times of Mashiach when we will know the truth that spiritual and physical are the same and not different. It matters not if you are alone or in a group, nor a difference between being in a desert and being at an oasis.


Please leave a comment or suggestion on my posting to let me know you are reading this and what thoughts you have on this Parsha. Suggestions for improvement are highly encouraged and appreciated. I write this from my heart, as it comes out, and trying not to second guess myself or over-thinking it (too much). For I have seen what I started to think to write at the beginning of the week, differs from what I (sometimes) end up writing, and what I think upon after hearing other's thoughts upon the Parsha, or even just rehashing what I have originally thought.

entry.title: Parsha Behar-Bechukotai
entry.content:
''
May 1, 2013 / 5773 Iyyar 21 / '' ''

Parsha Behar-Bechukotai / -
Vayikra 25:1 27:34
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Behar and Parsha Bechukosai combined into a single Parsha, as this is not a leap year.

Rashi has an interesting insight for us on the very first verse of this Parsha, Vayikra 25:1 on the words Mount Sinai, he says, What does the subject of Shemittah have with Mount Sinai? Weren't all the commandments states from Sinai? But this statement in intended to suggest the following comparison: How is it in the case of the law of Shemittah? Its general rules, and minute details were ordained on Mount Sinai! So, too, were all commandments with their general rules and their minute details ordained on Mount Sinai. This is what is taught in Torath Kohanim (25:1). It seems to me that the following is explanation of this: Since we do not find the laws of Shemittah of the land reiterated on the plains of Moab in Deuteronomy, we learn that its general principles, finer details, and explanations were all stated at Sinai. The express mention of Mount Sinai here appears therefore to be unnecessary but Scripture states this phrase here to teach us that, every statement that was conveyed to Moses came from Sinai, their general principles and finer details and that the commandments delineated in Deuteronomy were merely repeated and reviewed on the plains of Moab not originally given there. This is a fundamental concept of Judaism that Moshe Rabbeinu reviewed not just the Written Torah, but the Oral Torah as well, which goes hand and hand. One cannot learn one without the other. Moshe Rabbeinu was taught all the laws, details, and principles at Sinai and taught them to the people. From this body of knowledge and wisdom, that Moshe Rabbeinu received, we have the Judaism of today. Everything in Judaism falls into three categories: it was taught by Moshe Rabbeinu, who learned at Mount Sinai; it was Rabbis' rulings that were derived from those teachings based upon a set of rules; or it was Rabbis' ruling that were instituted as protection for the people but not directly based upon Torah. All three are valid and make Judaism as robust as it is. It allows the very same teaching that Moshe Rabbeinu handed down to still work for us.

Vayikra 25:2, a rest period to the Eternal, Rashi explains the Shemittah is for the sake of the Eternal, just as is stated of the Shabbat of Creation. Just as HaShem sanctified each seventh day in the week (seven days), so too, did He sanctified the seventh year in a cycle of seven years. From Rashi's comment about tying Shemittah to the Shabbat, we can teach several parallels. One that comes immediately to mind is that, just as the Shabbat exists for spiritual reasons, so too does the Shemittah year exist for spiritual reasons. Just as there are physical benefits from the Shabbat, so too, there are physical benefits to the Shemittah year. We can also learn from the Shemittah to Shabbat: the Shemittah year teaches us that we depend upon HaShem only and not upon the physical fruits of our labor, so too, the Shabbat teaches us that we depend upon Him for spiritual matters as well. HaShem can provide for us both mundane and spiritually, yes, we need a vessel to hold HaShem's blessing, but that vessel can be something as simple as resting. I should note that Shemittah only applies within the land of Israel, while Shabbat applies universally. When we live on Mars, Shabbat would still need to be observed, but Shemittah would not be observed there. Shemittah is observed in our day within the land of Israel.

Shemittah sounds easy, but it's a test of faith that the produce of the sixth year will carry you over until the eighth year's crop is available.

And then there is the Yovel year the fiftieth year, seven times seven plus one. Which means that one does not harvest for the forty-ninth year and the fiftieth year, being carried by the forty-eighth year into the fifty-first year. It was done in Biblical times, and late not, and our Sages say for not keeping the Shemittah and Yovel years, we were exiled.

Interestingly, there is no weekly counterpart to the Yovel, per say. There is no fiftieth day equivalent. But one could make a case that the Festivals are the Yovel counterparts. Having said that and reading about the Shofar sounded on Yom Kippur, I would have to say that maybe, in my opinion, the equivalent of Yovel to the week-structure, would be Yom Kippur, itself, as the Yovel is called a Shemittah of Shemittahs (seven cycles of seven cycles), Yom Kippur is called the Shabbat of Shabbatim. The problem with that is of course, Yom Kippur is but one day out of the entire year, while the Yovel is every fiftieth year in the seven cycle of seven years, plus one.

After discussing the Shemittah and Yovel, the Torah tells us, Vayikra 24:14, you must not cheat, which Rashi points out refers to cheating in money matters. So we went from spiritual cycles within the years/decades/century, to something more mundane and social. What's the connection?

Is there a connection? Yes, because the Torah is Divinely organized, everything is placed according to Divine wisdom, there are no coincidences within Torah. The obvious connection is that the same HaShem that's worried about the land/agriculture/livelihood, is the very same HaShem that is worried about mortals actions between themselves. Also that the same HaShem, Blessed be He, that will sustain you through the Shemittah and Yovel years, will also sustain your basic needs so that cheating in monetary matters is not needed. HaShem is there for us in the big and small. HaShem is the same without the entire Cosmos/Creation and within the quarks and leptons. To quote a green Muppet, size matters not. The miracle of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds is not different than the miracle of birth, or the miracle of waking up in the morning. All civil, social, and judicial ruling come from HaShem.

This is also providing an insight to the importance of the Yovel as well, as we are the account the years until the Yovel when establishing the price for land. For within the Yovel year, all lands return to their original ordained owners.

Vayikra 25:19 And you will eat to satisfaction to which Rashi points out, even if you eat only a little it will be blessed in your stomach. Because it is blessed, even a small crumb can be fulfilling. The reverse is also true, if its cursed, G-dforbid, no amount of food, even an endless buffet will not save you.

Vayikra 25:20-21, (20) And if you ask, What will we eat in the seventh year? After all, we must not sow nor gather in our produce.' (21) I will then order My blessing for you in the sixth year, and [the land] will produce for the three years' [use]. HaShem, Himself, promises us that if we fulfill His word, He will take care of us. He know fashioned the heart, knows the heart. Thus, the Torah teaches us the obvious question to ask about Shemittah, HaShem, Himself, answers us. Even when we ask only in our hearts or quietly in secret, HaShem answers us, for it said, Tehillim 81:8, In distress, you called and I released you; I answered you-[though you called] in secret- with thunder; I tried you by the waters of Meribah, forever. Of course, while HaShem always answers us, the answer may be to our liking. For sometimes the answer can be no, not yet, or wait and see.

Vayikra 25:25, his redeemer who is related to him, who should be first to redeem someone? That's someone's closest relative. The one that redeems, there is a bond between the redeemer and the redeemed, like family. The first to help out should be one's immediate family, if they cannot do so, then one's extended family. If they cannot, then one's House, and so on. Ultimately we are all related, for we are all the sons and daughters of Yaakov, Yitzchak, and Abraham.

Vayikra 25:32, The Leviyim will have a permanent [right of] redemption. Unlike their Israelite counterparts, the Leviyim were not given any portion of the land of Israel for an inheritance, thus, in order to protect what little they had, the Torah had to command this. An Israelite might lose a piece of his inheritance of land, but a Levite, whose inheritance is HaShem, He cannot be lost.

Vayikra 25:35, you shall support him Rashi explains, Do not allow him to fall down and collapse altogether, in which case it would be difficult to pick him up again. Rather, support him while his hand is still faltering. To what can this be compared? To a load on a donkey while it is still on the donkey, one person can grasp it and hold it in place. Once it falls to the ground, however, five people cannot pick it up (Siphra). In my own professional life, I have found this to be very true. The quicker a defect in the software is found, the cheaper the support (fix) will be. It is much easier to fix during the development phase, then to fix one that is out in the field (among the end-users). Our Sages teach us that fortune is a wheel, it spins around, what's on top, spins to the bottom, and the bottom to the top, and around-around it goes, where it stops, only HaShem knows. It is HaShem that makes one poor or rich, or makes the rich poor, or the poor rich.

Vayikra 25:41, he and his sons with him Rashi comments, Rabbi Shimon asked: If he sold himself who sold his children? But from this that the master is bound to provide his (servant's) children with food (Kidd. 22A, cf. Rashi on Ex. XXI. 3). Our Sages tells us, he that buys a Jewish slave, buys a master. For the laws are: if there is only one pillow, the slave gets it; if he has children, the master has to feed and care for them; when the slave goes free, the master has to give the slave going-away presents.

Vayikra 26:4, I will provide your rains at their time, the land will yield its produce, and the trees of the field will give forth their fruit. If only we harken to the voice of HaShem, then He, Himself, will irrigate the fields for us and HaShem will provide for our needs.

What is the ultimate reward for fulfilling HaShem's command, peace! For it is said, Vayikra 26:6, I will grant peace in the land. To Rashi expounds, Perhaps you will say. Well, there is food and there is drink, but if there is no peace, is nothing! Scriptures therefore states after all these promises I will grant [you] peace in the land. Hence that peace counterbalances everything. In a similar sense it states, Who makes peace and creates all things. Without peace, how can one enjoy anything? For during war, one needs to be careful of their lives or thieves hidden in the shadows. But if you have peace, then you have nothing to fear.

But when we do not listen to the Voice of HaShem, bad things happen. Is this punishment, yes, in a way, but mostly it is simply consequences to our actions. HaShem is the Source of Peace, without the source, there is no peace. The further one pulls away from HaShem, the more lost into the mundane they become. As our Sages tell us, the consequence of a mitzvah is another mitzvah. The consequence of a sin is another sin.

After curse after curse, the Torah states Vayikra 26:42, I will recall My covenant with Ya'akov, and My covenant with Yitzchak, and I will even recall My covenant with Avraham and take account of the land. Thus, despite and even become of all those terrible curses, the Jewish People will remain, for the merit of our Fore-fathers remain with us. And even when the mortal Fore-fathers are not enough, the land itself will call for us, so that we may both fulfill the will of our Creator.

For the Torah assures us, Vayikra 26:44, And even though [I will bring upon them] these [calamities] when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not have despised them nor rejected them to completely destroy them [or] to annual My covenant with them, for I am the Eternal, their G-d. As G-d lives, we are His children. Not matter what happens, whether the child needs to be praised or punished, it is done out of love and remains one's child that one's loves always.

The three book of the Torah ends with Vayikra 27:34, These are the commandments that the Eternal commanded Moshe at Mount Sinai for the Children of Yisrael. This is to remind us that Moshe Rabbeinu took the teaches from HaShem's mouth and placed it within the ear of the people. What they heard, we still follow today.

All Jewish law came from Mount Sinai, both the general law and its details, all came from one source.

May we all merit the ultimate peace, the coming of Mashiach, speedily in our day. Amen.

If you got this far into my writings, please, take a moment and tell me know you are reading this. Comments, suggestions, and criticisms are accepted.

entry.title: Parsha Emor
entry.content:
''
Apr 25, 2013 / 5773 Iyyar 15 / '' ''

Parsha Emor /
Vayikra 21:1 -- 24:23
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Emor and deals with the standards for Cohenim and the offerings, what's done with offerings that become invalid, and proclamation of the Holy Days, and ends with the tale of the blasphemer.

The very opening of the Parsha, we have Vayikra 21:1, "Say to the Priests [ and you shall say to ...], Rashi informs us that the Torah is telling us, ""Say" and again "You shall say to" - to admonish the adults about their children also (Yevamot 114a)." For that is the survive of Judaism, we pass our heritage down from generation to generation ( ). Although, the verse is speaking of the special care to be pure for the Cohenim, it is also true of everything else. I recall very fondly being pre-Bar Mitzvah age standing under my Abba's tallit during , learning from my father, as he, himself, learned from his father, and so on, I can not describe the feelings that go through me during , for I am doing as my father does, and his father's father, whom I am named for, for his father's father, whom my Abba is named, as my ancestors had done in the Holy Temples, and in the Mishkan since HaShem instructed Moshe Rabbeinu to tell Aharon and his sons. And I pray that one day I may teach my own sons as my Abba did for me.

Vayikra 21:2, except for his relative Rashi tells us that the term [closest] relative () here denotes his wife (Siphra; Yevamot 22b). For one might think that the Torah was ignoring his wife, but Rashi points out, the Torah is telling us that there is none closer to a man than his wife. For it was said in Bereishit 2:21, Therefore, a man shall leave his father and his mother, and cleave to his wife, and they shall become one flesh. For a man and his wife are one.

Vayikra 21:11, And he must not enter any dead person, Rashi explains this verse to mean, he shall not enter the tent or home, etc., wherein the dead person lies. Growing up, I went to Merrimack Valley Hebrew Academy in Lowell, Massachusetts, where classes were held within the building that also held the synagogue. Thus, when G-d forbid, someone passed away, my teacher, Rabbi Cohen, and I would have to step outside the building in fulfillment of this biblical verse.

Vayikra 21:18, Since any man who has a deformity draw near, Rashi addes, This means: it is not right that he should approach; the same idea as (Mal. I. 8) [And if you offer the blind for sacrifice, is it not evil? And if you offer the lame or sick, is it not evil?] Offer it now to your governor; [will he be pleased with you?] For those that serve HaShem a higher standard is followed, to reflect the higher state the service of HaShem requires. It is ruled that a modern-day Cohen with a deformity may not appreciate in , until the congregation is used to him. For and any Temple service was not about the Cohen, but HaShem. So anything that distracts the observer from HaShem is to be minimized.

Vayikra 22:31, You shall preserve My commandments and do them; I am the Eternal. And how do we preserve HaShem's commandments? Rashi informs us that we preserve HaShem's commandments through studying them. And the Torah, itself, states, that study is not enough, but we must do them too. Thought and action are required of us. Good thoughts are good, but if there is no action associated with them, those thoughts are stuck and lifeless.

The Torah in Chapter 23 of Vayikra, describes the details of Shabbat, Pesach, Shavuot, Rosh HaShanah, Yom Kippur and Sukkot. On the third verse, Rashi asks, What relation is there between the Shabbat and the festive seasons? Rashi answers his own question with, to teach you that he who desecrates the festivals ios regarded as though he had desecrate the Shabbat, and he who keeps the festivals is regarded as though he has kept the Shabbat (Siphra). So Rashi is telling us there is a linkage between Shabbat, a marker of Creation, and the festivals (Yom Tovim), markers of the season. From this we can draw a parallel as well, just as Creation fixated the Shabbat, so too, the festivals were a part of Creation as well. Our Sages tell us that when the three Angels visited Abraham to tell him of the coming of his son, Yitzchak, it was Pesach time, so Sarah was baking matzahs. And yet, the true Pesach (the Exodus from Egypt) would not happen for another four hundred years. But the spirit of Pesach was embedded into Nissan before the Exodus happened, or rather the Exodus from Egypt was planned to be in Nissan from the beginning of Creation. For HaShem, it is said, the End is seeing in the Beginning and the Beginning in the End. For time, itself, is a creation just as much as space is.

Vayikra 23:13, From the day after the rest day, Rashi tells us this means, from the morrow after the festival, meaning the first day of Chol HaMoed. For we might mistaken think that the rest day is Shabbat. But on the night of the second Sedar, we begin the count of the Omer.

Vayikra 23:40, Fruit of the Citron tree, which Rashi explains, a tree the wood of which has the same taste as its fruit (Siphra; Sukkos 35a). Which our Sages say is the Citron fruit/tree. Rashi addes, remains () on the treee from one year to another and this is the Etrog. Which we use during Sukkot and Hallel to fulfill the biblical verse, and afterward, using in Shabbat tea or make into a tasty jam.

Vayikra 24:14, [and all those who heard the blaspheny] shall rest their hands [on his head] Rashi expounds the verse, They said to him: your blood is upon your head: we do not deserve punishment on account of your death, for it was you yourself who brought it about (Siphra). When capital punishment is given, it is not killing/murder, but justice.

And the ultimate justice will come when Mashecha comes, may those days be soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim
entry.content:
'
Apr 17, 2013 / 5773 Iyyar 7 / ''

Parsha Acharei Mot-Kedoshim / -
Vayikra 16:1 20:27
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Edition Chumash; Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is also a double-portion Parsha to ensure that we complete and renew the annual Torah cycle on Simcha Torah. Parsha Acharei deals with the Yom Kippur service and what needs to be associated with it (oversimplification), while Parsha Kedoshim deals with individual holiness and interacting with people (again, oversimplification).

The Parsha begins, Vayikra 16:1, The Eternal spoke to Moshe after the death of Aharon's two sons etc., to which prompts Rashi to write, Why is this intended to tell us? Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah illustrated this by a parable: a sick person whom the physician visited. He (the physician) said to him: Do not eat cold, and do not lie down in a cold damp place. Then, another [physician] visited him, and advised him, Do not eat cold foods or lie down in a cold, damp place so that you will not die the way so-and-so died. This put him on his guard more than the former; that is why Scripture states after the death of the two sons of Aaron. (Siphra) What does this mean? It is along the lines of the old saying:the apple does not fall far from the tree. From here, we learn that Aharon's two sons got their desire to get closer to HaShem from their father, and it could be said that their death was not a punishment, but a consequence of getting too close to HaShem, Whom is like to fire.

That both Aharon and Moshe Rabbeinu felt this way shows us that it is not completely wrong, but as Aharon's two sons did die suggests that there is an issue with it. The issue is that HaShem is the Creator of both Heaven and Earth. He created animals on Earth and angels in Heaven, but only Man was created in both and moved in both. That is the unique and purpose of Man, to bridge Heaven and Earth together. Aharon's two sons, Nadav and Avihu, desired a purely spiritual existence and such, they expired upon the mundane existence. Comes the Torah and warns Aharon against this. HaShem created the Earth for a reason, and set us here for a purpose and a task for fulfill. Yes, we need to strive to be closer to HaShem and more spiritual, but not at the expense of the mundane. In fact, our Sages taught us that the whole purpose of Creation was for us to create a dwelling place for HaShem in the lowest of places, to combine the spiritual and the mundane into a single existence. And this can only be done through Divine wisdom.

The Parsha continues after this warning to instruct Aharon (and later Cohen HaGadolim) in the service for Yom Kippur. On Yom Kippur is a very spiritual day and a day in which we resemble angels. And yet, we are not angels in truth. But,we can stand higher than the angels when we fulfill HaShem's Will, or fall lower than the animals when we cause others to sin.

In the end, we are mortal, thus, Torah tells us, Vayikra 16:32, to act as priest in place of his father, to which Rashi explains, to teach that if the son is able to fill his place he has to be given preference to any man (Siphra). Thus, the first candidate to replace his father, the High Priest, should be his son. Why? Because a child is the product of a man, woman, and HaShem, thus, a child inherits a bit from each. Traits and such are inheritable, but can be utilized in many ways. Thus, if the father has served as a High Priest, then the son will inherit those traits as well. But children are not carbon-copies of their parents, children express themselves directly, given environment and resources. There is no automatic that if the father is of good-character, the son will be too, and yet, the potential is there. Whether it is realized or not.

Vayikra 16:5, that they are sacrificing, Rashi informs us that the Children of Israel were accustomed to do so, but HaShem wanted that their sacrifices should only be done within the Mishkan (and the Holy Temple). Whether this was a restriction to lean the People off of sacrifices or ensure that the People had the proper intention for the sacrifice, I am not sure. Although, both are possible and in a metaphoric way still applicable. Meaning that one should only make their sacrifice in their daily life with the proper intention and in the proper place. One should sacrifice a bit of their time during the day to daven, but one should not use the excuse to go daven to avoid familial duties of helping with the children.

Vayikra 17:11, For the life-force of the body is in blood. Rashi expands on this by saying, of every creature is dependent on its blood, and its for this reason that I have placed it on the alter to atone for mans soul. Let a soul (of an animal) come and atone for the soul (of man)! Thus, a true offering is symbolic and spiritual. The sinner exchanges his soul for the animal's in a procedure created by HaShem to achieve atonement for himself. Nothing HaShem does or had done for Him, is done without Divine reason and wisdom.

Vayikra 18:3, and you must not follow their customs Rashi asks, What has Scripture left unsaid? He answers, But it refers to their social customs things which have assumed for them the character of a law as, for instance, theatres and race-courses. Rabbi Meir said: These refer to the ways of the Amorites (superstitious practices) which our Rabbis have enumerated (Sabb. 67a; cf. Also Tosefta Sabb. Ch7). In other words, the old saying, when in Rome, do as the Romans, according to Torah is morally corrupt.

The Torah goes on to list acts of unchastisement having warned us of the people of Egypt and Cana'an, as these were acts that they did. These laws of chastisement give holiness and respect to the family unit, the foundation upon which our morals stand upon. It never ceases to amaze me how so many arrogantly believe they know better than HaShem. That these arrogant people believe that they can do whatever unnatural things they wish, for they are not hurting anyone. And yet, they are hurting themselves spiritually, and spreading their moral decay into others in the name of so-called tolerance. For HaShem is the same G-d that established the spiritual services of Yom Kippur and the G-d that established holy matrimony and the found of society. From the highest to the lowest, HaShem is there, wanting to help us and guide us into being better people.

Vayikra 19:2, you shall be holy, Rashi explains, keep aloof from the forbidden sexual relations and from sinful thoughts. Because whenever you find in the Torah a command to fence yourself in against such relations you also find mention of holiness. Thus, holiness is linked to restraint.

Vayikra 19:3, shall fear his mother and his father, Rashi comments on this thus, Here mentions the mother before the father because it is manifest to Him that a child fears the father more the mother. In the case of honoring parents, mentions the father before the mother because it is manifest to Him that the child honors the mother more than the father because she endeavors to win him over by kindly words. (Kidd. 30b). HaShem knows our natures, for He is the Author of it. Whether we follow the guidelines or not, is up to us.

Vayikra 19:10, I am the Eternal, to which Rashi expounds, the Judge Who punish and will exact from you nothing less than your souls, as it is said, (Prov. XXII, 22, 23), Do not rob a poor man... for the L-rd will plead their cause, and rob those who rob them, of life. (Siphra). As it is said, in the end, HaShem balances the books and Justice will be done. Yes, bad things(tm) happen in life, but we should not think for a moment that nothing comes of bad things(tm), rather, we should know at some point, HaShem, Himself, will address it and Divine Justice will be carried out.

Vayikra 19:14, You must not curse [even] a deaf person Just because our actions cannot been seen or heard by others, does not excuse us. We have to be mindful of others, regardless if the other(s) know or not, or care or not. For all our actions have consequences. As the saying goes, no man is an island unto himself. We know not who is impacted by our actions. As an example, maybe in several decades someone will find this blog and it will inspire them to study and make their own blog as well. Or help them in some way, I pray. For these words of mine come from my heart. Chassidus teaches what comes from the heart goes to the heart. Thus, I am speaking from the heart and not thinking of what I say but feel them.

Vayikra 19:14, And you shall be afraid of your G-d Rashi expounds, Because this case not given to human beings to know whether the intention of this man (the offender) was for the advantage or the disadvantage, and he might be able to evade by saying, I meant it for the best, therefore states with reference to him: and you shall be afraid of your G-d. Who recognized your thoughts. Similarly in all actions where it is given only to the heart of the person who does it and where other people have no insight into it, states, and you shall be afraid of your G-d (Siphra; B. Mets.. 58b). And sometimes, even we ourselves are not sure if we did something for the good or bad, but HaShem knows and will take it into account of our action. Nothing is hidden from HaShem.

Vayikra 20:15, and you shall kill the animal, Rashi explains, If the man has sinned, what sin has the best committed? But because the man's opportunity to stumble (sin) was occasioned by it, there Scripture says, Let it be stoned! How much the more to a human being who knows to distinguish between good and evil and yet brings evil upon his fellow-man to commit a sin. In a similar way you should explain: (Devorim 12:2) You shall utterly destroy all the places [where the nations . served their gods... under every bushy tree] Now is not logical conclusion? In the case of trees which can neither see nor hear? Merely because an opportunity to sin was occasioned by them Scripture says, Destroy, burn, exterminate them. One who makes his fellow-man deviate from the path of life to the path of death; does it not follow all the more that [he should be punished?] (Siphra; cf. Sanh. 54a, 55a). For such is the Loving-Kindness of HaShem so that people should not point and say that animal so-and-so sinned with; the animal is killed to avoid that.

Vayikra 20:26, And I have distinguished you from the nations to be Mine Rashi writes, If you are separated from them, you will be Mine, but if not, you will be belong to Nebuchadnezzar and his ilk. Rabbi Eleazar ben Azariah says: How do we know that a person should not say, I find pork disgusting, or It is impossible for me to wear a mixture of wool and line, but rather, one should say, I wish to, but what can I do, my Father in heaven has imposed upon me? Scripture says here, And I have distinguished you from other, to be Mine your very distinction from must be for My Name, separating yourself from transgression and accepting upon yourself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heave. (Siphra). Meaning, all the laws, statures and decrees of the Torah are all from HaShem and should be followed because they come from HaShem, whether we understand them or not. HaShem commanded us shall not steal, did He truly needed to do that? Any group that wishes to get along knows the importance of property rights in order to get along. But from where do those rights come from? They are from HaShem, as everything else is. Thus it is necessary for the Torah to say, shall not steal. Our moral conduct of today, comes from thousands of years of Torah study and others learning it from us. The Torah was a huge influence on the creation of the United States governments and system of law. Wherever you see Torah-influence, you see justice and moral, and the opposite is true, the lack of Torah-influence, negatively affects those too. We are the chosen nation, to be a light upon the nations to bring them out of the darkness they have fallen into. That the others are so used to the darkness they have forgotten they are ensnared by the darkness does not make a difference. For even the small of lights banish darkness. We need to only but heed the Words of HaShem and walk in His ways, and the world will be fully in the light of HaShem.

And may it be soonest, when Mashiach comes, darkness will be completely transformed into light for all of eternity. Peace, justice and loving-kindness will rule supreme everywhere. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Tazria-Metzora
entry.content:
/ April 12, 2013 / 5773 Iyar 2

-   / Parsha Tazria-Metzora
Vayikra 12:1 15:33
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash Edition; Silbermann Edition Rashi


This week's Parsha is a "double" Parsha, in that, in a leap year (or such) we would read these two Parshiot separately, but since this is not a leap year, to make sure that we finish the Torah cycle on Simcha Torah, we combine these two Parshiot into "one," Tazria-Metzora.


The Parsha starts talking about laws of cleanliness of humanity, saying Vayikra 12:2, "if a woman conceives," to which Rashi comments, "Rabbi Simlai said: Just as the formation of man after that of every cattle, beast and bird when the world as created, so, too laws [concerning the cleanness], regarding him is set forth after the law [concerning the cleanness] regarding cattle, beast and birds (Lev. R. 14)." Why did Rashi need to bring this up? After all, the order of the Mishkan was the structure itself, then the priests; so why did not Rashi just point this out, why the comparison to Creation itself? Our Sages have several answers for this, plus, Rashi's hint by referring to his source's name directly. The one that comes to my mind is that the Mishkan and everything associated with it is a reflection/model of the Creation. Not only was the Mishkan the model/reflection, it was the crown of Creation. So just as within Creation, Man came "last" so too in giving the laws of cleanness, man is mentioned last as well. Chassidus has a saying that ties to this: a person should have two pieces of paper, one in each pocket; in one pocket, the piece of paper should say, "For my sake, the world was created;" and in the other pocket, the piece of paper should say, "I am but dust." Although the world was created for the sake of man to perform mitzvahs, man needs to be humble as well.


Also, just as it was HaShem that created the obvious physical world and how it runs, so too, did He create the spiritual world and how it runs. Thus, it is HaShem, the Creator of Heaven and Earth that decreed that a mother will be impure when she gives birth. The birth of a child is a miracle and a blessing, so one may think that there is nothing wrong with it, but come to the Torah and tells us that there is some impurity involved. It should be mentioned that impurity in itself is not a bad thing; just something to be aware of, for one is responsible for being pure when entering a holy place or doing such activities.


Vayikra 12:4-5 states that a woman is impure for thirty-three days if she gives birth to a boy and sixty-six days for a girl. Why is this? The Sages have several understandings of this passage. What I know is that for a girl, the woman has to do thirty-three days for herself and thirty-three days for her daughter, whom she "modeled" upon. For a sin, a mother cannot do this, and the son has to go his own path, including his bris.


Vayikra 12:6 informs us that a woman needs to bring an offering after giving birth, both a burnt-offering and a sin-offering. Why a sin-offering? Our Sages say that during the birthing process, a woman while in pain can/will say things that she shouldn't or even did not mean to say, such as never having a child again. But after holding her precious miracle in her arms, she will regret her having said that. Thus, the Torah, knowing of our natures, institutionalized that the woman, having regretted her oath, has to bring a sin-offering to ensure her oath/words are not counted against her. For even words spoken in pain or distress have power.


Vayikra 13:2, "[he shall be brought] to Aharon", to which Rashi replies, "It is a Scriptural decree that the uncleanness and purification of leprous plagues are pronounced only by the mouth of a priest (Siphra)." Why a priest, for the descendents of Aharon, who is known for pursuing peace. So matters of uncleanness needs to be handles by through who are inherently pursuers of peace.


Vayikra 13:46, He shall live alone, Rashi explains, that people who are unclean shall not abide with him (Pes. 67a cf. Siphra) Our Rabbis said: Why is he treated differently from other unclean persons that he should abide solitary? Because he, by slanderous statements, parted man and wife, or man from his friend, he must be parted (Arach. 16b). For such is the spiritual power of speech, when used incorrectly, the damage is vast. Now, consider if negative speech is so bad, then positive speech must be even more powerful. HaShem could have created the world in many ways, but He choose to do so via speech. Thus, speech has the power to create and destroy.


Vayikra 14:4, [ritually]-pure, Rashi says, excludes an unclean bird (of a species that may not be eaten). Because the plagues come as a punishment for slander, which is done by chattering, therefore birds are compulsory for his purification, because these chatter, continuously with a twittering sound (Arachin 16b). Which relates to HaShem's measure for measure way of doing things. Since the symptom involved chattering, so too, the cure involved something of chattering as well.


Vayikra 14:4, a thread of scarlet [wool] and [a bunch of] hyssop. Rashi explains this combination, What is the remedy he should use, that he may be healed? Let him, abandoning pride; regard himself lowly as a worm and as hyssop (cf. Yalk I. 559). He, whose heads where in the clouds, not seeing others, needs to come down to earth and feel the very soil with his being. From dust we came, dust we return; but also, from Heaven we came, to Heaven we return.


Vayikra 14:34, and I put a tzara's mark, Rashi informs us, This was an announcement to them that these plagues would come upon them (Siphra; Horiyos 10a), because the Amorites concealed treasures of gold in the walls of their houses during the whole 40 years the Israelites were in the wilderness, and in consequence of the plague they would pull down the house and discover them. For such is HaShem's mercy. Although, the slander should have been struck himself, first, HaShem's mercy has it that, first his house was struck, then his clothes, and only then was he, himself, struck with tzara. And those that represent, found those treasures that were hidden within the walls.

entry.title: Parsha Shemini
entry.content:
''
Apr 3, 2013 / 5773 Nissan 23 / ''

Parsha Shemini /
Vayikra 9:1 11:47
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Edition Chumash and Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemini. The Hebrew word shemini means eighth as our Parsha starts, Vayikra 9:1, It was on the eighth day [...] Rashi states that it was the eighth day of the inauguration of the Mishkan and the Aharon and his sons as priests to HaShem. HaShem had only commanded seven days for the initial inauguration of the Mishkan and the priests into their office. So how can there be an eighth?

What is eight? The definition of eight is the number that comes after seven, or mathematically, seven plus one (more). There are seven days to a week. This phenomenon does not occur within nature, unlike a day which is the rotation of the Earth, a year which is a trip around the Sun, or a month which is a cycle of the moon. There are seven days to a week, because HaShem decreed that when He created creation. Thus, seven is seen as a complete set within nature. And if seven is a complete set, then eight, which is one more, is seen as something extra or beyond natural. For all seven days of the inauguration of the Mishkan, everything went as HaShem had commanded Moses, as stated in Vayikra 9:21, and yet no Divine sign was seen. Everything was done, but HaShem did not react. Until, Vayikra 9:23, Moshe and Aharon then entered the Mishkan and they came out and blessed the people, and the Glory of the Eternal was then revealed to the People. Everything until that point was needed to bring HaShem, as it were, to the People. It was not the offerings or priestly services that did it, but two brothers, united, with the people, wanting and desiring HaShem in their midst that actually brought HaShem's Glory to them. There is a powerful lesson for us, today, when we lack the Holy Temple, and yet, unity and blessing is still available to us, if we but desire and work to bring HaShem here, and He will come.

The Sages point out of Nadav and Avihu punishment was Vayikra 10:2, A fire came out from before the Eternal and consumed them, and they died before the Eternal. Just a couple of verses prior, the Torah tells us Vayikra 9:24, A fire then came out from before the Eternal and, on the altar, it consumed the burnt-offering and the fats. [...] The two phrases are identical, a fire came out from before the Eternal both to show the Glory of HaShem to the people and for Nadav and Avihu's action. Thus the death of Nadav and Avihu were liken to the burnt-offering. Moses remarks on this by saying, Vayikra 10:3, This is what the Eternal spoke, Rashi explains, Where had He spoken this? And there I will be met by the children of Israel and it (the Tabernacle) shall be sanctified by My glory (). Read not , by My glory, but , through My honored ones (Zev. 115b). Moses here said to Aharon: My brother, Aharon! I knew that this House was to be sanctified by those who are beloved of the Omnipresent G-d and I thought it would be either through me or through you; now I see that these (your sons who have died) are greater than me and than you! (Siphra). By HaShem doing as He did, He showed that His ways are just and true. Our Sages say that although they had died, HaShem's reaction to Nadav and Avihu's action wasn't a punishment per say, but a natural consequence to their action. Why did Nadav and Avihu did what they did? Our Sages say they wished to closer to HaShem than mere flesh, and so their souls departed from their bodies. Rashi points out Vayikra 10:5, by their shirts, of the dead (not in their own garments.) This tells us that their garments had not been destroyed by fire, but their souls (neither their clothing nor bodies showed signs of burning; they had been struck by fire inwardly): they entered into their nostrils something like two threads of fire (Siphra; Sanhedrin 52a).
Vayikra 10:20, Moses listened and approved. Rashi tells us, He admitted and was not ashamed, saying, I have not heard (Siphra; Zev. 101b). For such is a Jewish leader, he admits when he is wrong and is not ashamed to say so. Moses had lost his temper, in fear for Aharon's sons' lives and fear of upsetting the priestly service of the Mishkan, and yet, he listened to Aharon's reasoning and agreed with it.

Vayikra 11:2, This is the living creature, Rashi points out, This! Teaches us that Moses held each animal and showed it to Israel, saying, This you may eat, and this you may not eat (Siphra; Chullin 42a) He that brought the animals to the Noach's Ark, brought each animal to Moses and Israel so they may know which animals are clean and which are impure. Rashi also points out Also of the swarming creatures of the waters he held some of every species and shows them to them. So too in case of birds: (v13) and these you shall abhor among birds, and similarly as regards the swarming reptiles (v. 29): And these are for you the impure. (Siphra; cf. Menachos 29a). Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, shows Israel every creature and told them if it was pure or not, whether it was local or not.

Why does the Torah seems to stop of the telling of the inauguration of the Mishkan to tell us in detail what animals are pure and which are not? For HaShem warned the Priests (and Sages) not to be intoxicated so they can differentiate between pure and impure. And in order to distinguish between the two, we need to know which are pure and which are not. Thus, the Torah tells us.

What is pure and not, is not something we, humans, can tell by mere sight, which is a physical ability. Purity is a spiritual component that we cannot distinguish without the Torah/HaShem to tell us. Purity, itself, is not defined, but we know that the more pure something is, the closer it is to its Source, while the impure drives one away. One's sensitivity to purity is directly proportional to one's closeness to HaShem. The Righteous can, somehow, see/feel, the purity around them.

The Torah generalizes and says, Vayikra 11:3, Among animals, all those that have a divided hoof, completely split hooves, [and] chew the cud those you may eat Meaning, these animals are pure and the rest are not. There are many spiritual and mystics concepts involved in this. Among those I have heard, chewing one's cud is a desired trait in that it means that you go over the same matter over and over again.
