We, humans, are finite and should not make decisions in haste, rather, we should ponder over our thoughts over and over again before finalizing the matter. The listed animals that are not pure, each has spiritual and mystical concepts as well. For example, I have heard of the pig, it has the outer sign but lacks the inner sign, thus it's not kosher for it lacks both that are required. Thus, we need to be weary of those that on the outside seem okay, but in truth, their insides are impure, thus we must examine both the outer and inner parts of the matter before us.

Vayikra 11:9, This is what you may eat of all that are in the waters: all those that have fins and scales in water, [whether] in the seas or in rivers those you may eat. These two have mystical and spiritual components, but I have not heard of them. But I would guess that scales can be liken to protection and fins are liken to maneuverability, so I would say that in the waters of life, one cannot just hope HaShem will take care of us and do nothing, rather, HaShem provides protection for us and we need to use it; as well as; we need to navigate our way through the waters of life with purpose and not just be swept away by the currents.

Of the birds, the Torah takes a different approach, instead of listing all the pure birds, the Torah lists only the impure birds as that is a shorter list. The Torah is exacting and concise, using the least amount of words.

Vayikra 11:20, the Torah talks of the impure and pure insects that can be eaten. This I have heard very little on, but then the idea of eating, even a kosher, insect does not sit well with my American tastes. But I had read that in Northern Africa and other such places, there are kosher chocolate-covered grasshoppers available. While I agree they are kosher, I am not sure I would wish to try them, even with chocolate. And yet, they are kosher, so there is purity and purpose to them that we can learn from.

In regards to the pure, we may eat, but the impure we need to be careful not only in eating but not even getting near them.

By studying this section, one can learn a lot about purity and behavior that HaShem desires from us.

HaShem tells us, Vayikra 11:33, Since I am the Eternal, your G-d, because I am Holy so shall you sanctify yourselves and you will become holy [...]. Thus, but following HaShem's commands and ways, we emulate Him. In doing so, we become holy and draw closer to Him.

May we merit to draw even closest to HaShem with the coming of Mashiach, and then what is pure will be obvious to all and we all will be holy to HaShem.


---

If you've gotten this far, please, leave me a comment. Let me know what you think!

entry.title: Parsha Tzav / Shabbat HaGadol
entry.content:
''
Mar 21, 2013 / 5773 Nissan 10 / ''

Parsha Tzav /
Shabbat HaGadol /
Vayikra 6:1 8:36
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash Margolin Edition; Rashi Silbermann Edition

I write these words not knowing where they will end, but I know that they start from my heart and desire. It would warm my heart to know who is reading these words and what thoughts or comments these words invoke upon you, the reader. Yes, these words are not that well organized, as they are my thoughts and feelings, upon the the weekly Parsha as I go through it. As I said, these words flow in the way of the heart, to express my desire and thoughts into words to share. And some words are to note emphasis on what I consider important verses, comments by Rashi, or other sources I have read from. This is not all-inclusive or a scholarly work, just words from my heart as I study the weekly Parsha, whatever they may be. I use Chayenu's weekly publication, so I usually only have the Chumash and Rashi in front of me. If you know more or feel I have something wrong, please, please, let me know.

That said, this week's Parsha is Parsha Tzav, which continues to talk about the various offerings and details involved with their service.

Vayikra 6:1, Command Aaron, Rashi informs us, The expression command ... always implies urging on and upon future generations. Rabbi Shimon said: Especially must Scripture urge where monetary loss is involved. Which answers the question why the expression command instead of say or speak, the usual expression. What is the monetary lost that occurs here? With other offerings, the Cohen () receives a portion from the offering in the form of parts of the animal offered, but with the burnt offering, he does not. The Torah, while talking to us, Cohenim (), it is also talking the average Jew, and even we Cohenim in this day and age (until Mashiach comes, may he come soonest), have a lesson to learn here as well. Yes, we are all very eager and excited to help our fellow Jew when we can benefit from helping, whether in some form of warm and fuzzy feeling, a thank you, or getting something out of it. We are not so helpful when we think if we help, there will be a loss, be it, a loss of time, loss of importance, or loss of resources. Such thinking is not what HaShem desires of us, as the Torah says, Command! Do it, regardless of loss, for it is right and Divine to help another Jew, to assist another Jew in his or her service to HaShem and to connect another Jew to HaShem. This verse could have just said, command the Cohenim, but it did not. It says, Command Aaron and his sons. Why Aaron? Because, one must be like Aaron the Cohen, when helping a fellow Jew. Who was Aaron the Cohen, a lover and pursuer of peace. Also, one should not think they are above helping a fellow Jew, for it was Aaron, the chosen of HaShem to be the first Cohen HaGadol, to whom first this commandment was given to. Can any of us say, we are great than Aaron the Cohen HaGadol? If one such as he, needs to be instructed, how much more so do we?



Vayikra 6:4, He shall then remove his garments, Rashi informs us, This is not compulsory (cf. however, Nachmanides), but it is a matter of decency so that he should not, through removing the ashes, soil the garments in which he was regularly to minister at the altar; in the clothes he boiled the pot for his master (a menial task) he should not pour out a glass for him (an honorable office). On this account: And he shall put on other garments inferior to those [in which he ministers at the altar] (Yoma 23b; Siphra; Shabbos 114a). Should not this be obvious to us? Would one wear soil garments when presented to a mortal of authority, much less The Source of Blessings? Ah, but the commandment to take out the ashes, is a service to HaShem, in as much, as any other service in the Mishkan/Temple was. And thus might have been done in the Priestly garments, save the Torah commanded otherwise. For the Cohen that removed the ashes, even in inferior garments, is still performing a service for HaShem. Yes, we should not be afraid to get dirty in our service to HaShem, but we should be mindful that if we know we will get dirt we should adjust our outer appearance for decency sake, but we are still the same Cohen, start to finish, performing HaShem's will.

Vayikra 6:6, [The fire on the altar] must not be extinguished. The Sages tells us that a Heavenly fire would descend and consumed the offerings, and yet, HaShem commanded us to have a fire upon the altar as well. Not only that, but that this Earthly fire must not be extinguished. What is this Earthly fire upon the altar? It is the human effort to match/copy the Divine. It is a warning for us, not to put out that fire of Yiddishkeit in every Jew. We must be careful, in our service to HaShem, not to cause others to be put off to Yiddishkeit. Just as its worse for a sinner to cause others to sin, so too, it is worse for one that should have caused others to draw nearer to cause others to be pushed away instead. Yes, we light our fires and a Heavenly fire joins in, when we do our part. HaShem could do everything Himself, but that is not why He created us. We need do our part, to make sure that fire of Yiddishkeit continues and not go out, especially out of inaction.

Vayikra 6:15, It shall be completely burnt up Rashi tells us, The three-finger fistful is not taken off from it so that there can be any remaining of it to be eaten, but the whole of it is burnt entire. Similarly ever free-will meal-offering of a priest shall be wholly burnt (Siphra). When in service to HaShem, one needs to give one's all, and not expect anything to be returned. When dealing with others, there is a part for you involved, but when dealing with one's self, all parts should be given to HaShem.

Vayikra 6:21, shall be broken Rashi explains, because the substance absorbed in it becomes as (the technical term for any portion of a sacrifice not eaten by the time prescribed for this) (cf. Avoda-Zara 76a). That, too, is the regulation applicable to all sacrifices (i.e. that an earthen vessel wherein they have been cooked must be broken). A similar say is you are what you eat. When something is heated, it expands and substances can fall into those pockets of expansion, making the item, literally, a part of what was in it, much as the human body uses what you ate to build itself. This is why we have one set of pots/pans/plates for Milk and another set for Meat. Note that only earthenware is broken, other vessels can be cleansed through ritual. Why is this? The truth is; it should be that all vessels should be broken, but the Holy One, blessed be He, know that that would not be practical. So He permitted ways of cleansing expensive vessels as a kindness, but cheap/common vessels, He was just.

In comparing a thanksgiving-offering for a miracle, a offering of fulfilling a vow or gift-offering, Vayikra 7:16, whatever is left over from it may be eaten on the next day. The thanksgiving-offering has to be eaten within a day; but a gift-offering, two-days is given. Why the extra day? I'm sure the Sages have an answer to my question (if you know please tell me), but I will try to answer my own question (how Rabbinic of me). The thanksgiving-offering was given as Rashi says, on account of miraculous deliverance that was wrought for him. Which we now say Gomel ( ) for. This is something miraculous, and not natural thus, HaShem wishes, as it were, that one should make a big deal about it with the offering and unleavened loaves but not dwell too long upon this and get back to regular stuff. Now, a gift-offering, that's day-to-day stuff, that's natural, this, is just an offering, no loaves, and one can dwell a bit on it, taking two days to enjoy.

Vayikra 7:26, And you must not eat any blood wherever you may live [both] of birds and of animals. The Torah stress this several times. Here, Rashi points out, the Torah is telling us, this excluded (from this prohibition is) the blood of fish and locusts (Toras Cohenim 7:143) For the Torah does not truly repeat itself, but seems to, in order to instruct us in something additional. There are cultures that do eat blood to this very day, in various parts of the world, believing it to be health. I have not seen any studies that suggest either way. But the Creator of Heaven and Earth decreed that we should not eat(/drink) blood, so even it is healthy physically, it is not so spiritually. For in truth, our health comes not from what we eat, but from HaShem, the Source of Everything.

Vayikra 8:2, Take Aaron, Rashi explains this expression to mean, win him over with fine words and draw him on (Siphra). Why did Moses have to take Aaron? For Aaron was embarrassed over what had happened with the Sin of the Golden Calf, and felt unworthy to be the Cohen HaGadol. So Moses had to use fine words to convince Aaron that he was in deed worthy. How many of us hesitate or even not do something, simply because we feel unworthy or something in our past holds us back. Comes the Torah and tells us take, as in take action. HaShem, and HaShem alone, knows who is truly worthy of what; if we find our Divine calling, we need to take it up and do so. Yes, we lack a Moses to tell us personally what we are to do, but HaShem is there to inform us in some manner. We just have to listen.

Vayikra 8:5, This is the procedure Rashi states that Moses told the people, The things you will see me doing in your presence has the Holy One, blessed be He, bidden me do and do not think I am doing them for my own glory and for my brother's glory. Moses wished to ensure that the people understood that, that which he was doing, he was only doing so because of HaShem's commandment. For a Levite or another should not say, if Moses, a Levite, could do it, so shall I. Rather, the service is only to be done by Aaron and his sons, the Cohenim. As well as, the Mishkan service might have seemed strange to the People, so Moses made sure that the People knew the details of the service came exactly from HaShem, and not his interpretation or such. Also, during the seven days of inauguration of the Mishkan, Moses acted as like a Cohen, when it was but a Levite, again, only because of HaShem's commandment. Yes, Aaron was a prophet as well, but it is important that all the laws, including those that dealing with the Cohenim, came from the same source.

Vayikra 8:36, Aaron and his sons carried out, Rashi tells us that this is stated to tell their praise that they did not turn to the right nor to the left (Siphra). As I said, Aaron was a prophet in his own right, but he followed the commandments of HaShem as given to Moses to tell him, as if it was given directly to him. And his sons took the commandments of Moses as if they had come direct to them, or through their father. Nor did they give the commandments their own interpretation, thinking that they were metaphors or allegories. They, Aaron and his son, took what Moses said and did, and they did the same, not adding or subtracting anything, because of personal reasoning or forgetfulness.

This Shabbat is Shabbat HaGadol, the Shabbat before Pesach. Our Sages say this Shabbat is the Big Shabbat for when the Jews left Egypt, it was the very first Shabbat that the entire Jewish nation observed completely as a whole. Our Sages also say that if the we could once more unite for another such Shabbat, that such a powerful force of peace would make Mashiach come instantly.. Just one Shabbat is all it would take. There is also, I think, the fact as it is the Shabbat before Pesach, our Sages tells us that the Shabbat blesses the rest of the week. So this Shabbat is the one that will be blessing Pesach, the festival of redemption. How much bigger can you yet? If it was not for Pesach, we would not be here today.

As my ancestors said in the Holy Temple in Jerusalem, as my father, and his father have said, and I join them in saying, saying that are reading this: May the Lord bless thee and keep thee. May the Lord make His face shine upon thee and be gracious unto thee. May the Lord lift up His countenance upon thee, and give thee peace!

And may we merit the ultimate peace of the coming of Mashiach, speedily in our day. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Vayikra
entry.content:
''
Mar 14, 2013 / 5773 Nissan 3 / ''

Parsha Vayikra /
Vayikra 1:1 5:26
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Edition Chumash, Silbermann Edition Rashi

This week's Parsha is Parsha Vayikra, which is the very first Parsha of the Sefer Vayikra ( ), which is the third book of the Torah. The Sefer Vayikra deals with many of the laws and practices of the Mishkan (and the Holy Temple). The last two Parshiot of Sefer Shemot dealt with the actual construction of the Mishkan, and now that it's built, we are informed how the Mishkan is actually to be used and what practices are to be taken within it.

In the Torah (and in many Chumashim), the final Alef () of the word Vayikra () is written as a small letter. Our Sages tells us that, the Alef is small because Moshe Rabbenu () was humble. Vayikra is a term denoting affection and communication. A large Alef was used with Adam HaReshon ( ), thus, Moshe in his humility, did not wish the same, as well as, to minimize the seemingly special treatment he got from HaShem. Both of his siblings were Prophets, and there were other non-Jews Prophets, such as Balaam, out there as well, and Moshe was humble about himself. For the Torah, itself, tells us that Moshe was the most humble of men. Moshe was not some nobody, he was a Jewish Leader, a Prophet, the Lawgiver, a priest, and Judge. He stood before the ruler of the then-world as a messenger of HaShem, he argued with HaShem, Himself, on behalf of the People, lead the Children of Israel for forty years, and fought at the front of wars against Og and Sihon. And yet, because of his closeness with HaShem and what he had done, he was humble. Thus, all Jewish leaders should have this same humility of themselves.

Vayikra 1:2, Man (), Rashi asks, Why is this term for man employed here? Since also means Adam, its use suggests the following comparison: what was the characteristic of the first man? He did not offer sacrifice of anything acquired by way of robbery, since everything was his! So you, too, shall not offer anything acquired by way of robbery. As the saying goes, two wrongs do not make a right. One can not steal and then make it right by sacrificing the stolen item to HaShem. The intention of the sacrifice has more meaning then its actuality, in several cases.

The very first offering that the Torah talks about is the free-will offering that one can make in thanksgiving or fulfillment of a vow, and not of the other types of offerings. Why is that? As awesome and inspiring as the Mishkan and later the Holy Temple in Jerusalem were, without people willing to come, they were but empty dwellings. Yes, the People had to come upon the Holy Festivals, but that was not the limitation of Judaism. A man (or woman) could bring an offering at any time or any reason, simply for the desire to draw closer to HaShem. The Mishkan (and Holy Temple) was a place where one could literal feel HaShem and through the offering have a festive meal with Him! How many can truly say they invited HaShem to their meal and a part of their lives. With the Mishkan (and Holy Temple), through the free-will offerings, you can do that. Judaism isn't a part doom and gloom, oh, you did a sin, there is no hope for you.... HaShem forbid! In those days, one gave a sin-offering as part of their repentance, and enjoyed on their salvation. How much more so, for those that came for good reasons to begin with. The Mishkan is hidden, and the Holy Temple in waste, although we cannot offer up animals or such anymore, we can still offer our free-will offering of prayer () to HaShem, as our ancestors offered their sacrifices.

Vayikra 1:7, And [the sons of Aaron] shall put fire [on the altar], Rashi informs us that Although the fire descended from heaven, it was nevertheless a religious duty to begin also some fire of profane origin. In other words, we cannot expect HaShem do everything, we must be partners with Him as well. You cannot say, HaShem will do His part, there is nothing for me to do. Rather say, HaShem had done as His wills, and has given me the tools that I need, so I shall do as my Creator desires, to work with Him in His work as I was created for. HaShem does so much for us, but not to the point of laziness and idleness, if we are to do nothing, what was the point in our creation? The world was created for us to make a dwelling for the Infinitude of HaShem within the finite of our lives.

For the bird-offering that includes its feathers, the Torah writes Vayikra 1:17, it is a burnt-offering a fire-offering, a pleasing aroma to the Eternal. But the smell of feathers burning isn't a pleasant smell, normally. The bird-offering is the offering of a poor person, who could not afford an animal-offering. Not to embarrass the poor person, the feathers remain to give the impression of a greater offering for much of the volume of a bird, is its feathers. Whether the offering is an animal or a bird, the fact that the people has fulfilled the will of His Creator is what pleasure HaShem receives from us.

And if one is so poor as to not even afford a bird, one can offer a offering of fine flour on its own. This too is pleasing to HaShem. There are several ways the fine-flour offering was done, again as not to embarrass anyone, the fine-flour offering could be done in several ways, pan-baked, fried, or rumbled.

Vayikra 2:11, Any meal-offering that you offer to the Eternal must not be made up of leavened bread [...] From Pesach, we know that leavening takes about eighteen minutes or so, and the fine-flour offering was cooked near/at the altar, so this verse is teaches us an important lesson. When doing HaShem's will, we should not allow the time to just pass us by, but to be focus and driven to do what needs to be done, when it needs to be done.

Vayikra 4:22, Rashi remarks, The word is connected in meaning with , happy. Happy is the generation whose prince (king) takes care to bring an atonement sacrifice even for an inadvertent act of his; how much more the certain it is that he will do penance for his willful sins (Siphra; Hor. 10b)! How unfortunate are we, to be in a generation where our leaders won't admit their mistakes and try to cover them up. The word if () can also be translated as when for our Creator knows that it is not a question of if, we mess up, but of when, we mess up. But it is something of a time of rejoicing when our leaders admit their mistakes, intentional or not, and seek repentance. Alas, how many of our so called leaders, instead of repenting, merely hide or try to justify what they did, in doing so, they have caused more damage then their original mistake did.

Vayikra 5:2 [...] and he [later] forgets that he is impure, and incurs guilt. Just because you forgot something does not excuse you from the consequences of that action. Why this? I'm sure the Sages have several wise and profound understanding, but for me, it is something over-simple; one's state of purity should not be so neglected that one can forget whether one is pure or not. Yes, it's human to forget or get catch up in the moment, but just means that once we become impure, we should immediately seek a remedy. Least we forget, and cause additional issues. As bad as sinning is, causing others to sin is far worse.

For such is the power of an oath: Vayikra 5:4, Or if a person verbally pronounces an oath, either to do bad or to do good, whatever a man may pronounce with an oath, and he forgets about it, and [then] realizes [that he forgot about the oath] and incurred guilt [by violating] one of these [oaths]. Our words have meaning and weight to them, and an oath, how much greater weight do they have? One can not say, oh, I forgot, too bad. No, comes the Torah and tells us, yes, you might forget your oath, for some reason, but as it's an oath, it still must be kept, and if you violate that oath of yours, you will be guilt and need to make atonement for it.

The Torah tells us that, ideally, an animal should be used for an offering, but if one cannot afford one, then a bird-offering is acceptable. If one cannot afford a bird-offering, then a meal-offering is permitted. But if one can afford an animal-offering, but brings a bird-offering that is not acceptable. As the saying goes, what you put in, is what you get out. Rather of what type of offering, it is your heart that matter, the poor-man's meal-offering with his entire heart is more meaning and profound than the many animal-offerings without one's heart involved.

The Parsha ends with Vayikra 5:26, The priest shall make an atonement for him before the Eternal, for each of all [the things] he may have done that he thereby incurred guilt, and he will be forgiven. Thus, the Torah promises us, that although we might make mistakes and sin, redemption is always possible through HaShem's mercy and ways.

And may, this month of redemption, show HaShem's ultimate mercy by bring Mashiach and the final redemption, to which our Sages say all the offerings but the thanksgiving-offerings will be discontinued, for there will not be need for them. May those days be soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Vayakhel-Pekudei - HaChodesh
entry.content:
''
Mar 6, 2013 / 5773 Adar 24 / ''

Parsha Vayakhel - Pekudei / -
Shemos 35:1 40:38
Parsha HaChodesh /
Shemos 12:1 12:20
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha is a double pasha, of the last two Parshiot of the Sefer Shemos ( ) and we have a special Maftir reading for Parsha HaChodesh, the Shabbat before the Jewish month of Nissan () starts, Rosh Chodesh Nissan ( ) fails on Tuesday, March 12th, this year. At the end of a Sefer we say (Be strong! Be strong! And may we be strengthen!), for having finished a Sefer, and hopefully, incorporated the Sefer inside of ourselves for blessings.

And what a blessing... for in this Parsha we deal with the actual construction of the Mishkan and its assembly. Our Sages say that those that study the Torah as counted among those that actually did the subject of the studying. Thus, this week, we merit the opportunity the study the construction of the Mishkan and be a part of it.

The Mishkan is special and unique. First and foremost, it was built solely by the Jews under the supervision of Moses Rabbenu, himself. It is unique that it was the first home for HaShem ever constructed, and presented a physical manner to which the Jewish people could show their desire to be with HaShem.

And yet, despite the endearment and specialness of the Mishkan, it did not over-ride the Shabbat, as the Torah states, Shemos 35:2, Work may be done for six days, but on the seventh day it shall be holy for you a complete cessation of work for the Eternal. Which is a bit interesting as we learn from the construction of the Mishkan, what labors are not permitted on Shabbat, and yet, those say labors were performed by the Cohenim () within the Mishkan (and later, the Holy Temple ). So why the prohibition? To stress the importance of the Shabbat. And after the construction of the Mishkan/Holy Temple, the importance of the holiness of those structures.

Shemos 35:27, and the leaders brought, Rashi points out on this verse, Rabbi Nassan said: What prompted the leaders to be the first to contribute in the dedication of the altar, but in the construction of the Mishkan they were not the first to contribute? Rather, this is what the leaders said: Let the community contribute whatever they will contribute, and whatever is missing we will complete. [However,] when [the people of] the community [themselves brought] everything in its entirety, as it says: What had been brought was enough (36:7), the leaders said, What shall we do [now]? [So] they brought the Shoham stones... Therefore, [later] they were the first to contribute in the dedication of the altar. [However,] because at first they acted indolently, a letter was omitted from their name (Bemidbar Rabbah 12:6) For such was the love and desire of the People of Israel for the Mishkan, they donated so much that Moses had to tell them they had enough and not to donate any more. For the Children of Israel are, in our hearts of heart, givers, since the days of Abraham Avenu ( ), represented loving-kindness that he passed on to his children.

Shemos 35:30, Chur, who was Chur? Rashi tells us, He was the son of Miryam (Sotah 11b). Thus, pointing out to us that Miryam's great-grandson, Betzal'el, who was one of the foreman of the Mishkan's construction, was who, in part, of Miryam's merits.
Shemos 35:34, and Oholiav, Rashi explains that he was from the tribe of Dan, one of the more lowly tribes, from the sons of the maidservants. [Nonetheless,] the Omnipresent gave him equal status for the construction of the Mishkan to Betzal'el, who was from [Yehudah,] one of the greater tribes, [thus] fulfilling what it says, and [before HaShem] a noble is not [more highly] regarded than a poor man (Iyov 34:19) Yehudah is the tribe of kingship, leaders, while the tribe of Dan, lacks such distinction, but before HaShem, they are equal regardless of their origin. These two had the similar personal characteristics that HaShem chose them for their sacred task. This also illustrates what is said in the Mishna and other places, that each person has a sacred task to perform here on Earth, within our lifetime. For a few, like Moses Rabbenu, himself, find out their life's mission through HaShem, while others find out as Betzal'el and Oholiav did by being informed by Moses. Many of us may not know until we stand before the Heavenly Tribunal after our allotted time is up, but such a mission still exists. Each of us has a special and holy mission to fulfill, even if it is as the Baal Shem Tov has been quoted as saying, A soul may descend to earth and live seventy or eighty years for the sole purpose of doing a favor for another -- a spiritual favor, or even a material favor. For in doing such kindness () is what HaShem, Himself, is known for, and by doing so, we emulate Him and grow closer to Him.

Shemos 37:1, Betzal'el made Rashi comments, Because he devoted himself to the work more than the other wise men, it is reckoned under his name (Tanchuma 10). For Betzal'el was not alone in the construction of the Mishkan and its vessels, but his devotion was so great, it is mentioned this way in the Torah. The Gemara (Berachos 55a) mentioned that while Moses instructed the people about the Ark and the vessels first, Betzal'el questioned Moses about this and Moses confirmed that the order should be reversed, which Moses agreed. This should be a lesson for us, just has Betzal'el used his own wisdom to question Moses about the order of the construction, so to should be not be intimidated by someone, even Moses Rabbenu, himself, to ask for clarification and seek knowledge.

Shemos 38:8, from the mirrors of (lit.) the women of multitudes Rashi informs us, The women of Israel possessed [copper] mirrors in which they would look when they adorned themselves, and even these they did not withheld from bringing as contributions for the Mishkan. Moses [at first] rejected them because they are used for [arousing] the yetzer hara ( ). [However,] the Holy One, Source of Blessing, said to him: Accept [them], for these are more precious to Me than everything else, since through them the women produced many multitudes in Egypt. [] From them, the urn was made, which serves to create harmony between a man and his wife [...] I would also think that these copper mirrors were prized possession and one of the few items that truly belonged to the Jewish people (women). Most, if not all, the wealth that the Jews had, was obtained by either upon their asking their fellow before departing Egypt, what was washed ashore after the drowning of the Egyptians, or by some similar means. For in Egypt, the Jews were slaves, lacking any wealth. And yet, not even these personal possession were withheld from the construction of the Mishkan. The Sages say that out of all the items donated to the Mishkan, the copper mirrors outshone them all. The urn brought harmony between husband and wife through the waters of the Sotah.

It should be noted that the Torah uses the single, he for describing the created of the Mishkan and its vessels, for it was with a single heart and a single mind that the Children of Israel made the vessels and the Mishkan.

Shemos 38:21, These are the accounts, our Sages tell us that Moses Rabbenu wished to make sure there would be not misunderstanding of where what went and that there should be no accusation of wrong doing, Moses gave an accounting of all the material that went into the Mishkan. This is a lessons for us all. If Moses Rabbenu, whom it is said was most trusted by HaShem, gave an accounting to the people, how much more so, should we too should be able to give an accounting as well. That account need not be that no wrong doing was not done, but where our materials went into building our lives and houses. How much time do we give to our children? To our parents? To HaShem? Can you say, with any certainty? How much of our time do we spend on meaningless things over important things? Do we even know the difference? We can learn from Moses Rabbenu and Torah.

Shemos 39:32 All the work for the Mishkan, the Tent of Meeting, was completed, and the Children of Israel [had] carried out [all the work]; they had done exactly according to everything that the Eternal had commanded Moses. Such is the praise, for any artist when given a design/idea from another, take it upon themselves to improve it or alter it in some way. But for the Mishkan, all the artisans restrained themselves and did not add or subtract from Moses commandments that he received from HaShem.

Shemos 39:33, They brought [all the parts of] the Mishkan to Moses, our Sages tell us that Moses spent so much time making sure that everything was done correctly, that he had no direct part in the Mishkan's construction. Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, left the actual task of erecting the Mishkan to Moses. As a lesson, we can learn from here, that we should not think for a moment that we are missing out on anything when we devote ourselves to helping others; for HaShem, Himself, will save a task (or two) for us. We can also learn as Rashi comments on this verse on how Moses, a single human being, could erect the enormous Mishkan that HaShem answered him, Occupy yourself with [it in such a way that] it looks as though [you are] erecting it, and it will be set up and erected by itself. Not only would we not lose out, but HaShem will help us in our task as well. In fact, in every task we undertake, HaShem helps us in some manner. To paraphrase a saying, HaShem provides the tools before giving the task.

Shemos 39:43, so Moses blessed them. The verse does not say what that blessing was, so Rashi tell us, He said to them, May it be [HaShem's] Will that the Divine Presence rest upon the work of your hands and may the pleasant aura of the L-rd, our G-d, be upon us, and [may He consolidate for us] the work of our hands... (Tehillim 90:17; Bemidbar Rabbah 12:9). [These words are part of] the eleven Psalms [beginning with] A prayer of Moses (Tehillim 90) [that were compiled by Moses].

The Sefer Shemos ends with Shemos 40:38, For the cloud of the Eternal was above the Mishkan during the day, and at night, there would be a fire, visible to all the House of Israel, wherever they stopped. Thus, the Mishkan, after its construction became the focal point of the Children of Israel, and we see that just as the Sefer Shemos started with HaShem in exile with the Jews in Egypt before the Exodus, HaShem is with the Jews in their redemption and travels to the Land of Israel; for HaShem is always with us.

Be strong (for HaShem was with us), Be strong (for HaShem is with us), And may you be strengthen (for HaShem will always be with us). Amen!

As it is the Shabbat HaChodesh, we re-read the chapters about how still within Egypt, before the Exodus, HaShem commanded us to set Nissan as the first month of our calendar. A calendar that still exists and we follow today. Unlike other calendars, we follow the Moon, but take note of the Sun as well. One should not become so fixated upon the Moon that we forget the Sun. Yes, time marches on, as the saying goes, but we must note the seasons, and ensure that even though the Moon might say it's time for a festival, the Sun (season), must also agree. Thus, we should not lose track of what's going on around us while we look at something. HaShem created an entire system, literally, for us to know when we are to have the festivals and holy days, and not just one thing for us.

As it is written, Kohelet 3:1, Everything has an appointed season, and there is a time for every matter under the heaven. And the appointed season of redemption is Nissan, as the first redemption was carried out through Moses Rabbenu, may the final redemption be carried out through Mashiach Hamelech soonest in our day, for it is the season!

entry.title: Parsha Ki Sisa
entry.content:
''
Feb 28, 2013 / 5773 Adar 18 / ''

Parsha Ki Sisa /
Shemos 30:11-34:35
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition


This week's Parsha is Parsha Ki Sisa, in which the last of the instructions for building the Mishkan are given, the sin of the Golden Calf is recorded, and the repentance, including the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy are given as well.

The word literally means raising but as Rashi points it, the word is used as an expression of obtaining as Onkelos translates it: when you wish to obtain their total number so as to know how many they are, do not count them by a head count, but rather each one [of them] shall give half a shekel, and you shall [then] count the shekels and [thereby] know their number. How is this raising? By giving, each individual elevates themselves into a collective, as the saying goes, there is strength in numbers. The individual becomes a part of something greater than themselves. When we give, we emulate our Creator, the Source of Giving, for everything is His, and grew closer still to Him.

Shemos 30:12, and there will [then] not be a plague among them Rashi explains this verse saying, for counting [people] is subject to the influence of the evil eye and [causes them to] be affected by pestilence, as we find [actually occurred] in the days of [King] David] (Shemuel II 24:10, 15). It is said that blessings are infinite, thus, if we count people, we are putting a limit to that blessing, which in times of trouble, can cause problems. Notice that trouble is limited to a fix number, while blessing is unlimitedness.

Shemos 30:12, this they shall give Rashi tells us, [HaShem] showed [Moses] like a fiery coin the weight of which was half a shekel, and He said to him, Like this they shall give (Tanchuma 9; Bemidbar Rabbah 12:3). A coin of fire, Moses was shown and he understood. For tzedakah () is like fire, it consumes what came before and illuminates the present. Fire of the four classical elements, also represents humanity reaching Heavenly. Fire is energy, never still is fire. A small fire combined with other small fires, grows and grows, becoming larger, brighter, and hotter. So each individual candle, alone, but many small flames, each casting away the shadows, combine into a bonfire, driving away the cold and the darkness.

Shemos 30:21, throughout your generations, Rashi states, From here our Rabbis derived that [the anointing oil] in its entirety will still exist in the future (Horayos 11b; Kerisos 5b) For Moses Rabbenu, himself, made the anointing oil with the purest Holiness of intentions. Our Sages say that the original Menorah of the Mishkan (King Shlomo made several others for the Temple) and the beams of the Mishkan, will exist exist now as well. Thus, somewhere in the area of Israel, probably buried/stores somewhere is the main structure of the Mishkan. That is to say, a place for the Holy Ark, when it is found, has a place waiting for it, if not the actual Third Temple. In other words, the anointing oil that Mashiach will use, may it be soonest, will be the very same oil that Moses Rabbenu created and used with the Mishkan so long ago.

Shemos 31:3, with knowledge, Rashi remarks, that knowledge is that which a man hears from others and [thus] learns [it].

Shemos 31:3, with understanding, Rashi differs understanding from knowledge, as he can deduce something on his own from the things he has [already] learned. In other words, knowledge comes from without, while understanding comes from within. The Torah is HaShem's knowledge given to us, it up to us to take that knowledge and understand it by applying those concept to our every day life.

For those that ask how could a bunch of uneducated slaves build the Mishkan, the Torah answers, Shemos 31:6, I have instilled every wise-hearted person with knowledge, and they shall make everything Thus, those with the desire in their hearts and understood that desire to commit such an undertaking, HaShem gave them the means to which they could accomplish their goal. Such is Life, with a capital 'L'; we need only to have the desire to come closer to Him and understanding of that desire, and HaShem will provide us with the means to carry out that desire

Shemos 31:13, you shall nevertheless keep my shabbosos Rashi comments, even though you will be anxious and eager to [carry out] the work promptly; do not defer Shabbos on its account. Every or [written in the Torah signifies] a limitation, [and here is added] to exclude Shabbos from [the days when] the work of [building] the Mishkan [may be done]. For so important is the Shabbat () that one needs to be care of it, even when performing HaShem given commands. The Torah verse continues to explain why Shabbat is important, for the Torah says, for it is a sign between Me and you, throughout your generations that it be known that I am the Eternal Who sanctifies you. As long as there is a Shabbat, there will be the Jewish People to sanctify that HaShem created the world in six days and rested upon the seventh.

Shemos 32:4, these are your gods to which Rashi points out, but it does not say, These are our gods. From here [we may thus infer] that it was the mixed multitude [of peoples] who came up [with them] from Egypt who congregated against Aharon, and it was they who made [the Golden Calf] and afterwards led Israel astray after it. Thus, we should know that the people of Israel were not looking to make an idol, something to replace HaShem, rather the people were looking for something/someone to replace this man, Moses

Shemos 32:5, a festival to the Eternal, Rashi states, [This shows] that [Aharon's real] intention was for the sake of [HaShem in] Heaven, [for] he was confident that Moses would come and they would [actually] serve the Omnipresent. Aharon called for a festival to HaShem, the four-letter name, denoting transcendence and mercy. For Aharon believed in HaShem and Moses, His prophet, and hoped that HaShem's mercy and wisdom would prevail in such a confused and distressed time.

Shemos 32:7, your people... have become corrupt, Rashi points out, It does not say, the people have become corrupt, but: your people; [i.e.] the mixed multitude [of people] whom you accepted on your own initiative and converted them to Judaism and you did not [first] consult with Me, but you said, It is a good thing that proselytes join with the Divine Presence it is they who have become corrupt and have corrupted [the others] (Shemos Rabbah 42:6). Thus, the sin did not begin with the Children of Israel, but with the mixed multitudes, while not responsible for the direct act, they were punished for not rebuking it, and not stopping the foolish from joining in.

Shemos 32:10, Let Me be Rashi notes, We have not yet heard that Moses prayed for them, yet [HaShem] says, Let Me be! Rather, here He gave [Moses] an opening and informed him that the matter was dependent on him, that if he would pray for them He would not destroy him. For such is the way of HaShem, He prompts us to repent and shows us the way to be closer to Him. For even the most grievous of sins, there can be redemption. And from redemption, a stronger, closer bond can be forged.

Shemos 32:14, The Eternal relented from the evil that He had declared, That is to say, any evil decree can be annulled, but any good decree can never be annulled.

Shemos 32:16, were G-d's work, Rashi explains, [Its meaning is] as literally implied, [i.e.] G-d, Himself, made them. Another explanation: Just as a man says to his friend, So-and-so's entire occupation is with a particular work, so, too, the entire delightful preoccupation of the Holy One, Source of Blessing, is with the Torah ) (Tanchuma 16). Meaning that the Torah is what HaShem does, the blueprints of existence.

Shemos 32:25, all the sons of [the tribe of] Levi, Rashi states, From here [we see] that the entire tribe was virtuous (Yoma 66b). Thus, the elderly righteous, the tribe of Levi, the children under twenty and the women of the generation that left Egypt, were those that entered the Land of Israel.

Shemos 32:32, from your book, Rashi writes, from the entire Torah, so that [people] will not say about me that I was not worthy of [effectively] pleading for mercy for them. For such is the character of a true Jewish leader, to sacrifice everything for the Jewish People. For what would have been the Five Books of Moses, without Moses? Moses very existence was to give the Torah to the Jewish People. Thus, when Moses said, erase me from your book, he was saying remove me from everything that I was created for.

Shemos 33:7, Anyone who sought the Eternal, Rashi says, From here [we learn] that one who seeks [the counsel of] a wise man is considered as though he had met with the Divine Presence (Tanchuma 27). For those that are wise, are close to HaShem, the Source of Wisdom.

Shemos 33:20, You will not be able to see My Face, our Sages have pointed out, many, many times, we do not see the working of HaShem (His face) until after the fact (His back). We also may not recognize the work/hand of our Creator at the present time as things are happening, and maybe not even after, but has our Sages say, everything is in the hands of Heaven, but the fear of Heaven. We might not see that HaShem is watching us (His face turned to us), but He is there, and there is more going on that we know.

Shemos 33:22, and I will spread (lit.) my palm [over you] Rashi teaches us, from here [we learn] that license is given to the destructive angels to harm (Bemidbar Rabbah 14:18). Onkelos translates [these words] as: I will protect [you] with My word, which is a euphemism of respect used with regard to the One Above, for He does not need to protect him with an actual [physical] hand. He that unleashes the destructive angels can also protect those He wishes.

Shemos 34:3, No man may ascend with you Rashi says, The first [set of Tablets], since they were [given] with loud acclaims, thunder claps and [in the presence of a large] crowd, the evil eye had an effect on them. [HaShem was thus indicating here to Moses:] There is no better trait than modesty. Why did not HaShem protect His people from the evil eye? Why allow the Golden Calf to happen, but to teach the lesson of modesty? Just because there is an effect, does not guarantee failure, the people had free choice in what they did. And to show us, even from the sin of the Golden Calf, we can learn something positive. There is nothing in Creation that is truly divorced from HaShem, there is no true (100%) evil.

Shemos 34:6-7, (6) The Eternal passed before him and declared, [I am] the Eternal [before the sin and] the Eternal [after the sin], all-powerful, merciful and kind, slow to anger, abundant in kindness and faithful; (7)preserving [any] kindness [done before Him] until two thousand [generations, and] bearing [any] transgression, iniquity and sin. He will not completely overlook [any sin]; He reckons the father's transgression to the sons' and grandsons' account, [even] up to the third and fourth generations. Rashi points out, Thus it follows that [HaShem's] good measure [of rewarding] is five hundred times more than [His] measure of punishment, for with regards to [HaShem's] good measure it says: preserving kindness for two thousand [generations] (Tosefia, Sotah 4:1). For HaShem is good and just. He does not forget that the grandchildren inherit from the children, the children inherit from the parents. But just because parent(s) are bad/evil, does not mean that the children should be bad/evil as well, but if they are, they will pay for their own sins and those of their parents that they should have known better. A child has a choice whether to follow in their parents' foot steps or step out of their shadow, and make their own decisions.

The sixth aliyah is talks about the three Pilgrim festivals, as for Pesach, Shavuot, and Sukkot, all your menfolk shall appear before the Lord, the Eternal, G-d of Israel. (Shemos 34:23)

The seventh aliyah tells us that after his encounter with HaShem's glory, Moses's face would shine. Because of the people's sin, they could not bear to look at Moses unless he was studying Torah with them. For such is the power of Torah, to illuminate one and protect the others. For it is said, HaShem is an all-consuming fire, but through and by the Torah, we are not consumed and live with HaShem.

May the day come when we all can be illuminated as Moses Rabbenu was; and as he did so too may we all merit to learn directly from HaShem, face to face, which can happen with the coming of Mashiach, speedily within our days. Then, our faces will radiate like Moses will with HaShem's glory.

entry.title: Parsha Tetzaveh
entry.content:
''
Feb 21, 2013 / 5773 Adar 11 / ''

Parsha Tetzaveh /
Shemos 27:20-30:10
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition


This week's Parsha is Parsha Tetzaveh, which deals with the Priestly garments that were used with the Temple Service. After the details of the making the vessels and the structural outline of the Mishkan, the Torah goes into the details of the garments that the Priest wore. Why this order? The Sages have many answers. To ask another question, what is the single most important "item" of the Mishkan? The obvious answer is the Ark of the Covenant, for it was the very first item mentioned, and it was from the under the wings of the Cherubs above the lid of the Ark that HaShem spoke to Moses. And yet, HaShem really did not "use" the Mishkan, until after Moses and Aaron blessed the people and offered prayers and incense. For as important as the objects within the Mishkan are, and even the Priestly garments, it is the actions of the Cohanim () that makes the Mishkan and the Temple the holy place it is when they fulfill HaShem's Will.


To underscore the importance of action, the Parsha starts off with the requirement of the oil for the Menorah.
The purpose of the Menorah was enlightenment, as the Mishkan and within the Temple, the area of the Holy and Holies of Holy, was inside. The olive oil that fueled the Menorah had to be purest of oils, only the very first from a olive was acceptable. What does this mean? It means that when we try to illuminate others, we must be sure that our methodology is pure as well. One of the greatest harms comes not from idolatry, but from wrongful teaching. It is misunderstanding and lack of knowledge that many of the faults which people "find" that causes many of the issues we face today.


The next item that is discussed in the Torah is the High Priest ( )'s eight garments.and the four garments of the "regular" Cohan (). As the saying goes, the "clothes make the person" and "respect the uniform, it not the man."


Within the Breastplate of Judgement was the Shemos 28:30, "the Urim and Tumin". Rashi tells us that the Urim and Tumin as a piece of parchment upon which the Explicit Name of HaShem was written upon it. Although, the Sages are not sure which name this was, being the four-letter, forty-two letter, or seventy-two letter name. Our Sages tell us that the Urim and Tumin would "power" the breastplate of Judgement causing individual names to light up, thus the Cohen Hagadol ( ) would be able to receive the answer that the Sanhedrin or the King wished to pose to HaShem. On the Breastplate of Judgement had twelve different stones upon it four rows by three columns. Each stone represented and engraved with the name of each of the twelve Tribes. The answer that HaShem would send had to interpret since the letters illuminated may not have been in the correct order.


Also of note was the head-plate, which said, "Holy for HaShem ( -)" with the explicit four-letter name. It is said that a Rabbi had a chance to look into the Vatican vaults, which contains items the Roman Empire stole. Within this vault, there was such head-plate, which had HaShem's name higher than the word "Holy ()". Why is this of note, after all, the Cohen Hagadol cannot see it, rather it is for the others to see and be reminded for whom the Cohen Hagadol services. The Cohen Hagadol also can feel its weight, as it was made from pure gold, upon his head and that too services as a reminder that the weight of his office and whom he services is upon him.


Shemos 29:18, "a pleasing aroma", Rashi informs us, "[i.e.] it gives Me [HaShem] pleasure that I asked [that this to be done] and My will was carried out (Zevachim 46b)." It is not the actual sacrifice that matters to HaShem, rather it is His will that is carried out that matters. To HaShem, everything is His, and there is no difference between an offering of flour (poor man) and an offering of ram.(rich man). It is man's obedience that HaShem enjoys. The Midrash relates a "story" of the king had commanded that the Cohenim reserve the altar solely for his multitude of sacrificial animals, which was done. At some point, a poor man came with two turtle-doves as his offering to HaShem. The Cohen Hagadol informed the poor man of the situation, but the poor man begged him to offer his sacrifice, saying that he always went out to the field and caught four turtle-doves, two for his family and two for offering to HaShem. Moved by the poor man, the Cohan Hagadol, himself, the sacrifice, and then carried out the rest of the king's sacrifices. That last the king had a dream and was told that despite the countless animals he had offered, the poor man's offering of half his livelihood meant more to HaShem. In the morning, the king sent word to the Cohen Hagadol that he was correct in what he done.

Shemos 29:29, "to his sons after him," which Rashi says, "to the one who succeeds him in [his] office of greatness [as High Priest]." Also, the literal meaning is true in that, the son of the previous Cohen Hagadol is the first choice to be his father's successor. 

The Parsha also mentions the sacrifices that were offered for the inauguration of the Mishkan. Sacrifices were means for a person to obtain atonement and to draw nearer to HaShem. It was a means to share with HaShem and invite Him into our life in a real physical sense.

The end of the Parsha talks about the golden incense altar, this altar was inside the Mishkan, in the Holy, and all that was offered upon this altar was the incense offering. On the altar of copper was the animals, upon the altar of gold, the incense. The incense was special, for it was offered daily and by the community as a whole.

What is daily and harmonious is very important to HaShem. That is many ways is the goal of Creation for the lowest realm being in constant and peace with our Creator, by doing His will, whether we understand it or not.

Maybe Mashiach come soon, so we may once again offer the incense and thanksgiving offerings to Him that it is due, and peace will reign supreme through the cosmos.

entry.title: Parsha Terumah
entry.content:
''
Feb 14, 2013 / 5773 Adar 4 / ''

Parsha Terumah /
Shemos 25:1 27:19
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha is Parsha Terumah ( ), which begins with asking donations for the building of the Mishkan () and the details of its constructions. The following four Parsha, which will concluded Sefer Shemot ( ), will deal with the Mishkan as well. Up until this point in the Torah, no subject has filled so many Parshiot. Sefer Shemot began with the Egyptian exile and ends with building of the Mishkan.

The fact that the Mishkan's instructions and construction take up almost five Parshiot is telling how important it is. Our Sages tell us that the Mishkan represented all of Creation, in miniature, a microcosm of Creation itself, as the very purpose of Creation is for HaShem to have a dwelling place within the lowest of the realms. That dwelling place is among the People, and represented by the Mishkan and later the Holy Temple within Jerusalem. Creation began in Parsha Bereishet and Sefer Bereishet and accumulated with the building of the Mishkan at the end of Sefer Shemot. It was something that only with HaShem's help was possible. For the entire Cosmos is HaShem and cannot contain Him, but this 60 cubit by 120 cubit enclosed tented area did. Or rather, the space between the wings of the cherubim and the lid of the Ark, which was 2.5 cubits long, 1 cubit wide, and 10 hand-breath high. How was such an infinitely small space able to contain the Infinite?

Because it was created out of Love and Harmony by the Jewish People, who gave from the bottom-most of their Hearts all that they could.

As it is a microcosm of Creation, the study of the Mishkan can tell us many things about ourselves and Creation as a whole.

The beginning of the Mishkan, the Torah mentions the ingredients that will create the Mishkan.

Shemos 25:5, Tachash, which Rashi informs us is a type of animal, and it existed only at that time. It was multicolored and therefore [Onkelos] translates [it as]: , [meaning] that it rejoices () and prides itself in its various colors () (Shabbat 28a). There are several Sages that say that Tachash was the unicorn. Whatever the animal was, it existed only in those days, and for the Mishkan's sake.

Shemos 25:11, from inside and outside you shall overlay it as Rashi points out on this verse, three arks were made, two of gold and one of wood. The wooden one slipped into the outer golden one, and the inner golden one slipped into the wooden one. This begs several questions, the foremost, why gold inside? It would not be seen by anyone and gold does not preserve items like wood does. There is a lesson for us here, our Sages tell us what we are being told here is that one's outside should match one's inside. One should not having think one thing, but say something completely different. Another lesson, while no one would see the inner gold, we know it is there from the Torah, thus there are hidden things in our lives that can over be discovered through HaShem. The lining of the Ark was gold, wood, and then gold, in terms of material, it was soft, hard, soft thus we should buffer our hardness with softness both before and afterward. The Ark of the Covenant was ultimately nothing more than a box, simple and functional. What was important was what it contained, not the box itself. And yet, the Ark of the Covenant is not called the box containing the covenant But the Ark of the Covenant itself, for what it held became apart of it and because of that, it is an Ark and not a box. The Ark because of its important cargo could not be basic/plain but beautiful and regal in appearance. In other words, one should not just do the minimum and be done with it, rather, one should embrace it and beautify both the object in question and its container.

After the Ark of the Covenant was described, the next item is the the Table of the Show Bread, from the spiritual representative of the Covenant, HaShem goes to the Table of the Show Bread, which is the mundane, physical. Twelve loafs of bread were placed by this table, in two stacks of six, every Erev Shabbos and were taken down a week later when new bread was placed upon the table. This table was also made of wood and covered in gold, unlike the Ark, there was no inside, only the outside. The focus of the table was not the table itself, but the show bread that was placed upon it. Unlike the Ark, which after the Covenant was placed within and never removed, the Show Bread was replaced on a weekly bases. I think this can teach that sustenance comes and goes, or fluctuates, but the spiritual remain constant. Our Sages link the Table with nobility/kingship, which teaches us that those in leadership position are responsible for their charges and need to provide their food/substance for them.

After the table of the Show Bread, HaShem gave instructions for creating the Menorah. The Menorah, unlike the Ark and Table, had to be created from a single piece/sheet of gold, and had no wood within it for it was made from pure gold (only). This seems to me to tell us, when one is a source of light/knowledge, they should be completely pure, without anything else involved. What is shown that should be all that there is. The Menorah was whole, so too, our enlightenment should be as well. It is not true enlightenment if it deals only in parts, or within certain cases, or even from certain points of view. The Menorah, only from a single piece of gold, was not a simple light-holder, but beautified with decorations, which have mystical meaning that I am unsure of, but need to explore.

After the Menorah, the Torah talks starts to talk the Mishkan's structure itself. First the Torah talks about the drapes that created the roof and side-covering of the Mishkan. Which was the outermost part of the Mishkan. When one came upon the Mishkan, the very first thing they would have seen was the drapes, covering and protecting the Mishkan. The message, I think, is when one does a service to HaShem, one should be covered There are times when one's service to HaShem should be done in privacy and other times when it is done in public.

After the drapes, the Torah talks about the actual beams that gave the Mishkan its the physical structure and boundaries. This teaches us, there no matter how spiritual or important, there are all ways boundaries. And boundaries are not a bad thing. It is in fact these boundaries that define the importance and spirituality of the Mishkan (and our lives).

After the beams, the Torah talks about the partition covering that separated the Holies from the Holy of Holies. A clear division is needed between the mundane, the holy, and the holy of holies.

After all that, the copper altar is mentioned. It was upon the copper altar on the outside where most of the Temple Service took place. The golden altar was inside and only incense was burnt there.

Shemos 27:1 and you shall overlay it with copper, which Rashi tells us, in order [for it] to atone for brazen impudence, as it says: and your forehead is [raised and hard like] copper (Yeshayah 48:4). This can also tell us that the altar that the sin-offerings and the thanksgiving-offerings was done upon copper not gold, for it would be unseemly that should humble acts should be done upon gold, rather, that which is an act of humbleness should be carried out upon humbleness as well, start to finish.

The Mishkan was created by Moses Rabbenu and the entire Jewish People, as such, it's eternal. While the two Holy Temples were destroyed, the Mishkan vessels and structure, itself, remains, hidden away somewhere.

The biggest issue with the Ark of Covenant is where to put it, if we merit it's public return, and the third Holy Temple could not be immediately built, then conceivably we could store it within the Mishkan once more.

The Mishkan could houses HaShem for it was built through love and peace, fulfilling the purpose of Creation. May we see the ultimate expression of love and peace through the coming of Mashiach, may he come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Mishpatim
entry.content:
''
Feb 6, 2013 / 5773 Shevat 26 / ''

Parsha Mishpatim Shabbat Shekalim /
Shemos 21:1 24:18
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

Parsha Mishpatim states with, Shemos 11:1, And these are the laws, to which Rashi informs us, Wherever [a section begins with] these, [it] rejects something previous, [but where a section begins with] and these, [it] adds to something previous (Shemos Rabbah 30:3). [Thus here it says and these to teach us that] just as [the commandments written in] the previous section [where received at] Sinai, so, too, these [written in the section were received at] Sinai (Mechilta, Parsha Mishpatim, sec. 1). Why, then, is the section dealing with civil laws placed following the section [about the construction] of the altar? To tell you that you shall place [the seat of] the Sanhedrin next to the Temple. Which is an amazing thing: although, Judaism does have a division between Temple and State as the Tribe of Levi (only) was assigned to the Holy Temple in Jerusalem, so too, the Tribe of Judah (only) was assigned the Kingship over Israel. And yet, one should not think, G-d forbid, that the State should be G-d-less, for HaShem that gave over the Temple service is the same HaShem that commandments the Jewish judges in regards to civil court cases. Yes, even King David ( ), himself, could not perform the sacrificial service, nor could the High Priest ( ) declare/lead the people in war, but the two could not ignore the other. Just as the laws of the Temple Service has many, many spiritual components and concepts, so too does Jewish civil law.

In other words, within Judaism there is no distinction between religious and secular, as the Torah says, there is but one law. A Jew is a Jew, secular or not, religious or not. For HaShem that gave us the Ten Commandments and the Temple Service, is the same HaShem that enlighten us to civil laws and justice. What seems to obvious to civilized nations today, is but the trickle down effect of the Torah, which was given over three thousand years ago. As the Temple Service brought peace between HaShem and Man, so too the Jewish Courts are to bring peace between Man and Man.

Out of all the civil cases that the Torah could use to start this section, the Torah uses the case of a man that stole, could not repay it back, the Court sells the thief to pay off the debt as a slave for maximum six years. Why did the Torah pick this one? Only HaShem truly knows, and I am very sure our Sages have many discussions about it.

Here are my thoughts on this: the Written Torah only highlights the extreme cases, whereas the Oral Torah goes into details of the Laws. And this case is an extreme case and evolutionary to human understand. Many of the understandings of the day believed in eternal damnation/punishment for an event in the past, comes the Torah and says, Shemos 21:2, [...] and in the seventh [year] he shall go free without paying. Which illustrates the connection that Rashi mentioned with this section and the previous section of the altar, just as the altar and its appropriate service can atone for one's sin, so too there are prescriptions for one atoning for one's crimes. Stealing is a major crime, so bad is stealing it was one of the causes for Noach's Flood. And yet, the Torah comes and has a solution for a thief to repair his/her relationship between Man and Man and between Man and HaShem. There is also a hidden warning; such as the penalties for invalidating the Temple Service were sever, so too the penalties for corrupting Justice are as sever as well.

Shemos 21:7, And if a man sells his daughter as a maidservant [...] Which is usually misunderstood, our Sages tell us that this is a special case, a poor man cannot support his daughter the Torah gives him permission to set up a marriage where her dowry is her service to her future's husband's mother or female relative, where this girl can learn what her father could not provide her.

Shemos 21:13, [...] G-d caused [it] to happen [...], Rashi explains this saying, And why was this decreed by [HaShem]? This is [to] what David said: As the dictum of the Ancient One says: From wicked people comes forth wickedness (Shemuel I 24:14) and the dictum of the Ancient One is the Torah, for it is the dictum of the Holy One, Source of Blessing, Who is the One Who preceded the world. Rashi goes on to explain what's happening here, the Torah is talking of something that unintentionally kills someone else. That someone else is someone who killed another intentionally but there was no witnesses for a Earthly Court to convict him, so the Holy One, Blessed be He, arranges for this intentionally murderer to be killed by an unintentionally one. Even though this one, the unintentionally murderer is carrying out a Heavenly Court decree, the reason why this person was selected to carry out the decree is because this person has an account to be settled too.

So important is justice that Shemos 21:14, [even] from My altar you shall take him to die. meaning that the verdict of a convicted murdered should not be delayed for something as important even the Temple Service, or in modern terms, just because a convicted murderer finds G-d does not commute their sentence.

Shemos 21:17, And he who curses his father or mother must be put to death. The Torah had talked of those that are convicted of murder, and the Torah links one who cursed their parent in the same category. For such is the power of words and coupled that these cursed were against one's own parent, the damage that they cause are liken to murdering a person.

Shemos 21:19, [...] He shall, however, pay for his lost work-time and provide for [his] complete recovery. From here, we learn it is a forgone conclusion that one should seek medical service/aid to deal with one's injury or illness. Thus, one that caused another an injury, needs to compensate for the injured parties lost of income and medical costs.

Shemos 21:24, an eye for an eye [...], one of the most misquoted/misused verse in the entire Torah. Rashi explains its meaning: [If] he blinded the eye of his fellowman, he must pay him the value of this eye, [i.e.] how much his value has depreciated to be sold [as a servant] in the market [as a result of losing his eye]; and similarly with all [the other cases mentioned in the verse]. [It does] not, [however, mean] the actual removal of [the offender's] limb, as our Rabbis explained in Chapter Hachovel (Bava Kamma 83b/84a). I do recommend reading the Talmud passages where our Sages explain this passage. This simple meaning is that, one pays the value of the same and not the value of something else. An eye is important to anyone, a tooth can be worthless, while a hand and foot can be of varying values but not as important as an eye, which is why these four were selected by HaShem.

Shemos 21:37, five oxen, Rashi tells us, Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai said: The Omnipresent has consideration for the dignity of [His] creatures; [For stealing] an ox, which walks by itself and [thus] the thief did not suffer indignity by carrying it on his shoulders, he pays fivefold [compensation, but for stealing] a sheep, which he carried on his shoulders, he pays [only] fourfold, since he suffered indignity through it. Rabbi Meir said: Come and see how great is the virtue of work: [For stealing] an ox, which he [thereby] causes to desist from its work, he pays fivefold [compensation, but for stealing] a sheep, which he did not cause to desist from its work, [he pays only] fourfold (Bava Kamma 79b, Mechilta sec 12). Even the sinner does the HaShem, the Source of Mercy, consider, for He considers the sinner's dignity and the victim's needs when He established the sinner's compensation. This is stated if the civil law, where such is not truly needed, how much more so, for those that sin in spiritual matters?

Shemos 22:1, [...] he has no blood. Rashi instructs, [this means] it is not [considered] murder [if one kills the thief, for[ he is as though he were a dead man [already] from the start [of his criminal act]. Here the Torah teaches you [that] if someone comes to kill you, preempt [him] by killing him [first], and this [burglar definitely] came to kill you, for he is fully aware that no person holds himself back and sees someone stealing his property before [his eyes] and stays silent, [and] so he came with the intention that if the owner of the property stands up against him, he will kill him (Sanhedrin 72a). If its obvious that someone is going to kill you, you have the Divine Right to kill them before they can kill you. For sin begets sin, from trespassing to stealing to killing.

The Torah states that a person is responsible for their own actions and the actions of that which is in their dominion, as such as animals that does damage to another. Thus we need to think of the possible consequences of what we are doing. Again, just as within the civil matters, so too, we need to think of such within the spiritual realms as well. As our Sages says, if only man know what a sin does to him, he would not sin. Thus, we sin out of ignorance or foolishness as our Sages say. Sinning is spiritual, something the common man knows little and seeing none, thus the Torah talks of civil law, which he can see and learn. And HaShem is the Source of both and parallels can be made from either to the other.

Shemos 22:6 You must not pervert the judgment of your destitute in his dispute. If the case is against him, one must rule that way and not think that they are doing HaShem's work by helping this person at the expense of justice. It is not for us to decide that justice should be set aside, there is more going on than we know of. In the End, the Heavenly Court balances the books. We cannot upset the balance just because we think we know better.

In honor of Purim that's coming up, we read a special Maftir and Haftarah for Shabbat Shekalim ( ), the Shabbat before the month of Adar comings in. The Maftir and Haftarah reading both mention the annual half-shekel coin donation that was used to purchase the communal sacrifices which was collected in the month of Adar. Why half coin? To show that we need others to be whole and how great is the power of unity. Also, the half-coin was given by everyone, the king gave the same half-coin as the poorest of the people, for before HaShem we are all His children and equal in His eyes.

As we read about the half-shekel, hinting of Purim and the Temple Service, may we merit the coming of Mashiach so that we may once again unite in spiritual harmony to carry out HaShem's will.

entry.title: Parsha Yisro
entry.content:
''
Jan 30, 2013 / 5773 Shevat 19 / ''

Parsha Yisro /
Shemos 18:1 20:23
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha is Parsha Yisro. Who was Yisro that an entire Parsha of the Holy Torah was named after him? The opening verse of the Parsha tells us, Shemos 10:1, Yisro, the lord of Midyan, Moses's father-in-law Thus we know three things: first, that he was a goy from Midyan; second, he was their lord/ruler; and third, Moses married one of his daughters.

Another famous father-in-law within the Torah was Laban, the father-in-law of Ya'akov, and yet the Torah does not call him that. Nor does the Torah call Laban a lord of anything. Quite the opposite, in fact. So just from those few words, we have learned that Yisro was the opposite of Laban. A lord, Yisro was respected and of good character. Such a good character that Moses Rabbenu married into his family, by taking his daughter as a wife.

Rashi notes, Shemos 10:11, than all [other's] gods means, [This] teaches [us] that [Yisro] knew about every [form of] idol-worship in the world, for there was no idol-worship which he had not practiced. In other words, Yisro was a seeker of truth. He went from idol to idol, seeking the truth. A truth he could not find among the idols of the world, for they are false. So he had an understanding of the world, what was true, and a drive to find it. This is not a common-man, but a truly noble-man of character and intelligence.

And yet, the Torah is filled with such people and we only find two other Parshot prior named for people, Noach and Chayei Sarah. Noach was the father of all of modern-day humanity and Sarah was the mother of the Jewish nation. And yet, Yisro does not fall into those categories. We are told of Moses's children, Yisro's grandchildren, when they are born, but they have no notice within the Tanach (''). In Parsha Shemos, the Torah relates that Moses, himself, was almost killed because one of his sons were not circumcised prior to his undertaking his Divine mission. In fact, the Midrash tell us that Moses had agreed with Yisro that one of his two sons would be raised Jewish, while the other son would find his way. Something that almost cost Moses his life.

Within the Parsha itself, the Torah relates that Yisro saw/watched Moses sit in court and he remarked on a system upon which to judge the people, which HaShem seemingly agrees with. Which is interesting in itself. The Torah only tells us, Shemos 10:24, Moses heeded his father-in-law's [words] and did everything that he had said. Among the words of Yisro was to consult with HaShem and seek His agreement to implement such a plan.

Our Sages disagree when this exchange took place, as whether the Torah is completely in chronological order or not. And yet, this is placed before the verses of the Giving of the Torah ( ) at Mount Sinai. So Torah-wise, it was needful for this to happen before the Giving of the Torah.

Why? I am sure there are many of Sages and Rabbis that have various answers to that, but here is mine.

Moses was a prophet unlike any other. When the time came for him to bless the people, he said, Devarim 32:1, Listen, O heavens, and I will speak For he said Heaven first, for he was closer to Heaven than Earth. He was more spiritual than mundane. For him, the spiritual was mundane, and he wished, Bamidbar 11:27, If only all the Lord's people were prophets, that the Lord would bestow His spirit upon them! And the Torah itself states, Devarim 34:10, And there was no other prophet who arose in Israel like Moses, whom the Eternal knew face to face Thus he was someone that no one could copy (exactly). Joshua, his student and successor was compared to the Moon, to Moses's Sun.

Whether Yisro was correct or not about Moses being able to judge the people himself, it would definitely be the case that those that followed after Moses would not be able to. More over, Devarim 30:12, It [Torah] is not in heaven Moses judged through Divine Inspiration ( ), which is the ideal way of doing it. Thus, Yisro's system was more materialistic and practical from a mundane perspective. Ideally, we should all involve HaShem in everything and within court, in a holy manner. Unfortunately, our animal souls do get the better of us so that Moses's system, while ideal, is not practicable as such, but Yisro's system would be.

Plus, the purpose of Creation, our Sages tell us, is for us to create a dwelling place for HaShem here in the lowest realm. To do so, we need to reach out to HaShem and do His mitzvos. Which means taking our G-dly souls and involved it into the mundane. To use our own intellect not Ruach Ha-Kodesh ( ) to do things. Not that it is wrong to do so, but we must make our own effort to do mitzvos and not depend upon HaShem to do them for us.

For the Torah was once in the Heaven, but Moses brought it down to earth for us, and it is here, on Earth, where the Torah remains and guides us. It is up to us to make a home for the Torah and HaShem within the Earth and our lives. And Yisro and his system of judgment made that possible.

Shemos 19:1, On this day Rashi explains, [i.e.] on the first day of the month. [According to the context, the Torah] ought to have written [here]: on that day. [For] what [reason, then, does it write] on this day? [To indicate] that the words of Torah should [always] be to you like something new, as if they had been given [to you] today (Tanchuma Yashan13). One should not think that the Torah was given to Moses and his generation, over three thousand years ago, thus should not have any meaning today. Rather, one should understand that the Torah is the word of HaShem, as HaShem is eternal, so too are His word. Torah is not old and thus out of touch, rather is it is the very blueprint of the creation. The world does not change Torah, Torah changes the world. Torah is not stale, but refresh, thus allowing me to write this blog entry and all the others.

Shemos 19:2 Israel camped there, Rashi points out, as one man [and] with one heart, but all [their] other encampments were [involved] with grumbling and quarreling. But for Matan Torah, all of Israel waited like a bride waiting to be married.
