Shemos 19:8, Moses then conveyed the people's words, Rashi comments on this phrase with, on the next day, which was third day [of the month], for [whenever] he ascended [the mountain to speak with HaShem, it was] first thing in the morning. But was it [really] necessary for Moses to convey [Israel's reply]? [Is not HaShem Omniscient?!] However, the verse comes to teach you correct behavior from Moses['s example], that he did not say, Since He Who sent me knows [the reply anyway], I do not need to convey [it]. In other words, even when it seems that completing a task seems pointless, it is proper behavior to follow-through and complete it.

Shemos 19:9, The words of the people Rashi tells us, [Moses said to HaShem:] I have heard from them a response to this matter, that they wish to hear from You, [for] one who hears from messenger cannot be compared to one who hears from the king [himself]. [They said,] Our wish is to see our King. Such is the power of peace and unity of the Jewish people. As one the Jewish people asked for something that had never been done before or since, something completely out of the ordinary without precedent, and because of the unity and peace of the people, it was granted.

Shemos 19:11, For all the people to see, Rashi points out a miracle at Matan Torah, [This] teaches [us] that there was no blind person among them, for they were all healed.

Shemos 19:15, do not come near a woman, this was said to man, and Rashi points out, this was for the benefit of the woman (in question, the man's wife), so that he should not make her impure, not about him becoming impure. This is also, I think, to set the mood in which martial relationship, a very important activity yet physical, which was set aside for the spirituality of Matan Torah.

Shemos 19:21, And many [of them] will fall [dead] Rashi remarks, However many of them fall, even if it be one individual, I [HaShem] consider it [like] many. So precious is the Jewish people to HaShem that even the lost of a single Jew is very painful to Him.

Shemos 20:1, G-d then spoke, Rashi says that Elokim, the name denoting Divine Judgment, is used here that such are the Ten Commandants that HaShem, Himself, spoke to the people that He is a judge who exacts punishment [for not fulfilling these mitzvos].

Shemos 20:1, All these words, Rashi writes, [This] teaches [us] that the Holy One, Source of Blessing, said the Ten Commandants in one utterance something that is impossible for a person to [do]. If so, what [is the Torah] teaching [us] by saying further: I am (20:2) and You must not have (20:3-6)? [It is telling us] that [HaShem] repeated and expressly uttered each commandant by itself. By saying all Ten Commandants as a single utterance, HaShem demonstrated that the Ten Commandants aren't ten separate items but rather they are a single unit. And by a single utterance that is was HaShem, and not some trick, to who was speaking.

Shemos 20:2, I am the Eternal (' ), two words, and our Sages tell us that all of Creation ceased and stilled. When Mashiach comes, HaShem will once more say those words and we will see and understand, as the Children of Israel sang in the previous Parsha, This is my G-d At that very moment, the entire Children of Israel stood at the level of the Prophets and heard with their own ears and saw with their own eyes, HaShem. For such was the Matan Torah, HaShem spoke to the entire people, all them, all six hundred (odd) married men, their six hundred (odd) wives, and their children, which if you average (2.5), which estimates the entire people, adults and children, around three million. All saw and heard HaShem speak to them, individually and as a people as a whole. This is what Judaism is based upon. Not some individual, but the entire people saw and heard directly from HaShem, Himself. This is the core of Judaism.

Such was Matan Torah that Shemos 20:15, And all the people seeing the sound, which our Sages say that which was heard was seen, and what was seen was heard, is the best what can be given to explain what happened at Matan Torah. For such was the experience that, that which was mundane became spiritual and that which was spiritual became mundane.

Shemos 20:21, an altar of earth which Rashi writes attached to the ground, that they should not build it on pillars or on a base. Another explanation: that would fill the hollow of the copper altar with earth when they encamped. The copper altar, the outer altar, was filled with earth. Copper and earth, two humble materials. After such a high of Matan Torah, HaShem instructs the people not to build something fancy, but a simple altar of earth. In other words, when we get too spiritual, we must remember to be attached to the ground HaShem created this world for a purpose, and for us to work within this world. Here, attached to the ground, we are to perform our services to HaShem. And when we do our services, whatever form it takes, although our hearts and minds are directed towards HaShem (whom is everywhere and in the Heavens), our feet are still attached to the earth.

May He who said to our fore-fathers and fore-mothers, I am the Eternal who took you out of Egypt (Shemos 20:2), say onto us, I am the Eternal who took you out with the Mashiach Ha-Melekh and Moses Rabbenu, so we may once more build Him an altar of earth and a dwelling place among us. HaShem, Himself, will guide the world in peace and justice. May it be soonest. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Beshalach
entry.content:
''
Jan 23, 2013 / 5773 Shevat 12 / ''

Parsha Beshalach /
Shemos 13:17 17:16
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha is Parsha Beshalach, a direct continuation of last week's Parsha, and the details of the actual exodus of the Jews from Egypt, the Splitting of the Sea of Reeds, the Song () at the Sea of Reeds, the giving of manna, and the war with Amalek.

Shemos 13:18, Rashi tells us means armed. Which Rashi points out that as the Jews were heading into the desert, the People had to have everything they would need as they would not be able to gather anything within the desert (save by miracles). Rashi also states, Another explanation: One out of five () [of the Children of Israel] left [Egypt], but [the other] four-fifth died in the three days of the darkness. (Mechilta). Those that died in during the Plague of Darkness were Jews that for various reasons refused to leave Egypt, and so HaShem dealt with them where the Egyptians could not see.

For those Jews that refused to leave Egypt, they were eternally lost in the darkness, literally and figuratively. Which, sadly, was a vast majority of the Jews of those times. Even sadder, how many of us have learned from them? How many of our fellow Jews have been lost in the Darkness? How many have assimilated among the Goyim? How many refuse to have anything positive to do with the Land of Israel, even if we are still in Galus ()?

A Chasidic story is told of a gathering that took place in secret, in a basement, and a fellow wished to join them. He walked down the stairs. Someone from the group warned him not to make any light as not to betray the group to outsiders. The fellow asked what was he to do? Someone replied that he need only to wait a little so his eyes would adjust to the darkness. The one leading the gathering remarked to the effect, this is what Galus () is, we have grow too accustom to the dark that we think it's light.

There are many movements that call themselves enlighten and progressive but their goals are self-centered and self-serving. These movements talk about tolerance and compromise, giving without anything taking, old is out-of-touch, modern is best, and other such catch-phrases. There is euphemism for euphemisms. A group, usually a bit of a minority, dictating to others they are right, simply because it's fashionable or human-based morality based upon human-made thinking is the way to live. History has seen many such groups, with very levels of successful, and yet, they will be left in the Darkness as well, while those of us, that belief in HaShem, we will walk in His Light.

Shemos 13:19, and you shall [then] have my bones taken up with here with yours. Rashi explains, It was his brothers whom [Yosef] made swear this [oath]. [This] teaches us that [Children of Israel] brought up the bones of all [the other] Tribes as well, since [the verse] says: with yours. Thus, the Tribes, themselves, went with their descendents out of Egypt and back to the Land of Israel. The Children of Israel did not forget their ancestors. We are told in the same verse that it was Moses that took Yosef's bones, and only through Rashi (and the Oral Tradition) that the other brothers' bones were also taken. In other words, it was a given that the other brothers' bones would be taken with their children, but Yosef needed assistance from Moses to be taken as well. The Midrash tells us that the Egyptians knew of the oath that Yosef had his brothers swear, so they buried his coffin within the Nile, and Moses had to perform a miracle to get the lead-lined coffin to float out of the water. While Moses was busy with the bones of Yosef, the Children of Israel were fulfilling HaShem's commandant for them to ask their Egyptian neighbor for precious jewels, metals, and clothes. As former slaves, the Children of Israel had no desire to remain in Egypt any longer than necessary, so it had to be a Divine commandant for them, let they just hurry and left.

Shemos 13:12, And the Eternal went ahead of them by day with a pillar of cloud, to have them guided on the way, and at night with a pillar of fire to give them light [...] HaShem, Himself, the four-letter name denoting Mercy and Transcendence, guided the Jews out of Egypt. Not Moses, not an angel, but HaShem, Himself, guided them on their way. And this is still true today. It is HaShem, Himself, that guides each of us to where we need to go on the journey of our lives. Each of us, leaves our own Egypt travels in freedom to the Promised Land. There is no pillar of cloud or fire, anymore, but the ours Sages of old and today, whom are liken to a cloud, and Torah, which is liken to fire, that leads us even now. These are our pillars of today through which HaShem still guides us today, even if we are lead into a seemingly desert, that is where we are meant to go by Divine Providence.

Shemos 14:2 directly opposite ba'al tzefon Rashi comments, This [was the only one] remained of all the gods of Egypt, in order to mislead [the Egyptians into] saying [that this] idol of theirs is difficult [to overcome]; and it was about this that Iyov (Job) stated: He caused nations to err and [then] destroyed them (Iyov 12:23)(Mechilta). For such is the non-believer in HaShem, the smallest, irrational, illogical twig they cling to, despite all that happened before, during and after the Ten Plagues.

Shemos 14:7 and all the Egyptian chariots, which Rashi asks, And from where were all these [chariot horses]? If you say [they were] from Egypt, [this cannot be] for it says, and all the Egyptian's livestock died (9:6); and if you say [these were] from the Israelites, does it not say: And our [own] livestock will also go with us (10:26). [So] from who were they? From [those Egyptians] who feared the Eternal's decree [and saved their animals by bringing them into the house]. [Deriving it] from here, Rabbi Shim'on would say: The finest Egyptian kill [him]! The best among snakes crush its brain! (Mechilta). For the record, Rabbi Shim'on was speaking of times of war, for many Egyptians left Egypt with the Jews among the mixed multitudes. For these Egyptians had been G-d-fearing and took Moses's warning to heart, thus protecting their animals, and yet, when Pharaoh needed horses to challenge HaShem, they gave up their horses, siding against HaShem and His prophet.

Of the miracle of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, which says, Shemos 14:21, and the waters split Rashi states, all the waters in the world. Not just that HaShem split the Sea of Reeds, but every source of water was split as well. This then publicized the miracle that HaShem did for us.

Shemos 15:1 Then Moses will sing to which Rashi after explaining the literal meaning, adds, But [with regards] to its Midrashic explanation, our Rabbis of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 91b): From here there is an allusion in the Torah [that there will be] the resurrection of the dead[...] Meaning, our Sages are saying that after the resurrection of dead (in Mashiach's time), Moses and his generation will was again sing this song. This song is that the Torah records is one of ten songs that the Jews will sing. The tenth will be sung with Mashiach. All of these songs are deeply prophetic filled with many layers of meaning.

The song's meaning is discussed in many places, so I will just skim over it.

Shemos 15:2, This is my G-d [HaShem Himself] appeared to them in His [Divine] Glory, and they were pointing to Him with [their] finger [and saying, This is my G-d] (Shemos Rabbah 23:15). [Thus even] a maidservant at the sea saw [a level of Divine Glory] which [even] prophets did not [merit to] see (Mechilta, sec. 3) Meaning the most uneducated and most basic of a person could see and understand HaShem at that moment. For such was the relationship between the Jews of the Exodus and HaShem that they merited something none of the prophets could achieve. The prophets speak of HaShem in metaphors and subtract concepts, but the Jews at the Splitting of Sea of Reeds, needed not any subtract concepts or metaphors, they saw with their own eyes what, who, how, HaShem is HaShem. The Prophet Moses spoke of HaShem with the verb this is, while other prophets spoke of Him with like this. How wondrous and awesome was the revelation so that even the simplest could say, This is my G-d! Oh, how I wish we could merit such! And we will when Mashiach comes, for then we will again be able to point and say, This is my G-d and there will be no confusion or misunderstanding.

Shemos 15:9, The enemy said, I shall pursue [them], catch [them and] divide the spoil. My desire will be satiated with them. I shall draw my sword; my hand will impoverish them. Throughout the ages, the various enemies of HaShem have said this, they, and they alone, will do what no other has done, through a mere single sword shall destroy an entire nation. Our enemies think only of themselves , in the terms of I, and not of others. They say, I will do as I please, merely because I have a sword.

And HaShem's reply to the enemy is, Shemos 15:10, You [HaShem] blew with Your wind, the sea covered them; they sank like lead in the mighty waters. The enemy needs to use a sword, military might but HaShem needs only the wind (air/unseen) and their downfall is assured. The greatest of human (physical) strength is nothing compared to HaShem's simplest and smallest of air. Man's might which is visible in the form of a sword, is nothing compared to HaShem's might, which can't be seen but felt.

Shemos 15:20, Then Miryam the prophetess, Aharon's sister, took the tambourine in her hand, and all the women followed her with tambourines and dances. Which Rashi points out, Miryam was a prophetess before the birth of Moses, when she was only sister of Aharon, for she prophetized that At some time in the future my mother will give birth to a son [who will save Israel]. Rashi also points out with tambourines and dances means that the righteous women in that generation were sure that the Holy One, Source of Blessing, would do miracles for them, [so] they took out tambourines [with them] from Egypt. Thus, all the women, the Tribe of Levi, the old, and the children, where the ones that actually entered the Land of Israel, and not a part of those that were decreed to not enter the land because of the sin of the Spies.

Shemos 16:6 in speaking of the manna that fell upon Friday, the Torah says, there will be double portions of manna, for the sixth day and for Shabbos. From here, we have the tradition of having two loaves of bread/Challah for our Shabbat meal. To remind us of how HaShem gave us double portions on sixth day for both the sixth day, itself, and for Shabbos.

Why was it called Manna? For the Jews asked Ma (what is it?) For it was the bread of heaven, which was not seen before and since.

Shemos 16:21, and [when] the sun shone hot it would melt Which Rashi points out, that which was left in the field, and it turned into rivulets. Gazelles and deer would then drink from them, and non-Jews would trap [and kill these animals] and savor in them the taste of manna and [thus] become aware of the praiseworthy status of Israel. Thus, the non-Jew would receive an indirect benefit that was left over from the Jewish direct reward, so they would know what rewards that the Jews received, in hope that they would join us.

Moses preserved a omer's worth of manna, so that other generations could see it and know that HaShem can support an entire generation however He wishes if they but fulfill His will, even with the bread of heaven, if not the bread of earth.

After the question of water in the desert, the Torah says that the Children of Israel tested HaShem by saying Shemos 16:7, Is the Eternal['s Presence] among us or not? To which, HaShem response as Rashi points out is Amalek then came In all the miracles that they say in and out of Egypt, and they ask that? So Amalek came and showed that HaShem was indeed among us. For not by mighty do we survive, but through HaShem and His mercies do we live.

For Amalek, our Sages tell us, dare to strike at Israel and HaShem, when all the other nations were in fear for all the miracles and all that HaShem had done for Israel. By attacking HaShem, Amalek made it easier for others to attack. The Sages relate this to a story: there was once a very hot tub of water, too hot for anyone to enter, but one brave soul entered, and then other, and another, each took some injuries, but in doing so cooled the tub down for others to enter more easily. For this, HaShem swore that Amalek would be destroyed completely. Our Sages say that Amalek, as an actual people, is not known, but the concept of cooler to the passion of Judaism still exist and we must eternally be on guard for them. We can not fight these Amalek on their terms, but rather, on own terms, through Torah and prayer.

May the ultimate prayer, the coming of Mashiach, be fulfilled in our day, if not this very moment. So we may sing with Moses Rabbenu the Song at the Sea of Reeds and, we too, can say, This is my G-d! Praise to Him, the Source of Life and Peace. So that He that brings peace to the Heavens, may bring peace to the Earth and Israel. And let us say, Amen!

entry.title: Parsha Bo
entry.content:
''
Jan 16, 2013 / 5773 Shevat 5 / ''

Parsha Bo /
Shemos 10:1 13:16
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha is Parsha Bo (), which means either to come or to enter. The name of the Parsha captures the essence of the entire Parsha. The Parsha can be summed up: the final three plagues, the establishment of the Jewish Calendar, the very first offering of the Pesach offering, the actual departure of the Jews from Egypt, and the sanctification of the first-born of both animal and man. So why is the Parsha named to come? The context of the name/word is Shemos 10:1, The Eternal then said to Moses, Go to Pharaoh, for I have made him and his servants stubborn, so that I may display these signs of Mine among [them]; Who was Pharaoh, he was the leader of the then most powerful nation in the known world. Pharaoh, who on his own, withstood the first five Plagues and thought himself a god. And HaShem commanded Moses to go to him for the reason that Rashi makes, and warn him [about the forthcoming plague].

Moses was commanded to go to Pharaoh to warn him about the last three Plagues. In establishing a new Lunar/Seasonal calendar, the Children of Israel entered into a new spiritual/temporal structure/understanding of the universe. When the Children of Israel sacrificed the gods of the Egyptians, the Pesach offering, they entered into a new relationship with HaShem, leaving behind the old way of thinking about religion. When the Children of Israel left Egypt, they were entering into a convent with HaShem and were about to enter into the Land of Israel to make it holy. By sanctifying the first-born, HaShem entered into a covenant that the first-born was His.

Why was the ninth Plague, the Plague of Darkness? Each Plague was worse than the preceding one. So how was the Plague of Darkness, worse than all the other plagues before it? It is known that the Egyptians worshiped the Sun, and this idol was their chief idol. This Plague was more than the mere absence of light, but a darkness that could be felt, physically, and for the Egyptians, spiritual, showcasing that their idolatry of the Sun was worthless. In contrast, the Jews were not affected by the darkness (of idolatry) for they had the Light of HaShem

The Torah writes, Shemos 11:5, to the firstborn of the prisoner to which Rashi comments, Why were the prisoners smitten [since they had not enslaved Israel]? In order that they should not say that their deity claimed [retribution for] their humiliation and brought punishment upon the Egyptians (Mechilta, sec. 13). The Torah write includes, and all the firstborn animals, Rashi points out, [They were also smitten] because [the Egyptians] were worshiping them, and when the Holy One, Source of Blessing, punishes a nation, He punishes its gods [at the same time]. From the highest human to the lowest of animal, none are exempted from the Judgment of HaShem. For we know that Justice and Trust are the stamp of HaShem, it follows that those prisoners of Egypt where there at that time, for them to be part of this, were there because HaShem orchestrated it. Of what crimes, the Heavenly Tribunal judged them guilt of, I don't know, we only know that they were guilty of capital crimes.

The Torah records that Moses and Aharon were instructed in the Jewish calendar by HaShem, before the Tenth Plague, while still in Egypt. Rashi explains the literal meaning of in the land of Egypt, I will add that as stated before, the Egyptians were very big sun-worshipers, so their entire calendar (and many others) revolved solely upon the Sun. Not so the Jewish calendar, the months are calculated by the phases of the Moon, with corrects to ensure that the festival of Pesach is always in the season of spring. As far as I know, the Jewish calendar was the first calendar that was dependent upon the Moon, and not the Sun, although the Sun/Seasons play a minor part within it. Thus, for the ancient Hebrews, it would have been a significant culture shift for them. In making the Jewish calendar, HaShem constructed it so that everything had it's place within the calendar and the calendar had a place in everything. Thus, the Jewish People have a place within everything and everything had a place within the Jewish People as well. Paraphrasing our Sages, There is no chance or random factor in the Universe, everything is Divine Providence, safe the fear of HaShem, Himself. We are, where we are, because HaShem wishes for us to be where we are. There is something only we can do where we are, and HaShem willing, we will be able to do what is needed.

The first Pesach offering, the second commandant to the new nation of Israel, the Torah states, Shemos 12:3, A lamb per ancestral house, which Rashi points out means, [i.e.] for one family. Now, I might think that even if [the family] were many, [they would still only require] one lamb for all of them. [The Torah therefore] teaches [us] by saying: a lamb per household

Meaning the very first Divine-given commandant was to the entire nation, as a hold, the second was given to the household/family. The Pesach offering, be it from Moses or from a water-carrier, all was based upon their household, not the individual. By doing so, I think, HaShem was teaching the young nation the importance of nation-hood and family-hood. Yes, we are all individuals, each unique, but still a part of our households/ancestral houses, which each Tribe had it's own ways, but even further, we are all a part of one nation, under one G-d. There are three: the individual, the family, and the nation, each has its part.

Shemos 12:12 Every firstborn in the Land of Egypt which Rashi remarks on saying, even the firstborn of other [nations] who were [then] in Egypt. And from where [do we know that] also the firstborns of the Egyptians who were in other places [were smitten]? [Scripture] teaches [us this] by saying, To the One Who smote the Egyptians through their firstborns (Tehillim 136:10)(Mechilta) The Midrash tells us that not only was obvious first-born was smitten, but the first-born of any union between man and woman, for Egyptians did not honor their marriage vows, were smitten too, for it says, every firstborn

Shemos 12:12, I will carry out acts of Judgment... I, the Eternal, Rashi comments that this means, [i.e.] I, Myself, and not through a messenger (see Pesikta Zuterasa). HaShem uses His four-letter name, denoting the aspect of Divine Mercy and Transcendence, as the One that carries out the Judgment against the Egyptians. One would think that the aspect of Divine Judgment, Elokim, should have been used. But HaShem is not human, even in Judgment He is Merciful and Just. This final plague was not the act of revenge or war, but the act of Divine Mercy and transcending the limitations of nature. Those that were smitten by HaShem, where obvious smitten by HaShem and not by other means. The Tenth Plague, the Killing of the First-born, was HaShem truly acting in Mercy, Justice, and Trust, upon the Egyptians and their idols. To commemorate this event, HaShem instituted the Festival of Pesach, where we recall the Egyptian exile and our redemption.

Shemos 12:30, for there was no house where there was not a dead person, which Rashi informs us, If there was a first-born there, he died. If there was no first-born there, the most senior person in the house [died, for he] is [also] called firstborn (), as it says: I, too, [for My part,] will make him a great person () (Tehillim 89:28) (Pesikta Rabbasi, app. 1, ch. 2). Another explanation: the Egyptian women were unfaithful to their husbands and they bore children from [other] unmarried men, and [thus] they had many firstborns sometimes [even] five for one women each one being a firstborn to his father (Mechilta, sec.13, v33).

Shemos 12:38, A mixed multitude, which Rashi comments, [i.e.] a mixture of [people from different] nations [who had become] proselytes. Thus, the Jews left not only with all their kin, but those that feared HaShem or wished to join the winning side left with them. Our Sages tell us that this was done by Moses on his own, and not by Divine command.

Shemos 12:41, It was at the end of [four hundred and] thirty years, on that every day Rashi enlightens us with, [This] tells [us] that once the [predetermined] end [of the exile] had arrived, the Omnipresent did not detain them for [even as much as] a blinking of an eye; on the fifteenth of Nisan the ministering angels came to Abraham to inform him [that Sarah would bear him a son], on the fifteenth of Nisan Yitzchak was born, and on the fifteenth of Nisan the decree Between the Parts was pronounced. Thus, it is said, when it's time to go, go.

Shemos 12:49, [There will be] one law, Rashi comments, [This verse is added] to equate a proselyte with a native[-Jew] regarding [all] the other mitzvosin the Torah as well. Which the sayings. all are equal under the law originated from.

Shemos 13:3-15 is the source of Pesach Haggadah's four sons and the commandant that we are to retell the redemption from Egypt.

May our retelling of that redemption be a merit to our final redemption that will come with the coming of the Mashiach. As it was in those days, with signs, wonders, and HaShem, Himself, acting on our behalf, so too it will be with our redemption, may it speedily come soonest. And in the blink of an eye, we will be redeemed and once more offer the Pesach offering in Jerusalem, in the Holy Temple, as our ancestors did. We will offer the thanksgiving offerings and rejoice with HaShem.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eira
entry.content:
''
Jan 10, 2013 / 5773 Teves 28 / ''

Parsha Va'eira /
Shemos 6:2 9:35
Translation Source: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

The name of this Parsha is Va'eira (), which means And I appeared. This is the Parsha of the first seven of the Ten Plagues, and the beginning of the redemption of the Jews in Egypt. This is where HaShem fully displays Himself, as not only as Judge, who sits outside as with Noach's flood, but as Judge, who sits among us. There were those among those that created the Tower of Babel because they thought Noach's flood was natural, just as today there are those that think the weather is caused by a butterfly rather than HaShem. The one that did know of HaShem's involvement was Noach, but the others did not survive. While Egypt was beaten, it stood testimony to what HaShem had done for the Jews, as Yisro and other Goyim heard. Yes, visible miracles occurred throughout the Ten Plagues, but Egypt was not wiped off the map.

HaShem could have simply killed every Egyptians in an instant, regardless of where they were, or even something similar Divine. Rather, HaShem in His mercy dealt with them in His manner of Measure for measure ( ).

To paraphrase the Psalmist, HaShem does/say one thing, we perceive (at least) two. For what HaShem does is not the work of Man, but eternal, for it affects the past, present and future. I say that HaShem never does anything for a single reason, but rather, HaShem does as He does, to instruct the current situation (usually correctly Humanity as a Father does his child), specifically, and to instruct future generations, in generalizations.

The Egyptians of those days, did not see themselves as evil. Nor does the Torah call them evil, but they are sinners. Those Egyptians were doing what they thought they could, for they were the super power of the then-world. There was no nation stronger militaristically, economically, or politically than the Egypt before the Exodus. It was they that set the standard of society. By the Light of Torah, it was immoral and unjust, but the Egyptians justified themselves as any sinner will do.

Thus, the Ten Plagues were a punishment and a lesson to the Egyptians, in general, and an answer to Pharaoh's question, Who is HaShem? From each Plague, we find out how the Egyptians embittered and enslaved the Jews. But I leave that exercise up to the reader.

Shemos 6:23, [...] Nachshon's sister [...], which the Torah did not have to say, therefore, Rashi comments on this, From here we learn [that] he who marries a woman should [first] inquire into [the character of] her brothers. (Bava Basra 110a). Why her brothers and not her sisters? And why plural? I have not seen any comments on this, but my thinking is thus: in the equation of life there is the male and female elements plus HaShem. The purpose of a marriage is to have and raise children. Sons tend to reflect their mothers while daughters reflect their fathers, a reflection (opposite but equal), like a mirror or a magnet. Each person is born with certain potential that comes from their parents. This potential is like potter's clay, one's own soul, which comes from HaShem, and one's own experiences throughout one's life, shapes this clay into something. This something is unique to each person and the final work only HaShem knows. When a man looks for a wife, he should know himself, but as a man, he cannot understand his wife fully, but he can understand her brothers, being male. Her brothers and herself have the same clay foundation, but the brothers are a bit more understandable. And it is plural, because one does not set a case. The Torah states that Ya'akov Avenu and Esau were identical twins, the same clay foundation, and yet, the Torah also says that Ya'akov Avenu was a Torah student, while Esau was a murderer, their mother's brother was Lavan. It is said by our Sages that when Shmuel the Prophet ( ) saw King David ( ) for the first time, he noted to HaShem that he seemed to be very similar to Esau, for they both had similar characteristics/foundation, but whereas Esau sought to distance himself from HaShem, King David embraced HaShem (making the difference).

Artscroll edition (and others) translates Shemos 7:3 as , I shall harden Pharaoh's heart [...], which is the literal translation of the text. The Margolin edition translates it as, And I will strengthen Pharaoh's resolve [...] The literal translation has always left me a bit puzzled harden a heart, what does that mean? Strengthening a resolve sounds good, but how does it relate to one's heart? What is the heart? We know that it is a muscle that pumps blood throughout the blood, but we romanticize that the heart is the seat of emotions. We say, I heart something, meaning I love something. Love is very connected with the heart, but so too are other emotions. We say someone that's unfeeling is cold-hearted, or someone that's not moved by emotions has a heart of stone. Thus, HaShem was telling Moses that He did not wish for Pharaoh to be affected by his emotions, but react based on his intellect. As Rashi points out, the first five of the Ten Plagues, the Torah tells us that Pharaoh was the one that harden/strengthen his heart/resolve, and only HaShem did it afterward.

Shemos 7:12, But Aharon's staff swallowed up, to which Rashi clarifies, after it had turned back into a staff it swallowed up all of them (Shabbos 97a; Shemos Rabbah 9:7). In other words, Aharon's staff did nothing while it was alive, but when it was dead wood (again) it then able to consume (a biological function) the other staffs. There is a difference of opinion among the Sages as to where the Egyptian sorcerers were able to transfigure an inanimate object into an animate one, or it was just illusion. But, all Sages agree that HaShem turned a wooden staff into an actual serpent (I've read it was turned into a crocodile, which was an idol of Egypt). Which was a greater miracle, making something dead into something living or something dead without a mouth swallowing? Recall that the staff is and was a symbol of power/nobility. HaShem turned that into something that was cursed (the Serpent from the Garden of Eden), and back again. And took what should have been strength as a staff that could not in the physical/material world do something and swallow. This was a hint or what was to come, but Pharaoh did not listen.

The first Plague was the Plague of Blood, just to talk a little about it, this affected the Nile the most, which was an idol of the Egyptians, as rain does not fall upon Egypt, so the Nile brings the water for farming. The Egyptians were shown that their idol, the Nile, was powerless against HaShem, it was turned from a source of blessing into something else at the Word of HaShem.

Interesting enough, during the telling of this plague Shemos 7:19, Rashi points out that HaShem told Moses to say to Aharon, as since the River [Nile] protected Moses when he was cast into it, therefore it was not smitten through him, not in [the plague of] blood nor in [the plague of] frogs, but it was smitten through Aharon (Shemos 9:10). If an inanimate object is deserving of such kindness, how much more so a human being, created in the image of HaShem.

From water of the first plague, to frogs, amphibians, of the second plague, whom are born in the water and then mature, living on the land. Both the first and second plagues where more annoyances than lethal, for HaShem was build up to the grand finale, but as showing His mastery of water and land.

The third plague was the plague of lice; an animal so small, the magic of the Egyptians could not duplicate it as they did the first two plague, thus they were forced to say, Shemos 8:15, this is the finger of Elokim. Even in their defect, the Egyptian magicians downplayed it, saying it's but a finger, not something more.

The four plague was the plague of wild beasts, from the small animals to the large animals. Even the king of the jungles bows to HaShem, the King of Earth and Heaven. And this plague states directly that there was a separation between the Jews and Egyptians, which had happened, but HaShem made it known that He was the Cause.

The fifth plague was the plague of pestilence. From the water, to the land, to annoyance, to fear, and now, an attack upon the livestock. HaShem started small and ups the ante with each plague.

The sixth plague was the plague of boils, from affecting the livestock, to affecting humans.

The seventh plague was plague of hail. This hail was unlike any other hail, for HaShem caused the center of the frozen hail to be fire, to natural apposing forces, working together at HaShem command. As Rashi says, Shemos 9:24, [There occurred here] a miracle within a miracle: the fire and the hail were mixed together, [even though] hail is [made out of] water. [However,] in order to carry out the will of their Creator they made peace with one another (Shemos Rabbah 12:4). To unthinking, unfeeling objects, worked together, for the sake of HaShem, how much more so should we?

For the first six plagues, they were in the realm of nature, if magnified, but something we can visualize. The seventh plague, the hail, we can only guess at. We cannot mix hail/water and fire, for we believe that they will fight and make stream or cancel each other out. And yet, hail and fire, however, they were put together, is still something we know of. Although, never having rained in Egypt before, they must have felt as if the very heavens were falling.

HaShem could have easily done to the people as He did to the water, land, livestock, and food stuff. But He desired His people and to show His mercy and judgment upon Egypt and upon the Jews.

For HaShem is our inheritance, just as HaShem went through a lot of effort to free the Jews in the Egyptian exile, so too, our Sages tells us, He will do so again, to free us from our current exile.

May the day come soonest, when we can study Sefer Shemos with those that where there first-hand, and Moses Rabbenu can teach the Torah once more.

entry.title: Parsha Shemos
entry.content:
''
Jan 3, 2013 / 5773 Teves 21 / ''

Parsha Shemos /
Shemos 1:1 6:1
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha is Parsha Shemos, which is the very first Parsha of the Sefer Shemos. The Hebrew word Shemos () is translated as names. Which is interesting, because the Parsha itself deals with the set-up of the enslavement of the Jewish people that lasted for approximately two hundred years and the first step of the Jewish people's redemption, their exodus from Egypt, which cultivated in the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, and the building of the Mishkan ().

So what is the connection between what happens in this Parsha and the entire Sefer, with the Hebrew word Shemos?

Interesting, our Sages say that in the merit of three things, the Children of Israel, themselves, were worthy to be taken out of Egypt through HaShem's direct invention. Those three merits were: they kept their language, Hebrew; they kept their manner of dress, which was modest; and they kept their Hebrew names. Which set them a part from the Egyptians.

So of the three, why is name the highlighted merit of the three, that the entire Sefer is named after it?

For names are powerful.

Names are identifiers and connections to our Past. How is this a connection to our past? Ashkenazim have the tradition of naming their children after past loved ones. I, myself, am named for my father's father, as my father is named for his father's father, and his father was named for his father's father, or some other loved one that passed on. It is not that we are recycling the name for the lack of imagination, but honoring those that came before us. When my name is called, I do think upon my father's father for whom I am named, and I am sure others that know do to.

It is said by our Sages that when the parents name their children, a touch of Prophecy is involved. For a name is not only an identifier, but a description. Names, especially Biblical names, have meaning about the person they are identifying. One's name is not some completely random chance. The names of HaShem have meaning as well, after all HaShem is Infinite, and we are but limited beings, so we can only understand HaShem through His various aspects, such as HaShem the (substitution for the four-letter name Y-H-V-H) representing the aspect of mercy and transcendence and while Elokim represents the aspect of judgment and nature. Thus, we have a handle to understand HaShem in His Infinity with our finite understanding.

Our Parsha begins with Shemos 1:1, And these are the names of the Israel's sons [...]. Why does our Parsha start with the word and? For this is a continuation of the previous Parsha and Sefer. Bereishet tells us how Humanity started and the infancy of the Jewish People. Shemos continues that and shows us the true formation of the Jewish People, from just a group of brothers from the same man, into a holy nation. And the sons of Israel are the foundation stones upon which the holy nation of Israel is founded upon.

Shemos 1:8, There then arose a new king over Egypt who did not know Yosef. According to Rashi, the Sages Rav and Shemuel differ on whether this verse is literal or figurative. If it was literal, this meant that some foreign ruler with no know of the local history/culture came to power, or, as is all too common, for whatever reason, decided to ignore all the contributions that Yosef (and Jews in general) have made to the welfare of the nation, in the past and currently.

Shemos 1:10, Let us deal cleverly (lit.) with him ( ), to which Rashi explains, with the nation. Let us consider wisely what to do with it. But our Rabbis explained [the word to him as referring to HaShem, and the verse means:] Let us outwit the Savior of Israel, by sentencing them [to death] by water, for He already sworn that He will never bring [another] flood upon the world. (Sotah 11a). For every anti-semite deep within knows what they are doing is wrong in the eye of HaShem, and yet, tries to find justification for their actions. They either did not know or care that HaShem's promise not to bring another flood was a flood against the entire world as in the days of Noach, or they thought themselves to be the entire world, thus they thought themselves protected and justified in their actions.

Shemos 2:1, A man from the House of Levi went and married the daughter of Levi. Our commentators point out that the daughter of Levi is to be taken literal, meaning this is Yocheved, who was born to Levi. So we know the name of Moses's mother was Yocheved.

Shemos 2:5, her maid, to which Rashi writes, Our Rabbis [however,] explained [it] as meaning hand (Sotah 12b), though according to the grammar of the Holy Language is should [then] have been punctuated with a dagesh. [Nevertheless] they explained [as meaning] her hand [to indicate that] her hand increased in length many cubits [in order for her to reach the box]. Thus, the daughter of Pharaoh, saved Moses. Our Sages say that the reason why the daughter of Pharaoh went down to the river was to immerse herself in order to convert to Judaism. Thus, because she converted, she was honored with saving Moses from her father's decree to kill all the male children.

Shemos 2:9, Pharaoh's daughter said to her, Take this child [...], Rashi comments on the word take and says, She was prophesying, but did not realized what she was prophesying, [for in effect she was saying:] here is what is yours. If the daughter of Pharaoh did not know she what she was prophesying, why did HaShem have her prophetize at all? Rashi says that she did not realize what she was prophesying, not that she was prophesying at all. So Pharaoh's daughter knew something was going on, but not the details. And it was her that allowed Moses to live despite her father's decree. In fact, it is Pharaoh's daughter's naming of Moses, by which we know him. Our Sages say that Moses had ten names, among which was what Amram and Yocheved named him, and yet, HaShem, Himself, calls him only Moses, as Pharaoh's daughter says, Shemos 2:10, [] for I drew him out of the water.

Shemos 2:11, And he saw their suffering to which, Rashi says, [i.e.] he set his eyes and heart on being distressed about [their plight] (Shemos Rabbah 1:27). Even though he grew up in Pharaoh's palace and was in charge of Pharaoh's household (much like Yosef), Moses still saw the Jews as his brethren and was distressed over their suffering.

Shemos 2:12, He turned this way and that and saw there was no man, so he struck the Egyptian [dead] and hid him in the sand. Rashi comments on the phrase saw there was no man, and says, destined to be born from [this Egyptian] who would convert o Judaism (Shemos Rabbah 1:29). Which seems a strange thing to say, especially for Rashi who only deals with the literal translation of the verse. For the Torah uses the least amount of words and could have just said, something like Moses saw no one around and struck, so that the Torah adds words, Rashi realized that there had to be more going on than a physical survey of his surroundings. In fact, the Mishnah says that Moses did not physically struck the Egyptian but pronounced HaShem's holy name, which caused the immoral Egyptian to die.

Shemos 2:15, [...] and he [Pharaoh] sought to kill Moses [...], Rashi comments, He handed him over to the executioner to kill him, but the sword proved powerless against him. It was to this that Moses [was referring when he] said: and He saved me from Pharaoh's sword. (Shemos 18:4) I think this is the source of the saying by our Sages of even if the sword is upon your neck, salvation can come to you.

Shemos 2:16, Now, the lord of Midyan, Rashi writes, [i.e.] the chief among them; but he had abandoned idol-worship so they ostracized him. The text of the verse uses the word Cohen () which usually means priest, but here, as Rashi points out, it means chief/lord/noble. I am unsure if it was because in the ancient world, the priests were among the ruling class, or some other reason. I am sure there is something to Cohen () being translated as either priest or noble, but I don't know currently.

Shemos 2:20, [...] let him eat bread [...] to which Rashi writes, [This is an euphemism meaning:] maybe he will marry one of you. [It is similar meaning to] that which it says [about Potifar]: except the bread would eat (Bereishet 39:6) (Shemos Rabbah 1:32) Our Sages say that bread is an euphemism for wife. I believe this is so, for just as bread (food) sustains a man physical/nutritiously, so too does his wife sustain him spiritually/support.

Shemos 2:23, [...] that the king of Egypt died [...] Rashi enlightens us and tells us, He [did not actually die, but] was stricken with tzara'as, and he would [therefore] slaughter Jewish babies and bathe in their blood [as a cure] (Shemos Rabbah 1:34). The Egyptians, when they enslaved the Jews, did not just try to crush them with hard labor, but they sought to crush their very Judaism out of them. The Egyptians demonized and terrorized their Jewish slaves at every opportunity.

Shemos 3:2 [...] from within [a certain thorn] bush [...] Rashi comments, but not [from] another [type of] tree, to convey [the idea]: I am with him in [his] distress (Tehillim 91:15)(Shemos Rabbah 2:5). Rashi here is emphasizing the fact that as HaShem had promised Ya'akov in the previous Parsha, HaShem is with us in our exile. We are not alone in exile, we have not been abandoned, nor have we been cased off, rather we, the Jews and HaShem, Himself, are in exile together (in so far, that HaShem is everywhere,every-when,etc.).

Shemos 3:5, [...] Remove your shoes from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground. I have read, but do not recall where, the verse could have just said, remove your shoes, by adding feet, it emphasizes a connection between feet/ground and holiness. All too often, there is something (the Evil Inclination) separating us from holiness, but if we but remove something as simple as our shoes we can full connect to that holiness. Why was this ground holy? Because HaShem's meeting of Moses took place on Mount Sinai.

Shemos 3:6, He then said, I am the G-d (Elokim) of your father, the G-d (Elokim) of Abraham, the G-d of Yitzchak and the G-d of Ya'akov. [...] Our Sages tell us that by HaShem saying of your father, Moses knew that his father, Amram, had passed away, for HaShem does not link his name with the living, for the living's character is not fully known until after their passing. Also by invoking the three Fore-fathers, HaShem is telling Moses that his mission will succeed in the Fore-fathers' merits, if not in their children's own merits.

Shemos 3:12, [HaShem] replied, For I will be with you[...] Rashi explains, He answered his first [question] first, and his second, second. About that which you asked, Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh? [I answer:] This is not your [individual task] but it is [also] Mine, for I will be with you. For Moses was but an instrument for HaShem to carry out His plan. HaShem would be doing the heavy lifting, Moses was along for the ride so to say.

Shemos 3:13, [...] What is His name? [...], meaning what aspect/concept will HaShem express to the people. For up until this point, HaShem had worked within the boundaries of nature, and Moses was wondering how that would work in this situation.

Shemos 3:15, [...] This is My name forever [...] Rashi writes, [The word is written] without a [between the and ], implying: Conceal it that [My name] should not be pronounced as it is written. Thus we don't say Y-H-V-H, we say HaShem, in general or during Communinal Torah Reading (or Holy Tasks), it's pronounced as if it was (my master/lord). So those that think they know how to pronounced HaShem's name, do not.

Shemos 3:18, [...] They will listen to you [...], Rashi explains why, Since you will say to them this expression, they will listen to you; for this sign has already been handed down to them from Ya'akov and Yosef: that with [the mention of] this expression they will [subsequently] be redeemed. Ya'akov said to them, but G-d will surely remember you (Bereishet 50:24), [and] Yosef said to them, G-d will surely remember you (Bereishet 50:25). (Shemos Rabbah 3:8). For their was an oral tradition passed down of the prophecy giving to Abraham, and the reminders from Ya'akov and Yosef.

Shemos 4, HaShem turns Moses's staff into a snake. Why? Because a staff is a symbol of power and support (figuratively and actual), but a snake is not a support, but something that can attack and kill you.

Shemos 4:14, [...] and he will see you and feel happy, Rashi explains that HaShem is telling Moses about Aharon, not as you suppose that he will resent you that you are rising to [a position of] greatness (Shemos Rabbah 3:17). And as a result [of this heartfelt rejoicing] Aharon merited to [wear] the breastplate ornament with which was placed upon the heart (Shabbos 139a). Moses felt that his older brother, Aharon, who has been a spiritual leader among the Jews in Egypt desired to be the redeemer and so he might resent his younger brother doing so. HaShem told him, not so, for such was not the character of Aharon.

Shemos 4:20, on the donkey to which Rashi says, the special donkey; this donkey was the donkey that Abraham saddled for [traveling to carry out] the binding of Yitzchak (Bereishet 22:3), and it is the one on which the Anointed King (Mashiach) will [ride when he is] revealed, as it says, [...] a humble man, riding on a donkey (Zecharyah 9:9) Thus, Moses, the first redeemer, is connected to Mashiach, the final redeemer.

Shemos 4:25, So Tzipporah took a sharp stone and cut off her son's foreskin[...] For Moses Rebbanu was almost killed for not circumcising his son. Shemos 4:26, [] then [...] Rashi states, she understood that [the angel] had come to kill him because of [the delay in] the circumcision. For such is the importance and severity of the mitzvah of circumcision that even Moses, on a mission from HaShem, Himself, still needed to circumcise his son without delay.

Shemos 5:1, Afterwards, Moses and Aharon went [...] Rashi points out, but the elders slipped away one by one from behind Moses and Aharon, until they had all slipped away before they reached [Pharaoh's] palace, because they were afraid to go [to Pharaoh]. And at [Mount] Sinai they received retribution [for this, for it says]: Moses alone shall then draw near to the Eternal, but [the others] must not draw near (Shemos 24:2) [i.e. G-d] made them stay back. (Shemos Rabbah 5:14). Measure for measure, when told to go with Moses on HaShem (and Israel) behalf, they chicken out, thus, they were punished in not being able to go with Moses up to Sinai. For if they could not see a mortal king, then how could they see The King of All. Our fears in the present can deny us pleasures of the future. It is our fears that can hold us back from reaching up. But with HaShem, we can go anywhere.

Shemos 5:2, Pharaoh said [to them], Who is the Eternal that I should heed His voice to let Israel go? [...] Our Sages say that because Pharaoh said this, who is, HaShem answered him, and His answer was in the form of the Ten Plagues.

Shemos 5:4, go to your labors, which Rashi explains, go to your work which you have to do in your houses, but [Pharaoh was not referring to slave labor, for] the slave labor of Egypt was not [imposed] upon the tribe of Levi [to which Moses and Aharon belonged]. Proof that this was so was that Moses and Aharon came and went [freely]. (Shemos Rabbah 5:16) For even the idol-worshiping Egyptians knew of others gods, so they allowed the Tribe of Levi to act as priests/clerics to their brethren.

Shemos 5:14, the overseers of the Children of Israel...were beaten. Rashi states, [These overseers were Jews, and they showed pity to their fellow by not pressing them; and when they were complete the bricks for the taskmasters, who were Egyptian, and the total was missing, [the taskmasters] would beat them because they did not press the workers. There these overseers merited to become [members of] the Sanhedrin, and some of the spirit [of prophecy] which was upon Moses was drawn [from him] and placed upon them, as it says, Gather for Me seventy men of the elders of Israel of those whom you recognized the good which they did in Egypt for they [were] the elders of the people and its overseers (Bemidbar 11:16) (Shemos Rabbah 5:19-20). For looking out for the welfare of the people, they were rewarded. Good for good.

Shemos 5:22-23, (22) Moses returned to the Eternal and said, O Lord! Why have You caused this people to be mistreated [and] why have You sent me? (23)For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has made things worse for this people, and You certainly have not [yet] saved Your people. For the Torah does not hide the blemish of even Moses Rabbenu, for it would seem from the text that Moses thought his mission was unsuccessful. For such was the way of the world that when invoking something religious, nobles take notice, but this time, the opposite happened, things got worse. To which Shemos 6:1, The Eternal said to Moses, Now you will see [...] Using HaShem's four-letter name denoting the aspect of Divine Mercy and Divine Transcendence, now Moses will see something unique and beyond his understanding.

Moses had been warned about Pharaoh's reluctance against setting the Jews free, and yet, the Jewish leader that Moses Rabbenu was, when the people were suffering, he felt it, especially because he was the leader. Moses wondered why things had to get worse and thus questioned HaShem, and HaShem's explanation is that HaShem was not going to have Pharaoh free the Jews, rather, HaShem was going to do things His way, as Moses reminds the Jews Devarim 4:34, Or has any god performed miracles to come and take him a nation from the midst of a[nother] nation, with trials, with signs, and with wonders, and with war and with a strong hand, and with an outstretched arm, and with great awesome deeds, as all that the Lord your G-d did for you in Egypt before your eyes? For in those days, Egypt was the super-power, leader of the world. And yet, HaShem made a mockery of them and answered Pharaoh (and the rest of the world) question (Shemos 5:2).

And in our days, the so-called super-powers (nations) think they can do whatever they wish and just as Pharaoh did. Thus, the final redemption shall be like the first, and HaShem Himself will answer, I am the Eternal and will once again with trials, with signs, and with wonders, and with war and with a strong hand, and with an outstretched arm, and with great awesome deeds redeem us as the Eternal redeemed them.

May it be soonest, amen.

entry.title: Parsha Vayechi
entry.content:
''
Dec 26, 2012 / 5773 Teves 13 / ''

Parsha Vayechi /
Bereishet 47:28 50:26
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

This week's Parsha begins with Vayechi Ya'akov ( ), Ya'akov lived, and our Sages named this portion, Vayechi () / he lived. Yet, our Parsha deals with the passing of Ya'akov Avenu ( ), his blessing of the Tribes (his children), and the passing of Yosef (and the Tribes). Not exactly, living per say, but, as with Chayei Sarah ( ), we see that true life is not within ourselves, but seeing our traditions and ways passed on to our children, to our children's children, and from generation to generation. And Ya'akov Avenu ( ) saw his sons, the Tribes, their children, and their children's children all following the ways of his fathers.

It is interesting to note that it says Vayechi Ya'akov, and not Vayechi Israel, I have not seen any comments on this. Which must meaning I have not looked deep enough or far enough. Ya'akov Avenu ( ) has two names, Ya'akov, which he was born with, and Israel, which an angel/HaShem gave him. Unlike with Abraham Avenu ( ), for when his name was changed from Avram to permanently Abraham, the Torah continues to refer to Ya'akov Avenu by both his old name and new name. Generally, we find when the Torah uses Ya'akov, it refers to mundane struggle and Israel refers to spiritual nobility. The lows and highs of the Jewish character. So this begs the question, why Ya'akov lived, not Israel lived, for where not the last seventeen years of Ya'akov Avenu's life the best of his life? We are told in the Oral Law that Ya'akov spent the last seventeen years of his life, in comfort among his children, and yet, the Torah uses Ya'akov, denoting struggle, as his name. Why? Why not, using Israel for the tranquil and spiritual that our fore-father must have felt then. I believe it is because ultimately the purpose of Creation, our Sages say, is for HaShem to dwell in the lower world. And Ya'akov is of that lower world. More over, the struggle of Ya'akov is not always with the Lavan's, Esau's, and the such. The struggle of Ya'akov includes the struggle of a grandfather being with his children and their children. It is truly the Ya'akov who struggled with Lavan, Esau, and all that lived in Egypt with his viceroy son, his other children and all. It was Ya'akov Avenu that ensured that there was a Yeshiva established in the land of Goshen. It was Ya'akov that dedicated his son, Levi, and Levi's children, to the service of HaShem, as he blessed each Tribe with their mission in life. Abraham, Yitzchak and Ya'akov could and did serve HaShem, but themselves, in each of their generation, but now, each of the twelve Tribes would be responsible for a piece of that mission. For such is the world, from each level below, there is a descent. Abraham was called the Prince of HaShem and Ya'akov was but a shepherd. It is the twelve Tribe's names that rested upon the Breastplate of the High Priest ( ), for a remembrance. And it was Ya'akov that established the Tribes and what each of their places among the Children of Israel was. Through the Tribes, and their children, us, the spirit of Ya'akov Avenu still lives within us. For Ya'akov was the struggle of life for a Jew in this world. Each of us has to deal with our Lavan's, Esau's, and children. The lives of our fore-fathers is a model for us. What happened to the fore-fathers, happened to their children (and throughout history). When Mashiach comes, then, we too will live as Ya'akov did in his final years. For struggle is not a necessarily a bad thing. For live is always in motion, growing, learning, and loving.

Bereishet 48:20, May [the children of] Israel bless with [your name], Rashi comments, he who wishes to bless his sons will bless them with the same blessing as they were blessed, and each will say to his son: May G-d make you like Efrayim and Menashe. Efrayim and Menashe, were sons of Yosef, born to him in Egypt, and yet, these two were worthy to be counted among their uncles, the Tribes, in their father's place when Levi was not to be included, such as the division of the Land of Israel in Yehoshu'a's time, for the Tribe of Levi did not receive an inheritance within the Land, as HaShem commanded. These two sons of Yosef, the first Jews born outside of the Land of Israel and the first Jews raised outside the home of our fore-fathers, who established their own homes in the accordance with the ways of our fore-fathers in a foreign land that was very much the very opposite of a Jewish land should be. Especially, in our day and time, our sons liken to be Efrayim and Menashe, to survive in a land not our own, with ways not our ways.

Bereishet 49:1, Ya'akov then called his sons and said [to them], Come together, and let me tell you what will happen to you at the end of time. Rashi takes the phrase and let me tell you and comments on it, saying, He wished to reveal [when would be] the end [of their descendents' exile], but the Divine Presence departed from him, so he began to speak of other things. Our Sages tell us that Ya'akov Avenu wished to them his children (and pass on down) knowledge of the coming of Mashiach, but HaShem did not permit that. As we know, as Mashiach has yet to come (may he come soonest), our Sages would said had we know when Mashiach would come, the previous generations would have despaired knowing we have to wait for so long. And yet, our Sages also say, that Mashiach can come in a blink of an eye, at any time. As the punchline of a Chasidic story goes when told that Mashiach said he would come today, Today being if only we all did teshuva, Mashiach would come then and there. So too, the time of Mashiach is not an absolute fixed point in time, but rather a calculation of a formula that only HaShem knows.

Bereishet 49:6, In their secret counsel let my soul not be mentioned[...] Rashi remarks, This [refers to] the story of Zimri (Bemidbar 25:6-9), when the tribe of Shim'on assembled to bring the Midyani woman before Moshe and they said to him, Is this [woman] forbidden or permitted [to be taken as a wife]? If you say she is forbidden, who, then, permitted for you the daughter of Yisro? [Ya'akov said:] Do no let my name be mentioned in connection with this affair! [Therefore it says:] Zimri the son of Salu, the leader of an ancestral house of the Shim'oni [tribe] (ibid. v. 14), and it does not say [that Shim'on was] the son of Ya'akov. And Bereishet 49:6, [...] in their congregation [...], Rashi states, when Korach, of the tribe of Levi, will congregate the whole community against Moshe and Aharon (Bemidbar ch 16) (Bereishet 49:6) [...] let my honor not be included [...] may my name not be included with them, as [indeed] it says: Korach, the son of Yitzhar, the son of Kehas, the son of Levi (ibid v.1), but it does not say, the son of Ya'akov. But in Divrei Hayamim, when the genealogy of Korach's descendents is listed in connection with [their service on] the duchan, it says, the son of Korach, the son of Yitzhar, the son of Kehas, the son of Levi, the son of Israel (Divrei Hayamim 6:22-23). For through prophecy, Ya'akov Avenu knew of the troubles that would descend from his sons, Shim'on and Levi, and wished not to be a part of it. But when they were doing HaShem's will, such as when the Sons of Levi, who sang as part a service in the Holy Temple, then his name was added. Thus, we should learn to distance ourselves from sin, and attach ourselves to good.

But of his sons, themselves, he said, Bereishet 49:7, Cursed is their anger for it is powerful To which, Rashi points out, Even when he admonished them, he only cursed their anger. It was [about] this that Bil'am said: How can I curse [whom] G-d [Himself] has not cursed? (Bemidbar 23:8) He did not say that what they did was wrong, in rescuing their sister, Dinah, only that their anger (and manner) was not the best way of doing so.

Bereishet 49:10, Until Shiloh comes, Rashi says, the Anointed King (Mashiach) who will have [complete] sovereignty. This is also how Onkelos tranlates it. And according to the Midrashic explanation: [is a combination of the words] a present to him, as it says [concerning Mashiach]: [the peoples of the world] will bring a gift () to the one who is to be feared. (Tehillim 76:12)

In the blessing of his children, Ya'akov seemingly did not for his first three sons, Re'uven, Shim'on, and Levi, so the Torah tells us, Bereishet 49:28, [...] this is what their father spoke to them, and he blessed them[...] To which, Rashi comments, But where there not some of them whom he did not bless but reproached? However, this is the explanation [of the verse]: And this is what their father spoke to them [i.e.] that which was said above. Maybe [this means] that he did not bless Re'uven, Shim'on, and Levi the verse [therefore] tell us: and he bless them implying [that he blessed] all of them. The verse continues with With the [particular] blessing that was [destined] to come to each [individual] he blessed them. Rashi explains, [The verse] need only to come to each did he bless him. When, then, does the verse say: he bless them? [The answer is:] Since he gave to Yehudah the power of a lion, to Binyamin the rapaciousness of a wolf, and to Naftali the fleetness of a hind, this might seem [to indicate] that not all of them were included in the all the blessings the verse [therefore] says: he blessed them [all with the blessing that was to come to each of them]. Thus, the children of Ya'akov got individual and as a group blessings from their father.

Bereishet 50:6, as he made you swear, Rashi remarks, but were it not for [this] oath, I would not allow you [to go]. But [Pharaoh] was afraid to tell [Yosef]: Break the oath! so that he should not answer: If so, I will [also] break the oath that I swore to you not to reveal the fact that I know the Holy Language, besides the [other] seventy languages, but which you do not know as is stated in Tracte Sotah (36b). For as Ya'akov foresaw this, and this is why, in the begin of the Parsha that Ya'akov had Yosef swear that he would be buried in Israel, not in Egypt (which Pharaoh wanted).

Bereishet 50:13, His sons carried him For Ya'akov had instructed his sons, and not his grandsons, to carry his bier, and the manner in which they were to do so. Through Divine Inspiration or Divine Agreement, this arrangement of Ya'akov's bier was the same that his children would use when they were freed from Egypt, with three sons per side. For as the Holy Ark carried the Law, so did Ya'akov Avenu.

The Parsha and the Sefer Bereishet ends with Bereishet 50:25-26, (25) Yosef made the sons of Israel swear, saying [to them], G-d will surely remember you, and you shall [then] take up my bones from here. (26) Yosef died at the age of one hundred and ten, and [the Egyptians] embalmed him and placed him in [his] coffin in Egypt. This shows more of the character of Yosef, that even in death, Yosef looked after his children and brethren. For Yosef and the children knew of the exile they were facing, and so Yosef gave them hope, reminding them that just as HaShem promised Abraham that his children would be enslaved, so too, would the people enslaving them be judged and his children would be freed.

Chayzak (), Chayzak (). From strength to strength.

It has been said that the Lubavitch Rebbe said we are the last generation of exile and the first generation of redemption. With the Rebbe's hope, may HaShem, the Source of Mercy, surely remember us as he recalled our fore-fathers in Egypt and redeem us from our exile as He redeemed them from theirs. May HaShem, Source of Blessing, send the final redeemer, Mashiach, to us today, speedily in our time. So we may offer up a new song to HaShem and true peace will reign forever more.

entry.title: Parsha Vayigash
entry.content:
''
Dec 20, 2012 / 5773 Teves 7 / ''

Parsha Vayigash /
Bereishet 44:18 47:27
Translate Source: Chayenu Margolin Chumash-Rashi Edition

Parsha Vayigash starts with Yehudah then stepped forward, the Midrash relates the confrontation between Yehudah and Yosef, which is only hinted at with Yehudah stepping forward. Why did Yehudah step forward? For he, personally, was responsible for his brother's Binyamin welfare, but also because he was the leader of the brothers. Which is interesting, because Ya'akov, their father, had really appointed Yosef for that position. And this was among the sources of the friction between the brothers, for Yosef had one view, and Yehudah and the brothers had another.

The brothers, as is said in Bereishet 46:32, were shepherds, as Ya'akov, Yitzchak, and Abraham were, workers of the field. But Yosef was an administrator, a worker of the city. The brothers wished to live a part from the world, and concentrate upon HaShem and His ways, while Yosef wished to be a part of the world while he concentrated upon HaShem and His ways.

For nothing is hereditary wrong with either approach. In fact, during our exile, we have been following the ways of Yosef, as we follow many of his examples. When Mashiach comes, we may return to the ways of Yehudah, or a balance between the two, as what will happen then is not fully known until it happens, hopefully soon in our days.

When Yehudah confronted the viceroy of Egypt,.not knowing it was actually his brother Yosef, he was ready to do whatever it took to free Binyamin, be it using the role of a lawyer or a warrior. It was seeing that Yehudah was ready to die to defend Binyamin and the immediate threat of what the brothers could do that moved Yosef to reveal himself to them.

When Yosef revealed himself, he took into account his brothers' reaction, for Bereishet 45:1, Yosef could not withhold himself before those standing[...], to which Rashi comments, [means: Yosef] could not abide that the Egyptians would be standing by him and hearing how his brothers were ashamed when he made himself known to them. Such was the character of Yosef. For Yosef, himself, said, Bereishet 45:5, Now, however, do not be upset or angry with yourselves that you sold me here, for G-d sent me ahead of you to be [a provider of] sustenance [for you]. For Yosef understood that everything that had happened, had happened for a reason in accordance with the Divine Plan.

Interesting of note is Bereishet 45:14, He then fell on the neck of his brother Binyamin and wept, which Rashi comments why did Yosef weep, for the two Holy Temples that in the future were to be in Binyamin's territory and would ultimately be destroyed. The torah ends the verse with, and Binyamin wept on his neck. Rashi's comments on why Binyamin wept, for the Shiloh Dwelling which in the future was to be in Yosef's territory and would ultimately be destroyed. If those are not reasons to cry, what is? For such was the loss for the entire world when the Holy Temple was destroyed.

It is interesting to note that Bereishet 46:1,starts with, Israel journeyed with everything that he had and seemingly in a good mood for he was to be reunited with his most favorite son, Yosef. And yet, HaShem had to tell him, Bereishet 46:3, [...] Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt [...] For what had changed? Rashi answers, [HaShem said this to him] because he was upset that he was forced to leave the Land [of Israel]. Which is the simple meaning, but Ya'akov must have also known that he was being forced to leave because of the promise that HaShem made to Abraham that his descendents would be strangers in a land not their own. Ya'akov took comfort from HaShem's promise to him that (Bereishet 46:4) I will surely bring you up [from there] as well, but it's simple meaning is as Rashi wrote, He [HaShem] promised him [Ya'akov] that he would be buried in the Land [of Israel]. Which Ya'akov (and Leah) are buried in the Ma'aarat HaMachpela - the Cave of the Patriarchs (the structure above the actual cave, which you can visit in Chevron, Israel. Which I do highly recommend doing), along with Adam and Eve, Abraham and Sarah, and Yitzchak and Rivka.

Bereishet 46:20, To Yosef were born in the land of Egypt, Menashe and Efrayim; whom Asenas, the daughter of Poti Fera, the lord of On, bore to him. Such was the praise of Yosef, whose wife was a high-ranking in Egyptian society as well as himself, and yet, his sons, Menashe and Efrayim, are counted among the Tribes (when Levi is not), and in later Parsha, Ya'akov Avenu said that we should bless our sons to be like Menashe and Efrayim. For they were the first Jews to born in Exile and exceeded in their Judaism in a land filled with immorality.

Bereishet 46:28, Prior to his arrival there To which, Rashi says, And the Aggadic explanation is to establish a house of study from which teaching [Torah] would emanate. For Ya'akov knew that the study of Torah would permit the survival of his children. For it is HaShem, and his teaching, the Torah, that has allowed us to survive through the Ages. For it said, Torah is a tree of life for all that cling to it. Thus, prior to the start of the Egyptian Exile, Ya'akov charged his son, Yehudah, to establish a house of Torah study, to ensure that we would survive that and the other exiles.

Bereishet 46:29, states that Yosef wept upon seeing his father, but Rashi states, Ya'akov, however, did not fall on Yosef's neck, nor did he kiss him. Our Rabbis said that he was reciting the Shema. A reunion which in the very next verse Ya'akov says, If I were to die now [I would be comforted] and yet, indeed of being emotional like Yosef, he's reciting the Shema. For such was the stature of the Forefathers, whom Ya'akov was able to channel the immense joy in seeing his beloved son and channel that energy into his service to HaShem, reciting the Shema.

Bereishet 46:30, that you are still alive. Which sounds obvious, but I believe that what Ya'akov was amazed at, was that Yosef, viceroy of the immoral Egypt, was still a Tzaddik. For it is said, that a sinner is not alive, and the righteous are alive even when their bodies have expired. Thus, I believe, that what Ya'akov Avenu was saying was that he was amazed that Yosef was still righteous having been away from the family (and its safety) and in the land of such immorality.

Bereishet 46:34, For [any shepherd] is an abomination to the Egyptians[...] which Rashi comments, because [sheep] are considered by them as gods. Which one can look to India and their sacred cows for a modern day equivalent. I have seen, although I don't recall where, that the abomination is not Yosef's word, but the Torah's about the Egyptian gods; that the Egyptians actually looked upon shepherds as their priests for their idols. The Torah refers to idols as abominations. After all, we find by Moses and Aaron, that the Tribe of Levi was separated from the rest of Israel's labors so they could minister to the other Tribes. So the Egyptians, who were very big on enslaving the Jews, took the Priesthood very seriously.

Bereishet 47:10, Ya'akov then blessed, which Rashi comments, in the manner of all who leave the presence of princes: they bless them and obtain permission [to leave]. And what was the blessing that he gave him? That the [River] Nile should rise at his approach, since Egypt is not irrigated by rain water, but the Nile rises and irrigates it; and from the blessing of Ya'akov onwards Pharaoh would come to the Nile and it would rise towards him and irrigate the land. Thus, Rashi tells what Ya'akov blessed Pharaoh with. But also, in Sefer Shemot, this is the source of Pharaoh's supposed divinity that the waters of the Nile, one of Egypt's idol, would rise for him.

Bereishet 47:21, And the people he transferred, to which Rashi adds, from city to city as a reminder that they no longer had a portion on the land, and he settled [the people] of one city in another. There was no need for the verse to write this except to recount to you Yosef's praise, that he intended [thereby] to remove a stigma from his brothers, that [the Egyptians] would not call them exiles. For the Egyptians themselves were exiled from their cities to other places by Yosef. Also to Yosef's praise, he had them circumcise themselves so that the Jews would not stand out among them.

For such are the leaders of our people, helping us, even before we need it, making sure that we are cared for. May the ultimate Leader of our People, HaShem, send Mashiach so that we all will be cared for and true peace will reign throughout the world, speedily in our day, Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Mikeitz
entry.content:
''
Dec 12, 2012 / 5773 Kislev 28 / ''

Parsha Mikeitz /
Bereishet 41:1 44:17
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi

The Parsha is called Miketz (), which means end, as the Parsha opens, Bereishet 41:1, It happened at the end of two full years, [...] that the time of Yosef's release had come, and HaShem did not waste any time in freeing him when the time had come. Such do our Sages say, salvation can come in the blink of an eye. Thus, when it was time for Yosef's release, Pharaoh became troubled with his dream, and Yosef was in position to answer and calm Pharaoh from his dream.

Interesting to point out that the Tzadik () Yosef had two dreams with similar meaning; one of earth and the other of heavens, while Pharaoh also had two similar dreams, but both were of the earthly things. Our Sages say of this, that as a Jew, we dwell in both the Earthly and Heavenly spheres, while the goyim concern themselves only with the Earthly sphere.

Bereishet 41:12, A Hebrew youth, a servant, Rashi comments, The wicked are accursed, for [even] the good they do is incomplete. [The wine-butler] mentioned him in disparaging terms: [signifying that he was] a fool and unsuitable for a high position; "a Hebrew [signifying that] he does not even know our language; "a servant and it is written in the protocol of Egypt that a servant may not become a ruler nor wear the robes of nobility () And this was the wine-butler that Yosef had hoped who be the agent of his freedom, but since Yosef thought his release was solely a matter of mundane, HaShem sentences Yosef to two years in jail. But when those two years ended, immediately Yosef was freed. This points out that while we should work within the mundane framework, we must still keep HaShem and His ways in mind. As the Psalmist said, Perek 146:3, Do not place your trust in nobles[...] but rather in HaShem, the Author and Source.

Bereishet 41:48, [...] The food of the surrounding fields of the city he stored inside it Rashi comments, since each and every district preserves its own produce.
