[Therefore, people] put some of the earth of that place among the grain and it [thus] prevents the grain from rotting. The Lubavitch Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson of Blessed Memory, mentions that soil/earth represents humility, and as the verse says that the soil/earth preserved the food, so too does humility help to preserve one's Torah knowledge. The Rebbe adds that as just as local soil was used to one's humility should be in the same area as one's greatness.

Bereishet 42:3, [...] brothers of Yosef went down [...], Rashi remarks, [The verse] does not write [here] the sons of Ya'akov. It [thus] teaches [us] that they regretted having sold him, and had made up their minds to behave towards him in a brotherly way and to redeem him at whatever price would be demanded of them. It was a Divine mission for the Children of Israel to be enslaved in Egypt, there was many ways that could have come about, but HaShem used the ten tribes, for whatever reason, and when that mission was complete, our Sages say that then brothers' jealously/hatred of Yosef went with it.

Bereishet 42:11, [...] we , all of us, are the sons of one man [...] Rashi comments, They had a spark of the Divine Spirit [of prophecy] and included him [Yosef] with them, for he, too, was the son of their father. Did the brothers know they were speaking prophecy? At that time, definitely not, for the Torah says, Bereishet 42:8, [...] but they did not recognize him. So they did not, so what was the point of this prophecy then? Yosef knew it was true, but the brothers did not. I don't know what the Sages say about this, but I feel that as the Tribes, the sons of Ya'akov, were special to HaShem, and the Tribes walked in the way of HaShem, such that HaShem (prophecy) slipped into their speech, which this is an example of. More probably though was that this also showed to Yosef that the time of the separation between him and his brother had come to an end.

Bereishet 42:18, Yosef told his brothers, I fear G-d, when he was impersonating an Egyptian ruler, a land of moral corruption, and yet the Tribes were not suspicious of this. Because such was the Fear of Heaven upon them that they probably did not think this strange that others would fear HaShem as they would.

Bereishet 42:28, [...] What is this that G-d has done to us, Rashi comments, by bringing us to this accusation, for it was [surely] only put back [into our sacks] in order to make an accusation against us. Thus, the Tribes knew that everything was the work of HaShem, so if they were accused, it was because of some sin of theirs was the true cause of what was happening to them.

Bereishet 43:6, Israel replied. This is the first time in the Parsha that Ya'akov is referred to by his secondary name, Israel. For we see the transformation from the struggling Ya'akov to the spiritual Israel that hopes in HaShem.

Bereishet 43:8, Yehudah then said to Israel, his father, Let the boy go[...] I find it interesting that Yehudah (and others) refer to Binyamin, who at this time, is the father of ten sons. In answer, there is the fact that Binyamin was the baby of the family, the youngest of the Tribes.

Bereishet 43:11, ", Rashi comments on this word, I do not know what they are, but I saw in Rabbi Machir's dictionary [that they are] pistachios, and it seems to me that theses are peaches. Rashi, the greatest commentator on the Torah, was not afraid to say, I do not know Commentators on Rashi's comment suggest that Rashi was not familiar with pistachio nuts, so he thought them peaches. Which makes me wonder at the sizes of the peaches that Rashi knew or the size of a pistachio nut, as I would think that a handful of pistachios would fit into the volume of a single peach, so the size would be different. But then if Rashi had never seen a pistachios, peaches were the closest he could come up with.

Bereishet 43:14, [May] the All-Sufficing G-d Rashi comments, Now you are lacking nothing [for the journey] except prayer, [so] I am [now] going to pray for you. We can make any number of physical preparations in life, but it will never be enough without prayer. For we must acknowledge the Author of All and ask for His mercy in our undertaking to be successful.

Bereishet 43:32, as this was an abomination, Rashi explains, it was a hateful thing for the Egyptians to eat with the Hebrews, and Onkelos gives a reason for this. Onkelos translated the Torah from Hebrew into the then language of Aramaic, but here, Rashi points out that he is giving an explanation which is, for the animal which the Egyptian worship, Hebrews eat. Which shows the courage of the Tribes, for they ate the idol of Egyptian (as their children would before the Exodus as the Pesach sacrifice), and they were not afraid of the Egyptians becoming upset with them for their action. What part Yosef played in this, I am not sure, but since they ate separated from the Egyptians still holds true.

Bereishet 44:16, G-d has found. Rashi says of this phrase, We know that we have done nothing wrong, but it has been caused by the Omnipresent that this happened to us. The Creditor has found an opportunity to collect His debt. In others words, HaShem will always find a way to balance the books, and plans everything. What happen to us is the result of our choices, which are a part of the Divine Plan.

And just as Yosef was set up as the vice-royal to safe the family during the time of famine, so Mashiach will safe us from famine of spiritual which afflicts the world. May it be speedily in our day.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeishev
entry.content:
''

Dec 5, 2012 / 5773 Kislev 21 / ''
Parsha Vayeishev /
Bereishet 37:1 40:23
Translation Source: Chayenu: Margolin Chumash-Rashi


Our Parsha is called Vayeishev (), settled, and it deals with Yosef's two dreams, his journey down into Egypt, and the dreams of two servants of Pharaoh. It would seem that settle has very little to do with this Parsha, but since our Sages named it thus, there should be some connection here. What does it mean to settle? It means to go and live permanently in a particular place. And yet, Yosef is sold and sent to Egypt. How is this settling?

Here is how I see it, to live permanently some place, requires ownership or agreement with the owner. Here in this Parsha, we have the beginning of the first exile which HaShem told Abraham about about his children living in a land not their own. In doing this, the Children of Israel were able to finish the second part, inheriting the land that HaShem had promised Abraham. The Commentators say that when Moses asked the Ishmaelites and Edomites to pass through their land to get to the Land of Israel, Moses pointed out that they, the Children of Ya'akov, had fulfilled the first part of the HaShem's decree to Abraham, and thus, entitled to the second part.

Interesting enough, there are four dreams mentioned within this Parsha, Ya'akov's dream of a ladder previously, and Pharaoh's dream next week. Two of the dreams are Yosef's, and the other two are two servants of Pharaoh. So are dreams important? After all, they are mentioned in the Torah. Even two lowly servants of Pharaoh had them.

We all have dreams after all. Medical science says that the average person has four to six dreams per night. Whether you recall them or not, is a different matter, dreams seem to be part of deep sleep called, Rapid-Eye Movement (REM). Throughout history, people have tried to understand dreams and their meaning. Our Sages differ on whether dreams have true meaning or not, the Sages do say that every dream will have bits that are nonsensical, but the rest is open for debate.

When one recalls a dream, our Sages tell us that how that dream is interpreted will affect how the events might play out. After all, anything can happen within a dream, as the old saying goes, it is possible to thread an elephant through an eye of a needle in a dream. In our dreams, we can travel beyond our own limitations and touch the Divine. As the song goes, life is a dream.

Like any dream, it is how we interpret that dream that makes life as it is, those with positive outlooks have positive lives while those who are negative have to deal with their consequences.

Which Yosef is a good example, although his brothers were jealous of him, Yosef kept a positive attitude to his life, believing in HaShem throughout his life. He could have easily been defeated and assimilated among the slaves in Egypt, but because he believed in HaShem, he remained a Jew, even in the lands of immoral Egypt.

Seemingly the Torah interrupts its narrative of Yosef, to tell us of the marriage of Yehudah, his three sons by Shu'a, and the arrangements of Tamar. Tamar married Yehudah's first two sons, who die because of their sins, and when Yehudah doesn't allow Tamar's marriage to the third son, she tricks Yehudah, himself, into impregnating her, for she desired to be a part of Yehudah's family was so strong. Tamar's twin sons were Peretz and Zerach. Peretz would be the ancestor of Ruth, King David and Mashiach.

But this isn't an interrupting, but a further sign of Divine Providence, for as the Egyptian exile was just about to begin, the fore-father of Mashiach, the final redeemer was born. As our Sages say, HaShem provides the cure before the illness.

To illustrate this best, Bereishet 37:26, From Me, Rashi comments, she is pregnant. And our Rabbis, of blessed memory interpreted this [to mean] that a bas kol (Heavenly Voice) announced: from Me and through Me these things came about. Since she was modest in her father-in-law's home I have decreed that kings will descended from her, and I have [also] decreed that from the tribe of Yehudah kings will be appointed in Yisrael.

From Me and through Me, HaShem said, this is very true in Yehudah and Tamar, in Yosef's going down to Egypt, and everything else that happens in our lives. As it is said, everything but the Fear of Heaven, is in the hands of Heaven.

And thus the secret to Yosef's success was that Yosef kept the ways of his father, so HaShem was with him. Since HaShem was with him, Yosef did well in his captivity. And we have survived in exile, these thousands of years, because we have kept the ways of our fore-fathers and HaShem is with us.

May HaShem show the world that He is with us with the ultimate redemption with the coming of Mashiach, speedily in our days. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Vayishlach
entry.content:
''
Nov 28, 2012 / 5773 Kislev 14 / ''

Parsha Vayishlach /
Bereishet 32:4 36:43
Translation Source: Chayenu Margolin Chumash-Rashi

The name of this week's Parsha is Vayishlach () which means sent. As the Parsha begins, Bereishet 32:4, Ya'akov sent angels, which Rashi comments, real angels, as the word messenger () used for both human or angelic messengers. So to set the stage, Ya'akov Avenu ( ) has returned to the Land of Kena'an, having left the House of Lavan, and seemingly goes straight to confront his brother, Esau. He sends actual angels to Esau to let him know of his return and seeks to have brotherly-relationship with him. The interesting note of this is that Esau isn't blinded or intimidated by the actual Heavenly angels. Neither Lot nor Hagar were either, but they are not called wicked by the Tanach ('') either. And yet, he could withstand against the angels, as it is said, Bereishet 32:7, [...] We have been to your brother, to Esau [...], to which Rashi clarifies, you used to say, He is my brother, but who behaves towards you like Esau the wicked, he still has his hatred. Just like Ya'akov Avenu ( ), Esau was the son of Yitzchak and Rivka. So, despite, the wickedness of Esau, there is some spiritual standing that allowed him to withstand the meeting of the Divine. Interesting of note, several Sages compare the likeness of King David to Esau, where as King David walked in the Ways of HaShem, Esau did not. It is said that the higher something is, the greater the fall. So somewhere deep within Esau, there was a high-spark, which Esau would not access but was there none the less.

Bereishet 32:8, Ya'akov was extremely afraid and distressed [], which Rashi comments, He was afraid that he might have killed, and he was distressed that he might have to kill others. And yet, despite his fear and distress, Ya'akov took action, in which he split his camp into two. Rashi comments, [Ya'akov] prepared himself for three things: to [give] a present, for prayer and for war to [give] a present, [as it says]: The gift went on ahead of him (v.22); for prayer, [as it says]: G-d of my [grand]father, Abraham,... (v10); for war, [as it says]: then the remaining camp will escape. This tactic has been adopted by us throughout the millenniums.

I believe that we can see this in another way, as a metaphor: present, using natural/passive means to seek peace; prayer, using Divine/passive means to seek peace; and war, using aggressive means to seek peace. It is notable that; first is present/natural, second is prayer/Divine, and last is war. War should always be a last resort, but understood that there are times where it is required. While the first two are passive, the last is not. In Ya'akov Avenu ( )'s case, prayer worked, though he had prepared for war, it did not come to that. And HaShem willing, most of the time the first two are enough, but on those rare occasions, one needs to be prepared for war as well act upon it. There are two passive/peaceful ways, but only one aggressive way. We should not think of war as evil, unto itself, HaShem, Himself, the Source of Mercy, commanded the Children of Israel to wage war to conquer the Land of Israel, defend the nation, and eradicate Amalek. That's not even counting the wars that King David and the Prophets were involved in. War has its place, but should be a last resort and a valid option. Also, with present, one gives something of value over to another mortal being, to express themselves and desire for peace. In our Parsha, Ya'akov Avenu gave Esau; goats, camels, and donkeys, both male and female of those species. In our days, we have tried to give land for peace since 1930s, which unfortunately, has yet to work. Ya'akov Avenu, after preparing the gifts for his brother, Esau, then prayed, which starts at Bereishet 32:10 through 32:13. And we too say various prayers, Tehillim, and such. And of course, Israel has an army to defend itself.

Having done all this, the Torah tells us, Bereishet 32:25, Ya'akov was left by himself, and a man wrestled with him until dawn. Who was this man, Rashi tells us, Our Rabbis, of blessed memory, explained that [this man] was Esau's guardian angel. Why until dawn? Bereishet 32:27, For it is [already] dawn, Rashi says, and I must sing [HaShem's] song [of praise] by day. For each angel had their turn to praise their Creator. Ya'akov refuses to release the angel until the angel blessed him, to which the Torah begins, No [longer]... Ya'akov, to which, Rashi explains, it shall no longer be said that the blessing came to you through deceit and trickery, but rather with nobility and openly, [for] eventually the Holy One, Source of Blessing, will appear to you at Beis El and change your name (35:10), and there he will bless you, and I will be there and admit to your right to [the blessings].

Rashi points out the dots written over the word, Bereishet 33:3 and kissed him saying, There are dots over [this word]. There is a difference of opinion in the beraisa of the Sifrei (Beha'alosecha 69) about this. Some explain these dots [to mean] that he did not kiss him wholeheartedly, [but] R. Shim'on bar Yochai said, It is an established fact that Esau hates Ya'akov, but at that moment his compassion was aroused and he kissed him wholeheartedly.

Why the option? Because, according to the Talmud Yerushalmi, Pesachim, 9:2: The Sages say, when there are more undotted letters than dotted letters, expound upon the undotted letters and dont read the dotted letters, and when there are more dotted letters than undotted letters, expound the dots and dont read the letters. Rabbi says, even when there is only one dot above them, expound the dot and dont read the letters.

And here, all the letters are dotted, meaning that the word doesn't quite mean what it means, hence the opinions. Either way, it shows that Ya'akov did not need to fight.

Of note of the character of Yosef, Bereishet 33:7, Yosef drew near, with Rachel, to which Rashi comments, With all [the others], the mothers drew before the children, but in the case of Rachel, Yosef drew near before her. He said, My mother is beautiful [and] maybe that wicked man will take a fancy to her. I will [therefore] stand in front of her and prevent him from looking at her. As a result of this Yosef merited the blessing: upon the eye Thus, it is said that Yosef was protected from the evil eye.

After the brothers reconciled, Esau offers to travel with Ya'akov, which Ya'akov begs off citing the children and their needs, and then cites Bereishet 33:14, Until I reach my master at Se'ir, to which Rashi writes upon, He mentioned to him a much longer journey [than he intended to make], for [in fact] he intended to travel only to Sukkos. He said [to himself]: If he wishes to harm me let him wait until I come to him [to Se'ir], but [in reality] he did not go. And when will he go [there]? In the time of Mashiach, as it says, The liberators on Mount Tziyon will then go up to carry out judgment on the mount of Esau (i.e. Se'ir) (Ovadyah 1:21). There are [also] many Aggadic explanations of this section. For Ya'akov embodied Truth with a capital T, so Ya'akov even for safety sake, did not lie outright. Of course, many Sages point out that when in a questionable situation, one can cite a destination much further along one's travels to avoid trouble, like Ya'akov did, citing this passage as an example.

After his confrontation/meeting with Esau, Ya'akov is troubled by the kidnapping and rape of his daughter, Dinah. The two are put together for the Sages say, since Ya'akov withheld his daughter from Esau, this happened. Which shows what a high level the Patriarchs were on, as we cannot understand such a situation happening, nor are we held to such an accountability. Here, Shim'on and Levi take back their sister and wipe out the entire city of Shechem. Ya'akov is upset at the manner in which Shim'on and Levi carry out their rescue of their sister.

Afterward, HaShem appears to Ya'akov and renames him, Israel, and blesses him.

The twelfth son of Israel is born, and Rachel passes away in childbirth. As it is recorded, Bereishet 35:18, As her life ebbed, for she was dying, she named [the child] Ben Oni (son of my sorrow), but his father called him Binyamin (son of the south).

After the passing of Rachel, Ya'akov seemed to favor Rachel's handmaiden, which Re'uven took offense too as Rashi points out.

Bereishet 35:22, [...] Ya'akov's sons were twelve. Which Rashi points out, It starts [again] with the previous subject: When Binyamin was born, [Ya'akov's] bed was complete and [his sons] were now fitting to be counted, so [the verse] counts them. And our Rabbis explained, [This count] comes to teach us that they were all equal and all righteous, because Re'uven did not [really] sin. as implied by the previous verses. The Torah then goes on to count and name Ya'akov's sons. At the end of the count, the Torah slips in that Yitzchak has passed away and that his sons buried him.

The Parsha concludes with the re-counting of Esau and his descendents.

In the listing of the children of Esau, the Torah says, Bereishet 36:12, Timna was a concubine, to which Rashi comments, [This is written] to tell [us] of Abraham's greatness, [expressed by] how eager people were to attach themselves to this descendents. This Timna was a descendent of chieftains, as it is says, and Lotan's sister was Timna (v. 22), and Lotan was one of the chieftains who inhabited Se'ir, of the Chorim who were the original inhabitants [of that land]. She said [to Elifaz], [Maybe] I am not worthy to be your wife. If only I could be [your] concubine! In Divrei Hayamin (I 1:36) she is counted among the children of Elifaz. This teaches [us] that he had relations with Se'ir's wife and Timna was born from them, and when she grew up she became his concubine. That is [why it says]: and Lotan's sister was Timna, yet she is not counted among the descendents of Se'ir, for she was his maternal sister but not his paternal [sister]. Abraham was called a Prince of HaShem, he's greatness was known, but the greatness of the other Patriarchs wasn't as known. It also shows that Esau's descendents wickedness.

The Torah recounts the descendents of Esau to show his wickedness and also to finish the story of Esau, so that the Torah can then on concentrate upon Ya'akov and his children.

As the Parsha said, In the time of Mashiach, as it says, The liberators on Mount Tziyon will then go up to carry out judgment on the mount of Esau (i.e. Se'ir) (Ovadyah 1:21) and may that time be soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeitzei
entry.content:
''
Nov 22, 2012 / 5773 Kislev 8 / ''

Parsha Vayeitzei /
Bereishet 28:10 32:3
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash Margolin Edition; Rashi Silbermann Edition

The name of this Parsha is ", (he) left, and the Parsha talks about Ya'akov's departure from his father house, finding his wives, the birth of the Tribes, and Ya'akov's return to the Land of Kena'an. Rashi comments on this word saying, It need only have written, Ya'akov set out for Charan. Why then, does it mention his leaving? [In order to] tell [us] that the departure of a righteous person from a place makes an impression for while the righteous is in a town, he is its glory, he is its brilliance [and] he is its splendor, [but] once he has left there, its glory is gone, its brilliance is gone [and] its splendor has gone. Similarly, She left the place (Ruth 1:7) that is mentioned in connection with Naomi and Ruth [has the same significance].

With Rashi's comment, I think, we can understand this Parsha and it's name, better. Every Jew is like our Fore-father. While we are not as righteous as our Patriarchs, we too make an impression upon where we live. For as it is said, we are a light unto the nations, to show the way to civilization and know our Creator. We do so by being an example of what HaShem wants from us.

There are two types of leaving that Ya'akov does in our Parsha, he leaves behind all that he knows to start a family and heads to his uncle's house, and he leaves behind his uncle and returns to start his own house.

It should be noted that the Jewish Nation isn't like the other nations of the world. It through miracles that we were born and through miracles that we remain. If it was not for HaShem, the nations of the world would have swallowed us long ago.

It was in the mists of Lavan, the prototype wicked person, that the Tribes were born and the founding our nation took place. Not in the Holy, but among the wicked, do we see the contrast and miracles of our existance. Not in the high, but the low, we are can do holy things, elevate this world.

The Ya'akov that left his father's house, is still the same Ya'akov that returned with a family, despite his time and actions against Lavan.

Some interesting verses from our Parsha....

Bereishet 28:17, [...] This is none other than the House of G-d, and this is the gateway to Heaven. For our Sages said that the Holy Temple here on Earth, corresponds to the Heavenly equivalent there, and it is from the Holy of Holies that our prayers are directed and ascend to Heaven. For we pray towards Jerusalem, and those in Jerusalem, pray towards the Temple Mount, those upon the Temple Mount, pray towards where tradition says the Holy of Holies was and will be. For it is on that site, the site of the Holy of Holies that the Ark of Testimonies rested, where Yitzchak was offered like a sacrifice, where Noach offered his sacrificed after the Flood, and many other important/holy events took place.

Bereishet 29:1, Ya'akov felt light-footed, to which Rashi said, When he received the good news that he was assured of [HaShem's] protection, his heart lifted his feet and it because easy for him to walk. So it is explained in Bereishis Rabbah (70:8). Just as a fore-father Ya'akov was laid down by worry and then uplifted by HaShem's protection/promise, so too can we look to HaShem to lighten our worries. When things became too much, lend upon HaShem and He will support you.

Bereishet 29:17, Leah's eyes were tender. Rashi comments on the word tender, saying, for she thought that she would fall to the lot of Esav, and she was [therefore constantly] weeping; for everyone was said, Rivkah has two sons, and Lavan has two daughter the elder daughter is for the lot of elder son, and the younger daughter for the younger son. Why Esav acknowledged Ya'akov's purchase of the birthright, it was obviously not publicized. Leah did not know about the purchase, but did what she could against her fate and for her weeping (and praying), she was rewarded with marrying Ya'akov. For this (and others), we can learn that prayer is stronger than destiny No matter what others might say our fate is, only HaShem knows for sure, and we can influence HaShem with prayer and teshuvah ().

Bereishet 29:33. She [Leah] again became pregnant and gave birth to a son, and she said, Since the Eternal heard that I am hated, He has given me this [son] as well, so she named him Shim'on. Which is a load verse, so much in so little. HaShem heard, for the matters of the Forefathers and Tribe is dear to Him. I am hated, was Leah truly hated? No, for our forefather Ya'akov would not have stayed married to our fore-mother Leah if that truly was, but in comparison to Rachel, Leah would feel hated, for most of Ya'akov's love went to Rachel, but some was there for Leah and the two maids.

Bereishet 30:1, [...] and Rachel became jealous of her sister, Rashi comments, she was jealous of her good deeds. She said, If not that she were more righteous than I, she would not have merited [to bear] children. For Leah bore six of the twelve sons of Israel, half of children of Israel, came from Leah. Leah and Rachel knew that Ya'akov would have twelve sons, and he would have four wives, thus, each of the four wives should have had three sons. But because of Leah's righteousness, she bore six, and each of the other wives, had two. Leah could have just had her share of the children, but as Matriarch Rachal said of Matriarch Leah, because she was so righteous, she had more children.

Bereishet 30:1, [...] She said to Ya'akov, Give me children, for if not, I am [as good as] dead. To which, Rashi comments, From here [we learn] that who has no children is considered like dead. Which sounds strong, but, the every first commandment given to Adam HaReshon ( ), was be fruitful and multiply. Not having children is counter to the Will of HaShem. And for one that is not with the Source of Life, can be liken to one who is dead.

Bereishet 31:26, Lavan then said to Ya'akov, What have you done?! You deceived me and led away my daughters like prisoners of war. How queer are the wicked? Lavan, whom the Torah records tried to deceive Ya'akov by changing his wages over a hundred times, whom his own daughters said, Were we not considered by him as strangers that he sold us? Lavan has no problem with deceiving others, but when he, himself, is the target, then there's a problem. To his own flesh and blood, he had planned violence, which he boosts, I have the power to do evil to you, and last night, the G-d of your fathers spoke to me saying, Be careful not to speak with Ya'akov, neither good or evil. Such is the double-standard that exists in the world, unfortunately, even in our day, one needs to only look towards the news coming out of the Middle East to see the antisemitism is so strong even in America, the land of the free.

There are many, many, Lavans in the world, with their double-standards and self-centered-ness. And it would be so easy to join them. But we need to be like our Patriarch Ya'akov in our dealings with them. For then, HaShem will be with us, and we can overcome anything the Lavans of the world will try.

May Moshiach come speedy in our day, so that Truth will be revealed fully, and the Lavans of the world will be fully exposed. And with the death of falsehood, true Peace with a capital P with reign forever.

entry.title: Parsha Toldos
entry.content:
''
Nov 14, 2012 / 5773 Cheshvan 29 / ''

Parsha Toldos /
Bereishet 25:19 28:9
Translation Source: The Sapirstein Edition Rashi Chumash

I find it interesting that for Abraham Avenu ( ),there is three Parshiot () that feature him: one, Lech Lecha ( ); two, Vayeira (); and three, Chayei Sarah ( ). For Ya'akov Avenu ( ), the rest of the Parshiot () of Bereishit cover him and the Tribes, which are: one, Vayeitzei (); two, Vayishlach (); three, Vayeishev (); four, Mikeitz (); five, Vayigash (); and six, Vayechi (). And yet, for Yitzchak Avenu ( ), there is only this Parsha Toldos (). As such, we don't know as much about Yitzchak Avenu ( ) as we do our other two Fore-fathers.

Kabbalah tells us that Abraham Avenu ( ) embodied the attribute of Kindness (), Yitzchak Avenu ( ) embodied the attribute of Inner Strength (), and Ya'akov Avenu ( ) embodied the attribute of Beauty (). It takes three Parshiot to cover Kindness, only one for Strength, and the remaining six for Beauty/balance of the two.

The Torah says, Bereishet 25:19, Yitzchak , son of Abraham Abraham begot Yitzchak, which in Kabbalistic terms, strength comes from kindness and kindness begets strength. For Kindness and Strength would seem to be opposites and unrelated, but that is not so. Yes, Kindness is drawing in and Strength can be pushing away, but the underlining desire is the same. Abraham taught as many goyim about HaShem and His ways, while Yitzchak only taught his sons, Ya'akov and Esau. Yet, both Abraham and Yitzchak taught. We don't know for sure what happened to those that Abraham taught, but we know for sure that Ya'akov passed on his father's teachings to his children, as they passed on to their children (unto us, today). Esau, we can guess, only took what he wished of his father's teachings.

Abraham looked outwards and found HaShem, in a world that had forgotten their Source. Yitzchak knew his Creator, and so he could look within to find HaShem. HaShem was there for both.

The Parsha begins with a recap of who Yitzchak and Rivka were, and the miracle of the birth of Ya'akov and Esau. Of their birth, the Torah says, Bereishet 25:22, And the children crushed to which Rashi comments, You must say that this verse says, Expound me, because [the verse] remained vague what this crushing is, yet it writes, If so, why is it that I am? Our Rabbis expounded it as meaning running. When she [Rivka] would pass by the entrances to Torah [study] of Shem and Eber, Ya'akov would run and toss about to go out. She would pass by entrances of idol worship, Esau would toss about to go out. Alternatively, they were struggling with one another and fighting over the inheritance of two worlds[, this world and the World to Come]. Many are the verses in the Written Torah that requires the Oral Torah that the Rabbis/Sages of Old used to expound the verse upon. This is one of the more obvious spots for it, but in truth, all verses can be expounded upon by the Oral Torah. For there is many, many levels and layers to Torah, for it is Divine Wisdom gifted to us.

That Ya'akov and Esau, even in the womb, goes to show us that ever child has traits and characteristics from their parents (and their parents), for Ya'akov and Esau were physically identical twins, and yet, their personalities were opposites, Ya'akov gravitated to HaShem and Esau tried to distance himself from HaShem. Both had the same DNA, the same teaching, and the same options, and yet, the two went there separate ways, Ya'akov for Torah study and Esau for idol worship. Two identical starting points and two different outcomes. Esau was the acknowledged first-born, which in those days, was the priest of the family, and as the Torah says, Bereishet 25:34, Ya'akov gave Esau bread and lentil stew, and he ate and drank, gout up and left; and Esau belittled the birthright. To which Rashi comments, And Esau belittled The verse testifies to his wickedness, that he belittled the service of the Omnipresent. And yet, when presented with the opportunity, Ya'akov grabbed the acknowledged rights for the first-born, wanting to server HaShem.

To show that Yitzchak, while embodying Strength, unlike his father's Kindness, still followed Abraham's ways, the Torah says, Bereishet 26:18, And Yitzchak returned and he dug the wells of water which they had dug in the days of Abraham his father and which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham's death; and he them them by the same names that his father had called them. So even though, he followed his own style, Yitzchak still followed after HaShem as his father, Abraham, did.

It was Yitzchak that first felt antisemitism that has been around ever since, for the Torah tells us, Bereishet 26:16, And Avimelech said to Yitzchak, Go away from us, for you have become much mightier than we! Thus, antisemitism did not start with the Land of Israel, but with those that were jealous of blessings that HaShem bestowed upon us.

Even after Yitzchak complied, there were still antisemitism, for that which is irrational can not be understood or justified. For Yitzchak, this continued with the wells that Yitzchak dug as mentioned in Bereishet 26:19-22. The first two wells were quarreled over but the third (and final) well no one quarreled over it. This is a bit strange to have in the Torah, our book of instructions/teachings. What is this telling us? Of the many things, our Sages say that these wells that Yitzchak dug can be liken to the Holy Temple which once stood and will stand again on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. The first two wells were quarreled over and destroy, much like the first two Holy Temples where as well. And such as the third well held no quarrel, so too will the third Holy Temple will remain. Thus, our fore-father Yitzchak has some links/connections with Mosiach as our other fore-fathers do.

I leave to the Rabbis' sermons/teachings about the Yitzchak's blessings to Ya'akov and Esau.

I will note that even the wicked Esau, who did not seem to believe in the spiritual/religious, wished to be blessed by his father, so there is some Jewish spark within even Esau, who was born a Jew, and yet spent his life with idol worship. It is Yitzchak's blessing to Esau that the famous phrase comes from, Bereishet 27:40, By your sword you shall live[..] As one lives, so do they die.

The Parsha ends with Yitzchak sending Ya'akov off to his brother-in-law's house/land to seek a wife, and thus Esau tries to do the same, but in Esau's own wicked way. Thus, you have Ya'akov following the letter and spirit of the law from Yitzchak, while Esau twists the mere words to suit his purposes. So even though Ya'akov and Esau seeks wives for themselves, Ya'akov does it with Holiness and Esau does it with wickedness.

And yet, in the Days of Mosiach, there will be a reconciliation between the two brothers and their descendents. And may that day come soonest and swiftest.

entry.title: Parsha Chayei Sarah
entry.content:
''
Nov 7, 2012 / 5773 Cheshvan 22 / ''

Parsha Chayei Sarah /
Bereishet 23:1 25:18
Translation Source: Rashi Chumash: Sapirstein Edition

This week's Parsha is called Chayei Sarah, which is translated to The life of Sarah and yet the Parsha talks of her passing and of her son, Yitzchak, getting married. The obvious question is, how is this life? Especially, the life of one of the Prophetess and the very first Matriarch of the Jewish Nation.

The answer is, I think, can be found in an old ((c)1978) Safam song called, Only for the Children/Ariel's Song, written by Joel Sussman (of Safam), in which the chorus goes,
Only for the children do we live,
Only through the children can we give,
Only for tomorrows that they bring
Can our lives mean anything, I pray,
The children are our future here today.

And for Yitzchak is the purpose and goal of Sarah and Abraham. It for the children, our future, do we live. All the sacrifices our parents made was for us, so that we, the Children of Abraham, Yitzchak, and Ya'akov can grow and keep Judaism alive. For our children are our futures.

It was for Yitzchak's sake that Sarah had Hagar and Ishmael dismissed from Abraham's household. It was for Yitzchak's sake that Abraham sent Eliezer back to the lands of Abraham's father household to find a wife for Yitzchak. For it was Rivka that would give birth to the twins, Ya'akov Avenu and Esau.

The burial site that Abraham Avenu purchased was the Cave of Machpelah, which still exists today in Chevron, Israel. As Rashi points out, The cave was called by this name because it consisted of a lower floor with an upper floor on top of it. Alternately, because it is doubled with couples. The couples buried within the Cave of Machpelah are: Adam and Chavah/Eve, Abraham and Sarah, Yitzchak and Rivka, and Ya'akov and Leah. You can go there today, and there are chambers dedicated to each of the couples, although, off the top of my head, I don't recall seeing the chamber for Adam and Chavah/Eve. But the chambers for Abraham and Sarah and for Ya'akov and Leah, are easily accessible. Unfortunately, the chambers for Yitzchak and Rivka, which I believe contains the actual opening to the actual underground Cave, is not accessible because of the Muslims.

It is ironic that Abraham brought the Cave of Machpelah and its surrounding lands outright, so that none would contest his ownership of the Land, and as King David brought the land for Jerusalem, and yet, these lands which there should be no questions, are questioned by so many.

It is my understanding that many, in Israel and other places, have a custom to specifically visit the Cave of Machpelah on this Shabbat of Parsha Chayei Sarah. I wish I could afford to do that. Or even better, merit to live in Chevron.

I take comfort that when Mosiach comes, I and all the People, will be able to visit the Cave of Machpelah and with the Resurrection of Dead, speak with those that were once buried there. And we will rejoice with Adam and Chavah/Eve, Abraham and Sarah, Yitzchak and Rivka, and Ya'akov and Leah and Rachel. And we will tell them of the miracles and mercy that HaShem has given us since their passing and in their merits. May those days come quickest and soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Vayeira
entry.content:
''
November 1, 2012 / 16 Cheshvan 5773 / ''

Parsha Vayeira /
Bereishet 18:1 22:24
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash, Margolin Edition; Rashi, Silbermann Edition

The Parsha is entitled Vayeria (), which is translated to appear, as the Parsha opens, Bereishet 18:1, The Eternal appeared to [Abraham] at Elonei[...]. What does it mean that HaShem appeared to Abraham? Of course, only Abraham, himself, can tell us, which he will/can do after the resurrection of the dead. But until then, we are left with the question what does it mean? After all, this is not the first time that HaShem has spoken to Abraham. This is happening, as our Sages say, on the third day after HaShem had commanded Abraham to circumcise himself and his household. So what is different?

The only difference is that Abraham, on HaShem's commandant, had circumcised himself, to which, the Torah called Abraham, perfect. It was on HaShem's commandant for Abraham to leave his father's household and journey to what would be, and is, the Holy Land, so it was not the first commandant that HaShem gave him. But it was one that altered the relationship between HaShem and Abraham Avinu ( ). For it was the covenant of the circumcision that started it all. So HaShem appeared to Abraham, we don't know how this was done, but we know why. The why Rashi points is in order to visit the sick. Rabbi Chama the son of Chanina said: It was the third day after his circumcision, and the Holy One, Source of Blessing, came and asked after his well-being. Thus we are taught about the mitzvah of visiting the sick. Which can give us a bit of insight in HaShem's appearance. In the mitzvah of visiting the sick, one pays a personal visit, to be seen and see another who is sick. Ideally, when one visits the sick they should do so in an uplifting manner.

In what uplifting manner did HaShem do on his visit to the recovering Abraham? The Holy One, Blessed be He, sent three angels, disguised as men, to visit Abraham so that Abraham could perform his hospitalities, for which was Abraham's defining characteristic. For it pained our Fore-father Abraham not to have guesses, so to uplift Abraham's spirits, as one does for a sick person, HaShem sent three angels. Why three angels? Our Sages tell us that an angel can only perform one task/mission. And these three had three missions: mission one, tell of Issac's upcoming birth; mission two, to save Lot from Sedom; and mission three, to destroy Sedom.

HaShem could have skipped the angels and merely told Abraham outright about the upcoming birth of Issac, but He understand Abraham and sent an angel so that Abraham could perform his act of kindness of hospitality. So one should take into consideration of the nature of the sick person they are visiting as HaShem did. So that the visit should be beneficial to the sick person.

Another lesson in this week's portion is keeping the peace, as Rashi remarks to the words of Bereishet 18:13, For I am old., Rashi says, The verse altered for the sake of peace, for she had said, for my master is old. Thus, HaShem, Himself, chose His words to maintain the peace between husband and wife. For one like Abraham, called perfect by HaShem, Himself, needs to alter his words to maintain peace between husband and wife, how much more so for us mere mortals.

Bereishet 18:15, Sarah denied it, saying, I did not laugh, because she was afraid. [...] If our Fore-Mother, Sarah, the foundation/rock upon which the Jewish Nation was established upon, one of the seven known Prophetess, whose powers of prophecy exceeded that of her husband's, and just, she lied to HaShem because she was afraid. And yet, Abraham himself had laugh as well. The difference such as it was, is that Abraham laughed in joy, while Sarah laughed in disbelief. And why did Sarah disbelief? Actually, disbelief is probably not the correct word, rather, she had trouble understanding how they could have a children, when according the science of those days, said it was impossible and HaShem had done all that he had done within the confines of nature; Noach's Flood, while unusually was still natural in a sense. The Creation of the World, one can easily say that was the defining of nature, and the obvious starting point. What we have to understand that the Jewish Nation has always from its beginning been supernatural in its origin and ways. Which is why all four Fore-mothers did not have children in the conventional sense. But needed prayers and miracles to have their children. Even today, the Jewish Nation, only exists through HaShem's continuous mercy and special Divine Providence.

Another lesson, for Judges, the Parsha tells us, Bereishet 18:21, Let Me descend now and see, Rashi tell us, This teaches judges not to give rulings in cases involving capital punishment without [equivalent of] visual knowledge []

In defense of Sedom, Abraham, talks of groups of ten. Why ten? Our Sages tells us that Noach, his wife, his three sons, and three daughters-in-law, which is eight, were not enough to save their world, only themselves. Even counting HaShem it would have only been nine, so that is why Abraham, learning from Noach, used ten for his arguments, first ten in each city, for a total of fifty. And then Abraham talked HaShem down to see if not ten per city. Alas, for Sedom and the other four cities, there was none righteous but Lot, his wife, and two daughters. And even then, Lot's wife wasn't that righteous and was turned to salt. For such was the corruption and sin of Sedom that it spread like a cancer, and like a cancer, the only solution is to remove it.

And remove it, HaShem did. Bereishet 19:24, Had rained down... on Sedom Rashi comments, at dawn, as it says, When the dawn broke (v15) a time when the moon is in the sky together with the sun. [] Therefore, it is written, when dawn broke that He punished them at the time when the sun and moon rule. So that the sun-worshipers nor the moon-worshipers could claim against HaShem. For such is the nature of humans that we will try to justify that which we don't wish to acknowledge.

For HaShem judges us and the world, measure for measure, as it is said, Bereishet 19:26, and she was became a pillar of salt. Rashi comments, She sinned with salt, so she was punished with salt. [Lot] would ask her, Give a little salt to these guests, [and] she would answer him, Even this evil custom you are going to introduce in this place. Hospitality, the cornerstone of civilization, was considered evil in Sedom, can it be any wonder why it was destroyed?

And out of all this, two nations, born from Lot and his daughters, came about, Mo'av and Ammon. Ruth, the grandmother of King David and Mosiach was a descendant of Mo'av. So even in the destruction of Sedom, the seed of the final redemption was planted, with the birth of Mo'av.

Another lesson, Abraham said, Bereishet 20:11, There is no reverence of G-d, to which, Rashi said, A guest who arrives in town does one ask him about [his requirement of] food and drink, or does one ask him about his wife, Is she your wife or your sister? Such we see how unG-dily, many of the nations of those days were, to various degrees. Bereishet 20:15, My land is here before you. Rashi remarks about this, but Par'oh said to him, Here is your wife take [her] and go! (12:19), because he was afraid [for Sarah's safety] since the people of Mitzrayim were steeped in immorality.

Another lesson, Bereishet 21:1, The Eternal had taken account of Sarah Rashi comments, This passage is placed next to [the previous one] to teach you that a person who pleads for mercy for his fellowman and he [himself] is in need of this same thing, he is answered first, for it says, [Abraham] prayed... (20:17), and it is followed by: The Eternal has taken account of Sarah [i.e.] He had already taken account of her before he cured Avimelech.

Side note, our Sages say that Avimelech is a title like Par'oh.

Another lesson, Bereishet 21:17, the boy's voice, Rashi comments, From here [we learn] that a sick person's [own] prayer is more effective than other people's prayer for him, and it is accepted before [theirs].

A lesson for Rosh HaShana and Yom Kippur, Bereishet 21:17, There, where he is, Rashi comments, according to his present deeds he is being judged and not according to his future deeds. For the ministering angels were incriminating [him], saying, Master of the world! For him, whose descendants in the future will kill Your children by thrist, You are goingn to provide a well! He replied to them, What is he now: righteous or evil? They answered Him, He is righteous. He said to them, I judge him according to his present deeds.[...] Like Ishmael, we are judged as we are, not on what he might do wrong in the future that HaShem knows we will do.

The Parsha ends with the Binding of Issac which I will leave for the Rabbis to discuss as there is so much to talk about within it. I point out that it took HaShem Himself to ask for something extra-ordinary, but a mere angel to restore. Our Sages count out the years and tells us that Issac was thirty when this happened. He was not a mere child, as several paints suggest, but a full-grown adult. Although, Issac was a willing participant, this was the tenth and final test of Abraham.

It was after the Binding, that the Torah tells us of the birth of Rivkah, Issac's intended wife.

So in many (all) cases, we see that HaShem guides the World and us. And may He guide us by bringing the final redemption with Mosiach, to bring final and total peace to the World, soonest in our days.

entry.title: Parsha Lech Lecha
entry.content:
''
Oct 24, 2012 / 5773 Cheshvan 8 / ''

Parsha Lech Lecha /
Bereishet 12:1 17:27
Translation Source: Chayenu Chumash: Margolin Edition; Rashi: Silbermann Edition


Our Sages say that from Adam HaReshon ( ) to Noach there were ten generations, and from Noach to Abraham Avenu ( ) there was ten generations. The first ten got worse and worse, and the next ten brought things back to the original levels.

Some points for the Parsha:

Point the first, Rashi comments on the opening words, Bereishet 12:1, Go for yourself, [means go] for your own benefit and for your own good. There I will make you into a great nation, [but] here you will not merit having children. [...] From here, we learn that one can change one's fate through changing one's location/going into exile. The other two, which come later, are changing one's name (nature) and Teshuvah ().

Point the second, the Prophets know of what is to come. Bereishet 12:6, [Traveling] as far as the site of Shechem, Rashi comments, in order to pray for the children of Ya'akov, when they would come to fight against Shechem.

Point the third, what happened to our Forefathers, reflects our own journeys through life. Just as Abraham had to descend down to Mitzrayim, so too, do we have our own descendents and ascensions as well. What was Mitzrayim? The Torah relates Abraham telling his wife, Sarah, Bereishet 12:12, It will be when the Mitzrim see you, they will say, This is his wife, and they will kill me and keep you alive. That was the way of Mitzrayim; murder, kidnapping and rape. That Abraham's planning and HaShem interference prevented it to a degree, does not underscore the nature of Mitzrayim. To avoid adultery, they resorted to murder. To avoid the woman's choice, she was not given one. So what happened in Sefer Shemot ( ) is not so much a surprise, given their immoral ways.

The word mitzrayim comes from the word for restraint. We all fall into various restraints and immoral decisions, but like Abraham, we can by staying true to Torah (and with HaShem's help), we can overcome the Mitzrayim of the world and even benefit from them as it is said, Bereishet 13:2, Avram was heavily laden with livestock, silver, and gold.

Point the fourth, Bereishet 13:3, He went on his journeys. to which Rashi states, When he returned from Mitzrayim to the land of Kena'an, he stated in the [same] lodging-places as he had stayed on his way to Mitzrayim. This teaches you correct behavior, that a man should not change his lodging-place. Another explanation: On his way back he repaid his debts. This is one of the very reasons why we are told the lives of our Forefathers, to teach our correct behavior. For that is what the Torah is, instructions on how to life a meaningful, righteous life.

Point the fifth, we are introduced to Sedom and its people, with the war of the five kings against the four kings, and Abraham's saving his nephew, Lot, from the powerful, four kings. Yet, Abraham did not wave or tarry in helping family.
Point the sixth, Bereishet 13:18, And Malki Tzedek, the king of Shalem to which Rashi says, The Aggadic explanation is that he was Shem, the son of Noach. In honor of both Shem and Abraham, we get the name Jerusalem. Also that Shem lived into the times of Abraham, in fact, he lived into the days of Ya'akov Avenu ( ). Shem had a Yeshiva, so that there was a line of tradition that started at the very beginning with Adam that was passed down to Shem and Shem passed down to others, including Abraham and Ya'akov. So there were records (of some sort) of first-hand accounts of what had happened before.

Point of the seventh, the importance of children for Abraham said to HaShem, Bereishet 15:2, Avram responded, My Lord, Eternal G-d! What is [the benefit of] what You have give me [if] I am going to be obliterated[...]? Why was Abraham headed towards oblivion? Because, Bereishet, 15:3, [...] To me You have not given a child[...] Why did Abraham say this? Because the science of those days, said that Avram could not have children. What was HaShem's response? Bereishet 15:5, [The Eternal] tool him outside[...] to which Rashi replies, According to the Sages and Rashi, HaShem took Abraham outside of the natural world so that HaShem lifted him above the stars,and thus the word looking downward from above. Thus it has been since the beginning of the Jewish People, with our Forefather Abraham, we, Jews, are something super-rational/super-natural. The sciences of the day can correctly predict one thing about us, but HaShem will decree another. The other nations are bound by the sciences, not so with the Jews. We are bound up in HaShem, himself.

Point of the eight, such is the way of Righteous: Rashi comments upon Bereishet 16:1, A Mitzri maidservant She was the daughter of Par'oh (the King of Mitzrayim). When he saw the miracles performed for Sarah, he said, It is better that my daughter be a maidservant in this house, than be a lady in another man's house. Better for a daughter of the King of an immoral nation to be a maidservant in the House of the Righteous, than to be the wife of another.

This is said of Abrahams house, how much more so can be said of Mosiach, which includes all of our fore-fathers, fore-mothers, the Judges, Kings, and Prophets? May we see, soonest, the fulfillment of the coming of Mosiach, when nations will serve HaShem, all together in peace and harmony.

entry.title: Parsha Noach
entry.content:
''
Oct 17, 2012 / 5773 Cheshvan 1 / ''

Parsha Noach /
Bereishet 6:9 11:32
Translation Source: Chumash Margolin Edition; Rashi Silbermann Edition

This week's Parsha is Parsha Noach, about the Flood, the tower of Babel, and introduction to Abraham. Many, many Sages and commentators have written about the Flood, the whys, the hows, the whens, the wheres, etc., so I do not wish to spend too much time upon it. I do wish to point out a few things about the Flood.

First, the Flood, itself, was not just water, but much more. Rashi points out in Torah's statement that the Ark was made from Gofer Wood (Bereishet 6:14), That is its name. And why of this type? Because its name ( ) resembles sulfur, by which it was decreed that they were to be wiped out. Bereishet Rabbah (27:3) makes a connect between the Flood and Sedom, saying just as Sedom was wiped out by sulfur and fire, so too was the generation of the Flood, and as the generation of the Flood was wiped out by water, so too was Sedom. For HaShem said, Bereishet 7:4, [...] I shall wipe out all beings that I made, from off the face of the earth. So there was boiling (fiery) water, sulfur, and other stuff involved.

Second, the Flood covered the entire Earth, completely. In fact, the Torah says, Bereishet 7:19-20, (19)The waters swelled tremendously high over the earth, so that all the high mountains which are beneath the entire heavens were covered. (20)The waters swelled fifteen cubits higher [than where] the mountains were covered. According to The Practical Talmudic Dictionary by Yitzhak Frank, a cubit is equal to approximately 48 cm/18.9 inches to 57.6 cm/22.7 inches, to average it out, let us say a cubit is 20 inches. Fifteen times twenty is 300 inches, or 25 feet (approximately). According to Wikipedia, the tallest mountain on Earth is Mount Everest, which is 29,029 feet tall. So we are talking about the water level being around 29,054 feet above sea level. That's a body of boiling water five and half miles above the surface of the Earth. So not only do you have all that sulfur, heat, but water pressure as well. And won't you know it, a way to fake the date of something is to heat it and apply pressure to it. Which is why any dating before the Flood is suspect. Also, the Flood lasted for an entire year, start to finish.

Third, the Flood did not affect the fish (sea-life), as it says, Bereishet 7:22, Every being that had the breath of the spirit of life in ts nostrils, of all those on dry land, died. To which Rashi replies, but not the fish in the sea. So the fish, through HaShem's Mercy, survived through the sulfur, boiling water, and five additional miles of water-pressure.

Fourth, our Sages are unsure if the Universe was frozen or ceased to exist during the Flood as Rashi points that It was called Flood () [...] because it put everything into confusion ().[...] As it was a time of confusion, everything including the universe; Sun. Moon, and the Stars. Either side have implications that should be considered.

Fifth, although the Torah would not be giving for another two thousand or so years, Rashi points out Noach knew of the laws/concepts of the Torah as verse Bereishet 7:2 uses the word pure, to which, he comments, which in the future will be pure for Israel. We learn [from the fact that he was requested to discern which were the pure animals] that Noach learned Torah. In fact, Adam HaReshon, also learned Torah, as did our Fore-fathers, and the Tribes. Which they in turn passed on to their children. They also kept, as a personal tradition, all of the Torah concepts.

Sixth, the Talmud interprets Bereishet 9:9, I [HaShem] am going to set up My covenant with you and and with your descendents after you; that the covenant that HaShem established was the Seventh Noachide Laws, which are (1) believe in HaShem, (2) do not curse HaShem, (3) do not murder, (4) do not commit adultery or incest, (5) do not steal, (6) establish just courts/law system, and (7) do not eat the flesh from a living animal. The Sages say that the first six were told to Adam HaReshon, and repeated to Noach, with the addition of the seventh. These Seven Noachide Laws are incumbent upon all of humanity, even now, and these are the foundation upon which any civilization is founded upon.

In the seventh aliyah, the Torah tells us about the Tower of Bavel, which starts with, Bereishet 11:1, The whole world [spoke] one language and was of a united cause. Rashi comments on the Biblical words, and of a united cause, saying, They decided on one plan and said, He has no right to select the heavens for Himself. Let us ascend to the sky and wage war with Him. Another explanation: about the Unique One of the World. Another explanation: They said, Once every 1,656 years the skies collapse, as they did during the Flood. Let us make support for them. (The Flood occurred in the Year 1,656, hence the every...)

The first part of the reason for the Towel of Bavel does not surprise me, unfortunately. But when I first read that Rashi comment, how many people thought the Flood was a natural occurrence that surprised me.

But alas, such as repeated itself many times over, even in our own days, when we should know better. How many G-dly events that are happening now, are attributed to nature or even so-called Mother Nature is somehow divorced from HaShem?

Rashi makes in an interesting comment in regards to Bereishet 11:9, [..] and from there [He] dispersed them.. Rashi says to this, This teaches that they have no portion in the World to Come. Which [sin] was greater: [that] of the generation of the Flood or [that] of the generation of the Dispersion? The former did not raise their hands against HaShem, but the later did raise their hands against HaShem to wage war against Him; yet the former were drowned, but the later were not exterminated from [this] world. The generation of the Flood were thieves and there was strife among them, there they were destroyed, whereas [the generation of the Dispersion] behaved with mutual love and friendship, as it says, one language and was of a united cause. [From this] you learn [how] hated [by HaShem] is strife and [how] great is peace. Thus we learn why for seemingly similar sins, the two generations were punished differently.

Such was the punishment for that sin, but image what would occur if we all came together as they did in those days, but for true peace and for HaShem? Our Sages tells us that the reward greatly exceeds the punishment, one can but imagine the reward, if we only put worked together in one language and a united cause for HaShem.

Such it will be in the days of Mosiach, we will be one language and a united cause, in keeping with the Ways of HaShem. Who knows what a completely unified humanity could accomplish?

May we found out in our lifetime.

entry.title: Parsha Bereishet
entry.content:
''
Oct 11, 2012 / 5773 Tishrei 25

Parsha Bereishet /
Bereishet 1:1 6:8
Translation Source: Chumash Margolin Edition; Rashi Silbermann Edition

Rashi, Rebbanu Shlomo (ben) Yitzhaki, one of the greatest commentator on the Torah and Talmud, lived in year 4800 (1040 Common Era) to 4865 (1105 C.E.), whose self-stated goal of his commentary is to talk only about the literal meaning of the verses. Rashi's style is to quote a biblical word/phrase and then his comments follow it. This was done because originally Rashi would write his comments on a simple slip of paper, so the biblical word/phrase was needed to tie it together. Thus, Rashi very first comment on Parsha Bereishet is: IN THE BEGINNING OF. Rabbi Yitzchak said: The Torah needs only have begun with: This month is for you (Shemos 12:2), which is the first commandment given to Yisrael. For what reason then, does it begin with Bereishet? Because: The strength of His actions He told to His people, so as to give them the inherited land of the nations (Tehillim 111:6) for it the nations of the world were to say to Yisrael, You are bandits because you conquered the lands of the seven nations, they would answer them, The entire earth belongs to the Holy One, Source of Blessing; He created it and gave it to whom He saw fit. When He wanted, He gave to them, and when He wanted, He took it away from them and gave it to us. Which is very interesting, it's not an explanation of the verse/word itself, but on the entire book of Bereishet itself. Why start here, when the word torah means instruction/guide. The Torah is not a history book, in that it does not care only of what happened and when, but it comes to instruct us of HaShem and His ways that we are to follow. Everything within the Torah is true and accurate, but not necessarily in historic order, as connectivity between events is more important that chronology that a history book would focus on. In truth, the Torah is the word of HaShem given form for us to understand and learn from.

So why did the great Rashi, who lived nine hundred years ago, begin his comments thus? There are many that write of this, more scholarly than I, but this exercise to work upon my thoughts so here some are.

This very day, there are many that question the right of Israel to exist and reclaim our land. This was known then and before, and has been forgotten in many circles today. It our land, not because of force of arms or weight of history, as other lands have been taken. The Land of Israel is the place of Israel solely because HaShem has decreed it. There is no other reason. The Creator of All, Himself, has decided who goes where, and who gets what, when. And He has sworn that the Land of Israel will be the eternal inheritance of the Children of Abraham, Yitzchak, and Jacob. Other lands change hands upon being conquered that is the way of the world, even today. And yet, the Land of Israel, regardless of who may conquer it, will always remain its connection to Israel, simply because the Holy One, blessed He be, decided before creation how the world would flow and as a Captain set the course for the world.

This is a very important point in Judaism, it is HaShem who is the architect of All and the ultimate source of everything. We all owe HaShem for everything. He is the maker and the shaper of all. Of course, since the Torah is not a history book, the account (for a lack of a better term) of Creation, could have been told later, as a note to when HaShem promised the Land to Abraham, or when HaShem took us out of Egypt. But the HaShem started His Torah with the account of Creation. I should note as many others before me have, in which, the account of Creation within the Torah is only the highlights, all the hows are missing, the whys are hidden within the text, the wheres are known to a degree, and the whats and whichs are mentioned in passing. There is a lot going on within the accounting of Creation, which many commentators remark on. I've touched one point and could spend more time on this, but do wish to get the rest of the Parsha. I have many occasion spent most of my time here, within the mysteries, and not on the later parts of the Parsha.

In the accounting of Creation, Bereishet 1:4, [...] It became evening and became morning, one day. Rashi poses a question on this, why one day, when the others are second, third, etc., why not first day? Rashi answers, the Holy One, Blessed Be He, was the Sole Being in His Universe. In other words, the first day of Creation was in fact the Day of One, the One is HaShem. This teaches that HaShem needs no helpers or anyone else nor is He lacking in anything, in anyway. HaShem, alone, is the sole complete being in the universe.

Interesting of note to me, is that it was not until the fourth day that the Sun and the Moon were positioned for day and night, thus, no one can say how long the first three days were, for we don't have any measurement to use, for the rotation of the planets has not come into being until this point.

Which is another interesting note that the commentators point out, in many cases, the Torah only tells us that HaShem positioned something, implying that it was in fact created earlier. In fact, in Kabbalah, to my understanding, teaches that in fact, everything was created in an instant and HaShem took some time-that's-not-time-beyond-human-understanding to plan out everything and then took six days to place everything just right.

For the Torah records that Adam HaReshon ( ), was created last upon the Sixth Day, and yet, he/we are the goal of All of Creation. The Sages give two reasons for this; one to humble mankind, for even the lowly gnat processed us in the order of Creation, and two, to show proper conduct as one should set the table before inviting a guest over. Every piece of Torah is an precious jewel of Divine knowledge to improve ourselves.

Chapter two of the Book of Bereishet goes into a bit more details in the formation of Mankind. Interesting of note is that Mankind alone is made differently then the rest, as well as, Mankind has his feet on the Earth, while his head is in Heaven, in that we have two parts/missions; one in the physical and one in the spiritual. For HaShem is known as Maker of Heavens and the Earth, for the One created both, the Heavens, the spiritual, and the Earth, the physical. So that we should not think that although they were created separately, what happens in one affects the other, and the other affects the one.

The biblical verse Bereishet 2:23 [...] This one will be called a woman, for this one was taken from a man. To which, Rashi replies, One word () is derived from the other (). From this [we can learn] that the world was created in the Holy Tongue (). Also of note, and I think I got it from Rashi but can't currently find the passage, the two words for man () and woman () share two common letters, Alef () and Shin (), which spells a word aish () which means fire. The other two letters, Yod () and Hay () spell out a name of HaShem. From this the Sages say, if there is no G-d(liness) among man and woman, there is only fire. For it takes all three, HaShem, man and woman to form a child. I think the parts would be HaShem, the Soul, the Man, the Mind, and the Woman, the Body. But the boundaries between the three, Soul, Mind, and Body are not known so I can't say for sure. Man/Woman could have been named for other things, why fire? The Sages have many things to say to that, but this is what I say, for fire is unique among the classic elements, fire alone seeks upwards, it has no weight but its energies are unmistakeable, its passage is easily seen, and fire can be useful or harmful.

Chapter four talks of the next generation, the children of Adam and Chavah, and tells us of their ways. And continues with Kayin's descendents. Also mentioned in this chapter, Bereishet 4:22, [...] and Taval Kayin's sister was Na'amah. Rashi points out on this, She was Noah's wife. Na'amah was one of Kayin's descendents, while Noah, himself, was a descendent of Shes (Adam's third son).

Chapter Five talks of the descendents of Adam ending with Noah and his children.

Chapter Six tells us of what lead up to Noah's flood, which is next week's Parsha.

One who reads Bereishet should come from it with a sense that the World was not created by accident, but through Divine Wisdom. There is no chance, but the Divine. Alas, now there are falsehoods in the world, so we may choice between Life and Death, and when Mosiach comes, may it be speedily in our days, we will see clearly all that HaShem has done for us.

entry.title: Parsha Vzos HaBeracha
entry.content:
''
Oct 4, 2012 / 5773 Tishrei 18

Parsha Vzos HaBeracha /
Devarim 33:1 34:12

Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash Margolin Edition, Rashi Silbermann Edition

This Shabbat () we will be reading the Portions of Shabbos Chol Hamoed Sukkot ( ), which is: Torah Reading, Shemot 33:12 34:26; Maftir, Bamidbar 29:26-31; and Haftarah, Ezekiel 38:18 39:16.

We will be reading this Parsha, Parsha Vzos Haberacha, on Simcha Torah ( ). This is the last Parsha of Devarim, which is the last book of the Five Books of Moses. Upon completion of this Parsha we begin immediately into Parsha Bereshet. For like life, the Torah is a cycle. The Torah is also liken to an onion, there are many, many layers one can find within the Torah, and the deeper one goes, the more one finds.

I had originally started this to go over the weekly Parsha that I was/am studying for the week and read upon Shabbat. On Shabbat, there are seven aliyahs. For the record, Shabbat has seven aliyahs, Yom Kippur has six aliyahs, the week-day Yamim Tovim ( ) has five aliyahs. Plus, an additional aliyah called Maftir. The person called up for Maftir also says the Haftarah.

Still although it won't be read this Shabbat, I am studying it, hence this entry. :)

Upon reading this Parsha, I am immediately struck by it's name, Vzos Haberacha, which means and this (is) the blessing. The And/v () is obvious, as this is a continuation of Moses Rebbanu ( ) final words to his beloved People. And in actuality, not only is this a continuation it actually it's conclusion. But my thoughts aren't on that so much as the fact that the Torah uses the single form Beracha () not Berachot (). After all, Moses gave each of the 12 tribes of Israel a blessing. So that should be 12 blessings, plural, given to each of the twelve tribes, not a single blessing. Interesting enough, Rashi does not comment on this. Meaning that it can be understood in the literal sense, with some work.

So let's review a bit to see if we can figure this out for ourselves.

To begin with, in the very first verse, Devarim 32:1, Moses is addressed as a man of G-d or in Hebrew Eish HaElokim ( ). As you may or may not know, HaShem has many, many names and yet as we say every morning, Harken O' Israel, HaShem is our G-d and HaShem is one. So why are their so many names for HaShem? The reason I knew of, and there are probably many more that I don't know of, is that each name of HaShem reflects a different understanding of G-d and refers to different aspects of the truly Infinite that is HaShem. The two common names for HaShem are, HaShem and Elokim. HaShem is a protection for the four-letter name of G-d, which we do not pronounce at all, that denotes His Mercy and transcendentalism, while Elokim, denotes G-d's Justice and working as what we think of as nature As we will read on Simcha Torah and the following Shabbat in Parsha Bereishet, HaShem originally started the creation of the world with His aspect of Elokim, but knowing Mankind would need Mercy, adding HaShem/Four-Letter name, denoting such mercy. And yet, here, Moses Rebbanu is called a man of Elokim.

The first aliyah is the introduction of Moses's final blessings to the people of Israel, in which he praises the Source of Blessings. In his praises, Moses mentions an important verse, Devarim 33:4, The Torah [that] Moses commanded us is a heritage [for] congregation of Ya'akov. Meaning that no Jew can say that s/he alone does the Torah belong, but rather that it belongs to all of us.

After Moses praising HaShem, Moses blesses each tribe, much as our Forefather Ya'akov did. Moses begins with the tribe of Re'uven, the firstborn of the Foremother Leah. From Re'uven to the tribe of Yehudah. Why the transition is discussed by Rashi and various commentators.

The second aliyah starts off with the blessing for the Tribe of Levi. Glossing over details of the blessings, Moses when from the Tribe of Levi to the Tribe of Binyamin.

The third aliyah continues Moses blessings moving on to the Tribe of Yosef, mentioned Yosef's two sons, Efrayim and Menashe.

The fourth aliyah mentions the Tribes of Zevulun and Yissachar, again please check out Rashi and the commentators why they are mentioned together and what their blessings means. The Tribe of Gad is next.

The fifth aliyah the moves onto the Tribe of Dan, the Tribe of Naftali, and finally the Tribe of Asher.

In the sixth aliyah, Moses speaks again of HaShem's praise and what he will do for the Children of Israel, which seems to conclude Moses's blessing of the children of Israel.

The seventh aliyah tells us of the passing of Moses as ordained by HaShem. The aliyah ends with Devarim 34:12, and regarding everything [carried out with his] strong hands, and everything [performed in] the fearful [and] great [desert], that Moses did in full view of all of Israel.

The final word of the Torah, the Five Books of Moses, is Israel (), and that I think is one of the reasons why it's blessing, singular, and not blessings, plural. For all there are twelve tribes of Israel, we are all the sons of Ya'akov/Israel. We are all one. Each tribe has it's own path to follow, ways of doing things, and personalities, but ultimately, we are all Israel. So really, Moses only gave one blessing, which just happened to have multiple parts to it. One can get easily lost in the analysis of each tribe's individual part of the blessing, but one has to remember, in the end, we are all parts of the whole.

Interesting enough, as I said, we begin again with Parsha Bereshet, which begins with the word Bereishet, which is usually translated as in the beginning. But in our continuation, we have Israel and then in the beginning. Our sages tells us, the ending is in the beginning and the beginning is in the ending. What are the beginning and ending of the Torah, Bereishet and Israel

May we see with our own eyes the end of this exile and the beginning of our redemption with the coming of Mosiach speedily in our days.

entry.title: Parsha Ha'azinu
entry.content:
B"H
Sept 28, 2012 / 12 Tishrei 5773

I am late with this, this week because of Yom Kippur and preparation for Shabbos and Sukkot. But here we go.

Parsha Ha'azinu
Devarim 32:1 - 52
Translation Source: Chumash -- Margolin Edition; Rashi -- Silbermann Edition

================================

This week's Parsha is the next to last Parsha in the Torah, and it contains the song that HaShem told Moses Rabbenu to tell the people. The "songs" within the Tanach are special, the Sages tell us that there has been nine songs sung to date, and the tenth song will be sang when Mosiach comes.

The first aliyah is the beginning to the song and talks of the greatness of HaShem and the foolishness of man.

The second aliyah is a recap of HaShem's kindness to the House of Israel. Interesting, the song says to Devarim 32:7, "ask your fathers[...]; your elders", and Rashi says that "these are the prophets who are termed fathers, as it is said Eliyahu (2 Kings 2:12), "My father, my father, the chariot of Israel." And Rashi also says, "your elders -- these are the sages." Taking the second first, that the elders and sages are the same should be obvious. The first, that the prophets are liken to the fathers is also a bit obvious, I would think, as like a father needs to look after his child(ren), so too does a Prophet look after the Children of Israel. Especially, as traditionally, it is the father that teaches his children education, both secular and spiritual. Thus, a prophet's job is also to educate the people about the spiritual. Prophets/fathers or elders/sages, either way, it is best to ask of those that were there or connected what happened before.

The third aliyah speaks of then future, after the settling of the land by Joshua son of Nun. The songs relates how all the prosperity that came from HaShem's blessing, that the blessings became too common and took for granted, which lead to the corruption that happened in the days of the Judges. All because the people forgotten that it was HaShem who is the source of all things.

The fourth aliyah speaks of HaShem's reaction to the peoples corrupt and abandonment of HaShem's Ways.

The fifth aliyah speaks the nations of the world will not recognize that HaShem is punishing His people.

The sixth aliyah speaks of HaShem's Justice, how those that in punishing the Jews will be called upon to answer for that which went beyond what was required for them to do. For Justice is mindful of those that take the opportunity and do evil with it. And HaShem will accept the people's teshuva.

The seventh aliyah Moses finished the song, gave a final warning, gave Joshua a speaker to show that Joshua was the new leader and heads to Moses's final rest. The Torah records, Devarim 32:48, "The Eternal then spoke to Moshes in broad daylight". Rashi remarks that the Torah only used some terminology in three places, Noah entering the Ark, the exile from Egypt, and Moses's death. For in all three times, the major of the people were against it, but HaShem's Will prevailed. The link among the three is discussed by the Sages. I will say that; by Noah, this reflected the entire world; by Egypt; this reflected the entire Jews; and by Moses; this reflected a single individual, and all three are the same, in each case, it shows that HaShem is HaShem, justice is justice, and others might think differently but they would be wrong. The Yom Tto of Sukkot is this coming Sunday night, and we will dwell within the Succah. May we merit to dwell in Mosiach's Succah with Moses Rebbanu, in a world of peace and joy.

entry.title: Parsha Vayelech
entry.content:
''
Sep 19, 2012 / 5773 Tishrei 3

Parsha Vayelech |
Devarim: 31:1 - 29
Translations: Chumash Margolin Edition; Rashi Silbermann Edition

This week's Parsha Vayelech (), deals with Moses Rabbenu's ( ) literally last days on Earth, as Rashi comments on Moses's saying Devarim 32:2, I am one hundred and twenty years old. And this Shabbat () is also Shabbat Shuvah ( ), the Shabbat () between Rosh Hashana ( ) and Yom Kippur ( ). So what does these two things have do with each other? For it is no coincidence that this happened.

I have been thinking on this and not really coming up with anything. But as I write this, I recall the very first verse of the Parsha, Devarim 31:1, Moshe then went and spoke these words to all Israel. This is the very day that Moses Rabbenu ( ) was going to past away, no ifs or buts, as it was a Divine Decree. And yet, ever the Jewish Leader, he goes out to the people and explains himself and what will happen. That is what a Jewish Leader truly is, he puts his people before himself.
