He could have just passed things on to Joshua son of Nun ( ), but he does what he can. He gives comfort to the people and instructs them.

The days between Rosh Hashana ( ) and Yom Kippur ( ) are called the Ten Days of Repentance. The actual word is Teshuvah , which actually means return for in Judaism repentance is returning to HaShem. This Shabbat () is about repentance/return, and the ultimate return to HaShem when the soul departs our bodies and returns to our Maker. Which is what Moses ultimately did. But, HaShem willing, our return needs not be so permanent. For all of Heaven, the mitzvah ()/commandments are to be done here on Earth.

So Moses was on his last day on the job as his first day, doing all he could to fulfill the commandments of HaShem, and passing on all that he could, when he could. So we do what we can to fulfill HaShem's commandments.

We can find instructions from Moses, upon his last days, for our Days of Repentance, ensured that the next generation was taken care of, he wrote a torah (for each tribe, our Sage say), and gave encouragement to the people. He did not have to say anything about the future, but Moses talks about the Shemittah year/Seven-Year cycle, at which a gathering of the people is to take place so that they may hear the words of the Torah. By saying this commandment at this time, Moses gave the people hope/guarantee that they would enter the Land and be able to call out this commandment.

Teshuvah () is about returning, which the Jewish People have done several times, and each time HaShem has taken us back, for HaShem knew that we would stray from His ways as He said to Moses, Devarim 31:16 [...] but this people will arise and stray after the gods of the nations of the land that they are entering among them, and they will forsake Me [....] and Devarim 31:21, It will then be, when many misfortunes and calamities befall them, that this song will testify as a witness before them, for it will not be forgotten by their descendents[...]

When misfortunes and calamities befall us, we shall know that it is HaShem, who is the Author of such and we are blessed that it will not be forgotten by us. If we but do Teshuvah (), blessing and fortune wait us. And how do we get to these blessings and fortunes, through Torah.

As Moses Rabbenu redeemed the People from Egypt, so to will Mosiach redeem us from this final Galus. In this time of Divine Mercy and earthly teshuva, may the final redemption come swiftly and speedily. 

May we spend Yom Kippur like Purim in Jerusalem with HaShem and Mosiach.

entry.title: Parsha Nitzavim
entry.content:
''
Sept 12, 2012 / 25 Elul 5772

Parsha Nitzavim
Devarim 29:9 30:30
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash Margolin Edition, Rashi Silbermann Edition

The Parsha begins (Devarim 29:9-10), (9)You, all, are standing today before the Eternal, your G-d; leaders of your tribes, your elders and officers, every man of Israel; (10)your small children and your wives, and proselytes who are within your camp from your wood choppers to your water drawers The commentators note that the previous Parsha talked about the curses, and this week's Parsha begins with you are standing as if to say even after all the curses, you are still standing, still existing in an upright. It has been over two thousand years we have been in Galus (), and yet we still are standing. Also of note to me, this verse speaks of you before HaShem, we are the same, whether we are leaders or water-drawers before HaShem. And yet, each of us, unique and special to HaShem, have different roles to fulfill among ourselves.

In the second aliyah, Moses says, Devarim 29:14, but with those who are standing here with us today, before the Eternal, our G-d, and those who are not here with us today. Rashi replies, with the generations that will be in future(i.e. Moshe is not referring to people who happened to be absent from the assembly, for its states, v 10, that all were present, You are standing this day all of you before HaShem. Which meant that our Souls were there. For Am Israel ( ) stretches from Abraham to Mosiach's coming and everyone in between. We are all interconnected with each other. Our children are our future and our elders are our past. Much like snow-flakes, each one is unique and on its own a beautiful, if small, object. But snow-flakes can accumulate into snow-balls or an avalanche.

The third aliyah talks about the individual and how he or she might hide among the groups of people, but Moses Rabbenu ( ) warns that HaShem will know and act against that individual. The aliyah ends with Devarim 29:28, The hidden are the Eternal, our G-d, but the blatant are you and our children's, so to carry out the words of this Torah. Meaning, that which is not hidden, we need to act upon, as the saying goes, no one is an island upon themselves, which is especially true of B'nai Israel ( ). What one individual does, truly affects us all in ways that we don't full understand. We can not say we are not warn, for that is what Moses Rabbenu is doing.

The fourth aliyah speaks of what happens after the sins and the curses have befallen us that HaShem will accept our teshuva () as the Torah says, Devarim 30:5, The Eternal, your G-d, will bring you to the land that your forefathers took possession of, and you will take possession of it, and He will do good to you and make you numerous, more than your forefathers. For that is the power of teshuva, it can uplift us higher than we were before we fell, to reach levels that our forefathers did not. This Parsha is read the Shabbos () before Rosh Hashana ( ), in which we stand in judgment. Each and every Rosh Hashana we stand before HaShem as our forefathers did, knowing that HaShem accepts our teshuva, for that comes from our hearts.

The fifth aliyah continues on that if we but do teshuva () and things will be well for us. The aliyah is relatively short, with only four verses within it, but they are powerful. For the talk about the power of teshuva and following the commandments of HaShem then blessing will follow.

The sixth aliyah states, Devarim 30:11, For these commandments that I am commanding you today they are not concealed from you nor are they far away. Not only are HaShem's commandments not concealed, they are shared with the world. Throughout history, others have looked upon the Jews and our Torah, and converted to Judaism for what they have seen. In our day and age, Judaism is all over the place through the internet, books, and our fellow Jews. As much as you put into your study, you shall take more of it.

The seventh aliyah contains the famous line, Devarim 30:15, Look, I have put before you today life, and the good, and death, and the evil. Or simply put, every human being has a choice, we can choice between life/good and death/evil. If we do good, which is following the ways of HaShem and His commandments, there will be life, but if we do evil, then death will result. For HaShem is the Source of Life, and if we (G-d forbid) depart from our source then we would wither away. The choice of good/evil isn't the choice of chocolate/vanilla, but rather, do we help our fellow man, or do we ignore him? And if we ignore him, how can we not be ignored in turn?

The Parsha began, you are standing, and yes, we are, for over three thousand years, we are standing, as Jews, and human beings created in the image of our Creator, following His ways. Mark Twain ended his article entitled, "Concerning The Jews," which was published in Harpers Magazine 1899 with, "All things are mortal but the Jew; all other forces pass, but he remains. What is the secret of his immortality?" That secret is no secret, for it is HaShem's mercy and our Torah that remain when so many other peoples and societies have passed us by. As Moses Rabbenu said, You are standing here today (Devarim 29:9), we are still standing, while others have fallen, for we have chosen Life and Good over Death and Evil, for we follow the ways of the Source of Life and are still standing today.

May we all be inscribed in the book of life for a sweet, joyful and good-fill year.
May Mosiach () come this year, if not soonest, so the verse of our Parsha may be fulled, Devarim 30:5, The Eternal, your G-d, will bring you to the land that your forefathers took possession of, and you will take possession of it, and He will do good to you and make you numerous, more than your forefathers.

Shana Tova Vemetukah ( )

entry.title: Parsha Ki Savo
entry.content:
''
September 6, 2012 /19 Elul 5772

Parsha Ki Savo
Devarim 26:1 29:8
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash Margolin Edition, Rashi Silbermann Edition

Last week's Parsha was Ki Seitzei/When you go out, and this week's Parsha is Ki Savo/When you come in. Last week's Parsha dealt with matters between Man and Man, and thus this week's Parsha deals with matters between Man and HaShem. For your fellow human being, you need to go out from where you were and actively help him/her. For HaShem though, you need only look within, for HaShem is everywhere, within and without. HaShem is with us in all that we do, whether we know it or not, whether we follow His Will knowingly or not, HaShem is there, so you need to just be, and you are with HaShem.

The first aliyah talks of the ritual of bring the first fruits () to the Holy Temple ( ). It is written that there was parades and festival-like events done in honor of the first fruits, amazing sight to see and be a part of, and will once again when Mosiach comes and HaShem builds the Third Temple. Fruits take care and effort to grow and ripen, but for the most part, it is HaShem that does most of the work. It is He that brings the rain, the sun, and the insects to pollinate the fruit. It is us that makes sure when there is little or no rain to get water from elsewhere. Everything that exists, belongs to HaShem, and yet, He only asks for the very first of the fruits, not all of them, only those that ripen first. The Torah does not give a minimum amount nor a maximum. The farmer would mark these fruits by tying a piece of straw/grass around the first fruits and then follow the procedure as given in the Parsha. Of course, one did not go to the Holy Temple empty-handed, the farmer and his family would offer a thanks-giving sacrifice and have a festive-meal there. Where else could one go and have a meal with the King of the Kings? For that was in part what the sacrifices were, sharing one's blessing with HaShem as one would invite a guest to a BBQ/family outing, for HaShem is a part of our family as any other member is, more so, for He is our Beginning and Originator of each and every one of us.

The second aliyah talks of the the tithes and their procedure. The first fruits went to the Holy Temple, while the first tithe went to the Cohenim () and the second tithe went to the poor or Leviyim () depending upon which year of the sabbatical year cycle it was. The tithing, unlike the first fruits, required a lot more direct human action. So there is more work on the farmer's part. Like the first fruits, given over to HaShem His share, so to with the tithes, whereas there is going over to the Cohenim (first tithe) and Poor/Leviyim(second tithe).

The third aliyah tells that following HaShem and His Ways will bring blessings and good-will for us. The good we do in this world, HaShem responds to for measure for measure ( ) from good flows good, and from bad flows bad. Thus, when we do HaShem's Will, HaShem blesses us.

The fourth aliyah states that upon entering the Land of Israel, they were to set up an altar to sacrifice to HaShem and set up write down the Torah upon stones. These stones held the Torah written in the seventy languages of mankind. Thus, anyone could understand what was written, regardless of their mother-tongue. Having done so, allows us to begin to study the Torah now.

The fifth aliyah has Moses Rabbenu ( ) talking about the blessings and curses said upon Mount Gerizim and Mount Eival. And yet, only the curses are recorded in the Torah. From them, we learn the blessings. But why do we have to learn the blessings for the curses, why not learn the curses from the blessings? The Sages have several answers for this question, but I am not they. My answer is this: it seems to me that human nature is such that we don't really pay as much attention to the blessings as much as we should. How often do we hear or say, have a good day. The phrase is wishing a blessing that the day should be good. We say it heartfelt and sometimes out of reflex but we don't, unfortunately, truly give it much thought. But if we hear, Watch out, don't trip on -- that gets our attention. So too, does the Torah get our attention with stating the curses, as example, Devarim 27:18 states, Cursed is he who misleads an undiscerning person, and the entire people shall say, Amen. It's something that could be done unintentionally, but because the Torah says, Cursed [...] We need to pay attention to that. We should be extra careful when giving advice to others, let we lead someone astray. The blessings we take for grant at times, but curses make sure you know what's going on. There is also the fact that the blessings can be learned from the curses, also tells us something, or suggests to us that from a curse a blessing can come. Like pulling a rabbit out of a hand, it's not so obvious how that can be, but with HaShem anything is possible.

The sixth aliyah talks about how small blessings lead into greater blessings, for HaShem's mercy exceeds his wraith. This aliyah also warns that if we don't follow the ways of HaShem, bad things will happen too, small bad following greater bad. Each more terrible than the one before. The Sages speak of these curses and bad tidings for not following the way of HaShem. And yet, after all those terrible/curse-ful things, all which has happened throughout our history, and yet, we are still here. For within those terrible curses, there are hidden blessings that have kept us going, for HaShem Himself is our heritage that can not be taken from us. Those curses were the result of our misdeeds, and we have, hopefully, learn from them. For when HaShem does anything, there are multiple reasons for it; if nothing else, as lesson for the present and instruction for the future.

The seventh aliyah reminds us of HaShem's mercy and loving-kindness in the desert and came to the place where the beginning of converting the land of Canaan into the Holy Land, the Land of Israel. Just as everything in the desert happened for a Divine Reason, so too, does everything happen to us for a Divine Reason. Our forefathers were worth of knowing some of the reasons. The Parsha ends with Devarim 29:8, You shall keep the words of this covenant and carry them out, so that you may achieve success in everything that you do. For when HaShem is with us, nothing is impossible.

And may the day come soonest when we can truly see HaShem fully with us as we will when Mosiach comes. On that day, we will see that the curses that befelled us truly were and there will be nothing but blessings for all to see.

entry.title: Parsha Ki Seitzei
entry.content:
BH
Aug 30, 2012 / 12 Elul 5772


Parsha Ki Seitzei
Devarim 21:10 25:19
Translation Source: Chayenu Chumash Margolin Edition

The name of this week's Parsha is Ki Seitzei which means when you go out. And the first aliyah speaks of what can happen after war with captives. Among these captives, a solder desires one of them as a wife, so the Torah tells of a process the soldier must follow to fulfill that desire. The wording of the process is such that one should realize that the Torah does not actually wish this, but the Creator of the human hearts knows His Creation and created a process so minimize what will take place.

It is not coincidence, but a point of lesson, that the very next paragraph speaks of two wives, one hated and one loved. And continues into a tragic set of events that logically will follow on the consequences of what will occur; hated wife will have the firstborn, who must retain his rights despite his mother's hated status, that hatred will reflected upon the child, which in turn will need such a child to dark end.

What this is telling us is that each of our consequences, regardless of their intent, will have consequences of their own. Which will have consequences and so on, and so on. Such is life, as the old saying goes, from a little seeds, might oaks are born. Good deeds bring more good deeds, and bad deeds the same. From a single moment of lust/passion on the battlefield, a chain of events can take place that will have eternal consequences.

The soldier of Israel, of those times, were those that knew they were sinless and fearless, else they would have left the battlefield when the Cohen who is anointed for war, gave his speech of such. And yet, on the battlefield itself, the evil inclination is able to tempt/lure this person astray.

To the modern man, this seems strange and inconceivable. But then the wars fought back then were much different than their modern day counterparts. Things were more primitive and involved than they are now. So a comparison between modern-day and then, is unjust.

Yet the warning is still valid. A moment of lust can have far reaching consequences, regardless of our original intentions.

From this, the second aliyah takes about returning lost objects, skipping the opening paragraph about the laws of hanging a convicted person. After four verses of lost objects, the Torah narrative speaks of cross-dressing for immoral purposes, then speaks of sending a mother bird away when you collect the eggs.

So we went from taking of dark passion to lost objects in two aliyot.

Why?

There is a connection between them, as the Torah has them next to each other. The Sages, I'm sure, have some excellent ideas and understanding on what that connection is. Having said that, here is my personal view. The first is a warning of bad things that can/will happen from bad starts. The second is a remedy of the first, and all an example of good things that can/will happen from good starts. Just as a person/soldier (Devarim 21:11) see among the captives a beautiful-looking woman and desires her, so a person can (Devarim 22:1) see your brother's ox or sheep wandering astray [] return them to your brother. Sure, an ox or sheep is not a beautiful-looking woman and yet, the sight of one, the bad, and the sight of another, the good, took but a moment. On the battlefield, things happen quickly and passionately. In everyday, things happen slowly and happenstancely. Just as there are rules of the battlefield captive, so to there are rules for lost items. So too, if one does a good deed of choosing to following HaShem's commandment, so too, good things will follow. And by following HaShem's Ways, one can avoid the pitfall of the bad things(tm) from happening.

Which takes us to the third aliyah, when you do good things, good things happen, which is illustrated in this aliyah. Build a house and make a guard-rail for the roof, and thus you will be spared from being involved in a bad event. The aliyah immediately talks of improper mixtures and then makes an exception for tzitzis (which had to be said to be known). It sounds, again, as if it doesn't belong, bad things, good things, and improper mixtures. The connection? The Creator of the World knows what goes with what, and we should not second-guess Him, I think. Just as we might not see the moment of sight which can lead to good or bad, we don't know how mixtures can affect things as well, but HaShem knows.

From improper mixtures, the aliyah continues talking about (Devarim 22:13), If a man takes a wife, marries her, and then hates her, again seems strange, but as Rashi says about this verse and the next, combined, One sin brings another sin in its train; if he transgresses you shall not hate (Vayikra 19:17) the end will be that he will fall into slander (Sifri). So it does follows the theme of the Parsha. The aliyah continues with the slander, and the consequences whether its true or not. And since it's on that topic, the Torah tells us about the consequence/punishment of adultery and rape within the city, where the girl could call for help but didn't, or in the field, where none would hear her.

The aliyah (long one :)) then speaks of improper mixture of people; incest and those whose very nature doesn't mix with us. The first one is obvious, but the second, to us, is not, because there are no Ammoni or Mo'avi anymore as they were because various people were moved/mixed around as mentioned in the Talmud.

The fourth aliyah continues, how there are those that cannot mix with Israel at all, and there are those that can, with refinement. Since the aliyah talks of refinement of people, it goes on to talk about impurity. In addition to impurity, the spiritual, the Torah also talks of the mundane, about latrine.

Which might seem strange to add, unless you understanding that HaShem is involved in all facets of our lives. Especially when back then, plumbing and hygiene were unknown to the typical person, and yet, the Torah speaks of such, hence the saying cleanliness is next to godliness. The aliyah goes from not sending a runaway slave back to prostitution. Both are dealing with mixtures that we have to be careful of. The runaway slave is better off among Israel than his former master (obvious now-a-days, but we learned that from Torah). There was prostitution is a mixture of immorality that is not of the good.

As then, in the same aliyah, go from prostitution to taking interest from a brother to fulling vows. These three are mixtures as well, and needed to be handled in accordance with Divine Truth. Taking interesting can get complicated and I will leave that for others to talk about, while fulling vows should be obvious.

The fifth aliyah talks about a worker in the field and the Torah permits him to eat the grapes or corn as he works, but only as he works as he has the grapes/corn in his hands as he harvests them. This is both an understanding of the human heart (as the first aliyah) and a kindness.

From this kindness of a worker in the field at harvest-time, the aliyah continues with talking about divorce, the divorcee goes and marry someone else, who either divorces her or passes away, she cannot be taking in by the first husband, because he had divorced her. This is also of consequences and mixtures that HaShem knows.

The sixth aliyah speaks of a husband and a new wife, having original dealt with a bad wife, Torah talks of the positive and adds, (Devarim 24:5) [...] For one year he shall remain free for his house and make his wife whom he married happy. Happy marriage is a good marriage.

From marriage to talking of item-guarantor to kidnapping to tzara'as and back to item-guarantor and the behavior governing such. All about proper behavior, keeping things in the proper way and not mixing properly.

The seventh aliyah talks of prompt payment, punished for one's own sin and not a father's/son's. From father/son, the Torah then talks about the proselyte, orphan and widow, not to take advantage of them, for HaShem, Himself, looks after them. From that, the aliyah continues with a court case and the wicked's punishment. The Torah then states about not muzzling an oz while threshing. Then speaks about the levirate marriage, as this is an exception for previous rulings, to ensure that a line continues.

From the levirate marriage is talks of quarrels where a woman interferes, and then speaks of correct weights. From weights to remembering Amalek. How does when you go out connect with Amalek? For those, Amalek, went out, for battle HaShem. We need to remember that there are people out there that will do so and we can not allow such to mix with us and others. Just as a cancer must be completely eradicated, so too, does Amalek. A soldier goes out for war and sees a captive, there is something that can be done, but with Amalek, the Source of Mercy, knows that nothing good came from Amalek, and like a cancer, it will inflect its surrounding areas as well.

So this Parsha is about sequence, consequences, and mixtures. Many are spiritual that we cannot see on our own, but Torah assists us in this with the commandments. And when Mosiach comes, we will be able to actually see all this for ourselves. And that, we will see that HaShem is One and the source of all. Then mixtures will not be different things, but everything will be HaShem. May that day come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Shoftim
entry.content:
BH
August 22, 2012 / 4 Elul 5772

Parsha Shoftim
Devarim 16:18 21:9
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash - Margolin Edition 

The name of this week's Parsha is Shoftim which means Judges, and within the very first aliyah we are told, Devarim 16:20, Justice, justice shall you pursue[...]

The commentators ask the obvious question, which is, of course, why is justice repeated twice. The Sages have various answers, among them is that; in your pursuit of justice, you have to be just. In other words, especially, in justice, there must be justice within your pursuit as well as without it. One can not lost sight of that which you are pursuing.

In talking of justice/judges, the Torah states, Devarim 17:9, You shall come to the priests, the Leviyim, or to the judge who is at that time[...] to which Rashi comments, and even though he is not as other judges that have been before him, you must obey him. You have none else but the judge that lives in your days. Meaning that the quality of the judge might not be the same as one's grandfather's day, but that person is still the judge that should be followed. For the most part, the downward quality of the judges is not surprising, as one gets further and further from the source, the weaker one gets.

In the third aliyah, Devarim 18:1 states: The priests, the Leviyim, the entire tribe of Levi, will not have a share or heritable property with Israel[...] and the theme of the entire Parsha is judges/justice, how does this fit in? The very tribe fully devoted to HaShem and HaShem decrees that they don't have a portion of the Holy Land to call its own unlike the other eleven tribe. How does that fit into the theme of judge/justice of the Parsha? What is justice? The act of doing that which is moral right. And HaShem is the Source of Justice, and is just in all that He does. As the tribe of Levi is fully dedicated to the service of HaShem, we are not focused upon the material things of the world, but upon the service to HaShem. In other words, we do not get involved in the land/material itself, but within the spiritual. Thus, an heritage of the physical land would be an injustice for the tribe of Levi, but as the Torah says, Devarim 18:2, [...] The Eternal is their permanent portion [...] For there is the justice, just as the tribe of Levi serve the Holy One, so does the HaShem watch-over the tribe of Levi. For among the all the tribes, the tribe of Levi has always been the smallest.

In the fourth aliyah, Devarim 18:12 states, For anyone who does these things is an abomination [to] the Eternal[...] which witchcraft is listed among things that are an abomination to HaShem. Given the positive view that modern media gives witchcraft, how is it that HaShem says that witchcraft is an abomination? First, right off the bat, modern media doesn't care what something is, so long as it sells. Second, the torah fits witchcraft between idol-worshipers and necromancers. Since the Torah starts with the least and moves to the worst; that means that witchcraft is worse than idol-worship, although, better than necromancy. Of course, that is like saying death by stabbing is better than death by being shot, which is still better than death by radiation poisoning. Which in actuality is meaningless as death is death. What the Torah definition of witchcraft actually is, I leave to the Rabbis to explain.

In the fifth aliyah, Moses explains to the Children of Israel about the future (then) prophets saying, Devarim 18:15, The Eternal, your G-d, will appoint for you a prophet from among you, from your brethren, like I am; to him you shall listen. Again, with the Parsha theme of Judges, this verse (and the rest) is necessary to know what judges/prophets would follow Moses and Joshua. So the aliyah also talks about duties of the prophets. The aliyah also contains, Devarim 18:21-22, (21) And when you asked yourselves, How will we know that are the words that the Eternal did not speak? (22)that which the prophet speaks in the name of the Eternal but will not be nor will it happen these are the words which the Eternal did not speak. The prophet spoke brazenly; do not be afraid of him. Which talks of a false prophet, or a prophet that has strayed.

Also in keeping the theme of Judges/Justice, this aliyah talks about the Cities of Refuge that an accidental killer had to go to; to avoid the blood avenger. The justice of this, I think, is that legally the blood avenger can claim the life from the accidental killer, but since it is an accident, HaShem sets a place of refuge for him. Nothing happens by chance, so there was Heavenly reasons for the entire scenario to happen. For the record, the Cities of Refuge do not protect an intentional killer/murderer. He that killed intentionally in hatred, the Torah states, [...] he shall die. (Devarim 19:12) This is Justice.

In the sixth aliyah, the Torah continues to talk about other forms of justice, respecting the ownership of land and also about not giving false witness, for our just courts are based upon witnesses. Also within this aliyah is the famous (and misquoted) verse, Devarim 19:21, And you must not have pity; a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth [...] Without the Oral Law, one can be easily be mislead on this, as it is talking of monetary compensations, and not purely literal. And yet, it is written within the Torah as such, for in strict justice there is no mixing, no eye for a tooth, or a life for an eye. Strict justice is only in the hands of Heaven though, so we, mere mortals, deal in monetary compensation instead.

The Torah also talks about being just in war, and to ensure that justice is done, it is done by those that are Righteous. Thus, those that have sinned, are excused from the front-line fighting while being among those that Justice also calls to avoid war as they have duties to attend to that cannot be put off.

The seventh aliyah talks about waging a just war, given the opposing people a chance to flee and not unnecessarily damage the environment while waging a war. It is also within the aliyah that famous comparison between a man and a tree is made, which ties into the Upsherin ceremony.

This aliyah ends with the one of the true justice when unsolved murder occurs. When an unsolved murder occurred in Biblical-days, a calf was taken and sacrificed. This is unusual in that the sacrifice was done outside of the Holy Temple and done by the closest city elders and judges, who have a speech they are to say with the sacrifice. For as the Parsha began, it is the judges (elders) who are to guard and guide the people of their city. For ultimate, the burden of the city falls to the judges/elder of the city. If the elders/judges of the city were fully doing their job/duty, an unsolved murder would not occur, such is the responsibility of a judge.

Judges/justice is the theme of the Parsha. For one cannot judge without justice, not be just without judgment. We can only follow the examples that HaShem has set for us in the Tanach. Yet, the world won't have full justice until the coming of Mosiach, and HaShem, Himself, will judge the world with justice, righteousness, and truth.

May that day come soonest. Amen.

entry.title: Parsha Re'eh
entry.content:
BH
August 16, 2012 / 28 Av 5772
Parsha Re'eh
Devarim 11:26 16:17
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash - Margolin Edition 

As usually, it's hard to just pick a verse or two out of the weekly Parsha to talk about; for reasons I am unsure of a few did stand out that I feel in my heart that I should comment on. These are my own words, from my heart, unless quoted from other sources. :)

Devarim 12:21 states, If the place where the Eternal, your G-d, chooses to rest His Divine Presence is far from you, you shall then slaughter your cattle and flock that the Eternal has given you, in the way that I commended you, and you may eat in your towns according to all your heart's desire.

The place that HaShem has chosen, this is Jerusalem and the resting place of His Divine Presence is the Holy Temple. How do we know this? For our Prophets has recorded this for us, in many, many places throughout their writings, as well as, having been passed down from parent to child. And yet, the Five Books of Moses doesn't name Jerusalem, Jerusalem, only as the place of HaShem's choosing. Why?

To further the question, the name Jerusalem, our Sages tell us, comes from Shem son of Noach and Abraham. The Jeru- part comes from Bereishit 22:17 And Abraham named that place, HaShem will see (Yerah), as it is said to this day: on the mountain, HaShem will be seen. And the -Salem, comes from Bereishit 14:18 And Malchizedek the king of Salem brought out bread and wine, and he was a priest to the Most High God. (Malchizedek was another name for Shem son of Noach). So it was not the case that these names were not known, especially to a prophet, much less to a prophet of Moses Rabbenu's caliber. For there are many examples with the Torah, itself, that our Forefathers/Foremothers knew of the future and yet that knowledge is only hinted out. Which bares part of the answer to the question.

Yes, even before Creation itself, the location of the Holy Temple in Jerusalem was chosen, for our Sages tell us that it was the starting point of the world, just as an orange's starts from the bud on a tree and grows from there, so too did the world start from Mount Moriah/the Temple Mount.

And yet, Jerusalem and its purpose, the Holy Temple, did not come into being until David HaMelech set about establishing the first Holy Temple there, having known through the teaching of our Sages that it was the place for the Holy Temple to be. Thus, the name Jerusalem, I think, was reserved until the Holy Temple was ready to be built by us.

Which is all a side thing from what I was originally going with on this verse, as I wish to note that Rashi says about biblical verse/phrase then you may slaughter as I have commended you. Rashi writes; This teaches us that there was already a commandment regarding the slaughtering of animals as to how one should slaughter. It is not written in the Torah but it comprises the traditional regulations regarding the slaughter of animals that were given orally to Moses on Mount Sinai (Sifri, Chul. 28a).

This is one of several examples of were the Oral Law (Torah shal'be peh) is referenced/mentioned within the Written Torah (Torah shal'be khtav). Yes, many, many, many people know (or think they know) the Written Torah, but sadly how few know of the Oral Law as well. And yet, the Oral Law is as important as the Written Law. In fact, many of the details of Judaism are only recorded within the Oral Law and only referenced/hinted at within the Written Law.

Why was this so? The Sages have several answers for that. For myself, the Written Law is, was, and shall be, was literally written in stone. It is unchanging and eternal. The ignorance and the lazy would even say it is inflexible. It covers our past and foreshadows our future. It protects us and guides us through the world as the Torah is the literal blue-print of the world. For the primordial Torah was black fire upon white fire and pre-dated the creation of world by two thousand generations, and what that means, you need to study Kabbalah and ask a Rabbi, as that is beyond me and way beyond what I am currently writing. Having said that, the Torah of black fire upon white fire is equivalent to the Written Torah we have. For the Torah of Moses is the same that Adam HaReshon, Noach, Abraham, Moses, the Prophets and we study today. Which, when you stop and think about it, is a miracle in itself. That a document that is literally several thousands year old is still the same after all that time, regardless of where in the world or time you are.

If the Written Law is like stone, the Oral Law is like the wind/air, I think. I say that because, earth is relatively easy to study, basically, just pick a rock (or such) up and look at it and know its a rock. The Oral Law isn't so simple (relatively speaking), for it is a body of laws, regulations, and understand that has to be studied and studied and studied and studied some more to even begin to have an inkling of understanding of. Much like the wind/air, which you need to study over time, and still not fully understand as any honest Meteorologist will tell you. The Oral Law is just as eternal as the Written Law, and unchanging, but to the ignorant/lazy, it would appear to change over time. And yet, those changes are within the Oral Law itself.

As the next verse I wish to mention from the Parsha relates, Devarim 13:1, The entire thing that I am commanding you this you shall be careful to do; you must not add to it nor subtract from it. Thus it is an eternal decree that no prophet, sage, rabbi, or any one has the right to change the Eternal Words of HaShem; not even HaShem himself, may change the Torah. For if the Torah could change, then ergo it is not eternal and not from HaShem.

Which simple straightforward and simple, and yet we are warned, Devarim 13:2-5, (2) If a prophet or a dreamer of a dream arises among you, and presents you with a sign or wonder, (3) and the sign or wonder of which he spoke to you happens, [with him] saying, Lets us follow the gods of others that you do not know, and let us worship them, (4) you must not heed the words of that prophet or that dreamer of dream, for the Eternal, your G-d, is testing you, to ascertain whether you love the Eternal, your G-d, with your whole heart and your entire being. (5) You shall follow the Eternal, your G-d, and fear Him; and you shall keep His commandments, head His voice, server Him, and adhere to [His ways].

How could others lead us astray? Alas, unfortunately, it is all too easy to do. One has but to look to history to see it happen. Worse still, one need only look through a current newspaper and see it today. How many of us follow (worship) the gods (precepts) of the so-called enlightenment or progressive movements. Of course, they don't present themselves that they are gods of others, or that we should worship them. Instead they claim the world has changed and we don't need to cling to old-fashion ideals or what they call superstition. Never-minding that for something to be truly be old-fashion, it had withstood the test of time.

The world was set upon its creation, over five thousand years ago, and it has not changed. A rock is a rock, a tree is a tree, a human being is a human being and so on. What has changed is our view of the world. Our view of the world has has its highs and its lows, which are interesting terms in themselves and reflect a truth in them. For when our views of the world are high, they reflect the Heavens that are above us, and when they are low, they reflect the dirt below us.
And yet, we are given another warning, Devarim 13:7, he who is [as dear to you] as yourself induces you in secret, saying, Let us go and worship the gods of others that neither you nor your fathers have known Yet, within this warning is a clue/life-line to save us, that neither you nor your fathers have known.

For if we invert the last part of the verse, you and your fathers know, this is what can/will save you. What will save you, what you, yourself, knows, and what your father knows. And we can add to this, as the Hebrew word for father can also refer to your grand-father. So we can say that what was known for three generations, yourself, your father, your grand-father, has weight to it. As can also add a non-literal translation to this, as the Sages have taught that fathers can refer to the Prophets. Thus, if we listen to our fathers and grand-father and the Prophets, we cannot go wrong. Although, a joke about fools and mistakes come to mind, but that is upon us, not them. As the Sages say, one sins only when a spirit of foolishness enters us.

Further into the Parsha, we are warning about an entire city going astray. It is said by the Sages that this never actually happened, and they give various reasons why its mentioned if its purely academic. I say, it serves as a warning, for the placement of verses within Parsha has meaning as well, thus, if one does not heed the individual's wrong-doing, it can spread to the entire city. For proof of this concept, one needs only check the current newspapers/media of today and compare them to the newspapers/media of yesterdays.

In the fourth aliyah, the Torah reviews the kosher animals, fishes, birds and insects. Yes, there are kosher insects, you can perform an internet search and see for yourself if you wish. And the aliyah ends with Devarim 14:21, [...] for you are a holy people before the Eternal, your G-d [...] The ultimate reasons for keeping kosher is, of course, the Creator of Heaven and Earth, Who knows everything, instructed us so. For the verse itself, I would think that keeping kosher is in keeping with holy people before HaShem.

The aliyah verse (Devarim 14:21) ends with, You must not cook a young animal in its mother's milk. For this is said by the Source of Mercy, so that we may too, practice this mercy and not be cruel.

Which leads into another practice of mercy, the tithe, recorded in the fifth aliyah, which is given to HaShem, and shared with the the Levite, the proselyte, orphan and the widow, which brings us closer to He that take care of those mentioned, and we are blessed. In this merit, one is blessed upon their four; their sons, daughters, man-servants and maid-servants (Rashi on Devarim 16:11).

The sixth aliyah deals with the Shemittah cycle and the releasing of loans, and the consequences of following and not following this commandment, which Rashi and other commentators have expanded upon.

The seventh aliyah talks about the Temple Sacrifices, what, when, and where, of the Holy Days sacrifices. The aliyah ends with Devarim 16:17, Each man [shall offer] according to his ability to give, [and] in accordance with the blessing of the Eternal, your G-d, that He has given you. Thus, may the Merciful One fulfill His eternal words and bless us so that we may take what we have and use it according to His words.

And the ultimate fulfillment of those blessing will be with Mosiach, may he come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Eikev
entry.content:
BH
Original Timestamp: August 9, 2012 at 9:01pm / 22nd of Av, 5772
Parsha Eikev
Devarim 7:12 11:25
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash - Margolin Edition 

There is, as usual, so much going on within the Parsha, it's hard to limit myself to just one.

So I figure I would use the old adage, start at the beginning. Jokes about Bereishet aside, there is, I think, an over-all theme running through this Parsha, which is applicable to our day and time.

To begin with, the Torah is the living word of the Eternal, our G-d. It not some ancient writing to be forgotten, nor ignored. Nor is the Torah a history book, to mere chronicle the events that have happened. That is not to say, that what is written within did not happen, for the entire Torah is true and all that is recorded did happen. As I said, the Torah is HaShem speaking to us, sharing His Divine Wisdom with us in a form that we can grasp.

The words of Torah are Divine Truths that will always exist. From the beginning to the end, its all within the Torah.

So going through the aliyahs:

In the first aliyah, speaks of the Land of Israel, to those that think logical, as the Torah poses, Devarim 7:17, If you say to yourself, These nations are more numerous than I. [...] How can we claim the Land and survive surrounded by so many that wish to push all the way to the sea The Torah answers, Devarim 7:18, do not be afraid for them. You shall constantly remember what HaShem, your G-d, did to Pharaoh and to all of Egypt Back then, Egypt was the super-power within the world, according to any calculation or logical, there was no nation that could equal or surpass it. But the world is not limited to mere physical. It matters not what calculations or what the reigning super-power thinks or desires, for only HaShem matters. No matter how high and mighty a nation is, it will answer to HaShem in the end.

The second aliyah reminds us that we should not forget that it is HaShem, and not us, for which there is a State of Israel and that there are Jews in the world, as the Torah states, Devarim 8:17-18, and you say to yourself, My strength and the power of my hand have amassed this wealth for me. You shall then remember HaShem, your G-d, for it is He who gives you the ability to amass wealth[...] Yes, we have to do our part, for that is the reason for which we were created, but we still need to do our part, but not forget from whence we came.

The third aliyah caution us about our attitude and understanding of HaShem and the world, as the Torah says, Devarim 9:4, [...] do not say to yourself as follows, Because of my righteousness, HaShem brought me to take possession of this land, and because of the wickedness of these nations [...] How often do those that think themselves righteous can do no wrong. Or bad things happen to those that we think are wicked. Such things are matters are the realm of Heaven. The aliyah also recalls the giving of the Ten Commandments and that which followed, to show that how the very same people can go from one extreme to another and back again.

The fourth aliyah talks how repentance is always possible through prayer and effort on our part.

The fifth aliyah answers that age old question, why are we here? As it says, Devarim 10:12, Yet now, Israel, what does HaShem, your G-d, request of you? Only to fear HaShem, your G-d, to follow his ways and to love him, and to serve HaShem, your G-d, with your whole heart and your entire being. Or as the Sages say, All things are in the hands of heaven, save the fear of heaven. For we all are created by our Maker, each and every one of us. We would not exist without HaShem. Nor did He place us here randomly, but with purpose.

The sixth aliyah tells us of the uniqueness and how special the Land of Israel is. As the Torah states, Devarim 11:12, It is a land which HaShem, your G-d, cares for; HaShem, your G-d, keeps a constant eye on it, from the beginning of the year until the end of the year. Which is an interesting statement to make. Why say, beginning [] until the end [...] wouldn't constantly cover that? Comes Rashi to explain, Torah says From the beginning of the year, thus At the beginning of the year it is decided by G-d what will be right up to the end of it. For it is said, in the beginning is the end, and in the end, is the beginning (not sure the source of that. Mishna?) But it is saying, that HaShem already knows what the end will be, and prepares for it while still dealing with the end, as well as, knowing what the beginning will be, prepares the end for it as well. The English language fails here with the concept, I think, as the tenses gets confusing. Such is the Land of Israel, it is under the direct supervision of HaShem and everything is planned out by Him, from beginning of the year to its end. Why not, from start to finish? So each year, we, human beings, all have a chance to re-evaluate ourselves and improve ourselves for the better, which HaShem will in turn improve things for us. While on one hand, everything is fixed, there still are periods in our lives where and when we can re-assess and improve ourselves. If we slip, we can with the help of HaShem, pick ourselves up and start anew.

Within this aliyah, I wish to point out, is the second paragraph of the Shema, which I can't help feeling in many shuls is not given its due as the first paragraph is. And yet, all three paragraphs are the Shema. Going back to the name of the Parsha, Eikev, which can mean heel, Devarim 11: 16. Be careful that your hears do not entice, and you go astray and serve estranged gods and bow down to them. Which you would think, should not be needed, and yet, how often is this part ignored. How many of us worship the so-called Almighty dollar, are mere wage slaves, or believe something because the arrogant say to think otherwise is bigotry, superstitious, or intolerance. While the Source of Mercy, Justice, and Truth says otherwise.

The seventh aliyah finishes that if we but follow the ways of HaShem, HaShem will be there for us for our benefit, in the concept of measure for measure. As Rashi replies to the biblical phrase, Devarim 11:23, then HaShem will drive out, that if it was as if HaShem said, If you do what devolves upon you, I will do whatever devolves upon Me. [Sifri] For in the end, pardon the pun, how we deal with others (and Heaven), Heaven will deal with us. It won't matter if the other nations are greater and more powerful than you (Devarim 11:23), for all that matters is HaShem.

For what may seen as small to us, can in fact be by Divine Truth, be something major, with far reaching affects. For the small can conquer the large, if HaShem is with us.

For it will not be by our merits that Mosiach will come, but because of HaShem and His love for us that a new era will come. Having just said that, that does not mean we don't have our own parts to play for our final redemption. Even if it's but a heel, as the Parsha began, Devarim 11:23, HaShem will then drive out all these nations from before you [...] for us if we but, Devarim 11:22, [...] carefully safeguard all these commandments that I am commanding you, to do them, so as to love HaShem, your G-d, to follow all His ways and to cling to Him.

May we be yet another step closer to the coming of Mosiach and the complete restoration of our Land which will include world peace and harmony with the One True G-d.

entry.title: Parsha Va'eschanan
entry.content:
BH
Original Timestamp: August 1 at 10:15pm / 14 Av 5772
Parsha Va'eschanan
Devarim 3:23 - 7:11
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash - Margolin Edition 
===================

AS always, there is so much within our weekly Parsha it is hard to decide what to write about. So much just grabs you and touches your heart. How easily it is to relate everything in the Parsha to what's happening around us.

If I was to be political, the verse Devarim 4:2, You must not add to that I am commanding you, nor subtract [...] One needs only to pick up a newspaper or listen to the news to know how many have forgotten or out-right ignored this commandment, as many seem to think they know better than their Creator.

If I wish to speak about the spiritual, there is so much to talk about, the re-telling of the Ten Commandments, the first paragraph of the Shema, how the Ten Plagues (against the Egyptians) are also called wonders, and so much more.

The entire Parsha is called, Va'eschanan, means I implored/requested/begged. Rashi explains, Another explanation of the word va'eshcananis that this is one of the ten terms by which prayer is described, as are enumerated in Sefrei. Which is interesting, as the Parsha's Maftir Aliyah (Devarim 7:9) begins:You shall realize that it is HaShem, your G-d, who is G-d, the faithful G-d, [...]. Va'eschanan/I implored is the theme of the entire Parsha, and yet, what does requesting a gift for free have to do with HaShem's faithfulness to reward and punish?

Recall that Moshe Rebbanu was requesting to be allowed entry into the Holy Land, and his request was denied as it is stated in Devarim 3:26, [...] and HaShem said to me, You have enough. Do not continue to speak to Me anymore on this matter. Which is the verse you shall realize [], is so important. How many of our heart-wrenching prayers have been sent to HaShem, and the answer is a resounding no, or worse, as if HaShem isn't even listening. The eternal answer remains, you shall realize [...] that HaShem is faithful to reward/punish, when the time is right, be it now, today, tomorrow, next year, or in 120 years. HaShem knows what we truly need, when we need it, and where we need it.

May the answer to all our prayers, the coming of Mosiach, come soonest.

entry.title: Parsha Devarim
entry.content:
Original Timestamp: July 26 at 10:04pm / 8 Av 5772
Parsha Devarim
Devarim 1:1 - 3:22
Translation Source: Chayenu: Chumash - Margolin Edition

I have felt for some time that I should do more than just study the weekly Parsha each week. A thought I had was to write about something within the Parsha and post it, so whom may, may read it. My words would be but feathers in the winds of the internet. But my shyness and such has prevented me from doing so before. But with a new Sefra, now, would be a good time I feel.

The entire Torah has been studied by many more learned than I for literally thousands of years. I don't expect to come up with anything original or scholarly, but to the point of this exercise, these words will be mine, from my heart and mind, to be written "down" in a "stream of conscious".

This is your "warning," these is but a stream of my conscious. This is just me typing what I think/feel as I study this week's Parsha.

The weekly Parsha of our Eternal Torah always has meaning in our lives, and something will touch us in various ways. This week, the very name of these Parsha and this Sefra, touches me.

The word "devarim" means "words" as the first phrase said, Devarim 1:1, "These are the words that Moshe spoke to all of Israel on the opposite side of the Jordan (river) [...]"

Words.

This, "Words," is what the entire Sefra Devarim is all about. Literally as it says, "These are the words" that Moshe Rabbenu spoke, knowing by Divine Command he was going to pass away afterwards. Last words that Moshe Rabbenu spoke in the last several months of Moshe Rabbenu's life.

That is how Moshe Rabbenu spent his last days/months on Earth, speaking words to the people of Israel.

Words.

Verbal communication of concepts through speech.

How much we take such things for granted, nor do we consider what their impact will be. A word could uplift someone or bring them crashing down. A word can make us laugh or cry.

Words have power.

A power that cannot be measured or fully understood.

Sefra Berashet, the first book of the Torah, began with words, the words spoken by HaShem, and Sefra Devarim, the five (and last) book of the Torah, begin with words as well, spoken by HaShem's Prophet, Moshe Rabbenu.

Probably in keeping with the Master of the Universe, as HaShem began the Creation with strict Justice, so too, Moshe Rabbenu begins with a rebuke of the People of the Israel, recalling what had happened since Mount Sinai until that point. Those that Moshe Rabbenu spoke about had passed away in the Desert, as decreed by HaShem. But the wives, the children, the Tribe of Levi, the Old, and the Righteous remained of those that had sinned in the Desert.

They listened and accepted Moshe Rabbenu's rebuke. Why? For these where the words of Moshe Rabbenu. Even has he was rebuking, he was teaching. What he was teaching in this Parsha, the Sages have explain much better than I, so I'm not here going to try. And here, Moshe taught through words.

Words carefully measured out. None wasted, nothing extra, and nothing left out.

How many of us can say we were concise and practical with our words?

How many words do we waste?

How many words do we labor over?

How can we learn to use our words wisely? Simple, study the Torah.

Listen to the words of Moshe Rabbenu and follow his example from this week's Parsha (and others).

Rapping up this stream, I will conclude, with the Parsha ends, Devarim 3:22, "Do not fear them, for its HaShem, your G-d, who does battle for you." Moshe Rabbenu was speaking of those that would oppose the Israelite's claim to the Holy Land. More words, but no truer words ever spoken. For the Torah is Eternal, its words are eternal. Thus it was then, so it is now.
